HEADLINE: A Remedy for the Rootlessness Of Modern Suburban Life?

BYLINE: By SARAH BOXER 

 BODY:
Attacks on suburbia are as old as cul-de-sacs. Suburbs have always been derided as bourgeois, consumerist and conformist. But now they have become the enemy of family values, too. That's right. Karl Zinsmeister, the editor of the conservative magazine The American Enterprise, has written that "suburbia is actually a fairly radical social experiment," one that can be linked to "the disappearance of family time, the weakening of generational links . . . the anonymity of community life, the rise of radical feminism, the decline of civic action, the tyrannical dominance of TV and pop culture over leisure time."
What is to be done? 
 A group of architects and planners who have named themselves the Congress for the New Urbanism have vowed to halt the spread of faceless, car-centered suburbs by promoting friendly, people-centered towns with corner stores and public greens.
They call for some old-fashioned things: walkable neighborhoods with a mix of residences, businesses and public places; straight and narrow streets; wide sidewalks, and no cul de sacs. They believe houses should be built close enough together and close enough to the sidewalks to define streets and public squares. Above all, they want strong town centers and clear town boundaries. No one, they believe, should live more than a five-minute walk from most of their errands. (Otherwise, what's to stop people from getting in their cars and driving?) And like their British counterpart, the Urban Villages Group, the architects favored by the Prince of Wales, they want to preserve old towns and cities through "infill," building on unused urban lots.
"No one can be opposed to those principles," said Alex Krieger, a professor of urban design at Harvard University. They are like "mom and apple pie," he said. Yet many new-urban towns have been scorned as cutesy, regressive and un-urban. The new urbanists -- or neo-traditionalists -- should instead be called the "new suburbanists," some say, because they are less interested in planning principles than in porches, picket fences and gabled roofs.
Seaside, designed in the early 1980's by Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk and Andres Duany, two of the founders of new urbanism, is the oldest new-urban town. Built on a stretch of the Florida panhandle, Seaside was meant to foster community life and beach access. The houses, a pastiche of historical styles in pastel colors, are set close to one another and connected by straight brick streets and a network of sand walkways cutting through the middle of each block. When the town is finished, it is supposed to have 350 houses and 300 apartments, a school, an open-air market, a town hall, a tennis club, an amphitheater, a post office, and a number of shops, offices and beach pavillions.
If you're having trouble picturing it, think of the idyllic town in the movie "The Truman Show." That was no movie set. That was Seaside.
Since Seaside was built, new urbanism has won a lot of fans and building contracts. There are dozens of new-urban towns and projects built or under construction, including Celebration in Florida, Laguna West in California and Kentlands in Maryland. The Department of Housing and Urban Development is renovating some of its public housing according to new urbanist principles: more porches, more fences, lower buildings, narrower streets. Jane Jacobs, the author of "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," has praised the movement as "sound" and "promising." And publications from The Sierra Club Yodeler to The American Enterprise have smiled on the new urbanists.
"But is their particular vision of urbanization an innovative model appropriate to the 21st century," Michelle Thompson-Fawcett asked in the journal Urban Design International, "or is it regressive nostalgia?"
New urbanism is, by definition, nostalgic. Towns built on a human scale, with strong centers and clear edges, have been around for 5,000 years, said Robert Davis, the developer of Seaside and the chairman of the new-urban congress. It is only in the last 50 years, with the rise of modernism, he said, that Americans have forgotten how to build them.
The new urbanists want to induce neighborliness with architecture. In this sense they are utopian. Like the modernist master planners of the 1930's, they believe social change can be brought about through architecture and planning. The difference is that most of them hate modernism.
While the modernists "tried to get to the future by destroying the past," Robert Fishman, the author of "Bourgeois Utopias," said, the new urbanists "are reviving the past in order to change" the present. That, the new urbanists think, is why many architecture schools view them with contempt.
Most schools of architecture are "so in the grips of the modernist ideology and so defensive of the avant-garde that they see the Congress for the New Urbanism as fundamentally conservative," said Daniel Solomon, a founder of the movement. Peter Katz, the author of "The New Urbanism: Toward an Architecture of Community," said that the nation's most powerful architects, particularly those in New York, "laugh at the poor souls who live in suburbia."
Kenneth Frampton, an architecture professor at Columbia University, agrees that many architecture schools (though he excludes Columbia) have ignored some questions about land settlement. But what bothers most professors about the new urbanists, he said, is not their critique of suburbia or land settlement. It is their design ideas.
The new-urbanist charter says nothing explicit about what styles are acceptable. Yet because many new urbanists believe that modernism ruined American cities, nearly all of their designs rely heavily on building styles from the past. Kentlands in Maryland is full of Georgian houses. Celebration, Disney's village in Florida, is full of brand new Victorians and Colonials.
"What's upsetting" about new urbanism, said Mr. Frampton, "is that the imagery is so retrograde." It is based on a "sentimental iconography" as if there were something inherently good about Victorians, Georgians and Colonials and something inherently bad about modernism. To be fair, there were a lot of modernists in the 1930's who advocated low-rise, high density housing, he said. Besides, the kind of modernism that the new urbanists see as their enemy is a straw man. No one is advocating tearing down whole cities to make way for skyscrapers.
"If you want to look for the demon that destroyed Main Street in America," Mr. Frampton said, "it is not the modern movement but the American bureaucracy that opened the way for freeways and suburbanization." The railroads were deliberately undermined by the automobile industry, he said, adding, "That was an economic, a capitalist, operation," not an architectural one.
New urbanism has not attacked the root of the problem sufficiently, suggested Alex Marshall, who has often written about new urbanism for Metropolis magazine. "What new urbanism tries to do is imitate older communities that existed before the automobile" without getting rid of the automobile. But if you want to return to these older forms of life, he said, you "have to bring back the transportation system." If you simply change the way houses are built, "it's like changing hemlines."
New urbanists like to see themselves as radicals, said Mr. Krieger, who was once a supporter of the movement and is now a critic. But, he added, they are "no longer the radical fringe but conventional wisdom." Developers have begun using the term new urbanism to sell their projects.
That's not to say the movement hasn't had a good effect, Mr. Krieger said. The Department of Housing and Urban Development has dedicated $2.6 billion to "Hope Six," a nationwide plan to rebuild mid-century public housing according to new urbanist principles. From Boston to Cleveland to Helena, Mont., high-rise projects are being replaced by town houses with porches and fences. "That is the part of the movement that most impresses me," said Mr. Krieger.
The problem, Mr. Marshall noted, is that most new-urban developments are not urban at all. They are rich developments on the town's edge. "They are sprawl under another name," he said, and they are as restrictive as any suburban development. Most are privately run by homeowners' associations that give developers extraordinary control.
For example, in Celebration, Disney's new-urban town, the deed restrictions specify what kind of drapery, roofing tiles and political signs are allowed. "Disney has a history of making warm and fuzzy dog movies," said Evan McKenzie, the author of "Privatopia," a book on housing associations, but "they can take your dog if it makes too much noise."
"It's as if the people are saying: 'Who needs democracy? It's utopia already!' " said Mr. McKenzie.
People are looking for homeyness and safety, and they don't mind giving up some freedoms for it. In Kentlands, there is a gate in front of each entry into the development, Mr. Krieger said. "It's a decorative gate but it evokes the same associations as a real gate. It's a subtle form of 'Keep Out.' "
If decorative gates can evoke the same response as real gates, then maybe the look of neighborliness -- porches, wide sidewalks and village greens -- can evoke real neighborliness. Or can it?
The one big criticism about new-urban towns is that they are fake towns. Given that, it's curious that the developer of Seaside agreed to let "The Truman Show," a movie about a real man in a false world, be filmed in Seaside. The movie all but said, "This is not really a town but the shell of a town, an image of a town," Mr. Krieger said.
After the filming was over, the painted plywood storefronts that had been put up for the movie stayed up for months because the developer liked the way they looked, Mr. Krieger said. After all, looking like a real town is the next best thing to being one.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Team Backs a $2.2 Billion Loan for Hard-Up Ukraine

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: VIENNA, July 31

 BODY:
An International Monetary Fund team announced today that it would recommend a $2.2 billion loan to Ukraine, where the United States has showered assistance for much of this decade but where the economy remains crippled by corruption and a lack of reform.
The loan, small by the standards of recent bailouts by the fund but significant because of the political implications, will help Ukraine cover foreign and domestic debt payments due in August. 
 The tentative loan package is subject to a vote of the fund's board on Aug. 24, and the expected approval would clear the way for a first payment of $200 million to $250 million.
The agreement announced today followed visits to Ukraine last week by American officials, including Vice President Al Gore.
Mr. Gore said after meeting with President Leonid Kuchma that Ukraine would find it difficult to get an agreement with the fund unless the country made bolder economic reforms. Ukraine has a poor record in keeping its pledges, and in January the fund suspended a $542 million loan.
There was some question whether the steps announced by the Ukrainian Government this week to comply with the fund's conditions would translate into action.
Among the I.M.F.'s demands for the latest loan is a requirement to cut the Ukrainian budget deficit to 2.5 percent of its economy. In response, Mr. Kuchma has issued a series of decrees to raise revenue and slash expenditures. But these decrees could be overruled by Parliament, which is headed by an avowed opponent of the monetary fund.
Putting the best face on the situation, an American Embassy official said Mr. Kuchma had told Mr. Gore that he would push hard to insure that the fund's conditions would be met. The embassy official said that lately the Ukrainians had been presenting a "very different tone" to the fund.
Since becoming independent in 1991, Ukraine has been a critical focus of Washington's policy toward the former Soviet Union.
One of the early successes of American diplomacy in the region was persuading Ukraine to give up its nuclear arsenal, which was the second-largest in the Soviet Union after Russia's.
Washington has sent about $250 million in aid a year to Ukraine in an effort to insure its independence and bolster its economy, an amount that has made Ukraine the third-largest recipient of American foreign aid.
The Clinton Administration has justified the assistance by asserting that it would be difficult for Russia to become an imperial power again without Ukraine falling back into its clutches.
But foreign investors, citing rampant corruption, have largely stayed away from Ukraine -- the country has attracted a paltry $2 billion in outside direct investment. Industry and agriculture remain almost entirely state-run.
But under President Kuchma, Washington says, Ukraine has followed through on two important counts.
First, Mr. Kuchma is ambivalent -- but unlike Russia not hostile -- to NATO expansion. And this spring he agreed, under pressure from Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, to cancel the sale of two turbines destined for a nuclear reactor in Iran. That made Ukraine's record on deterring the spread of nuclear arms much better than Russia's.
In canceling the sale of the turbines, Mr. Kuchma found an effective negotiating tactic with Washington.
Publicly, Mr. Kuchma has complained that his country was not compensated sufficiently for the loss of the $45 million order or for the loss of other commercial opportunities in Iran. Privately, Mr. Kuchma has told Washington that Ukraine should be rewarded for the cancellation in "units of I.M.F. funding," a Clinton Administration official said.
The head of the fund's mission, Mohammed Shadman-Valavi, who has been in Ukraine all week, said today that Mr. Kuchma had agreed to one of the fund's key conditions but that it would take time for his agreement to have an effect.
The fund demanded that the Ukrainians close a major loophole in their tax code that allowed energy companies to escape the value added tax, a kind of sales tax. Mr. Shadman-Valavi said at his news conference that a decree issued this week by Mr. Kuchma closing the loophole was subject to parliamentary veto.
It so happens that some of the most powerful members of Parliament are managers of Ukraine's major energy companies, including Yulia Timoshenko, who is head of the Parliament's budget committee and president of Unified Energy Systems.
Also, American officials said they were counting on the sudden good will of the Speaker of Parliament, Aleksandr Tkachenko, an avowed leftist and opponent of the monetary fund. In a letter last Friday, Mr. Tkachenko ceded Parliament's authority to pass the budget to Mr. Kuchma's Cabinet.
But there was debate among some financial analysts and diplomats about the legality of the move, since the Ukrainian Constitution says Parliament must pass the budget.
Mr. Tkachenko, who was elected Speaker earlier this month, has spoken repeatedly of his disdain for the fund, calling it of "dubious charity" and intent on swallowing Ukraine's independence.
But American officials were somewhat optimistic that Mr. Tkachenko would keep his word and allow the executive branch to decide the budget, if for no other reason than a special deal between the President and the Speaker.
Just after Mr. Tkachenko was elected Speaker, President Kuchma rewarded him with a big favor. Mr. Tkachenko was charged by prosecutors three years ago with embezzling about $70 million of Ukrainian and United States Export-Import Bank money. The Government issued a decree that wiped away the debts of Mr. Tkachenko's agro-industrial enterprise.

HEADLINE: Harvie Branscomb, a Shaper Of Vanderbilt U., Dies at 103

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Harvie Branscomb, the chancellor of Vanderbilt University from 1946 to 1963, who put the institution on the path to national prominence, died on July 23 at his home in Nashville. He was 103.
Dr. Branscomb was the first chairman of the United States Advisory Commission for Education Exchange, whose purpose was to keep alive the spirit of cooperation among Western nations and to combat Communism. 
 In the 1950's, he was chairman of the Commission on Education and International Affairs of the American Council of Education. He later was educational consultant to the World Bank and a chairman of the United States Commission for Unesco as well as a member or officer of other international conferences and organizations formed to counter illiteracy and foster education.
When Dr. Branscomb was named chancellor in 1946, he was only the fourth person to hold the office since Vanderbilt's founding in 1873. He proved an energetic and engaged leader.
By the time he retired, Vanderbilt was on its way to the top tier of American research universities. The number of full-time faculty members had doubled, faculty salaries had almost tripled and the number of buildings on the campus had more than doubled. The university's annual budget increased by more than 400 percent, and the endowment jumped to $88 million from $38 million.
From 1953 to 1962, the schools of engineering, divinity and law all acquired their own buildings and 15 additional residence halls were constructed. A history of the university, "Gone With the Ivy" (University of Tennessee Press, 1985), by Prof. Paul Conkin, asserted that at the end of Dr. Branscomb's tenure, Vanderbilt could count itself among the top 20 private universities in the United States.
Throughout his long tenure, he was a leading fund-raiser. In 1960, Dr. Branscomb became caught up in a fierce conflict that drew wide attention, over the expulsion of a black student from the divinity school. The student, James M. Lawson Jr., had been dismissed on grounds that he advocated civil disobedience as a leader of a civil rights sit-in in Nashville. At least a dozen faculty members, arguing that local ordinances had been used to deny blacks their constitutional rights, resigned.
Dr. Branscomb tried to negotiate a compromise, but wound up angering many African-Americans and their supporters on the faculty with his statement, "The law has been the basis for much of the Negro's progress in the past and is the guarantee of their continued progress."
Eventually, the dean of the divinity school, who had supported Mr. Lawson, was forced to resign, and Mr. Lawson completed his studies at Boston University.
In a memoir published in 1978, Dr. Branscomb acknowledged that "with the advantage of hindsight, it appears to me now that the best course might have been to bury the issue in administrative procedures."
In 1996, the Rev. Dr. Lawson, who had become a Methodist pastor in Los Angeles, returned to Vanderbilt to receive the divinity school's Distinguished Alumnus Award, at which time he was warmly greeted by Dr. Branscomb.
Educated at Birmingham College, later named Birmingham-Southern College, Dr. Branscomb won a Rhodes Scholarship to Oxford, where he began his career as a New Testament scholar in 1914. He later published four books on the cultural and religious roots of Christianity.
While at Oxford, Dr. Branscomb was among the group of American student volunteers who worked for Herbert Hoover's Commission for Relief in Belgium. He and a fellow student daringly smuggled a letter out of Belgium addressed to Belgian religious leaders encouraging resistance to the German invasion then under way. The letter, published in The Times of London, led to the decoration of Dr. Branscomb and his fellow student by the Belgian Government.
After Oxford, he earned a doctorate in philosophy at Columbia University and later became dean of the divinity school at Duke University.
A native of Huntsville, Ala., he is survived by three sons, Harvie Branscomb Jr. of Corpus Christi, Tex., Dr. Ben Branscomb of Birmingham, Ala., and Lewis M. Branscomb of Concord, Mass.; a brother, Lewis C. Branscomb of Columbus, Ohio; two sisters, Dr. Louise Branscomb and Mrs. Charles L. Dill, both of Birmingham; nine grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren. Dr. Branscomb's wife of 71 years, Margaret, died in 1992.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Harvie Branscomb, second from right, was among members of the United States Advisory Commission on Educational Exchange who met with President Harry S. Truman in September 1948. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Corporate Earnings, Hurt by Asia Crisis, Depress Shares

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Share prices dropped sharply yesterday, more than erasing big gains from the prior day, in a sign that investors remain troubled by unimpressive corporate earnings.
After having largely dismissed the Asian economic crisis, investors are finally awakening to the effects of a slowdown in the Pacific region, Wall Street analysts say. That slowdown may diminish the growth in corporate profits at home, and thereby stifle stocks for the remainder of 1998. 
 This prospect has caused several weeks of fluctuating expectations and volatile trading, pulling the major stock indexes down from all-time highs set earlier this summer. Many smaller-company stocks, which have been battered for months, are in negative territory for the year.
"This ain't pretty," Robert F. Dickey, a technical analyst at Dain Rauscher in Minneapolis, said. "We've been in a correction since April, but the big blue chips are finally joining the rest of the market, which has been crumbling for weeks."
Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 143.66 points, or 1.59 percent, to close at 8,883.29. The sharp drop came a day after the Dow rallied 111.99 points, or 1.3 percent. For the week, the average fell 54.07 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent.
Broader indexes were hit harder. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 22.28 points, or 1.95 percent, to 1,120.67, and the Nasdaq composite fell nearly 2.5 percent to close at 1,872.39, leaving that index about 7 percent below its all-time high of 2,014.25 set July 20.
The swings in trading and sentiment have more than a few analysts worried about whether stocks can regain the momentum that has propelled one of the greatest bull markets in history.
Mr. Dickey and other analysts say the overriding concern among investors is corporate earnings. And the growing consensus is that despite a robust domestic economy, troubles in Asia and rising wage growth at home are depressing corporate profits.
With more than 80 percent of the companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500 reporting, corporate earnings are up just 1.7 percent from a year ago, according to I.B.E.S. International, which tracks earnings estimates. Analysts are lowering their third-quarter estimates.
Worries about corporate profits may have been aggravated by a Government report yesterday that the nation's gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of just 1.4 percent in the second quarter. Although stronger than expected, it was still a sharp slowdown from the first quarter's 5.5 percent rate.
"There's clearly a lot of nervousness out there right now," Philip J. Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management, said. "People are worried about Asia's impact on earnings, and this Asia problem is getting worse."
In contrast to stocks yesterday, bond prices rose slightly, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury down to 5.71 percent, from 5.72 Thursday.
Because investors have low inflation expectations, long-term bond yields have remained in a narrow range for much of the year. The 30-year bond has hovered between 5.6 percent and 5.8 percent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europe Says Yes to Arms Industry Mergers

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, July 31

 BODY:
Military industry mergers may be history in the United States, but in Europe they are very much alive.
France's decision last week to privatize its aerospace giant, Aerospatiale, shows that the process of sorting out European aviation and military industries is just beginning. 
 American military companies, by contrast, have evolved into a few giants, concentrated to the point that Lockheed Martin scrapped its bid for Northrop Grumman a few weeks ago. The Pentagon said the merged company would be too powerful, sending the message that further combinations were not likely.
European military companies, unlike their American counterparts, remain highly fragmented, with hundreds of small competitors struggling to pay for expensive research and development, even as national defense budgets have shrunk.
After the fall of Communism, European Governments slashed military budgets so much that they collectively equal only about half the Pentagon's $270 billion allocation.
This is the main reason why Europe wants its aviation and military industries to group into an enormous conglomerate, tentatively named the European Aerospace and Defense Company, with divisions that would include Airbus Industrie, the commercial aircraft manufacturer, as well as space and defense activities like military aircraft, missiles and weapons systems.
To be sure, Airbus has been a resounding success, getting half the worldwide orders this year for new jetliners despite bitter competition from its rival, Boeing.
Last week, Manfred Bischoff, chief executive of Daimler-Benz Aerospace, said that Airbus, which until now operated as a loose consortium of four European aircraft manufacturers, would be ready to start operating as a single company, probably a corporation under French law, by the first half of next year. The challenge now is building the rest of the new European aviation and military conglomerate.
"The real problem," said Nick Cunningham, aerospace analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in London, "is putting the monster together."
The obstacles to such an undertaking are large. British Aerospace, privatized in 1981, is one of the most efficient and profitable companies, while Aerospatiale has a history of Government largess and bureaucratic management.
Moreover, as industries are merged and duplication eliminated, jobs will disappear. Deciding who remains employed will be particularly difficult because Europe's unemployment rate is roughly double that of the United States.
For Airbus, the chance to extend its newfound momentum by tapping financial markets and financing new products, like a planned jet for more than 500 passengers, depends on its ability to operate as a single company, with its own management and bookkeeping. European Governments agree. This spring, Bonn warned Airbus there would be no German Government money for the superjet until Airbus became a unified corporation.
But the idea for a unified aerospace and military company goes beyond the plans for Airbus.
Under a grand design proposed earlier this year by Germany, France and Britain, the big new company would be effectively owned by the present Airbus partners -- Aerospatiale, Germany's Daimler-Benz Aerospace, British Aerospace and Spain's Construcciones Aeronauticas S.A. -- plus private investors. Run by a single management, the company would consist not only of Airbus as its commercial aircraft arm, but other units for space technology, military aircraft and helicopters, missiles and weapons systems. Italy and Sweden, though not part of the Airbus consortium, support the plan.
The reasoning is that Europe's military contractors, without the influence of such a huge group, would wilt against the powerful American companies like Lockheed Martin, Boeing and Raytheon that emerged from five years of consolidation in the United States military industry. Earlier this year, the largest European companies -- British Aerospace, the market leader; Aerospatiale, the No. 2., and the No. 3, Daimler-Benz -- ratified the plan.
As part of that plan, the Government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin agreed last week to push the Government stake in Aerospatiale under 50 percent, bring in the big defense and publishing group, Lagardere, as a private shareholder, and give the Government a "golden share" to assure national security interests.
The carousel of mergers and acquisitions is now expected to begin in earnest to form the clusters that will ultimately be the planned European company's divisions.
Last week, Daimler-Benz announced that by year-end it will merge its space activities into Matra Marconi Space, a joint venture formed last year by Britain's General Electric Company and Lagardere. The resulting space contractor, with $2.5 billion of revenues, will be the world's third largest, after Lockheed Martin and Boeing-Rockwell. At the same time, Spain announced it would put 25 percent of its national aerospace group, the Airbus partner Construcciones Aeronauticas, on the block for private investors, and British Aerospace immediately said it would acquire a stake.
Of course, there is no assurance that the proposed new aerospace and defense group will succeed.
Indeed, even as Daimler and British Aerospace officials praised the French, they said they were continuing to talk with each other -- about first choices, like the shape of the new European company, but also about fallback positions, such as a possible merger of their own. "We're always talking with each other," said Simon Raynes, the British Aerospace spokesman. "All this talking is really about seeking solutions."
But reports of discussions between the British and the Germans have raised fears in Paris of a special British-German deal designed to cut out the French.
Moreover, Daimler's planned takeover of the Chrysler Corporation has contributed to speculation in France of Daimler's possible withdrawal from the aerospace business, to focus on automobiles. Daimler officials have denied that and said earlier this week that Chrysler could even create aerospace opportunities for Daimler in the United States.

Deal for Aerospace Unit
 LONDON, July 31 (Bloomberg News) -- BTR P.L.C. said today that it would sell its aerospace unit to a venture capital firm, Doughty Hanson & Company, for £510 million, or about $835 million, cash, extending a plan to trim its extensive holdings.
BTR, Britain's biggest diversified industrial company, said it would make a £190 million one-time profit on the sale. It includes the Standard Aero engine repair and overhaul business, a unit that makes turbofan engine parts and the Dunlop brake and rubber manufacturer.
The sale adds to more than £3.7 billion BTR has raised since September, when the London-based company put a third of its assets on the block to help revive a flagging stock price. Its stock still has slumped one-third since then on concern about a strong pound and Asia's turmoil.
BTR's shares rose 4.75 pence today to 151.25 pence, about $2.47.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Congress Cancels a Vote to Increase Visas

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
One week after announcing a compromise to increase the number of visas available for high-technology workers, Congressional leaders canceled planned votes today on the legislation under the threat of a veto.
Although supporters of the legislation remained optimistic about the chances of a compromise with the White House, the canceled vote dashed hopes of relieving critical worker shortages before the fiscal year ends in September. 
 The White House threatened a veto on Thursday night, expressing concerns that provisions to insure that American workers would not be replaced with cheaper foreign labor were inadequate.
The 65,000 visas available this year for skilled foreign workers were used up in May. Technology companies have been lobbying heavily for an immediate increase this year, saying crucial projects, including the repair of Year 2000 computer problems, have been delayed by the shortage of workers with the necessary advanced computer programming and engineering skills.
Among concessions the Administration is seeking is a fee on employers who sponsor foreign workers. The money would go into a fund to train American workers. The White House also wants stronger language to insure that Americans are not being laid off and then replaced with cheaper foreign labor and an arbitration process for American workers who think they have been wrongly let go.

HEADLINE: The Grand Central B.I.D. War

 BODY:
New Yorkers who understand the key role that business improvement districts have played in the city's revitalization may have been unnerved by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's decision to dissolve the Grand Central Partnership, one of the largest and best-known B.I.D.'s. The Mayor's action seems drastic, but his position is not, on the whole, unreasonable.
Mr. Giuliani's chief complaint is that the Partnership's president, Daniel Biederman, is also the head of two other midtown B.I.D.'s, at Bryant Park and 34th Street, creating a sort of mini-empire. Mr. Biederman's defenders say that the district operations are deeply intertwined, and that the smaller ones could not provide the present level of services if they were forced to stand on their own. That argument makes Mr. Giuliani's case. The money the city collects from neighborhood property owners for a B.I.D.'s use is supposed to stay in that neighborhood -- something that is hard to guarantee when operations are as blended as Mr. Biederman's seem to be. 
 The Grand Central Partnership's leaders seem ready to fight the city in court, a decision that could create a long period of uncertainty that would threaten all the gains the Partnership has made in improving the area around Grand Central Terminal. They appear to regard their organization as a private company that can do what it likes as long as the board of directors is pleased. But B.I.D.'s are actually public-private partnerships. There are now 40 B.I.D.'s in New York City -- The New York Times is a member of the Times Square B.I.D. -- and they have done a great deal to improve the cleanliness, security and atmosphere of our commercial districts. But if City Hall begins to feel that the districts threaten its prerogatives, the whole concept will be undermined.
Mr. Giuliani's position appears to be based on a reasonable conviction that B.I.D.'s should stick to a limited agenda, and remain both community-based and self-supporting. To end this crisis, Mr. Biederman must sever his ties with two of the B.I.D.'s he controls. The Grand Central Partnership should respond to the administration's other complaints about bidding procedures and keeping operations open to government scrutiny. Property owners who finance the Partnership's operations must protect their own investment in their community by making sure these things happen quickly.

HEADLINE: MONTANA JOURNAL;
Wide Open Spaces Lure The Best and the Worst

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: HELENA, Mont. July 26

 BODY:
Montanans are learning that their "last best place" label cuts two ways. It attracts land investors as prominent as Ted Turner and Charles Schwab. But it also attracts runaway loners as troubled as the Unabomber and Russell E. Weston Jr., the man charged with killing two Capitol Police officers.
Today, Montanans are saying it is unfair for the nation to judge a little-known state by its delinquents. 
 "We don't judge L.A. by O.J.; we don't judge New York by the World Trade Center bombers," Andrew H. Malcolm, the spokesman for Gov. Marc Racicot, said here in the state's capital. "Montana shouldn't be judged by its kooks."
Montanans emphasized this week that many of their state's notorious residents moved here from elsewhere.
Mr. Weston and Theodore J. Kaczynski, the convicted Unabomber, grew up in Illinois. In trials of members of the anti-government Freemen movement, based in eastern Montana, the state's juries have convicted people who came here from Canada and from Arkansas, California, Colorado, North Carolina and Utah. In the 1980's a sect based in California, the Church Universal and Triumphant, moved to a ranch north of Yellowstone National Park, dug bomb shelters and waited for the world to end.
"This guy Weston isn't a native -- it doesn't have anything to do with Montana people," Jim Allison, a retired cowboy, said this morning as he read a newspaper on Last Chance Gulch, the central pedestrian mall in this former gold- and silver-mining city. "They had the same problem in Texas after the Civil War. Every renegade, every outlaw, moved there. It got so bad they had to develop the Texas Rangers."
With a little prodding, Mr. Allison, a grizzled man in a straw cowboy hat, admitted that he, too, moved here from out of state -- from Texas.
Indeed, for the first time in decades, people who moved here from other states now outnumber native-born residents of Montana. Moreover, second-home owners are flocking to a state that is nearly the size of California, but has only 900,000 inhabitants.
Boosters of Big Sky Country would prefer that Montana's name be tied to these glamorous second-home owners: Stephen E. Ambrose, the author and historian; Tom Brokaw, the NBC News anchor, and a slew of Hollywood actors: Mel Gibson, Whoopi Goldberg, Michael Keaton, Jeff Bridges, Andie McDowell, Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid.
"A lot of people are drawn to Montana and Idaho because of the isolation of the mountains, because there are fewer rules and regulations, because there is a kind of mind-your-own-business ethic out here," said Robert Balch, a sociology professor at the University of Montana in Missoula.
Montana is the nation's fourth-largest state in area (after Alaska, Texas and California), but it ranks 44th in population. In this state with only six people per square mile, automobile drivers can cruise the Interstates in Montana during daylight unencumbered by speed limits.
"Montana has a certain mythical attraction to it that allows for 10 times as many people who live here to visit, to pass through," Governor Racicot said today, referring to the nine million tourists who are drawn to the state every year, largely in the summer. "The fact about Montana is that a huge amount of open space provides for a lot of privacy."
Some people say the Western penchant for self-reliance and small government might have been why the state mental hospital apparently did not conduct follow-up contacts with Mr. Weston in the 20 months since he was released, in December 1996. Doctors at Warm Springs State Mental Hospital released Mr. Weston after concluding that he was not a threat to himself or to others, and with the understanding that he would return to his family home in Illinois and continue treatment.
"Montana has no more mentally ill than the rest of the nation, but being so rural it is hard to keep up with them," said Dr. Nathan A. Munn, a psychiatrist in Helena.
But Mr. Racicot said the state was not at fault.
"Apparently, the Illinois authorities did not reach a conclusion that was distinctively different from Montana's," the Governor said. "Apparently, the F.B.I. and the Secret Service did not see the need for a higher level of security."
T. H. Watkins, a professor of Western history at Montana State University in Bozeman, also would not tar the region for its deviants.
"This guy, like Kaczynski, is an anomaly," Professor Watkins said of Mr. Weston. "He's a paranoid schizophrenic. I don't think the West did it to him. Why do we simply assume that the West breeds these characters? It doesn't."

HEADLINE: Dispirited Republicans Struggle for Foothold in West Virginia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 30

 BODY:
Sally Kay is running for Congress this year. But hardly anyone in her home state of West Virginia knows it.
As the Republican challenger to Representative Robert E. Wise Jr., a popular Democrat who has held his seat since 1982, she has no money, no campaign staff, not even a bumper sticker of her own. She has yet to make her first campaign speech and remains a virtual stranger to groups that typically support Republicans. 
 "My fear is that I'll start to get checks and I'll have to return them because I don't have a treasurer," Ms. Kay said, sitting in the cramped office of West Virginia's Republican Party headquarters here in the state capital. "I'm not abdicating, but without a treasurer, it's hard to run."
Ms. Kay's inability to find a campaign treasurer is only one example of the hard lot of Republicans in West Virginia, one of the few remaining examples of a one-party state, and a stark contrast to Republican gains elsewhere in the region.
Here, Democrats rule. As a legacy of strong coal-mining unions, the New Deal policies of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and family traditions of party loyalty, Democrats have held sway over most of West Virginia's political institutions for more than 60 years. And it is unlikely that Republicans will achieve parity anytime soon.
In West Virginia, registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by more than 2 to 1, a disparity that almost always works to the Democrats' advantage.
One exception is Gov. Cecil H. Underwood, who also served as Governor from 1956 to 1960. He won a narrow victory in 1996 by defeating a Democrat who was widely perceived as even more liberal than the out-going Governor, Gaston Caperton, who had served two terms. But since 1932, voters have elected only one other Republican Governor, Arch A. Moore Jr., who served two terms from 1968 through 1976.
Of the state's three members of the United States House of Representatives, only Mr. Wise faces opposition in the general election this year, as he did in 1996 when he won easily. Representative Nick J. Rahall 2d, who was first elected in 1976, faced his last challenger in 1992. Representative Alan B. Mollohan, who succeeded his father in 1982, faced his last in 1990.
A Republican has not held a House seat since 1980, and Democrats have held both Senate seats since 1959.
At the state level, Democrats have controlled the House since 1928 and the Senate since 1930, a dominance that was common among Southern states until recently.
In Florida, for example, Republicans won control of the state Senate in 1994 for the first time in 120 years and now have a majority in both chambers. Three years ago in Virginia, Republicans pulled even with Democrats in the Senate and, now with a Republican Lieutenant Governor as a tie-breaking vote, control it for the first time since the Civil War.
In West Virginia, Republicans have made marginal gains in the 34-member Senate, picking up eight seats since 1990, when they had a record low of one. But seats in the 100-member House have been harder to come by. Republicans picked up 6 in 1990 to reach 26 but no more since.
And it is unlikely they will make significant gains in this year's elections to fill all seats in the state House of Delegates and half the seats in the Senate. For the second election year in a row, the party failed to find candidates in more than 50 races.
The lopsidedness of a two-party system here has resulted in a state Republican Party that seems to exist in name only. Betty White is the executive director and sole full-time employee, with an annual salary of $19,000. She has a desk but no computer. Not that one is needed.
"Someone wiped our computer out in March 1995," Ms. White said, hinting at sabotage to erase the list of the state's Republican voters. "There were rumors about a virus, but I don't believe them."
The size and shape of the state party office reflects a grim reality for Republicans throughout West Virginia despite the recent efforts of a new state party chairman and a new group, the Republican Legislative Commission, to raise money and recruit candidates.
The absence of credible Republican challengers in more state and Federal elections reflects two chronic political conditions here, one feeding the other. The first is the star status of the state's leading politicians. The popularity and tenure of Senators Robert C. Byrd and John D. Rockefeller 4th have deterred potential challengers from both parties, including the three House members. And the House members' popularity has discouraged many state legislators from taking the next step.
Over the years, the overall dynamic has ushered in a certain ennui among Republicans, who have felt helpless to change the political balance. In a long conversation, Ms. White spoke several times of her unsuccessful efforts to raise money and to encourage people to run against entrenched, well-financed Democrats.
"The party has been pretty weak," Governor Underwood, who is 75, conceded in an interview. "I feel it needs to rebuild its base in the legislature. That's the only way we can build. We just can't depend on dissatisfaction from the other side."
Robert J. Gould, a 40-year-old lawyer and state lobbyist, said the party's lack of elective success led him to create the Republican Legislative Commission in 1994 as a vehicle to identify new candidates at the grass-roots level.
Mr. Gould said his narrow loss in the 1992 state attorney general race, his first run for public office, convinced him that many Democrats, despite their party affiliation, are more moderate than liberal and would be willing to vote Republican in certain elections. That belief, he said, was bolstered two years ago when Mr. Underwood's opponent, Charlotte Pritt, was widely perceived as a candidate too far removed from mainstream voters.
On the strength of his political connections, Mr. Gould began arranging fund-raisers with the goal of spreading the money among Republicans in elections where a Democrat appeared vulnerable. Through this year's elections, he said, the new group will have contributed $150,000 to Republican candidates for the statehouse.
In addition, the state's new party chairman, David R. Tyson, who was recently elected to a four-year term, said he had made great strides in raising money and generating new interest among Republicans across the state. Mr. Tyson said he was planning six fund-raisers to assist Mr. Gould's efforts.
But tugging against this kind of progress is the aversion of Mr. Gould's organization and Ms. White to working together even though Mr. Tyson insisted that he, not Ms. White, was doing the bulk of the work for the state organization and that he enjoyed a good working relationship with Mr. Gould.
Nonetheless, sparks have flown, leaving at least a perception of party disunity. Ms. White, who said she intended to resign soon, contended that Mr. Gould had intentionally undermined her by "promoting his own candidates while shoving others aside" and by tapping Republican donors for his own purposes.
Mr. Gould said his group was merely performing where the party had failed, searching out viable candidates and helping them financially.
Whatever direction the Republicans are heading, Mr. Tyson and other Republicans say any real measure of party progress will not come before one of the Democratic Congressmen resigns or runs for higher office, creating a rare opening. Mr. Wise has acknowledged that he is seriously considering a run for governor in 2000.
But even if the wait is longer, party leaders acknowledge that they have to do a better job of raising money, finding candidates and convincing voters that Republican positions are more in tune with their moderate views than the Democrats'.
"The state is changing," Governor Underwood said, referring to a diversifying economy that no longer depends solely on the coal industry. "With new jobs and new people, we have a different mix now. My instincts tell me that if we can capture that growth, we can build a new party."

HEADLINE: Study Says Trading Pollution Permits Would Be Economical

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Paying other countries to cut their pollution could be the cheapest way for the United States to help control the heat-trapping gases that cause global warming, the Clinton Administration said in a new economic analysis released today.
A system of buying and selling pollution permits internationally, as proposed by the Administration, would cut the costs to the United States at least in half and possibly by as much as 85 percent, according to a study by the White House Council of Economic Advisers. Many economists favor the trading of pollution permits as a free-market mechanism that reduces the costs of pollution controls. 
 "The world is filled with unbelievably cheap opportunities to reduce emissions abroad," said Janet Yellin, President Clinton's top economic adviser.
The study was intended to substantiate Ms. Yellin's recent testimony before Congress that the United States could meet the targets of a new international climate change protocol, negotiated last year in Kyoto, Japan, at a modest cost. She has estimated that the typical household's annual energy bill might rise as little as $70 per year, although others insist the amount would be far higher.
With the Senate balking at approving any treaty that does not include a substantial role for developing countries in the control of emissions, the Administration has struggled for more than a year to produce a comprehensive analysis of its proposals.
The study released today was attacked by critics on several sides of the climate debate.
Connie Holmes, the chairwoman of the Global Climate Coalition, a group representing large companies that oppose the treaty, called the report "smoke and mirrors." The Administration, Ms. Holmes said, had not faced up to the fact that many foreign nations oppose the idea of pollution trading.
Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who opposes the global warming treaty, said the report "gives every appearance of being a post hoc rationalization, full of tautologies and self-fulfilling, unrealistic or unprovable assertions and assumptions."
Some environmental groups strongly criticized the Administration, saying the study suggested that the United States, which emits more heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide than any other country, is seeking to avoid much of its responsibility for solving the problem of climate change.
"Their plan is to buy reductions abroad," said Gary Cook, legislative director for the climate campaign at Greenpeace. "We need to take the first steps largely at home."
The Administration's study was based on sophisticated computerized economic models, including one developed by the Battelle Laboratory in Ohio to estimate the economic costs of actions to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, the principal heat-trapping gas produced when fossil fuels are burned.
The models suggested that the United States could meet its emissions targets, which require reductions of 7 percent below the 1990 level over the next 10 to 15 years, at an annual cost of $7 billion to $12 billion.
Energy prices would increase by amounts equivalent to about 5 cents per gallon of gasoline, according to these projections.
The models suggested that about one-fourth of the reductions in emissions would actually be accomplished within the United States. The rest of the reductions would be bought from other countries that were cutting emissions more than the treaty required, and therefore had surplus pollution permits to sell.
Ms. Yellin and Todd Stern, the White House's senior aide on climate issues, said today that these projections underestimated how much the Administration's policies would reduce emissions at home.
Ms. Yellin said the model did not take into account any of several initiatives the Administration favors to reduce domestic emissions of carbon dioxide. Among these are elements of its proposal to restructure the electric utility industry, to provide tax incentives for energy-saving investments, and to subsidize research into new technologies like solar power and fuel-efficient automobiles.

HEADLINE: Black Parents Say Learning Supersedes Integration

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
African-American parents are more interested in having public schools raise their academic standards than put their energies into promoting integration, according to a new survey by Public Agenda, a nonprofit research organization, and Public Education Network, a national umbrella group of organizations whose goal is to improve public education.
While 8 in 10 parents, black as well as white, said they believed that integrated schools could help improve race relations and were a laudable goal, the consensus of both groups was that schools should concentrate on academics. 
 "We've spent a lot of time on race issues, and we need to redirect some of those energies to getting our children better educated," said a black parent from Pennsylvania in one of the follow-up telephone interviews with parents who had taken part in the survey, which was released this week.
Half of the black parents polled and 72 percent of the white parents said they thought that integrated schools made little difference in the quality of the education their children received.
Furthermore, nearly three-quarters of black parents and 77 percent of white parents agreed with the statement that "too often, the schools work so hard to achieve integration that they end up neglecting their most important goal -- teaching kids."
The report is based on a national telephone survey of 800 African-American and 800 white parents conducted this spring. The margin of error was plus or minus three percentage points. In addition, Public Agenda held eight focus groups across the nation and interviewed 20 specialists in the field.
The study also called attention to fear among some white parents about integration. For example, one white parent in a Walnut Creek, Calif., focus group said: "They redrew the lines and brought in a large section of low-income-housing kids into my children's elementary school. Test scores dropped. These are kids that need help and they get it. But it dumbs down the curriculum, and it takes away from the gifted kids."
Three-quarters of African-American parents said race should not be a factor when choosing a teacher or superintendent for a predominantly black school district. "As long as he's doing his job, I don't care if he's green," said a black parent in a Cleveland focus group.
Among other areas of agreement between black and white parents was on the question of whether teachers should teach such values as honesty, respect and civility: 84 percent of the black parents and 83 percent of the whites agreed it was a good idea.
There was a sharp difference, however, in attitudes toward diversity. Sixty percent of the black parents favored it, while only 34 percent of the whites did.
Deborah Wadsworth, executive director of Public Agenda, said the big surprise to her and her colleagues was "the laserlike focus of black Americans on the need for achievement, rigor and standards, which must not be distracted by other considerations."
Irving Hamer Jr., an African-American member of the Board of Education of New York City, said the loss of interest in integration that the report revealed was "not surprising and somewhat disappointing."
Nevertheless, he said, he shares the view that educational quality should be the top priority.
"Society is facing cataclysmic change, what with technological development and the growth of the global economy, and once again African-Americans are being left out. If we want to prevent that, we have to focus, and the focus has to be on improved education."
The survey also studied views on standardized tests. Forty-four percent of African-American parents said the tests that are used to determine acceptance to college and eligibility for certain types of financial aid measure "real differences in educational achievement," and an additional 18 percent said whites tend to score higher because black students have less faith in their ability.
But only 28 percent said they believed that the tests are culturally biased against African-American students.
Over the next year, Public Agenda, which is based in New York City, and the Public Education Network, which is in Washington, intend to sponsor community discussions on issues raised by the survey.

HEADLINE: Paula Jones's Lawyers Ask That Her Suit Be Reinstated

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones asked a Federal appeals court today to reinstate her sexual misconduct suit against President Clinton, arguing, among other things, that a lower court should never have excluded evidence about any relationship he had had with Monica S. Lewinsky.
In their brief, Ms. Jones's lawyers maintained that Susan Webber Wright, the Federal district judge in Little Rock, Ark., who threw out the suit four months ago, exceeded her authority in ruling earlier that any evidence of a sexual liaison between Mr. Clinton and Ms. Lewinsky was not material to the case. 
 The Jones legal team said evidence of a Clinton-Lewinsky relationship would have helped them show a pattern of how Mr. Clinton treats subordinate women in the workplace. The lawyers said Mr. Clinton had used his position of authority to engage in sex with Ms. Lewinsky, a onetime White House intern.
The brief said evidence about Ms. Lewinsky was relevant to "the core issue of whether he engaged in the conduct alleged by Ms. Jones."
Ms. Jones's suit maintains that in 1991, at a Little Rock hotel where a state economic conference was under way, a state trooper summoned her to meet in a suite with Mr. Clinton, who was then the Governor. By the account of Ms. Jones, who at the time was a state employee, Mr. Clinton propositioned her there, dropping his trousers and asking her to perform a sex act. The President has vehemently denied such an occurrence, although he does not dispute that he may have met Ms. Jones at the hotel.
What might have been a sensational trial was averted on April 1 when Judge Wright ruled that Ms. Jones had not presented any tangible evidence of damage, even if the encounter had occurred as she contended. "While the alleged incident in the hotel, if true, was certainly boorish and offensive," the judge wrote in dismissing the lawsuit, "the Governor's alleged conduct" constituted neither sexual assault nor actionable harassment.
Despite his victory, the Jones lawsuit had already caused enormous damage to Mr. Clinton, both politically and legally. It became the basis for the current investigation by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, into whether Mr. Clinton had a sexual relationship with Ms. Lewinsky and then colluded with her to lie about it.
In a deposition taken by Ms. Jones's lawyers in January, Mr. Clinton denied under oath that he had had a sexual relationship with Ms. Lewinsky. Mr. Starr is investigating whether Mr. Clinton committed perjury that day.
Ms. Jones's appeal today was filed with the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis. The court has a generally conservative cast of judges who have been consistently unhelpful to Mr. Clinton in other cases. But those judges have also been notably reluctant to entertain complaints of workplace sexual discrimination like the one brought by Ms. Jones.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Resume Slide On Worries About Profits
Share prices dropped sharply, more than erasing big gains from the day before, on persistent concern about unimpressive corporate earnings. Wall Street analysts said investors were finally awakening to the effects of the slowdown in Asia, which could diminish growth at home and stifle stocks for the remainder of 1998. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 143.66 points, or 1.59 percent, to close at 8,883.29. The sharp drop came a day after the Dow rallied 111.99 points, or 1.3 percent. Broader indexes were hit harder. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 22.28 points, or 1.95 percent, to 1,120.67, and the Nasdaq composite fell nearly 2.5 percent to close at 1,872.39. Page D3.
 
Economic Growth Slowed in Spring
The nation's gross domestic product grew at a 1.4 percent annual rate during April, May and June, the most sluggish quarter in three years. But economists said the performance still showed the economy's resilience in the face of the Asia financial crisis. A1.
 
New Microsoft-Justice Skirmish
The Government accused Microsoft of resisting requests to provide technical information and to make 17 executives including the company's chairman, William H. Gates, available for depositions as part of the antitrust case against the software company. The trial is set to begin Sept. 8. D3.
 
GE Capital to Buy Reinsurer
GE Capital plans to acquire the Kemper Reinsurance Company, in a deal estimated to be as much as $500 million. The acquisition will broaden GE Capital's already strong presence in insurance in the United States. D3.
 
Crackdown on Options Trader
Securities regulators in Texas, Ohio, Idaho and California, aided by the F.B.I., have moved to shut down the Cleveland-based Options Trading Group, a firm accused of defrauding investors of millions through the sale of foreign-currency options. D3.
 
I.B.M. Fined in Russia Export Case
An I.B.M. subsidiary pleaded guilty to illegally exporting 17 advanced computers to a Russian nuclear weapons laboratory and agreed to pay an $8.5 million fine. It is believed to be I.B.M.'s first criminal conviction. A1.
 
Mass Layoffs at Korea Auto Maker
Hyundai, South Korea's leading automobile manufacturer, dismissed 1,569 employees, or 4 percent of its work force, making use of new labor laws to cut wages and weaken powerful unions. Hyundai is the first big South Korean company to dismiss workers en masse, and other employees have gone on strike in protest. D2.
 
Worker Visa Vote Canceled
Under the threat of a veto, Congressional leaders canceled planned votes on legislation to increase the number of visas for high-technology workers. D2.
 
French Gamble on TV Sale
For years, France's state-owned Thomson Multimedia was known mostly for color television sets and losses. The Government is betting this will end with its deal to sell part of the company to an international corporate alliance of Microsoft, Hughes Electronics, NEC and Alcatel. D2.
 
On-Line Privacy Proposals
Calling privacy in the age of electronic commerce a basic value that "must be protected," Vice President Al Gore announced initiatives that seek to tighten the security of financial and medical records and to protect the privacy of children who use the Internet. But many of the proposals are simply endorsements of existing bills, while others require new Congressional action that is, in some cases, uncertain at best. A10.

HEADLINE: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT A SLOWER PACE IN THE 2D QUARTER

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
A powerful array of forces at home and abroad slowed the economy to a modest but still healthy pace during the second quarter, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department said the nation's gross domestic product grew at a 1.4 percent annual rate during April, May and June. It was the most sluggish quarter in three years and marked a substantial slowdown from the blistering pace of growth in the first quarter, which the department today revised upward to 5.5 percent from its earlier estimate of 5.4 percent. 
 The slowdown further unnerved Wall Street, where investors are already anxious over the ability of companies to sustain strong earnings growth. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 143.66 points to close at 8,883.29. It has fallen more than 450 points, or nearly 5 percent, since hitting a new high two weeks ago.
But growth in the second quarter was considerably stronger than had been projected by economists. Many had expected no growth or even a slight contraction in total output.
Although considerable uncertainties remain, not least among them the continued effects of Asia's financial crisis on the United States, the consensus among analysts is that growth for the rest of the year should be 2 percent to 3 percent, considered respectable.
Indeed, the details of today's report suggested that the economy had so far weathered the Asia crisis -- plus the effects of the now-settled strike against General Motors and a decision by industry to prune large stockpiles of unsold goods -- without much fundamental damage or any serious risk of recession.
While export-oriented manufacturers and farmers are suffering from Asia's problems, many of the forces that have driven the seven-year expansion remained very much intact, especially strong growth in spending by consumers and businesses within the United States.
The report showed that domestic final sales, an indicator of domestic demand, surged 6.3 percent in the second quarter, compared with a 6.6 percent gain in the first quarter, as consumers continued to spend freely and businesses continued to invest in new equipment.
Personal consumption increased 5.8 percent in the quarter, down from 6.1 percent in the first three months of the year. Capital spending by businesses rose 17.8 percent, roughly half the rate of the previous quarter but still a vibrant pace.
The report also suggested that inflation remained dormant, with the main price index rising eight-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, down from nine-tenths of 1 percent in the first three months of the year.
"The economy has taken a lot and come through it well," said Richard D. Rippe, an economist at Prudential Securities in New York.
Like many economists, Mr. Rippe said it was unclear how strong growth would be for the rest of the year, and that much depended on the situation in Asia.
Today's report was a preliminary estimate by the Commerce Department, and it will almost certainly be revised as new data come in.
Still, officials at the White House expressed relief that the economy, the cornerstone of President Clinton's political support, continued to show considerable resilience.
At a news conference in the Rose Garden, Mr. Clinton said that while "growth in the second quarter of 1998 was more moderate than the truly remarkable first quarter, it shows that our economy continues to enjoy steady growth."
The slowdown seems unlikely to have any immediate effect on the Federal Reserve's interest rate policy, economists said. The Fed's most aggressive inflation fighters will continue to focus on the combination of low unemployment and strong demand, while another contingent, including Alan Greenspan, the chairman, seems willing to keep rates unchanged as long as there are no clear signs of broad-based increases in wages and prices.
The second quarter's 1.4 percent growth rate followed six consecutive quarters in which growth was 3 percent or higher, a streak that was accompanied by falling unemployment and little or no inflation.
But much of the slowdown was caused by temporary factors that are unlikely to persist. Commerce Department economists estimated that the strike that crippled General Motors subtracted about one percentage point from gross domestic product during the second quarter. Because the strike was not settled until this week, it will also depress third- quarter growth somewhat, but economists said G.M. would likely try to make up for lost production, helping to strengthen growth by the end of the year.
The sharp downturn in exports to Asia and increased competition from imports took another two to two and a half percentage points off second-quarter growth rates, economists said. Decisions by companies to reduce production to work off some of the big inventories they had amassed in the first quarter also reduced growth by around two percentage points, they said.
Most analysts say the inventory adjustment is now largely complete, removing one impediment to more robust growth. With the G.M. strike settled, the big question remains how much of a drag Asia will have on exports for the rest of the year, with some economists saying the worst is past and others saying the deterioration will continue.
Some analysts also think there could be a downturn coming in consumer demand, which has been fed by the strong stock market, low unemployment and high levels of consumer confidence.
The Commerce Department report showed that the personal savings rate plummeted in the second quarter to six-tenths of 1 percent from 1.2 percent in the first quarter and 3.5 percent in 1994. Economists at Chase Securities in New York said in a report today that the low savings rate could leave many consumers with little financial cushion if the stock market were to plummet.
Today's report from the Commerce Department also included revisions to economic growth statistics for each of the last three years, showing that growth from 1995 through 1997 was slightly higher than previously reported. For 1997, growth was revised up to 3.9 percent from 3.8 percent; for 1996, the revision was to 3.4 percent from 2.8 percent, and for 1995 the change was to 2.3 percent from 2 percent.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the second quarter of 1998 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: A Slaughter of Cormorants in Angler Country

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
The double-crested cormorant is a protected species, its safety guarded by Federal law. But on the Lake Ontario shoreline west of Watertown, N.Y., the long-necked black birds have become a pest to anglers, who say the growing colonies of cormorants are devouring smallmouth bass and, along with them, the livelihood of people who sell bait and run charter fishing trips.
This week, wildlife officials visiting an island nesting ground in eastern Lake Ontario made the grim discovery of more than 800 cormorants slaughtered by shotgun fire. Although they have no suspects and have made no arrests, officials say they think the festering conflict between conservation and commerce is the motive in what they are calling one of the worst mass killings of a federally protected bird species in recent years. 
 New York State biologists said that when they went ashore on the uninhabited Little Galloo Island on Wednesday they encountered heaps of carcasses of fledgling cormorants, piles of shotgun shells and starving chicks squawking weakly amid the carnage. Clifford Schneider, who directs Lake Ontario projects for the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, said, "You see a young chick still lying there alive among all the others that had been wiped out, and you can't help but be moved emotionally."
The mass shooting appeared to be the latest of several recent instances in which a once-rare species has recovered so much that it has come into conflict with local interests. On July 23, Carrollton, Tex., bulldozed a rookery filled with nesting snowy egrets, little blue herons and other species protected by Federal law, after complaints of noise and odors.
The count of dead birds from that incident could be more than 1,000, said Pamela McCroskery, a spokeswoman for the Texas chapter of the National Audubon Society.
Around eastern Lake Ontario, fish-eating cormorants have staged a remarkable recovery since the 1950's, when they were nearly wiped out by pesticides and hunters.
In Henderson Harbor and other fishing spots near Little Galloo Island, owners of charter boats and other fishing-related businesses, joined by some officials, have been pressing the Government for several years to allow legalized hunting of cormorants, which they say are responsible for a drop in the populations of smallmouth bass and other popular game fish.
But with no action from the Government and the sport fishing industry in decline, there has been more and more talk along the shore lately of taking action against the birds, said Ron Ditch, a charter boat owner and guide for 43 years in Henderson Harbor.
"I've been pretty instrumental in trying to do this in a proper and legal manner," Mr. Ditch said yesterday. "But everyone's been hearing rumblings forever about how people are going to go out and take care of the situation. Apparently someone finally wouldn't be talked out of it anymore."
The controversy over the cormorants has centered on Henderson Harbor, a hamlet on a peninsula several miles from Little Galloo Island. The docks are a magnet for fishermen from across the country, some of whom spend $300 a day to charter boats and pursue smallmouth bass, salmon and other trophy fish.
The hamlet has nine marinas and more than 60 professional captains, and for many years, fishing has been about the only source of jobs or revenue, said Grover Moore, captain of the Charter II. "When I was growing up, there were signs at both ends of the harbor that said, 'The Home of the Black Bass.' "
But black bass, including smallmouths, have been hard to come by for several years, he said, and the fishermen say the birds are the only obvious culprit.
He said anglers had shot videotape of cormorants devouring freshly stocked brown trout to persuade state officials to press for a hunting season. "You can see them eat so many that they couldn't fly off the water," Mr. Moore said. "But nobody wants to listen to the fishermen."
Growing threats against the birds first turned to action in April, when eight cormorants were killed, Federal wildlife officials said. In June, about 100 cormorants were killed. But this week's massacre, which left 840 birds dead and more than 100 others wounded, transformed the local issue into an extraordinary environmental crime.
Mitchell Snow, a spokesman for the Fish and Wildlife Service in Washington, said a quick survey of officials there turned up no recollections of mass killings of a protected species that compared with the cormorant slaughter, except perhaps for the incident in Texas. "I've been with the department for almost 20 years and this is certainly the biggest in my memory," he said.
The long-necked diving birds have been protected for 25 years under the Federal Migratory Bird Treaty Act, which prohibits the killing of ducks, geese, egrets, cormorants and other migrating birds without a permit.
Cormorants have made a comeback in recent years, amd the island now contains the largest rookery for those birds in eastern Lake Ontario, with as many as 8,400 active nests. The 52-acre island is owned by the Phillips Petroleum Company but is only used as a bird preserve, state officials said.
Fishing guides and charter captains in the area have increasingly pressed members of Congress to write legislation authorizing controlled, legal hunting of the cormorants to reduce their numbers.
Representative John M. McHugh, a Republican who represents the lakeshore area in northern New York State, complained last fall that the Fish and Wildlife Service was taking too much time to assess the impact of the birds on local fish stocks.
The birds can be legally hunted in only a few places where they pose a clear economic threat, for example at catfish farms in Louisiana, Federal wildlife officials said. But research on their impact, if any, on the fish in Lake Ontario is still in the early stages, the officials said.
Federal biologists have estimated that cormorants eat 400,000 to 1.2 million smallmouth bass a year in the eastern part of the lake. But the significance of that number depends on the age of the bass, said James Farquhar, a biologist for the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
"If those are newborn bass, that's a drop in the bucket," Mr. Farquhar said. "There are literally billions. But if those 1.2 million fish have already lived through several years, that is a significant number."
Yesterday, officials were continuing their investigation. Conservation officers were interviewing anglers and others who might be able to pinpoint suspects around the fishing town of Henderson and other spots on Lake Ontario. Offers of money for information were being made, but no specific reward was posted.
John P. Cahill, State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, said: "We're making an all-out effort to find these people and prosecute them to the full extent of the law. This was an act of savage brutality."
Killing a bird protected by the migratory bird law can result in a maximum penalty of a $5,000 fine and six months in prison for each count, said Adam O'Hara, the special agent in charge of law enforcement for the Fish and Wildlife Service in the Northeast.
Mr. O'Hara said that evidence collected on the island, including more than 100 shell casings and some bird carcasses, was being sent to state pathology laboratories and a Federal forensic laboratory for investigating wildlife crimes in Ashland, Ore.
David J. Miller, the executive director of the New York chapter of the Audubon Society, said the shooting recalled the turn of the 20th century, when waterfowl and gulls were shot by the millions for sport and to supply feathers to the hat industry.
"This is a dark act that takes us back to that time," he said. He called for a swift investigation, and aggressive prosecution of those responsible.
"The message has to be strong that people really can't take the law into their own hands," Mr. Miller said.
