HEADLINE: Joined in a Corporate Marriage, but Divided by Style and Vision

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

 BODY:
Long before Robert B. Catell and Dr. William J. Catacosinos parted company yesterday, the two strong-willed utility company executives had established themselves as men of such different vision and personality that their partnership at the helm of the Marketspan Corporation seemed destined for trouble.
Mr. Catell, 61, had been president of Brooklyn Union Gas since 1991 and its chairman since 1996. He is the jovial public face of a company that gives low-interest loans to struggling businesses, seed money to rehabilitate dilapidated buildings and a postage-paid return envelope with every gas bill. 
 Dr. Catacosinos, 68, was enveloped in an entirely different sort of glow during the 14 years he ran the Long Island Lighting Company.
His tenure was dogged by controversy over his frequent pay raises and by bitterness over the high electricity rates, the highest in the continental United States, paid by Long Island consumers. It is a measure of their deep enmity toward the aloof Dr. Catacosinos that Long Islanders still publicly scold him for not immediately returning home from vacation after Hurricane Gloria knocked out power lines -- in 1985.
"Many of us believe Lilco was an avaricious greedy utility that always put the interests of its shareholders ahead of those of its ratepayers," said Wayne Prospect, a former Suffolk County lawmaker who works with a citizens group opposed to the state-financed deal that broke up Lilco and created Marketspan out of some of its parts and Brooklyn Union.
"And Catacosinos," Mr. Prospect added bluntly, "was the architect of all that."
Mr. Catell evokes far different reviews. "He has no airs of the corporate titan sitting atop the great utility," said Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.
Every summer, Mr. Catell is out in the sunshine at the annual chamber golf outing, part of the leading foursome with the borough's political elite. Once a year he returns to his Brooklyn alma mater, New Utrecht High School, and assumes the post of honorary assistant principal for the day.
"He's a Brooklyn guy," Mr. Adams said. "He knows everybody and everybody knows him. He has always been extremely visible and accessible."
Marketspan placed Mr. Catell and Dr. Catacosinos in a marriage of convenience that was not only short-lived but unsettled by their two very different visions of the company's future.
Mr. Catell, who served as chairman of the American Gas Association in 1994 and 1995, had already tried to steer Brooklyn Union toward a strategy of acquisitions of energy-related businesses, including distribution networks. He had said he envisioned building Marketspan into a diversified energy company to dominate the Northeast market.
During his brief term as Marketspan chairman, Dr. Catacosinos steered in a different direction that won praise from some stockholders. In meetings with Wall Street analysts and investors, he indicated that the company was on the block, available to outsiders for either a merger or acquisition.
While their corporate careers diverged sharply in matters of style and substance, the two men rose from similarly modest circumstances.
Dr. Catacosinos is the son of Greek immigrant parents who, he has said, impressed upon him the virtues of hard work and diligent study. He grew up in Washington Heights, earned a master's degree in business administration at New York University and then a Ph.D. in economics while working full time at the Brookhaven National Laboratory.
By the time he joined Lilco, Dr. Catacosinos was a millionaire, thanks to the propitious sale of his start-up companies to competitors. He once attributed his success to what he called his "barracuda instinct."
There are echoes of that inspirational story -- minus the killer fish -- in the career of Mr. Catell. Born and educated in Brooklyn, he went to City College for undergraduate work and then earned a master's degree in mechanical engineering there. He joined Brooklyn Union in 1958 as a junior engineer, at first laying pipe in neighborhoods familiar to him from his childhood, and worked his way up the administrative ladder.
Once at the top of their respective utilities, the two men faced vastly different challenges that indelibly shaped their reputations.
Mr. Catell took over a well-established company with a community-friendly image. Its popular Cinderella program, which provides seed money to rehabilitate run-down buildings, had been in operation since the 1960's. Brooklyn Union rates were in line with gas rates elsewhere in the country. And, to its good fortune, the competing energy company in its service area, Consolidated Edison, had a reputation for poor customer service.
Dr. Catacosinos, on the other hand, inherited a company mired in debt from its partially built and wildly over-budget Shoreham nuclear power plant. Community groups were fiercely opposed to the plant ever opening and had as their ally Mario M. Cuomo, then the Governor. Shareholders were no happier with Lilco's stock price at rock bottom, largely because of Shoreham's troubles.
The new chairman got Lilco on its feet, but not without further cost to the utility's public image. He dumped Shoreham, but the deal with the state transferred to ratepayers the more than $4 billion cost of paying off the plant's debt. That guaranteed Long Island ratepayers the highest rates in the nation except for Hawaii.

HEADLINE: Goodwill Games Fail to Draw Crowd

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, N.Y., July 31

 BODY:
At the delicatessen across the street from the Nassau Coliseum, the Goodwill Games have been deemed a dud.
"Without getting too analytical, I don't think the games were promoted or marketed properly, and that's evident in the poor turnout," said Ralph Galdorisi, whose delicatessen windows have a view of the Coliseum and its vast parking lot, which has been noticeably underused since the games began on July 19. 
 Other business people, particularly sponsors or promoters, insist that the games, which end tomorrow, have been a success. They said they have been good for Long Island's image and its long-term prospects for attracting sporting events.
But many of the businesses located here on Hempstead Turnpike at the hub of the sporting events at the Goodwill Games had expected to be overwhelmed by people flocking to see more than 1,500 top athletes from 60 countries compete for gold and $5 million in prize money.
Three Nassau County sites -- Nassau Coliseum and the Mitchel Field Athletic Complex, both in Uniondale, and the new Goodwill Games Swimming and Diving Center at Eisenhower Park in neighboring East Meadow -- are being used for 9 of the 15 events. Six other events were held at sites in Manhattan and Staten Island and had similarly low turnouts.
The limited number of hotels in Nassau County and western Suffolk County were almost completely booked by the athletes, officials and employees of the Goodwill Games. But except for a few events such as diving, soccer and figure skating, there have been low ticket sales. Tickets cost between $24 and $48 for each event and up to $60 for final events.
Among those who chose to skip the games because of the high prices was Mary Ann Reardon, a librarian and archivist at Friends Academy in Locust Valley. She said she wanted to purchase tickets for her family and as a birthday gift for her husband. "But that's an awful lot of money for me, considering my family's other financial obligations, which include college tuition bills," Mrs. Reardon said. "When you start buying tickets at that price for the entire family, it adds up quickly."
Richard Finn, manager of public relations for the Goodwill Games, said that ticket prices were equal to those of most major sporting events in the New York metropolitan area. He said the games had sought to encourage family attendance by offering $5 tickets for children under 12. However, a ticket seller for Ticketmaster said today that he was unaware of the special $5 tickets.
Officials said they had initially projected the sale of 600,000 tickets for the games, but then reduced the estimate to 492,000. As of July 28, they said, 237,000 had been sold to the public, 20,000 given to sponsors and 80,000 distributed to charitable institutions.
Ted Turner, the founder of the games and vice chairman of Time Warner, the chief sponsor, recently stated that losses from the three previous Goodwill Games totaled $100 million.
The games get revenue from a variety of sources. The TBS Superstation, which is owned by Time Warner, is providing 45 hours of live prime time coverage. In addition, CBS has been scheduling 10 hours of coverage on weekends and HBO has been airing live coverage of boxing events.
Michael E. Lewellen, chief spokesman for the games, said this year's operating costs for the games were expected to be between $90 million and $100 million. He said it was too early to tell what this year's loss would be, but he said the games have already been a success for the children's charities that were promised contributions.
"We never expected to make a profit," Mr. Lewellen said. "We've met our goal of at least a million dollars each for UNICEF and the Boys and Girls Club of America, and we find ourselves in the best possible position yet of any of the games."
Michael Hollander, president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau, said, "As I see it, success is seeing Long Island every day on the Turner channel as the backdrop for the Goodwill Games."
Fred Parola, the Nassau County Comptroller, said the games were expected to add $2.5 million to the county's predicted sales tax revenues of $748 million for this year. "And if we hit that mark, it will be a welcome plus," he said.
Mr. Finn, meanwhile, cautioned against viewing the world from the window of a delicatessen or a single year's tax receipts.
"I don't think the impact of the games should be limited to just how much is pumped into the local economy and bars and restaurants," he said. "The fact is officials from around the world have seen Long Island and the great facilities here, and that should enable aggressive bidding for future national and international swim meets and track events. That's the legacy that will be left over by the games."

HEADLINE: Clinton Vows 'Complete and Truthful' Testimony

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER and DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
President Clinton declared today that he would testify "completely and truthfully" in the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation on Aug. 17 but said that until then he would have no public comment on the matter.
The President's brief remarks on the subject that has consumed Washington for the past week came as F.B.I. crime laboratory technicians began examining a navy blue cocktail dress that Ms. Lewinsky gave prosecutors on Wednesday. Lawyers say she told prosecutors that the dress contains a stain that could provide evidence of a sexual encounter with the President. 
 The President's testimony will be transmitted live to grand jurors on closed-circuit television, said a person with knowledge of the agreement. The arrangement met a central condition that Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, set in exchange for withdrawing a July 17 subpoena to compel the President's testimony.
Also today, Mr. Starr announced that he was taking an indefinite unpaid leave of absence from the Chicago law firm of Kirkland & Ellis to complete his investigation. Mr. Starr, a former solicitor general and Federal judge, had come under criticism for making nearly $1 million a year from the firm to represent such clients as the General Motors Corporation at the same time he is conducting a publicly funded investigation of the President.
Mr. Clinton, responding to a cacophony of shouted questions about the Lewinsky matter at a Rose Garden appearance today, held up both hands and said, "Wait, wait, wait, wait."
Mr. Clinton has said nothing since Ms. Lewinsky reached a deal with prosecutors on Tuesday giving her immunity from prosecution in exchange for testimony about her relationship with the President.
"Everybody's got a question," the President said, smiling, after delivering a statement on the domestic economy and before departing for the Hamptons for a weekend of fund-raising and socializing. "Well, let me give you the answer to all of them."
He continued, "No one wants to get this matter behind us more than I do, except maybe all the rest of the American people. I am looking forward to the opportunity, in the next few days, of testifying. I will do so completely and truthfully. I am anxious to do it."
However, he added, "I hope you can understand why in the interim I can and should have no further comment on these matters. Thank you very much."
Mr. Clinton's personal lawyer, David E. Kendall, announced on Wednesday that he would provide testimony for grand jurors on Aug. 17, after months of resisting Mr. Starr's requests that he answer questions on the Lewinsky matter.
The President's lawyers and advisers had been deeply split over whether Mr. Clinton should subject himself to the risk of answering grand jury questions in an inquiry in which he is the potential target. But all agreed that Mr. Clinton should not speak publicly about the matter before giving his testimony, senior White House officials said.
Ms. Lewinsky spent much of the day with prosecutors from the independent counsel's office, who are continuing to prepare for her appearance before the grand jury. She is expected to meet with prosecutors over the weekend as well. No date has been set for her questioning.
Mr. Clinton's lawyers will spend the next two weeks assessing Mr. Starr's case against the President and trying to anticipate questions that Mr. Clinton might face. While Mr. Clinton plans to maintain an ordinary schedule of official activities over the next two weeks, he has set aside the entire weekend before the testimony for preparation.
The F.B.I. had not completed its initial examination of Ms. Lewinsky's dress by day's end, Angela D. Bell, a bureau spokeswoman, said. She said a determination of whether there was a stain containing semen or any other identifiable material would not be made until Monday at the earliest. And she said the information would be given to the independent counsel's office and not disclosed publicly.
If there is a semen stain, it would take "several weeks" to identify or eliminate any individual as the source, Ms. Bell said, although some experts on DNA testing said the matching could be done in a matter of days.
White House officials would not comment on whether Mr. Clinton would voluntarily supply saliva or blood samples for DNA matching.
Mr. Starr issued a statement late today announcing that he would drop his private law practice to devote full time to the Presidential investigation. White House officials and others have harshly criticized Mr. Starr for continuing to represent private clients while overseeing the independent counsel's office.
"Since my appointment, my duties as independent counsel have been my top priority," Mr. Starr said. "I have said that I would fulfill my obligations to my private clients, and I have done so. At this critical stage of our work, I am taking an unpaid leave of absence from my law firm until I complete my public duties."
Thomas Yannucci, the firm's managing partner, said Mr. Starr was currently in "no position" to represent private clients.
Mr. Yannucci said the indefinite leave was granted at Mr. Starr's request, with the expectation that he would return to work full time after the investigation was completed.
Told that some Clinton allies were spreading the word that the firm had nudged Mr. Starr out, or at least was glad to see him go, Mr. Yannucci said, "I'm not surprised, but that's completely false."
On Capitol Hill, Senator John Ashcroft, a conservative Missouri Republican and a possible Presidential candidate in 2000, said he would conduct hearings during the August recess on legal and constitutional questions arising from the investigation. Mr. Ashcroft said he would explore whether the President was subject to ordinary criminal prosecution while in office, or must first be impeached and convicted by Congress.

HEADLINE: Big Aid Bill Likely for Farmers Hurt by Drought and Rain

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Though most highly productive farm regions seem to be on the way to bumper crops, the drought in Texas and Oklahoma and the excess rain in the Upper Midwest are now expected to require an emergency aid package topping $1 billion.
Earlier this month, the Senate approved $500 million in disaster aid, about half of which would probably go to the Dakotas and Minnesota. With the drought growing worse in Texas, Oklahoma and parts of the Southeast, Congress is expected to increase the assistance before adjourning in October. 
 But on Thursday, Representative Larry Combest, Republican of Texas, said: "I think we're talking about substantially more. We're looking at at least twice that number and maybe more."
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman told the House Agriculture Committee that the Agriculture Department would soon revise its estimate of the costs in the affected areas. Mr. Glickman said revision would come after the release of the Aug. 12 crop production figures, which rely on actual field surveys of crops to be harvested in the fall.
A Texas A&M University study has estimated more than $1.4 billion in direct losses to farmers because of the drought and $4.6 billion in overall economic loss. In Oklahoma, officials say the disaster could cost $2 billion in total losses.
That comes on top of repeated disasters in the Upper Midwest, where wet weather has spawned a wheat disease that has destroyed crops for several years in a row. In North Dakota, Mr. Glickman said farm income fell 92 percent in 1997 compared with the year before.
The House is expected to vote next week on a measure to permit farmers to receive on Oct. 1 all or part of $5.5 billion in transition payments. That money, which was scheduled to be paid next year, is intended to wean farmers from the subsidy system that was done away with in 1996 with passage of a farm law backed by Republicans. The Senate is expected to follow suit, and Mr. Glickman said the Administration supported the move.
Aside from the weather disasters, Mr. Glickman said the overall farm economy was in a tailspin that would cut income by $7.5 billion this year. Prices for corn, wheat, soybeans and other commodities are off sharply because exports have decreased because of the Asian financial crisis and huge crops have been produced worldwide.
Projected fall harvests here are again expected to be huge and farmers are taking on more debt, he said.
He said many producers will withstand the downturn because of the strong markets of the early 1990's and because production expenses actually dropped $1 billion this year because of low inflation, low interest rates and low oil prices.
In addition, unless weather patterns change markedly over the next few weeks, there will be big crops through the Corn Belt and other areas, bringing higher yields per acre that will soften the blow of lower prices.

HEADLINE: Eating Up the Summer;
With Tables Full, Restaurants Skip Traditional Break

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Just a few years ago -- or once upon a time, as the trend flies -- the high-end restaurants of Manhattan wouldn't have considered staying open all summer long.
As soon as their regular customers began to break a sweat, Le Bernardin, Lutece and their comrades in gastronomic tradition would begin to close their doors so their chefs and staffs could return to Europe for a month or so of recuperation on their native soil. After all, they knew that come September, everybody would return tanned and refreshed, kiss-kiss hello and live happily ever after. 
 But that was once upon a time. Now there is a new generation of restaurants, a new generation of chefs and an economically booming, improbably safe and increasingly clean New York City. In this hypercompetitive foodie climate, summer breaks -- "les vacances," as they are known in the trade -- have become a luxury only the most historically correct few feel they can afford.
For 17 years, when his restaurant was simply Le Cirque, Sirio Maccioni recalls, he would close in July.
"The important and rich people left after the last week in June, and the kind of tourists who came to New York had no interest in what we offered," he said. He smiled. Now his restaurant has been reinvented as Le Cirque 2000 and reopened in grand new premises in the New York Palace Hotel on Madison Avenue, and, he said: "We are open and we are very busy. New Yorkers may go away for a week, but they have to come back for business."
In fact, this summer, a lot of New Yorkers are making so much money that they cannot even think about going away for more than weekends at the beach or in the Berkshires. And they are jousting for tables with swarms of tourists bursting forth from overbooked hotels, armed with their strong currencies and their reviews printed from Web sites.
"Visitors from all over the world are now coming to New York with a list," said Daniel Boulud, chef and owner of Restaurant Daniel. "They absolutely must go to their favorites."
The result, said Diane Forley, executive chef at the restaurant Verbena, on Irving Place, is that "summer now is actually the height of our season."
If New York's top chefs are busier than ever this summer, though, it is not simply because their restaurants are mobbed. After all, what self-respecting chef is just a chef nowadays?
These entrepreneurs are building new restaurants, writing books, starring in television shows, opening cooking schools. They may be getting away, but it is generally for a day here and there. A working vacation. A vocational experience. A lecture turn. And of course, a book-signing or three.
"It would be crazy not to be open while the business is here," said Drew Nieporent, whose Montrachet, Nobu and TriBeCa Grill are booming and who is juggling the construction of three new restaurants (Nobu Next Door, Nobu in San Francisco and the new restaurant in the W New York hotel that replaced the Doral Inn).
Of course, a lot of less-fabulous restaurants never stopped for a long summer stretch in the first place. At the other end of the spectrum are the ever-fewer luxe places where the old ways are honored even now.
La Grenouille, on East 52d Street, closed last Saturday and more than 20 staff members returned to their native village, Gourin, in Brittany. The restaurant will not reopen until after Labor Day.
"We have always done this," explained Philippe Masson, the manager. "We work very hard in a difficult business, and if our employees did not take some real time off to refresh themselves, they would just run themselves down."
But La Cote Basque, the grande dame on West 55th Street, isn't closing at all this summer. Neither is Le Bernardin, that palace of poisson. Aureole used to close for three weeks during the summer. Not this year. The classic La Caravelle, accustomed to an August vacation, will be closed only Mondays and Sundays, and Lutece will close only Mondays.
"It is true that at the end of June some of the regular customers say, 'See you in September,' " said the restaurateur David Bouley, "but now they are being replaced by a strong international client base" at the 40-seat dining space in his Bouley Bakery in TriBeCa.
Mr. Maccioni agreed. "European people are telling you now that they like to come to New York just to eat -- and they never said that 20 years ago," he said. "The whole level has gone up, yet the price in New York is a bargain. In France the food in a great restaurant will cost $150 alone."
This state of affairs has produced a certain warm-weather inversion of the usual weekday-weekend rhythm. On weekends -- when everyone is rushing to get away to make up for the vacations they are not taking -- there are often good tables to be had. But weekdays can be as jammed as a Saturday night in winter.
"I'm going to be working here most of the summer," said John Raphael, a money manager for a Swiss company. He was making the best of his imprisonment the other day at Jean Georges, overlooking the beige umbrellas of the outdoor terrace on Central Park West and savoring slow-baked salmon in a tarragon-and-caper sabayon sauce.
"My friends and family members are taking shorter vacations," he added. "And with working couples, when one partner can get away, the other can't."
Not that all of the summer-stranded seem to mind terribly much. "All the psychiatrists are gone and the people talk to each other, so New York in the summer is delightful," said the actor Ron Silver, tucking into the braised veal kidneys at Le Cirque 2000. "Everyone seems to be around -- the place is mobbed."
There is competition for more than customers this summer. "If you close for a few weeks these days, you'll lose your wait staff," said Vincent Scotto, the chef who opened Fresco and presided over the kitchen there for four years. But instead of losing his staff this summer, Mr. Scotto is actually hiring one: preparing to open Scopa, a new restaurant celebrating upscale pasta and pizza.
This summer some restaurants are closing for nontraditional reasons. For the first time, Mr. Boulud is shuttering Daniel, for seven weeks.
But instead of taking a vacation, he is moving Daniel to East 65th Street, in the space formerly occupied by Le Cirque. At the same time, in the old space on East 76th Street, he is building the new Cafe Boulud. There, he and his sous chefs "will turn the restaurant into a cooking studio, as we train on the new menu and use the space to create a Cafe Boulud cookbook," he said.
Other restaurateurs who are definitely not taking a long break include the 64-year-old Mr. Maccioni, who is opening two restaurants at the Bellagio Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., Le Cirque and Osteria del Circo. Similarly, the 43-year-old Mr. Nieporent said he would be "taking working vacations on Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket," where, of course, he has restaurants.
Since Butterfield 81 opened so recently to strong reviews in May, Tom Valenti, the 39-year-old executive chef, will be lucky to be able to take a day here or there at his house in upstate New York, near the Beaverkill River, one of the nation's great trout streams.
"I enjoy the meditative quality of it," he said of the angling. "It's so focused, and so quiet. You know -- the antithesis of a kitchen."
But these days it is the quest for the perfect wave that fills the soul of John Schenk, who opened the Monkey Bar and is now, at 43, the chef at Clementine. In July he has been so busy that he has been working the line six nights a week, visiting his summer rental in Napeague, near Montauk, when he can.
"This summer, it's surf or die," he said. "In surfing you get knocked down more than you stay up, just like cooking. The idea is to keep getting back up."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The kitchen is still bustling at Jean Georges on Central Park West in Manhattan. The booming economy has prompted many high-end restaurants to give up their annual vacations. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICAL BRIEFING;
Gay Issues a Problem For Illinois Democrat

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Almost from the moment he won the Democratic nomination in this year's race for governor in Illinois, Representative Glenn Poshard, a downstate moderate, has been under pressure to move to the left on issues like gun control, abortion and gay rights. If he does not, party leaders say, he may not run well in the more liberal Chicago area to the north, which is where Illinois Democrats seeking statewide office tend to win or lose elections.
Worse, the party leaders warn, if Mr. Poshard remains fixed in the ideological middle -- his social conservatism is balanced by economic liberalism -- he risks the loss of some of his Democratic base to his Republican opponent, Secretary of State George H. Ryan. Mr. Ryan, also a moderate, supports gun controls and recently participated prominently in a gay-pride parade. 
 Mr. Poshard, who in the past has opposed same-sex marriage and expansion of anti-discrimination laws to protect homosexuals, skipped the parade, a decision roundly criticized by the relatively large and politically powerful Illinois gay community. State Representative Larry McKeon, the only openly gay member of the Illinois legislature, announced that he would not join other Democrats in endorsing Mr. Poshard -- just the kind of defection party leaders feared.
Now, with polls showing Mr. Ryan out front in the race by better than five points, Mr. Poshard seems to be moving toward repairing some of his fences on the left. His campaign manager, Josh Silverman, says Mr. Poshard plans to "open a dialogue" over the next few days with leaders of gay groups. Further, he has been discussing possible campaign strategies with Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, who, as the first openly homosexual member of Congress, is probably the most powerful gay politician in the country.
"I told him that one early way to begin repairing the damage," Mr. Frank said, "would be to vote in favor of bills now before Congress that would extend and strengthen gay rights."
Gay leaders are skeptical that Mr. Poshard will moderate his views on the issue. But Rick Garcia, a gay Democrat who is the political director of the Illinois Federation for Human Rights, said the Congressman would deserve "high marks" should he open a meaningful dialogue.

HEADLINE: Everybody's Colony

BYLINE: By Frank Gibney; Frank Gibney is president of the Pacific Basin Institute at Pomona College. His most recent book on East Asian subjects is "Unlocking the Bureaucrats' Kingdom."

 BODY:

DUSK
 By F. Sionil Jose.
 323 pp. New York:
 The Modern Library. Paper, $12.95. 
 JUST over a century ago, on June 12, 1898, at the bayside town of Cavite, a freshly minted generalissimo named Emilio Aguinaldo, then 29 years old, proclaimed the independence of the Philippines from three centuries of colonial rule by Spain. The month before, Rear Adm. George Dewey's squadron had destroyed the antiquated Spanish fleet in the Battle of Manila Bay. Aguinaldo's nationalist soldiers were already besieging the Spanish troops inside Manila in the climax of a three-year rebellion. After a visit from the rebels aboard his flagship, Dewey assured them that they could expect firm support from "the cradle of genuine liberty," the United States.
What ensued was something that no one could have foreseen -- not Dewey, who was anxious to go home to celebrate his victory, or Aguinaldo, now optimistically planning his new Government, or, least of all, President William McKinley, the small-town politician in the White House who had recently had trouble finding the Philippines on a map. After weeks of vacillating between the choices of alliance, protectorate and outright annexation, McKinley announced proudly that a prayerful night had given him God's approval for annexation of the Philippines. Inevitably, United States ground troops were mobilized in support of McKinley's deity.
America's first stumble into colonialism resulted in four years of grinding warfare with the disappointed revolutionaries before Aguinaldo's countrymen could be considered "subdued." The cost was a body count of 20,000 Philippine "insurrectionists," along with some 10,000 American soldiers killed, wounded or dead from disease. Over all, probably 200,000 Philippine civilians perished from famine, exposure and atrocities perpetrated by both sides.
For all its bad and brutal beginnings, American colonial tutelage had its good points. The "sentimental imperialists," as the historian Peter Stanley has aptly called them, brought with them education, health and public works programs. Guarantees of independence followed, climaxed by liberation from the Japanese in World War II. Rule from Washington also implanted in the Philippines a hopeless fascination with American mass culture, which came to cohabit with Spanish Catholicism, upper-crust elitism and Malay-Hispanic mores. As the old Philippine adage has it, revised after the recent two decades of brutal and venal dictatorship by Ferdinand Marcos and his wife, Imelda: "Three hundred years in a Spanish convent, 50 years of Hollywood and 20 years of 'his and hers.' "
So much for the outside view of the Philippines. In the novel "Dusk," F. Sionil Jose, a colorful author, editor, bookstore proprietor and all-round interpreter of modern Philippine culture, presents us with a belated education in how Filipinos view themselves. It is the last of his five-novel Rosales series -- best sellers in the Philippines -- but the first chronologically. Spanning roughly the past century, these books set out to tell the same kind of story that John Dos Passos told for Americans in "U.S.A."
Jose's work, however, is determinedly microhistory, played out on a small screen. Rosales, the town in central Luzon where the author grew up, is the center of the series. "Dusk," as Jose explains in his introduction, "is simply the story of a family, or rather of a peace-loving man who led his clan in its flight from the narrow coastal plain of the Ilocos in northern Luzon to the central plains. It is also a story of Spanish tyranny, and the Philippine response to it and to the American intrusion into our islands after the Spaniards left." He continues: "All too often, our history is adorned with heroes of high station; there is nothing written about the common people, the foot soldiers who die in the hundreds so that their generals may live."
The appeal of Jose's story lies in its simplicity. Forced off its land by the all-powerful Spanish administration, the family of Istak Samson loads its meager belongings in several carts and pushes its way into decent farmland and a new home. Istak finds himself a beautiful and compassionate wife and gains a reputation as a local healer, fortified by the literary Spanish and Latin taught him by his old priest-teacher, Father Jose.
Their journey is the book's subject, and it is told with such sympathy that the reader inescapably joins them. It ends sadly. After successfully evading the Spanish Guardia Civil, Istak reluctantly joins the revolutionaries and dies at the hands of American troops, on his way to deliver a message to Aguinaldo. The idyll is over. Istak's struggle to provide for his family is to be subsumed in a larger conflict.
Faithful to his own background, Jose has etched a black-and-white picture of poor farming families whose native courage and emerging sense of nationalism were ironically stiffened by the centuries-old faith given them by their Spanish oppressors. (Equally ironic was McKinley's announced motive for annexation: "To educate the Filipinos and to uplift and Christianize them," despite the fact that the people of the Philippines had been Christian a century or two before McKinley's Methodists got the idea.) The first martyrs to Philippine independence were native Filipino priests, executed by the Spanish administration.
The prophet of Philippine independence, Jose Rizal, executed by Spain in 1896, wanted only to provide his countrymen with a voice in Madrid's administration (taxation without representation, Americans might call it). Apolinario Mabini, the theoretician of the independence movement, borrowed heavily from the Enlightenment and the United States Constitution. He appears as a central character in Jose's novel, and his ideals give purpose to Istak's sacrificial death.
The story of Istak's difficult journey with his small clan from the Ilocos south to the coastal plain offers us an idea of the multitude of different peoples, speaking their own languages, who make up the modern Philippine nation. It was the late-19th-century struggle for independence that gave them a new sense of unity, as they fought against two kinds of imperialism. All too often, as the novel suggests, the bureaucrats and rich landowners -- the so-called illustrados -- were co-opted either by the Spanish or the later American occupiers. Even now, the gulf between rich and poor yawns wide and deep. Yet the sense of a native Philippine democracy has put down strong roots.
Despite the enormous amount of attention to multiculturalism in recent years, Filipinos have not received much notice. This is a pity. For their blend of European, American and Asian traditions, with all their inner conflicts, is about as close as one can come in East Asia to some kind of cultural fusion. Reading a book like Jose's in the centenary year of Philippine independence is good medicine -- for Americans, who may come to acknowledge the strong, persistent culture of a people once dismissed by William Howard Taft as "little brown brothers," and for the Filipinos themselves, who may learn that by going past the flamboyant politics of Manila's upper-crust establishment to give Istak's still neglected peasant people a fair deal would do much toward providing their country with the economy and polity that its old culture deserves.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 29; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 677 words

HEADLINE: Our Crowd

BYLINE: By Anthony Gottlieb; Anthony Gottlieb, the executive editor of The Economist, is the author of "Socrates: Philosophy's Martyr."

 BODY:

FROM PLATO
 TO NATO
 The Idea of the West
 and Its Opponents.
 By David Gress.
 610 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $28. 
 Where is the West? Even if the question is confined to America, the answer is not easy. Practically all parts of the United States except for those with their toes in the Atlantic have been included in "the West" at some stage. Zoom out for a global view and the question becomes almost nonsensical. The Western world includes a Japan-sized chunk of the Far East, among other anomalies. Global positioning satellites may nowadays guide your BMW home, but the West remains elusive. One achievement of "From Plato to NATO," by David Gress, a fellow of the Danish Institute of International Affairs, is to demonstrate that history can be as misleading as geography in finding it.
The story of the West used to be told as if it were a simple one. What Gress calls "the Grand Narrative" described "a synthesis of democracy, capitalism, science, human rights, religious pluralism, individual autonomy and the power of unfettered human reason" whose progress could be traced from its beginnings in Athens in the fourth century B.C. to its climax in 20th-century America. This narrative held sway in American higher education from around the 1920's to the mid-1960's.
Much of Gress's book is a retelling of that story, with the rough edges restored. On closer examination, the moral values of the ancient Greeks, for example, turn out to be rather more foreign to current ideas than some would have us believe. Hector's pride, for instance, is not easy to reconcile with what are taken to be Western ideals of virtue. Gress's account of the evolution of the idea of the West also has room for crucial elements that were often neglected, like the individualism and nationalism that the Germanic tribes -- formerly cast merely as invading barbarians -- brought to the feast of the Roman Empire.
As a historian, Gress is understandably more interested in historiography than some of his readers will be. Although the changing attitudes of German scholars toward Greece is indeed central to his story of how our concept of the West was formed, there will be those who want more history of the world and less history of history. It would be a pity if his sometimes tortuous historiographical arguments and difficult logic put off readers who will find here, if they persevere, an excellent account of Europe's complex civilization and its ideals.
Gress certainly believes that there is such a thing as a distinctively Western civilization. This comes out most clearly when he seeks to defend it against its recent opponents -- the post-modernists, ex-Marxists, muddled environmentalists and would-be communitarians who claim that 19th-century liberalism has conspicuously failed, that Enlightenment ideals are bankrupt and that Western technology is destroying the planet. These opponents of the values trumpeted by the Grand Narrative (who have been steadily growing in influence) are the targets of Gress's most vigorous and withering criticism.
He argues that the losses recently suffered by core Western values on the intellectual battlefield are partly the result of bad history. If we had a better idea of the roots of Western civilization, a more nuanced picture than the Grand Narrative provides, we could do a better job of defending it. Be that as it may, it would be hard to improve on the trenchant reasoning of Gress's penultimate chapter, where he lands resounding blows on the paradox of cultural subjectivism -- according to which all value systems are equally valuable, except the West's, which somehow manages to be objectively awful.
Among Gress's other well-found targets in this chapter are the confused post-modernism of Vaclav Havel, the meandering environmentalism of Al Gore and the briefly fashionable nostrum of "Asian values" -- of which one has heard little since last summer. Gress's defense here of rationality, science, technology and liberalism is, on its own, worth the price of the book.

HEADLINE: Lucky Cedric

BYLINE: By Sara Mosle; Sara Mosle is an editor at the Book Review.

 BODY:

A HOPE IN THE UNSEEN
 An American Odyssey From
 the Inner City to the Ivy League.
 By Ron Suskind.
 372 pp. New York:
 Broadway Books. $25. 
 EDUCATORS, reporters and more than a few Hollywood screenwriters have been telling, and retelling, the same story about American education for nearly half a century. Its elements -- in books like "Up the Down Staircase,"
"36 Children," "Death at an Early Age," "The Way It Spozed to Be," "Lives on the Boundary," "Small Victories," "Will My Name Be Shouted Out?" and, most recently, "On the Outside Looking In" -- are so familiar they've become cliches. Liberal teacher or reporter ventures into ghetto school, meets students resembling the sweathogs -- the charmingly delinquent, ethnically diverse, underachieving teen-agers depicted in the 1970's sitcom "Welcome Back, Kotter" -- and witnesses inspirational scenes of learning.
That this story bears repeating is a testament to how little the prospects of the nation's most impoverished students have changed since Brown v. Board of Education. But it's also indicative of the narrowness of the debate about education as a whole. To judge from these books, one would think that most classrooms are in terrible urban neighborhoods, when in fact a majority of American students -- including a majority of black students -- now live outside the city, where they attend public schools that their parents, at least according to polls, regard as good. Indeed, after reading Ron Suskind's extraordinary, formula-shattering book about Cedric Jennings, a poor black teen-ager at a blighted Washington high school who strives to attend the Ivy Leagues, one can't help concluding that we are no longer one country divided between black and white, but two nations even among blacks: the first increasingly middle-class and suburban, the second poor and disastrously isolated in our ghettos.
Almost everything about "A Hope in the Unseen" goes against type. Most books of its kind have the air of a travelogue; typically told in the first person, they are usually as much about the journey of the writer as they are about the students' experiences. By becoming a part of the narrative, the author -- who is almost invariably white -- operates as a kind of proxy for the race and class biases of the reader. Suskind, by contrast, is completely absent from his story. In a subversive twist on the genre, he allows Cedric to appeal directly to middle-class notions of merit. A nerdy, driven youth, whose grade-grubbing intensity would almost certainly annoy a laid-back teacher like Kotter, he is the very antithesis of a sweathog and is no different in his goals from many upper-class students in Greenwich, Conn.
Yet in the topsy-turvy world of the ghetto, his ambition exacts enormous costs. His single mother briefly goes on welfare to provide her son with the intellectual stimulation he needs before entering kindergarten. Even her steady Federal job can't keep the eviction notices at bay. Many nights Cedric must study without benefit of food, heat or electricity. Far from applauding these efforts, his father, a convicted drug dealer who spends most of the book in jail, thinks of his son as "a straight-A momma's boy who gets no respect from any of the kids."
In this sense, "A Hope in the Unseen" has more in common with memoirs of black aspiration such as Brent Staples's "Parallel Time" than with most of the literature of urban schooling. Although most education writers show greater sympathy for those left behind than for those who make it, Suskind suggests a far more troubling thesis: that at a ghetto school like Frank W. Ballou Senior High, a smart kid like Cedric may have it worse.
Cries of "nerdboy," "whitey" and "geek" rain down on him in the hallways. Gang members steal his books, mess with his hair and beat him up between classes. After one awards assembly, a student accosts him with a gun. Terrified, Cedric flees to the bathroom, but fails to report the incident for fear of retaliation. With the exception of a chemistry teacher who takes Cedric under his wing, adults at the school are hardly more encouraging. When a girl taunts him with sexual gibes, it's Cedric who gets ejected from the classroom; the principal describes him as "too proud" for his own good. Teachers seem to resent his brash and boastful intellectualism. Real self-esteem -- as opposed to the kind taught in courses -- is frowned on. Even Cedric's sole friend at Ballou, an obese girl who is as much a pariah as he is, scoffs at his dreams of attending an Ivy League school. "What kind of fool spends his life trying to go somewhere he ain't even seen?"
It's Cedric's profound belief "in the unseen" that sustains him. He and his mother are fervent members of a black Pentecostal church -- although even here the bishop warns him against trusting too much in his own abilities instead of in God. Nonetheless, mother and son pin their hopes on a summer school program for minority-group students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology before Cedric's senior year. At first, he is thrilled to be among other smart black teen-agers and is amazed to discover that he, the "king of the Ballou nerds," has suddenly attained an "imprimatur of coolness" because of his ghetto background. Academically, however, he suffers a similar reversal. Although the top student at Ballou, he soon learns that his similarity to the "suburb-bred minority kids" who constitute most of the program is only skin deep. As the director concedes, "It would take two years of tutoring, not six weeks, to bring some of the inner cities' brightest up to a level where they might be accepted to M.I.T." Cedric returns to Ballou in despair.
Most "year in the life" books would end here, but Suskind relates all of the above in a stunningly economical 100 pages. Cedric remains almost irrationally determined to attend a brand-name school -- despite a combined S.A.T. score of just 960 (some 400 points below the average at most Ivy League schools). On a whim, he applies to Brown University for early acceptance and miraculously gets in. When Cedric and his mother arrive on campus, they spot "a tall, thin Caucasian girl with . . . a row of earrings and a shaved head." "Isn't that awful," his mother murmurs. "Must be chemotherapy." Cedric nods sympathetically. It's a comic moment of cultural confusion -- indicative of the greater academic and social disorientation he will initially suffer.
A trip through the bookstore leaves him dizzy with apprehension. Authors and subjects like Plath, Hemingway, Theodore Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson sound only "vaguely familiar" or "draw a blank." He spots a biography of Winston Churchill. "Oh, God," he thinks, "I should know who he is," and tries to commit the name to memory. The point isn't that Cedric needs more rote learning, as "cultural literacy" is often misunderstood. Rather, he has no context in which to incorporate new information. In class, there are so many "references he doesn't understand -- he often feels like a foreigner." His failure is not a matter of effort or ability; he has simply never been exposed to much of the material.
Similarly, when assigned a research paper in his education course, he panics and turns in "an epic poem" about his own schooling; it's the kind of self-expressive exercise that typically invites raves from inner-city teachers. But Cedric's professor is not so patronizing. Although he praises Cedric's creativity, he insists that he master the analytical skills that he'll need to escape the ghetto. When Cedric aces a calculus midterm, his success is all the more sweet for being genuine.
Suskind underscores the crudeness of many discussions of diversity and identity without ever minimizing Cedric's very real struggles. College, Suskind rightly sees, is a time of experimentation and growth for just about everyone. The fierce antagonism that develops, for instance, between Cedric and Rob, his affluent white roommate, has as much to do with personal differences -- in music tastes (Cedric likes gospel and hip-hop; Rob, heavy metal), morals (Cedric avoids dating, dancing and drinking; Rob does all three) and style (Cedric is maniacally neat; Rob is a slob) -- as with weightier issues of intolerance.
Suskind also perceives the range among blacks at Brown. Many of Cedric's African-American classmates have spent years interacting with whites as some of the few minority-group students in prestigious private academies or in the tracked programs at top suburban schools. They yearn for black companionship and gravitate toward the black dorm, which serves as a cultural center. Cedric, by contrast, has spent his whole life among blacks and is more curious to mingle with whites. A subtler anxiety, however, underlies his attitude. "He was unnerved," Suskind writes, "by the brew of black coolness and youthful achievement" at Brown -- "a casual blend that almost mocks the brutal adolescent trade-offs he had to make to get here. He had dealt with this crowd somewhat at M.I.T., black kids . . . with bright futures who are as anxious to co-opt inner-city coolness as the white kids in the unit. The difference is that the black middle-class kids can really pull it off."
For many students like Cedric, the notion that anyone who works hard enough can escape the ghetto through education is an empty promise. The vast majority of Cedric's classmates at Ballou who do graduate either can't afford college or are so overwhelmed once they arrive that they drop out by the end of their freshman years. And what Cedric's success finally means, the reader can never know. For, in a mystifying decision, Suskind has chosen to write his book entirely from the point of view of a dozen people, much of it in internal monologues. Besides robbing his subjects of their voices and him of the opportunity to provide some badly needed background -- on affirmative action, the rise of Pentecostal churches or even the Jennings family finances (which the reader must piece together from scattered asides) -- the approach finally prevents him from ever accounting for his own impact on Cedric's life.
"A Hope in the Unseen" arose from a two-part series that Suskind wrote for The Wall Street Journal and that went on to win a Pulitzer Prize; the newspaper stories appeared before Cedric was accepted to Brown and attracted widespread attention. But the reader doesn't learn, until nearly halfway through the book, that a "Dr. Korb" happened to "read about Cedric" and began paying "for periodic tutoring and incidentals." Did his help improve Cedric's chances? Is it possible that Brown's admission officers read The Journal, too? And did it influence their decision to let him in?
Because Suskind can never break out of his internal monologues, he can't tell us. No one reading this book will doubt that Cedric deserves to go to Brown; if anything, his monumental efforts put to shame arguments against affirmative action. But one begins to fear that his ostensibly inspirational story may be more depressing than we know. For all Cedric's superhuman drive, it may be that the most crucial factor in his eventual success was dumb luck: that in 1994, a reporter named Ron Suskind took an interest in his story.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1573 words

HEADLINE: America's Paint and Body Shop

BYLINE: By Liesl Schillinger; Liesl Schillinger writes about American culture for The London Independent on Sunday and is on staff at The New Yorker.

 BODY:

HOPE IN A JAR
 The Making of
 America's Beauty Culture.
 By Kathy Peiss.
 Illustrated. 334 pp. New York:
 Metropolitan Books/
 Henry Holt & Company. $25.
 
 VENUS ENVY
 A History of Cosmetic Surgery.
 By Elizabeth Haiken.
 Illustrated. 370 pp. Baltimore:
 The Johns Hopkins University Press. $24.95. 
 What do women want to look like? Beautiful, youthful, desirable, unattainable. What will they do to get that way? More than 150 years ago, they dabbed their faces with the urine of little boys or rubbed their arms with lead-laced whitening solutions that sometimes killed them. Ninety years ago, they smoothed their wrinkles with paraffin injections, something that produced an unsexy side effect called "wax cancers." Some of them enlarged their breasts with paraffin; more recently, they went in for silicone implants, whose occasional leakage left some of them with far graver beauty defects than a flat chest. Although women once staunchly denied using even rouge, by the mid-1930's Vogue had declared the act of putting on lipstick one of the "gestures of the 20th century"; today, respectable suburban wives and daughters routinely resort to everything from nose jobs and face lifts to liposuction and rib removal, and no one raises a tweezed eyebrow.
Jonathan Swift once sourly imagined a painted Jezebel preparing for bed who
Seated on a three-legg'd Chair
Takes off her artificial Hair. . . .
Untwists a Wire; and from her Gums
A Set of Teeth completely comes.
But even Swift could not have foreseen the bone-crunching practices to which women -- and men -- willingly submit. When surgeons can turn men into women, women into feral apparitions from the isle of Dr. Moreau, and Michael Jackson into Diana Ross, the limits to which people will go in the name of beauty may exist, but it's hard to think what those limits might be.
Two excellent new books trace the evolution of self-image and beauty practices in this country. In "Hope in a Jar: The Making of America's Beauty Culture," Kathy Peiss looks at the subject from the outside in. In "Venus Envy: A History of Cosmetic Surgery," Elizabeth Haiken looks at the same subject from the inside out. Peiss's study, intrinsically more lighthearted, follows women as they move from the farm and drawing room to the mall and the boardroom. A professor of history at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst, she documents their progress with a collection of quaint and deftly chosen vintage advertisements that show that while beauty ideals may change drastically, women's desire to embody them remains constant. In a Victorian illustration from 1881, mustachioed gents throng a bare-shouldered socialite, who leans forward alluringly, a cloud of frills cascading from her cinched-in waist. A young bystander wonders out loud: "Who is that lovely young creature on whom all the heavy swells in the room are dancing attendance?" An older man replies, "That lady is old enough to be your mother! . . . The wondrous preservation of her youth and beauty is due to that most extraordinary preparation: Laird's Bloom of Youth."
Some 60 years later, plump white arms were out, tawny fitness was in, and the world was at war. Ad men switched models and beauty products but relied on the same tactics, encouraging women to imitate the new svelte belle ideale with ads that showed a Venus in a work shirt, pausing mid-rivet to apply Tangee lipstick to her flawless mouth and to remind other war-effort women to do their bit "and a Little Bit More." Peiss acknowledges the popular view of make-up's detractors that "the act of beautifying, though it seems enticing and freely chosen, is really compulsory work, so narcissistic, time-consuming and absorbing as to limit women's achievements," but she does not share it.
Instead, she prefers to accentuate the positive, relating the sagas of such female groundbreakers as Annie Turnbo Malone and Madam C. J. Walker, two black women who turned home recipes for hair growing tonic into nationwide businesses; Elizabeth Arden and Helena Rubinstein, the rival immigrant glamour mavens who built cosmetic and salon empires and referred to each other spitefully as "that woman." At a time when nearly all businesses were run by men, these women and others turned femininity to advantage, identified a new market and successfully exploited it. Peiss gloats, "Women have used makeup . . . to announce their adult status, sexual allure, youthful spirit, political beliefs and even to proclaim their right to self-definition." For her, the lipsticked mouth is a red badge of courage.
Haiken, an assistant professor of history at the University of Tennessee, shows why women need that courage in "Venus Envy." Whereas Peiss showcases Vaseline-lens beauties and urbane cartoons, Haiken has a darker story to tell and she illustrates it with, for example, a two-page 1937 photo essay of a woman undergoing a nose job. One photo shows "the hump . . . being withdrawn through the nostril by means of a pair of clamps."
Americans are discontented with their appearance, Haiken finds, and many of the men and women who seek surgery are actually chasing ethnic anonymity and conformity. In a probing chapter called "The Michael Jackson Factor," she presents black, Asian and Jewish women who seek WASP noses and Playboy breasts. They are caught in the vexed immigrants' dilemma of struggling not only to keep up with the Joneses but to look like them, too. Cosmetic surgery became respectable only during the First World War, she explains, after courageous surgeons went to the trenches in Europe and tried to give young men back the faces that had been blown off under their helmets, faces that no longer had teeth or jaws. As one surgeon observed: "We know from a considerable experience the patient wants to be left as nearly normal in appearance as possible. He will undergo untold hardships to be restored to the normal. This rule has no exceptions."
The notion that an intact, healthy man or woman would seek surgery to correct a feature that was merely unbecoming elicited disapproval and even disgust, and a proliferation of dangerous quacks also kept "beauty doctors" in check and generated horror stories of cosmetic catastrophes. But by the early 1920's, regulatory and advisory boards existed for plastic surgery.
At the same time Alfred Adler's theories of the "inferiority complex" grabbed the public's imagination. Adler argued that people were plagued by psychological problems growing from feelings of inferiority, and before long Americans decided that a poor self-image was reason enough to submit to the scalpel. For working women, who believed their livelihoods depended on their good looks, cosmetic surgery was defended as a necessity, not a luxury. Indeed, five years ago studies emerged showing that attractive people receive higher wages and easier advancement than unattractive people in any profession, however exalted or humble, and to true believers plastic surgery seems as sensible a career step as computer classes or an Ivy League education.
Women and men are lining up for plastic surgery in record numbers, but as everyone knows, women far outnumber men, because they believe that not only their economic success but their romantic fortunes hang on the face and body they present to the world. To most, even the penalties of pain and potential mishap or exposure to ridicule are a small price to pay for the chance to remain in the game for an extra decade.
It's fun to glide on the candy-slick sheen of an Orlane lipstick with its sugar taste, to change hair color with the seasons, to paint your nails silver, to delight in the metallic impact of stiletto heels on hollow pavement -- just as it was fun 60 years ago for daring women to buy Hussy lipstick instead of Lady. But nothing is fun when it is done out of compulsion or fear, even if that fear is only the fear of not seeming to have fun.
OF all the expectations that have been placed upon American women, perhaps none is as cruel as the supposedly liberated one that currently prevails: that any woman who isn't beautiful isn't trying, that women should look as good naked as they do clothed and that they should do so into their 60's if they intend to keep their men. It is a tyranny more unrelenting than the wasp waist; a corset, after all, can be unlaced in the dark. The ideal modern body, however, has to pass the broad-daylight test -- a standard that requires unstinting exercise, near starvation and surgical upkeep. Even if ever larger numbers of women now may succeed in looking like vixens well into what once would have been their dotages, it is no wonder that as early as 1939 commentators in The Ladies' Home Journal were announcing, "There has never been a time when so many women have been discontented with their appearance."
Peiss, for all her optimism, might well agree. Like the girl in the folk tale who was happy until a traveler gave her a mirror that showed her she was homely, many American women would be better off if they didn't examine themselves so closely. The problem is, the girl in the story had the sense to return the mirror. American women carry theirs wherever they go -- in every jewel-like compact of pressed powder, in every glittering case of rouge. How, being a woman, can you not want to look? And how, being an American, can you not want to look better?

Copyright 1998 The New York Times Company

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

BYLINE: By Paula Friedman

 BODY:

Never Let Me Down
 A Memoir.
 By Susan J. Miller.
 Holt, $22.50. 
 "Memory is a kind of accomplishment" -- or so Susan J. Miller quotes William Carlos Williams in the epigraph to her memoir about growing up with her jazz-loving, heroin-addicted father during the 1950's and 60's, the height of the Birdland years in New York. As a child, Miller was aware of her family's struggles with unemployment, poverty and rootlessness, yet she did not know -- until she was 21 years old, when her father confessed -- that the reason for these problems lay in his seven-year addiction to heroin. What makes "Never Let Me Down" so powerful is how Miller winds in and around her topic so that each pass through the family's early life is more revealing, while the emotional atmosphere gathers a ragged intensity. Miller's increased knowledge alters her grasp of the past, creating a sense of disorientation with which she struggled for years. Learning of her father's addiction also clarified for Miller, now in her mid-40's, her violent childhood attachment to her older brother, a relationship as troubled and complex as that with her father. Paula Friedman

HEADLINE: Real Life in the Little House

BYLINE: By Eden Ross Lipson; Eden Ross Lipson is the children's book editor of the Book Review.

 BODY:

Becoming Laura Ingalls Wilder
 The Woman Behind the Legend.
 By John E. Miller.
 Illustrated. 306 pp. Columbia:
 University of Missouri Press. $29.95. 
 Laura Ingalls Wilder died in 1957 at the age of 90, and in the succeeding decades entire libraries of fiction, memoirs, women's studies and regional history have appeared dealing with women's lives and the settling of the prairies. By and large those titles simply reinforce the affection generations of children and adult readers alike feel for Wilder's autobiographical accounts of growing up on the frontier in the 1870's and 80's, the beloved "Little House" books.
The availability of so much similar material makes the question posed by John E. Miller at the outset of his generous, spirited biography, "Becoming Laura Ingalls Wilder: The Woman Behind the Legend," both fair and helpful. What happened, he asks, to the "young girl and adolescent named Laura" from the time she married at 18 to the age of 65, when "Little House in the Big Woods" was published? And how did Laura Elizabeth Ingalls Wilder, "this seemingly ordinary woman," find the resources and skill to produce a body of work that succeeding generations of Americans, as well as readers of more than 40 languages around the world, adore and take as a true account of one family and an entire aspect of American history?
Miller decides it was perseverance: "Her readers know how her family withstood the challenges of poverty, crop failures, blizzards, grasshoppers, prairie fires and other setbacks. Throughout her life, Wilder faced similar challenges: the loss of a child, her husband's physical disability, hardscrabble economic conditions, conflicts with her daughter, a patriarchal social environment and a long apprenticeship at the writing trade with little to show for it." But, Miller adds, this "ambitious woman" as a child had "received just enough feedback from adults to reinforce her feeling that somehow she was different."
He gives some credit to her sense of her own superiority, some to her experience writing for local papers and some, but probably not quite enough, to her remarkable daughter, Rose Wilder Lane.
Born when her mother was only 19, Rose left Mansfield, Mo., where her parents finally settled, as soon as she could. She worked her way to San Francisco, became a journalist, mixed with literati and lefties, traveled extensively in Europe (even settling in Albania in the 20's), wrote fiction and nonfiction under her own name (she was also a ghostwriter for Herbert Hoover and Lowell Thomas, among others) and went to Vietnam in 1965 at the age of 78. Her libertarian tracts, written later in her life, have come back into print and are in vogue these days with conservative groups.
The central figure in her life was unquestionably her mother. Rose's brief early marriage was a failure; her friendships were often combative. Indeed, her most successful interpersonal relationships were sustained by letter. In her extensive correspondence she spent a great deal of time complaining about her mother -- feeling responsible for her, resenting her. Her relationship with her "Mama Bess" was fraught. The title Rose's biographer, William Holtz, chose for his book, "The Ghost in the Little House" (1993), was also his thesis -- that Rose Wilder Lane, at great personal cost, was her mother's ghostwriter.
Miller perceives Rose's midlife and midcareer hysteria more clearly and has looked very closely at the manuscripts that Rose edited before they were submitted to Harper & Brothers. While it is not a universal truth that memoirs are fiction, though the best often read that way, it is true that the "Little House" books are novels, and that Laura Ingalls Wilder intended them to be.
The Missouri housewife with a frontier education and modest experience, beginning at 44, writing essays for The Mansfield Mirror and The Missouri Ruralist, "relied on the tools that fiction writers normally employ." She received first-class editing from her daughter, the lightest on the first book, "Little House in the Big Woods," the heaviest on the powerful later novel "The Long Winter," and together they polished and shaped remembered experience into fiction that endures.
Miller, a historian who teaches at South Dakota State University in Brookings, uses the resources his trade normally employs, the ones that citizens find numbingly dull until they are gracefully explicated: deed claims, local newspapers, the manuscript original of the 1880 census. That document described the 116 residents of De Smet, S.D., where Wilder lived as a teen-ager, precisely, and Miller sees that they were not just "disproportionately young and male." While there were approximately equal numbers of boys and girls, of those in their 20's there were 34 men and 16 women; of those in their 50's three men and no women. Most husbands were "between four and nine years older" than their wives.
Thus it was not so exceptional for 25-year-old Almanzo Wilder to court 15-year-old Laura Ingalls, fetching her home for the winter weekends from her teaching job at a one-room schoolhouse 12 miles away. Even so, when she wrote about it decades later she reduced the difference in their ages, lest her young readers think she had been a "child bride" when she married in 1885. Wilder never fully recovered from the diphtheria he suffered in 1888; he remains, in all accounts, a stoic, almost silent, limping figure for the rest of his long life.
In his conclusion, Miller understates the case carefully when he says: "The tangled relationship between mother and daughter was clearly crucial. . . . Without Rose's help and encouragement, there would have been no 'Laura Ingalls Wilder' as we know her today, only a sprightly, energetic Ozarks farm woman and sometime farm-newspaper writer known as 'Mrs. A. J. Wilder.' But then without her mother and the attentions that she lavished upon her daughter, there would have been no 'Rose Wilder Lane,' either." There's rich fodder for fiction in their story, too.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Fire Safety For Ships at Sea

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
UNLIKE the Titanic or the Andrea Doria, the Carnival cruise ship Ecstasy lost not a single passenger or crew member. But in its smaller way, the Ecstasy fire, which produced thick smoke that was on hundreds of television newscasts, will probably contribute to the evolution of marine safety.
The time line of progress on marine safety reads as a perfect counterpoint to tragedies afloat. After more than 1,000 people, mostly children, died on an excursion aboard the General Slocum, which caught fire in New York in 1904, requirements for lifesaving gear and fire equipment were tightened. When more than 1,500 died on the Titanic in 1912, lifeboat personnel were required to be certified, and an international conference was called to approve a Convention on the Safety of Life at Sea. The Andrea Doria-Stockholm crash in 1956, in which 52 died, brought requirements that hulls be divided by steel bulkheads. 
 With the Ecstasy, which was built with sprinklers, smoke inhalation in corridors caused the only injuries, and they were mild. (The investigators, at this writing, do not know if the sprinklers were going to be effective in the fire, or if the fireboats were essential. There were also complaints of confusion and delay in informing passengers of the fire and the procedures to follow.)
There were no sprinklers aboard Commodore Cruise Line's Universe Explorer, where five crew members died of smoke inhalation in a 1996 fire. That accident put the menace of smoke high on the list at the National Transportation Safety Board, which investigates these events, and the Coast Guard, which controls ship safety for American vessels and provides the United States delegates to the negotiations on international maritime rules. There are many other ships without sprinklers, or even smoke alarms that go off on the spot. Sometimes they are installed then taken out -- in a laundry, for example -- because they go off too often.
Experts at the two Government agencies are pressing urgently for changes that insure better safety for cruise passengers, 80 percent of them Americans.
 
Ships Not Under U.S. Rules
Most passengers presume that United States standards are in force on ships that dock in Florida, Louisiana, California, Washington State or even New York. But the giant cruise ships, while they may be American owned, are all registered and taxed in foreign countries, and covered by those countries' regulations. The Coast Guard does inspect ships that dock in the United States, but only to verify that the vessel meets the standards of the Convention on Safety of Life at Sea, or Solas. There should be twice as many lifeboat seats as potential passengers, and life jackets for 125 percent of capacity. The Coast Guard also inspects cruise ships' food facilities and their hot tubs, under the direction of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
In severe cases, either for overall safety or for bad kitchen conditions, the Coast Guard can keep a vessel from leaving an American port. But it is rare, and the stringent safety rules that govern inland ferries and riverboats do not apply.
The Ecstasy, built in 1991, is registered in Liberia. Her owner, Carnival, an American company, discussed in its 1997 annual report why it believes she is virtually exempt from United States taxes. Panama and the Bahamas also provide flags of convenience to shipowners who find it more economical to register outside the United States. In 1982, a Government report found that 74 percent of ships visiting United States ports were registered in the Bahamas, Liberia, Panama and Norway.
Only one United States ocean-going cruise ship remains, American Hawaii Cruises' Independence, and she is not subject to international rules because she sails in the Hawaiian islands.
Some ships that visit the United States are registered in countries with venerable seagoing traditions, Britain, Italy and Norway among them. But of Liberia, Barry Sweedler, head of the office of safety recommendations and accomplishments at the National Transportation Safety Board, said: "What kind of standards can it apply? Isn't it in the grip of civil war?"
 
 Sprinkler Exemptions Found
But just as mailing letters requires some international concords about doing business, moving in international waters implies some harmony on standards: signals, rights of way, communications and rescue obligations.
These basics are adopted by the International Maritime Organization, a specialized agency of the United Nations set up in 1958, with headquarters in London. Its primary vehicle is Solas; the most recent version, adopted in 1974, has been amended several times. The rules, first designed to protect sailors, cover most aspects of life at sea, such as load limits for ships and how tonnages are measured. A passenger ship must be capable of being abandoned 30 minutes after a warning, for example, and lifeboats must be partly covered to protect the passengers.
Each country is responsible for certifying that ships bearing its flags meet the requirements of Solas. Each nation delegates the inspection task to a group called a classification society, which is paid by the nation's shipowners to do the work.
The Solas cruise ship safety rules are now a patchwork because the organization's delegates, representing national interests, are reluctant to tell ship owners to modify existing ships; they would rather lay down rules for new construction. Starting in 1994, for example, all new ships had to come out of the yard with sprinklers and smoke alarm systems. But long phase-in times were left for older ships.
The most recent date for retrofitting requirements was October 1997. Solas fire protection rules at that point were nominally applied to all ships built before October 1994. Mr. Sweedler said that his agency and the Coast Guard had gotten the impression that there would be "zero tolerance for noncompliance" with rules requiring sprinklers, fire detection systems and smoke alarms in all accommodations, including atriums, stairway enclosures and corridors, plus self-closing doors. (In the Ecstasy case, the 1997 rule was redundant, because Carnival had been building in sprinkler systems on all of its ships since 1982.)
But then, Mr. Sweedler said, American safety people began to discover that the 1997 rule was not watertight. They learned that 15 vessels, including the Universe Explorer, whose laundry room caught fire near Juneau on July 27, 1996, and the Vistafjord, which lost a crew member in a linen room fire April 7, 1997, had sought or received from their countries of registry what amounts to an exemption from the requirement for sprinklers on board.
The retrofitting rules permit older ships to postpone installation of sprinklers until 2005 or 2009 provided they were built of noncombustible materials and met other criteria. Owners get this exemption by asking their flag nations -- the Bahamas, Panama, Liberia -- to certify that the ship meets these criteria, called Method I. If the exemption is granted, all the Coast Guard can then do to protect passengers' safety is to verify that the Method I standards have been met.
The National Transportation Safety Board conducted a gruelingly detailed study of the Universe Explorer's failure to meet 30 of the Method I criteria under which it was claiming an exemption. In addition to the lack of sprinklers, for example, a bulkhead was found to be missing between the laundry room and other areas, and other repairs and replacements had been carried out with materials that did not meet Method I rules.
Fred Mayer, chief executive officer of Commodore Cruise Line in Miami, said that the line was not required by the rules to install sprinklers, but had a "moral duty" to do so. He said that this work would be done in January 1999, if the design and parts were on hand in time, or in May 1999. He said that his company relied on the certification of the Universe Explorer by its classification society, because it could not count each door and wall; the previous owner removed the laundry room bulkhead, he said. It has been replaced now, he added.
 
Is Your Cruise Ship Safe?
Mr. Sweedler said that detailed inquiries, like the one on the Universe Explorer, showed the impossibility of declaring all pre-1994 vessels fire-safe, either by virtue of sprinklers or by virtue of construction methods and materials. He recommends a tough road: that all potential passengers ask their travel agents if their intended vessel has sprinklers, everywhere, including the laundry room. The situation is too inconsistent to assess otherwise, as Carnival's forward-looking decision in 1982 to build in sprinklers demonstrates.
In addition, it is worth checking the brochure to learn the country of registry of the ship and the date it went to sea. Ships built before 1994 may have received exemption from the 1997 sprinkler requirement by claiming they conform to Method I specifications. The National Transportation Safety Board points out that continual modifications may have undone the validity of the claim, for instance, through use of flammable putty or insulation materials during a repair.
