LENGTH: 2840 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
In Bali, $3 Goes A Long Way

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE; DAISANN McLANE writes about music and culture.

 BODY:
I LEANED back lazily in my hammock and surveyed the panorama from my private veranda: coconut palms and mango trees in sizzling jungle greens, cascades of purple trumpet vines and pale-yellow frangipani, a tropical explosion of foliage that would have kept Gauguin working overtime for a month. While waiting for breakfast to arrive, I mulled over the day's options: A massage and body scrub? Shopping? My thoughts were interrupted by the arrival of a mug of industrial-strength, locally grown coffee and a big plate of juicy pineapple and papaya. It was all impossibly sweet and delicious, but for a frugal traveler there was something even sweeter about this cottage in the central hills of Bali: the price tag. It was $2.85 a night, breakfast and tax included, at the prevailing rate of 14,000 rupiah to the dollar.
Every so often the roulette wheels of economics and politics come to a stop in a configuration that produces a traveler's windfall. During the Asian monetary crisis that began last summer, Indonesia's rupiah fell by more than 70 percent against the dollar. In mid-May, demonstrations and riots tore through Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, and thousands of American citizens were evacuated. Soon both the United States State Department and the British Government had issued travel warnings on Indonesia. 
 However, when curiosity led me to search the Web site of Britain's Foreign and Commonwealth Office (www.fco.gov.uk), I ran across this phrase: "The Embassy has at present no basis for advising against resumption of tourist visits to Bali." (Six weeks later, the State Department's public announcement on July 13 about the demonstrations stated: "Tourist areas in Bali have not been affected.")
Through the grapevine, I began to hear tempting stories of Bali bargains. Empty hotels had slashed room rates, and would negotiate downward at the reservations desk. One London newspaper reported that it cost only about $7 to rent a car with driver for a day.
I knew that culturally Bali was separate from the rest of Indonesia. A Hindu minority in that predominantly Islamic country, the Balinese have a complex, village-oriented culture that runs according to an intricate calendar of religious ceremonies, familial and ancestral obligations and auspicious occasions. There hadn't been any riots in Bali, even during the worst of Jakarta's unrest. So in mid-June I started looking for a cheap fare to Bali. Garuda, the Indonesian airline, had suspended service to the United States, so there were fewer seats. I didn't want to go through Jakarta, which ruled out Japan Airlines. I narrowed it down to Cathay Pacific, Singapore, and Malaysia Airlines, each of which offered roundtrips to Denpasar that ranged between $1,400 and $1,800 in economy -- pricey, for summer is when many air fares to Asia spike.
But consolidators offered substantial discounts. I purchased a round-trip ticket from Newark to Denpasar, via Dubai, for $1,150 on Malaysia, which allowed me to change my return date without additional charges (just in case) and offered the intriguing option of a free stopover in Kuala Lumpur.
Because I don't like to land in an unfamiliar place after a 24-hour trip without my first night's hotel reservation confirmed, I booked a room for a single rate of $75 at the Holiday Inn Resort Balihai at Kuta Beach, one of a long list of Bali hotels that offered discounts ranging from 25 to 50 percent on the Web site Bali Online at www.indo.com. Breakfast and a free transfer from nearby Ngurah Rai airport were included. From this side of the world it sounded like a terrific deal.
Little did I know that, once I got to Bali, the Holiday Inn would turn out to be the least remarkable value I'd find during my 10-day stay. The 200-room resort was fine: It had an impressive, huge thatched-roof reception area modeled on a Balinese bale, or town meeting hall. My room was pleasant and decent-sized, and had a balcony facing a large tastefully landscaped courtyard with a swimming pool. But it had a package-tour sameness about it -- was I in Fiji? Jamaica? Puerto Vallarta? Also, it was full, or so it seemed to me (actually, only 57 out of 200 rooms were occupied), with gregarious Australians on vacation packages. My first night at dinner, the boisterous table next to me suddenly burst into a loud chorus of "Yellow Submarine." I plotted my escape.
I decided, first of all, to get out of Kuta, the strip of beach hotels, shopping malls and tacky thatched-roof McDonald's in southern Bali. A few miles southeast was Nusa Dua, a more recently developed enclave of exclusive self-contained resorts, including the well-known Amanusa, one of a chain of super-luxe hotels. A short drive northeast of Kuta, Sanur also looked promising, with a selection of older, boutique hotels, and a huge Hyatt resort.
I thought I'd try a bit of haggling, and rang up the pricey Amanusa. "We have a no-discount policy," the reservations clerk sniffed. "Perhaps if you booked one of our $500 rooms we might be able to upgrade you to our $600 room." The Bali Hyatt in Sanur, though, was eager to deal. The Bali Online Web site had listed a discount single room there at $200, but over the phone the clerk instantly offered me the same room for $110. When I went over to look at the hotel -- a lush resort on 36 acres of immaculately groomed gardens -- the price dropped yet again, to $96, taxes and breakfast included. I said I'd think about it.
Meanwhile, I cast another feeler in the direction of the Tandjung Sari, an older, Indonesian-owned hotel with 26 cottages that came highly recommended by several guidebooks as an example of what Bali was like before the tourist boom. The Balinese manager giggled when I told her I was not happy in my Kuta hotel. "You will be happy here," she laughed, offering to slash the rack rate of the standard cottage by $75, to $127.
A welcoming gong resounded as my taxi pulled up the long driveway of the Tandjung Sari. Two Balinese men in sarongs guarded my luggage as I inspected my potential new home, the price of which abruptly dropped again, to $100. I was, indeed, happy -- the cottage, tucked into a wild tangle of vines and tropical trees, boasted a stone bathtub the size of a double bed, surrounded by glass walls. The bathroom extended beyond the walls, to a shower in an open-air garden filled with bougainvillea and stone temple statues. "For $27 more, you can have the ocean view," suggested the manager.
I was ecstatic. In my room brochure, I read that Tandjung had hosted artistic and illustrious travelers for more than 30 years -- Anais Nin had even written about the hotel in her diaries. It was still rife with character. At dinner in the open-air dining room, I was regaled with tales of the Maharajah of Jodhpur by an aging British aristocrat -- who insisted on picking up my check, an act of gallantry that I accepted since my portion of the bill came to all of $3. Meals in Bali, even at upscale restaurants, seldom amounted to more than $3 or $4 at the prevailing rates of exchange -- which were becoming more favorable every day.
I adored Tandjung, but I was growing ambivalent about the Bali outside. Far from an island paradise, it was turning out to be a constant hassle, an irritating hustle. The moment I stepped out of the hotel gates, the clamor began: "Madam! Transport? What is your program for today?" I'd stop to admire a roadside temple, and a guy on a motorcycle would pull up and wave a display case of cheap watches in my face.
The Balinese economy depends almost entirely on tourism, and with fewer tourists around, I was, understandably, a prize target. One morning I slipped out to the beach to admire the sunrise. The beach was deserted, the air cool, and I was happily enjoying the fabled Balinese "morning of the world," when, out of thin air, a small boy appeared at my elbow with an armful of carved frogs. I jumped.
Bali bursts with spiritual signifiers. Everywhere I looked there were temples, and even shopping malls were strewn with little offering packets of rice and coconut. But, as a tourist I found the way to spiritual Bali blocked by a wall of souvenirs, until I landed at the door of the Canti Dasa Ashram. Situated in the ramshackle beachside resort of Candidasa, a two-hour drive northeast of Sanur, the ashram is a community of about 24 young Balinese run by a formidable woman in her 70's, Ibu Bagoes Oka, who is a member of the district's royal family.
Ibu Oka, as she is called, took up the spiritual life some decades ago, turning her family's prime beachfront land, a peninsula poised between ocean and lagoon, into an ashram with guest cottages that welcomes visitors who have spiritual interests and accept the rules -- no smoking or alcohol -- for a minimum three nights' stay, at $20 a night including vegetarian meals.
It wasn't the cheapest place to stay in Candidasa (the nearby Ida Homestay had comfortable cottages for $3 a night), nor the most luxurious. The cottages have no fans (though they do have private bathrooms), and mine had an austere single wooden bed. But the ashram had location, location, location, and a serenity that is hard to find at any price.
EACH morning for four days, as the sun threw dappled pink light on the wild ocean lapping at the foot of my cottage porch, I decided I needed just a bit more time away from the marketplace of paradise. The vegetarian meals were delicious and my fellow guests, a securities trader from San Francisco and a schoolteacher and her daughter from Canberra, made for interesting company during lazy days of swimming, yoga classes and snorkeling excursions. (Ashrams are to the adult traveler what hostels are to the teen-ager, I've decided.) One day I hired a car and driver and spent a morning exploring the remarkable fountains and gardens of the nearby water palace of Tirta Gangga. The next day I boarded a fishing boat for a 30-minute ride to the "Blue Lagoon" reef ($4.50), and watched dolphins jump out of the sea 30 feet from starboard.
Soon I was ready to tackle the material world again. Ubud, in Bali's central hills, is the culture capital of the island -- a sort of tropical Santa Fe, brimming with painters, expat entrepreneurs and hippie dropouts. Despite the travel warning, Americans were everywhere in Ubud.
I met Beth, a teacher from Alaska, in a Balinese cooking class taught by an Australian emigre named Janet de Neefe. (Four hours of instruction plus lunch was about $6.) Beth, like other Americans I ran into, expressed misgivings about the enormous bargains that, thanks to the vagaries of global economics, Bali offered.
"I told my landlady that she had to raise the price of her guesthouse -- it was only $4 a night!" she exclaimed. "And I'm going to leave money here with a children's school before I go."
I found myself tipping often and generously, and rounding most of my bills upward. Still, the deeper I delved into Bali, the less I found myself spending, for I discovered that the things I liked best were to be found in the most remote spots. And the more I strayed from the tourist track, the lower the prices fell. By traveling three hours to the far eastern coast of Bali, I was able to stay in a huge two-story beachfront cottage with garden bathroom at the Good Karma Bungalows, which, except for its lack of telephones, offered most of the luxury amenities of Tandjung Sari for only $9 a night.
On a walk deep into the forest outside Ubud, I followed a path along a river, across a rice field, around a temple and came upon the Pugig Homestay, four two-story cottages tucked upon that Gauguin hillside overlooking a sacred Balinese bathing spot. Save for a French couple, the place was empty, and Nyoman, the manager, said that one of the cottages could be mine for $2.85 a night. Granted, it didn't have hot water or a fan, and the toilet was an Asian-style squat. But I've learned to love squat toilets, for they are practically a guarantee that you'll always be able to get a reservation.
I settled in, and the wheels started spinning. How much cash could I make by subletting my New York apartment at a profit? How many days would the money pay my bills at Pugig? A day passed, and then another. One day I watched a temple procession down the hill. Another day it rained. And one morning, finally, I wrenched myself from the hammock and cast myself out of paradise.
 
The bottom line in Bali, from $8 a day to $130
 
Logistics
I spent as much as $130 and as little as $8 a day in Bali for accommodations, meals, local transport and activities during my 10-day stay, calculated at 14,000 rupiahs to the dollar; the wide range reflects the fact that I was trawling for discounts at all levels of accommodation. My average daily expenditure worked out to around $50, but if you leave out my splurge at the Tandjung Sari Hotel, the average drops to around $25 a day -- a reasonable estimate of what it takes to travel very comfortably in Bali at the moment.
My round-trip ticket on Malaysia Airlines from Newark to Denpasar, via Dubai and Kuala Lumpur, cost $1,150 plus $60 tax from the Adventure Travel Network consolidators in San Francisco: (800) 467-4595.
The price of a car with driver in Bali is highly negotiable. The ashram staff referred me to Ketut Salin, based at the Kelapa Mas hotel in Candidasa, telephone and fax (62-363) 41947, who turned out to be a reliable and safe driver-guide. A half-day of touring the island in his air-conditioned Toyota van was around $5. Mr. Salin's nephew, Made, takes tourists out to Candidasa's Blue Lagoon reef in his fishing boat for $4.50; inquire at the same number.
 
Lodging
Prices quoted include a 21 percent tax and service charge that Indonesian hoteliers call the "plus-plus"; clarify whether it is included when you negotiate rates. Also, if a hotel offers you a rate in United States dollars, and you are paying by credit card, make sure you ask what rupiah conversion rate the hotel uses before agreeing to the price. (Credit card bills are charged in rupiahs.)
At Kuta Beach, the 200-room Holiday Inn Resort Balihai, Jalan Wana Segara 33, Tuban, (62-361) 753035; fax 754548, cost $75 a night, including breakfast.
At the Tandjung Sari Hotel, 41 Jalan Danau Tamblingan, Sanur, (62-361) 288441, fax 287930, my deluxe cottage was quoted at $127 a night with breakfast, but since the hotel calculated my credit card bill at a more favorable exchange rate, my actual cost was $114. (In late July, the hotel quoted a rate of $156.)
The Bali Hyatt, Box 392, Sanur, (62-361) 281 234, fax 287 693, is one of the island's most attractive large resorts, set in lush gardens on a private beach. The "superior garden room" I saw was discounted to $96.
The Canti Dasa Ashram, Candidasa, Karangasem, telephone and fax (62-363) 41108, offers (but does not require participation in) yoga classes and chanting-meditation ceremonies three times a day. Rates are $20 a day (three-day minimum), including three sumptuous vegetarian feasts, afternoon tea and snacks. No smoking or drinking.
The nearby Ida Homestay, Candidasa, Karangasem, telephone and fax (62-363) 41096, rents decent garden cottages with double beds and ceiling fans, for around $3 a night including breakfast.
In Ubud (actually Penestanan, a village 15 minutes' walk from the center of Ubud), my little two-story house at Pugig Homestay, (62-361) 974-362, had electricity, no fan, a squat toilet and cold shower, and a veranda with a drop-dead view of a river gorge -- for $2.85 with breakfast. If I were to return I'd try to reserve the main house for about $6 a night; it's larger, with a better bathroom, a fan and an even nicer view.
In eastern Bali, at the Good Karma Bungalows in Selang near Amed, Karangasem, my beachfront cottage cost $9 a night.
 
Places to Eat
Ubud is the place for fine dining, both European and Asian. My favorite spots were Cafe Wayan, Monkey Forest Road, Ubud, (62-361) 975447, where I paid about $3 for a tasty lunch of Thai chicken in green curry sauce, spring rolls, and a Bintang Indonesian beer, and Han Snel's Garden Restaurant, Jalan Kajeng, Ubud, (62-361) 975699, which serves, on a banana leaf, a delicious Indonesian-style rijstaffel, also around $3.
 
Activities
At Nur's Beauty Salon, Hanoman Street, Ubud, (62-361) 975 352, Balinese massages and other treatments are performed by young, somewhat inexperienced girls. The massage is followed by an herbal skin exfoliation and a soak in a tub strewn with blossoms ($4.50 for 90 minutes). Lovely, but it was no match for the skilled massage I got from Ni Ketut Suwite ($1.75), a middle-aged woman who can be found by asking along the main street of Candidasa.
Janet de Neefe holds Balinese cooking classes (about $6) three times a week in Ubud. More demonstration than hands-on, they're the prelude to a lunchtime feast. She also rents four very nice guest cottages for about $6 a night. Information: telephone and fax (62-361) 973282.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 14; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1349 words

HEADLINE: An Analyst of Passion, and Paris

BYLINE: By LESLIE CAMHI; Leslie Camhi writes frequently about film, art and contemporary culture for The Village Voice.

 BODY:
BENOIT JACQUOT is not about to turn out autobiography. "I'm not interested in recounting my life through my films," the famously reticent French director said recently. "I'd rather they teach me something about my life."
His presence in his work is close to transparent: a finely tuned eye and intelligence, focused on the intricate, oblique entanglements of human beings. Inspired by the sensual, emotional immediacy of actors, he also partakes in his films of an analyst's measured distance and reserve. His characters, veiled in silence or adept in miscommunication, rarely say what they're thinking. And while Mr. Jacquot is not the product of a tell-all society, he also remains largely faithful to a city, Paris, and a set of psychological concerns that differentiate his work from recent French films set in the provinces. 
 Viewers can see Mr. Jacquot's analytical mind at work in "Seventh Heaven," a 1997 film that opened in New York on Friday. Subtle, cryptic and funny, it explores a modern triangle among a wife, her husband and her therapist. Mathilde, a young woman, neglects her job and suffers from frigidity, fainting spells and bouts of kleptomania. When an enigmatic hypnotist cures her of these ills, her husband, Nico, begins to shirk his work as a surgeon and his conjugal duties. A poignant survey of the shifting grounds of marital power, this comedy of the unconscious is also a compendium of Parisian neuroses and pleasures, from adultery to psychoanalysis.
Mr. Jacquot, 51, is as contradictory and recondite as his oeuvre. Tall and angular, with elegant manners, a foxlike face and a gaze that nails its object, in conversation he can seem at once surprisingly self-effacing and rather wearied by the limits of language. He has set two films (one recent, one to come) in the 18th century, and that age of enlightened libertinage probably appeals to him, for despite his crow's-feet, he reminds an interviewer of an oddly amiable Marquis de Sade -- fundamentally chilly but as mirthful as a schoolboy.
"A Parisian by birth and by existence," as he puts it, Mr. Jacquot grew up on the films of the French New Wave, assisted the great writer and director Marguerite Duras when he was in his early 20's and began his own career as the director of abstruse, rigidly stylized dramas amid the theoretical ferment of Paris in the 1970's. "I don't like my early films," he admitted. "I have a hard time seeing them and acknowledging them as my own. When I made my first film, 'The Musician Killer,' in 1975, it seemed like my last; while 15 years later, with 'The Disenchanted,' I felt that I was beginning my career anew."
That lyrical, deeply moving film, which was shown this spring at Film Forum in New York, stars Judith Godreche as a 17-year-old high school student who lives with her mysteriously paralyzed mother and her little brother in a once-grand apartment. The film traces her encounters over the course of three days with several men: her handsome, arrogant boyfriend; Chan, a Chinese friend and fellow student; Alphonse, an older writer whom she meets by chance, and "the uncle," a cultivated and insidious retired doctor who supports her impecunious household.
"The Disenchanted" moves across Paris with the exactitude of an anatomist palpating a body, revealing the city's lush little islands, afternoon dance clubs, high-rise workers' housing and gracious bourgeois apartments. It's also a remarkably tender vivisection that all but exposes the beating heart of a young woman.
"The relationship to Paris is extremely precise in all of Benoit's films," said Philippe Carcassonne, the prolific French producer who is Mr. Jacquot's frequent collaborator. "We are working right now on 'Pas de Scandale,' to be shot this fall. Benoit has already indicated the two or three avenues where we are to look for the main character's apartment."
Mr. Jacquot's later films have all focused on the mystery of women's identities and desires, set against the exigencies (material, social, psychological and physical) that circumscribe them. "Marianne" (1994), an adaptation of Marivaux's novel "La Vie de Marianne," stars Virginie Ledoyen as the 18th-century heroine of indeterminate origins who moves uncertainly through an often predatory world of servants, tradespeople and aristocrats.
Ms. Ledoyen also stars in "A Single Girl" (1995), which was well-received in the United States two years ago. Filmed for the most part in real time, it follows a young woman through an early hour of a gray Parisian morning, as she meets her unemployed boyfriend in a cafe, tells him she's pregnant and begins her first day of work as a room-service waitress, delivering breakfast in a four-star hotel. There she navigates a maze of bosses, co-workers and a multitude of strangers with whom she shares unwanted moments of intimacy; all the while, her secret is privately at work within her. This small, dazzling film tells almost no story; instead, it focuses with the intensity of a lover's gaze upon the riddle of another's existence.
The inspiration for "Seventh Heaven" was double. Mr. Jacquot wrote the script with Jerome Beaujour for Sandrine Kiberlain and Vincent Lindon, the two French stars who play the married couple, and who are, in fact, husband and wife. "I could only have made this film with a couple who live together," Mr. Jacquot said. "It's fiction, but it also has a documentary aspect, in the way that George Cukor's films play off the real-life couple of Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy."
That the film has the lightness of a 1930's domestic comedy is all the more striking when one considers its second source of inspiration: Lacanian psychoanalysis. In 1974, Mr. Jacquot directed the only televised interview with Jacques Lacan, the highly celebrated and controversial Parisian psychoanalyst.
"I had read Lacan's work, and it moved me very deeply," Mr. Jacquot says. "Before him, psychoanalysts tended to write of the unconscious as if they themselves had none. For me, he was a brilliant model of someone who could be at once extremely rigorous and precise, and yet open to the effects of the unconscious."
"He also had a remarkable sense of comedy; he was extremely adept in the art of surprise," Mr. Jacquot continued. "And surprise is our only real proof of the unconscious."
It's an art that, as a director, Mr. Jacquot takes pains to cultivate. His preparatory work with actors is lengthy but oblique; he never rehearses, and all his films are shot using very few takes. "The films always spill over the idea I had of them," he said. "They lead me, together with the cast and crew, elsewhere. Otherwise, they're just illustration."
In relation to his work, he attempts to preserve something of the analyst's fertile silence and enigmatic power.
Ms. Kiberlain's troubling and touching performance as Mathilde in "Seventh Heaven" required her to feign fainting, hypnosis and (discretely) orgasm. "If there's a rapport between hypnosis and acting, it has to do with the sense of surrender," Ms. Kiberlain said. "When Benoit would tell me, now you faint, I didn't have the faintest idea of how to go about it. But you just let go, you fall. There has to be a great deal of confidence between actor and director for that to work."
Mr. Jacquot enjoys the reputation of a director who is highly respected by actors. Mr. Lindon concurs. "It's because he loves actors, listens to them, respects them, and because the actors in his films are always good," he said.
What is it about women that so interests Mr. Jacquot?
"I was born a man," Mr. Jacquot said, "and women are the part of humanity that is at once familiar and very, very strange to me. It's difficult for a man to ask the question, what is a man. It's as if the question just doesn't arise. Or as if we already know the response, and it's not necessarily amusing. But a woman can ask herself the question, what is a woman. I try to respond to that question with the female characters I invent and the actresses I film. And they always lead me to further questions."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 25; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1519 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Of the South and Its Imprint on Literature

BYLINE: By ARIEL SWARTLEY; Ariel Swartley writes frequently about popular and literary culture from Los Angeles.

 BODY:
TO drop the term "Southern writers" in a roomful of literati is to find oneself momentarily in possession of a staff as powerful as Moses'. Opinion sucks itself up into two formidably glittering walls, while faces turn, some alight in passionate defense, others with chins drawn in and hackles visibly raised. The dispute goes well beyond whether William Faulkner was the American Shakespeare or a suffocatingly long-winded chronicler of characters who were the same way themselves. It also goes beyond ideas about the region itself, though these are apt to cloud the issue.
Although not always acknowledged, traces of this divide are evident in "Tell About the South," a documentary on Southern literature from 1920 to the 1940's that interviews or profiles more than two dozen writers, black and white. (The first of what is planned as a three-part series, the film, written, directed and produced by Ross Spears, will be shown Thursday at 10 P.M. on PBS.) 
 Arms crossed and facing the documentary's cameras from the center of a striped sofa, the novelist and journalist Willie Morris describes an encounter he had in 1960 while a Rhodes scholar at Oxford with the poet Robert Frost. Noticing Mr. Morris's accent, Mr. Frost asked where he was from. "Mississippi?" the poet exploded on being told. "Hell, that's the worst state in the Union." Well, it had produced some fine writers, a shaken Mr. Morris allowed. "But can anyone there read them?" Mr. Frost returned.
At bottom, threading like a narrow spit of sand between the Red Sea waves of opinion lies the very notion of a regional literature, and the issues it raises are peculiarly American. Does the convening of so many disparate voices under a single banner enhance or diminish the individuals involved? Or, more fundamentally, are writers born or made? And if the answer is the latter, then what is responsible for their making: the landscapes of their youth, culture and traditions, or some central validating literary establishment? The questions become more urgent when the voices are drawn from a region as racially divided as the 20th-century American South.
In her influential 1956 essay "Place in Fiction," the Mississippi-born novelist Eudora Welty allowed that "it is both natural and sensible that the place where we have our roots should become the setting, the first and primary proving ground, of our fiction." At the same time she spurned the "regional" designation, calling it "a careless term, as well as a condescending one." Condescending, because it was a judgment passed by outsiders. But, in fact, the passing was a bit more complicated.
The song "Dixie" was written in New York by an Ohio native -- information that depending on your point of view illustrates either the transformative power of myth or a willingness to disregard inconvenient truths. Similarly, "Southern," as applied to writers, is an attribution that is open to interpretation. Edgar Allan Poe, reared and schooled in Virginia, left the South both literally and figuratively. Thomas Wolfe wrote most of his books in Brooklyn but his affiliation remains clear. The author of "Roots," Alex Haley, brought up in Alabama and Tennessee, remained, perhaps by virtue of his journalism, the consummate New Yorker.
Few regions have had critics as vituperative as the Baltimore journalist H. L. Mencken, who in 1917 wrote off the economically depressed world south of the Potomac as "a vast plain of mediocrity, stupidity and lethargy." And yet not even New England has been as successful as the South in promoting itself as the home ground of a distinctive literature. One might argue that New England sidestepped the need by presuming its tastes and standards to be those of the nation as a whole, a feat made easier by the powerful opinion makers that called the region home: Harvard, for instance, and Yale, and The Atlantic Monthly. The South, on the other hand, had considerable practice in making a virtue out of adversity.
"Tell About the South" focuses first on the Fugitive poets, including Allen Tate, John Crowe Ransom and Robert Penn Warren, who took their name from the literary magazine they founded at Vanderbilt University in Nashville in 1922. Young, gifted, white and relatively privileged (all three were Rhodes scholars) they turned "regional" into a badge of distinction. In addition to being poets, the Fugitives were articulate critics. From Vanderbilt, founded to be the South's answer to Harvard and liberally endowed by the railroad baron (Cornelius), their academic influence radiated outward, fueled by the 1930 publication of "I'll Take My Stand."
Subtitled "The South and the Agrarian Tradition," this essay collection provided a philosophical and political rationale for literature that drew its sustenance from the land and the farmer's virtue, cultivation, and was therefore a moral counterweight to empty technology, rootless modernity and other Northern contributions. By the 1960's and 70's, leading figures of the group were fugitive no longer, but well-placed members of the literary establishment, with professorships at Yale and Kenyon, books of criticism and prestigious awards. Last month's strong showing of white Southern writers (including relatively minor figures like Carson McCullers and Erskine Caldwell) on Modern Library's recent list of the century's best novels (as well as the complete absence of black women) is evidence of how powerfully certain sorts of Southerness have become identified with literariness per se.
An assumption within the agrarian tradition holds that art somehow follows the laws of the vegetable kingdom, flourishing in proportion to the depth and tenacity of its roots, springing up on hitherto barren ground from a God-strewn seed. In light of this assumption, the Fugitives were poets who just happened to come together, driven by their individual talents and not by anything as -- well -- sordid as the marketplace. And if such amateurism, however organically grown, sounds disingenuous in light of the Modern Library list, it's downright patronizing when it's applied to the blues.
That the compressed, ironic, extravagantly imagistic song lyrics that flourished across the black South from canebrake to back porch to back-street bordello were a legitimate and powerful poetics has been recognized, in print, for at least half a century. The oft-quoted legend (which "Tell About the South" repeats) of the Delta bluesman Robert Johnson receiving his talent through a pact with the Devil is a dramatic piece of myth making. But, like other arts, the blues flourished because, after World War I, there was a community, and technology, able to nourish them. Traveling tent shows aimed at exclusively black audiences crisscrossed the South, disseminating new musical styles and vividly topical lyrics.
Even Johnson, whose imagery generally inclines to the starkly rural (storms, lonesome roads, welcoming kitchens) could describe a woman as having "Elgin movements." More important, from 1920 on, as the phonograph came into popular use, blues were assiduously recorded and marketed to an increasingly far-flung black audience.
Today, too, the region that many modern black Southern writers identify with is one that's largely independent of geography. Rather, it is a region of shared experience. "I became aware of my need of Zora Neale Hurston's work some time before I knew her work existed," the novelist Alice Walker begins her foreword to Robert Hemenway's 1977 biography of Hurston, the Florida-born, Barnard-trained folklorist and novelist. The need Ms. Walker cites is specifically "accurate material on voodoo practices among rural Southern blacks of the 30's," material that Hurston returned to her hometown to collect and published in 1935 as "Mules and Men."
But Ms. Walker has in mind a deeper need as well. Whatever territory a writer chooses to call his own -- fertile or rock-strewn, inherited or mortgaged -- and however far it is from home, what's required is the imaginative certainty that it is indeed a place of promise. "Place," for both blacks and women, has been a double-edged word: not only the inspiring subsoil that Eudora Welty had in mind, with its dense specifics of sensation and history, but an assigned region of self-effacement and confinement that one is expected to know and keep to.
AS Ms. Walker testifies, Hurston's loping, brash and elegantly colloquial prose gave a new voice to commonplace details of Southern experience, a voice that was at once distinctive and literary, assuredly black and undeniably female. It was as if by embracing an actual place so entirely and fearlessly she was able to fly the metaphorical coop.
Perhaps the divine is the only literature that can come into being in a true wilderness, written in short commandments on stone tablets. The human writer requires assurance that his or her thoughts are worth voicing and that there is someone out there to receive them. It's not the region that inspires the varied voices in "Tell About the South." It's the communities they've found there.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A SENSE OF PLACE: Both William Faulkner, left, and the folklorist and novelist Zora Neale Hurston wrote eloquently and profoundly of the Southern experience. (Corbis (left); PBS (right) ) (pg. 25); ANTI-REGIONALISM: The Mississippi-born author Eudora Welty. (Thomas Victor) (pg. 26)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Shared-Office Industry Expands to Meet Demand

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
KENNETH B. SCHWARTZ runs his K & M Advertising Specialities firm from a shared-service office in Freehold. Down the hall another office is being used by Aspect Telecommunications, an international company based in San Jose, Calif.
Their offices are among the 52 at the 13,893-square-foot Alliance Business Center in a 65,000-square-foot building on Route 9 in Freehold. The two companies, along with the others, share a receptionist, secretarial help and conference rooms, among other amenities. 
 Entrepreneurs like Mr. Schwartz have traditionally turned to shared-service offices, also known as executive suites, as a cost-effective and flexible alternative to renting conventional office space. But with increasing frequency they are being joined by large firms such as Aspect that need to set up satellite offices quickly and in many locations. Both want access to the latest available technology for telecommunications.
To meet those demands the shared-office industry is consolidating "to have the criticial mass to warrant the investment in sophisticated technology," said Kevin J. Danehy, a vice president at the Manhattan office of CB Richard Ellis, the national commercial brokerage.
Three of the industry's larger operators have recently expanded into New Jersey by acquiring regional or local operators, opening new centers or both. One is Alliance National, a privately held concern based in Manhattan that runs the Freehold center.
The others are OmniOffices, of Atlanta, an affiliate of Carr America, a real estate investment trust, or REIT, and Reckson Executive Centers, an affiliate of Reckson Realty Associates, based in Melville, L.I., which is also a REIT. Collectively, they operate 18 executive-suites complexes with a total of 840 offices in New Jersey.
The growth is not limited to big operators "whose expansion is expected to bring recognition to the entire industry," said Jeannine Windbigler, executive director of the Executive Suite Association, a trade group in Columbus, Ohio. Small firms that decline to be acquired by larger counterparts are also expanding and "will continue to have a place in the market because everyone requires different levels of technology," she said.
There are no exact statistics on office suites available. But estimates are that there are about 157,500 suites nationwide, and the pace of new shared-office openings is 15 to 20 percent greater than two years ago, according to the association, industry specialists and suite operators.
Typically, space and furnishings and such things as a shared conference room, reception area and receptionist and maintenance are included in the rent. Tenants pay extra for support services such as the shared secretary's time and sending materials on the shared fax. Though suites are generally small, ranging from 60 to 250 square feet, they offer flexible lease terms. The typical lease is for three months to a year.
Executive suites evolved in the late 60's from the secretarial services industry as its customers began demanding other amenities, such as meeting and conference rooms and eventually office space. They were, however, slow to catch on because of their early image as a makeshift for tenants who could not afford conventional office space.
But now that advances in technology have made it easier to conduct business, executive suites have become more appealing for large corporations whose space needs change more frequently because of downsizing or expansion.
And for new companies that have formed because of the current strong economy they are a way to satisfy modest space needs and minimize costs.
Those factors, along with New Jersey's healthy office market, have prompted large suite operators to invest in the state. As of the second quarter the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market registered an overall vacancy rate of 8.9 percent, down from 11.6 percent a year ago, according to CB Richard Ellis.
That is benefiting the executive-suite industry. But shared offices will never overwhelm the conventional office market, said Mr. Danehy, the CB vice president said. He noted, however, that suites provide companies "speed to market, including the ability to plug into the latest technology," which is critical in an era of rapidly changing global markets.
Alliance National, along with the Freehold center, purchased two other centers in central New Jersey. One is in Bridgewater, the other in East Brunswick. Together they total 145 offices in 37,500 square feet of space.
THE New Jersey purchases are part of a nationwide expansion program for Alliance National, which in the last two years has grown from 14 centers to 88 centers with 5,600 offices in 27 markets. Corporate clients make up 63 percent of the company's customer base, up from less than 40 percent five years ago, David Beale, Alliance's president said, and added: "There is a growing demand from corporations to go to a single provider for their space needs."
That appealed to Aspect Telecommunications, which provides services and products to telephone customer-support operations, and is itself growing. In opening satellite offices in the emerging markets Aspect wants to enter quickly, executive suites are the most economical and flexible alternative, said James L. Hayden Jr., associate account manager at the Staubach Company of Dallas, which handles Aspect's real estate needs. Dealing with a single operator, he added, "provides consistency to the process and makes it even faster."
Alliance plans to double the number of its centers nationwide by 2000. That includes 12 more centers with 600 more suites in New Jersey, which is a viable market "because of the supply-demand imbalance in office space that exists in many areas" of the state, Mr. Beale said.
The Freehold center, like the company's others in New Jersey, is being equipped with high-tech wiring. Its 52 suites range in size from 95 to 252 square feet and rent for $600 to $1,875 a month. Support services range on average from $400 to $700 more a month; the technological amenities are expected to add a minimum of an additional $40.
Carr America, an office REIT based in Washington, D.C., purchased OmniOffices last August as its entry into the executive-suite market. The company did so because it sees suites as an extension to its conventional office business and, more important, as an opportunity to provide alternative offices to companies -- either expanding or downsizing -- that are looking for small blocks of space, said Karen Widmeyer, a spokeswoman.
Since then Carr, through its affiliate OminOffices, has acquired 107 executive-suite complexes in England and the United States with a total of 7,307 offices. Of that total 14 executive-suite centers with 741 offices are in New Jersey, the result of its acquisition earlier this year of two Headquarters Companies (known as HQ) franchises. High-tech wiring is being installed at the New Jersey centers, which continue to operate under the HQ banner.
"To be competitive you have to invest in a system that provides one-stop shopping and access to technology," said Thomas Carr, president of Carr America, adding that "we see New Jersey, with its proximity to Manhattan and good economy, as providing us with tremendous opportunities."
Typical of the company's New Jersey operations is its Red Bank center, comprising 8,700 square feet of space in a 100,000-square-foot building on Half Mile Road. The 29 suites range from 60 to 140 square feet in size and rent for $600 to $1,000 a month. Support services range on average from $300 to $600 a month; the cost for the technological amenities have not been set, but Internet access is expected to cost around $100 a month.
The company expects to open 1,700 new shared offices nationwide within the next six months.
Reckson Executive Centers, which has nine complexes with 500 offices, most of them on Long Island, entered New Jersey six months ago. Its parent, Reckson Realty Associates, had earlier acquired several office buildings in the state "where the overall market is healthy, providing us an opportunity to follow through with office suites," said Arnold M. Widder, president of Reckson Executive Centers.
Mr. Widder said that after the last wave of corporate downsizing national companies that sought out suites "found they were an economical way to operate." And, employees who "themselves were downsized formed new companies that also needed small blocks of space," he said, adding: "Suites serve as 'incubator' space and as companies grow any number of them can become tenants in Reckson office buildings."
The company's first New Jersey center comprises 45 suites in 15,000 square feet of space in Reckson Associates' 450,000-square-foot, three-building office complex off Executive Drive in West Orange. The suites, with 150 to 250 square feet of space, rent for $700 to $1,500 a month, with support services costing on average from $200 to $500 a month. Plans call for providing access to the latest in technology.
Mr. Widder said that by 2000 his company intended to open 100 centers, with at least 5,000 offices nationwide, some of them in New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Spiffing Up Helena's Last Chance Gulch

BYLINE: By JIM ROBBINS

DATELINE: HELENA, Mont.

 BODY:
ABANDONED since 1954 when the popularity of train travel was fading, the weed-choked Great Northern railyard in this historic capital city is the site of an ambitious $40 million project now under way at the north end of the city's downtown.
The complex, called the Great Northern Town Center, will include a 150-room hotel with 25,000 square feet for a convention center, the only one in this city of 40,000 residents; a bank; a 23,000-square-foot office building; up to 120 condominium and rental apartments; small shops; a 6,000-square-foot, three-story tented outdoor amphitheater and an enclosed carousel. Rubber grommets will be built into the streets and parking ramp to allow tents to be erected for farmer's' markets and other events. 
 The project has been a catalyst for many other changes on the city's moribund north end. Carroll College, a four-year Roman Catholic school that sits on a hill next to the old railyard, is building a new student union and a new science complex at a total cost of $10 million to complement existing structures and is replacing an existing stadium at a cost of $1 million. It also plans to reorient the campus to the east to face the new complex. A local television station is building a $2.5 million studio on the campus, a 100,000-square-foot Federal office building is to rise next to the town center and the city is to add more soccer and baseball fields to its outdoor sports complex.
Streets, sewers and other improvements for the town center are nearing completion and construction of the office building is under way. The entire project is expected to be done in three to five years.
"We're doing something communities everywhere ought to be doing, infilling where there's already infrastructure," said Alan Nicholson, president of Nicholson Inc., which is developing the project. "We hope people who would build on the edge of town will come here."
In Montana and throughout the West growth usually means strip development, with fast-food restaurants, car lots and big- box stores on the edges of town, a pattern that has led to rampant sprawl, the loss of farms and ranches and traffic congestion. The town-center developers hope to enhance the density of downtown and to draw some development back to within city limits.
Helena was born as a free-wheeling mining camp in 1864 when four prospectors stopped to look for "color" along a creek. It was their last chance to find gold before they headed back to the thriving goldfields at Alder Gulch, farther south in Montana. One of the men, Reginald Stanley, recounted in a letter how he felt as he washed some gravel. "Three or four little flat, smooth nuggets and some fine gold was the result; nuggets that made the pan ring when dropped into it -- and a very refreshing sound it was."
OTHER miners, many of them Civil War veterans, flocked to the rich diggings and a settlement of hastily constructed log cabins, tents and dugouts sprang up along "Last Chance Gulch," which is still the name of the city's main street. In less than a year there were 3,000 people living on the gulch and 45 stores, 14 saloons, 7 restaurants, and offices for 10 doctors and 16 lawyers.
Crime became a problem in the boom town, so a secret group of citizens, primarily Masons, formed a Vigilance Committee to summarily apprehend, try and hang bandits and other felons. Between 1865 and 1870 at least 13 men were hanged from a large pine tree by the committee, and a note was often pinned to the body warning others to mend their ways or suffer a similar fate. The heritage of the self-appointed posse is still celebrated with a parade down Last Chance Gulch every May.
In an evolution typical of mining towns, affluence led to permanent structures to replace wooden stores, saloons and hotels. And as the silver and gold mining industry grew, the wooden structures gave way to granite-and-brick office buildings, banks and retail businesses, all built on top of the now-buried creek where gold was originally found. Dozens of nuggets, gold dust and flakes taken from the area are on display in a museum in a Norwest bank downtown.
Historic photos from the 1880's show Helena as a bustling city, its streets lined with office buildings and crowded with carriages at a time when most of the West was still wilderness. At one time the city had more millionaires per capita than any city in the country.
But mining was dealt a blow by the Silver Panic of 1893 when the Federal Government removed silver price supports. The downtown stopped growing and then entered a slow decline and gambling and prostitution flourished. The last brothel, called Big Dorothy's, was raided and closed in 1973.
In the 1960's urban renewal came to Helena and more than 250 historic buildings, some of them architecturally noteworthy, were demolished. Some development filled in the gaps, but for a long time the downtown languished.
In recent years, however, Montana's economy has improved. The scenic downtown, which is nestled at the foot of timber-draped peaks and less than a 10-minute walk from the surrounding Helena National Forest's hiking trails, has recovered, with offices replacing some stores. Retail and office space downtown is in demand.
A large number of unusual downtown historic buildings still remain. The Great Northern Town Center, for example, is being built behind the Helena Civic Center, a huge building resembling an Islamic mosque with a prayer tower that was constructed by the Shriners in the 1920's.
There is some concern by merchants in the existing downtown that the new development could draw businesses away. "People are nervous," said Paul Reichert, executive director of the Downtown Helena Business Improvement District. "But I think it's positive. Basically it fills in an eyesore in the heart of our downtown. I hope people will see downtown as a larger entity."
THE town center will foster a pedestrian scale and incorporate traffic-calming features. Its main street, Great Northern Boulevard, is only 24 feet wide, instead of the more traditional 40 feet. The street has six-inch risers in some places to slow traffic.
The structures in the new development will echo the rest of this city's 19th-century downtown architecture. "All of the building lots are zero lot lines," said Mike Dowling, an architect with Dowling Tintinger in Helena who designed the town center. "You have to build your building to the lot line to encourage an urban fabric. No gaps. That's a historic concept that doesn't exist today."
To foster a sense of a traditional downtown and encourage owner occupancy, covenants require that first floors of all but the all-office building be retail businesses, second and third floors be for offices and fourth floors be for homes. The covenants also encourage the use of brick and stone instead of metal and glass and require slots for windows rather than walls of glass.
"They'll be modern buildings, but classical modern buildings," said Mr. Nicholson.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Kimberly Stewart And John Butler

 BODY:
Kimberly Lynn Stewart and John Hudson Butler were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Roseland, N.J. The Rev. Frank McNulty performed the ceremony.
Mrs. Butler, 32, is a vice president of Marina Maher Communications, a public relations company in New York. She graduated from Hamilton College. She is a daughter of Mary Stewart of Fayetteville, N.Y., and John Stewart of Jamesville, N.Y. Her father, who is retired, owned the Stewart Group, a real estate appraising and consulting company in Syracuse. Her mother teaches home economics at Cazenovia (N.Y.) High School.
Mr. Butler, 38, is a vice president and senior stock analyst, covering the telecommunications equipment industry, for Prudential Securities in New York. He graduated from Lafayette College and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania.
He is a son of Eileen and Robert Butler of Essex Fells, N.J. His mother is a broker in the Montclair, N.J., office of Weichert Realty. His father, a former chief financial officer of the International Paper Company in Purchase, N.Y., is the chairman of the advisory council of the Financial Accounting Standards Board in Norwalk, Conn., the accounting industry's governing board.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KEW GARDENS;
On Alert for Concealed Candy

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIR 

 BODY:
People have become accustomed to having their bags searched at airports, courthouses, schools and even stadiums. Now, moviegoers in Kew Gardens Hills can add their local theater to the list.
Ticket takers at Main Street Cinemas are requiring patrons to open their knapsacks and pocketbooks so they can check for any "outside" candy, beverages or other food, items not allowed in the theater. 
 Among patrons who find the policy intrusive is Selma Moses, 64. When she took her 7-year-old grandson to see "Mulan" on July 12, Mrs. Moses was asked to unzip her macrame handbag. She protested, but said a manager told her the theater had the right to inspect her bag and if she refused he would refund her money.
"How could I disappoint this child?" she asked. So she acquiesced, revealing no contraband. But then she fumed through the entire movie. "What right is it of theirs to know what I've got in my pocketbook?"
Mrs. Moses is not alone in her indignation. Since The Queens Tribune reported the incident two weeks ago, it has received more than a dozen phone calls and nearly that many letters, said Jeremy Olshan, the managing editor. A Queens woman, Jean Chiffriller, wrote that after turning over her Kit Kat bar at the door, she has boycotted the theater.
Mark Serale, co-owner of the theater, on Main Street near 73d Avenue, defended his policy, begun in late 1996. He said it discourages people from sneaking in candy, beer, weapons and videocameras. But Mr. Searle admits it also bolsters concession sales at the movie house and its sister theater in Sunnyside. "I am not going to lie, part of it is economic," he said.
In a survey released last week, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs found a pattern of high movie concession markups; for example, a 6-ounce box of Twizzlers cost $1.25 at Pathmark supermarkets but an average of $2.47 at city theaters. (The survey found Main Street Cinemas comparatively inexpensive. They charge $4 for a large container of popcorn; the citywide average is $4.27.)
Defending his policy, Mr. Serale also said, "Some people think it's unfair, but if you go into some retail shops, they won't even let you bring a bag in. You've got to check it."
The policy is rare in the film business, though. While most large chains apparently ban or discourage outside food, Maryann Grasso, executive director of the National Association of Theater Owners, said she has never heard of a theater prying into someone's parcels. Mark Pascucci, a spokesman for Sony/Loews Cineplex Entertainment, said, "If somebody walks in with a pizza, yes, we would ask them to put it aside and return it to them when the show is over." But, "searching people's bags and patting them down is contrary to the mood we want to establish." RICHARD WEIR

HEADLINE: COLLEGE & MONEY;
Students Abroad Find A Wealth of Choices, And Even Bargains

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

 BODY:
A generation ago, American collegians going abroad were typically well-bred women with rich or indulgent parents, students whose commitment to mastering the pluperfect sometimes wavered before the myriad enticements of Paris or Madrid.
While distractions remain, foreign study these days is a far different proposition. No longer confined largely to language courses, study abroad offers a vast array of places and subjects from which to choose. 
 And students have no need for investment-banker lineage. In fact, they may save money by spending a semester or two abroad -- perhaps as much as 50 percent off the cost of a private American college, which can range from $20,000 to more than $30,000 a year.
"I don't know any country that has colleges as expensive as here," said Paulo Sotero Marques, a Brazilian journalist who lives in Washington and has three college-age children.
Nissa Petersen spent the 1997-1998 academic year studying sociology at University College in Cork, Ireland. The cost, including housing and one-way air fare but not meals, came to $15,200 -- not inexpensive but significantly less than the $20,000 or so she would have paid to Salem College in Winston-Salem, N.C., where she was enrolled back home.
"I was pleasantly surprised," said Virginia Petersen, Nissa's mother. "I thought it would end up costing more." For her part, Nissa Petersen said the savings gave her the sense "that I wasn't gallivanting around at my parents' expense."
Heidi Janes, 18, of Chevy Chase, Md., who spent her freshman year at Reed College in Portland, Ore., heads off this month to Capital Normal University in China. She needed to stretch her resources, since her parents had set aside a specified amount for her education. She looked to China for a bargain year expected to cost $7,500, including room and board, far less than the $28,000 she would have paid to stay in Portland. "She believed she had to do something like this to be able to graduate from Reed," Heidi's mother, Elizabeth, said.
Adding to the possible savings is the fact that students can sometimes apply their financial aid to foreign studies. While state aid and grants and scholarships from the home college cannot always be applied, Federal aid like Stafford loans and Pell grants can; in fact, it's a requirement.
But no matter how much less a foreign program appears to cost, students need to check whether they still have to pay their school at home the full domestic tuition. Among the increasing number that do are Wesleyan and Columbia Universities, Swarthmore College, the University of Pennsylvania and, beginning in the 2000-2001 academic year, Smith College.
Some institutions are "shutting the doors," said William Hoffa, a foreign-study consultant in Amherst, Mass. "The new compact is, 'You owe us eight semesters worth of tuition, regardless.' "
Students do tend to remain enrolled in a college or university at home while studying abroad, and American schools generally grant full credit for their foreign study. But because methods of evaluation vary widely by country, grades are normally disregarded in calculating grade-point averages.
More than 80 percent of students enrolling in foreign-study programs do so through their own schools or other American colleges. They can also apply on their own directly to foreign universities, taking a route that is becoming somewhat more popular, largely because it is the least expensive option. But undergraduates don't always have this choice. Some colleges will not let their students go independently and still have the work blessed with home-school credit.
With hundreds of foreign-study programs, finding the right one often involves one of the two dominant placement bureaus that have made a business of linking American students with appropriate courses in foreign institutions. One is the Institute for Study Abroad at Butler University in Indianapolis; the other is Beaver College in Glenside, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia. The broker, who takes care of all arrangements and continuing supervision, is paid a fee that varies by place and situation and is built into the total cost quoted.
Students seeking the widest options may want to consult one or more of the standard references published by the
Institute of International Education in New York (Web site: www.iie.org). These include "Academic Year Abroad" ($44.95), "Vacation Study Abroad" ($39.95) and "Financial Resources for International Study" ($39.95). A free pamphlet called "Basic Facts on Study Abroad" is also available. All can be ordered by writing to I.I.E. Books, P.O. Box 371, Annapolis Junction, Md. 20701; by calling (800) 445-0443, or by connecting to the institute's on-line catalogue (www.iiebooks.org). Another useful reference is "Peterson's Study Abroad" ($29.95), from Peterson's, P.O. Box 2123, Princeton, N.J. 08543; (800) 338-3282 (www.petersons.com).
Of course, students study abroad for reasons that transcend finances: to expand their cultural horizons, and their resume. The following choices meet those criteria, but also are regarded as good value.
 
Britain and Ireland
Studying in foreign countries is not a guaranteed bargain. London and other major cities in Western Europe can be expensive. But Britain is still the most popular choice for Americans, attracting more than 25 percent of those going abroad, and it offers a wealth of programs.
Beaver College, which places the most American students in Britain, deals with 28 universities there, including University College London, known for its economics department ($19,900 for the full year, including housing but not meals). City University in London offers a popular program in which students attend classes two days a week and intern three days a week in places like the London Zoo and Parliament ($18,000 a year, including housing but not meals).
Beaver also places students in Ireland. University College Galway exerts the strongest pull on Americans, especially those of Irish descent, because of the sizable Irish-speaking community and its idyllic, west-country bayside location. (The cost is $8,700 for the fall semester, $15,200 for a full year, including lodging and one-way air fare but not meals.) Other highly regarded places are University College in Cork, which specializes in Irish studies and music, and the Institute of Public Administration, where students work as unpaid aides to members of Parliament.
Beaver College Center for Education Abroad, 450 South Easton Road, Glenside, Pa. 19038; (888) 232-8379 (www. beaver.edu/cea/).
Rutgers University has a junior-year program for study at one of 10 English and Scottish universities that students are assigned to after they are accepted into the program. Students from other colleges and universities get secondary consideration. Costs range from $14,280 a year for New Jersey residents to attend the Universities of Bristol and Sussex to a high of $21,370 for students from other states who attend University College London. The prices do not include room, board or air fare.
The other universities are those of Exeter, Manchester, Reading, York, Glasgow and St. Andrews and City University in London.
Rutgers Study Abroad Office, 102 College Ave., New Bruns-wick, N.J. 08903; (732) 932-7787 (www.rutgers.edu/academics/study/uabroad/sao.html).
 
Germany
Germany has some of the biggest potential bargains because all its institutions of higher education are government-financed. Under an increasingly rare policy, as more countries end or sharply limit subsidies for noncitizens, foreigners are not charged tuition.
As might be expected, however, this policy has led to an emphasis on one-for-one exchanges between American and German students, making arrangements more difficult. A good source of information on scholarships, visas and other foreign-study matters is the New York office of the German Academic Exchange Service, 950 Third Ave., New York 10022; (212) 758-3223 (www.daad.org).
One seasoned American operator, the Institute for the International Education of Students in Chicago, has setup its own programs instead of brokering students. One is in Berlin ($9,000 a semester, $16,200 for a full year, including lodging but not meals), and two are in Freiburg. One Freiburg program, on the European Union, costs $8,400 for the semester, including lodging but not meals.
Institute for the International Education of Students, 223 WestOhio St., Chicago, Ill. 60610; (800) 995-2300 (www.iesabroad.org).
The University of Maryland University College runs sizable German programs, mostly for the military, but it also offers one in Schwabisch Gmund for civilians planning careers in international business. This English-language curriculum costs $11,000 a year for Marylanders and $16,000 for nonresidents, including room and board.
U.M.U.C. International Programs, University Boulevard at Adelphi Road, College Park, Md. 20742; (301) 985-7442 (www. umuc.edu/internat/germany.html).
 
Italy
Florence, not Rome, is the most popular Italian destination for American students, with Georgetown University, Smith College and Sarah Lawrence College offering programs of some renown. But the program that educators usually mention first is run by Syracuse University, which for more than 30 years has been a sizable presence with its own campus in this arts capital, a virtual museum without walls. Art history and architecture are the chief subjects of study for the American contingent -- 200 strong last semester.
This program is unlikely to be a money-saver, though, because Syracuse charges the same amount, about $13,000 a semester, that students pay at its campus in New York State. The price includes housing, some meals and one-way air fare. Students who join the program from higher-priced universities might find Florence cheaper than, say, Yale or Princeton, but even as a financial wash, the sunny seat of the Medicis is hard to resist.
Division of International Programs Abroad, Syracuse University, 119 Euclid Ave., Syracuse, N.Y. 13244; (800) 235-3472 (sum web.syr.edu/dipa).
Fairfield University, a Jesuit institution in Connecticut, offers two monthlong summer programs and one-semester and full-year programs. Cris Bowers, Florence Program Assistant, Fairfield University, Dolan House, Fairfield, Conn. 06430; (203) 254-4220 (www.fairfield. edu/sce/index.htm).
New York University has begun offering a year in Florence for freshmen. New York University Study Abroad Admissions, 7 East 12th St., Room 608, New York 10003; (212) 998-4433 (www. nyu.edu/studyabroad/under graduate/florence.html).
 
Central and South America
The University of Costa Rica attracts students interested in the rain forest and other environmental subjects; a brochure mentions the country's 800 varieties of butterflies. The university has become such a magnet for foreigners that some students have complained about a lack of connection to the local populace.
The University of Kansas sponsors a highly regarded program that costs only $5,300 a semester, $4,300 for those enrolled at the Kansas school. This price covers everything but transportation and includes intense Spanish-language study.
Office of Study Abroad, University of Kansas, 108W Lippincott, Lawrence, Kan. 66045; (785) 864-3742 (www.ukans.edu/osa/).
The University of Illinois leads an American consortium that expects to place 70 students in one or more of three top institutions in Buenos Aires this fall. The three are the University of Buenos Aires, still a center of political ferment but not as strike-prone as it used to be; the Catholic University of Salvador, and Torcuato Di Tella University, which has rigorous economics and business programs.
"This isn't a fun-in-the-sun type of program," said Joan Solaun, foreign-study director at the University of Illinois, noting that the program requires two weeks of orientation at an Andes retreat. Tuition, room and board come to $7,985 a semester.
Study Abroad, University of Illinois, 115 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth St., Champaign, Ill. 61820; (217) 333-6322 (www.uiuc.edu/providers/ ips/sao/).
 
The Middle East
Israel offers many choices for foreign students. Its five principal universities have formed a consortium to coordinate efforts, but each maintains individual admissions requirements and sets its own price, although costs for each are around $10,000 a year for tuition and housing. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem and Tel Aviv University are the most popular choices of American students. Bar-Ilan University, in a Tel Aviv suburb, concentrates on Jewish heritage; Ben-Gurion University of the Negev in Beersheba offers a desert experience, and the University of Haifa exploits its location in a cosmopolitan port city and center for high technology.
The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Office of Academic Affairs, 11 East 69th St., New York 10021; (800) 404-8622 (www2.huji.ac.il/www/usfos/top.html). Tel Aviv University, Office of Academic Affairs, 360 Lexington Ave., New York 10017; (800) 665-9828. Bar-Ilan University, Office of Academic Affairs, 91 Fifth Ave., Suite 200, New York 10003; (888) 248-9327. Ben-Gurion University, Center for International Student Programs, 342 Madison Ave., Suite 1224, New York 10173; (800) 962-2248 (www.bgu.ac.il/osp/). University of Haifa, Overseas Student Programs, 352 Seventh Ave., New York 10001; (800) 334-0755 (www.haifa.ac.il).
An intriguing new Arab-studies program is being offered this fall in Sana, capital of newly unified Yemen in the southwestern corner of the Arabian peninsula, along ancient trade routes for spices and luxury goods. The 10-week program consists of Arabic and two other courses: one on the country's 5,000-year history, the other on its current political science. Study of Arabic is recommended before starting the program, but it is not required. Registration is through Portland State University in Oregon, which has more than 30 years of experience in the Middle East. The Yemeni program costs $5,500, which covers tuition, lodging and at least one meal a day.
Study Abroad, Portland State University, P.O. Box 751, Portland, Ore. 97207; (503) 725-8246 (www.oaa.pdx.edu/International /InternationalEd/studyabroad).
 
Australia
Sydney, host to the Olympic Games in 2000, is becoming a highly popular destination for American students. In size and breadth of curricula, institutions like the University of Sydney and the University of New South Wales are similar to state-financed universities in the United States. The cost is $11,500 to $12,000 a semester, including housing and air fare, but not meals. The first semester runs from February to June and the second from July to November.
A student must take a full course load to qualify for a student visa, and a guidebook cautions that foreign students are sometimes "surprised at the workload required of them."
Butler is the main broker for Australian study. But students can save money by enrolling directly at, say, the University of Sydney, paying about $6,675 a semester for tuition, room and meals.
Institute for Study Abroad, Butler University, 4600 Sunset Ave., Indianapolis, Ind. 46208; (800) 858-0229, (www.butler.edu/ www/isa). Study Abroad Adviser, University of Sydney, NSW Australia 2006; 61-2-9351-5841 (www.usyd.edu.au/su/io).

HEADLINE: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

BYLINE: By ALEXANDRA McGINLEY 

 BODY:

UPPER WEST SIDE
Settlement Houses Mean Much More Than Services
"Uniting Neighbors: The Role of Settlement Houses in New York City," exhibits more than 150 photos and artifacts at the New-York Historical Society through Oct. 4.
Besides social services, settlement houses were active in advocacy and reform movements. This exhibition chronicles their involvement in issues like housing, public health, labor laws and unemployment insurance. 
 University Settlement, the first such house in the United States, opened on the Lower East Side in 1886. Today, there are 38 such houses in New York City under an umbrella group, United Neighborhood Houses.
A 1924 photo of Abraham D. Beame, the future Mayor, and his future wife, Mary Ingerman, at University Settlement's Camp Beacon is shown here. Mr. Beame had joined a boys' club at the settlement house.
"Uniting Neighbors: The Role of Settlement Houses in New York" at the New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street (at Central Park West); $5 for adults, $3 for students and people 62 or over; Tuesdays through Sundays from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; (212) 873-3400.
 
MIDTOWN
8 Rodin Masterpieces Fill a Sculpture Garden
Visitors to the Channel Gardens at Rockefeller Center are immediately greeted by Rodin's powerful sculpture "The Three Shades," shown here. The garden will be filled with eight of Rodin's muscular figures, framed by a row of Italian cypresses, through Aug. 31.
Figures from "The Burghers of Calais," along with "Whistler's Muse," "Meditation," "Monumental Torso of the Walking Man" and "The Thinker" are in this free show.
Rodin at Rockefeller Center on Fifth Avenue, enter between 49th and 50th Streets; daily through Aug. 31; free; (212) 632-3975.
 
PARK SLOPE
Silent Films, Salsa And Blaxploitation Sound

On Friday Nona Hendryx and Sandra St. Victor join the Black Rock Coalition Orchestra in "The Blaxploitation Songbook," evoking sound tracks of films like "Shaft," "Super fly" and "Foxy Brown."
On Saturday, the band shell will sway to the salsa of Ray Barretto and his orchestra, and pieces by William Cepeda's Boricua Ensemble and Yomo Torro. The concert will cap the Boricua Festival, Puerto Rican cultural events in Prospect Park from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.
"The Unknown," 8 P.M. Thursday; Black Rock Coalition Orchestra at 7:30 P.M. Friday; Ray Baretto 7:30 P.M. Saturday, Prospect Park Band Shell at Ninth Street and Prospect Park West; suggested donation $3; (718) 855-7882, ext. 52.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Strike Force;
The Relentless March Of Labor's True Foe

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
THE 54-day General Motors strike erupted over local issues, like the auto maker's push to speed up work at a plant in Flint, Mich., but the strike shared a theme with walkouts as far away as Denmark and South Korea.
Underlying these strikes and others is labor's push to resist what many economists say is an irresistible force: globalization, which opens markets to fierce competition. Globalization has pushed G.M. and other companies to reduce costs, and has created downward pressures on wages in wealthy countries. It has pushed companies to downsize, transfer jobs overseas and press their workers to produce more. 
 It was G.M.'s effort to take many of these steps -- to speed up production and to transfer work to low-wage Mexican factories -- that precipitated the strike, which was settled last Tuesday after paralyzing production and idling 190,000 workers.
Labor leaders say they are trying to slow -- and possibly even tame -- globalization, to make it less hostile to workers, and limit, for example, the exportation of jobs. But many economists say unions can neither slow nor stop globalization, a trend in which the economies of the world are growing ever closer and competition keener.
"I think they're fighting history," said Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington-based research group. "It's partly a doomed effort to preserve an old way of life that's not preservable."
Also, the G.M. strike and other anti-globalization actions may backfire by provoking companies to accelerate plans to export jobs so they can minimize their dealings with truculent unions.
The G.M. strike can backfire in other ways. With the dealers complaining that their lots are depleted, sales of G.M. cars are expected to fall, and the consequent loss in market share will pressure the auto maker to close more plants and lay off more workers.
Some Wall Street analysts predict that G.M., frustrated by the union's resistance to cost-cutting measures at individual plants, will simply close several plants altogether to slash costs.
Bruce Josten, executive vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said unions were often short-sighted in fighting efforts, like G.M.'s, to cut costs in the face of global competition. "General Motors management has to do what it's doing, as painful as it is, and bite the bullet now," Mr. Josten said. "If they don't do that now, G.M.'s market share will diminish. It will become increasing less competitive and ultimately there will be fewer G.M. employees due to layoffs."
But labor unions are stepping up their battle against globalization. In California, the nation's largest apparel union has protested Guess's decision to move jeans production to Mexico.
In South Korea, workers staged a rash of strikes, angry that foreign pressure to open markets and to stop subsidizing industry is undermining their job security. In Denmark two months ago, 500,000 workers struck after employers resisted demands for six weeks of vacation, saying they could not afford it because of foreign competition.
 
Shaping History
 Labor leaders acknowledge it is impossible to halt globalization, saying their goal is to transform it into a less harmful force.
"Trade unions are trying to shape history, not reverse it," said David A. Smith, director of public policy for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
"We're not going to put the globalization genie back in the battle," Mr. Smith said. "Whether it's workers in Flint or workers in Seoul, people are wrestling with the question of, 'How are we in this moment of epochal change going to make this work for working people?' "
The unions argue that corporations gain too many of the benefits of untamed globalization, fattening profits while squeezing wages and encouraging downsizing. And they say they are fighting for all workers, not just for union members.
"History will show you that wherever there have been strong trade unions, there has been a fairer distribution of the wealth created," said Bill Jordan, general secretary of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, a coalition of unions from 141 countries.
Many economists say globalization is boosting not just corporations but the world at large by helping hold down prices, by pressuring industry to increase efficiency and by making more inexpensive products available to consumers.
And, economists point out, globalization sometimes helps push wages up, not down. Boeing and Microsoft, for example, can pay high salaries partly because of the immense foreign demand for their products.
Still, concerned that globalization could prove the great downward leveler of wages, union leaders often state that their goal is "upward leveling" -- to improve wages and working conditions abroad.
Last November, when American unions pressured Congress to shelve legislation to extend free trade to other nations, labor was often branded as protectionist.
But unions defended themselves, saying they would go along with the legislation as long as new trade agreements guaranteed labor and environmental rights.
"If you raise labor standards in low-wage countries, that's good for them and it's good for us," said Frank Borgers, a professor of labor relations at the University of Massachusetts. "It would slow the exodus of jobs."
