HEADLINE: U.S. Officials, in Indonesia, Warn Rulers to Respect Rights

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 1

 BODY:
With American officials warning that Indonesia is on the verge of economic and social collapse, a Clinton Administration delegation led by Defense Secretary William S. Cohen called on Indonesia's new President and military commanders today to honor their pledge to end human rights abuses and show restraint if Government opponents take to the streets again.
Mr. Cohen is the highest-ranking American official to visit Indonesia since President Suharto was forced to resign last May after 32 years in power. He said that the country, the world's fourth most populous, was in the midst of a crisis and that he had urged its leaders to move quickly "toward a democratic form of government." 
 The Defense Secretary described his meetings here with President B. J. Habibie, Mr. Suharto's former Vice President and his successor, and Gen. Wiranto, the military commander, as "very open, very candid." He said he was encouraged by their response. Mr. Habibie, he said, "indicated his strong commitment to place human rights at a very high level of concern and his commitment to the people of Indonesia."
More than 1,200 people were killed in May in the rioting that led to President Suharto's resignation.
The end of the Suharto era did not halt the staggering economic slide of Indonesia, which now faces its worst economic crisis in decades. An estimated 100 million people -- about half of the population -- are expected to sink below the poverty line by the end of the year. The crisis has wiped out 30 years of impressive economic growth. Malnutrition is widespread and growing.
Administration officials say that Mr. Cohen and senior American military commanders were sent to Indonesia this week in hopes that such a high-level visit would impress the country's military. As the strongest Government institution in Indonesia, it may hold the key to the future of this sprawling archipelago nation.
Ties in recent years between American and Indonesian military commanders have been close -- far too close, according to rights groups in Indonesia.
The Pentagon has been embarrassed by reports that an elite American-trained Indonesian military unit was responsible for some of the killings in May, as well as the kidnappings of democracy activists who have still not been found.
The special forces unit, known as Kopassus, was led at the time of the riots by Lieut. Gen. Prabowo Subianto, a son-in-law of Mr. Suharto who is known to be especially close to his American military counterparts. General Prabowo has since been demoted by General Wiranto, his military rival.
Mr. Cohen held a news conference at the Defense Ministry after meeting here with General Wiranto (who like many Indonesians uses only one name). The Defense Secretary said he had urged the Indonesian commander to press forward with investigations of the military's responsibility for the recent violence.
"I do know that the Indonesian Government has a number of investigations under way in terms of any abuses of human rights," Mr. Cohen said. "It's important that such investigations be carried out openly, honestly, with integrity. And if that is done, it will enjoy the support of the Indonesian people and the commendation of the world community."
The United States suspended most of its ties to the Indonesian military as a result of the uprising in May. Yet despite the allegations that American-trained troops might have been responsible for some of the worst of the violence, Mr. Cohen said the United States hoped to "build upon a military relationship in the future."
He added, "We would not be resuming our normal military-to-military relations at this time; hopefully in the coming months that can be a reality."
Other American officials here said the Defense Department had determined that even if American-trained soldiers had committed some of the murders, the United States should continue to work with the military, to maintain influence over what happens next. Indonesia is considered important to American economic and strategic interests in Asia.
One official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that "we want to find out whether American-trained forces were involved, but we don't begin from the proposition that even if they were, that somehow means that the training programs were wrong." He said it was "wrong to damn the whole program simply" because of the actions of a fraction of its graduates.
Mr. Cohen said today that the Indonesian military decision to withdraw some combat troops from East Timor was also "very encouraging."
President Habibie has vowed to find ways of providing greater autonomy to East Timor, the former Portuguese colony that Indonesia invaded in 1975 and annexed in 1976. The disputed territory has been the scene of fierce fighting between the Indonesian military and separatists, and troops have repeatedly been accused of rights abuses.
Last week the Indonesian Army began the withdrawal of 1,000 fighters from East Timor in what it said was a gesture of good will. Its force of soldiers and police officers there numbers about 11,000.
Mr. Cohen welcomed the move today. "I think there have been some encouraging signs as far as a willingness to try to resolve the tensions and the friction over East Timor," he said.

HEADLINE: Mainers Say Hello Headsets, Farewell Chicken Plucking

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG

DATELINE: BELFAST, Me.

 BODY:
The tide used to blush red with chicken blood here and when it ebbed, leave watermarks written in feathers. Flurries of down sometimes whitened Main Street, as if left by a town pillow-fight. Pleasure boats shunned the harbor, fearing the slimy fat that would coat their hulls. And summer visitors, not used to the smell, held their noses as they passed from odor to odor: the poultry plants, the sewage plant, the fish plant.
Such are residents' unaffectionate memories of Belfast a decade or two ago, when the economy of this sloping-to-the-sea city of 6,500 residents was dominated by poultry processing, one of the heavy, messy industries Maine has been known for through much of the century. 
 But now, Belfast is becoming the poster town for the quick-spreading change taking place as the state -- long famed for its textile mills, paper plants and shoe factories -- makes a belated entry into the post-industrial age. In what Gov. Angus King advertises as the most striking transformation of a Maine town by higher-tech industry, Belfast's rubber-boot jobs -- most lost when plants closed -- are being more than replaced by telephone-headset jobs, of the sort that have turned other states, like Nebraska and Wyoming, into headset hot spots.
"We're not chicken pluckers anymore; we're telecommunicators," said Gail Berry, a 49-year-old Belfast native and former hairstylist.
Ms. Berry works for MBNA, the largest independent credit-card lender in the world. So do 1,500 other people in the mall-like building the company opened here in 1996, handling calls from credit-card users or would-be users, and their numbers are expected to swell by 2,000 more. Across Maine, such call centers have become the state's largest new industry in the last decade, creating more than 10,000 jobs.
Call centers are "the sort of post-industrial analogue to the mill economy," said Charles Colgan, an economist at the University of Southern Maine. "In a way, they have replaced the textile and apparel and shoe mills in the sense that they employ moderately skilled people, a large number of them, at a lower cost than you would employ those same people in a larger urban setting, and at a much lower cost for the land and buildings."
That mill analogy may help to explain what seems at first a psychological mystery to outsiders: the lack of unanimous rejoicing over the call centers.
After all, a company like MBNA has created thousands of nonpolluting jobs where they were much needed; the jobs offer health insurance and other benefits and pay not badly for hereabouts, beginning at an average first-year salary and bonuses of $25,000; employees work in seas of cubicles in airy, climate-controlled rooms. On top of all that, the company has given millions in charity to local hospitals, libraries and schools.
And yet, ask people in Belfast about MBNA and the feelings they express are often decidedly mixed. Their appreciation of the jobs and the philanthropy is swirled with unease and skepticism over an arrival of such size, with so much money, and with a powerful corporate culture of slogans, performance incentives, suburban-looking design and even jacket-and-tie dressing much more familiar in, say, Connecticut than in rural Maine.
"I don't hate it," said Ryan Brown, tending bar one recent night at Bruno's & Rico's Pub, a shabby-cozy, bear-cave of a town bar. "It's just that, would you rather live and die on your own time cutting sardines or would you rather be bought and paid for and owned by MBNA?"
"At least," countered Mike Reynolds, who runs the laundry next door, when you work for MBNA, "you don't smell like fish when you get out of work."
And at least people have work. Maine has lagged about two years behind the national recovery from the recession of the late 1980's, and though it has replaced all the jobs it had lost and begun expanding, it still has northern pockets where unemployment reaches 10 percent.
Belfast particularly hit the skids in the 1980's, as its shoe and poultry factories closed, and the fine old shipbuilding city gained a reputation as a druggy, dead-end spot.
By the mid-1980's, said Jay Davis, deputy editor of the weekly Maine Times, the seedlings of the city's turnaround were being planted, and outside grants came in to put in an industrial park, fix up the downtown and create a waterfront park. A new civic energy was growing among the town's disparate groups of old-time Maine families, former hippies and transplanted retirees, he said.
But there was no great influx of jobs until 1993, when MBNA, seeking to base a branch of the company in New England, brought several hundred jobs to nearby Camden, attracted in part by summertime ties the company's president, Charles M. Cawley, had to the seaside area.
And as for MBNA's arrival in Belfast in 1996, said Mr. Davis, who is co-writing a town history, "It's the biggest thing to happen to Belfast since the poultry industry in the 1950's by far."
He, too, sees the call center as an improved, 21st-century version of a mill or factory. "It's trying to do what the shoe factory did, too, which is to make money for its owners and shareholders," Mr. Davis said. "And that's what it's there for, and when it stops doing that, it's not going to be there, just like the shoe factory wasn't here anymore."
Governor King sounds less skeptical when he paints his picture of the new, improved Maine. In an interview, he spoke about the magnetism that Maine's quality of life -- its low crime and rocky beauty (he did not mention its winters) -- is exerting on high-tech workers.
The two top industries in the state remain tourism and manufacturing, with an emphasis on paper and shipbuilding. But already, Mr. King said, biotechnology, at $350 million in gross annual revenue, is a bigger money-maker for Maine than lobstering and potato farming combined.
Yet Mr. Colgan, the economist, said Maine's high-technology sector had failed to achieve the critical mass needed to take off. And the call centers, he said, should be seen mainly as great employment lifts for particular rural regions, like Belfast's Waldo County, known as one of the poorest counties in New England.
Already, MBNA has opened a call center that is likely to employ up to 200 people in Presque Isle in far-northern Aroostook County; ICT Group, another call-center company, has opened centers in the last year in inland Oxford and Pittsfield, and the Sitel Corporation has moved into remote Limestone, in distant Aroostook. L. L. Bean, known as the grandfather of Maine telephone business, is also thriving, and call centers are becoming so common that they are known to poach one another's workers in some Maine spots.
Although MBNA may not define Maine's economic future, it certainly seems likely to define much of Belfast's, at least for the near term.
"We're here and we love it here," said David Spartin, vice chairman and spokesman for MBNA, which by last year was the eighth-largest private employer in the state, with well over 3,000 workers.
That size and power disturb some people here. "My beef is that they're too big for this area, much too big," said Doug Hufnagel, a local columnist who has been one of the few residents to air doubts about MBNA in public. He has printed up scenic postcards depicting a Hollywood-like sign and satirically declaring "Welcome to Cawleywood," a reference to Mr. Cawley of MBNA.
Mr. Hufnagel's criticisms bespeak a broader culture clash: MBNA has struck many here as profligate in its willingness to tear down structures or undo decor that seems perfectly fine. Its new money can strike those used to old-money summer people as brash, and even the very business it is in -- credit -- contradicts the Maine emphasis on thrift.
Still, Mr. Hufnagel backtracked. "I don't know -- it's jobs," he said. "For a lot of people it's better than McDonald's or the chicken factory."
Some people say MBNA seems just about like heaven, and applications outnumber jobs 10 to 1, company officials say.
Before coming to work at MBNA two years ago, Lisa Ripley, 31, worked mainly at near-minimum-wage jobs in a local seafood-smoking factory and at a leather tannery. There were seasonal layoffs and little chance of advancement. Now, she said, her family is so proud of her work as a customer advocate ("You know that number on the back of your credit card? That's me.") that her grandmother insists on broadcasting that she is an MBNA "manager," even though she is not.
"I think the biggest difference between my family and me is they still get up in the morning and go to their job," Ms. Ripley said. "I get up in the morning looking forward to another day in my career."

HEADLINE: Indians Proudly Revive a Tradition of Running

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: SHIPROCK, N.M.

 BODY:
Against a backdrop of junked cars and sagging trailers, a long line of young Navajos set off one recent morning, running toward the East, running toward the rising sun.
"When the sun comes up, the gods come up, so we run to greet the gods in the morning," Kelly Upshaw, a Navajo from Fort Defiance, Ariz., said as she unwound from the run, pacing about a high school track here. "That is how my parents taught me." 
 A 20-year-old college junior, she came home to the giant Navajo Nation reservation this summer to help teach running clinics organized by Wings of America, a youth program for Indians based in Santa Fe, N.M., which is leading a running renaissance in Indian country.
"Running has its roots in the spiritual tradition," said William E. Channing, the group's president. "Running increases pride, self-esteem, cultural identity. It brings people together in a healthy life style."
Since before recorded time, American Indians ran -- for trade, for communication and for the spiritual belief that a runner creates a living cord between the earth and the sky. This tradition carried over into the 20th century when, in the 1912 Olympics, Jim Thorpe, a Sac and Fox, won gold medals in the decathlon and the pentathlon and Louis Tewanima, a Hopi, won a silver medal in the 10,000 meters.
But in recent decades, the American Indian running tradition has faltered. As the Indians' fleet-of-foot styles of life have ceded to the sedentary, health indicators for Indians have plummeted.
Here on the Navajo Nation, home to one-fifth of America's one million Indians living on reservations, one-quarter of the population has diabetes, a condition not detected here a half century ago. About one-quarter of Navajo young people are obese.
"Two generations ago, people were more active physically, growing their own food, chopping their own firewood, herding their sheep," said Dr. Chris Percy, director of Shiprock's community heath services.
On the social level, the Navajo Nation has 45 percent unemployment, high rates of drug and alcohol abuse, a teen-age suicide rate that is 3 times the national average, and a murder rate that is 4.5 times the national average. With half the reservation population under 21 years old and gangs proliferating, Navajo elders are desperate to steer the younger generation toward self-discipline and attainment of goals.
Becki Wells, 23, a Blackfoot Indian who hopes to run the 1,500 meters in the 2000 Olympics, believes she is a role model to Navajo girls who are flocking to the 17 Wings clinics on the reservation this summer.
"You can go with the alcohol and sex -- or you can go with the running," she tells teen-agers. "If you are serious about high school athletics, you are less likely to go out drinking every weekend, you are less likely to get pregnant and more likely to go to college."
The revival of running among Indians is easily seen here in Shiprock, one of the Navajos' largest towns. At Shiprock High School, which was built within view of the town's 7,200-foot-high namesake butte, running teams for boys and girls draw about one-fifth of the 500 students eligible for school sports.
Reynalda Harry, a 15-year-old Navajo, said that running builds pride at her school, Newcomb High School. "We are lifting up the school, showing people we are not just a low-class high school," she said.
Wings is successfully tapping American Indians' dormant running talent. Every year since Wings was founded in 1988, the group has sent teams of boys and girls in the 14-to-19 age group to the National Cross Country Championships sponsored by USA Track and Field. Wings teams have finished first 9 times out of a possible 20 times.
Although Wings clinics have been held on 60 reservations, from the Penobscot in Maine to the Jicarilla Apache in New Mexico, the strongest runners often come from the Southwest, in part because of high-altitude training.
"We get calls every week from Indian communities around the country, but there is not a huge percentage we can help without more money," Mr. Channing said. The organization's largest corporate sponsor is Nike, which this year covers almost one-quarter of Wings's $250,000 budget, and about $70,000 in shorts, shoes, shirts, caps and bags.
The impact of running on self-esteem could be seen tattooed on the right arm of Tim Martin, a Navajo running instructor who prefers his tribe's traditional name, Dine. Leaving behind high school friends in dead-end jobs, the 24-year-old Wings runner is completing his college education this year and sporting a tattoo on his shoulder. Under a green-blue spear is printed: Dine-Warrior.
"When I go out, I want people to know I am Navajo," he said. "It drives me to run harder."

HEADLINE: As the Old-Line Anglican Churches Wilt, Those in Africa Flower Profusely

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR

DATELINE: CANTERBURY, England, Aug. 1

 BODY:
As the world's Anglican bishops are gathered in this historic cathedral city for their once-a-decade meeting, the Lambeth Conference, a major trend can be discerned among the lists of those invited to attend.
For the first time since these conferences began 130 years ago, the bishops who are heads of dioceses in the Church of England, the Episcopal Church and the Anglican Churches of Canada and Australia -- which historically sent missionaries abroad -- are outnumbered by their counterparts from the Anglican churches of Africa and Asia -- the continents to which so many of those missionaries were sent. 
 It is a sign of something larger, say some bishops and academic experts who study religious trends, that among the 37 churches that make up the Anglican Communion (and within other branches of Christianity as well), the center of gravity is gradually shifting toward the Southern Hemisphere. The faith there is growing rapidly, while many churches in North America and Europe increase slowly or even decline.
Within Anglicanism, "the growth takes place mostly in the south, in the developing churches," said Bishop Simon Chiwanga, a leading prelate at the conference, who is head of the Diocese of Mpwapwa, in east central Tanzania.
When his diocese was created out of a larger church jurisdiction in 1991, it contained 93,000 members of the Church of the Province of Tanzania, the Anglican church there. But since then, he said, his flock has increased to about 120,000 -- a figure greater than the number of Episcopalians in New York City and northern New Jersey combined.
Unlike Congressional districts in the United States, church dioceses are not devised to be roughly equal in population. But an expansion in their number within a particular church typically signifies membership growth. In addition, an increase in the number of bishops from a particular region means a rise in that region's influence within a larger religious organization, like the Anglican Communion.
Officials here said the churches represented at the last Lambeth Conference, in 1988, comprised about 500 dioceses, while this year the number is nearly 600, with the difference coming largely from among the African churches. The Tanzanian church sent bishops from 12 dioceses in 1988. It currently has 16 dioceses. Ten years ago, the Church of the Province of Nigeria had 26 dioceses; now it has 61.
In keeping with their increased numbers, the bishops from Africa and Asia have helped set the tone of discussions at this year's conference, which might be described as economically liberal and socially conservative.
The conference, for example, has expressed deep concern over foreign debts carried by developing nations, declaring that these impose a financial burden that keep poor countries mired in poverty.
At the same time, some African bishops have sided with church conservatives against any attempt by liberal bishops from the United States and Europe to adopt a more welcoming stance toward homosexuals in the church.
In all, about 800 bishops are attending the conference, some of them assistant bishops and others suffragan bishops, or bishops-elect.
The three-week gathering, a purely consultative affair that ends on Aug. 9, is being held at the University of Kent, a complex of modern beige-colored buildings atop a hill with a sweeping view of Canterbury's skyline and its massive cathedral.
This city -- popularly associated with Chaucer's pilgrims and their goal, the shrine to Thomas a Beckett -- is the seat of the Archbishop of Canterbury, spiritual leader of the Church of England, an independent religious body since King Henry VIII broke with Rome in the 1530's. Within the Anglican Communion, the Archbishop, the Most Rev. George L. Carey, lacks the power and prestige of a pope, but does possess a degree of mystical authority as a "unifying symbol" for the various Anglican churches.
As late as 1978, a majority of the world's Anglican population lived in Britain, said David B. Barrett, a professor at Regent University in Virginia Beach, Va., who is editor of the World Christian Encyclopedia, a huge compendium of statistics about churches around the globe. But today, he estimated, the British constitute only about 35 percent of 73 million Anglicans worldwide.
Dr. Barrett distributed a pamphlet to the bishops at the conference, projecting that by the year 2000, Anglicans would number 31.6 million in Africa and 6.1 million in Asia. By contrast, the Church of England estimates its current baptized membership at 26 million.
"The point is," Dr. Barrett said, the Anglican population is increasing in Africa and Asia "while in Britain, it's declining very slightly." He added that similar growth patterns prevail among Roman Catholics, Baptists, Methodists and Pentecostals and many independent churches.
According to Vatican statistics, between 1976 and 1995, the Roman Catholic population in Africa more than doubled to 107 million, while Catholics in Asia increased by 90 percent, to 101 million. Europe's Catholic population grew by less than 10 percent, to 288 million, according to those statistics.
To a degree, those changes have been reflected in the College of Cardinals, the body that chooses the popes. In the 20 years since the election of Pope John Paul II, the proportion of European cardinals in the college has declined from 50 percent to 46 percent, while the cardinals from Africa, Asia and Latin America, taken together, have risen from 36 percent to 41 percent of the total, according to figures in an analysis of the college by the Rev. Thomas Reese, editor of the Jesuit magazine "America."
For some years now, Vatican-watchers have included cardinals from outside Europe on their short lists of possible candidates for the next pope. Recently, a similar idea was raised, albeit obliquely, about the next Archbishop of Canterbury.
Among the documents available for study here at the Lambeth Conference is one known as "The Virginia Report," a consideration of the nature of the Anglican Communion, written by theologians and church leaders. Among the questions it raises is, "Does an Archbishop of Canterbury necessarily have to be a member of the Church of England?"
Those who have studied the phenomenon of church growth in developing nations, whether church leaders or academics, offer a variety of reasons for it. The churches, they say, are benefiting from general population growth trends, the desire for people migrating to cities for a sense of community, the attraction of church-run school and hospital systems, and the comfort of services that practice forms of spiritual healing.
But Archbishop Khotso Makhulu of Botswana, another leading figure at the conference, said many Christian churches had grown as they had adopted African forms of worship, incorporating music and dance into their liturgies. "The church in many areas is moving away from staid and bland expressions of Christianity," he said.
"A big day in the past would have been pretty well a Solemn High Mass Western-style, with Gregorian chant and plainsong," he said. "Now what is happening is musicologists are coming to the fore, writing African hymns."
The result, he added, is rooted in local cultural expression: "It's an affirmation of who I am before my God and the world."

The Worldwide Anglican Communion is growing faster in the developing world than its traditional bases in Britain and North America. Chart shows the number of Anglican Dioceses in various regions in 1988, 1998, and the change during the decade. (Source: World Anglican Communion)

HEADLINE: THE BOATING REPORT;
Entering Kenwood Cup With a New Perspective on Life

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
Driving across the Golden Gate Bridge recently on his way to work, Paul Cayard gave way to idle reflection. He was an hour behind schedule at his San Francisco office. And, trying as he is to begin an America's Cup campaign, each of his calendar hours looks more like a week of commitments. Not a good time to be running late.
"I knew I was late," the 39-year-old yachtsman said recently. "But I was thinking, 'I'm not in a hurry.' A year ago, I would have been completely stressed out. But the Whitbread race has put everything in perspective. Alone in the Southern Ocean, the way we were, there were those moments where you are really scared. And that really makes an impression on you." 
 The adrenaline-charged reports that Cayard sent by satellite from the 60-foot EF Language are history. Regarded at its finish last May as a stunning victory for a team of mostly round-the-buoy sailors, the achievement by the EF crew in the Whitbread Round the World Race was a personal triumph for Cayard.
But now it is back to rounding orange buoys instead of eerie white icebergs. And the next event on the list is the 11th biennial Kenwood Cup, which is expected to begin tomorrow off Honolulu.
To get back into day-racing, Cayard has agreed to sail as tactician on Illbruck-Pinta, a One Design 48 being chartered for the Hawaii series by an aspiring around-the-world team from Germany. The Germans are so committed to the next equivalent of the Whitbread in 2001-2002, which will be called the Volvo Ocean Race, that they purchased EF Language and EF Education, both former Whitbread competitors -- for training purposes. In charge of Illbruck-Pinta will be John Kostecki of San Francisco, the regular Illbruck skipper who also happens to have signed on with Cayard to participate in his America One 1999-2000 America's Cup campaign.
"It's John's program," Cayard said about the Illbruck. "I've got a huge load on my shoulders with America One, and I want to limit my responsibilities in other areas."
Cayard is struggling to find the $20 million or more in corporate sponsorship that he and most of the other 15 cup challengers are still seeking. In addition, Cayard has lost several key members of his team to competing syndicates.
The first defection came last year when Laurent Esquier, Cayard's veteran cup manager, took a job with Prada, the Italian challenger. Last spring, Steve Erickson, a longtime friend and sailing cohort in the Whitbread Round the World Race, also took a position with Prada. Then last week, Kimo Worthington left America One. Worthington is expected to sign on with Young America, the New York Yacht Club team.
For Kostecki, a vital member of the America One effort and still loyal to Cayard, sailing with his America's Cup boss is a two-way street.
"Obviously, adding Paul Cayard to our Illbruck-Pinta crew is a nice bonus for the Kenwood Cup," Kostecki said recently.
The 12-day Kenwood series includes eight day races: four ocean triangles and four windward-leeward courses of about 10-12 nautical miles each. On Friday is a 150-mile middle-distance race from Honolulu to Maui, and on Aug. 11, a 376-mile race from Oahu to Maui and back.
America's Cup teams are revving up their intensity now, with many sailors choosing to hone their skills in the Kenwood Cup. Also scheduled to race off Hawaii is Peter Gilmour, the intense but amicable skipper from Australia who has signed on with the Japanese Nippon team.
Also competing is John Kolius, helmsman for the 1D48 Abracadaba and skipper for the Aloha Racing Team of Hawaii, and Dawn Riley, the Detroit sailor who plans to campaign the America True boat in the 1999-2000 America's Cup races.
Six of the One Design 48 yachts have been transported to Hawaii for the regatta. Their presence is being felt by Ken Morrison, Kenwood's race director for the last 20 years. Since its inception as the Clipper Cup in 1978, the biennial regatta has featured team racing based on handicap rules for differently designed boats.
But that mix is eroding, as is over-all participation. A weak Asian economy this year has reduced the number of handicap entries from Japan, Australia and New Zealand. In 1982, there were a record 82 boats; now there are about 30.
Of those, the six 1D48 yachts are not competing in the long-distance race because of a tight shipping schedule. That leaves 24 boats to sail the last and most important race.
"We have to look very closely at the proliferation of One Design 48's," Morrison said about realistic prospects for a greater one-design fleet in the Kenwood Cup 2000.

HEADLINE: A Top M.B.A. Is a Hot Ticket as Salaries Climb

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The 1990's were supposed to be lean years for graduates of the nation's top business schools. Overpriced, overabundant and caricatured in movies like "Working Girl," M.B.A.'s were destined for the same fate as junk bonds and Manhattan real estate -- or so business school deans and business journalists predicted at the start of the decade.
Seven fat years later, M.B.A.'s have never been more numerous -- or more in demand. At schools in the top tier, variously defined as the top 5, 10 or 25, recruiting by companies has turned cutthroat. The typical University of Chicago graduate turns down so many job offers that the dean's main worry has become "dealing with all the disappointed companies." And the salaries of M.B.A.'s have climbed even faster in the 1990's than in the so-called Decade of Greed. The first-year pay packages of Stanford graduates, for example, have soared 62 percent after inflation in the 1990's, compared with 21 percent for the 1980's. 
 The ferocious competition for top M.B.A.'s reflects the best economy since the 1960's, specifically a surge in businesses that advise companies on new products, acquisitions or overseas expansion. It also reflects the long-term shift of pay and opportunity in today's service economy toward those with knowledge and ideas. More than anything, though, it is a sign of the extraordinary degree to which the term M.B.A. has become synonymous with raw business talent.
"You're trying to find the best people you can, and business schools happen to be accumulating them," said William Matassoni, a partner for communications at the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, which expects to hire more than 400 M.B.A.'s this year. "So you go there."
The median offer this year for a new Stanford M.B.A., for example, was $120,000, more than double the first-year salary at the peak of the 80's, and more than five times the 1978 figure. Inflation has been 142 percent over that period.
And Stanford does not boast graduates with the highest earnings. East Coast schools whose graduates are more likely to wind up in high-cost, high-pay cities like New York and Boston report even loftier starting pay. Half the graduates of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania received offers of more than $133,000 this year.
At the top 25 schools, the best compensation packages offered to new M.B.A.'s are well above $200,000. Small wonder that more of the best and the brightest are headed to business school instead of law school. A graduate of New York University Law School who joins a leading firm will make $91,000 a year, not precisely peanuts but nearly $30,000 less than a counterpart from the university's Stern School of Business. At Stanford, law school and business school graduates were neck and neck in starting pay in 1978 and in 1988, but the school's new M.B.A.'s are making 50 percent more than its law graduates this year.
What makes the pay all the more noteworthy is that an M.B.A. has become something of a commodity. In 1965, fewer than 10,000 were granted. As recently as 1977, the nation was producing 48,000 M.B.A.'s a year -- a figure sufficiently alarming to prompt Lawrence Fouraker, the dean of the Harvard Business School, to predict a collapse in starting salaries. Since then, the number has risen to 94,000, almost two and a half times the number of law degrees.
The sheer volume of M.B.A.'s is deceptive, though. The graduating classes of elite schools have grown little. The explosion has happened among the more than 600 programs that do not make it into the top 25 nationally ranked schools.
Two-thirds of the degrees are awarded to part-timers who stay on the job, who tend to be subsidized by their employers and who are looking to change career tracks or move into middle management. More than a fifth are getting degrees to start businesses, according to a recent survey by the Graduate Management Admission Council.
Starting salaries for the mass of M.B.A.'s have hardly climbed into the stratosphere. This year, the typical M.B.A. with some experience will earn almost $60,000, compared with $25,000 in 1980, or the equivalent of $49,000 in today's dollars.
At the high end, M.B.A. pay packages are also swelling from a clutch of extras. A typical offer from an investment bank consists of a $75,000 salary, a $25,000 "stub year bonus" for the rest of 1998, and $30,000 in signing and moving money. Other companies lure recruits with second-year tuition, "settling in" allowances and other goodies like forgivable loans. High-technology companies and venture capital firms give stock options and equity stakes.
"Consulting pays better in cash," says Mark D. Homan, 30, a graduate of the Kellogg School at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., who will receive stock options at Cisco Systems, the networking giant. "But if you hit the right high-tech company, you can make more money."
The risk, not to mention the workload, is often commensurate with the rewards. The typical tenure on first jobs in consulting, investment banking and some of the faster-growing high-technology fields is less than three years. "The salary number doesn't tell the whole story," said Robert Hamada, dean of the business school at the University of Chicago. "How many fall off the ladder? How many work 80 hours a week?"
Mainly, companies are looking for something that is notoriously difficult, and thus expensive, to identify: raw business talent.
It has never been tougher to get into a top school. Applications have soared since the early 1990's by as much as 25 percent at Harvard and 89 percent at Wharton. To fill a class of 383, Stanford sifted through 6,336 applications.
Today's M.B.A.'s don't just test better; they are road-tested. In the 1970's and 80's, employers complained that M.B.A.'s lacked the experience or wisdom to handle mid level management jobs. "We're not talking about wet-behind-the-ears youngsters," says Karen Dowd of Brecker & Merryman, a human resources consulting company. "Now M.B.A.'s are 30 years old, have a minimum of four years' work experience. Thirty percent are married."
Christian Barry, 31, and a graduate of Northwestern's Kellogg school, is exactly the kind of seasoned recruit that McKinsey & Company favors. After earning a bachelor's degree in operations research and industrial engineering from Cornell, Mr. Barry spent six years as a lieutenant in the Navy's nuclear submarine fleet. Four-month stretches at sea demonstrated that he has a capacity for teamwork and personal sacrifice. An internship at Marakon Associates, a consulting firm in Stamford, Conn., suggested that he knows what to expect from a consultant's peripatetic life.
And M.B.A.'s from top schools have made an enormous financial commitment. Tuition at these business programs is $25,000 a year for two years, five times the average for state schools. The biggest expense, though, is lost earnings.
Consider Catie McCreary, 33, a University of Chicago graduate who received a fistful of offers from manufacturers and consulting firms. Like more and more new M.B.A.'s, Ms. McCreary walked away from a fast-track job, hers in the booming fresh vegetable packaging business that paid in the high five figures.
"My father almost had a heart attack," she said, "but my decision was based on what I wanted five, 10 years out." While her friends were buying houses, Ms. McCreary poured the $50,000 she had saved into tuition. Thanks to that nest egg, she graduated with just $30,000 in student loans.
Snaring the best M.B.A.'s is just as vital for some businesses, like consulting and investment banking, as attracting customers or capital for other enterprises. Consulting, a field with annual growth in the double digits, sucks up a third of the graduates of top schools like Wharton.
"You don't take someone out to develop a business strategy for a global organization that doesn't have an M.B.A. from a top school," said Jeanie Mabie, head of recruiting for Price Waterhouse Coopers, the accounting and consulting firm. Price Waterhouse hired nearly 250 M.B.A.'s from 25 top schools this year. Consultants at such concerns start at $125,000 and can double or triple that by their third year.
The prospects are causing some to change careers. Mike Lynch, 33, an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago, joined the Boston Consulting Group in March. A tenured professor in audiology and speech at Purdue University, he figured that he could apply the same analytical and communications skills that won him tenure and research grants to better effect.
Within a year or two, he expects to be making three times what he was at Purdue -- and seeing more of the world than West Lafayette, Ind.
Of course, the M.B.A. boom won't last forever. After the stock market crash of 1987 and during the slow economic growth of the early 1990's, job offers shriveled and starting salaries flattened out. For now, though, M.B.A.'s get to write their own ticket. When trying to decide between competing job offers, Mr. Barry created what he calls a "discounted happiness flow model" on his computer. He assigned a weight of just 7 percent to compensation, 15 percent to "interesting co-workers" and 12 percent to location, among other criteria. "The market is so good," he says, "that you can afford to ask: What do I want?"

HEADLINE: Public Schools See Enrollment Slowing Down

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

 BODY:
After seven years of galloping growth, enrollment in the New York City public school system has suddenly begun to slow down, puzzling demographers but bringing relief to school officials, who for years have had to accommodate swelling numbers of children in cramped and aging schools.
Projections show that this year, enrollment will rise by 3,000 to 4,000 students, roughly one-fifth of the average increase of 19,000 over the last seven years. 
 What accounts for the slowdown -- and whether it will continue -- is a mystery, though Board of Education officials cite two main factors: fewer babies being born as baby boomers reach the end of their childbearing years, and more children leaving the city schools, some in favor of nearby suburbs, others to return to their home countries.
Demographers hired by the Board of Education say the slowdown may also signal a decline in immigration to the city, though other experts dispute that theory.
Because predicting school enrollment is an inexact science, educators warn that even if the increase in overall enrollment slows to a trickle, some neighborhood schools will remain overcrowded, and a few will continue to see rapid growth. Still, with the economy booming and city coffers flush, the trend, if it continues, could offer school officials the first opportunity in years to repair crumbling buildings, erect new ones and reduce class sizes.
"It would have been a backbreaking task to improve schools and at the same time accommodate more students," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and planning at the Wagner School of Public Affairs at New York University. "A leveling off in growth isn't a reason to slow down, but you have breathing space. It's a good opportunity to catch up."
Over the years, school enrollment -- because it is based not only on birth rates but on far-flung wars and crises that draw immigrants to the city -- has fluctuated wildly.
It grew sharply at the turn of the century with heavy immigration from Europe, and again in the 1960's when baby boomers reached the schoolhouse door, peaking in 1971 at 1.1 million children. In the early 1980's, it dipped below 920,000, and the school system sold several buildings, only to see major increases beginning in 1990 as the children of baby boomers and a new wave of immigrants from Latin America, the Caribbean and Asia started school. Today, nearly one of every two school-age children in the city is born to an immigrant parent.
The most recent shift became apparent last fall when, defying official projections, total enrollment grew by only 8,300 to about 1,084,000 children -- a sharp contrast with the last seven years, when the school population rose an average of 19,000 children annually. All the while, the overall New York City population has remained steady.
Most of the growth in enrollment is occurring in Queens, but Board of Education officials were not able to say which grade levels were growing the fastest.
By 2002, the numbers are expected to flatten out. Then, in what seems unthinkable at the moment, the school population is expected to start shrinking.
Nationally, public school enrollment is not expected to flatten until 2007. And New York City school officials said they had not expected city enrollment to drop until several years into the next century either.
"We were not looking at it tapering off now," said Chiara Coletti, a board spokeswoman. "This is certainly a surprise."
It is also, in many ways, a blessing.
For years, children in the city's most crowded school districts have been squeezed into coat rooms, spread out in hallways and packed into temporary trailers, while city officials bickered over the extent of overcrowding and how many new schools should be built. Meanwhile, the School Construction Authority had its budget slashed and, instead of building new schools, spent its resources leasing empty warehouses for classrooms -- often at exorbitant prices -- and repairing crumbling schools. Neither proved adequate.
Now, the slowdown in enrollment growth is likely to raise new questions about where and how to spend city construction dollars. Should the city take advantage of this demographic shift to repair the oldest and worst buildings, speed up new construction, or continue to erect trailers in schoolyards? Should it seek to change community school district lines to shift students from more crowded districts to less crowded ones? And how will the system accommodate today's elementary school children when they begin to crowd into high schools in the next few years?
Some education officials say the slowdown in enrollment growth should not be used to justify delaying school construction and repairs.
"You can't say to a child entering elementary school, 'We are terribly sorry, but you're going to spend the next six years in a trailer,' " said Harold O. Levy, a member of the State Board of Regents who documented the deterioration of city school buildings two years ago. "At the turn of the century, New York City built hundreds of schools. No one said sooner or later the enrollment is going to go down. You're forced to ask the question: why is this wave of immigrants being treated differently?"
This fall, even with the slowdown in enrollment growth and 16,000 new seats -- primarily in trailers and leased buildings -- the schools will still exceed their capacity by 65,000 students, according to Board of Education figures. The worst problems are in 10 of the city's 32 community school districts -- including Washington Heights, the city's Dominican hub; the northwest swath of the Bronx and central Queens.
Moreover, as today's elementary school students move up, the high school population is also expected to grow, forcing school officials to add space in high schools and the extras that older students need -- including expensive items like science labs and gymnasiums.
Finally, new state laws require schools to offer prekindergarten classes starting this fall and reduce class sizes in the early grades in the fall of 1999. With slowing enrollment growth, those mandates may become less difficult to carry out in certain neighborhoods.
"If, in fact, we see a leveling off or a decline in the next couple of years, we can think about managing capacity in those particular districts," said Patricia Zedalis, director of school facilities for the Board of Education. But, she said, "whether we grow by 3,000 or 20,000, we need to know where we are growing."
Demographers say that a crucial factor in the slowing rate of growth is the declining number of births in the city in recent years. After a steady increase through the 1980's, the number of babies born in New York City reached a peak in 1990 and then began to taper off, as the last of the baby boomers began to reach the end of their childbearing years.
George and Eunice Grier, a husband-and-wife team of demographers hired by the Board of Education, offer a second explanation for the slowdown in enrollment growth: they see in it the first signs of a decline in immigration to the city.
In fact, it is virtually impossible to determine to what extent shifts in the school population are the result of immigration, since the board does not track what portion of its total student body was born outside the United States or born here to immigrant parents. It does, however, know the number of newly admitted students who are foreign-born, and its figures show such admissions have dipped slightly in the last couple of years, to 42,245 in the 1996-97 school year, for instance, from 45,750 students in 1994-95.
The number of new immigrants in the student body -- children who have been in this country for less than three years -- has also decreased in the last few years. According to an annual Emergency Immigrant Census conducted by the board, the number of new immigrants fell to 112,000 earlier this year from roughly 138,000 in the 1992-93 school year.
Demographers with the City Planning Department say they have not seen a downturn in the number of newcomers to New York recently, and they say they are cautious not to read too much into the school enrollment figures. "We haven't seen a big movement," said Joseph Salvo, the department's chief demographer.
There is little dispute about a third explanation offered for the downturn in school enrollment growth: many more students seem to be leaving the city's public schools. In the 1996-97 school year, 44,600 students left, compared with 40,600 the year before and 38,800 the previous year. According to board figures for the most recent year, nearly 4,500 moved to New Jersey and 4,800 to Florida.
Like children moving to other states, the number of students who returned to their home countries grew considerably over the last two years: 2,800 students, for instance, returned to the Dominican Republic in 1996, compared with 1,800 the year before, while 744 went back to Mexico in 1996, compared with 487 the year before. School officials who work with immigrant students say it is not unusual for immigrant parents to send their children back home when they reach the troublesome years of adolescence, but did not know whether the increase would turn out to be a long-term trend.
The exodus from the city schools, others said, could signal a growing dissatisfaction with the system, especially among middle-class parents -- both immigrant and native-born -- who can afford to take their children elsewhere as the students remaining in the city's public schools become poorer and poorer; last year, more than 80 percent of elementary and middle school students had family incomes low enough to qualify for free lunches, compared with 72 percent in 1990, Professor Tobier said.
"Crime has gone down, but there's a lot more concern about schools than before," he said. "New York's public schools have taken their lumps."
Nevertheless, some neighborhood school districts continue to see such an influx of new students that they have had to ship them to old warehouses and old government buildings, pack them into trailers parked in the schoolyard and vans idling on busy streets.
District 10 in the northwest Bronx has nearly half a dozen schools with no room for arriving kindergartners; they are bused to less crowded schools nearby. This year, the district is likely to have 6,500 more children than it can properly accommodate -- a reflection, said Lois Harr, a Bedford Park mother of two public school children, of years of neglect and poor planning.
"They may think the trend is slowing down, but we are still needing to catch up from the past 10 years trend," said Ms. Harr, who is also on the board of the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition. "This slowdown is nice, but you can't even say it gives us any room to breathe -- not in District 10."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles 

 BODY:

Planes With a Past
Long ago when aviation was young and eager to please, passengers could sleep stretched out in a berth, rather than twisted like a pretzel in their seats. Some planes even had small lounge areas where drinks were served.
The 1942 Sikorsky VS-44A Flying Boat, just put on permanent display at the New England Air Museum in Windsor Locks has no lounge, but the 16 passengers it carried across the Atlantic on overnight flights had humane sleeping accommodations. Available mostly to the well-heeled, it was the transportation of choice of Humphrey Bogart and Eleanor Roosevelt, among others. 
 After World War II, Maureen O'Hara and her husband bought it for their island-hopping Antilles Airboat Flying Service in the Virgin Islands. About 10 years ago a group of volunteers sponsored by the Sikorsky Aircraft Division of United Technologies undertook its restoration.
The plane was built at Sikorsky in Stratford, and it joins about 80 aircraft to be seen at the museum. The collection includes airline and small air service planes, helicopters, stunt planes and planes from both World Wars. The latest is a military attack plane from the Gulf War.
The museum, which is next to Bradley International Airport, is open from 10 to 5 seven days a week. Admission is $6.50 for adults, $3.50 for children. The number for more information is (860) 623-3305.
 
Detailed Ceramics
James Christensen's minutely detailed, whimsically conceived and utterly realistic paintings fairly burst from the canvas, but his three-dimensional ceramics are even more vivid. Plump, rosy-cheeked fairy tale figures of kings and commoners, children, lovers, hausfraus, cats and chimney-sweeps populate fanciful turreted buildings out of a Grimm storybook. All the detail in "The Lute Player," for one, is crammed into a height of 9.5 inches.
The pieces sell for about $200 to $450, and will be on display at the Greenwich Workshop Gallery, 1657 Post Road in Fairfield, Tuesday through next Saturday from 10 to 5:30. The number is (203) 255-4613 for more information.
 
Remembering Robeson
"Paul Robeson," now playing at the Hutensky Theater in Hartford, celebrates the centennial of the birth of one of America's most extraordinary citizens, a birthright that proved to be a heavy burden. As controversial as he was distinguished in the fields of athletics, music, drama and law, Robeson spent most of his adult life in Europe to escape the racial prejudice that inhibited his development here.
Raphael Nash Thompson portrays Robeson in the Theater Works production of a play, written by Phillip Hayes Dean and first produced on Broadway in 1978 with James Earl Jones in the title role.
It will run through Sept. 6, with performances scheduled on Tuesday through Saturday at 8 and Sunday at 2:30. Ticket prices are $20, $25, and $30. The theater is at 233 Pearl Street. The number is (860) 527-7838 for reservations or more information.
 
Art Outdoors in Mystic
Forty-one years ago the Mystic Outdoor Art Festival was started by Irving Berlin's cousin, Milton Baline, and a group of art lovers, patterned after the Washington Square Arts Festival in Manhattan.
Today it draws some 50,000 people a year who stroll along two miles of downtown Mystic where exhibits featuring oils, watercolors, photography, sculpture and a variety of crafts by more than 300 artists.
The festival will be in progress next Saturday and Sunday from 10 to 7. Musical events on Saturday include the Mystic Highland Pipers, the John Moore Jazz Ensemble, Bea Ambach African Drumming and the Glorybound guitar-bass duo. The Rivergods and the Society for the Preservation of Barbershop Quartets in America will entertain on Sunday.
A children's Art Park will operate both days, offering cartooning, toy boat building, board games, juggling and face-painting, and food will be available for purchase.
Mystic, originally called Missi-tuk, meaning great tidal river in the Pequot language, has many additional attractions, including old sea captain's homes, one of the oldest drawbridges in the country, the Olde Mistick Shopping Village, the Mystic Pizza Parlor featured in the 1984 film and, of course, Mystic Seaport. The number for more information is (860) 572-9578.
 
Touring Solar Homes
A solar home tour taking place on Saturday from noon to 5 P.M. in Northwestern Connecticut has some unusual lessons to teach in energy efficiency and economical comfort.
Self-guided with a map, the tour includes two homes in Norfolk -- a modular cape of 1,290 square feet that gets most of its heat and electricity from the sun, and an Adirondack-style camp built for the Yale School of Forestry in 1941 within a 6,800 acre forest. Its cabins use the sun for energy and hot water.
In Lakeville a modern house that is underground uses the earth as an insulator, and in Salisbury a 2,500-square-foot Scandinavian-inspired house has Swedish low-flush toilets, a Finnish masonry fireplace that uses only one and one-half cords of wood in an average winter and other conservation technologies.
The tour is sponsored by the nonprofit People's Action for Clean Energy Inc., based in Canton. Tickets and a map cost $12 and may be obtained by calling (860) 693-4813.
 
Art Indoors in Kent
Joy Brown's sculptures and the paintings of William Oberst and Suzanne Howes-Stevens provide a rewarding exhibition on view through Aug. 30 at the Bachelier-Cardonsky Gallery on Main Street in Kent.
Mr. Oberst's technical skill as a classical painter underlies his contemporary take on his subjects, influenced by a degree in philosophy. His figures almost seem to speak to each other and his canvasses are often six feet tall.
Ms. Brown has created a signature style of figure sculpture -- balloon-like, airy creatures, large but not fat, moon-faced and charming in black and red stoneware that she fires in a Japanese kiln.
Two paintings by Ms. Howes-Stevens, called "Transformations" and "Seekers," are grounded in Greek mythology and imbedded with old maps, conveying a sense of timelessness. The gallery is open on Friday through Sunday from 11 to 5. The number is (860) 927-3129 for more information.
 
Church Fair in Ridgefield
St. Stephen's Church in Ridgefield will once again hold one of the longest-running church fairs in the region. Its Nutmeg Festival will be 92 years old when it takes place on Saturday from 10 to 4 on the grounds at 351 Main Street.
In addition to raffling off a 1998 Volkswagen Beetle, the fair will offer furniture, bric-a-brac, antiques, fine art, books, records, jewelry, crafts, home-baked pies, cakes and cookies, and fresh produce from local growers.
Food booths will supply Caribbean, Greek, New England country and Southern-style cooking. Visitors will be entertained by the Jackson Pike Skifflers, can tee off at the new miniature golf course, and there will be pony rides and games for children. Admission is free. ELEANOR CHARLES

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Sitter Holding Small One," stoneware by Joy Brown, in Kent.

HEADLINE: Spending More for Open Space

BYLINE: By ROBERT DUBROW 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S per capita spending on open space acquisitions has lagged behind that of other Northeast states. That is changing as a result of legislation proposed by Gov. John G. Rowland and passed in May by the General Assembly.
Mr. Rowland announced in January a 25-year plan to increase the amount of Connecticut land to be conserved as open space by more than 210,000 acres, bringing such land to 21 percent of the state's total acreage. 
 Some 10 percent would be state-owned, a goal mandated last year by the General Assembly. The Governor proposed spending $166 million in bond funds over the next five years for land purchases by the state and to assist municipalities, land conservation organizations, and water companies in open space acquisitions.
But the funding is only assured for this fiscal year, which began July 1.
"We have a once-in-a-generation opportunity to shape the way Connecticut's landscape is going to look," said David Leff, the Department of Environmental Protection's assistant commissioner for environmental conservation.
The program under which the department acquires land for the state, called the Recreation and Natural Heritage Trust, has been authorized to spend $19.5 million in bond money during this fiscal year. Municipalities and land conservation organizations can participate in these purchases, but the state retains ownership.
David Sutherland, of the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy, said that his organization has participated in several acquisitions. "In each case it was a plot of land that was important for our mission to preserve habitats for rare plant and animal species," he said. "We could assist the department in acquiring it, but neither of us had to put all the money in."
In June, the D.E.P. joined with the Nature Conservancy, the town of Weston and a local coalition in an agreement to purchase Trout Brook Valley, a 668-acre tract of land being sold by the Bridgeport Hydraulic water company. This deal ended a bitter dispute between conservationists and a developer over the fate of the land. The state will contribute $6 million from the Recreation and Natural Heritage Trust. A new D.E.P. grant program for municipalities, land conservation organizations and water companies to acquire land for open space and watershed protection received $10 million in bond funds this year.
"Properties that don't rise to the level of statewide or regional importance may be important locally," said Mr. Leff, "and this will provide an opportunity for municipalities and others to purchase those properties. We want to build a network of open space throughout the state, regardless of ownership."
Land acquired under this program must be preserved in perpetuity, predominantly in its natural condition. Development for recreational purposes, including golf courses, tennis courts, ball fields and swimming pools, is prohibited.
Depending on the type of buyer and the type of property, the amount of the grants will range from 40 percent to 65 percent of the fair market value of the land. "We anticipate a lot of applications for that money," Mr. Sutherland said. "We expect that the program is going to be drastically over-subscribed."
Oxford is one town that plans to apply. In May, voters passed a referendum to buy 517 acres from the Birmingham Utilities water company for $3.2 million, with the understanding that the town can apply for state funds to aid in the purchase.
A former Oxford First Selectman, Kate Cosgrove, said she hoped that this application would be more successful than the town's effort several years ago to get the state to use Recreation and Natural Heritage Trust money to purchase a tract of privately owned land abutting Lake Zoar. "We had to go through the Bond Commission," she said. "It was such a rigmarole that we lost the property. It was bought by a developer." While the developer is donating a substantial portion of the land to the town and the Oxford Land Trust, homes are being built on the waterfront property.
Experiences such as Oxford's prompted a major change in the law aimed at smoothing the land acquisition process. Under the old law, Mr. Leff explained, "every parcel that the department purchased, whether it was a quarter acre or 500 acres, had to be approved by the State Bond Commission. Landowners have reasons why they want to move quickly, why they want some assurance that the deal is definitely going to go through. That restricted our ability to move quickly."
Now the Bond Commission is required to approve the issuance of funds for open space in two equal lump sum installments each fiscal year. The D.E.P. will have the authority to spend this money without getting approval for each individual purchase. "It will make a huge difference," said Charles Reed, director of the department's division of land acquisition and management.
The other significant changes in the open space law pertain to the rules by which water companies are permitted to sell what is regarded as surplus land outside the watersheds of active drinking water supplies, such as Trout Brook Valley.
"Water companies plan to sell over 3,000 acres of pristine tracts of open space in Fairfield, New Haven, and Litchfield counties over the next three years," said Curt Johnson, staff attorney for the Connecticut Fund for the Environment. "The legislature has given towns and land trusts tools to begin transforming this threat into an open space opportunity."
The new legislation gives the state, towns, and land conservation organizations first crack at buying water company land during a 90-day exclusive negotiation period before the land can be placed on the open market.
The substantial open space funding now available makes such purchases possible, said Carolyn Hughes of the Connecticut Fund for the Environment. "A lot of these properties are very expensive," she said. "It would be very difficult for a town or a nonprofit to pull together that kind of funding on its own."
The new legislation also authorizes the Department of Public Utility Control to allocate up to 100 percent of the economic benefits of a water company land sale to the shareholders, as opposed to the rate-payers, if 100 percent of the land is sold for open space or recreation. This allows utilities to "get more profit to their shareholders if they sell for conservation purposes," said Ms. Hughes.
While financing is assured for only the first year of the 25-year open space plan, Mr. Sutherland of the Nature Conservancy said he was optimistic. "Every indication I have is that the Governor, other candidates and the General Assembly will continue funding in the future," he said.
Others are not so sure. The First Selectman of Orange, Robert Sousa, whose town has recently been involved in the acquisition of two open space properties, without help from the state, criticized the state for having been absent from this issue in recent years. "I'm cautiously optimistic that the state will be a partner," he said, "but the jury is still out about how serious they are."
To provide steady, long-term funding, said Mr. Leff, the assistant commissioner, "the department has to choose wisely and move efficiently in buying land, and the public has to support it. The people who believe that open space is important have to let their elected representatives know that this is important to them.
"They've got to talk it up with their friends and neighbors, even their children, because children who are not even born yet are going to be voters by the time this program reaches its conclusion."

PUB-DATE: August 2, 1998

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 2; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1441 words

HEADLINE: Job of Film Liaison Restored

BYLINE: By TODD SHAPERA 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WHEN the phone rang in Iris Stevens's county office in White Plains recently, a Hollywood location scout was inquiring about shooting parts of a film on the life of Ruben (Hurricane) Carter in Westchester, with other scenes set for Toronto. The producers wanted to know about nightclubs with black clientele. She will explore possible sites in New Rochelle.
The same afternoon, a television commercial producer for the on-line distributor CDnow called in search of large sites. Ms. Stevens ticked off Playland, the Purchase College Performing Arts Center and Roosevelt Stadium in Yonkers. 
 Within the next two days other scouting queries included a Paramount call regarding a new film, tentatively called "Sleepy Hollow." Then New Line Productions was looking for a campus to shoot "Lost Souls" with Winona Ryder. And HBO was exploring sites for a Susan Sarandon feature, "Earthly Possessions."
Although such filming benefits the local economy, until last month Westchester did not have an office, or person, dedicated to fielding those requests and trying to convert them into done deals.
Three years ago, the administration of Andrew P. O'Rourke disbanded the Westchester Film Bureau as part of a move to downsize and privatize economic development. Ms. Stevens, who held the bureau's No. 2 position as location director from 1993 to 1995, was reassigned to handle job training contracts in the county's Office of Employment and Training. Production companies were left to navigate for themselves among the county's towns; many went elsewhere.
Now, County Executive Andrew J. Spano has restored the liaison position, believing that becoming aggressive in attracting and accommodating film companies makes economic development sense. He tapped Iris Stevens for the role. "We have nearly everything in this county," Ms. Stevens said. "The diversity of locations makes us very desirable." Echoing that point is Joseph Zolfo, the location manager for an upcoming Hallmark remake of Hitchcock's "Rear Window" for television. "Westchester has some pretty beautiful and amazing locations," he said. "There are historic preservation sites, museums, performing arts centers, old mansions and quaint river towns."
Ms. Stevens would add rock quarries, dams, a power plant, bridges, a mine, 35 parks and shoreline on the Hudson and Long Island Sound.
In early June, when scouting locations for "Rear Window," Mr. Zolfo contacted Ms. Stevens. He was seeking two old warehouses that face each other. (The film's protagonist, who is being played by Christopher Reeve, looks out of his apartment window and sees suspicious behavior in the facing apartment.) Mr. Zolfo said Ms. Stevens steered him to a Yonkers site that was ideal for the production. The Yonkers location was chosen largely to accommodate Mr. Reeve. The production company signed a three-month, $24,000 lease for 25,000 square feet at Yonkers Industrial Park with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said Allen Morrison, a Port Authority spokesman. The rate was below market value to encourage filming, he said.
The film is also being shot at the Burke Rehabilitation Hospital in White Plains, where Mr. Reeve goes for therapy.
Beyond bringing stars and glamour to the area, films like "Rear Window" bring considerable revenue. Even if the small budget film is far from "Titanic" proportions, expenditures in Westchester throughout the "Rear Window" project are expected to exceed $1 million, said Steven Haft, the executive producer of "Rear Window." Mr. Zolfo said that six weeks of preproduction work alone, to build sets, has led to local purchases and rentals of supplies and equipment. In addition, he said a number of workers were hired, including plumbers, electricians and a locksmith. And the construction crew of more than 50 workers a day eats its meals locally.
During the earlier period, Ms. Stevens said film and related productions brought the county $5.4 million in economic benefits in fiscal year 1994-95. (New York City claimed $829 million in direct film expenditures in 1996.) Mr. Spano, who remembers being captivated by the shooting of Milos Forman's 1981 film "Ragtime" in Mount Kisco, said that besides providing immediate economic benefits the productions enhance the county's image.
This point is echoed by Maren Rudolph, a spokeswoman for Vintage Hudson Valley. The organization has 11 architecturally or historically significant inns, including the Castle in Tarrytown. Ms. Rudolph said she welcomes the more active film effort as being "an added boost for the region's growing tourism."
The logistics of filming in the county are complicated by the many jurisdictions, which have different permit regulations and fees. Some villages and towns like Croton-on-Hudson and Cortlandt assess no fees or low fees, whereas some municipalities discourage filming with high assessments. Pleasantville charges $1,500 just to submit a permit application and an additional $750 a day for filming on public property and $500 a day for private property. Scarsdale says fees are determined on a case-by-case basis.
"No one has ever filmed in Scarsdale," Ms. Stevens said. Even the producer Rob Reiner, a graduate of Scarsdale High School, was rebuffed. By contrast, Mr. Zolfo said, obtaining a permit from Yonkers was a simple process and the city had been very helpful.
Ms. Stevens said she hoped her one-person office would help productions cut through red tape and create the kind of film-friendly environment New York City's Office for Film, Theater and Broadcasting provides. That office's Web site lists 14 staff members. They are often assisted by about the same number of interns.
Filming in Westchester dates back to silent-era "Tarzan" productions starring Elmo Lincoln. They were shot on the vine-covered banks of the Croton River. A partial list of more recent films with some parts shot in the county includes "Wall Street," "Radio Days," "Goodbye, Columbus," "The Preacher's Wife" and "Age of Innocence." St. Barnabas Church in Irvington was one of the settings in the 1997 Harrison Ford and Brad Pitt film "The Devil's Own."
On July 8 and 9, Billy Crystal and Robert De Niro spent two days at Ward Pound Ridge and John Jay Homestead in Katonah for the Warner Brothers film "Analyze This."
Iris Stevens's path to the film industry did not follow a likely script. While raising three children in Croton in the 1960's and 70's, she became involved with environmental issues and eventually served on a county commission in the administration of Alfred B. DelBello. The county's film position became available in 1993, at a time when her marriage had dissolved and she was looking for work.
Ms. Stevens said she values the close relationship she often develops with film crews. A few years ago, this helped her through diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer. "The Juror" kept me alive, she said, adding, "The crew filled my hospital room and home with flowers and put a fax machine in my house so I could work from my bed." She returned to the set nine days after surgery and credits the movie with being a godsend.
Now a formidable challenge in rebuilding the county's position in the film industry is fierce, new competition from New Jersey, which, Ms. Stevens said, is aggressively luring productions.
As part of Mr. Spano's vision, the county is discussing with developers the possibility of building a full-scale sound stage, which would provide all services related to the production of a feature film, he said in a recent interview. He said he believes this would appeal not only to out-of-town crews but also to residents involved in the film industry who might like to work close to home.
In the meantime, Ms. Stevens is planning a Web site featuring photographs of attractive county locations, and she is about to produce an updated version of a 1994 resource book for location managers entitled "Filming in Westchester County." It offers details about regulations, fees and contacts for each of the county's municipalities.
Moreover, signaling a commitment to local talent, in her first week on the job, Ms. Stevens attended a monthly meeting of the 914 Film and Video Salon, a networking organization of professionals. Bob Curtis, who founded the group, said he was encouraged by Ms. Stevens's plans to publish a guide containing the names of local production professionals, including tradespeople, technicians and producers.
Ms. Stevens told the group, "The greatest pleasure I get is when someone calls and says, 'We are going to film in Westchester, and we are going to hire locally.' "
