SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 9; Column 6; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 835 words

HEADLINE: TRENTON;
Votes Taken On Land, Gambling And Drugs

BYLINE: By KIRSTY SUCATO 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
State lawmakers returned from summer recess last week to consider several bills that required action by Aug. 3 if they were to be presented to voters as ballot questions in November. Besides acting on those bills, which propose amendments to the state Constitution, the legislature took up dozens of other measures. Here are some of the highlights:
OPEN SPACE -- A bill that would ask voters whether the state should borrow $1 billion over the next 10 years to preserve 1 million acres of open space passed both houses of the Legislature on Thursday. The bill would dedicate $98 million a year in state sales tax revenue for the next 30 years to back the bonds, which would be used to buy the development rights to half of the state's remaining undeveloped land, as well as purchase land outright. The measure replaced a proposal by Governor Whitman to raise the money by levying a two-cent-a-gallon increase in the state's gasoline tax. Environmental groups and conservationists hailed the plan as providing New Jersey's first stable source of financing for open space acquisition. 
 GREEN ACRES -- A bill that would ask voters whether they would support a $295 million bond issue to pay for preservation of open space and the restoration of historic sites, among other things, was approved by an Assembly committee on Monday. The money would act as a bridge until the proposed dedication of sales tax revenue would take effect on July 1, 1999, said Senator Robert E. Littell, a Republican of Franklin, who co-sponsored the bill. The bill, which was passed by the Senate on June 29, goes to the full Assembly.
The amount includes $120 million for recreation and conservation, $50 million for the preservation of farmland, $35 million for cultural arts centers, $20 million to preserve historic buildings, $15 million to restore lakes and streams, and, for the first time, $10 million to plant and care for shade trees. The remaining $45 million would go to various other programs. New Jersey voters have approved nine similar referendums in the past 37 years.
CASINO NIGHTS -- Social clubs that have liquor licenses could offer "simulated gambling" to help raise money for charities under a bill approved by the Senate on Thursday. Under current law, a club cannot hold such games of chance as roulette and blackjack, even if no money changes hands as long as it is licensed to sell alcohol. The measure, which now heads to the Assembly for consideration, was designed to make it easier to hold fund-raising events, said its sponsor, Senator C. Louis Bassano, a Republican of Union.
DRUG USE -- Workers who are dismissed for using illegal drugs on the job would lose unemployment benefits under a bill approved by the Senate on Thursday. Under current law, only workers who are dismissed for criminal offenses can lose benefits. The bill now goes to the Assembly.
PENALTIES -- The Assembly on Thursday approved a bill that would increase the penalty for resisting arrest from a disorderly persons offense to a crime of the fourth degree, which carries a fine of up to $10,000 and up to 18 months in prison; the penalty had been a fine of up to $1,000 and up to 6 months in jail. If the person threatens the officer, the penalty would jump to up to $15,000 and three to five years in prison.
SOLID WASTE -- A bill that would ask voters to forgive about $118 million in state loans made to counties to pay for incinerators and other waste disposal facilities was approved by both houses on Thursday. Counties owe an estimated $1 billion to $1.7 billion for systems they were required to build under the state's old waste flow laws, which required trash to be disposed of inside county borders.
ELDER CARE -- A measure that would create a legislative task force to study the care of the elderly was approved by the Assembly on Thursday. Under the resolution, a 13-member Assembly task force would begin holding hearings this fall to gather information about the needs of senior citizens. In 30 years, about one in four New Jerseyans will be over 65. Currently, one in seven state residents is over 65, said the measure's co-sponsor, Assemblywoman Rose M. Heck, a Republican of Lodi.
HOV LANES -- Calling the high-occupancy vehicle lanes on Routes 80 and 287 a failure, members of the Assembly on Thursday introduced resolutions that would require the state Department of Transportation to study the effectiveness of the carpool lanes and to reduce the number of hours for which restrictions are in place. Under current regulations, vehicles using HOV lanes must have at least two occupants between 6 A.M. and 9 A.M. and from 3 P.M. to 7 P.M. Under the proposals, the hours would go into effect at 7:30 A.M., rather than 6 A.M., and at 5 P.M., rather than 3 P.M. A second proposal calls for a six-month study to determine if the lanes actually cause traffic congestion. The study could pave the way for lawmakers to seek permission from the Federal Government to dismantle the HOV lanes.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Good Tidings for River

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
President Clinton has named the Hudson one of 14 American Heritage Rivers. Begun by Mr. Clinton in September, the American Heritage Rivers program has three objectives: the protection of natural resources and the environment, economic revitalization and historic and cultural preservation.
The Hudson River received an overwhelming number of nominations from public officials, among them Gov. George E. Pataki, and private interest groups. Nominations were judged on the natural, economic, agricultural, scenic, historic, cultural or recreational resources of the river, which make it distinctive; effectiveness with which the community has defined a plan of action to put into effect the American Heritage River designation and the strength and diversity of community support. 
 Other rivers named are the Connecticut, the Cuyahoga in Ohio, the Detroit, the Hanalei in Hawaii, the New in North Carolina, the Potomac in Maryland, the St. Johns in Florida, the Upper and Lower Mississippi, the Upper Susquehanna and Lackawanna in Pennsylvania, the Willamette in Oregon, the Rio Grande in Texas and the Blackstone and Woonasquatucket in Massachusetts.

PUB-DATE: August 2, 1998

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2716 words

HEADLINE: Ties That Bind, Ties That Break

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

 BODY:
PETER KWAN spends three nights a week at his bachelor pad in Murray Hill, and the other four nights at his mother's apartment in Chinatown, where he keeps his old room even though he moved out years ago. On one of his days off, he visits his father in a nursing home in the West Village.
"It's a dual life to be the good son and have your own life," said Mr. Kwan, 34, who manages a carpet store in midtown. "Sometimes I don't sleep, but obviously it's the right thing to do." 
 Mr. Kwan shuttles between homes to hold together a tight-knit family that no longer lives in the same place. Like many Asian immigrants in New York City, he has redefined his ideas about family in the face of changing socioeconomic realities.
In Asian cultures, the extended family traditionally provided an economic and social base -- as well as a roof -- for its members. Children cared for their parents at home, just as their parents and grandparents did. This sense of filial duty remains strong in many Asian families, handed down from immigrants to those born in the United States.
But today, many younger Asians say it is no longer practical -- or desirable -- to care for their parents while holding down full-time jobs and raising their own children in apartments with limited space. Many older Asians, meanwhile, say they want to enjoy their last years without feeling obliged to cook, baby-sit and adjust their lives around their children's families.
"When old people live with young people, they have different opinions," said Mok Fung, 92, a Hong Kong immigrant who left his daughter's family in Kew Gardens, Queens, several years ago for a housing project for the elderly on the Lower East Side. "I move so slowly, they say you block my way. When I put on Chinese ointment, they don't like it. They say it smells. Before, I used to think if you don't live with them, you're no good. But now the world changes."
In recent years, hundreds of older Chinese, Japanese and other Asians in the city have left their families for nursing homes, assisted-living programs and Government-subsidized retirement buildings. "Culture-wise, it is a big difference," said Yvonne Jones, director of admissions at the Isabella Geriatric Center in Washington Heights. "You never saw Japanese in nursing homes. You never saw Chinese. The nursing home was the last resort."
For Jimmy Lou, 76, the Village Nursing Home in the West Village has been his "second home" for eight years. Pictures of his wife and daughter, who live in New Jersey, decorate his room, and he keeps photographs of his 4-month-old granddaughter on his nightstand. "I'd love to be closer to my family, but I'd be too much for them," said Mr. Lou, a Chinese-American who is confined to a wheelchair.
Experts say that what makes the experiences of Asians different from those of other immigrant groups in New York City is the large proportion of parents reaching old age at the same time, and the fact that many elderly Asians still live with their adult children.
Asians are the fastest growing racial or ethnic group among people 65 and older in New York City, according to census figures. Many came here as students and young workers after 1965, when changes in immigration laws lifted restrictions on Asians, said Ronald Takaki, a professor of ethnic studies at the University of California at Berkeley and the author of "Strangers from a Different Shore: A History of Asian Americans" (Penguin USA, 1990). "Think of it as a bump composed of young Asians in their 20's and 30's moving through time," he said. Now, "they're all getting older."
David S. Chen, executive director of the Chinese-American Planning Council in Chinatown, said more Asian families were looking for alternative ways to care for older parents. "The cultural tradition is to try to stay with the family, but the reality of that is getting harder," he said. "The burden on the individual families is tremendous."
Although many younger Asians say family is important, they are finding it difficult to live up to the tradition of the extended household. Some say privately that they resent having to rearrange their lives around their parents at home. They say they are expected to spend nights and weekends with their parents, rather than with friends, and to defer to their choices in music, food and television shows.
"Basically, I don't have a life," said one 32-year-old Chinese woman, an office manager for a consulting firm, who still lives with her parents on the Lower East Side and who would speak only on condition of anonymity. "I go to work, I come home, I spend my weekend doing things with my parents. When do I have time for myself?"
Others say they worry about supporting their aging parents while trying to start their own careers and families. Jennifer Choi, 27, a social worker from Bayside, Queens, said she plans to give money to her parents when they retire. "I have to think about my family and how I divide that money among not just my husband and children, but also my parents," said Ms. Choi, who is helping to organize a conference for Korean-American women that will include a workshop on investing for parents.
Feeling bound by cultural expectations, many younger Asians say they worry quietly, or commiserate with each other behind closed doors. "There's still a feeling that if I can't take care of my parents, then somehow I'm less Chinese," said Mr. Chen, whose parents live with his brother. But that is slowly changing, he said. "It's becoming more acceptable to not live together."
Lari Nguyen, 38, an interior designer, said she agonized for months before relocating her parents to an apartment a few blocks from her two-bedroom home in Flushing. She used to whisper to her two children at night, she said, because her parents went to bed early in the next room. Her husband, a lawyer who is of Anglo-European descent, had trouble communicating with her parents, who spoke Vietnamese.
"My parents always told me that I had to take care of them when I got older," said Ms. Nguyen, who emigrated with them from Vietnam in 1975. "It was hard to move them away, but I think it's the best for everyone. They have their privacy, and we have ours. And we still eat together every night."
 
Sometimes Parents Decide It's Time To Move Out
In other Asian families, though, the parents make the first move to leave the extended household. Mon Lam, 83, an immigrant from Hong Kong, said she and her husband became entangled in their son's marital problems when they all lived together. Her husband, she said, constantly argued with her daughter-in-law.
"The old tradition is the daughter-in-law must obey, but now it's different," Ms. Lam said. "I wanted to move out. It's not that my son didn't want to live with me or they kicked me out. They treated me pretty good, so they're not bad kids."
So many older Asians want to move out on their own in Sunset Park that Paul Mak, the president of the Brooklyn Chinese-American Association, said he regularly gets requests for what he calls a "boarding house for seniors."
"We don't have the resources for that, but they keep asking," Mr. Mak said. Last year, he said, he helped 8,000 elderly Asians apply for Government-subsidized apartments. Only 45 received them.
Mr. Mak said older Asians often feel obligated to do household chores for their children's families. "They would rather stay on their own than work as slaves for their kids 12 to 14 hours a day," he said. "But while you're still inside the house, it would be difficult to do nothing."
Mr. Fung said he felt as if he had won the lottery after moving into Hong Ning Housing for the Elderly on the Lower East Side, a 155-unit building with a steady waiting list of 100 people. In the last three years, 200 people have requested applications.
Mr. Fung pays one-third of his monthly income from Government benefits -- less than $500 -- to rent a one-bedroom apartment. He walks in the downstairs garden, plays mah-jongg and reads Chinese newspapers in the community room. "I have my own room, heat and hot water," he said. "My family, they have their own space. If they have time, they come to visit."
For older Asians who cannot live on their own, nursing homes and other care centers are an alternative to extended families.
At the Anna Erika Assisted Living Program on Staten Island, the staff not only speaks four Chinese dialects, but also serves oxtail soup and lo mein at mealtime. There are 160 Asian residents, compared with 125 a year ago. "It's like stepping into Chinatown," said Elliot Markowitz, the program's executive administrator.
The Village Nursing Home has hired four Chinese-speaking workers in the last year because more Chinese people are moving in. Of nearly 200 residents, 26 are Asian, compared with 10 in 1995, a staff member said.
The Isabella Geriatric Center has started a staff exchange program with Japanese health care workers, hooked up Japanese-language cable television, and given tours of the nursing home to dozens of Japanese tourists. In the last year, the number of Japanese residents has increased to 10 from 2, out of a total of 705.
The number of Asians in nursing and retirement homes in the city is relatively small. But before the 1980's, Asians were rarely seen at all in most of those homes, social workers said. And many older Asians still expect their children to take care of them.
"Where we came from, there's no such thing as a nursing home," said Betty Lee, 63, a Sunset Park resident who emigrated from Taishan, China, after World War II. "You have to rely on your own children and your close relatives to help you."
The Asian tradition of relying on family was reinforced in the United States by years of social discrimination. Before the 1964 Federal civil rights laws, many privately owned or locally funded nursing homes refused to take in minorities, Professor Takaki said, and few, if any, such places existed that served mainly Asians.
"It would be a historical mistake to just give the cultural explanation," Professor Takaki said. "Asians were segregated from white society. It forced them to become self-reliant and take care of their own parents."
In later years, Federal housing subsidies and Government benefits for the elderly opened the door to a variety of living options for Asians. And for many families, extended households have given way under the daily pressures of American life.
"It is that double-edged sword of American life," said Eric Liu, author of "The Accidental Asian: Notes of a Native Speaker," (Random House, 1998). "Living in this country allows so much more freedom for independent self-expression but at the same time can attenuate connections that hold families together."
The experiences of Asian families today are similar to those of Italians, Jews and Poles between the 1940's and 1960's, said Mary Waters, a sociologist at Harvard University, who is studying second-generation Asian immigrants in New York City.
"People come from farming and peasant backgrounds where the norm is the extended family living together," Professor Waters said. "The individualism of American life -- and the way it is set up -- is that people move in nuclear families." In the classic immigrant model, Professor Waters said, extended families start off together but separate as they become successful and adopt American values.
 
Children on Tatami Mats, Or Piled Into Bunk Beds
In the city, where living space is usually tight, extended families typically cram into two- or three-bedroom apartments because larger places are scarce and unaffordable. A grandparent may share a room with a grandchild. Children may sleep on tatami mats on the floor.
"Asian households are the most overcrowded, even if the extended family is changing," said Jessica Lee, executive director of the Coalition for Asian-American Children and Families.
A 1996 Census Bureau survey of New York City showed that 18.3 percent of Asian households had more than one person in each room, a standard measure of overcrowding, compared with 14.1 percent of Hispanic households, 9.6 percent of black households and 6.3 percent of white households.
Lai Yee Cheng, 41, a seamstress from Hong Kong, moved in with her in-laws in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, after she got married 15 years ago. Four children later, she is still there. Ms. Cheng and her husband, who works as a cook in a restaurant, share one room, while her in-laws take another. The children, ranging in age from 7 to 13, pile into bunk beds in the third bedroom.
"We're family people so we have to look after them," Ms. Cheng said of her in-laws. "I hope that when I get very old, my children do that for me, too."
But Li Aggarwala, 40, an engineer from Malaysia, waited until he moved into a brownstone in Borough Park, Brooklyn, before he sent for his mother. He and his wife, a secretary, live on one floor, and his mother stays on another. "Where we were before, there was no place for my mother," he said. "It's important for our family to stay together, but we also need our space."
For some Asians, the extended family is no longer practical because no one can stay home with older parents or relatives who need constant care and attention. Mari Sakaji, director of Japanese-American Social Services Inc., said that in the last few years, she had received a growing number of calls each year from working couples trying to place parents in nursing homes.
"Within our community, it's getting harder to find families that are trying to take care of them at home," she said. "Most of the time, they live separately."
Woon Yin Mui, 64, and her two sisters, who all work in a garment factory in Chinatown, sent their 92-year-old mother to the Village Nursing Home after she fractured her hip. "The idea of living together is good because you can have closer relationships," she said. "I want to do it, but I don't have the ability. We have to work, and nobody's home."
Every day, Ms. Mui visits her mother, Pak Chung Chun, bringing a bag full of sweet sesame rolls, salty dumplings and fermented eggs. But the delicacies go home with Ms. Mui because her mother cannot eat them. Ms. Chun has difficulty swallowing, so she drinks meals from a baby bottle.
"I feel guilty," said Ms. Mui, who emigrated from Hong Kong in 1972. "When I was younger, I had to work very hard to make a living. I didn't have a chance to take my mother to a restaurant and buy good food for her. Now I have time but it's too late. She can't eat anything. It's too late."
 
Breakfast With Dad: Dim Sum and Hash Browns
Peter Kwan sipped morning coffee with his father, Kam Sau Kwan, in a sunny corner of the community room at the Village Nursing Home. A bag of fragrant dim sum sat on the table between them.
"When he lived at home, my father went out every morning in Chinatown," he said. "He used to sit in the tea house for hours. He met friends and ate dim sum. It was a set routine."
Now the dim sum has become a routine of a different sort. Every Thursday, Mr. Kwan carries shrimp dumplings and roast pork buns to his father. Sometimes he brings McDonald's hash browns for himself.
The older Mr. Kwan, who was a steam presser in a garment factory, moved to the nursing home five years ago after he became paralyzed and lost part of his memory from meningitis. "No matter how much you want to," his son said, "you can't spend 24 hours a day taking care of him."
The father nodded his head though he did not understand the English words. After a while, he turned his wheelchair toward the window and lit a Marlboro. He pulled off his Giants baseball cap, a gift from his son, and looked off in the distance.
Mr. Kwan said he still hopes to bring his father home. But in the meantime, the Kwans lead separate lives. Every year, Mr. Kwan offers to give up his apartment for a house in the suburbs where his mother, a retired seamstress, could live with him, and perhaps his father, too. But every year, he said, his mother turns him down.
"I don't want to live in a house -- I love the city -- but whatever mom wants, she gets," Mr. Kwan said. His parents, he said, came to the United States to give him a better life. "You're grateful," he said, "and you want to take care of them."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 76; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 758 words

HEADLINE: Lives;
The Real Deal

BYLINE: By Adam Liptak; Adam Liptak is a lawyer at The Times.

 BODY:
We played poker every week for seven years, in apartments outfitted with round tables, green felt and nice chips. The core half-dozen of us, men and women both, lived in Manhattan, with good jobs and no kids.
It started as a goof, the way some people go bowling. For the first year or two we kept cheat sheets on the table to remind us of whether a flush beats a straight. Later on, we were sending away to Las Vegas for books on strategy. 
 The stakes increased over time, and by the end it wasn't too unusual to win or lose $100 in a night. But if you were any kind of player it more or less evened out. It wasn't about the money, anyway, not really. It was about winning, and the monstrous ambition we tried to hide at work blossomed at the table. Our careers colored the way we approached the cards.
David, a musician, comedy writer and schemer, was convinced that every big pot was his meal ticket, and he pursued them recklessly. Bursting with vulgar humor, epic self-involvement and the odd ditty, he approached the game with deep engagement, because he was entirely convinced he would win. He bad-mouthed all the lawyers at the table pitilessly and on principle. He loudly envied anyone doing better than he did that night or making more money than he did in life.
Jed, an entertainment lawyer, was distracted, jokey, always on the phone. He was there for company, for gossip and maybe for connections. Jed became steadily more successful, and we started to hear about Sundance and Cannes, equity stakes and executive-producer titles. He started to show up with clients in tow.
Jed was cheerfully aware of his superficial appreciation of poker. On hearing another player's measured and complicated reasoning for folding a strong hand in the face of a decent shot at half the pot, Jed promptly called the bet. "I'm in," he said, "because I have plenty of chips left." He wanted to be in the game, in the deal, and he hoped the economics would sort themselves out later.
George, whom we'd nicknamed the Ox, was a tax lawyer and raconteur who spun out intricate high-stakes games and endless sagas about his adventures with his college buddies at Amherst. He solicited romantic advice and lost methodically.
Lots of people came once and decided, sensibly, that we weren't for them. More often, we decided not to invite them back. They were too slow on the uptake, or too deliberate in their play, or too amateurish, or too cheap, or too rich to care. Or they were clients of Jed's, who were always hopeless. They expected us to bend the rules for them, because they were new or because they had just lost $20 in a misunderstanding about how to declare low. They left at 9:30 because they'd lost all they could lose. These were people we could do without.
We heard stories about games more genteel than ours, games that would rusticate even regular players for bad behavior. My favorite concerned a guy banished for two years for excessive gloating. I wouldn't have lasted half an hour in that game.
We were reckless gamblers, most of us, appreciative of the well-executed small plays but exultant at winning the big pot on luck and nerve.
That's not the right way to play, according to the books. They tell you to play tight, to "throw that trash away," that is, when you get bad cards early. Ted played the right way. He folded almost everything, and when he stayed in we all got out of his way. You can eke out a small edge doing this, but without joy.
Ted was a risk arbitrageur on Wall Street, making bets on which mergers would close, playing the spreads. Ted played cards the way he invested in deals: analytically, squeezing out the nickels. He tired of the game before any of us, and he left his job not long after.
Toward the end, we let a bunch of placid, cool artists and other downtown types join our game. They were much nicer than we were, solicitous even, which is odd in a game that calls for a killer instinct. They'd let the new guy who messed up have his twenty back.
The game collapsed not too long after that. It had been built on noise and confrontation, and without these the game became a little rote. We had by now learned what there was to know about the other selves we brought to the poker table.
Our not-always-attractive work personas were amplified for poker night, and for years this seemed liberating. By the end, though, this weekly exhilaration had grown hollow and unsatisfying.
In the civilized quiet, our bluster had turned out to be a sort of bluff, and it had been called.

HEADLINE: Strong Market Tempts Mitchell-Lama Owners To Leave Program

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
IT took a year and a half before her name was reached on the waiting list, but Peggy Goldsmith finally landed an apartment in 1989 in the middle-income Ruppert Towers development on Third Avenue at 90th Street.
A relocation counselor for corporate employees, she had been living for three years in a newly completed luxury building on York Avenue. But the rent was going up to $1,550 a month, which was too high for her. 
 The Ruppert rent for a 19th-floor, one-bedroom was $920.84, and her income -- below the maximum of $77,350 under the formula used in middle-income developments to determine eligibility, but higher than the minimum of about $36,000 -- made her eligible for it. The rent has remained at $920.84 ever since.
Older tenants are paying less for a similar apartment, and newer tenants are paying no more, unless they are on a higher floor or have a better view. Some tenants pay a surcharge based on income, but all pay less than what market rents have become for comparable vacant apartments on the Upper East Side.
"My own apartment would rent for at least $2,000 on the open market," said Ms. Goldsmith.
The prospect that these apartments may in fact be subject to market rents in the not too distant future -- for current as well as new tenants -- has the residents of Ruppert Towers and its companion project across the street, Yorkville Towers, alarmed. The owner has applied to buy out of the governmental program under which Ruppert Yorkville was built, and the rents, in contrast to those in middle-income projects in the city that have "gone private" in the past, will be unregulated once the buyout is complete.
Ruppert Yorkville Towers, on the two large blocks between 90th and 92d Streets, from Third to Second Avenue, was built in the early 70's under the middle-income housing production program known as Mitchell-Lama, in honor of the two deceased state legislators who sponsored it in the 50's, Senator MacNeil Mitchell, a Manhattan Republican, and Assemblyman Alfred A. Lama, a Brooklyn Democrat. The development has 1,258 apartments, 52,500 square feet of retail and office space and parking for 492 cars.
The Mitchell-Lama legislation allows the rental owner, or, in the case of co-ops, the co-op corporation, the option, 20 years after the building has been completed, of paying off the longterm bonds that financed construction and starting to pay full taxes. In the 1980's, a number of Mitchell-Lama projects across the state decided to do this. Some rentals that went private later converted to co-op or condominium status.
In the early 90's, in a weaker rental market and a difficult mortgage market, buyouts subsided. But with the strengthening of the market, they have resumed within the last few months, especially in locations with strong housing demand.
Both New York State and New York City operate Mitchell-Lama programs. Although the state's program is statewide, many of its projects are in the city. The state has generated 117 projects in the city, with 76,500 apartments, with the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal as the supervising agency. Sixteen of these projects, with 11,200 apartments, all rentals, have bought out of the program since its inception.
Most recently, the 373-unit co-op known as Rivercross, on Roosevelt Island, has filed an application with the state agency to withdraw.
Under the city's program, 153 developments with over 62,000 apartments have been built. There have been 11 completed buyouts -- nine rentals and two co-ops -- totaling 2,400 apartments. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development is the supervising agency.
In addition to the buyout application for Ruppert Yorkville, similar applications are pending at the agency for the 168-unit Cooper Gramercy Plaza apartments, at Second Avenue and 23d Street, and for the Kew Gardens Hills garden apartments, with 1,265 units, near Queens College.
The Westgate development on West 97th Street, between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues, completed its buyout from the state program in April. The apartments went into the rent-stabilization system at the existing rent level after the buyout, and vacancies, as they occur, are rerented at levels permitted under the rent-stabilization system.
"They're turning it into a luxury rental," said Judith Ennes, head of the tenants' association. "I have no problem with enhanced services, but all this comes at a cost for us." Tenants can no longer go directly to their cars in the garage; valet service must bring the cars to the entrance, she said. And laundering in the remodeled laundry room is more expensive.
But at Ruppert Yorkville, as at Cooper Gramercy, the rents will be unregulated after the buyout.
Under the state Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974, Mitchell-Lama buildings completed before Jan. 1, 1974, are subject to rent stabilization when they leave the program, if they are in a community that has adopted stabilization. Those completed later are not. Ruppert Towers received a temporary certificate of occupancy in August 1974, the management says, and Yorkville Towers received it in February 1975. Cooper Gramercy was completed in 1976.
Will tenants, therefore, be faced with an abrupt demand from the owner for a market rent once the city housing agency authorizes the buyout, as it appears compelled to do under the law? Will the many tenants paying as little as $400 to $700 for an apartment -- about 20 percent of the building, the management says -- be faced with rents two or three times that amount once their leases expire?
Not immediately, said Fred DeMatteis, the 75-year-old principal in the DeMatteis Organization of Uniondale, L.I., which built Ruppert Yorkville. A plan will be developed to raise rents in stages, he said. Robert Seavey, principal in the Seavey Organization, which built and manages Cooper Gramercy, also said that higher rents for existing tenants would have to be phased in gradually.
"It was always our plan to get of the program out at some time," said Mr. DeMatteis, who said that Ruppert Yorkville would be a longterm family investment.
But Lila Dyas, president of the Ruppert Yorkville Tenants Association, said that a market-rate development might ultimately endanger the social and economic integration that was a goal of the city, tenants and developer as well when Ruppert Yorkville was built. The development is in an urban renewal area, and government has invested both in land acquisition and site improvements, including a public park.
"It's a community, not just another luxury building," Ms. Dyas said. "If there are luxury rents most of the tenants will not be able to live there. Where will they go?"
Galvanized into action by notification of the buyout plan, the Ruppert Yorkville Tenants Association hired Stuart M. Saft, a lawyer who is also chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives, to represent it. Mr. Saft said he did not believe that DeMatteis had the right under existing agreements with the city to buy out of the program at the present time.
He also said that he was prepared to negotiate with the ownership. "I am happy to negotiate anything as long as the tenants are protected," he said. Some of the substantial operating reserves that the property has accumulated will have to be spent for what he said have been deferred building improvements.
Representing the DeMatteis Organization and the Seavey Organization is Albert A. Walsh , who was head of the Housing and Development Administration, predecessor to the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, in the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay in the 60's, and is also a former chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.
The form that any phase-in of rent increases might take is of considerable interest to housing specialists. Some suggested that in addition to a general phase-in over perhaps three or four years to a level at or near market rent, it might be possible to soften the year-to-year impact of rent increases on moderate-income tenants. The city would have to participate, perhaps by agreeing to phase in new property taxes, and/or by agreeing to let the ownership set aside a portion of any remaining reserve funds, which are normally turned back to the city after a buyout, for a subsidy pool.
One possible approach to protecting tenants, according to Louis Winnick, the longtime New York City housing economist, might be to guarantee those with incomes below a certain threshold, for a limited number of years, rent increases no higher than the rent-stabilization guidelines formula would allow. The difference between their rent payments and the actual phase-in rent for their apartment could be subsidized from building reserves.
"There can be a formula that protects the most vulnerable people for a limited number of years, but you can't eliminate pain altogether," Mr. Winnick said.
At Cooper Gramercy, however, reserves are minimal, Mr. Walsh reported. Current rents there average $600 for a one-bedroom and $750 to $800 for a two-bedroom.
Under the Mitchell-Lama program, rents are established on the basis of the amount of revenue needed to cover operating costs, limited property taxes, mortgage debt, building reserves, and return on equity, which has usually been 6 percent. The tenant pays a proportionate share of the buildingwide rent. This contrasts with the system in many subsidized low-income projects, in which the tenant pays only a fixed percentage of income as rent, and the Federal Government pays the remainder of the rent required for fiscal stability.
In re-rentals, there is usually no vacancy allowance. Incoming tenants typically pay the same rent that the departed tenant paid. When rents must rise to meet rising costs, the owner applies to the supervising agency for a buildingwide increase. The increase is apportioned to apartments on the basis of size.
IN 1996, for example, a 25 percent rent increase spread out over two years was granted by the city for the Kew Gardens Hills development in Queens. Two Trees Development Company, of Brooklyn, the owner, has applied for a buyout. The development will become rent-stabilized once it is approved.
There are income limits on eligibility for Mitchell-Lama apartments. The applicant's income cannot exceed seven times the annual rent if the household has three or fewer members, or eight times the annual rent if there are four members or more.
A family of three or fewer earning as much as $75,600 a year would be eligible for a one-bedroom apartment renting for $900 a month, or $10,800 a year. The typical incoming tenant pays about 15 to 17 percent of annual income as rent, managers say, which often makes Mitchell-Lama housing a good rental deal in its location. Waiting lists normally run from five to 10 years across the city.
At Ruppert Yorkville the waiting list is four years. The management, a DeMatteis entity called R.Y. Management Company, last applied for a rent increase in 1980. The increase was granted a year later, and the development was also granted, as of 1982, the unusual right to raise the rent after the first vacancy -- but not after subsequent vacancies -- for incoming tenants to a level based on 1982 market rents.
A similar system had been used to assist the Waterside Mitchell-Lama development on the East River at 25th Street, whose three phases were completed between 1973 and 1975, and which was threatened with longterm fiscal problems. City officials agreed with the owner that a higher rent schedule was needed, but rather than raise rents for tenants in place, they agreed to the system of higher vacancy rents. In subsequent buildingwide rent-increase orders in the 90's, new vacancy increases have been reauthorized.
The rental income that the one-time vacancy increases have provided at Ruppert Yorkville, supplemented over the last two years by surcharges paid by tenants whose incomes exceed the rent-to-income ratios for new arrivals, have been sufficient to cover costs and provide the limited return on investment that the program allows.
Another unusual factor at Ruppert Yorkville -- as at Waterside -- is that it is only in the last two years that tenants have been required to file income and household composition affidavits annually. They pay surcharges roughly equivalent to the percentage by which their income exceeds the maximum allowed under the admission formula. But whatever their income is, the rent cannot be more than 50 percent over the base rent.
The system of rent surcharges for over-income tenants is used in Mitchell-Lama developments generally. But in some of those that were completed in the 70's, surcharges were initially waived, because it was thought that it would have weakened rather than strengthened building finances to force tenants to pay them. The over-income tenants might well have moved out.
Robert J. Klehammer, vice president of R.Y. Management, said that, after Waterside, Ruppert Yorkville probably has the highest average rents of any Mitchell-Lama -- $725 for a studio, $925 for a one-bedroom, $1,340 for a two-bedroom and $1,700 for a three-bedroom, including gas and electricity. Mr. Klehammer also said that the operating reserve that would be available to return to the city after a buyout would probably be about $10 million.
The property is in the midst of a $9 million improvement program, he said, which has already brought in new boilers to produce hot water, and new roofs, and is replacing all the elevators and most of the sidewalks.
"After we leave the program the owner is planning to spend money to upgrade the lobby, with a new valet service and doorman and concierge service," he said.
He also said that 20 percent of the tenants pay the rent surcharge without reporting their income on the annual affidavits, and that among those who do report their incomes, 8 percent report them as over $100,000 a year. This suggests that close to a third of the tenants are paying no more than 15 percent of their income for rent, he said.
ACCORDING to brokers, unregulated one-bedroom apartments comparable to those at Ruppert Yorkville in the neighborhood rent for $2,000 to $2,200 a month, and two-bedrooms for $2,500 to $2,800. At the Whitney, a 200-unit co-op at 200 East 90th Street, Cheryl Bassin, a broker working for Charles H. Greenthal, the managing agent, said that if one-bedrooms were rented out, they would rent for $2,000 to $2,300 a month, and two-bedrooms would go for $2,800 to $3,000.
The Ruppert Yorkville buildings pay about $1.5 million a year in property taxes; as a private development they will probably pay about $6.5 million a year, Mr. Klehammer said. The property has $52 million outstanding on its mortgage, which will have to be repaid to the city along with the excess reserves.
"Uncertainty is already forcing some people to move," said Conrad Eberstein, an original tenant who is vice president of the tenants' association, "and if there is a significant disruption of the rent, a lot of people are going to have to move out of the city."
The Seavey Organization, the builder-owner of Cooper Gramercy Plaza on Second Avenue and 23d Street, is one of the city's major Mitchell-Lama developers. It has built six of them, with about 1,000 apartments. It has not previously applied for a buyout.
Cooper Gramercy has had an inadequate rent structure from the start, Mr. Seavey said, and it has been a struggle to operate it effectively.
Phyllis Seavey, Mr. Seavey's wife, a lawyer who has overseen the management of the Seavey buildings for 20 years, said that Cooper Gramercy was now operating in the black. But it is still not producing the income needed to make major needed plaza and roof repairs, she said.
Mrs. Seavey made it clear that building finances are not the only reason for the buyout decision. "The cumulative effect of the over-regulation that the building has been subjected to is discouraging," she said. She indicated a desire for greater flexibility in tenant selection and building management than has been possible under Mitchell-Lama rules.
The Westgate apartments, on West 97th Street, are owned by a partnership in which the Koeppel family, whose investments in Manhattan and Long Island real estate go back four generations, are the principals. The general partners are Adolph Koeppel, a lawyer based in Mineola, L.I., and H. Ralph Taylor, a retired official who once ran the Federal urban renewal program. There are three side-by-side buildings with 427 apartments, completed in 1968.
Among other changes since the buyout, security has been strengthened and Manhattan Parking has taken over the operation of the garage. William W. Koeppel, who manages the property, said that only two apartments, both one-bedrooms, have become available since the buyout. They got new kitchens, baths and wood flooring and rented out at the permissible rents for vacancies under the stabilization system. They rented for $1,100 and $1,200 a month. "Without stabilization the apartments would have rented for $1,600 to $1,700 a month," Mr. Koeppel said.
The buyout process under the Mitchell-Lama program usually takes nine months to a year, officials say. It will therefore be December at the earliest before the applications for Ruppert Yorkville or Cooper Gramcery can be approved.

HEADLINE: Superbugs

BYLINE: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg; Sheryl Gay Stolberg reports on medicine and health policy for The New York Times.

 BODY:
There was nothing out of the ordinary about the slender glass tubes of blood that arrived in Sharon S. Rotun's laboratory late in the afternoon of March 20, 1998. A pale, stocky woman with the impatient manner of someone who is overworked and underpaid, Rotun was the microbiology supervisor at United Hospital Medical Center, a small community hospital in the working-class town of Port Chester, N.Y., just north of Manhattan in Westchester County. The two blood cultures were among roughly a dozen sent to the lab that day. Whoever ordered the testing was evidently in a hurry, Rotun recalls, because he or she hadn't even bothered to scribble the usual instructions on the accompanying slip.
The blood belonged to a 79-year-old Westchester County man, a retired New York City narcotics detective who had been admitted to the hospital earlier that day. For the past year and a half, the detective's kidneys had been failing him, a condition that required him to undergo dialysis three times a week. On most days, he tolerated the tedious procedure with a smile. But on the morning of March 20, the retired detective awoke in an unusually sour mood. 
 "He didn't want to eat; he didn't want to get dressed; he didn't want to get washed," said his daughter, Carole, who agreed to be interviewed on the condition that she be identified only by her first name and that her father not be identified at all. She got him dressed, quickly served him
breakfast and, despite his protests, sent him to the local dialysis center. "You have to go,"' the daughter told him. "You have no choice."
The old man was feverish, short of breath and so disoriented he could barely speak by the time the kidney specialist, Dr. Sam Natarajan, saw him. Natarajan immediately suspected staphylococcus aureas, a bacteria that frequently causes illness among dialysis patients, who become infected when the microbes enter the bloodstream along their intravenous lines. The doctor performed just enough dialysis to clear the fluid backed up in his patient's lungs -- a "dry cleaning," in the argot of renal disease -- and then called an ambulance to take the man to the hospital. Twelve hours later, the patient was dead.
In what turned out to be the final hours of his life, the ailing detective was hooked up to an intravenous drip of vancomycin, a powerful antibiotic that has been the ultimate weapon against staph for the last three decades. Doctors regard vancomycin as the drug of last resort, the medicine they rely on to kill germs that are too vicious to respond to anything else. Normally, vancomycin begins attacking staph in the bloodstream immediately. "We call vancomycin 'the big gun,"' Rotun says. Which is why, when she first examined the lab results from the dead detective, she did not believe what she saw.
A staph infection was indeed flourishing in the detective's blood when he died. But not just any strain of staph. This was a rare and unusually dangerous germ, a supermicrobe that infectious-disease experts have been dreading for years. It goes by the name of VISA, for Vancomycin Intermediate-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureas, and it represents the bacterial world's most potent counterattack against antibiotics.
As soon as the results of the detective's blood tests came in, Rotun posted signs all over her laboratory, instructing her subordinates not to give out any information. The last thing the hospital needed, she thought, was a swarm of reporters generating panic over a killer superbug that could be spreading through the hospital's corridors. Not even Carole, the detective's daughter, was told. Instead, Rotun repeated the lab tests. Then, when she had convinced herself there was no mistake, she picked up the phone and called her longtime colleague and friend, Ginny McMath, United Hospital's infection control officer.
"I hope you're sitting down,"' Rotun told McMath. "I think we have the first VISA in New York State."
In recent years, it has become fashionable in the media to warn of the exotic new infectious diseases percolating in faraway lands. The gruesome Ebola virus, which swept through Zaire three years ago, has captured the public imagination in books and on film. But while Hollywood has been busy making scary movies, infectious-disease experts know that the bigger danger is in our own backyard: garden variety germs that for decades have been so easily felled by antibiotics that most people, including some scientists, naively assumed they were no longer a threat.
For the past decade, however, scientists at the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta and all over the world have been sounding alarm bells about the growth of antibiotic resistance, a problem that has been fueled by patients who demand antibiotics for every bout of the sniffles and by doctors who give in to such demands. The list of dangerously virulent drug-resistant microbes is growing all the time: streptococcus pneumoniae, which causes pneumonia, childhood ear infections and meningitis; mycobacterium tuberculosis, which causes TB, and neisseria gonorrhoeae, which causes gonorrhea.
But none are as frightening to medical experts as the VISA strains of staph. Within the past 18 months, the C.D.C. has documented the first four cases ever, the most recent being that of the New York detective. Their emergence is an ominous harbinger of what Dr. Stuart B. Levy, director of the Center for Adaptation Genetics and Drug Resistance at Tufts, calls "the worst thing that could happen in clinical infectious disease."
One reason for concern is that staph is a particularly common and robust organism; it lives on the skin and in the nostrils of otherwise healthy people as part of what scientists call the "natural flora," where it is relatively harmless. But if it gains access to the body through scrapes, cuts or surgical incisions, as it often does, it can cause a range of ailments, from pus-oozing cuts to sepsis, an often lethal infection of the bloodstream. Children who scrape their knees are susceptible to staph, as are housewives who cut their hands in the kitchen or anybody else with an open wound. Should VISA strains become common, simple cuts and scrapes could become mortal wounds.
To complicate matters, hospitals are already breeding grounds for a host of dangerous bugs. Each year, nearly 90,000 patients in the United States die of a hospital-acquired infection, and many of those cases are theoretically treatable with antibiotics. Staph is often the culprit, picking on vulnerable patients like the elderly, the immunocompromised and those undergoing surgery. The emergence of an untreatable strain of staph would put virtually any healthy person at risk, and could turn a bad situation into a disastrous one. As Levy says, "Right now, we are still in most cases able to use vancomycin. Now let's say we lose vancomycin. Where are the deaths going to go? They're going to go up. This number could double."
Now that these bugs are figuring out ways to evade the very miracle drugs that have always worked so well against them, there is little on the horizon to keep the virulent new supergerms in check. Joshua Lederberg, a Rockefeller University professor who is widely regarded as one of the nation's leading authorities on infectious disease, warns that far too little attention is being paid to the threat of drug-resistant germs. "The odds of Ebola breaking out are quite low, but the stakes are very high," Lederberg says. "With antibiotic resistance, the odds are certain and the stakes are just as high. It is happening right under our noses."
And it is happening at a particularly precarious moment, when many hospitals are cutting back on services as they struggle to survive the changing economics of health care. United Hospital in Port Chester, for example, reflecting national trends, plans to "outsource" Rotun's lab. Meanwhile, drug manufacturers, which in the early 1980's all but abandoned development of new antibiotics on the theory that they were no longer needed, find themselves behind the curve; they are hustling to invent new treatments and put them on pharmacy shelves. And that is why the emergence of the vancomycin-resistant strains is viewed as such a worrisome public health threat. The next generation of new antimicrobials is, by the industry's own estimate, at least several years away, creating a dangerous window in which the virulent new microbes might be able to spread unchecked. If that happens, modern medicine might revert to the days before penicillin, when sore throats could become fatal and patients who walked into the hospital for routine surgery might be carried out in coffins.
"If we have no antibiotics, it reopens the whole question of intrusive surgical procedures and vastly changes the calculus of their safety," Lederberg says. In the pre-penicillin era, people occasionally died while having their appendixes removed -- not because the surgery itself was dangerous but because germs crept into the patients' incisions, causing infections that spread to the bloodstream and raged out of control. "Those days," Lederberg says, "have a chance of coming back if the drugs we have been relying on just stop working."
To trace the evolution of the new superbugs, experts inevitably look back to the introduction of penicillin in 1943. If ever there was a miracle of modern medicine, it was penicillin, the first drug that could quell a wide range of microbial invaders without harming the body. "It was as if Prometheus had stolen fire from the gods," Levy, the Tufts University professor, wrote in his 1992 book "The Antiobiotic Paradox." "The applications of this wonder drug seemed all but limitless."
For its ability to kill bacteria, penicillin was dubbed an "antibiotic." It was available at first without a prescription, and consumers gobbled it up like candy. (Even with prescriptions, "the cult of the antibiotic," as Alexander Tomasz, chief of the microbiology laboratory at Rockefeller University, calls it, continues today.)
But amid the initial euphoria, penicillin's discoverer, the British bacteriologist Alexander Fleming, urged caution; in a 1945 interview with The New York Times, Fleming warned that misuse of penicillin could lead to the propagation of mutant forms of bacteria that would resist the new miracle drug. Before long, Levy writes, Fleming's predictions came true; an estimated 14 percent of the staphylococcus strains isolated from patients in a London hospital had developed resistance to penicillin by 1946, just three years after the miracle drug was introduced.
In the three decades following the introduction of penicillin, new microbe-killers were discovered, tested and approved for marketing at a phenomenal pace. Streptomycin, erythromycin, tetracycline, amoxicillin -- all became staples of the American medicine cabinet. Germs like staphylococcus aureas had never before seemed so vulnerable; by the 1970's, the common wisdom was that the battle of the bugs versus the drugs was over. With more than 100 antibiotics on the pharmacy shelves, the Government de-emphasized bacterial research and the drug industry, sensing a saturated market, shifted resources elsewhere. Bacteriology was passe.
Perhaps no drug is as emblematic of this hubris as Ziracin, a member of a new class of antibiotics called everninomicins. Everninomicins were discovered by scientists at the Schering-Plough Research Institute in the 1960's. From 1979 to 1984, company researchers worked with these antimicrobials, hoping to develop a medicine that could combat staph aureas and other similar microbes. But the effort was abandoned as unnecessary on the theory that no bug could beat vancomyin. "Of course," says Dr. Jean-Jacques Garaud, the company's director of clinical research, "that was pretty arrogant thinking. The bacteria were more creative."
In a report released in May, the Institute of Medicine complained that no nation, including the United States, has an adequate system for monitoring the emergence of these drug-resistant germs. It found that despite public education campaigns to persuade doctors not to prescribe unnecessary drugs, they still do: 20 to 50 percent of the 145 million prescriptions given each year to outpatients are unnecessary, the report found, as are 25 to 45 percent of the 190 million annual doses of antibiotics delivered in the hospital.
In the microbial world, where only the fittest survive, some germs inevitably stumble upon genetic mutations that protect them from the drugs. In the presence of antibiotics, the weak germs -- those that lack these mutations -- die off, leaving only the strong ones to survive and proliferate. The more antibiotics are used and misused, the more these drug-resistant bugs will spread. Moreover, as Lederberg showed decades ago in work that won a Nobel Prize, bacteria essentially talk to one another, exchanging genes -- including drug-resistant genes -- back and forth.
The net effect of this activity is clear: many germs are becoming resistant not only to one drug but to six and seven at a time. The story of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis is by now well known. Less familiar is this fact, reported by the Institute of Medicine: more than 90 percent of staph aureas strains are now resistant to penicillin and a wide variety of other antibiotics, including methicillin, the drug that is next to last in the line of defense, before vancomycin. These are not statistics of mere academic interest. In New York City alone, methicillin-resistant staph infections killed 1,409 people in 1995. That is precisely 200 more people than were murdered in the city that year.
As resistance to each antibiotic continued to develop in the mid-1980's, infectious disease experts have been waiting and watching for the last domino to fall: the emergence of staph strains that are resistant to vancomycin.
Perhaps the most wakeful watcher has been Fred C. Tenover, chief of the C.D.C.'s Nosocomial Pathogens Laboratory Branch, the national reference laboratory for hospital-acquired, or nosocomial, infections. Tenover has been anticipating the appearance of vancomycin-resistant staph for years.
In his cinder-block warren of laboratories on the third floor of the disease control centers' headquarters in Atlanta, Tenover analyzes novel microbes sent by scientists from all over the globe. His specialty is antibiotic resistance; if a patient anywhere in the United States has a persistent infection that does not seem to respond to drugs, the bacteria will be packed up in special sealed shipping tubes and sent overnight to Tenover, who can test its susceptibility to a host of different medicines and call the doctor with treatment advice in two to four days.
On Dec. 16, 1996, Tenover received a tip by electronic mail that a Japanese doctor had detected the world's first VISA. "At first, I was skeptical," says the C.D.C. scientist, whose lab had received numerous cultures over the last year purporting to be the long-dreaded VISA strain. "We tested all of them," Tenover says, but none of them had ever been true.
But the scientist who had isolated this strain was Dr. Keiichi Hiramatsu of Juntendo University in Tokyo, one of the most respected bacterial geneticists in Japan. The case, Tenover learned in a subsequent E-mail exchange with Hiramatsu, involved a 4-month old boy who had undergone surgery in May 1996 and developed a staph aureas infection that was resistant to methicillin. His doctors then tried vancomycin, but it didn't work. Hiramatsu tested the bug, classified it as a VISA and sent it to the C.D.C. for verification.
The bug arrived in Atlanta on Jan. 29, 1997. To confirm Hiramatsu's results, Tenover tried to grow the bacteria in a series of tiny test tubes of nutrient-rich solution, each containing a different concentration of vancomycin. The goal was to determine the smallest amount of drug necessary to kill the germ; microbiologists call this level the minimum inhibitory concentration, an important measure of a bacterial strain's virulence. Most staph bugs are wiped out by .25 to .5 micrograms of vancomycin per milliliter of solution.
But at those concentrations, the Japanese bug kept growing; the minimum knockout punch of vancomycin, both Tenover and Hiramatsu discovered, was a whopping 8 micrograms per milliliter -- in other words, 16 to 32 times the normal amount of vancomycin necessary to destroy staph aureas. "This," Tenover mused to himself, "is very new."
By the time Tenover and Hiramatsu published their findings in the July 11, 1997, issue of the C.D.C.'s Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, another patient, this one in Michigan, had come down with a similar vancomycin-resistant bug. The following month, a third case emerged in New Jersey. Then came the Port Chester strain. Each time, the minimum inhibitory concentration was the same: 8. Authorities in France and England have since reported several more cases, although Tenover has not confirmed them.
Experts have long believed that staph aureas would remain at least partly susceptible to vancomycin until the minimum inhibitory concentration reached a level of 32. That, at least, was the theory. Now that doctors have seen these superbugs in practice, Tenover thinks the figure may need to be adjusted downward. "It could be," he said, "that 8 is as high as an organism needs to go to cause a treatment failure." In other words, full resistance may already be here.
There is no evidence that the four documented VISA strains are linked to one another, although the spread of these bugs, Tenover says, is only a matter of time. That each occurred in highly industrialized, medically advanced nations is probably no accident; while drug-resistant organisms are cropping up all over the world, the problem has been aggravated by countries like the United States where antibiotics are widely used. But antibiotic resistance is a global and social problem. Even if an individual scrupulously follows antibiotic regimens and uses them sparingly, he or she is still vulnerable to resistant strains that have emerged anywhere in the world. And with air travel and international commerce shrinking the global village, no place is safe. "These are international problems," Tomasz says. "The next wave of bugs is just a few days away."
The patients in Japan, Michigan and New Jersey were fortunate; they were treated intensively with a combination of other antibiotics and all survived. The New York detective died of pneumonia and the staph infection, according to the doctor who treated him in the hospital, although the underlying kidney disease was a contributing factor.
Complete resistance looms on the horizon. "Before the end of the decade," says Levy, "we will have fully resistant staph aureas." He does not need to point out that the end of the decade is less than 18 months away.
Drug companies are now pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into new antibiotics; as of 1996, the last time the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America surveyed its members, there were 27 new microbe-killers in the development pipeline.
"The war is not won, as everybody knows," says Richard Colonno, the chief of drug discovery for the infectious diseases division of Bristol-Myers Squibb. "Clearly, the research excitement is now more on the bacterial side." In part, that is a response to the urgent need for new drugs. But it has just as much to do, Colonno says, with the revolution in molecular biology. Now scientists can map the genetic blueprints of bacteria, and those maps provide clues to the weak spots of the bugs.
Colonno's mission at Bristol-Myers, and the mission of countless other drug-company scientists around the nation and the world, is to create an entirely new antibiotic, one that employs different mechanisms to kill microbes than the ones already on the market. Simply adding new drugs to the existing antibiotic arsenal is not good enough; so many different germs have figured out ways to avoid so many different drugs that a whole new class of pharmaceutical agent is needed. "It is the only way," Colonno says, "that we are going to get out of the resistance dilemma." And so the race is on.
The most promising candidates seem to be linezolid from Pharmacia & Upjohn and the once-abandoned Schering-Plough drug, Ziracin. In the early 1990's, the company picked up the project again and Ziracin is now in the late stages of human testing. But bringing a new class of antibiotics to market will take time; even these front-runners are not expected to reach pharmacy shelves until at least the year 2000 or 2001.
In the meantime, it may be left to an experimental drug called Synercid, from the French firm Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, to fill in the gap. Synercid, which is on the verge of receiving approval from the Food and Drug Administration, is the first injectible form of a class of antibiotics called streptogramins that are being used in animals but not humans. It was not developed to combat vancomycin-resistant staph, but Tenover, the C.D.C. expert, has tested it against VISA strains in the laboratory and says it seems to work.
But Synercid has its limitations, says Levy. "It has been used in a different form already in animals," he says, "so resistance is already out there. The question is how long it will take before resistance compromises its use."
Perhaps the greatest obstacle to breaking the cyle of resistance may be economic rather than scientific. Drug companies, which are in business to make money, might be expected to market these new antibiotics aggressively, trying to persuade doctors to prescibe them as often as possible. But such rampant prescribing practices create the same problem all over again. Officials at the F.D.A. are wrestling with precisely this paradox. We have to balance drug development with drug use, says Dr. Dianne Murphy, director of one of the F.D.A.'s offices of drug evaluation. And that is a very difficult balance.
As the race to find new drugs proceeds, supermicrobes like the one that infected the New York detective will undoubtedly continue to flourish, leaving a trail of nervous public health officials and grieving families in their wake.
Three days after the former detective died, mourners gathered at a stately stone church in the town of Harrison. On that same day, with utmost secrecy, officials at United Hospital were frantically trying to determine where the vancomycin-resistant staph bug came from and, more important, whether the germ had spread. The unenviable job of getting to the bottom of those questions fell to Ginny McMath, the hospital's infection control official. The name of the detective was familiar to her; she remembered him from a previous admission in January, when he was treated for a staph infection that was resistant to methicillin. He was given vancomycin for several weeks, but the episode earned him an entry into a red loose-leaf binder where McMath carefully catalogues every instance of a drug-resistant strain at the hospital. The case fell under the worrisome category of M.R.S.A. -- methicillin resistant staph aureas.
When Sharon Rotun called with news of the detective's blood tests, McMath was alarmed but not altogether surprised; a 79-year-old man with a history of kidney disease and methicillin-resistant staph, she knew, was the optimal candidate for a VISA strain. "It's sort of like the natural experiment that we would do in the laboratory," explains Tenover, the C.D.C. expert, "except that in this case, the patient is the Petri dish."
McMath immediately began to track down everyone who had contact with the detective in the days before he died. Working with Natarajan, the kidney specialist, she identified 44 people -- dialysis workers, doctors, nurses and family members -- who might have been exposed to the deadly microbe. Each had their nostrils and, in some cases, their hands cultured to see if they were "colonized" with the bug.
Making the notifications was a delicate task. The cause of the detective's death had not been made public, and Natarajan and McMath were careful not to reveal too much. "There's a fear that people won't want to come here," McMath said. It was left to Natarajan to call the detective's family. "I told them that he had a staph infection, but there was a peculiarity and we wanted to see if anybody else had the same type of infection," he said. "I didn't want to cause them any panic."
That instinct -- not to cause panic -- is an understandable one, experts say, but it can also lead to public health problems of its own. Suppressing information about a potentially deadly germ might lead people who have been exposed to it not to take the testing seriously; indeed, Carole's daughter declined at first to be cultured, thinking it was unnecessary.
On April 24, one month to the day after the detective's funeral, Carole was driving to work when she heard a report over the car radio that an elderly dialysis patient in Port Chester had died of a rare staph infection. Her father was not identified, but it did not take much to put two and two together. "I didn't realize how serious a bacteria it was until I heard it on the radio," she said. "It really upset me that they were not more forthcoming."
As it turned out, 14 of the 44 people who were tested were carrying staph aureas. Of the 14, 2 -- a doctor and a patient -- harbored a germ that was resistant to methicillin. Genetic typing conducted by Tenover's lab, however, found that none of these bugs were identical to the one that infected Carole's father. It was an encouraging sign; the deadly bug, it seems, is buried with the detective.
Meanwhile, McMath's investigation, supervised by both state health officials and the C.D.C., quickly established that neither the hospital nor the dialysis center was a problem; Dr. David Ackman, who directs the state's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said infection control practices were meticulous at both. Even so, Ackman said: "We were very concerned. We wanted to make sure that there weren't other people carrying this around."
Ackman and other infectious-disease experts no longer view these episodes as isolated incidents; they are more like bullets that are becoming increasingly difficult to dodge. "We were lucky," says Tenover, who has no trouble spinning out scenarios for the near future that are far worse. "The next time it may be somebody who is on an open hospital ward, or maybe they have been in the hospital for several weeks, or been a lot of places before their infection is recognized. Or it might be someone in a nursing home that can spread it among 80 patients, in which case we are going to have a big job on our hands."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 2 about bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics misspelled the name of a species of bacteria. It is Staphylococcus aureus, not staphylococcus aureas.
