HEADLINE: Leaders, Leaders Everywhere

BYLINE: By Polly Morrice; Polly Morrice is writing a book about autism.

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
When I was in college I helped found a literary magazine that had no editors. Actually, two of us were given that title, but it was purely honorific. We held no more sway than anyone else on the staff. As for naming an "editor in chief" -- we were having none of that. It was hierarchical and patriarchal.
Twenty years later, our militant egalitarianism seems not only dated but also quaint, like a typewritten letter. 
 College students in today's boom economy show little interest in sharing the glory. Instead, like their elders in business, government and academia, they have embraced the cult of leadership.
The Internet currently lists nearly 5,000 matches for "leadership programs." They range from the University of Minnesota's Leaderquest, which "strives to develop student understanding and application of leadership theory and practice," to the programs offered at the Banff Center for Management in Canada, where "senior leaders . . . explore their leadership styles and requisite competencies, focusing on managing change and re-engineering processes."
The skills are described so nebulously that they could apply to working the cash register, but never mind: soggy, directionless prose is a hallmark of leadership mania. Your 1990's big shot would never do anything so point-A-to-point-B as, say, cross the Rubicon. She is much more likely to create value in an increasingly technoglobal society through outcomes-based decision making.
The most depressing aspect of this woolly hierarchy-speak is how it has seeped out of the world of business and management -- where you might expect it -- and into daily life. Parents who agree to organize the P.T.A. carnival are no longer good-natured helpers, but "volunteer leadership." Youngsters seeking summer jobs at the pool prepare themselves through courses in "Lifeguarding and Leadership"; their athletic peers don shoulder pads and jog off to "Football and Leadership" camp.
All this attention to life at the top begs a number of questions. As Garry Wills notes in his book, "Certain Trumpets: The Call of Leaders," published in 1994, "The ideal seems to be a world in which everyone is a leader -- but who would be left for them to be leading?"
The assumption that meaningful existence occurs only at the summit, preferably a corporate one, ignores how many endeavors (writing, painting, software design, among others) require the ability to work in solitude rather than command a platoon. And it undercuts the importance of essential nuts-and-bolts jobs like teaching, nursing and playing backup at a recording session. Finally, as Mr. Wills also points out, nobody assumes leadership unless others agree to become followers.
The truth is that the majority of us end up as members in good standing of the hoi polloi. Leadership courses notwithstanding, most recent college graduates don't step right into the corner office. Many never will, despite the injunction (repeated this spring by every college president in America) that they are the leaders of tomorrow, the rulers of all they survey.
At last the suspicion dawns that leadership is not what it used to be. It's no longer crossing the Rubicon, or even the street. Once you read the fine print, some of the university leadership programs boil down to teaching students to get along with other people, to use their time wisely and to try to grow up. An acceptance of conformity -- of going along to get along -- can be assumed. Doubtless, the popularity of these programs speaks to the same urge for security that has today's collegians flocking to study subjects that promise a comfortable financial return.
Compared with the play-it-safe attitudes of these future leaders, the idealism of my fellow college literati seems admirable, in a confused way. We managed to publish our magazine only twice. It could have been a lot better, too, especially if somebody had taken charge.
But our reticence has its own nostalgic value, as a relic of a time when people were willing to act, instead of wanting only to direct.

HEADLINE: Bringing China on Line (With Official Blessing)

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Peter Yip is not shy about his ambitions. As he steers a visitor through the bustling offices of the China Internet Corporation here, Mr. Yip describes how his company will be a catalyst for bringing the Internet to China and its 1.2 billion people.
Employees are busy collecting news dispatches from Reuters and Bloomberg, which they send to Beijing to be translated into Chinese. Later, China Internet will post the material on its service, where anyone in China with a computer and the $30-a-month subscription fee can log on to a world of Western news. 
 "The Chinese Government recognizes that the Internet is a global thing," said Mr. Yip, 43, the vice chairman of the company, which is based in Hong Kong and backed by the official New China News Agency -- not to mention an impressive array of American technology companies. "That's why they've established a strategy and asked me to help them create a vehicle to allow people to participate."
It is that kind of pronouncement that makes Mr. Yip's rivals seethe. They say China Internet, known as C.I.C., is only one of dozens of companies throughout the country that are racing to put China on line. In China, as in the United States, the Internet seems to be growing too rapidly -- and in too helter-skelter a way -- for any single company to mastermind its development.
"Because the Internet has taken China by storm, there are very different proposals about how to develop it," said Don Xia, chief executive of Unicom Media, a Hong Kong company that is developing Internet services for China Unicom, one of the country's two main telephone companies.
To Mr. Xia and others here, the debate is whether China's Internet should be open or closed; raw or edited, anarchic or controlled. Mr. Yip's company, they say, represents a more controlled, Government-directed approach. At the same time, hundreds of small-time entrepreneurs, most of whom lack China Internet's financial backing or political connections, are laboring to build a truly free Internet.
"C.I.C. is out of step with what Internet users in China are about," said Duncan Clark, managing director of BD Associates, a telecommunications consulting firm in Beijing. "I think companies that make deals with them are actually doing themselves a disservice."
The American companies that have made investments in China Internet, or formed other kinds of partnerships with Mr. Yip, include America Online, Bay Networks, Netscape Communications and Sun Microsystems. And whatever the controversy that Mr. Yip may arouse, the success of his sales pitch is proof that a Chinese Internet is no longer just a utopian vision, but a ripe opportunity for sharp-eyed entrepreneurs.
According to the latest Government statistics, 1.18 million people are using the Internet in mainland China -- nearly double the number last October. While cyberspace is still largely the preserve of 20-something men, it is growing beyond its roots as a tool for academics. Nearly 80 percent of those surveyed said they had bought merchandise over the Internet, and many said they used it for information about entertainment, sports and business.
After much hand-wringing, Beijing seems to have decided that the benefits of the Internet outweigh its dangers. Although it still filters the content of the World Wide Web through central computers -- and periodically blocks access to Web sites such as those of Western news providers like CNN and The New York Times -- Beijing is also upgrading China's network to carry more data, and it has licensed more than 30 companies to offer Internet access.
"The Chinese see the Internet as the savior of their economy," said Kenneth Farrall, a Web site designer who lives in Xiamen, in southeastern China, and is starting an Internet consulting firm. "My impression is that the people blocking Web sites are paying lip service to the old guard in Beijing."
Yet for all the talk about openness, Internet executives here say the Government is still drawn to the idea of creating a vast intranet within the country. Such a network could tap the Web's riches but remain walled off from features deemed subversive -- like pornographic sites, postings from dissidents or anything about Taiwan or Tibet.
China Internet's model is tailor made for this approach. The company, which was started in 1994, operates a proprietary news service called China Wide Web, which has about 1,000 subscribers. For a fee of $30 to $340 a month, depending on the level of service, subscribers receive stock quotations and news from the New China News Agency, Reuters, Bloomberg, the Nikkei wire service and Agence France-Presse. But they cannot gain Web access because the service does not have an Internet connection. By contrast, the majority of people in China who use a dial-up service to get Web access pay a monthly fee of roughly $68 for unlimited use, plus access charges amounting to 50 cents an hour.
Mr. Yip said his long-term goal was to turn the China Wide Web into a Chinese version of the World Wide Web, a vast consumer marketplace with Chinese-language information and entertainment. He said the lack of such content was the biggest hurdle to Internet growth here.
"If you're in New York and you get on the Web, and everything coming at you is in Arabic, you're not going to stay on all that long," said Mr. Yip, who lived in the United States for 20 years and speaks rapid-fire English.
Another analogy for the China Wide Web may be America Online, a subscription-based service that organizes material in a form more digestible than on the Internet. Unsurprisingly, China Internet has a partnership with America Online, in which the companies are developing a Hong Kong version of America Online service.
Mr. Yip's competitors point out that America Online has a link to the World Wide Web, while the China Wide Web does not -- which keeps the Internet's less acceptable material out of the country. "The China Wide Web is an attempt to create a Web that is isolated from the Net," Mr. Clark of BD Associates said. "We're kind of past that already."
Mr. Yip acknowledged that the China Wide Web's lack of an Internet connection was a weakness. But he said it was for financial, not political, reasons: the dominant phone company, China Telecom, had set access fees too high. Unless the Government broke up China Telecom's virtual phone monopoly, it would make no sense to offer Internet access.
China Internet's close ties to the New China News Agency mean other restrictions. The agency has several editors in the company's offices who sift through dispatches from the Western services and pull any that run afoul of laws barring the distribution of political news about Taiwan or Tibet. "We're relying on Xinhua to interpret Chinese law and insure that we don't stray," Mr. Yip said, using the press agency's Chinese name.
So far, China Internet has skirted trouble by sticking to less controversial business and financial news. Its other products include inoffensive features like a Chinese-language site about the World Cup and one about the film star Bruce Lee. But Mr. Yip said that merely by distributing Western news, China Internet was doing its part to open the country.
Mr. Yip, who started and sold several technology companies in the United States before returning to his native Hong Kong in 1989, said the industry's hostility reflected envy at his success in attracting partners and frustration that most companies are still losing money on the Internet.
Indeed, by most yardsticks China Internet would not seem that big a threat. It has fewer subscribers than many of China's struggling Internet-access providers. It has less than $10 million in revenue and is losing money, although Mr. Yip said he expected annual revenue to exceed $25 million in 12 months. And a much-publicized joint venture with Pointcast, the leading purveyor of "push" technology on the Internet, fell apart because of financial disagreements.
Still, Mr. Yip has raised $25 million from investors, and he has turned China Internet into the first stop for technology companies seeking to capitalize on Internet growth.
Some rivals said China Internet represented the triumph of salesmanship over substance. "It's like a Hong Kong-style newspaper," said Edward Zeng, chief executive of Unicom-Sparkice, another Internet venture backed by China Unicom. "It's different than a Western-style newspaper. There's more promotion."
Mr. Yip said he was wounded by the criticism. He said he had sought to build bridges to the younger entrepreneurs, even introducing some to executives or venture capitalists in the United States. "I don't want to be perceived as Big Brother, trying to control the Internet," he said with a sigh.

HEADLINE: Patents;
An appeals court says a mathematical formula can be patented, if it is a moneymaker.

BYLINE: By Teresa Riordan 

 BODY:
IMAGINE that Albert Einstein were alive today and that he were just now formulating his theory of relativity. Could he get a patent on E=mc2 ?
Some patent experts contend Mr. Einstein just might be able to, thanks to a recent ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington. 
 The case in question -- State Street Bank and Trust Company v. Signature Financial Group -- had nothing to do with physics. Rather, at issue was a patent for a data-processing system for a so-called hub-and-spoke mutual fund partnership in which mutual funds pool their assets in an investment portfolio.
The appeals court's ruling has been long awaited by financial services companies, which have resisted the idea that innovative approaches in their industry should be patented. Indeed, Visa and Mastercard filed an amicus brief in the case saying that they were doing just fine without patents, thank you.
But to no avail. The appeals court ruled on July 23 in favor of Signature Financial, upholding its patent.
In its ruling, the court said, "We hold the transformation of data, representing discrete dollar amounts, by a machine through a series of mathematical calculations into a final share price, constitutes a practical application of a mathematical algorithm, formula, or calculation, because it produces 'a useful, concrete, and tangible result.' "
Translation: If your mathematical formula has a practical end, you can probably patent it.
"I believe this is going to cause a surge in patents relating to financial instruments," said Peter A. Roberts, chief executive of College Savings Bank of Princeton, N.J., who in 1988 received a pioneering patent for a computerized prepaid tuition program.
Some patent experts suggested that such an interpretation might have allowed Michael R. Milken, for example, to have patented the idea of junk bonds back in the 1980's.
But the ruling may have even wider implications.
E. Robert Yoches, a partner with the law firm of Finnegan, Henderson, Farabow, Garrett & Dunner in Washington, said he thought the appeals court had made the right decision in the case. But he said the court had gone further than expected in its ruling.
"This is very broad, very sweeping," Mr. Yoches said. "You can probably get a patent on anything as long as it's not purely mathematical -- as long as it produces a concrete, tangible result."
The ruling seems to bolster software patenting guidelines issued three years ago by the Patent and Trademark Office, which expanded the definition of what kinds of software are patentable.
The last time the Supreme Court ruled in this area was in 1981, in the case of Diamond v. Diehr. Then the court held that three categories of matter are unpatentable: laws of nature, natural phenomena and abstract ideas.
Since then, the appeals court, which is the highest patent court in the land short of the Supreme Court, has deviated from this interpretation in a series of rulings.
"The direction the Federal Circuit has been moving is to say you can patent anything as long as it's economically valuable," said Richard H. Stern, who teaches computer patent law at George Washington University.
Stanley Amberg, a patent attorney in New York, said the appeals court had gone too far with the State Street ruling. "The Federal Circuit has crossed over a critical line, and now holds eligible for patent protection any computer-implemented math equation in which the input are numbers and the output are numbers," he said.
"Thus, if Einstein were alive and now uncovered the E = mc2 law of nature, he could effectively monopolize its use in the design of atomic reactors, bombs, et cetera," Mr. Amberg said. "Because, for all practical purposes, a computer must be used to perform the calculation of the amount of energy released."
 
Cutting Paper Use On the Exchange Floor
Despite the advent of cell phones and headsets and special electronic orders, most large buy and sell orders on the New York Stock Exchange still involve paper transactions.
The Papyrus Technology Corporation in New York has patented a system using handheld devices that allow floor brokers to receive and execute orders electronically.
"The floor broker enters information into the device as the order is being filled," said L. Thomas Patterson Jr., one of the inventors. "This takes the paper out of the whole process."
The exchange has developed its own handheld electronic device, which it recently introduced and which is being used by a small number of brokers. Mr. Patterson declined to comment on whether he thought the exchange's devices infringed his patent.
Mr. Patterson, Desmond Sean O'Neill and Stephen Tyler Carroll received patent 5,774,877, which is assigned to Papyrus Technology.

HEADLINE: Loud, Scurrilous and Poised to Win a Democratic Nomination for Governor

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 30

 BODY:
Before jumping into the race for the Democratic nomination for governor, Geoffrey Fieger was best known as the lawyer for Jack Kevorkian, the suicide doctor.
Now he is known as a politician who hurls insults like Thor does his hammer. A millionaire lawyer in a state that prizes the lunch-bucket ethic, he has never held political office. Worse yet, he has been seen driving a Swedish-made car on the streets of Motor City. 
 And he is winning, much to the horror of the Democratic Party and leaders of the United Auto Workers.
Mr. Fieger, who leads in opinion polls in Tuesday's contest over two more conventional politicians, Larry Owen and Doug Ross, cannot wait to throw insults at Gov. John Engler, Republican.
He has characterized the Governor as racist, a moron, a liar, fat and effeminate. "Dumber than Dan Quayle and twice as ugly," Mr. Fieger said about the Governor one recent morning, then stopped to chuckle. A brash populist, Mr. Fieger has taken the lead largely by building support among black voters in Detroit, who like his irreverent style and unvarnished talk about racism. As a lawyer, he has won some high-profile civil rights cases for blacks. And he talks loudly and proudly about his father's work on behalf of blacks as a Freedom Rider in the segregated South.
"With his no-holds-barred style, he reminds many African-Americans of Coleman Young," said Mario Morrow, a political consultant, referring to the first black mayor of Detroit. "And Fieger's got this tree-trunk of anger on his shoulder, which resonates among people who feel disenfranchised by the system."
The candidate favored by the auto workers union, Larry Owen, a wealthy lawyer and former mayor of East Lansing, has been desperately trying to court black voters. Earlier this week, he broke with Michigan tradition and named his running mate for Lieutenant Governor, Teola Hunter, a black woman who is clerk of Wayne County.
Mr. Owen has been compared with the former Presidential candidate Walter F. Mondale, a Democrat who has positions that labor and liberals find impeccable, but who has little charisma. Political analysts say it is unclear how the selection of a black running mate will play: it could win the support of black voters, but it could also backfire as a transparent political move.
While Mr. Fieger is in the lead among blacks in Detroit, Mr. Owen has had more success in the industrial I-75 corridor, which extends north to Saginaw.
Mr. Ross, meanwhile, a former Labor Department official in the Clinton Administration, is known as a pin-striped, businesslike politician with a voice of moderation. He does best with voters in the middle-class suburbs of Detroit, and in the western reaches of the state.
But whomever the Democrats pick on Tuesday, the campaign to unseat Governor Engler will surely be uphill sledding. Mr. Engler, who fits the socially moderate, pro-business profile that voters in many states have been choosing as governors in recent years, rides a robust economy in Michigan.
A decade ago, this state had the highest unemployment rate in the nation. Now the jobless rate in Michigan ranks among the lowest of the big states, at least before the recently settled auto workers strike.
Democrats will try to make political hay of Mr. Engler's reneging on his campaign promise to serve only two terms by running for a third, but a prosperous economy tends to make voters very forgiving.
While polls show that Mr. Engler would have a sizable lead against any of the Democratic candidates, he does best against the Democratic front-runner, Mr. Fieger.
"John Engler and the Republican Party are licking their chops waiting for Geoffrey Fieger," said Mr. Morrow, noting that Mr. Fieger's brash, take-no-prisoners style would seem unlikely to attract the conservative and moderate voters needed to win a general election.
While Mr. Fieger's prominence initially stemmed from his ties to Dr. Kevorkian, the Democratic candidate has kept his distance from the physician during the campaign.
Instead, Mr. Fieger has focused on the plight of poor Detroiters, saying he would revitalize the city's neighborhoods by imposing tariffs on developers who build on open land in the suburbs.
A big man with longish hair and a whiter-than-white smile, Mr. Fieger dropped in at a recent picnic for the elderly on the shores of the Detroit River, looking more Hollywood than politician, wearing a white T-shirt and a blue blazer. He kissed and hugged virtually every woman at the picnic, and talked hip with teen-agers.
But in an interview moments later, Mr. Fieger angrily denounced Governor Engler in personal terms, questioned the mental health of a Detroit editorial writer and fairly shouted profanities about a local political consultant.
"He is a loose cannon," Mr. Morrow said. "The Republicans would like to portray him as a lunatic, except that he's rich. When you're rich, you know, you're just eccentric."

LENGTH: 1174 words

HEADLINE: Bulgaria Becomes a Weapons Bazaar

SERIES: A WORLD OF ARMS: Suppliers of Choice

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria

 BODY:
Once the renowned supplier of weapons for the Soviet Union, this Balkan country has become the arms bazaar for rebels and terrorist organizations of every political, ethnic and religious persuasion, Western officials and experts in the small arms trade say.
Secret weapons shipments have gone to rebel groups forming in Congo, threatening another outbreak of war there; to rebels in Angola, who are preparing to take up their war anew there, and to Eritrea, adding to Washington's fears about the escalation of fighting in the Horn of Africa. And that is just in the last few months. Other arms shoppers have included the Tamil Tigers of Sri Lanka, a group Washington says is a terrorist organization, and the Hutu militia, who were responsible for mass killings in Rwanda. 
 If the Bulgarian arms traffic were shut down or cleaned up, the supply of weapons fueling regional wars would be significantly reduced, intelligence and industry experts say.
But Washington and the European Union, while voicing concern, have done little to stop the trade, diplomats from several nations said.
Indeed, both Europe and the United States have put more diplomatic muscle into getting the Bulgarian Government to shut down the production of pirate compact disks thanks to pressure from business groups, diplomats said. By contrast, they noted, there is no business lobby calling for a crackdown on Bulgaria's arms makers.
"We don't regard it as a subject on which to make a fuss," a Western Ambassador said, slightly chagrined.
The big attraction in Bulgaria is the Kalashnikov assault rifle. Light, durable and easy to maintain, it is ideal for young soldiers slogging through jungles or trekking up mountains. And Bulgaria makes the best. Having lost their traditional cold war markets, Bulgaria's arms manufacturers are desperate for customers, whom they have accommodated with false shipping documents to disguise both the buyer and the destination of the weapons.
Bulgaria's major arms suppliers declined to be interviewed. Government officials denied that the country has become a major center for illicit arms trafficking, as American and European officials maintain.
"The official Government policy is directed at restraining such activities," said Vladimir Tourtansky, a senior official in Bulgaria's Cabinet-level Council on Defense Industry and Logistics.
Advocates for greater controls on small-arms trade point out that so-called small arms and light weapons -- assault rifles, grenades, mortars -- have caused more death and destruction in the last 50 years than nuclear, biological and chemical weapons, which are the objects of international alarm and controls.
Bulgaria is not the only place where rebels and rogues shop. Arms manufacturers in Ukraine, Slovakia, Romania and Belarus are also major suppliers of weapons.
But at the moment, Bulgarian arms are the weapons of choice.
At the center of the trade are Kintex, the state marketing agency, and Arsenal, the country's largest arms manufacturer, which is also state-owned.
Founded by Bulgaria's secret police in the 1960's, Kintex has a history of dubious arms trading. During the Iran-Iraq war, the company sold to both sides.
Kintex "offers so many models of Kalashnikov assault rifles" that Jane's Infantry Weapons, the industry's authoritative guide, feels compelled to provide a summary. Altogether, Jane's lists 16 Bulgarian models, from the AKT-47, a training version of the original AK-47, to the AK-74, the latest version of the assault rifle, which was designed 50 years ago by Mikhail T. Kalashnikov for the Soviet Army.
All are made by Arsenal. Bulgarian officials boast that Mr. Kalashnikov has said Arsenal makes the highest quality Kalashnikov today. The company also manufactures the 9-millimeter Makarov pistol, which is often in the crates of weapons clandestinely shipped from here.
Kintex and Arsenal denied several requests for interviews.
Arsenal and Kintex, along with other Bulgarian weapons companies, are still largely in the hands of the men who ran them during the Communist days. In doing business today, they make use of the expertise and contacts they developed when Bulgaria handled Moscow's clients, including Libya, Iraq and Iran, and many African governments or guerrilla groups.
With the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, Bulgaria lost those secondary markets, as well as the Warsaw Pact. Struggling to survive economically has caused the companies to engage in shady practices, diplomats said.
"Their attitude toward the small arms trade is: We know we shouldn't but we can't afford not to," a European diplomat said.
An Asian diplomat put it this way: "If you can't sell to the Soviet Union, if you can't sell to the Warsaw Pact, if you can't sell to Iran, Iraq, Libya, what do you do?"
"They need capital," he went on. "So I suppose they don't look too closely at end-user certificates." That refers to the document that is supposed to identify the ultimate destination of the weapons.
A few months ago, acting for a British mercenary army, Arsenal shipped 35 tons of weapons for rebels in Sierre Leone, using documents that said they were going to Nigeria. In a deal for of 77 tons of Kalashnikovs and other weapons, air-dropped to a violent religious sect in India two years ago, Arsenal used phony documents saying they were going to the Bangladesh Defense Ministry.
Western and Asian diplomats said that the current Bulgarian Government, which came to power last year, was trying more than previous post-Communist Governments to curb shady arms practices, but that it was constrained by the country's economic needs and the influence of the military industry.
Mr. Tourtansky said he was not aware of any arms company that has been punished for using false documents. He added, however, that Bulgaria's arms sales policies "are in line with all international standards and norms." He stressed that Bulgaria was complying with the so-called Wassenaar Arrangement.
Pushed by the Clinton Administration, the Wassenaar accord -- named after the Dutch city where it was signed three years ago -- is aimed at controlling exports of conventional weapons and so-called dual-use goods, like computers and telecommunications equipment, to countries like Iran, Iraq, Libya and North Korea.
But Wassenaar, which has 33 member-nations, does not deal with illicit trade and does not require reporting on sales of Kalashnikovs and other small arms, American officials said.
The most comprehensive report on arms sales is published annually by the United Nations. But it covers only heavy weapons, like tanks, warships and combat aircraft. Assault rifles, mortars, rocket launchers and other light weapons are not included.
International policies like these allow Mr. Tourtansky to say with accuracy, "We are not required to report to anyone about our international sales."
The series is examining the spread of arms around the world. Previous articles explored how various rebel groups obtained their weapons.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Connecticut Politics -- It Isn't Brain Surgery

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Connecticut used to be known as "The Land of Steady Habits," but that was before an ad agency came up with "Connecticut, We're Full of Surprises." The earlier nickname was better. While it is true that the state did go through a disquieting period when large structures were collapsing left and right -- a hotel here, a bridge there -- it really does not like all that much excitement. I covered the capitol for a long time, and the only surprise I can remember was the day the State Senate, caught in a violent battle between fans of the deer and fans of the whale, dyspeptically voted to name the human being official state animal.
Connecticut's incumbent Governor, John Rowland, a Republican, may be familiar to out-of-state residents for his starring role in tourism promotion commercials. (Americans who plan their vacations on the basis of the local elected officials' affinity for water sports will remember that Mr. Rowland is the one in the canoe with his wife, while New York's George Pataki was the guy teaching a little boy to fish.) Mr. Rowland's opponent this fall will be Representative Barbara Kennelly of Hartford. As surprises go, it was at least a bit of one that she would give up her very safe seat to make the run. 
 "You've virtually got to have a lobotomy, and you could still get re-elected if the economy's good if you're the governor," said Bill Clinton at a Kennelly fund-raiser.
It was hardly a remark designed to bring the party faithful to their feet cheering. "He was just having too good a time," said someone who sat with the President at the $5,000-a-plate luncheon catered by Martha Stewart. Mr. Clinton caught himself in time to assure the crowd that he was not trying to suggest that John Rowland had had a lobotomy. But he obviously did mean that Barbara Kennelly would have a tough time winning even if surgeons disconnected the frontal lobe of the Governor's cerebrum between now and November. The President couched this as a tribute to Mrs. Kennelly's political courage, but it was pretty dispiriting all the same.
Mr. Rowland has been talking a lot about cities and schools and doling out tax cuts, but it is not as if there is nothing to carp about. Like New York, Connecticut's economic upturn is lagging behind the nation's, and the state labors under a disproportionate amount of debt.
"We have no economic development strategy. Where we've given publicly subsidized economic development aid, 86 percent of the jobs never materialized," said Bill Curry, who ran against Mr. Rowland in 1994. Mr. Curry, who obsessed with policy, wanted to try again this year, but party elders seemed to feel voters would prefer Mrs. Kennelly's warm persona to an analysis of Mr. Rowland's privatization initiatives.
But the Congresswoman, having made the jump, seemed to sink like a stone. She turned out to be a terrible speechmaker, as well as a teller of truths who grimly assured reporters that yes, the polls did matter. Deconstructing Mr. Rowland's administration began to look like a better idea, and a former state legislator who is known as a policy whiz was grafted onto the ticket as the candidate for lieutenant governor.
Hillary Clinton, making a local visit, told Mrs. Kennelly's staff to keep her away from big speaking engagements and get her in close to the voters, where she is most impressive. At the Martha Stewart lunch, someone complimented the President on his wife's knowledge of Connecticut politics. "We've been talking about this race," said Mr. Clinton, launching into a dissection of local politics. You would have thought that he came from the Lower Naugatuck Valley. Then the greatest campaigner of our generation walked up to the dais and delivered the lobotomy speech.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
Castro Arrives on Grenada Calling for Stronger Ties
The Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, arrived on Grenada, nearly 15 years after American troops landed there and expelled a militarized Cuban brigade that was building an airport. Mr. Castro, who received cheers and a 21-gun salute, said he was eager to deepen relations with Grenada and unveiled a plaque thanking Cuba for helping build the airport. A1
 
Fall of a Chinese Mob Ring
After a series of brazen robberies, murders and kidnappings, a Chinese mob ring was disbanded last week by China's national police. The gang's downfall is the latest chapter in the curious evolution of lawlessness in southern China, where organized crime flourished in step with the economy in the 1990's. A1 

Palestinians Demand Progress
Senior Palestinian officials said that they were prepared to pull out of peace talks unless Israel quickly showed a willingness to consider new options. Talks scheduled for today may be the last meeting, an official said, if Israel continues to resist an American-backed plan calling for a withdrawal from an additional 13 percent of the West Bank. A5
 
Mexican States Vote
Miguel Aleman Velasco, son of a former President, appeared to be winning by a broad margin as the governing party's candidate in gubernatorial elections in Veracruz, one of three Mexican states with local elections. Exit polls indicated that the governing party seemed likely to lose in Aguascalientes, a small state north of Mexico City, while in the southern Oaxaca state it seemed to have tallied a narrow victory. A6
 
Russian Miners Get Results
Officials on the island of Sakhalin in Russia's far east announced that as a result of a coal miners' protest, they might have to cut off electricity for 24 hours to all but essential users. Coal miners have held sit-ins, marched and blocked rail lines for months complaining that the Government, a shareholder in many mines, owes them back wages. A3
 
110 Killed in Rwanda Attacks
Hutu rebels armed with machetes and clubs killed at least 110 people in attacks northwest of the Rwandan capital, Kigali, an army commander said. The attacks occurred on Friday, but were not reported until Sunday, the official said. Last month the rebels, some of them former soldiers of the previous Government, killed 34 people on a main road between the capital and the northwest. (AP)
 
Italy Jails Suspected Mobster
The Italian police said they captured a suspected mobster wanted for about 40 killings resulting from a feud between Naples-area crime clans. The suspect, Maurizio Procida, 34, who had been a fugitive for seven years, was arrested on Saturday outside Avellino, a town near Naples, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. (AP)

Clinton Urged to Give Accounting of Relationship
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, said that President Clinton should "pour his heart out" to the American people about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, and that by doing so he could take the steam out of any possible drive to impeach him. Democrats too were beginning to suggest that some sort of public accounting from the President would be useful. A1
 
Pressure Over Crime Statistics
Police officials around the nation are concerned that the sharp drop in crime in recent years has brought new pressure on police departments to show ever-decreasing crime statistics and might be behind incidents in which commanders have manipulated crime data. So far this year, there have been charges of falsely reporting crime statistics in Philadelphia, New York, Atlanta and Boca Raton, Fla., resulting in the resignation or demotion of high-ranking police commanders. A1
 
Search for Fugitives Is Futile
Two months after two men who are wanted in the deaths of two police officers disappeared into the vast no man's land known as the Four Corners, the authorities do not know whether the men are dead, in hiding or enjoying life in Mexico. Even using devices like infrared cameras, night-vision scopes and motion detectors in the red-rock canyons and mesas, searchers have come up empty-handed. "If you know the territory, you can survive," said Duane A. Smith, a western history professor. A10

Geoffrey Fieger, a lawyer who had been best known for defending Jack Kevorkian, has taken a brash, insulting style of campaigning into the race for the Democratic nomination for governor in Michigan -- and he is leading, much to the horror of the Democratic Party and leaders of the United Auto Workers. The primary, which pits Mr. Fieger against two more conventional candidates, is Tuesday. A10
 
A.M.A. Settles With Sunbeam
The American Medical Association has agreed to pay the Sunbeam Corporation $9.9 million for backing out of a deal to endorse some of the company's products. The association had been criticized for not having a plan to test the products, which included humidifiers and blood-pressure monitors. A17
 
No Terrorist Links in Theft
The F.B.I. says it has found no links to domestic or international terrorist groups in the theft of 25 tons of ammonium nitrate, a component of the bomb in the Oklahoma City blast. The F.B.I. closed its command post in Bruceton Mills, W. Va., this weekend after conducting scores of interviews and checking with agricultural and mining customers of Bruceton Farm Supplies, the store where the chemical was taken from a storage bin. The theft was reported Wednesday. (AP)

Two Worlds Collide At Exhibit on Motorcycles
To the consternation of more traditionalist elements in the art world, ponytailed bikers in leather vests have become regulars at the Guggenheim Museum, brought from as far away as Florida and New Hampshire for an exhibit called "The Art of the Motorcycle." The exhibition is quite different from anything else that the Museum Mile has experienced, and it has become the most highly attended exhibition in the Guggenheim's 61-year history. A1
 
A Change in Prison Use
In a significant change in how New York State uses its clogged prisons, the Pataki administration has quietly been pursuing a strategy of releasing nonviolent felons, mostly into drug treatment, while increasingly denying parole for violent felons. The administration estimates that the influx of violent felons into the state prison system is likely to accelerate with the State Legislature's passage last month of the Governor's proposal to end parole for first-time violent felons. A lawyer for six Manhattan strip clubs and adult video stores says he can prove they have complied with the city's new restrictions on sex shops and should not be shut down. HEADLINE: As Doctors Trade Shingle For Marquee, Cries of Woe

SERIES: AFTER THE REVOLUTION: The Doctors

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: PLACERVILLE, Calif.

 BODY:
It has been 22 years since a young pediatrician named Earl R. Washburn 3d hung his shingle in this rustic old gold-mining town in the foothills of the Sierras. There were no pediatricians in Placerville back then; with fewer than 7,000 people, there was not even a McDonald's.
But the town, with its towering pines and firs, charming turn-of-the-century cottages and proximity to the state capital, Sacramento, seemed a fine place to set up practice and raise a family. And Dr. Washburn, fresh out of residency with a wife and 15-month-old son, had very definite ideas on how to do both. 
 Antibiotics would not be casually prescribed, especially not to infants. Immunizations were essential; parents who opposed vaccination could find another doctor. Prospective partners -- there are now four partners and one associate in the El Dorado Pediatrics Medical Group -- were told they would not get rich, but neither would they miss their children's soccer games.
The goal, says Dr. Jeffrey Rabinovitz, who joined Dr. Washburn in 1977, was this: "You take care of your patients, and your family."
Achieving that goal meant staying independent. But over the last five years, as managed care has transformed American medicine, the independence of doctors has often been the first thing to go.
Last year, 92 percent of the nation's physicians had some type of managed-care contract, according to the American Medical Association. "Capitated" contracts, which pay a set fee for each patient, accounted for one-third of the average doctor's salary. Five years earlier, capitation was barely a blip on the medical association's radar screen, so negligible that the organization did not bother keeping tabs on it.
As the free market has achieved what President Clinton's ill-fated health-care overhaul proposal could not -- increased efficiency and lower costs -- doctors have learned to cope with burdensome paperwork, discounted fees and insurance company restrictions on the specialists they refer to and the drugs they prescribe.
But what troubles them most, it seems, are the intangibles that have been lost, the cherished traditions that Dr. Washburn and his colleagues still dream of fulfilling: building their own practice on their own terms; forging a bond with patients that lasts through the years, no matter which insurance company pays the bills.
"Compare the Marcus Welby type of doctor that existed up until 10 years ago," said Dr. Alan Hillman, director of the Center for Health Policy at the University of Pennsylvania, "where a doctor owns his or her own practice, sets his or her own rates, practices his or her own style of medicine. Now you have doctors subject to outside management, most doctors being employees of an organization or highly managed. The loss of autonomy and control is astounding. The doctors are battered."
Battered is precisely how Dr. Washburn and his colleagues in Placerville feel. Like doctors across the nation, they have been swept up in a roiling wave of medical mergers and acquisitions. Physicians who once had 2 partners now have 200. Others have sold their practices outright, trading patient charts for cash payments and employee status at hospitals, H.M.O.'s or "physician practice management" firms. In 1997, the medical association reports, 43 percent of the nation's physicians -- excluding those in training, Federal employees and those who did not see patients -- worked for someone else, up from 24 percent in 1983.
While the buying and selling frenzy appears to finally be abating, perhaps nowhere has it been as furious as in the region surrounding Sacramento. Known as the managed-care capital of America because 90 percent of all insured people are enrolled in health maintenance organizations, California's capital city is "the chaotic extreme of a generally turbulent marketplace," said Dr. James C. Robinson, a professor of health economics at the University of California at Berkeley.
That turbulence nearly put El Dorado Pediatrics out of business. In the last two years, Dr. Washburn and his partners have watched as big medical groups have gobbled up smaller practices like their own, and then dismissed some doctors while keeping their patients. Resisting offers to sell, they nonetheless affiliated their practice with one such company, only to watch it drown in red ink. When that firm was sold, Dr. Washburn said, the new owner, FPA Medical Management Inc., stopped payment for patient visits. After five months, the pediatricians were owed $86,000.
"We were desperate," he said, "down to our last 58 cents." The dispute was eventually settled, but now Dr. Washburn's group has a new worry: FPA, which administers the Placerville pediatricians' largest health care contract, accounting for a third of their patients, filed for bankruptcy on July 19.
"It's like some science fiction story, a parallel universe," Dr. Washburn said, "where they keep switching you from one universe to the next with a new set of rules. In about the time you figure out how to make the universe work, it changes again."
The tumult has taken its toll. With doctors losing jobs and patients, there is intense competition for work. Collegiality is all but gone, said Bill Sandberg, executive director of the Sacramento-El Dorado Medical Society. "It's been a bloody war," he said. "All we have had is unpredictability, chaos and crisis."
Amid the chaos, medicine's elite have learned an ego-bruising lesson: They could not count on their patients. Given a choice between loyalty to a longtime doctor and cheaper medical care, the patient will choose to pay less. Dr. Washburn, the pediatrician, has seen this from both sides; he is recovering from colorectal cancer, and recently switched primary care physicians because his doctor left his health plan.
Managed care, he said, worked wonderfully for him; he never even saw a bill, and estimated that he paid no more than $100 for $250,000 worth of medical care. "But," he added, "everybody who took care of me lost money on me."
 
The Practice
Four Doctors Cling To Independence
The hilly two-lane road that leads to the El Dorado Pediatrics Medical Group stretches south from California's Route 50, past a string of auto body shops, the local fruit growers association and a church. Dr. Washburn and his colleagues work out of a low-slung stucco building the color of caramel, tucked unobtrusively behind a split-rail fence.
Inside, the office is old-fashioned, with hand-painted murals in each examining room that feature barnyard scenes and grassy fields of blue lupine, astronauts and even an Egyptian tableau. Dr. Washburn is a tall, slender 51-year-old with big square glasses, a soft-spoken man who reads philosophy in his spare time.
The story of the Placerville pediatricians' foray into the high-stakes world of mergers and managed care is a tale of miscalculations and dashed hopes. It began in 1993, when Foundation Health Corporation, then the second-largest health maintenance organization in Sacramento, decided to create a separate practice management company so that it could funnel its own patients to its own doctors.
The new company quickly bought the practices of 100 Northern California doctors, most of them primary care physicians, said Kurt Davis, a former Foundation Health vice president. At the same time, it invested millions in building a dozen state-of-the-art clinics, including one in Placerville measuring 25,000 square feet and with enough space for 12 doctors. "We dove in full blast," Mr. Davis said. Dr. Washburn, meanwhile, gave the new clinic a nickname: "the Taj Mahal."
El Dorado Pediatrics was courted heavily by the new group. At a time when the price of a doctor's practice was plummeting, Dr. Washburn said, he and his colleagues were offered "a generous buyout," along with salaries of nearly twice what they were earning and a three-year guarantee that they would not be dismissed.
To Dr. Washburn, it sounded promising. He is not, by his own account, a wealthy man. He bought a new Subaru this spring, a step up from his old 1990 Ford Taurus, and said he has never made more than $100,000 a year; the American doctor on average now makes $200,000 a year, according to the American Medical Association. At the same time, Dr. Washburn was cautious.
"I'd be delighted to make more money," he said. "There's always things to spend it on. But in this practice we are very careful about balancing our social and personal needs with the needs of making money."
That means that when a doctor needs time off, as Dr. Washburn did during his cancer treatment, the others pitch in without complaint. And it means they practice as they see fit. When a mother who lacked insurance brought her son in for a sprained thumb on a recent day, Dr. Rabinovitz waived the fee. When that same day Dr. Washburn evaluated a high school boy for attention deficit disorder, he patiently questioned the boy for 60 minutes. "If we need an hour," said Dr. Ulrich Hacker, another partner, "we take an hour."
A for-profit company, the group worried, would undoubtedly interfere with that freedom. But when it came to a vote, they split down the middle. Drs. Washburn and Hacker wanted to stay. Dr. Rabinovitz and Dr. Linda Eldred, the fourth partner, wanted to go. In the end, they decided to decline rather than split up.
What they wound up with seemed even better: a lucrative five-year contract in which they became Foundation Health's first and only "associate medical practice." The agreement called for El Dorado Pediatrics to see as many patients as Foundation could provide, a risky proposition, since doctors do not like to depend too heavily on one health plan. In return, Foundation would pay the doctors 100 percent of what they billed.
In this era of heavily discounted medicine, such an arrangement was unheard of. But Placerville had just one other pediatrician, and he was fresh out of training. Foundation needed El Dorado Pediatrics. "We were in hog heaven," Dr. Washburn said.
 
The Corporation
A Deal Too Good To Be True, Was
The euphoria did not last. Before long, the Foundation medical group was "losing just tons of money," said Mr. Davis, the former company spokesman. The fancy clinics were expensive to run, the doctors were not seeing enough patients to cover the overhead, and health insurance premiums were in a nose dive. "We didn't read the tea leaves right," Mr. Davis admitted.
By early 1996, 26 Foundation doctors had been laid off, losing their patients as well as their jobs. While Dr. Washburn and his colleagues were counting their blessings that they had not sold to Foundation -- "one or two of us would have surely been fired," Dr. Rabinovitz said, in retrospect -- they were owed money by the sinking firm. Meanwhile, some of the laid-off doctors went to Mr. Sandberg, the medical society executive, for help finding work.
"Some were totally devastated," Mr. Sandberg said. "Some of them were crying."
But Dr. Robinson, the health care economist at Berkeley, has little sympathy for the out-of-work doctors. "Don't think of these doctors as poor oppressed proletarians," he said. "These doctors that sell get rich selling."
The white knight that rescued -- or appeared to rescue -- Foundation was FPA Medical Management Inc., a company based in San Diego that until recently was one of the nation's biggest physician practice management firms. FPA had been snapping up medical practices across the nation. With 7,900 doctors in 29 states at its peak, it acted as a middleman between doctors and health plans, negotiating contracts and administering claims. A publicly held company, it was making a big splash on Wall Street.
In October 1996, FPA paid $220 million for the Foundation doctors' group, and leased the half-empty medical centers. But when Dr. Washburn attended a meeting where a Foundation executive described the sale, he felt a little queasy. "He kept saying, 'We have to take care of our shareholders,' " the pediatrician said. "What about the patients?"
The takeover was rocky. Doctors did not like doing business with FPA; in Tucson, Ariz., a group of FPA-owned doctors formed a union last year to fight the company's cost-cutting measures, like increasing patient loads and dismissing specialists. In Sacramento, some quit amid complaints that they were not paid on time.
But the Placerville pediatricians could not leave. They were not employees. When FPA took over the contract, Dr. Washburn said, he spent five months trying to collect on the $86,000 that was owed. In an interview in May, Dr. Stephen J. Dresnick, FPA's president and chief executive, attributed the dispute, which was eventually resolved, to "a mismatch of expectations." In any event, the FPA executive said, the amount was negligible.
"Eighty-six thousand doesn't sound like a lot of money, does it?" Dr. Dresnick said, noting the practice has five doctors. "You're looking at $16,000 per person. That doesn't strike me as an extraordinarily high number of outstanding claims."
The pediatricians take a different view. They gave up six weeks' salary to make up for the deficit. "To him it's chump change," Dr. Washburn said. "To us, it's the world. This was our No. 1 contract. It was one-third of our income, and we were dying."
 
The Fall
Doctors Left Holding Their Black Bags
Each Wednesday afternoon, the five doctors of El Dorado Pediatrics Medical Group gather around some folding tables for a two-hour brown-bag lunch and business meeting. The talk runs the gamut, from medical journal articles to bookkeeping matters. In recent months, it has centered largely on FPA.
At one point, before it became clear that the company was headed for bankruptcy, Dr. Rabinovitz threw out an idea. Perhaps, he suggested, the group should send a letter to its patients, informing them that its contract with FPA was due to expire in 1999, and that the doctors did not plan to renew it. "What I'm saying," he told his partners that spring day, "is we cut our losses. We put ourselves in a position where we could afford to lose this contract."
Everyone around the table knew that such a letter could cut both ways. Patients might try to switch health insurance plans to stick with the doctors. Then again, as Dr. Rabinovitz himself acknowledged, they might not. "I'm a firm believer that we always overestimate patient loyalty," he said.
Today, that dilemma is moot. On July 15, the California Department of Corporations issued a cease and desist order to FPA, ordering the company to pay its doctors; the bankruptcy petition was filed four days later.
While state officials scurried to make certain that patient care was uninterrupted, Dr. Jack Lewin, the director of the California Medical Association, began tallying the losses. He estimated that FPA owed $60 million to California doctors. Some of those physicians, Dr. Lewin said, traded their practices for FPA stock, which hit a high of $40 a share last October but was trading at 25 cents by July 30. "Those doctors lost their shirts," he said.
Analysts say FPA tried to grow too big too fast. Dr. Dresnick, the FPA executive, vows that the company will emerge, healthy and revitalized, from its reorganization by the end of the year. But it is pulling out of Sacramento, he said in a recent interview. While the FPA-employed doctors there are busy affiliating themselves with new groups, the company is laying plans to dispose of the expensive clinics, including the half-vacant one in Placerville.
"It was losing money every month," Dr. Dresnick said, "and so the decision was, do we put more money into it, or just admit that this was one we couldn't make work?"
 
The Future
White Knights Of the Apocalypse
For the pediatricians, that decision is somewhat of a relief. FPA still owes them $24,000, and they are continuing to see patients without being paid for their work. "We assume, if they filed for bankruptcy, that they are out of our lives," Dr. Rabinovitz said. "But the question is, who is going to pay us? We will probably have to stand in line at the bankruptcy hearings."
In the meantime, the doctors will continue to work longer hours, a practice they began when Dr. Washburn became ill, in an effort to bring in more income. They are trying to persuade patients to switch their insurance to plans not administered by FPA health plans. And they are looking to sign more managed-care contracts, in an effort to diversify.
Although they have entertained other offers to sell during the past two years, it no longer seems like a viable option. Companies like FPA have come to realize that buying a medical practice may not be such a good investment; health economists say doctors tend to work harder when they are self-employed. In any event, the pediatricians say, they no longer believe they have to join a larger group to survive.
"At this point," Dr. Washburn said, "we are not looking to anybody to come in and be the white knight to protect us or save us. We are simply going to have to do whatever we do on our own."
Dr. Robinson, the Berkeley health care economist, said he believed that out of all this churning would come something good. Perhaps not universal health care for all Americans, as President Clinton once envisioned, but at least a system that is cost-efficient.
"We are re-engineering the health care system," he said, "and we are doing it the American way, which means incredible competition. We're going to have a consumer-oriented system, not a doctor-oriented system." The change, he added, will continue to be painful for doctors. "We are seeing supply and demand equilibrate here at a new lower price, and it is nasty."
In Placerville, Dr. Washburn sees something else in the future of American health care: complete collapse. He believes President Clinton squandered an opportunity to make lasting change, that the time is past when things can be "fixed in an orderly fashion," and that any system in which a crucial component is so demoralized -- namely, doctors -- cannot possibly survive.
Lately, Dr. Washburn has been writing philosophical articles for medical trade magazines. He has just picked the title for his next one: "The Coming Medical Apocalypse."
 
After the Revolution
This series will look at the effects of changes in the nation's health care system. Future articles will examine efforts to help the uninsured, and the problems of managed care.

HEADLINE: Thirsty New Jersey Resort Sees New Use for Salty Water

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: CAPE MAY, N.J.

 BODY:
For decades, vacationers have flocked to this resort's broad beach on the Atlantic, its big hotels and its quaint pastel Victorian guest homes, bringing a welcome infusion of cash.
But the visitors have had a devastating effect on Cape May's underground water supply, depleting it to the point that, since 1950, two community wells have been abandoned after they became contaminated by salty ocean water that seeped in to replace the fresh water, and the use of two others has been curtailed. 
 With the salt front threatening its fifth and last well, Cape May is installing the first desalination plant in the Northeast, becoming the northernmost of dozens of resorts and cities on the East Coast that have turned to desalting to offset strains on their water supplies. All are purifying brackish ground water that was once useless.
The move toward desalination began in the late 1970's in highly developed resorts on Florida's gulf coast like Sarasota, Fort Myers and Cape Coral, said James Birkette, a consultant on desalination from Maine. Boca Raton and Hollywood on Florida's Atlantic coast also rely on the plants. Recently, desalination moved northward to Mount Pleasant, S.C.; Cape Hatteras and Nags Head on North Carolina's Outer Banks; Newport News and Chesapeake in coastal Virginia, and now, to New Jersey's southern tip.
"It's a natural result of population growth and overstress on aquifers," Dr. Birkette said of coastal cities' growing reliance on desalting plants.
The common denominators for the resorts, he said, are the steady arrival of new residents and tourists and the overpumping of aquifers, porous underground layers containing water. By allowing the resorts to use once-undrinkable salty water, the plants ease the strain on aquifers and help slow the incursion of salt water. When fresh water is removed in large quantities, rainwater and streams cannot replenish the aquifers quickly enough, and salt water then seeps in.
In Cape May, summer tourism swells the population to nearly 40,000 from about 4,500 and pushes daily water demand on busy weekends to about 2.7 million gallons from about 900,000 gallons, said Thomas Phelan, a former Mayor and now head of Cape May's desalination committee.
Over the last 50 years, salt water has been spreading through Cape May's well field at an increasing speed. In the 1950's, the salt front crept northward at a rate of about 92 feet a year. By the late 1980's, the incursion had sped up to about 271 feet a year, according to a study conducted by the United States Geological Survey in 1992.
Federal geologists estimated at the time that the salt front would reach Cape May's only unaffected well, No. 5, by 2000.
"We had to take 1998 as the year it was going to hit, to be on the safe side," Mr. Phelan said.
The salt front encroaching on Cape May is not New Jersey's first. Two others in the last 20 years have ruined hundreds of wells in communities along Raritan Bay and on the Delaware River south of Camden. About $500 million was spent for a new reservoir, new water treatment plants and distribution pipes on the Raritan and Delaware Rivers, said water managers in the state's Department of Environmental Protection.
Saltwater intrusion is also a problem, though a much less severe one, on Long Island, which gets all of its drinking water from aquifers. In Nassau County, water officials said, salty water has doomed two wells in Great Neck, which like Cape May is on a peninsula, and forced that community to drill new wells farther inland.
Cape May's $5 million desalination plant allowed it to drive its first well into the deepest of five aquifers, which are stacked in layers beneath the Cape May Peninsula, and to begin treating the previously unused brackish water. That aquifer, called the Atlantic City Sand, is 800 feet below the surface and 600 feet below the Cohansey aquifer, which Cape May has used for its five wells. Cape May will cut back on its use of the overpumped Cohansey, which has been increasingly fouled by salt.
State environmental officials had been prodding Cape May to rely less on the Cohansey in hopes of slowing the northerly march of the salt front toward the well fields of two neighboring communities, Lower Township and Wildwood, which also draw from the Cohansey.
The new plant is to begin test runs early this month, and officials hope to have it operating by Labor Day. It is designed to treat 1 million gallons a day and can be expanded to treat 2 million gallons.
The sodium chloride, or salt, level in the Atlantic City Sand's water is about 2,000 parts per million, far higher than both the Federal drinking water standard of 250 parts per million and the level in the Cohansey, which is up to 400 parts per million in the two wells that have been closed and in the other two fouled by salt. In the fifth well, the salt level is well below the Federal standard.
The plant is intended to eliminate all the salt, said David Blair, project manager for Metcalf & Eddy, the engineering company that designed Cape May's plant.
Like the other plants on the East Coast, Cape May's relies on a filtration process called reverse osmosis. Under this process, the brackish water in the aquifer, which is considerably less salty than water in the ocean, is pumped at high pressure into an array of 40-foot-long tubes filled with rolls of semipermeable membranes. As the brackish water is forced through the rolls, the chlorides are separated out, and that stream of brine is eventually discharged to a creek flowing to the Atlantic.
After flowing through the membranes, the purified water reaches a hollow core at the center of the rolls and enters the water distribution network.
Officials say reverse-osmosis plants are far cheaper to operate than desalination plants that treat sea water, which has chloride counts of 35,000 parts per million. These plants, common in the Middle East, use a technology called flash distillation, which removes contaminants by boiling sea water and condensing the steam. High energy costs have made such plants rare in the United States.
Here in Cape May, Federal and state loans and grants paid the plant's $5 million in construction costs. The plant will add $1.25 per 1,000 gallons to the resort's summertime water-sewage charge of $14.53 per 1,000 gallons. Mr. Phelan of the desalination committee said he expected his family's water bill to increase about $85 a year.
But the big hotels on the ocean use from 1 million to 8.5 million gallons of water a year, city officials said. The new plant will add anywhere from $1,250 to $10,625 to their annual water bills, they said.
Residents and innkeepers seem more resigned to the rate increase than angry about it. After all, they have wrestled for years with the need for water conservation and threats the salt front poses for tourism, the backbone of Cape May's economy.
Dane Wells, owner of the Queen Victoria, one of Cape May's 60 bed and breakfasts, said that through conserving water and raising room rates he would cover the higher water charge. But he said residents of towns north of Cape May should pay a surcharge to underwrite Cape May's higher costs because the resort city is cutting back on its use of the Cohansey aquifer to help keep the salt front away from well fields in those towns.
"Because we're on the front edge, we're paying for rampant development north of us," Mr. Wells said. "The state should charge others and the money should go to a fund to help Cape May."
Mr. Wells has reduced his inn's water use by installing pressurized toilets that use less water per flush. And like many other residents, he has sunk a private well on his property for water to wash his car and sprinkle his lawn and flowers.
Four years ago, Mr. Wells began giving two- or three-night guests the option of using the same bed linens during their stay. That policy has cut water used for laundry by 20 percent, he said.
But some year-round residents said conserving water has not saved them much money. Pat Dillon, a secretary at the Chamber of Commerce, switched to low-flush toilets. She said the toilets cut her water use in half, but that did not save her money because Cape May raised water rates to offset the loss of revenue brought on by conservation.
State officials say Cape May's shift to the Atlantic City Sand aquifer will require careful monitoring because it is the main source of water for resorts on a 70-mile stretch of coastline from Stone Harbor to the northern end of Long Beach Island.
Much of the aquifer in that stretch has been heavily pumped and contains a precursor of a salt front invasion: a huge V-shaped void that hydrologists call a cone of depression. Over decades, if overpumping continues, salty ocean water might fill the cone of depression, as it has done here.
So far, monitoring wells have not detected any intrusion of salt in the Atlantic City Sand north of the Cape May Peninsula, said Robert Kecskes, a section chief in the state's Office of Environmental Planning. But, he added, state hydrologists and geologists are uncertain whether Cape May's pumping that aquifer will cause a salt front to pop up elsewhere on New Jersey's resort strip.
If that happens, the options include more desalting plants, he said. But he said a more likely response would be to have the next generation of sewage treatment plants discharge treated effluent into the ground instead of the ocean, so it can filter down to aquifers.
Any salt intrusion along the coast north of Cape May is years away, he said. "We all believe there's enough time to react to it safely and inexpensively," he said.

Remedy: Desalting by Osmosis
Unlike a distillation process used to desalt water, the process used in the new plant is called reverse osmosis. This is how it works:
 
1: Aquifer water enters a 40-foot cylinder from a high-pressure pump.

2: The salty water is forced through rolls of mem 2/3branes to a hollow core, separating the salts. The clean water flows to the municipal water supply.

HEADLINE: Compressed Data;
One Expert's Buzz Is Another's Target

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
There are two main paths to credibility in the world of professional technology experts. One is to champion new trends, making sweeping judgments and pronouncing ways in which the latest technology could make all nonbelievers obsolete. This is called preaching to the chat room.
The other is to debunk new trends, poking holes in the assumptions that others have made and throwing cold water on the preachers. This is called being a calculated contrarian. Both techniques seem to work when it comes to selling reports for thousands of dollars. But the two strategies will go head to head this week as two of the more prominent high-technology consulting firms publicize reports on the convergence of voice and data traffic in the nation's communications networks. 
 In its report on the market for telephone calls that use Internet technology, Abhi Chaki of Jupiter Communications calls the consolidation of voice, video and data information onto unified networks an "inescapable reality." The firm says that will fuel the adoption of Internet-style phone calls.
Over the last year or so, the views of people like Mr. Chaki have taken on the patina of conventional wisdom. But what is really inescapable after reading the report is the feeling that Jupiter, based in New York, is congenitally friendly to the Internet.
The calculated contrarian, Forrester Research, based in Cambridge, Mass., is as in tent on tearing down the concept of network consolidation as Jupiter is in promoting it. In its latest report, Forrester says that businesses will not bother with unified voice-data networks and that multiple networks will live on.
"What we try to do is demystify hype," Maribel Lopez, the Forrester analyst behind the report, said in an interview. "The buzz, a lot of it has to do with data guys looking to sell the next router upgrade."
But in the interest of demystification, it should be made clear that Forrester made an early copy of the report available to a reporter in an effort to create some buzz of its own. SETH SCHIESEL

HEADLINE: BellSouth Workers Authorize a Strike

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Unionized workers at the BellSouth Corporation voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike against the company, the Communications Workers of America said today, threatening the regional telephone company with its first walkout since the 1984 breakup of the AT&T Corporation.
The union's three-year contract with BellSouth, covering 48,000 employees, expires at midnight, Eastern daylight time, Saturday. 
 Jimmy Smith, vice president of the union, said that a key issue was "forced overtime and inflexible scheduling" caused, he said, by work force reductions several years ago. He said other issues were wages, pensions and benefits.
A BellSouth spokeswoman, Deborah Spice, said negotiations, which started June 22, were held over the weekend and continued today. She said any overtime was done within the framework of the existing contract with the union.
The union said 93 percent of voting members had authorized a strike at BellSouth, which serves nine Southeastern states.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury to Retire $45 Billion of Debt Through September

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
The Treasury announced yesterday that it would retire $45 billion in debt through September -- the first time it has been able to do that in the third quarter since 1973.
The announcement came two days before the Treasury announces the size of its auction next week of new 5-year, 10-year and 30-year securities. It also came on a day when Treasury prices rose, helped by a stronger dollar, weaker commodities prices and an announcement by the Federal Reserve on security purchases. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 25/32, to 106 22/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.65 percent, from 5.71 percent on Friday.
The news that the Treasury would pay down $45 billion in debt represents a sharp shift from May, when the Treasury said it expected to borrow as much as $5 billion in the quarter.
Still, Treasury market analysts said they did not expect immediate changes to the Treasury's borrowing schedule as a result, noting that the announcement merely reflected the strong tax revenues that have come from a rising stock market and higher personal incomes.
"It just confirms what we've known for some time, which is as the surpluses rise, the borrowing needs fall, said Ward McCarthy, a partner with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates.
Treasury prices gained early in the day, following the dollar higher after Asian stock markets slumped.
The market got another boost later in the morning when the Federal Reserve announced a permanent purchase of notes and bonds maturing in 10 to 30 years. Analysts expected the Fed to make such a purchase, but not until the start of the next maintenance period of Aug. 13. The Fed bought $1.049 billion in securities maturing Aug. 15, 2008, through April 15, 2028.
The Treasury held its regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills yesterday. Following are the results of the auction:

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Falls 96.55, but Nasdaq Index Takes a Bigger Hit

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday as investor concerns that Asia's economic crisis will continue to erode the profits of American companies depressed share prices.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 96.55 points, to 8,786.74, a 1.09 percent decline. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 8.23 points, to 1,112.44. 
 But once again, the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index took a greater hit, declining 21.29 points, to 1,851.10, a 1.14 percent drop. Microsoft, Worldcom, MCI Communications and Tele-Communications Inc. were the leading decliners in the index, which lost more than 3 percent of its value last week. That compared with last week's 0.6 percent drop in the Dow and 1.8 percent fall in the S.& P. 500.
Concerns about Asia pushed the dollar higher against the yen, to 145.60, closer to its June 16 high of 146.75 yen -- its highest level in eight years.
Bonds gained as the strong dollar made Treasury issues an attractive safe-haven investment for foreign buyers. Treasury securities were also buoyed by a larger-than-expected decline in the July National Association of Purchasing Management's index. The key indicator of domestic manufacturing activity fell to 49.1 in July from 49.6 in June, its second consecutive decline after 22 months of being above 50, the dividing line between a manufacturing sector that is expanding and one that is shrinking.
Despite fairly strong consumer demand and tame inflation in this country, analysts are concerned that Asia's woes will crimp earnings, especially for large multinational companies.
"Based on second-quarter earnings, it's clear there's a meaningful slowdown in profit growth," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
Mr. Johnson noted that even companies with limited operations in Asia, like Computer Associates International, were being affected by the malaise. This is because some of the company's customers -- with greater exposure to Asia -- may delay spending on the software developers' products.
"It's hard to find a safe haven or avoid being hurt by what's going on in Asia," Mr. Johnson said.
In response to his more bearish sentiment, yesterday, Mr. Johnson lowered his earnings forecasts for the S.& P. 500. He now expects operating earnings for the S.& P. 500 to be $46.73 a share this year, down from $48.57, and $49.48 in 1999, down from $52.21.
His forecasts are slightly below the consensus estimates of $47.20 and $49.70, respectively.
Despite the declines and a strong bearish market sentiment, Mr. Johnson and several other analysts believe the declines simply signal a market correction and are not the beginning of a severe market decline.
"We view this short-term setback as a reality check, however, rather than the start of a meaningful move to the downside," Elizabeth J. Mackay, investment strategist at Bear, Stearns & Company, wrote in a recent market report.
Declines should be limited to a 7 percent to 10 percent decline for the major market indexes from their recent highs, Ms. Mackay wrote. At yesterday's close, the Dow was down about 5.9 percent from its July 17 record close of 9,337.97.
But if the index falls below its recent low of 8,627.93 investors may begin to worry more about whether the declines will end soon.
Yesterday's losses left the Dow 158.81 points away from its recent low of 8,727.93 on June 15. A close below that would signal an almost 8 percent decline from the July 17 high.
Elsewhere in the market, the German software developer SAP began trading on the New York Stock exchange yesterday.
The company, with a market capitalization of about $73 billion, is the world's second-largest technology company behind Microsoft. It is also the largest new listing ever on the Big Board, a spokeswoman said.
Its size is one reason SAP chose to list on the New York Stock Exchange, as opposed to the Nasdaq, said Kevin McKay, chief operating officer and chief financial officer of SAP Americas. "We don't characterize ourselves as a high-tech start-up," he said
In addition, the company favored a recent change in the exchange's policies that allowed SAP to select the specialist, or dealer, who is assigned to maintain fair and orderly trading in the stock. Generally, specialists are assigned securities by the exchanges.
The company's American depository receipts fell 1 15/16, to 59 9/16. One A.D.R. represents one-twelfth of a preferred share of SAP stock.
