HEADLINE: Albertson's In $8.3 Billion Deal for Chain

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Albertson's Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the American Stores Company for $8.3 billion in stock, in a deal that would create the nation's largest supermarket chain.
The transaction -- the latest in a round of deals announced in the grocery industry recently as supermarket operators have sought to form regional strongholds -- would create a chain of nearly 2,500 stores in 37 states with more than 200,000 employees and pro forma 1998 revenues of about $36 billion. The purchase would also establish Albertson's, which had been the fifth- largest chain, as the industry leader, vaulting past Kroger, which has nearly 1,400 stores in 24 states. 
 Albertson's is strong in the Western, Midwestern and Southern states and will now have a larger presence in the Southwest and on the West Coast, where American Stores is a large competitor. The acquisition would also move Albertson's into drugstore retailing because American Stores has 750 free-standing drugstores that operate under the Osco Drug and Sav-on names.
In all, American Stores, which is based in Salt Lake City, operates 1,558 stores in 26 states, including 269 food and drug combination stores and 539 supermarkets that operate under the names Acme Markets, Jewel Food Stores and Lucky Stores.
Albertson's, which is based in Boise, Idaho, operates 916 retail stores in 23 states. Both chains' stores will retain their names, and the company headquarters will remain in Boise.
Albertson's chairman and chief executive, Gary G. Michael, will run the combined company, and American Stores' chairman and chief executive, Victor L. Lund, will be vice chairman of the combined company.
"From a strategic standpoint, this transaction will strengthen our presence in many of our existing markets across the country -- particularly in Northern and Southern California and the Southwest -- and enables us to enter important urban markets like Chicago and Philadelphia for the first time," Mr. Michael said.
In addition to paying the $8.3 billion in stock, Albertson's will assume $3.4 billion in debt. American Stores shareholders are to receive 0.63 share of Albertson's common stock for each share of American Stores stock. Based on Albertson's closing price on Friday of $48 a share, the deal is worth $30.24 a share for American shareholders, who would then own 41.3 percent of Albertson's. Also, Albertson's will issue about 170 million additional shares in the transaction.
Albertson's said it expected to save $100 million in costs the first year from buying and distribution efficiencies and $200 million in the third year from reducing overhead and advertising expenditures in overlapping markets. Part of the lower overhead cost will come from eliminating some administrative jobs, although the number has not been determined. Albertson's said it would take an undetermined one-time charge related to the transaction, which it expects to add to earnings per share next year.
American Stores' stock rose $5.3125 yesterday to $28.50. Albertson's shares, meanwhile, were nearly flat, edging up just 50 cents, to $48.50. Shareholders' lukewarm reception may indicate that they consider the price of the transaction a bit rich or that they have concerns about how easily the companies can be combined.
Even so, "because of our consistent business philosophies and similar corporate cultures, I am confident the integration of these two companies will go smoothly," Mr. Lund said.
Analysts said the combination could be more difficult than the companies anticipate because of the numerous geographical regions in which they operate and because of the number and type of stores they run. The deal, which has been approved by both companies' boards, could also run into antitrust problems in such areas as California, where Albertson's stands to dominate the market.
The Federal Trade Commission is likely to mandate some divestitures where there is overlap, said Debra J. Levin, an analyst who follows the supermarket industry for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "They will have to sell some stores, but I don't think that will prevent this from working," she said.
Ms. Levin added that she had raised her recommendation on Albertson's stock to strong buy from outperform based on the acquisition announcement. "There are really a number of areas in which companies can achieve economies of scale by joining forces, and that is in the context of an intensely competitive environment," she said.
Indeed, the industry's merger trend is being driven by the benefits of size, namely, greater purchasing power, a larger bang for the advertising buck and additional stores from which to compete with WalMart, the warehouse clubs and other nontraditional retailers that now sell milk and eggs.
For instance, in May, Royal Ahold N.V. said it was buying Giant Food Inc., a supermarket chain, for $2.6 billion, adding 177 stores to its 830 domestic stores. And last year, Fred Meyer Inc. purchased Quality Food Centers Inc. and Ralphs Grocery Company in separate deals worth about $2 billion.

HEADLINE: Good Times Keep Rolling

 BODY:
The Asian crisis may alarm Alan Greenspan and assorted other economists, but to the American people the economic outlook could not be rosier. That is what they tell the pollsters, who put consumer confidence at virtually the highest level in 30 years. More important, consumers act on that belief.
Some economists thought the second-quarter numbers would show a decline in the American economy. But instead, the estimates issued by the Government last Friday showed continued growth, albeit at a reduced level. That was because Americans -- both individuals and businesses -- are buying at a very high, and ultimately unsustainable, pace. Adjusted for inflation, purchases by Americans are up 5.6 percent over the past year. Such rapid growth would be expected if the economy were coming out of a recession and pent-up demand were bursting forth. But this is the eighth year of economic expansion. 
 Unfortunately, incomes are not rising at anything like that pace. To support such spending, people are deciding not to save. The statistics on savings are muddied by the Government's decision to change the way they are calculated, but it appears that the savings rate is at the lowest level since the Government started collecting the figures in 1946. Perhaps people see little need to save. What savings they have are booming along with the stock market, and there is no worry about recession.
There are signs of problems for businesses brought on by the overseas weakness. So far those problems seem not to have dampened corporate investment, let alone the buying patterns of consumers. But the American trade deficit is soaring to record levels even with imported oil the cheapest it has been in many years.
For now, the trade deficit has little cost. The dollar is strong because the Japanese yen is weak, amid worries the Japanese recession will deepen. If Japan does get its economic house in order, the dollar could begin to fall, perhaps raising the reported inflation figures enough to trouble American consumers. But for now, consumers see a wonderful economy, and are spending on the assumption it will continue.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Russia and France Gain on U.S. Lead in Arms Sales, Study Says

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The United States remains the world's biggest arms merchant, filling the developing world's arsenals with billions of dollars of weapons, but Russia and France are poised to overtake the United States, a new Government report says.
The study, by the Congressional Research Service, says the United States retained its No. 1 position in the arms trade, which it has held for seven years, by selling $15.2 billion worth of weapons last year, a 44 percent share of the shrinking global arms market. 
 Russia and France are in a dead heat in the competition for sales pacts, says the report, which is based in part on data compiled by the Central Intelligence Agency. The accords, not all of which are carried out, indicate trends in sales.
The report shows that sales by the United States and other nations to the developing world are slowing. There has been a steady decline in most sectors of the international trade since the end of the cold war and the Persian Gulf war.
The arms bazaar of the 80's and early 90's in Asia and the Middle East has calmed, in part because of the Asian economic crisis, which has prevented nations from striking huge new deals. Another factor is the long slump in crude oil prices, helping slow purchases by Saudi Arabia, once the biggest buyer of American weaponry. The Saudis have also been constrained by the huge costs that they paid to help finance the gulf war in 1991.
Developing nations, however, are still the biggest buyers of American weapons. Last year the United States delivered attack helicopters and a variety of missiles to Taiwan, missiles and torpedoes to Egypt, multiple-rocket launchers and airborne-jamming equipment to South Korea and air-defense communications equipment to Saudi Arabia.
Saudi Arabia, with $11 billion in new weapons delivered, and Taiwan, with $9.3 billion, were by a 10-fold factor the largest buyers among developing nations last year, far outstripping their nearest competitors, Egypt, Iran and Kuwait.
They will soon have a new rival. In May the United Arab Emirates announced that it would buy 80 F-16 fighter jets, including weapons and support systems, a deal worth an estimated $7 billion.
The United States policy on weapons sales is set by an order signed by President Clinton in 1995, Presidential Decision Directive 34. It says the sales are "a legitimate instrument of U.S. foreign policy." The policy makes clear that increasing the sales and market share of American arms manufacturers is a goal of American foreign policy.
Lora Lumpe, who directs the Arms Sales Monitoring Project at the Federation of American Scientists, said, "This Administration has relied on armed diplomacy, weapons sales and military training, rather than fostering regional arms control and diplomatic initiatives to dampen or head off conflict."
No international arms deal has been rejected under the directive, which evaluates sales case by case. The policy also accepts the argument that if the United States does not sell weapons to developing nations, others like Russia or France will gladly fill the bill.
Among the biggest competitors, Russia is struggling to sign deals to obtain hard currency. But developing nations increasingly see it as a unreliable supplier because of its economic woes, the report says. Russia's best customers are India, which bought 40 Russian fighter jets last year, and China, which bought two destroyers.
In 1990, Iran was a major buyer of Russian fighter jets, bombers, tanks and submarines. But now "Iran, primarily due to its own economic problems, as well as U.S. pressure, most recently has ceased to be a major purchaser of arms from Russia," the report says.
Russia delivered $2.7 billion of arms from 1990 to 1993, but $700 million from 1994 to 1997. Iran has become more reliant on Chinese suppliers. But China's deliveries also fell, from $1.8 billion from 1990 to 1993 to $800 million from 1994 to 1997.
Of all regions the Middle East continues to have the deepest hunger for new weapons, the report says, and the United States continues to be its most reliable supplier. American allies in the region have received, among other weapons, 116 supersonic aircraft, 1,358 surface-to-air missiles, 1,332 tanks and self-propelled guns and 72 helicopters in the last four years, the study says.
But sanctions have effectively shut out two big United States enemies, Libya and Iraq, from the conventional arms trade, the report shows.
From 1990 to last year the United States signed contracts to sell $44.1 billion of weapons to Middle Eastern nations, the report says. France is in a position to overtake the United States as the region's biggest arms suppliers, the report states.
Asia is the second-biggest regional market, and Russian sales to India, China and Vietnam have given it the biggest share of arms-transfer agreements in the region. From 1994 to 1997, Russia concluded $29.6 billion in agreements to Asian nations, more than 40 percent of that market.
Over all, however, the United States has led the field in the 90's. From 1990 to 1997, it delivered $53.4 billion of weapons to the developing world, far outstripping Britain, Russia and France, the study shows.
The figures in the annual report, available from the research service at the Library of Congress, for United States sales includes just Government-approved military sales, not commercial sales of components and spare parts.

The United States leads the way in arms sales around the world. Figures are adjusted for inflation. Graph compares the biggest buyers and sellers of arms from 1994 to 1997.

HEADLINE: U.N. Arms Inspector's Talks With Iraq Break Down in Bitterness

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Crucial talks in Baghdad on the remaining issues blocking the lifting of sanctions on Iraq collapsed in rancor today, United Nations officials said.
The Iraqis, returning to the belligerent tone that heralded an international crisis last fall, rejected a plan for settling issues proposed by the United Nations chief arms inspector for Iraq, Richard Butler. 
 Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi delegation leader, accused Mr. Butler, an Australian, of using "old tricks" and following an American policy of continuing sanctions no matter what progress is made.
Mr. Butler told reporters in Baghdad after today's session that he had not made the progress he had hoped for. "I made a proposal for further acceleration of work and it was rejected," he said.
Danilo Turk, the Slovenian delegate to the Security Council and its current President, said Mr. Butler would cut his trip short and return to brief the Council by Wednesday.
United Nations officials here and in Baghdad said they had no further information on the stalled discussions and declined to speculate whether the show of obstinacy by the Iraqis was a ploy to rally support against Mr. Butler, whose frank style they dislike.
The Iraqis once again staged a funeral procession for 35 Iraqi children outside the building where Mr. Butler and Mr. Aziz met. Their parents told reporters that the children had died because of sanctions.
The Iraqis accused the United States of "wrecking" the program under which limited oil sales are permitted to pay for food and medicine. United Nations officials countered that a loosening of the sanctions has increased oil sales sharply and has allowed hundreds of millions of dollars in medical supplies to reach Iraq. They said it was the Iraqi Government that recently reduced a United Nations proposal to raise caloric intake in food distribution.
The Iraqis have been encouraged by Russia, France and China to hope for a phasing-out of sanctions should the Security Council acknowledge that every detail about Iraqi weapons will never be known and that enough progress had been made to warrant a relaxation.
In June, Mr. Butler, under pressure from the Security Council, provided Iraq with a "road map" of steps to take to meet his disarmament requirements. Mr. Aziz, repeating that Iraq had no more weapons or information to provide, strongly indicated then that there would be no more cooperation.
Mr. Butler did not go to Iraq this week with high hopes.
The collapse of this round of talks would leave little room for averting tensions when the sanctions are reviewed by the Security Council in October. Iraq has significant questions to answer and has provided no new information since May.
The Iraqis have, in fact, lost some ground because of the discovery of VX nerve gas on shell canisters and a less upbeat assessment than expected last week by the International Atomic Energy Agency on accounting for nuclear programs. Iraq also refused to hand over a document found by inspectors last month.
President Saddam Hussein has threatened unspecified retaliation if the embargo on oil sales is not lifted this year. Last year, his Government expelled American inspectors, put large presidential compounds off limits and threatened to freeze all inspections.
President Hussein's defiance of arms inspectors led to a massing of American and British forces in the Persian Gulf early this year.

HEADLINE: G.M. Plans To Spin Off Parts Division

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to spin off its gigantic auto parts subsidiary to its shareholders next year, a move that could reignite the labor troubles that led to nearly eight-week-long strikes that ended only last Wednesday.
If completed, the move would represent a historic shift away from vertical integration, a corporate strategy in which a company produces most of the parts as well as the final product. Through the 1970's, G.M. promoted its vertical integration as a source of financial strength and savings. 
 But John F. Smith Jr., the G.M. chairman and chief executive, said yesterday that General Motors wanted instead to be a company that assembles and markets cars, but does not necessarily make a large proportion of the parts inside.
The spinoff of the auto parts subsidiary, Delphi Automotive Systems, "represents nothing less than a fundamental shift away from vertical integration," Mr. Smith said.
The United Automobile Workers union reacted furiously to G.M.'s announcement this afternoon, which followed a regularly scheduled board meeting. "Should G.M. decide to proceed with the sale as announced, the U.A.W.'s record is clear: we can and will aggressively work to protect the rights and interests of U.A.W. members impacted by the sale," Richard Shoemaker, the union's vice president for G.M. issues, said in a statement.
General Motors' national contract with the union expires in September 1999, and the union could try to stop the spinoff of Delphi then with a strike.
Through strikes and the threat of strikes, the U.A.W. has sometimes forced G.M. to postpone or cancel factory sales and closings over the years.
Robert Stempel, the former chairman of G.M., announced in December 1991 the closing of two dozen factories and the elimination of 74,000 jobs, but some of those factories are still open and the jobs still exist.
But a spinoff of Delphi could be an attractive move for General Motors and its shareholders. The U.A.W. currently forces G.M. to pay the same wages of at least $19 an hour to assembly plant workers and parts factory workers alike, even though nonunion parts makers pay only half as much to their workers.
An independent Delphi could try to pay lower wages to its American workers who are members of the U.A.W. It might be able to sell more parts to other auto makers, which have been reluctant to order from Delphi for fear that it would share parts designs and other competitive information with G.M.
Ford and Chrysler have to pay the same wages to assembly workers and parts workers, but disposed of many of their parts factories piecemeal in the late 1970's and early 1980's, when their survival was in doubt.
Japanese auto makers pay close to $19 an hour to their assembly plant workers but buy the great bulk of their parts from outside suppliers with much lower wages.
Gerald Knechtel, G.M.'s vice president for North American personnel, had said last Tuesday, when a tentative settlement was reached with the U.A.W. in Flint, Mich., that the auto maker wanted a closer relationship with the union and would begin holding regular, top-level meetings with union officials. Mr. Knechtel said then that the strike could only be judged worthwhile if it produced a lasting improvement in the relationship.
Workers ratified the settlement last Wednesday and returned to work, but G.M. lost $3 billion in after-tax profits because of the strike, or nearly half a year's earnings.
Mr. Smith said at a news conference yesterday that G.M.'s board had been planning for months to decide on the spinoff of Delphi at its August meeting, but that the company had not told the union until after the Flint strike had ended.
Even if G.M. divests itself of Delphi, it will still be somewhat vertically integrated. G.M. factories that produce engines, transmissions and exterior sheet metal are part of G.M.'s auto assembly and marketing divisions, and would not be divested with Delphi.
The Delphi division makes hundreds of smaller parts, from spark plugs to dashboards to seats, that are less important to a car's exterior appearance or road performance.
The strikes in Flint affected two parts factories, a Delphi factory that makes speedometers, spark plugs and other parts and another, non-Delphi factory that stamps truck hoods and other parts from sheets of steel.
But G.M.'s planned spinoff of Delphi nonetheless represents a big decision. Delphi, based in Troy, Mich., is the world's largest auto parts maker, with slightly greater annual sales than the Intel Corporation.
Delphi's 200,000 employees around the world include 50,000 U.A.W. members in the United States, a sizable number for a union with around 730,000 members. There are another 150,000 U.A.W. workers in G.M.'s other operations that will not be divested.
General Motors said that it planned to dispose of Delphi in two steps.
During the first quarter of next year, G.M. plans to distribute to shareholders as much as 20 percent of Delphi's stock. The auto maker said it would dispose of the rest of Delphi later next year, by distributing shares or by exchanging G.M. shares for Delphi shares, or possibly by a combination of these approaches, in a transaction that is intended to be tax-free.

HEADLINE: Spending Climbed in June, Outpacing Income Growth

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Americans kept spending at a strong pace in June, even though their incomes posted the smallest increase in three and a half years. The combination of weak income growth and strong spending pushed the personal savings rate to a record low.
The Commerce Department reported today that personal incomes rose a scant two-tenths of a percent in June, just half the May gain of four-tenths of a percent. One reason was a loss of $2 billion, at an annual rate, in wages because of the General Motors strike, which was settled last week. 
 Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, rose at a strong clip of six-tenths of a percent in June. This was slower than the surge of nine-tenths of a percent in May, which was the strongest gain in nearly a year.
The strong growth in spending and the slowdown in incomes lowered the percentage of income that Americans were able to save to two-tenths of a percent in June, the lowest level since the Government began keeping monthly statistics in 1959. The savings rate had dipped to five-tenths of a percent in May from a 1.1 percent rate in April.
In a sense, however, the report of low savings is misleading because the Government report reflects the amount left over after subtracting spending from incomes, but does not count capital gains as income.
Another report today showed that a closely watched barometer of the manufacturing sector, the National Association of Purchasing Management's composite index, retreated in July to 49.1 from 49.6 in June. It was the second consecutive decline after 22 months of being above the 50 mark, the dividing line between a manufacturing sector that is expanding and one that is shrinking.
Analysts said the decline reflected the continued export problems that American companies are having because of the Asian economic crisis.
But a third report today showed that the domestic economy continued to have significant momentum, despite the Asian situation. Construction spending jumped 1.7 percent in June, the biggest gain in more than a year; spending for residential construction rose to a record high.
Overall construction spending climbed to a seasonally adjusted $644 billion in June, the second-highest level on record. The stronger-than-expected increase reflected a 1.6 percent rise in single-family homes and a 2.1 percent increase in nonresidential buildings.
"The economy is still quite healthy, but it is certainly slowing from the torrid pace that we saw last year and the first quarter of this year," said Cynthia Latta, economist at Standard & Poor's DRI.
Even with the end of the General Motors strike, many economists say economic growth will continue to be slow for the rest of the year as the Asian crisis pushes America's trade deficit to record levels and depresses manufacturing and foreign sales by American farmers.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Accuses Dain Rauscher of Fraud

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused Dain Rauscher Inc. and two former employees of fraud for their roles in underwriting bonds connected to the 1994 bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif.
The lawsuit, filed today in the United States District Court here, is the second S.E.C. action against a brokerage firm stemming from the bankruptcy. In the first action, Credit Suisse First Boston and two former employees agreed in January to pay $870,000 to settle S.E.C. charges. In addition, the commission is negotiating a settlement with Merrill Lynch & Company that is reported to be for a fine of less than $3 million. 
 The S.E.C. actions are distinct from lawsuits filed by Orange County. Those suits, several of which have been settled recently, generally accuse brokerage firms of selling risky securities to the county. The S.E.C. is concentrating on the adequacy of disclosures made by underwriters who sold bonds issued by the county or its municipalities to the public.
Dain Rauscher, a major participant in municipal finance, underwrote or was the financial adviser for 13 bond offerings, totaling more than $980 million, by cities and school districts in Orange County in 1993 and 1994, according to the S.E.C. complaint. The proceeds from the offerings were invested in an investment pool run by Orange County's treasurer, Robert L. Citron. The pool suffered heavy losses in 1994, precipitating the bankruptcy.
The S.E.C. accuses Dain Rauscher of misleading investors by not disclosing in the offering documents that the sole purpose of the bond sales was to obtain money to invest in the Orange County pool in the hopes of making profits. Moreover, the commission contends, Dain Rauscher did not disclose the riskiness of the pool's investments, which were highly leveraged and subject to big losses if interest rates rose.
Dain Rauscher, which is based in Los Angeles, strongly denied all charges. "We do not understand how the S.E.C. can allege fraud in these circumstances," the company said. It said it was not involved with the investment pool. It also said it knew less about the pool than the credit rating agencies, which gave the pool their highest ratings, and the S.E.C., which reviewed the pool at that time and took no action.
Moreover, the company said, all the investors who held the bonds it underwrote were paid in full. Michael J. Missal, a lawyer for Dain Rauscher, said it was common practice at the time not to disclose that the proceeds of a bond offering were going to the investment pool. But, he said, "Every investor knew where they were going."
Lawyers for the two former Dain Rauscher employees, who were the investment bankers in charge of many of the offerings in question, also denied the charges. The former employees are Virginia O. Horler, 57, of Moraga, Calif., and Kenneth D. Ough, 45, of Post Falls, Idaho.
Dain Rauscher was formed in January through the merger of Dain Bosworth of Minneapolis and Rauscher Pierce Refsnes of Dallas. It was Rauscher Pierce that was involved in the Orange County underwritings.
The action today was not a surprise. Rauscher Pierce disclosed in a quarterly filing last year that it was a focus in a Federal enforcement action related to Orange County. But talks aimed at a settlement broke down. In a separate case, the S.E.C. in January accused Rauscher Pierce of defrauding investors and the State of Arizona by engaging in "yield burning," in which Treasury bonds are sold to state or local governments at artificially high prices. The company denied any wrongdoing.
The S.E.C. also brought an administrative action against Ms. Horler, charging inadequate disclosure on bonds issued by Nevada County, Calif. She denies those charges, according to Mr. Missal, the lawyer.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Yen Hits Seven-Week Low Against the Dollar

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The yen fell to its lowest level against the dollar in seven weeks today, as currency traders tested the new Japanese Government's resolve to let the market determine the currency's value.
At 5 P.M. today, one dollar could buy 145.63 yen, up from 144.79 yen when trading opened this morning and from 144.70 yen late Friday in New York. The yen slipped more on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported, trading at 145.72 to the dollar early in the day, but its slide was limited because a Finance Ministry official said that Japan might act to buoy the sagging yen. 
 Many currency traders and economists expect the dollar to test this year's high of 146.75 yen any day, although few have forgotten being burned by intervention by the United States and Japanese Governments after that high was hit on June 16.
Kiichi Miyazawa, the newly appointed Minister of Finance, caught the markets' attention last week when he suggested that markets, rather than governments, should determine the appropriate dollar-yen exchange rate, although he hedged by saying intervention was "all right" in an "extreme situation."
"The comment by Miyazawa when he said he would leave the market to determine exchange rates was what got the most interest in the market, and now they're speculating about whether he will be as committed as his predecessor to capping the market," said Robert Alan Feldman, senior economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo.
Mr. Feldman has set a target of 160 yen to the dollar by the end of this year based on continuing gloomy economic fundamentals. Today, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said domestic vehicle sales fell 8.4 percent from a year earlier, the 16th consecutive month that sales have fallen.
Excluding mini-vehicles, however, sales climbed 13.5 percent from the previous month, and two of the country's five largest car makers, the Honda Motor Company and the Mazda Motor Corporation, reported a 3.5 percent and 4.5 percent sales increase, respectively.
The markets have been skeptical of new Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi's ability to address Japan's weak economy and shaky banking system quickly and comprehensively, even though his new economic team has won some grudging respect from the markets.
As yet, they have not articulated a single philosophy on what economic changes they will pursue, and Mr. Miyazawa is blamed in some quarters for doing little to rein in the speculative growth that created Japan's economic bubble in the 1980's.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Continue to Decline On Concerns About Profits
Investor concerns about the economic crisis in Asia and its impact on the earnings of American companies continued to send stock market gauges lower.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 1 percent, or 96.55 points, to 8,786.74. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 8.23 points, to 1,112.44. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index decreased 21.29 points, to 1,851.10. Page D11. 

The Hong Kong stock market fell sharply before a report showed that the economy shrank 2.8 percent in the first quarter of 1998. The effect of the Asian crisis on Hong Kong was also reflected in a sharply weaker earnings report from Hongkong and Shanghai Banking. D4.

In Tokyo, the yen fell to its lowest level against the dollar in seven weeks -- 145.63 to the dollar. The yen ended in late New York trading at 145.60 yen to the dollar. D4.
 
Chrysler's Sales Rose 3% in July
Chrysler reported a 3 percent increase in July vehicle sales, to 206,018, but that was below May and June sales. Its truck sales rose 9 percent, but car sales fell 8 percent. D9.
 
Ascend Confirms Deal for Stratus
Shares of Stratus Computer have increased in the last week amid speculation that it was being acquired by Ascend Communications. The $822 million stock deal, which was officially announced yesterday, values Stratus at $33.35 a share, 15 percent higher than Friday's closing price. D9.
 
Brokerage Firm Sued by the S.E.C.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused Dain Rauscher and two former employees of fraud for their roles in underwriting bonds connected to the 1994 bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif. The suit is the second S.E.C. action against a brokerage firm. The first was settled in January when Credit Suisse First Boston and two former employees agreed to pay $870,000. D2.
 
Kodak Buys a Medical Imaging Unit
Eastman Kodak will buy Imation's medical imaging business for $520 million in cash. The deal signals a turnaround for Kodak, which has been shrinking. D8.
 
Consumer Spending Rose in June
Spending by consumers rose a strong six-tenths of a percent in June, even though incomes posted the smallest gain in three and a half years. In another report, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its composite index retreated in July to 49.1 from 49.6 in June. D2.
 
Strong Dollar Bolsters Bonds
Treasury prices rose, helped by a stronger dollar, weaker commodities prices and an announcement by the Treasury that it would retire $45 billion in debt through September. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.65 percent, from 5.71 on Friday. D11.
 
Mobil Revives Familiar Flying Horse
Pegasus, the classical mythological creature associated with strength, power and beauty and the red flying horse used by Mobil gasoline for 77 years, is making a comeback. It is the star of TV commercials depicting Mobil as a trusted brand. Advertising. D10.
 
A Spanish Company Gains Overseas
The Spanish telecommunications company Telefonica doubled its Latin American holdings to more than $10 billion last week after it successfully bid for a third of the Brazilian carrier Telebras. D7.

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 751 words

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Clinton's Foreign Debt

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
I thought that by going all the way to Brazil, I might actually escape the Bill Clinton soap opera. Wrong.
Scene one: A Brazilian macho men's association recently voted Bill Clinton "Macho Man of the Year," and even delivered the award to the American Embassy. 
 Scene two: Lunch in Rio de Janeiro with a group of Brazilian businessmen. They want to know just one thing: What might Bill Clinton's troubles mean for U.S. investment in Brazil? "The whole world is depending on U.S. capital flows," explains Joel Korn, a leading Brazilian management consultant. "If there is a change in the U.S. situation because of the President's troubles, which affects U.S. investment overseas, the whole world will be hurt."
You have here in a nutshell the two basic foreign reactions to Mr. Clinton's troubles: 1) Surely you Americans can't be serious about prosecuting a President for adultery. World leaders always play around -- just look at ours. And 2) My God, what if you Americans are serious about prosecuting your President for adultery! Don't you realize how important you are for the rest of the world? You are the world's only superpower. Nothing happens without you. And every emerging market is depending on your economic stability. Maybe you think you don't need a President -- but the rest of the world does.
And so it goes. Half the time the rest of the world is snickering at us as naive Puritans and half the time they are unnerved that we might actually devour another President, with all the uncertainty that might entail.
They are right to be concerned. Americans may think the world is safe for us to indulge in this entertaining Clinton saga -- and for U.S. foreign policy to come to a standstill while it plays out -- but it's not.
Look what's going on out there: Russia, with 20,000 nuclear weapons and an impoverished arms industry ready to sell anything to anyone, is teetering on the edge of collapse. Kosovo and Albania are imploding. China is considering devaluing its currency, in a move that could trigger a whole new downward economic spiral in Asia that would surely hurt the U.S. economy. Japan is stumbling around, lost. Saddam Hussein is preparing to rear his ugly head again. Iran is testing a long-range missile. The Arabs are moving closer to Iran, out of a feeling that the U.S. is too weak now to protect them from any Iranian meddling. The expansion of U.S. free trade, through the fast-track process, is frozen because the President is afraid to confront Congressional Democrats on this issue, because they are his only core support. And the Arab-Israeli peace process is frozen, in part because the White House has completely wimped out from its vow to confront Israel's Prime Minister, Bibi Netanyahu, if he continues to reject the U.S. peace plan.
But this is not some backdoor argument for letting the President off the hook and just ignoring this whole tawdry affair. It is an argument for why the President, in whatever he says to the grand jury this month or to the American public afterward, has to bring this case to a close, once and for all. No more "I didn't inhale," "I didn't consummate," "Not to my recollection." It's enough, already.
The press is now full of reports about infighting in the White House between aides who think the President should come clean with the grand jury and aides who think he shouldn't. Excuse me, but are these guys nuts? Do they really think there is any hope for salvaging the Clinton Presidency with anything less than full disclosure? Do they really think America's national security interests can indefinitely tolerate a wounded President, constantly on the run from the press, courts and Congress?
Mr. Clinton has got to say and do now what is necessary to put this case behind him -- in a way that might give at least some chance for him to pursue the progressive agenda, at home and abroad, for which he was elected. He owes that to all the people who believe in the social and economic programs for which he stood, and still might be able to salvage. He owes that to all the people who don't want to see an isolationist, mean-spirited Republican right shaping America's future.
But to have a morally impeached Bill Clinton, without a shred of hope for Clintonism, well, what's the point?
Mr. President, whatever your aides might say, your options are to tell the truth or resign. I hope you tell the truth, because the country and the world can't afford to have you endlessly twisting in the wind.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: A Candidate Without Cash or Flash;
Larocca's Understated Race, the Weakest in a Field of Four

SERIES: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: The Race for Governor

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: LOWVILLE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Most people watching the Lewis County Fair parade had no idea who the man in the monogrammed shirt was or why he had joined the procession of baton twirlers, beauty queens and Boy Scouts marching through town on a steamy summer night.
He was politely shaking hands, and occasionally introducing himself as Jim Larocca, a Democratic candidate for governor. But he was not urging people to support him in the Democratic primary on Sept. 15. And unlike other politicians marching in the parade, he had no zealous campaign aides passing out buttons and shouting his name to the crowd. 
 James L. Larocca (pronounced la-ROCK-a), a former state official from Huntington, N.Y., is the most understated of the four Democrats hoping to oppose Gov. George E. Pataki in the fall, and his campaign has by far the least cash. But what he lacks in money and flash, he makes up for in doggedness. Mr. Larocca registered as a gubernatorial candidate more than a year ago, long before any of his better-known competitors -- Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross and Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney. And he has traveled the state ever since, courting Democratic leaders with a quiet intensity that has earned him a surprising amount of support, considering that Mr. Larocca, 54, has few ties to the Democratic Party establishment, has never held elective office and is barely known outside Long Island.
"Jim is just a super guy," said Charles Merrell, the Lewis County Democratic chairman, who invited Mr. Larocca to the upstate parade. "There's a lot to like about him. He'd make a great governor."
Why, then, have Mr. Merrell and other party leaders who gush about Mr. Larocca thrown their weight behind other candidates? Why is Mr. Larocca, admired by everyone from upstate dairy farmers to urban advocates of gay issues, considered the longest of long shots?
Because the other candidates have more money and name recognition, factors that party officials said count more than good ideas when the Republican incumbent is soaring high in the polls. Mr. Larocca has raised only $845,000 and spent all but $3,600, which leaves him miles behind Mr. Vallone and Ms. McCaughey Ross, each of whom has raised more than $3 million. Mr. Hynes has raised $500,000 and still has $200,000 on hand.
"I'm going with Peter Vallone because he's got money and, let's face it, more people know who he is," Mr. Merrell said. "I just think he's got a better chance at it than Jim."
Mr. Larocca is the only Democratic candidate who has worked in state government, as Transportation Commissioner under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Energy Commissioner under Gov. Hugh L. Carey. He was also president of the Long Island Association, the island's largest economic development group, for eight years. Demographically, Mr. Larocca is a political consultant's dream: Roman Catholic, Italian-American and the only candidate not from New York City. He and his wife, Dale, have three grown children. And he looks gubernatorial, with silvery hair, perfect posture and an earnest gaze.
His platform is broad enough to appeal to both upstate moderates and urban liberals. He supports abortion rights, affirmative action and gay marriage, yet he also calls the death penalty "appropriate." Mr. Larocca would cut tuition at public colleges and universities by 25 percent, ban corporate contributions to political campaigns and push the State Legislature to allow casinos in economically depressed regions.
He also wants to create regional partnerships involving businesses, universities and local governments to assist economic development. He encouraged such partnerships when he was running the Long Island Association, and he said they helped the region's economy when the military contracting industry collapsed in the early 1990's.
His supporters on Long Island said Mr. Larocca had positively influenced everything from energy policy and land preservation to job creation as president of the association, experience that they said makes him more qualified to make statewide policy decisions than the other candidates.
Mr. Larocca also said he is the only Democratic candidate who is "unequivocally" in favor of allowing dairy farmers to join an interstate compact as a way of negotiating higher prices for milk, a stand that increases his appeal in the upstate regions he has worked so hard to impress. "He is the only one who can mount a credible, broad-based challenge to Pataki and not drag the rest of the ticket down," said Phil Friedman, a Democratic consultant and a friend of Mr. Larocca's. "If you want a candidate who can unify the Democratic Party, there's no question you should pick him."
But increasingly large stumbling blocks have made political life difficult for Mr. Larocca in recent months. The biggest came in May, when the Nassau County Democratic chairman, Stephen J. Sabbeth, switched his support from Mr. Larocca to Ms. McCaughey Ross. As a result, Mr. Larocca did not win enough delegate votes at the State Democratic Convention to get an automatic spot on the primary ballot.
Mr. Larocca turned to a more laborious way of getting on the ballot: collecting at least 15,000 signatures from registered Democrats around the state. Despite predictions that he could not afford a petition drive, he succeeded and spent only $2,500. A Suffolk County resident filed a challenge to Mr. Larocca's petitions, but state election officials have not yet received the required detailed explanation of the challenge, which means it will probably be dismissed.
These recent complications have hurt his fund-raising efforts, Mr. Larocca said, as would-be supporters have decided his campaign is doomed. He complains bitterly about his fund-raising disadvantage, saying Mr. Vallone and Mr. Hynes can easily raise money as elected officials, and pointing out that most of Ms. McCaughey Ross's money comes from her husband, a wealthy banker. But he also attempts to make an asset of his relative poverty.
"I'm proving that it's not about money, but about the vision and independence and integrity of the candidate," Mr. Larocca said. "I am also the only one who can mount an all-out assault on Pataki's fund-raising, because I have not been part of this system of raising money that has so troubled the public."
The absence of a political record and his relative obscurity have meant that he has not attracted much campaign criticism yet, but on Long Island, some civic and business leaders complain that he has failed to take a strong stand on the state's takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company. "He has been strangely silent on one of the key issues facing Long Island," said Jack Kulka, a builder on Long Island who is chairman of a coalition opposed to the Lilco takeover. "I haven't seen him say anything gubernatorial other than 'Vote for me.' "
Other critics say his insistence on staying in the race with no money is a sign of arrogance. Sheldon R. Sackstein, the chairman of Action Long Island, a nonprofit business and civic group, said Mr. Larocca was more focused on advancing his career than on solving problems. "I have always seen a lack of team effort on his part," Mr. Sackstein said. "If he truly was a team player, he would bow out and support the folks with the more likely chance to win."
But Mr. Friedman and others said Mr. Larocca would be wise to stress his independence from the Democratic political machine, because people who vote in primaries tend to admire underdogs who lack party support. The best examples are Mr. Carey and Mr. Cuomo, both of whom defeated party favorites in Democratic gubernatorial primaries.
"Nothing makes primary voters madder than having Democratic bosses tell them who they can choose among," Mr. Friedman said. "These are voters who follow the issues carefully, who believe in a progressive, independent Democratic Party and whose votes can never be totally predicted."
Mr. Larocca's distaste for old-style politicking shows on the campaign trail, where he spends more time huddling with small groups than working rooms. On a visit to a nursing home in Watertown, N.Y., in July, he listened to concerns about staffing and health insurance, then quietly ducked out. And when his daughter showed up at a candidate's forum in Manhattan, he retreated to a corner for a personal conversation with her instead of pumping hands.
"It's to his credit that he's not a back-slapping type of guy and likes to have deep conversations with people instead," said Assemblyman Eric N. Vitaliano, a Staten Island Democrat who has known Mr. Larocca for years. "Jimmy's got quiet strength, and that's an asset in this time of superficial sound bites."
Even those who believe Mr. Larocca does not have a prayer said his soft-pedal approach was winning him a loyal support base that could make him a strong candidate in 2002. John Zogby, a pollster in Utica, N.Y., said that although Mr. Larocca's better-known opponents would suffer from a primary defeat, he has nothing to lose.
"He's young, he's attractive, he is making the kinds of contacts he needs and he is not hurting himself by attacking the other candidates," Mr. Zogby said. "My guess is that Larocca is the only one of these four who's got legs."

A series of articles examining the political appeal and campaign strategies of candidates in the race for governor of New York.

SECTION: Section D; Page 4; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 874 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Stocks Fall as Hong Kong's Slump Worsens

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The stock market fell sharply here today, as two new reports laid bare the depths of the Asian financial crisis and its impact on this former British colony.
First, Hong Kong's government reported that the economy shrank 2.8 percent in the first quarter of 1998. The contraction was even sharper than the provisional figure of 2 percent the government released in June. And it confirmed that Hong Kong is headed into its deepest recession since World War II. 
 Second, the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, the leading bank here, announced that earnings fell 41 percent, to $791.16 million, in the first half of 1998 because of a huge charge taken to protect it from bad loans. HSBC Holdings P.L.C., the bank's London-based parent, said it took a $1.14 billion charge -- a jump of $889 million over a charge in the first half of 1997. As a result, HSBC said net profit for the first half fell 16 percent to $2.402 billion.
The provision for bad loans is one yardstick of how severe HSBC believes the financial crisis will be. Analysts said its size indicated that the bank expected many Asian companies to face financial hardship as the crisis wears on -- with a good number defaulting on their loans.
"What the market has to realize is that this is not the end, but the beginning," said Roy Ramos, a banking analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company in Hong Kong. "There will have to be more provisions for bad loans."
Although HSBC and the government made their announcements after the stock market here closed, investors had anticipated the bad news. The benchmark Hang Seng index of 33 leading issues fell 383.43 points, or 4.8 percent, to 7,552.77, worsening a market decline just over 8 percent in the two preceding weeks. HSBC, which accounts for a third of the weighted index, also slid nearly 5 percent today, to $179 (Hong Kong), or $23.25 (United States) a share.
 Early Tuesday, the Hang Seng index was up six-tenths of a percent, or 45.16 points, to 7,597.93.
 Government officials said today that Hong Kong's economic performance in the first quarter was worse than initially thought because declines in consumer spending and in tourism revenue were steeper than expected. K. Y. Tang, a government economist, said the rapid onset of the financial crisis had made it all but impossible to accurately forecast growth. But Mr. Tang acknowledged that -- with the latest trade and retail sales figures showing continued declines -- he expected the second quarter to be "somewhat worse" than the first. Private economists said Hong Kong's output would probably decline 3 percent in the second quarter.
"The only bright spot I can see is the normal seasonal pickup in trade in the fourth quarter," said Ian K. Perkin, chief economist of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "But then we get into the problem of what happens in the first and second quarter of 1999."
Like many economists, Mr. Perkin said he worried that Hong Kong and other Asian economies faced several years of recession. Hong Kong's economy has been sapped by all the usual symptoms of the Asian economic ailment -- like an erosion of exports to its neighbors and a loss of consumer confidence -- and a few symptoms unique to this city. The trouble-prone opening of the Hong Kong airport disrupted cargo shipments, costing several hundred million dollars in exports.
All told, Mr. Perkin estimated that Hong Kong's gross domestic product would decline by 2 percent this year -- its first full year of contraction since the territory began keeping records in 1961.
Hongkong and Shanghai Bank is taking a similarly bleak view. It said it could not predict when Hong Kong or other markets would claw themselves out of their current trough. Executives at HSBC said the bulk of the $1.14 billion in bad-loan provisions was intended for loans to companies in Indonesia and Thailand.
Mr. Ramos noted, though, that the bank still needed to deal with loans to companies here and in South Korea, Malaysia and China. "We take a very strong premise that it is going to get worse in all these markets," he said.
At the moment, HSBC's nonperforming loans account for only 1.7 percent of all its loans in Hong Kong, and 6.9 percent of loans in the rest of Asia. But Mr. Ramos said he expected that the ratio of nonperforming loans could easily double in Hong Kong, and in some Asian markets -- like Thailand -- it could rise to as much as 30 percent of the bank's portfolio.
"In general, we've been taken aback by how severely economies in Asia have contracted," Mr. Ramos said. "And we've been taken aback by how high the ratio of nonperforming loans has risen."
HSBC executives noted, somewhat plaintively, that their underlying business was performing well. The bank's operating earnings before the bad-loan provision increased 13 percent, to $4.76 billion, in the first half. And HSBC's British and American operations both had solid profit gains.
But the bankers found it hard to accentuate the positive. Addressing a news conference in the bank's architecturally striking Hong Kong headquarters, John Bond, the group chairman of HSBC Holdings, said of the Asian crisis, "I think the speed and severity has caught everybody by surprise."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hong Kong's leading bank reported reduced earnings yesterday. At a news briefing, John Bond, group chairman of parent HSBC Holdings, said the severity of the Asian crisis had "caught everybody by surprise." (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Welcome to Grenada, Mr. Castro

 BODY:
A dictator who rules a country as long as Fidel Castro has governed Cuba sometimes gets to edit the history he helped create. Mr. Castro did just that over the weekend when he visited Grenada, the tiny Caribbean island the United States invaded almost 15 years ago in the name of preventing Cuban contamination in the hemisphere. Mr. Castro clearly savored the irony of his warm official greeting by the democratically elected Government of Prime Minister Keith Mitchell. He was welcomed with steel bands, a 21-gun salute and an official thank-you for Cuba's help in building the airport that Washington once viewed as a dangerous extension of Cuba's military reach into the eastern Caribbean.
The Cuban leader also got positive welcomes in Jamaica and Barbados, the first two stops in his tour of the English-speaking Caribbean. Six of the area's prime ministers have visited Havana in the past year and a half, and many of them are now pressing for Cuba's admission to the 16-nation Caribbean Community, a regional trade group. Further straining American ties with the Caribbean is a 90 percent drop in United States aid for the region between 1985 and 1995. Cuba has been quick to move into the breach with modest but appreciated programs of medical and technical assistance. 
 Meanwhile, Congress continues to treat Cuba as though the cold war had not ended. The Helms-Burton law of 1996, even though the Clinton Administration has been able to waive some of its most noxious provisions, denies the White House needed flexibility to modify America's 36-year-old economic embargo against Cuba to take account of changing circumstances. That embargo has failed to shake Mr. Castro's hold on power and hurts ordinary Cubans. It also runs counter to a theme of American foreign policy today, namely that increased trade and investment can be a useful mechanism for encouraging democratic change.
Despite harsh persecution by the Castro dictatorship, democrats within Cuba are pressing to expand the narrow legal boundaries of permitted political expression. The United States should reinforce their efforts to open up Cuban society by increasing its own official and unofficial contacts with the Cuban people. Isolation does not work.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CROWN BOOKS TO CLOSE 79 STORES AND LAY OFF 1,250

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Crown Books Corporation, the discount chain based in Landover, Md., said yesterday that it would close 79 of its 174 stores as soon as possible and lay off 1,250 workers as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy protection and return to profitability. Crown plans to close all of its stores in Philadelphia, Seattle and Texas but to keep a "strong presence" in the Washington area, Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles and San Diego. The plan requires approval of creditors and the bankruptcy court. Crown Books is part of the Dart Group, which was recently acquired by Richfood Holdings Inc.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Who Will Be Yanks' Newest Cable Guy?

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Each Yankees cable telecast should rightly be preceded by a notice like the ones that accompany public TV programs: "This game has been generously underwritten by a grant from the Madison Square Garden Network."
The MSG Network has made the Yankees flusher than flush since the start of their landmark $486 million cable TV contract in 1989. As the deal nears its end, MSG will pay the Yankees $53.3 million this year, $54.25 million next year and $55.25 million in 2000, according to people who have read the contract. 
 Most baseball teams survive on $45 million or $50 million a season less in cable cash. The entire National Hockey League gets less in its rights deal with Fox Sports.
But with the deal's expiration two years away, can the Yankees expect a new one to maintain such exorbitant payments -- or go even higher? When the deal was negotiated in 1988, it was the subject of rabid bidding among MSG, which wanted to become more than a six-month Knicks and Rangers service; Sportschannel New York, which had held the Yankee cable rights from 1982 to 1988, and Channel 11.
But now, Cablevision Systems owns MSG and Fox Sports New York, the former Sportschannel. Channel 11 is part of the WB Network and could not carry more than the 50 games it carries now under a subcontract with MSG.
"Probably less, as the WB expands," said Michael Eigner, who oversees Channel 11 as an executive vice president of the Tribune Company.
 So does Chuck Dolan, chairman of Cablevision, hold all the leverage? Can he dictate to George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, a significant cut in payments? Will Steinbrenner's cash wad shrink in the new millennium until he gets a new stadium?
No. No. And unlikely.
The Yankees' value has expanded in the past decade, almost making us forget the leanness of their 288-359 record from 1989 to 1992, the first four years of MSG's deal.
The Yankees are 78-28 after last night's victory in Oakland, and MSG's 3.88 rating after 63 games is up 51 percent from last year and 33 percent ahead of 1996's full-season MSG peak.
There are several scenarios that offer competition to Cablevision:
 Steinbrenner could create his own Yankee Network. For that he would have to set up an administrative structure to sell the rights to individual cable systems and commercial time to advertisers. He would get no cash up front, but would get all the cable system fees and advertiser payments. To execute the plan, he would need to make a deal with Cablevision, which owns systems totaling 2.6 million of the metropolitan area's 4.6 million cable homes. Dolan can be a tough negotiator, but any attempt to bar the Yankees from his systems would surely engender widespread viewer reaction.
 Steinbrenner could go into a partnership with Time Warner, which could create a sports channel on its New York City cable system, reaching 1.1 million subscribers. Time Warner would also have to deal with Cablevision to gain full local exposure beyond its environs. Can you imagine another entity starting a Yankee network and Dolan saying, "Nah, I'm not interested and my subscribers don't care"? Cable systems, including Dolan's, need the Yankees.
 ESPN could launch a regional sports channel. Until recently, ESPN contemplated creating ESPN West to carry games of the Anaheim Angels and Mighty Ducks, the teams controlled by its parent, Disney. When cable systems balked at carrying ESPN West, ESPN made 10-year deals to keep the Angels on Fox Sports West and the Ducks on Fox Sports West 2, two of the 22 regional sports outlets under the Fox Sports Net. A drawback to an ESPN New York is that it would remain a one-team service until other teams' rights became available. The Yankees plus college hoops and lacrosse is not a powerhouse channel. Josh Krulewitz, an ESPN spokesman, said, "We will consider regional opportunities if they make good business sense."
 New technologies, like digital television or satellite TV, could play a role in a non-Cablevision scenario.
"Chuck Dolan must realize George Steinbrenner has many options to work things out for himself," said Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College and an expert on sports finance. "Steinbrenner has put an emphasis on developing a winning team in anticipation of negotiating a new package. He's played his cards right. I see this as a $50 million-a-year contract."
Dolan realizes all this and knows that not having the Yankees' cable rights would hurt more than the defection of any other team. If Yankees games were broadcast on the Yankee Network, you could expect that cable systems would, if necessary, pre-empt whatever was being shown on MSG to carry the Bronx Bombers.
Dolan knows this, which is why he tried to buy the Yankees last year. If he had bought the team, he would have acquired the cable rights to eternity, which the Fox Group did by buying the Dodgers. If he bought a chunk of the team, it would come with a continued cable deal. The talks never yielded a sale. But if there exists a price that would make Steinbrenner bite, it has risen thanks to the successful juggernaut the Yankees have been through 106 games.
