HEADLINE: Tracing Money, Swiss Outdo U.S. On Mexico Drug Corruption Case

SERIES: PURSUING RAUL SALINAS: A special report.

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 28

 BODY:
When the young chief of Switzerland's drug police arrived here in late 1995 to inquire about $132 million found in Swiss bank accounts belonging to the influential elder brother of a former President, he knew enough about Mexico's political underworld to be wary of his official hosts.
No sooner had he been whisked from the airport by a squad of burly Mexican plainclothesmen, for example, than he began to wonder if he wasn't being kidnapped. 
 "I had seen it in the movies," the official, Valentin Roschacher, said, recalling what turned out to be merely some aggressive police security measures en route to his hotel. "I thought, 'Are these guys the good guys or the bad guys?' "
Now, more than two years later, Dr. Roschacher and his men have learned enough about organized crime in Mexico to follow a complicated financial trail and information from convicted drug traffickers to the conclusion that Raul Salinas de Gortari earned vast of sums of his money by assuring the safe transport of cocaine through Mexico to the United States.
Yet while the Swiss are preparing to use that evidence in a civil court action to confiscate the fortune of Mr. Salinas, the elder brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, a much larger and more experienced group of law enforcement officials in the United States has been unable to make a similar case of their own.
Some of those officials say they may yet win criminal indictments. Privately, others acknowledge that Washington's pursuit of Mr. Salinas has been troubled from the start, with turf battles among law enforcement agencies and Federal prosecutors, disputes over the handling of witnesses and complaints from agents in the field of meddling and a lack of interest by higher-ups.
The secrecy with which both Governments have proceeded makes it impossible to fully evaluate their evidence before it is presented in court, and Mr. Salinas has denied any wrongdoing.
Justice Department officials are also quick to note that they have sought to build a criminal case, which entails a higher standard of proof than the Swiss will face.
Nonetheless, the unlikely initial success of Dr. Roschacher's small detective team has turned an unflattering mirror on Washington's handling of what United States officials once described as a watershed effort to confront not just the flow of drugs through Mexico into the United States, but also the complex system of official corruption that has long allowed it to flourish.
The contrast is even more striking, officials say, because the Swiss appear to have relied almost entirely on witnesses and information that were first uncovered by the United States.
"They're like the mouse that roared," one former senior American law enforcement official said of the Swiss authorities. "They were blocked almost every step of the way. But they just kept going and kept going, and they finally made a case."
Whether any of the investigations will definitively resolve the question of the Salinas family's alleged collusion with the drug trade remains far from clear.
A partial account of the Swiss and United States inquiries, assembled from government documents and dozens of interviews, suggests that neither has penetrated into the brothers' inner circle.
But some experienced investigators have concluded that someone like Raul Salinas could have been a valued asset for the traffickers even if he could not necessarily pick up the phone and call off police raids. He might have been paid off, they said, just to provide an impression of acquiescence at the highest levels.
"Raul Salinas was not somebody who protected a truck with a gun as it went to the border," Dr. Roschacher said in an interview at his office in Bern, the Swiss capital. "What we are talking about is a system -- a system in which a person can give orders to someone who gives orders to someone else."
Raul Salinas, who remains in a maximum-security prison in Mexico on charges of ordering the murder of a leading figure in the governing party, has steadfastly proclaimed his innocence. He has insisted that most of the money in his accounts was given to him by Mexican industrialists for an investment fund that he was to establish.
"I have never had any kind of dealings with drug traffickers, nor have I received any benefit or money from any drug trafficker," he told the Swiss Attorney General, Carla del Ponte, in a handwritten letter from prison two months ago. "The source of my money, and of all the money that I managed, is legitimate."
Carlos Salinas, who left office just before the Mexican economy collapsed at the end of 1994 and soon left the country, has never been charged with any crime. He lives in Ireland and the south of France, one of his old friends said, waiting impatiently for some judgment more generous than the one a bitter Mexican public has handed down.
 
The Swiss Case
American Help Is Slow to Arrive
Within months after the Swiss police found Raul Salinas's bank accounts on a tip from United States drug agents, his case entangled some of Mexico's biggest businessmen, as well as banks in Mexico, the United States, Britain and France. Initially, though, Swiss officials saw nothing remarkable in the notion that a foreign leader's relative might have stashed illicit wealth in their banks.
"I thought it's just a case like any other case," Dr. Roschacher said.
Like the hidden fortunes of Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines or Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, the Salinas accounts presented an opportunity for the embattled Swiss to show that the proceeds of political corruption would no longer be safe in their vaults. There was another incentive as well: whatever part of Raul Salinas's money the Government could convincingly tie to drugs, officials said, it would be able to keep under Swiss law.
In Bern, Dr. Roschacher had three hard-working detectives and the support of Mrs. del Ponte, the plain-spoken Attorney General who has earned a wide reputation for pressing to open up Switzerland's banks. He had little else.
After years of collaboration with American law enforcement agencies, Swiss officials assumed that they could count on their help. Instead, banking and credit card records took months to arrive. Interviews with convicted drug smugglers and other witnesses from United States court cases were sometimes slow to be granted, sometimes postponed and sometimes refused.
By the second half of 1996, with the Swiss under pressure to show progress, tempers began to rise. At one point, officials said, as Mrs. Del Ponte was trying to interview one American-supplied informant in the presence of a fastidious Federal prosecutor from New York, she exploded in anger and later fired off a letter to her counterpart, Attorney General Janet Reno.
"Sometimes we have had difficulties coordinating our procedures," Mrs. del Ponte said euphemistically, emphasizing her gratitude for the American help that eventually arrived. "Of course, when I am over there and the public prosecutor says to me, 'You cannot ask this question,' I am going to get angry."
 
The American Fumble
Distractions For the F.B.I.
In Washington, law enforcement officials had far more investigative resources and more knowledge of the mechanics of Mexican corruption. But they also found themselves struggling to move their sometimes rivalrous agencies and prosecutors in the same direction at the same time.
The rumors that circulated about Raul Salinas during his brother's presidency centered on the notion that he had grown rich from the kickbacks of Mexican businessmen whom he might have helped to win lucrative deals from the Government.
United States drug enforcement, customs and F.B.I. agents also received reports linking him to at least two major Mexican cocaine smugglers.
Drug enforcement officials said the reports were startling, but not enough to merit a special inquiry. That view quickly changed after the discovery of the Swiss accounts, but after some bureaucratic struggle it was the F.B.I.'s office in New York, where Mr. Salinas had also banked, that was finally assigned the investigation.
Bureau officials said the inquiry was important because its targets were high-profile: Mr. Salinas, who had moved tens of millions of dollars through Citibank, and officers in the bank's private-client section, who appeared to have helped him without trying very hard to verify the legitimacy of his funds.
Still, people familiar with the inquiry said it had not been a primary focus of the bureau office, which was soon consumed by its investigation of T.W.A. Flight 800.
"It wasn't a big man-burner," said one former senior official, noting that the inquiry had focused more on the trail of financial transactions rather than on the history of Mr. Salinas's supposed misdeeds. "It was a paper chase."
At offices of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Washington, Mexico and Texas, agents were turning their attention to Mexico's new cocaine kingpin, Amado Carrillo Fuentes. Again, there was a thin record of informants who said Raul Salinas had met with Mr. Carrillo and his associates, received money from the trafficker's operations or helped insure the movement of his loads.
Officials said they knew they would be hard pressed to turn such intelligence information into witnesses who could stand up in court and convincingly accuse the brother of a former Mexican President. But some complained that the greater challenge was navigating the disparate and sometimes competing investigations going on around the United States.
 
The Breakthrough
The Swiss Sleuths Start to Get Lucky
For months after Mrs. del Ponte's confrontation with the New York prosecutor, two officials said, the Swiss authorities' access to American informants all but dried up. They had yet to link Raul Salinas solidly to the drug trade. And the outcry over Swiss handling of the bank accounts of Nazi victims was adding to pressure on the Government to prove its vows of greater openness.
Then, little more than a year into the effort, the investigators' luck began to turn.
"We had a chance to talk to witnesses who knew a lot about what had happened in Mexico," Dr. Roschacher said. "For the first time, they were people who knew things concretely -- 'I was there; I saw that' -- and not by hearsay."
Not long afterward, though, Swiss investigators also began to see the confidentiality of their witnesses start to erode as information leaked to news organizations, particularly in Mexico, raising questions about Mr. Salinas's accusers.
One such witness, officials said, was Marco E. Torres, a Mexican smuggler who pleaded guilty to drug charges in the United States in 1996 and received a reduced sentence for his cooperation.
Two officials familiar with his statements said Mr. Torres had asserted that he had arranged the protection of cocaine shipments with Raul Salinas and paid him one large bribe himself after a drug seizure in Mexico in 1993.
But parts of Mr. Torres's account, including his claim to having known the Salinas brothers for years, were refuted by Mr. Salinas's lawyers after they were first reported last year.
Dr. Roschacher said he was not sidetracked by such particulars.
"As long as no one can say, 'He is a notorious liar -- we have checked and what he says is wrong,' then for us he is a witness and we take a look at him," he said. "Our case is not built on Marco Torres. His credibility is good. But we have several others who are as good or better."
Swiss officials would not identify those other witnesses, saying their names would be disclosed only to judges who will review the matter if, as expected, lawyers for Mr. Salinas challenge the confiscation of his accounts.
But starting in early 1997, for reasons that remain unclear, the spigot of United States assistance opened wider. The Justice Department arranged for Swiss interviews with almost a dozen more witnesses, officials said, including at least three convicted drug smugglers who offered detailed information linking Mr. Salinas to specific payoffs.
Mexican officials also produced records showing that during the last half of his brother's six-year administration, Raul Salinas had made huge deposits in Mexican banks.
In an interview, Mrs. del Ponte said the evidence made it clear that he had been "directly involved in receiving money for protecting the shipment of tons of cocaine through Mexico."
 
The Misgivings
Political Pressure? A Nagging Suspicion
Precisely how Mr. Salinas might have arranged such protection -- without ever having worked in law enforcement and having left the Government altogether in 1992 -- was a question that law enforcement officials struggled to answer.
Mexican investigators said they had focused closely on a relationship between Raul Salinas and one of his closest business associates, Justo Ceja, who served as Carlos Salinas's private secretary and is a fugitive from charges that he illegally amassed a large fortune while in the Government.
Raul Salinas's accountant was arrested in mid-July on similar charges, and Mr. Salinas's wife was sentenced to two years' imprisonment for putting pressure on witnesses to lie in the murder proceedings against her husband.
Investigators said they had also determined that Mr. Salinas and Mr. Ceja had had dealings with several senior Mexican law enforcement officials, each of whom has since been accused publicly of taking bribes. But the only one of those former officials to ever be charged with drug offenses, Mario Ruiz Massieu, has shown little promise as a Government witness.
United States officials said drug enforcement agents in Mexico City, Houston and El Paso who had tried to build their own case against Mr. Salinas had found several informants by the spring of last year who had told of drug payoffs that Raul Salinas had supposedly received. Two of those witnesses, in particular, gave detailed accounts of having seen Mr. Salinas meeting with major drug traffickers.
The two most important informants were taken from Mexico to Texas, officials said, where they submitted to lie-detector tests and appeared at first to be telling the truth. But under what agents described as unusual high-level pressure to recheck the men's stories, they were given further tests, in which they appeared to be less candid. In May 1997, officials said, the United States Attorney in San Antonio abandoned the case.
"We knew there was an enormous political component to the case," said one former law enforcement official who worked on it. "But the Justice Department, without ever saying so, appeared not to want us to deal with the political targets. They wanted us just to concentrate on the drug traffickers."
Similar questions have been raised since the announcement in April by Citibank's parent company, Citicorp, that it will merge with Travelers Group Inc. -- a $70 billion corporate marriage that could conceivably snag if the bank is ensnared in a major money-laundering case.
Justice Department officials declined to discuss the Salinas investigation in detail. But they denied that their problems in making a case had anything to do with political or foreign policy concerns.
Still more doubts about Washington's coordination of the Salinas case were raised by two other key witnesses, a Chilean-born computer expert named Guillermo Pallomari and a Colombian cocaine trafficker named Jose Manuel Ramos.
Mr. Pallomari, a former aide to the main boss of the Cali cocaine cartel, Miguel Rodriguez Orejuela, fled Colombia in August 1995 after threats on his life and was interviewed by American drug enforcement agents for nearly three months.
But officials familiar with the debriefings said he had never been asked in detail how the Colombians had protected their shipments through Mexico, and some officials were stunned to learn what Mr. Pallomari, now a protected witness, told the Swiss last Nov. 19 at a Federal prison in southern Virginia where American officials took him to be debriefed.
According to officials familiar with his debriefings and a partial transcript of his statement recently published in the Mexican newspaper El Universal, Mr. Pallomari said the Colombians began to strengthen their partnership with Mr. Carrillo, the Mexican trafficker, about 1992, after problems with their operations in the Caribbean.
Mr. Rodriguez Orejuela also tried to replicate in Mexico the network of political protection he had established in Colombia, Mr. Pallomari said.
To that end, the informant said, Cali bosses drafted a manual on political corruption and sent a copy to Mr. Carrillo. They also funneled some $80 million in bribe money to Mexico -- about half of which was supposed to have gone to Raul Salinas to assure the compliance of his brother's administration, Mr. Pallomari said.
He said the money had been sent with cocaine loads, deposited with front companies or paid through a Bolivian intermediary whom the Colombians had stationed in Mexico. On one occasion, he said, Raul Salinas intervened at the Colombians' request to get back most of a five-ton cocaine load that the police had seized in Acapulco in early 1994 with American help.
Mr. Pallomari also showed the Swiss how payments to Mexican politicians were reflected in a partial set of 1994 accounting ledgers that were seized from the Cali cartel by an elite Colombian police unit in 1995.
Officials said Mr. Pallomari's story had some inconsistencies, but they did not question that it might have been vital to the drug enforcement agents in Texas who were then trying to tie Mr. Salinas to Mr. Carrillo's enterprise.
In the end, those agents did not learn even the outlines of Mr. Pallomari's account until a year and a half after he came under United States protection. When law enforcement officials from around the country caucused in El Paso in January 1997 to assemble the available evidence against Mr. Carrillo's organization, officials said, Mr. Pallomari's information was about the best they had against Mr. Salinas.
But Mr. Pallomari was unavailable. Federal prosecutors in Miami said they could not lend their witness until they had finished their own case against the Cali gang. Long before they did, the drug conspiracy case that might have linked Mr. Salinas to Mr. Carrillo collapsed when the trafficker died after plastic surgery last July.
United States prosecutors were apparently even less successful in coordinating the information offered by Mr. Ramos, a former lieutenant to the Colombian drug cartel based in the city of Medellin.
Two people familiar with Mr. Ramos's case said he approached prosecutors in Houston in 1991, the year he was sentenced on drug charges to two life terms in prison. He met Raul Salinas in the late 1980's, he told them, and contracted with him to arrange and protect the landing of drug planes in different parts of northern Mexico.
One American official said doubts lingered about part of Mr. Ramos's account, and his credibility was challenged by a Federal prosecutor who doubted that he had been forthright about another Colombian drug operation that had been discovered in Texas.
But Mr. Ramos offered unusual documentation to corroborate his claims: encoded payment ledgers, photographs and even a special Mexican passport that he had received under the carefully chosen alias Alejandro Salinas.
Still, two people familiar with the case said Mr. Ramos was all but ignored until late 1997, when the United States Customs Service arranged for him to be interviewed by a Federal prosecutor in New York and then by the Swiss authorities. "He knocked on the door several times," one of those people said. "He was rebuffed each and every time."

HEADLINE: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Dr. Peter S. Raven;
Through Politicking for Plants, He Made His Garden Grow

BYLINE: By NANCY BETH JACKSON 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
Peter S. Raven jumps up from the conference table at midsentence and disappears out the door, returning loaded down with a stack of fat books. He picks up the conversation as though he never left.
"These are my babies," he says, patting the latest volumes in "The Flora of China" and "The Flora of North America" series chronicling "survivors and new species." 
 While Dr. Raven, botanist, evolutionary biologist and director of the Missouri Botanical Garden, has not been out there picking all the daisies himself, his "biopoliticking" and networking lurk behind the collaborative projects to catalogue and understand plants all over the world.
The same biopoliticking behind the "Flora" series surfaced last month with the announcement that the Missouri Botanical Garden, Washington University, the University of Missouri and Monsanto Company would be partners in a new $146 million Donald Danforth Plant Science Center.
Supporters say it will be the largest plant science center in the world and turn St. Louis -- already renowned among botanists because of the garden -- into an agricultural Silicon Valley when it opens in 2000.
"I specialize in networking," Dr. Raven said. "There is an enormous kind of pleasure in working with people, helping them to realize what they want to do. I like to link people." Jonathan Kleinbard, a former University of Chicago vice president who recently became the garden's deputy director, said his boss "likes to have 27 balls in the air."
Indeed.
Since 1971, when he left an associate professorship at Stanford University with no more administrative experience than "part-time access" to a secretary, Dr. Raven has turned a rather scruffy patch of real estate in a decaying urban neighborhood into an international center of biodiversity research and activism, a community magnet and one of the nation's largest herbariums.
And, he quickly added, the fastest expanding collection in the world, with 120,000 specimens added each year and at least a dozen staff taxonomists collecting somewhere in the world at any given time.
When Dr. Raven arrived at the garden as a 35-year-old Californian with no particular plan in mind, he found 85 employees and a budget of $650,000. Today, he directs a staff of 354, including 55 researchers with Ph.D.'s, and oversees a budget of $20 million. The New York Botanical Garden, by comparison, has a staff of about 100, including 30 Ph.D.'s. Recently, the Missouri garden opened an $8.6 million research center, housing a 122,000-volume library, nearly five million herbarium specimens and the TROPICOS database -- http://mobot.mobot.org/Pick/Search/pick.html, which averages over a million hits a month.
Known locally as Shaw's Garden, the place was created in 1859 by Henry Shaw, a major landowner who made his fortune selling goods to traders and pioneers headed west.
An amateur botanist, Shaw worked with George Engleman, a physician and botanist, to create a center for education, research and horticultural display. Shaw also endowed a school of botany at Washington University, a link between garden and university that continues today with the director holding a tenured seat on the faculty, teaching graduate students.
By the early 20's, the garden had built a national reputation for research and training, but by the time Dr. Raven arrived it was, as he describes it, "like an art museum with exhibits only in a few rooms."
Only 10 acres were laid out in gardens -- most of the 79 acres Henry Shaw had set aside still looked like the treeless prairie it once was. Dr. Raven set to work not only gardening but also building support.
A 1982 election gave the garden access to property tax revenues, which now make up 28.9 percent of the budget. An additional 30.4 percent comes from contributions, bequests and memberships, now over 30,000.
Over 250,000 people visit the garden each year, wandering through the living rain forest, feeding giant carp in the Japanese Garden, strolling through the Victorian Garden or the Rock Garden or the English Woodland Garden or simply admiring sculpture by Alexander Calder, Henry Moore, Carl Milles or Frank Stella. Gardeners get tips; jazz and gospel fans come to concerts. Children troop through on class outings.
Dr. Raven never misses a chance to get people involved -- in St. Louis and beyond.
But unlike Candide, he is not content to cultivate his own garden. He travels the world -- Washington, Australia, India, China, the Vatican are ticketed these days -- not to collect plants but to stir others to action, build human networks and promote biodiversity in the face of development. He makes speeches, lobbies politicians and corporate leaders, puts scientists together with research projects.
Locally, he has been grand marshal of the Veiled Prophet Parade, a St. Louis institution for some 120 years, and served on the University of Missouri board of curators. When he was inducted into the St. Louis Walk of Fame two years ago, he joined Henry Shaw, Ulysses S. Grant, Josephine Baker, Stan Musial as famous folk with roots or other important links to St. Louis.
And if there is any doubt of his local commitment, Dr. Raven says "Missour-ah," not "Missour-ee."
On the national level he is home secretary of the National Academy of Sciences, chairman of the report review committee of the National Research Council, member of the committee for research and exploration of the National Geographic Society. He also serves on the President's Committee of Advisers on Science and Technology and this year chaired a While House panel on environmental and economic strategies.
Dr. Raven has been a National Science Foundation fellow, a Guggenheim Fellow, a MacArthur Fellow, headed the Botanical Society of America, the Society for the Study of Evolution, the American Society of Naturalists, the American Institute of Biological Sciences and then some. He has written 18 books and more than 450 articles.
"I have the type of personality that likes to be interrupted constantly," he said. "I like a lot of things in play. I get rejuvenated by noise and interruptions and have a great power of recall."
Dr. Raven, born in Shanghai in 1936 into a family of American bankers, counts as ancestors Mayflower pilgrims and a British Redcoat, but the strongest DNA may come from his maternal grandfather's grandfather: Patrick Breen, who arrived in California in 1847 after spending the winter snowbound with the Donner Party in the Sierra Nevadas. Of the 87 pioneers, only 46 survived, including all 9 of the Breens.
Now, at 62, Dr. Raven is doing what he began doing at age 6: exploring nature. An only child, he read a book on insects when he was sick in bed and then began growing caterpillars into butterflies. That led to exploring vacant lots around San Francisco in search of plant specimens. At 8, he became the youngest member of the California Academy of Sciences.
By 10, he was comparing field notes with Alice Eastwood, the grand old lady of California botany, then 90. At 12, he joined the Sierra Club and ended up sharing a tent with Ledyard Stebbins, who has been called one of the foremost plant evolutionary biologists of the century. At 16, he discovered a Clarkia franciscana, a member of the evening primrose, which had not been seen in Marin County since 1900; a subspecies, Ravenii, was later named in his honor.
Hardly surprising, he chose academic studies in botany, graduating Phi Beta Kappa from the University of California at Berkeley and obtaining a Ph.D. from the University of California at Los Angeles. He was networking even then.
"As a graduate student," he said, "I had 15 other graduate students working on the evening primrose. They said I was the only graduate student to have graduate students."
At Stanford, after a postdoctoral fellowship, he began looking beyond botany toward evolution and biodiversity. He and a colleague, Dr. Paul Ehrlich, came up with a theory of co-evolution, a process in which species change as the species they interact with change. But they also became increasingly worried about what was going on in the world.
"We began thinking about population," Dr. Raven said. "In the late 60's, we became concerned about plant extinction. We began to put it all together. The real problem was that the kinds of things we liked to study were disappearing."
And he started worrying about how many more species were disappearing than being created and about what was happening to the rain forest before botanists had even started to find out what was there.
Ticktock, ticktock. At the Garden's Climatron, a flashing electronic bank counts down the disappearing acres of rain forest. Dr. Raven also frets about topsoil, the ozone layer, skin cancer, cutting down forests without replacing them, industrial wastes, global warming. His warnings often have him labeled a pessimist.
"The 1990's and the first few decades of the 21st century are likely to be the most tumultuous and destructive of the natural resources of our planet that we may ever face," he has written.
"We can either decide to be conservative in dealing with biodiversity -- such species are of such fundamental importance to us, and their loss is absolute and irreversible -- or we can recklessly conclude, despite all the evidence to the contrary, that what we are destroying is not important to us."
But not everyone likes the strategies he chooses to save ecological systems. He bets on multinationals.
"The way I see it," Dr. Raven said, "multinational corporations are one of the best vehicles to achieve global sustainability. Unlike governments, which can pretend there is no global warming because they can live from election to election, the corporations can't live in fantasy. They have to return value to shareholders."
He and the garden have been criticized by various groups for working with corporations, particularly Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis. The garden's new research center is named the Monsanto Center and Monsanto is a major donor in the new plant science center, which will explore genetic engineering, leading to commercial applications.
Dr. Raven dismissed such criticism as he spewed out numbers of things that were disappearing. A man with a cause, he can wear out board directors, committee members, politicians, academics and critics with his enthusiasm.
Now he is after Pope John Paul II. Dr. Raven will be going to Rome three times in the next six months in an effort to persuade the Pope to join his crusade, and he plans to push hard for the concept of "sustainability," or preservation of the earth's resources.
"If I can get the Pope to put sustainability higher on his agenda, present it as a world problem," Dr. Raven said as though talking to himself, "then I would be very successful and happy."

HEADLINE: Russia Needs True Reform, Not Higher Taxes

BYLINE: By Michael McFaul; Michael McFaul is a professor of political science at Stanford University, a fellow at the Hoover Institution and a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment.

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
Russia's Government has come up with a new cure for the country's economic ills: higher taxes. A chorus of Western officials, including International Monetary Fund bureaucrats and Vice President Al Gore during his trip to Moscow last month, have praised the Government's new financial plan, which includes big tax increases, as important steps to advance reform.
The problem with this prescription is that the Russian economy produces very little to tax. Russia does need a more rationalized tax code, which might help collect revenue from a handful of oil and gas companies that do generate profits. But the vast majority of Russian companies are bankrupt and have been operating at a loss for several years. 
 Neither the $22.6 billion I.M.F. bailout nor the Yeltsin Government's so-called anti-crisis program addresses this deeper cause of Russia's economic problems: poorly defined property rights and the consequent dearth of profit-making companies.
In 1992, the Russian Government began an ambitious effort to privatize most of the economy. Two years later, Russia (and its Western advisers) trumpeted the program's success as more than 100,000 enterprises were declared to be in private hands.
While speedy, this privatization program did not produce effective owners or profitable enterprises. Instead, insiders -- that is, Soviet-era enterprise directors in cahoots with trade union officials loyal to them -- gained controlling shares at three-quarters of all large enterprises. These insider owners were interested first and foremost in securing control of their companies and thereby maintaining their jobs. Attracting investment or expanding market share were distant, secondary concerns.
Because these directors do not report to outside shareholders interested in profits, they have avoided pressure to become more efficient, to downsize and improve their products. Through complex arbitrage schemes, delays in paying workers and the stripping of assets, these directors can amass individual wealth while their companies continue to operate in the red.
Under market conditions, the companies would be forced into bankruptcy. Their assets would be reorganized and auctioned off, and either new owners interested in making profits would assume control or the enterprises would be shut down. In Russia, however, bankruptcies rarely occur. Instead, the state has continued to subsidize ailing companies, initially through direct state transfers and now by allowing these companies to not pay taxes or bills owed to other enterprises.
Given these conditions at the grass roots, the Russian Government's plan to raise revenue will not have any sustainable effect. No matter what the tax rate, you cannot generate revenue by taxing bankrupt businesses. Collecting taxes from the handful of companies that do generate profits is a necessary but only short-term solution. After all, most of these profit-making companies are owed huge sums from the same Government-supported, bankrupt enterprises.
At some point, the Russian state must break this vicious cycle by enforcing bankruptcy procedures as the first step toward restructuring enterprises, establishing real property rights and ultimately finding new, more responsible owners for the country's industries. The new owners, it must be remembered, will invest only under the right conditions, which include lower interest rates, state protection of their property and lower -- not higher -- taxes.
Those with a stake in the status quo are quick to warn that an embrace of a real free market risks creating more pain for the people and igniting social unrest. When companies are allowed to go bankrupt, workers lose their jobs.
But in contrast to Russia's first attempt at privatization, this next attempt should not be undertaken at all enterprises simultaneously. By moving more methodically, the Government can build a case that bankruptcy is necessary to clear away growth-stifling debt and to make companies more productive.
Here is where Western assistance can be most useful. Instead of allowing the Government to keep bankrupt companies afloat, Western money can help construct a social safety net so that Russian companies get out of the welfare business. Without this fundamental shift, enterprise directors will continue to blackmail the state by threatening mass layoffs of workers, and the workers will continue at their jobs even if they are only sporadically paid. And investors will keep their money elsewhere.
Areal social safety net in Russia would be expensive, but would it be any more expensive than the current I.M.F. bailout? Twenty-two billion dollars would pay for a lot of unemployment checks and job retraining programs.
Carrying out these reforms would take years, if not decades. And they can occur only if the I.M.F. remains engaged in Russia for the long haul.
But Western assistance should continue only if the Russian Government is committed to allowing real private control of its industries. The consequence of continuing to subsidize bankrupt enterprises will only be even more expensive bailouts down the road -- no matter how high the tax rate climbs.

HEADLINE: TEST KITCHEN;
Lemon Zesters, From Cruel to Cool

BYLINE: By Amanda Hesser 

 BODY:
THE lemon zester has a handy, if a bit esoteric, function. When its head is pressed against the skin of a lemon or other citrus fruit and dragged along the contours, it strips fine curly strands of rind.
Lemon zest is filled with essential flavoring oils that infuse dishes with the fruit's evocative essence. It can be added either whole or finely chopped to everything from marinades to cake batter. 
 A sharp, precise zester -- a straight-handled tool with a flat metal head rimmed with five holes -- will produce strips about an inch or two long and a millimeter or so wide. The strips should be neither so deep that they cut into the pith, which is bitter, nor so shallow that they merely skim off the top layer of skin.
Most zesters work, but few shine. J. A. Henckels makes various models, including one that sells for as much as $12 at Zabar's, 2245 Broadway (80th Street); (212) 787-2000. But a less expensive model, in the company's International Gourmet series, works much better. The head is angled so that the holes dig into the lemon skin, making uniform strands of zest. The zester is sold at Lechters stores for $5.99.
Econome, a French brand, has a zester that is absolutely cruel to the hand, with a hard plastic handle that was designed with no apparent regard for ergonomics. The zester is sharp and effective, but not without a good amount of elbow grease. It is $8.50 at Williams-Sonoma stores.
Until Oxo came along, it seems little attention was paid to comfort. The company, whose kitchen equipment is known for its black rubber, ergonomically correct handles, has two zester models, which outshone nine others I tested. They not only worked superbly but were also comfortable enough that if you had to zest a bucket of lemons, you could.
Oxo's original model -- sold at the Vinegar Factory, 431 East 91st Street, (212) 987-0885, for $4.99 -- has a fat straight black rubber handle, with a wide zester head. The stainless steel head is a little long, giving you less control, but it zests almost flawlessly.
Oxo hired Smart Design, a Manhattan company, to come up with its latest zester model, which will be available in September. Tim Kennedy, the head of the design team, said that the designers bought as many models as they could find and tested them to see their faults. Most zester blades, he found, were too flexible, hampering their ability to grip the fruit, and the handles were too small and thin to fit comfortably in the hand for long-term use.
For the new zester, the designers used a high-grade stainless steel for the head and created a short, rounded handle that rests snugly in the palm. They placed an indent where the handle meets the head, so that the index finger can rest there when pressure is applied to the lemon. The head is also short, so that the hand is close to the lemon, giving the user more control. It will cost about $5.99. For orders or information on retailers: (800) 545-4411.
Many zesters, including the two Oxos and one made by Hoffritz, are equipped with a stripper, which removes a single, wider strip of peel. If you drink martinis with a twist, you know the dimensions well. (It is, in fact, the only good use I know of for a stripper.) The strip is about two inches long and one-eighth inch wide.
A stripper is either a thin circle, like an eyelet, on the side of the zester head, or a pointed wedge pressed into the center of the zester head. Unfortunately, both designs are often positioned so that only right-handed people can use them; for everyone, eyelet strippers generally work more easily.
There is an alternative to buying a zester: wide flat strips of peel can be removed with a vegetable peeler and then cut into thinner strips. But it takes longer and fails to open up as many of the oily cells as a good-quality zester does.

GRAPHIC: Photo: READY FOR WORK -- From left: lemon zesters by Oxo (original model, far left, and new model), Hoffritz, Econome and the J. A. Henckels International Gourmet line. (David Corio for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
The Art of Film, via Brat and Brooder

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
If you had to boil down the personalities of the filmmakers Lars von Trier and Krzysztof Kieslowski into snappy cliches, Mr. von Trier might be described as a mischievous spoiled brat and Kieslowski (who died in 1996) as a gloomy neurotic fatalist. At least that is how these distinguished international directors appear in two short documentary portraits that opened today at the Film Forum as a double bill.
Both Stig Bjorkman's "Tranceformer: A Portrait of Lars von Trier," and Krzysztof Wierzbicki's "Krzysztof Kieslowski: I'm So-So," cut back and forth between interviews with their subjects and snippets of their films in hurried, only partly successful attempts to relate what they say about themselves to the images in their films. Both subjects appear wary of being interviewed. But once they start talking, both take an almost exhibitionistic pleasure in making extreme statements. 
 In the opening moments of "Tranceformer," Mr. von Trier, who exudes a Mephistophelean playfulness, announces cheekily that everything that's been written about him is a lie. "My whole life is a fabrication," he insists. He goes on to complain about his overly permissive upbringing by Communist-sympathizing Danish Jews whom he describes as "radical middle-class academics." His contempt for his upbringing is exemplified by the story of his mother, who returned from a visit to Yugoslavia exalting it as "the ideal society." The director then points to the country's subsequent disintegration to show how deluded she was.
As an adult, he is besieged with phobias that disappear only when he is immersed in work. Reflecting on the medium of film, he describes it as a "startlingly artificial product" that is paradoxically still capable of revealing some truth. The theme he is most interested in exploring, he says, is evil. And an actor in Mr. von Trier's acclaimed television serial, "The Kingdom," declares that the series is essentially the filmmaker's vision of the world as hell. At the end of the film, Mr. von Trier tells a story about having seen a U.F.O. as a child, then announces it is a lie. By this time, it's clear he's a more serious artist than he would like to let on.
Where Mr. von Trier is indefatigably puckish, Kieslowski conveys the sadness of a world-weary sage. The movie opens with frivolous evaluations of the Polish filmmaker by a graphologist, a clairvoyant, a psychotherapist and a priest, among other observers. But once the interview begins in earnest, Kieslowski emerges as a brooding intellectual and habitual pessimist who believes his social status is much higher than he deserves. When he visited the United States, he recalls, he was amazed at "the pursuit of empty talk combined with a very high degree of self-satisfaction."
Kieslowski seems incapable of self-satisfaction, and when the idea is put forth that he could be a political force in Poland, he insists he wouldn't want the responsibility. Brought up Roman Catholic in hard times, he has retained what he calls a "personal and private" relationship with God. But more than religion, what apparently shaped Kieslowski's cinematic vision was the experience of growing up in an economically depressed Communist country where freedom of speech was suppressed. The movie's most striking image is a montage from an early Kieslowski film of the grim, wizened, despairing faces of residents of Lodz.
"I have one good characteristic," he says without irony. "I am a pessimist. I always imagine the worst. To me the future is a black hole."
A year after uttering these words, Kieslowski was dead.

HEADLINE: The Politics of Poverty

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Nadine Gordimer ("Dare to Dream of Eradicating Poverty," Op-Ed, Aug. 1) gives a useful list of development goals for the next decade, namely, providing food, shelter, work and training for those in need. But she omits one of the most important prerequisites for eradicating poverty: the necessity for political empowerment of the poor. 
 With economic inequality increasing, foreign aid budgets falling, unpaid United Nations dues piling up and developing countries becoming increasingly marginalized in institutions like the World Trade Organization and the International Monetary Fund, there are few practical grounds for believing that the United Nations' Decade for the Eradication of Poverty will be any more successful than the United Nations' Development Decades, the fourth of which closes in 2000.
 
PAUL DE SA
Cambridge, Mass., Aug. 3, 1998
 
The writer is a research fellow at the Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard University.

HEADLINE: U.S. Privatization Move Threatens Agreement to Buy Enriched Uranium From Russia

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
A $12 billion deal to turn surplus bomb uranium in Russia into fuel for American nuclear power plants is threatened by recent moves that will cut uranium prices and give Russia less revenue.
The governmental agreement, drawn up in 1992, was intended to prevent Russia's highly enriched uranium, the fuel for the simplest nuclear bomb, from falling into the wrong hands and to provide hard currency to the cash-starved Russian Government. 
 It called for the United States to buy 500 tons of highly enriched uranium from 1995 to 2005, enough to supply tens of thousands of nuclear bombs. The United States was to have diluted the uranium, sold it to civilian power plants and given the Russians ordinary uranium in exchange.
In addition the Russians assumed that they would receive $8 billion for the enriched uranium and $4 billion by selling the ordinary uranium over 20 years.
By Jan. 1, 1998 the United States had taken delivery of 36 tons of uranium.
But the agreement has hit a snag. Last month the United States sold the Federal uranium-processing operation that is supposed to do much of the work for the deal with Russia.
And that company, the United States Enrichment Corporation, is planning to sell off a great deal of its own uranium, more than 70 million pounds.
That is certain to lower uranium prices, possibly to half of what the Russians were expecting, market analysts said.
The Russians are crying foul, and they are casting doubt on a variety of aspects of Russian-American nuclear cooperation.
"The transfer of the 78 million pounds of uranium to the enrichment corporation was a huge mistake," Pete V. Domenici, the Republican of New Mexico who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said. "The ripple effects of that decision will probably result in a national security issue of high importance."
Administration officials concede that lower prices are quite likely and that the uranium that Russia wants to sell will be worth less. But the officials add that they do not believe that the changes will scuttle the deal.
"Russia's fundamental economic interest is to continue to carry out the agreement," said a White House official who insisted on anonymity, because Russia would still earn money from the enriched uranium and would be able to sell the natural uranium.
Even if the Russians cannot sell all the natural uranium they want at desirable prices, "our judgment is they will follow that fundamental economic interest," the official said. He predicted that Russia would continue with the part of the deal that requires it to blend down the bomb-grade material.
But the official conceded that "there may very well need to be further negotiations."
In Moscow, Atomic Energy Minister Yevgeny Adamov, was less sanguine. In a letter to Mr. Domenici he said the prospects for the agreement were "dramatically deteriorating."
The privatization, he wrote, "constitutes deviation of the U.S. party from the implementation of agreed provisions."
He said the move made it harder for him to win approval for strategic-arms agreements and for American participation in projects to secure nuclear materials in Russia.
Another Administration official in Washington suggested that the complaints by the private uranium companies might simply be an effort to obtain the material from the Russians more cheaply.
Maj. Gen. William F. Burns, the former director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency who negotiated the original deal, said the accord was threatened now.
"Right now," General Burns said, "it seems that we have our priorities mixed up, and we've allowed a commercial good to overcome a national security goal, and I think that's wrong."
The deal is a multistep arrangement in which the Russians are selling a service, the enrichment, to the enrichment corporation and are seeking to sell a commodity, the uranium itself, to a group of international uranium companies.
The Federal Government wants to pay to buy the enrichment, but not the uranium itself, a little like paying for the value of cleaning and pressing a shirt, but not the shirt.
Uranium as found in nature is a mixture of two types, and separating them to obtain the fissionable material most useful in bombs and reactors is called enrichment. Less than 1 percent of the natural mix is uranium 235, which is fissionable. Bomb-grade uranium is more than 90 percent uranium 235.
After having painstakingly concentrated the uranium 235 over the years, the Russians have agreed to dilute it to 5 percent, the mixture that power plants use.
With United States help, the Russians lined up three Western companies to buy the ordinary uranium. But when the companies saw the enrichment corporation's plans to sell more uranium, they grew nervous.
The chairman of one company, Bernard M. Michel, of the Cameco Corporation of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, said his company would be agreeing to buy the uranium at a time when the price was all but certain to decline.
Cameco and the other two companies, Nukem G.m.b.H., part of the RWE A.G. Group, the huge German utility in Essen, and the Cogema Group of Velizy, France, which is 86 percent owned by the French Government, had agreed to pay $34 a kilogram, even as the market price has already declined to $28, Mr. Michel said.
The Russian Duma agreed to that deal on July 17. But Cameco withdrew, and a Cogema official said that a decision by the enrichment corporation to sell the uranium now could make the sale of the Russian uranium "extremely difficult, if not impossible."
Behind the problems are the woes of the nuclear industry. The number of American reactors is declining, and the figure may drop faster with utility deregulation. Worldwide, few reactors are being built.
The demand for uranium remains fairly constant. Companies do not, for example, go out and build reactors because the price of fuel has fallen, and most utilities use long-term supply contracts. Market analysts say that means that the enrichment corporation's decision to add uranium to the world supply would be certain to depress prices.
Another issue is how much the Enrichment Corporation will sell. Administration officials argue that it will not flood the market. The president and chief executive officer of the new company, William H. Timbers Jr., wrote on July 21 that "as a public company with fiduciary obligations to its shareholders, USEC can ill afford to unsettle this important market."

HEADLINE: Ernest Dickerman, Defender of the Wilderness, Is Dead at 87

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
Ernest M. Dickerman, who was known by the Sierra Club as "the granddad of the Eastern wilderness" for his efforts to persuade people to defend their forests and wilderness from the power saws and bulldozers of loggers, developers, road builders and other commercial interests, committed suicide late Friday or early Saturday at his cabin in the mountains of Buffalo Gap, Va. He was 87.
He was found under a cherry tree behind his cabin, having shot himself, the sheriff's office reported. In a note to his family, Mr. Dickerman said he took his own life as he had long planned to do after the infirmities of age left him unable to "master my own fate in the wilds of this wild country." 
 Mr. Dickerman was a well-known lobbyist for the Wilderness Society, president of the Smoky Mountains Hiking Club and a leader of campaigns that led to the designation of protected wildlife status for more than 100 million acres in the United States, beginning in 1964. For several decades he was in the forefront of efforts to hold down development in the national parks, forests and designated wild lands. Among his accomplishments was the halting of proposed oil drilling that he said threatened the scenic highlands of Laurel Park in the George Washington National Forest in Virginia.
Brock Evans, former vice president for national issues of the Audubon Society, said, "The only way the environmental movement ever gets anything accomplished is through endless pressure, endlessly applied. And that was Ernie Dickerman -- always writing letters or making calls."
Mr. Dickerman, by all accounts, was a tireless hiker who was said to have had a compass in his head. He never used trails or trail maps, often carried the backpacks of less hardy companions and plunged onward through the wild and up the sides of mountains to what he regarded as a greater glory. On one of his climbs to the summit of Mount LeConte in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park in Tennessee and North Carolina, he said, "This is what I was looking for on this planet," and instead of planting a flag he did a handstand at the top.
Ernest Miller Dickerman was born on Dec. 22, 1910, in Chicago. His father, Judson C. Dickerman, was a civil engineer with the Federal Power Commission in Washington. His mother died when he was 5, and he and his brother, Charles, were taken care of at home by their sister, Virginia, who was 11, and were then sent to boarding schools. Mr. Dickerman graduated from Gettysburg Academy in Gettysburg, Pa., and then from Oberlin College in 1931.
He loved the outdoors from an early age and went to work for the Tennessee Valley Authority in Knoxville in 1933, a job in which he hiked or biked or canoed around the poor villages of Tennessee, telling people what it was going to be like for them when they got electricity and trying to figure out where to put the power lines. He left after four years and went to work in a button factory in Knoxville.
Soon after, he joined the Smoky Mountains Hiking Club, which was formed to help preserve the natural woodlands and successfully pushed for three national parks, the Smokies, the Shenandoah Valley in Virginia and Mammoth Cave in Kentucky. He monitored the Government's management and development of the Smokies, fighting several battles on those issues with the National Park Service.
"Fortunately the service decided that there would be no commercial development, but it was unfortunate that the Civilian Conservation Corps was allowed to put in a dozen camps," Mr. Dickerman said. "The C.C.C. was one of the best things any government ever did anywhere but they overdid it in the Smokies. They built endless numbers of fire roads up every big hollow, and too damn many automobile camps, and 650 miles of park trails. Guys like me considered them another form of devastation."
Mr. Dickerman served in England and France with an Army chemical warfare unit in World War II. After the war, he found that, "where the Forest Service had been adding wild lands to its system, lands were now being removed."
"World War II technology made rough-terrain vehicles a reality," he continued, "and wilderness areas once thought inaccessible could now be logged at a profit."
A crisis arose in the mid-1950's for Mr. Dickerman and other conservationists when the Federal Bureau of Reclamation announced a plan to build a dam in Echo Park in the Dinosaur National Monument on the Utah-Colorado border. With the Wilderness Society and the Sierra Club leading the way, the conservationist groups, acting in concert for one of the first times, blocked the dam and persuaded Congress to pass the Wilderness Act in 1964 to provide permanent protection from development for wilderness areas.
Two years later, when George B. Hartzog Jr., then director of the Park Service, announced a plan to build a second highway through the Smokies, Mr. Dickerman quit his job at the button factory and joined the staff of the Wilderness Society as a full-time organizer. He traveled the country giving speeches and organizing hikes against the highway, and the resulting overwhelming public opposition killed the project.
After he retired from the Wilderness Society in 1976, Mr. Dickerman was given a number of awards from the Sierra Club and other groups for his work in conservation and environmental protection. But he did not slow down. He worked for years at promoting conservation from his cabin on the farm of a nephew, C. Robert Dickerman, his only survivor.
As he approached his 90's, the phone in his cabin often rang with calls from young conservationists seeking advice on how to overcome opposition.
"You have to keep right on pointing out how important it is to preserve the wild country," Mr. Dickerman told them. "There is always a lot of opposition to wilderness. People are always a lot more interested in the short-term economic benefits rather than the long-term quality-of-life issues."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Lower Income Taxes Proposed in Japan

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan proposed lowering the nation's income tax rates across the board today and said tax cuts for next year could exceed $41.7 billion, the amount Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi has pledged.
Mr. Miyazawa spoke to reporters after a meeting today with important members of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's tax panel. 
 "We are not considering any measures that will lead to a tax increase" for some individuals or businesses for now, Mr. Miyazawa said, indicating that a tax overhaul later might lead to higher taxes for some. "It doesn't make sense if we fail to achieve big tax reductions."
Mr. Miyazawa said he and the Liberal Democratic panel were considering lowering the top income tax rate to 50 percent from 65 percent, and other groups would also get tax reductions based on certain percentages of personal income. Japan currently has five income tax brackets.
Two Liberal Democratic politicians, who are members of the panel, said next year's tax cuts might amount to about 7 trillion yen, including tax breaks for home buyers, which Mr. Obuchi has also pledged.
One of the politicians said the Government planned to adopt different income tax reduction rates for different tax brackets, providing larger cuts for lower income earners. The average income tax rate will probably be 14 percent to 15 percent, the legislator said.
Because legislation authorizing the tax cuts will not be introduced until the next regular session of Parliament, which will convene in January 1999, the reductions will be retroactive to that month, a senior Finance Ministry official said.
Tokyo has been under pressure from the United States and other Asian countries to make permanent tax cuts part of an effort to revive Japan's long-slumping economy.
After taking office last week, MR. Miyazawa pledged to draw up the outline of next year's tax cuts before the Prime Minister made his policy speech to Parliament on Friday.
The Prime Minister has pledged 4 trillion yen in income tax cuts next year, along with 2 trillion yen in corporate tax reductions, in an effort to bolster consumer confidence.
The ministry official said lowering the top income tax rate to 50 percent from 65 percent would cost the Government one trillion yen in revenue.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, arrives at a meeting with important members of the Liberal Democratic Party in Tokyo yesterday. Discussions were held on lowering income tax rates next year. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: G.M. Will Pare as Many as 1,000 White-Collar Jobs

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation announced a sweeping reorganization of its internal distribution structure today that is expected to save $200 million to $300 million a year and eliminate as many as 1,000 white-collar jobs.
The move follows a meeting Monday of G.M.'s board, its first since the auto maker settled a nearly eight-week strike by the United Automobile Workers at two Flint, Mich., parts plants, which over time virtually shut down North American assembly operations. The strike, which cost the company about $3 billion in potential profit, has increased pressure to cut expenses. 
 The revamping of G.M.'s wholesale operation is the second such major move by company management this week. The first was G.M.'s announcement on Monday that it would spin off its huge parts business, Delphi Automotive Systems.
The changes, in the works for a year, create a single organization, rather than one each for the Buick, Cadillac, Chevrolet, Oldsmobile and Pontiac-GMC divisions. The new organization closely resembles that of G.M.'s Saturn Corporation, a separate subsidiary established nearly a decade ago to find new ways to build and sell cars; Saturn will remain outside the new organization.
Under the realignment, the United States will be divided geographically among five market area teams, a concept used by Saturn. The teams will be made up of sales, service, parts and brand marketing people. They will call on G.M. dealers, regardless of which brands they sell. By contrast, representatives from each division have traditionally called on dealers with that franchise. The change is intended to eliminate layers of bureaucracy and the number of people visiting a dealer, since 65 percent of General Motors sales are made by dealers who have more than one G.M. franchise.
"This work is all about getting faster, getting decisions and information flow much closer to customers and dealers, and leveraging G.M.'s size and market power across the whole business, instead of on a divisional basis," said Ronald Zarrella, vice president in charge of G.M.'s North American vehicle sales, service and marketing group, at a news briefing today. Mr. Zarrella, the company's strongest proponent of brand management, said the new structure would also help G.M. better reach customer groups.
In addition, G.M. will institute a pay-for-performance system, a practice unheard of in the automotive business, to reward employees for delivering cars and trucks to the customer through the dealer. Details of the new compensation plan have yet to be worked out, but as much as 25 percent of an employee's pay could be "at risk," Mr. Zarrella said.
"This is the first significant departure from the Alfred P. Sloan structure of G.M. that I can remember," said Frank Ursomarso, president of Union Park Pontiac-GMC in Wilmington, Del., and the National Automobile Dealers Association's G.M. representative, in a phone interview. "It's a step in a positive direction."
Mr. Ursomarso, like Mr. Zarrella, said the customer would not notice the change, although closer information sharing without layers of bureaucracy between the dealer and G.M. should result in the right products being in the dealer's showroom.
"The chances of a customer finding the car or truck he or she wants in a certain color and with certain equipment should theoretically be here," Mr. Ursomarso said. And the dealer should have the opportunity to increase business "and penetrate market share," he said, adding, "I can't do that now with my GMC franchise, for instance, because I can't get the right trucks here because there's no system in place."
Two new positions were created today. Roy S. Roberts, a G.M. vice president and previously general manager of the Pontiac-GMC division, becomes general manager for field sales, service and parts. John G. Middlebrook, also a vice president and formerly Chevrolet general manager, was named general manager-vehicle brand marketing.
G.M.'s other division general manager positions will be eliminated by Jan. 1, 1999, when the revamping is completed. The general managers, previously vice presidents of the corporation, will be replaced with managers without vice president status, addressing criticism that the company is top-heavy with executives.
G.M. expects to realize savings by eliminating up to 20 percent of the 5,000 jobs now in its distribution system, which will be done through retirements and retirement incentives. In addition, the company expects to save money by eliminating duplication and adopting common processes and systems throughout G.M., Mr. Zarrella said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Rwandan Role in Congo Revolt

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Intelligence reports indicate that the Rwandan Government is behind a growing rebellion in Congo, senior American officials said today.
The Government of President Laurent Kabila, installed just over a year ago in Congo with Rwandan help, today accused the Rwandan Government of involvement in the insurgency, a charge Rwanda denied. 
 While American officials were careful not to directly accuse the Rwandan Government of backing the rebellion, they said that Mr. Kabila's failure to control Hutu rebels in eastern Congo was an obvious motive for Rwandan interference.
"Eastern Congo is clearly considered a zone of security by the Rwandans," a senior American official said. "They care about eastern Congo and this wouldn't be the first time they've sent their people in. A year and a half ago when they did it, it resulted in the overthrow" of President Mobutu Sese Seko. "Whether the same dynamic is going on or not, we'll see."
At the same time, American officials did not offer Mr. Kabila any support, a marked contrast to the spring of 1997, when they rallied around him as the best alternative to the corrupt rule of Mr. Mobutu.
In public, American officials said today that evidence is sketchy. "We don't believe that governments should be intervening in the affairs of their neighbors," the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said today.
The Clinton Administration is consulting widely with countries in the region and in Europe, officials said, but for now is simply urging restraint on the parties and watching for further developments.
Officials said the American special envoy for the region, Howard Wolpe, is in Kinshasa and is urging Mr. Kabila to reach out to all Congolese, especially ethnic Tutsi, and guarantee their rights and security in order to hold the country together. "That is the best answer for him," one official said.
Mr. Rubin called Mr. Kabila's rule "a mixed bag," with disappointments in the areas of democratic development, human rights, justice and the economy, noting in particular Mr. Kabila's refusal to cooperate with a United Nations team investigating charges of genocide.
"I'm not prepared to comment on whether we would like to see a change in the Government there -- that's not something we normally do," Mr. Rubin said.
But the United States wants "the Government in Kinshasa to be in a position to control its territory" and "believes strongly in the territorial integrity of the Democratic Republic of the Congo," Mr. Rubin said, noting its strategic location and the risk of renewed violence between the Hutu and Tutsi ethnic groups.
"There are many important countries that border on it, and as goes the Congo, so might go the stability of some of the countries in the region," Mr. Rubin said. "We want to see the people there have a government that can help them thrive and prosper in a democratic way. Those are our objectives."
He called on all sides to "show restraint and resolve these differences in a nonviolent way."
Officials noted that this insurgency began soon after Mr. Kabila expelled the last Rwandan military advisers from the country, which caused Congolese Tutsi "further concerns about their diminishing influence within the Kabila Government," an American official said.
"Depending on what Kabila does with this mounting insurrection in his military, we have to see what the Rwandans do," the official said. "It's up to Kabila to send a reassuring message to the various elements of the society that they can work things out."
Another official said that the Rwandans may not be seeking to overthrow Mr. Kabila, but to give him a warning or to create a buffer zone in eastern Congo.
A White House spokesman, P. J. Crowley, said: "The situation in the Congo is something we are watching very carefully. We are in touch with several governments in the region to assess what is going on there and what we can do to prevent a widening of this situation."
The officials said that the situation in Kinshasa appeared to be calm with some scattered shooting overnight, while traffic was moving nearly normally and the airport is open. Goma is calm, the officials said, but there are reports of continuing clashes in Bukavu and nearby areas of south Kivu.

HEADLINE: Iraqi Rejection Of Scrutiny Brings Rebuke From U.S.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Iraq's decision to go for broke and refuse to discuss any further cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors provoked a warning from the White House today that the action will only insure that Baghdad remains under sanctions indefinitely.
"This once again leaves Iraq further from what Saddam Hussein says his goal is, which is relief from the sanctions," said P. J. Crowley, a White House spokesman. "That can only come when Iraq complies with the resolutions." 
 Russia and France, which have supported Iraq's demand for an early end to sanctions, reacted with concern today to the breakdown of the talks. The Russians, who have served as mediators with Iraq in the past, called for the talks to resume. The French Foreign Ministry expressed exasperation in a statement today that said, "We repeat that good cooperation between Unscom and Iraq is necessary and unavoidable if sanctions imposed by the Security Council are to be lifted."
 The next sanctions review is planned for October, and time is running out for the Iraqis to answer the crucial remaining questions.
Secretary General Kofi Annan, who took some political risk in going to Iraq in February to defuse the last crisis, which drew the United States close to war with Iraq, said today that the latest confrontation "may be a major hiccup, but a hiccup we can overcome, I hope." The accord he reached promised full cooperation from the Iraqis, who have been under a comprehensive embargo since their 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
The American and British position may be bolstered in the short term if Iraq provokes a new crisis at a time when its supporters on the Security Council thought they might be close to relaxing sanctions.
But some experts say that Iraq may be gambling that another confrontation will leave Washington even more isolated in the long run, as calls increase here and in the Middle East for an end to eight years of crippling sanctions that have failed to bring down President Saddam Hussein.
Many diplomats here also seem to accept as a given that President Clinton does not want a showdown with Iraq just before elections in the United States in November.
Richard Butler, the chief inspector, left Iraq early today to return to New York to brief the Security Council on Thursday about the early collapse of the talks. At a stop in Bahrain, he told reporters in somewhat more detail what happened at his meeting on Monday with Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz.
"I offered him a new accelerated schedule of work for the next five weeks in order to try and resolve most of the outstanding issues, mainly in the chemical and missile areas, before our October report to the Security Council," Mr. Butler told Agence France-Presse. Iraq must account for all nuclear, biological, chemical and long-range missile systems before sanctions imposed in 1990 can be lifted.
"Aziz refused to accept the proposal, saying he wasn't ready to continue working with Unscom on these issues," Mr. Butler said, referring to the United Nations Special Commission, which he leads. He said Mr. Aziz had told him that "no more discussion would take place for the present."
On Monday, Mr. Aziz told a news conference in Baghdad that he had only one message for Mr. Butler, who refuses to accept the Iraqi contention that it has no more prohibited weapons or the means to make them. "I asked Butler to go to the Security Council and tell the truth and he refused to do that."
At the Middle East Institute in Washington, Andrew Parasiliti, an Iraq expert, said today that it was now in Iraq's interest to engage in "diplomatic brinkmanship" in dealing with the United Nations.
"One lesson of the November-February situation is that crisis diplomacy works," he said. "There was some political gain from the last crisis. The Iraqis exploited positions within the Security Council, they showed a political sentiment in the Arab world that was in their favor and they got the intervention of the U.N. Secretary General. That's all in the plus political column."
"But since then, it's been a series of negatives," Mr. Parasiliti said, listing a "damning" report from Mr. Butler's commission at the last sanctions review in April, a lack of progress in inspections, a revelation that Iraq had loaded the nerve gas VX in shells and a gloomier than expected report on nuclear programs from the International Atomic Energy Agency.
"There's a belief that because things aren't going their way, they had to take this to the edge diplomatically," Mr. Parasiliti said. "Every time there is high engagement, they raise the stakes."

HEADLINE: Major Measure of Economy Edges Down for a2d Month

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A key gauge of future economic activity slipped in June for the second consecutive month in another sign the economy is no longer sizzling.
The Conference Board reported yesterday that the strikes against the General Motors Corporation, which lasted nearly eight weeks, dragged down its Index of Leading Economic Indicators, but it said it was too early to warn of a recession. 
 "It doesn't mean bad times for the U.S. economy, but we've seen the best," said Allen Sinai, chief global economist of Primark Decision Economics.
The board, a private business research group, reported that its index for June stood at 105, down two-tenths of a percent from May. The fall was in line with economists' expectations.
The measure was off one-tenth of a percent in May. Earlier, the board had reported that the index was unchanged during that month.
The index's double dip was the first since a string of five monthly declines from January through May 1995 that turned out to be a false warning of impending recession.
Analysts said the economy's current slowdown, from its earlier feverish pace, should help keep the Federal Reserve from pushing interest rates up.
"The U.S. economy is downshifting now," Mr. Sinai said.
The June decline was largely caused by an increase in initial claims for state jobless compensation, a result of the United Automobile Workers strikes against G.M., which idled more than 200,000 workers.
"The rise of unemployment claims in June, largely due to a fallout of the since-settled General Motors strike, drove most of the decline in the leading index," said Michael Boldin, a Conference Board economist.
He said other components making up the index were mixed, suggesting that the slowdown measured by other indicators for the second quarter will continue.
Six of the leading index's 10 components fell in June. Other decliners were manufacturers' orders for consumer goods, building permits, stock prices, consumer expectations, and the difference between 10-year bond yields and short-term interest rates.
The leading index is intended to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance.
