HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Land of Homeowners;
Most Israelis Own Houses, but Oh Those Mortgages

BYLINE: By JESSICA STEINBERG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
Julie Zuckerman and Josh Kulp, an American couple who moved to Israel three years ago, did not know what to expect when they shopped for their first mortgage here. What they got was a dizzying education in one of the more complicated home finance systems in the developed world.
Ms. Zuckerman, a vice president of an investment bank, and Mr. Kulp, a teacher of Judaic studies, now own a $212,000 five-bedroom duplex in Modi'in, one of the new towns that has sprung up along the 40-mile highway between Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. But it took three loans, at three interest rates, to make that possible. 
 A bank lent $74,000 at 4.8 percent. To encourage movement to a new town, the Government provided two more loans for another $41,000, charging 4.5 percent for one and 4 percent for the other.
"We had to decide on our mortgage within 20 days because the rates change on a daily basis," said Ms. Zuckerman, who used savings and family loans to come up with the rest of the purchase price. "The whole process was certainly more frustrating than we had expected."
And it may remain so. Ms. Zuckerman does not really know what she and Mr. Kulp will be paying because mortgages here are adjusted annually for inflation, as are salaries.
As baffling and daunting as the mortgage system is, it has nonetheless produced a nation of homeowners. About 73 percent of the country's five million citizens live in privately owned homes, compared with 66 percent in the United States.
Indeed, in Israel, home ownership is a type of pioneerism, the modern-day method of settling the Jewish homeland. Accordingly, the mortgage system has been a tool to foster land development and further other social ends. Children from big families receive larger loans than those from smaller ones, for instance, because their parents have less money to lend them. Ethiopian immigrants receive more than Russian immigrants because most Ethiopians arrive in Israel without any savings.
But now, the creaky mortgage system is at a crossroads, scrambling to find ways to keep pumping out all those new loans to people like Ms. Zuckerman and Mr. Kulp.
A holdover from the early days of statehood, when Israel's socialist nature promised home and hearth for every citizen, the system has had to expand to accommodate an ever more populous and diverse country. It has also had to adjust as that nation has lurched from heavy state control to a free market economy. Israel has nine mortgage banks, with the biggest now in the process of being privatized. Even so, the system remains an amalgam of private and public money.
The banks administer all the loans, including $2 billion a year in mortgages that the Government's Housing Ministry provides. The challenge is continuing the steady flow of $4 billion a year in nongovernment loans, a huge amount of financing for such a small country to generate.
While Israel is now experiencing a mild recession, and it is not uncommon to find new homes going begging for buyers, many in the construction and lending industries fear tight credit. And that means, those in the private sector say, that even as the Government tries to disengage from the mortgage business, there is an important new role for it to play: providing guarantees for a secondary mortgage market.
Such a market would serve as a new lending source by pooling and repackaging mortgage loans as bonds. The idea is for the banks to sell their loans to a quasi-government company, similar to Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac in the United States, which would bundle the mortgages as securities and sell them to institutional investors worldwide, funneling new cash back to the banks for use as new loans.
But despite the Government's traditionally deep role in the mortgage market, officials are balking at providing loan guarantees, which would make the bundled mortgages more attractive to investors.
After a two-year study, a Government committee made up of representatives from the central bank and the Finance and Housing ministries concluded that the capital markets should take responsibility for a secondary mortgage market.
In a report last June to Finance Minister Yaakov Neeman, the panel suggested easing regulations and lowering other barriers to such a market, including removing certain taxes. He is expected to seek approval for the market, but without the Government acting as insurer.
However the battle over a secondary market turns out, the mortgage system's central role in the country's social fabric is not going to change, industry experts say.
Many Israeli borrowers considered eligible for loans here would never stand the test of an American mortgage application, says Doron Nachmani, deputy manager of the Tefahot Israel Mortgage Bank, the largest of the mortgage banks.
Some are young couples who recently completed their army service and are entering college, while others are new Russian immigrants with little experience paying back long-term loans. Then there are the settlers living in politically disputed development towns over the so-called Green Line -- the local term for the border between Israel proper and the territories claimed by both Israel and the Palestinians.
The banks here have instituted their own checklists to determine who is creditworthy. Among other things, borrowers usually present various family members to vouch for them, a system that insures a high payback rate because the borrowers do not want to put their families at risk.
Construction was one of the fastest-growing sectors in the country after the wave of emigration from Russia and suburbanization of Israel in the early 1990's. Immigration has since slowed down, and so has the economy, resulting in an overflow of available homes.
Nonetheless, prices remain high. Mr. Nachmani, who is leading the lobbying for a Government-backed secondary mortgage market, says the Government's minimum mortgage loan of 70,000 shekels, or about $19,000, an amount that was set back in 1992, will not buy much more than a kitchen these days, much less a three-bedroom house.
Mr. Nachmani speaks in fatalistic terms about the long-term health of the lending system, contending that in five years there will be little private-sector money for mortgages.
A picture that is only a little less stark is painted by Boaz Schwartz, a principal of the Tel Aviv branch of Bankers Trust who has been hired as a consultant for Bank Tefahot, another mortgage bank.
"In the near future, mortgage banks will have less obvious resources to borrow from," he said. When the economy picks up, he added, there will be a renewed rush for mortgages and no ready new source for financing them.
The two logical sources are so-called provident funds -- long-term bank savings accounts that are invested in stocks and Government bonds -- and pension funds.
Government regulations sharply restrict the amount of money from provident funds that can be invested in mortgages. And pension funds are not allowed to invest that way.
Given the lack of cash flow into the mortgage banks' coffers, the idea of a secondary mortgage market, insured by the Government, has taken hold in the lending industry.
But Shai Talmon, the Finance Ministry's accountant general and head of the Government committee weighing the issue, is not interested in further involving the Government. He says that Government backing of the secondary market will not solve the long-term financing problem. What is needed, he says, is simply a commitment by the private sector to put up more money.
That is a paradoxical decision, said Menachem Feder, a Tel Aviv lawyer who is advising Bank Tefahot on mortgage securitization.
"Laissez-faire is a nice concept, but curious when the Government already slow-dances with several mortgage programs," he said, referring to the $2 billion in loans that it issues each year. Mr. Feder, a former Wall Street lawyer, welcomes the committee's recommendations to foster private initiative but is concerned about the slowness of change.
"Until that possibly distant day when the private sector will produce a secondary market all by itself," he said, "we're forced into half-baked methods of financing."
Mr. Nachmani and Mr. Schwartz are both annoyed with the committee's decision.
And David Brodet, chairman of the United Mizrahi Bank, Israel's fourth-largest bank and owner of 86 percent of Tefahot, said, "If you're establishing a secondary market, you need the U.S. system of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to give insurance."
For the time being, Bankers Trust, Bank Tefahot and Tefahot's lawyers are designing a simpler system that would allow investors to participate directly in mortgage pools, a riskier method of raising money. Mr. Schwartz would also like to see some more immediate improvements in lending terms, such as increasing the current maximum loan of 60 percent of a property's value to a level closer to the average 80 percent maximum in the United States.
"It's about the ability to borrow in an efficient market," Mr. Schwartz said of the push for change. "And that doesn't exist here."

HEADLINE: Allied Signal In $9.8 Billion Hostile Bid In Electronics

BYLINE: BY LAURA M. HOLSON and KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Allied Signal, a maker of aerospace and automotive products, announced yesterday that it was starting a $9.8 billion unsolicited offer for AMP Inc., a 55 percent premium over Monday's closing price.
The offer, $44.50 a share in cash, will begin in five days if management of AMP, a maker of electronics connectors, does not agree to sit down and discuss a deal on friendly terms, said Allied's chairman and chief executive, Larry Bossidy. 
 Mr. Bossidy said he had made several attempts in the last week to discuss a deal with AMP management, including two phone calls and a letter. The move has been approved by Allied Signal's board.
Shares in AMP rose $13.9375 after the 3:30 P.M. announcement to close at $42.5625. Shares of Allied closed down $3.5625, to $40.
AMP said that it was referring the offer to its board, but that it was urging shareholders not to take any action until the board reviewed its offer.
AMP, based in Harrisburg, Pa., has been struggling lately, making it an attractive target for Allied Signal, which is based in Morris Township, N.J.
In July, AMP said it was closing a Pennsylvania plant and would cut 3,000 jobs in the next two years, a result of the weak economy in Asia. That region accounted for 20 percent of AMP 1997 sales. The company has 48,300 workers in 53 companies, another attractive element for Allied.
For the most part, Wall Street analysts said a deal made sense, assuming that Mr. Bossidy and his team from Allied Signal could change the way AMP operates.
"From what we are beginning to learn about AMP, it is a nice, undermanaged company," said Phua K. Young, an analyst with Lehman Brothers. "With a strong management team, a combination with Allied Signal could lead to some nice synergies."
Allied Signal's offer, if accepted, would dilute Allied earnings by 27 cents a share, said Mr. Bossidy. It would be financed by the sale of $2 billion worth of Allied assets -- some analysts suggested in the automotive business -- as well as a $1.5 billion equity offering. That would offset the dilution, he said, and 1999 earnings of the combined companies would rise 13 to 17 percent. He added that the combination would generate cash flow of $200 million in 1999, $300 million in 2000 and an additional $100 million in 2001.
Analysts attending a meeting with Allied executives were skeptical of Mr. Bossidy's projections, particularly because his team had not inspected AMP's books.
"This strikes me as a kind of 'trust me in 2000 and 2001,' " one analyst said. "What is your competence on these numbers?" Mr. Bossidy replied, "I don't think we have any rose-colored glasses." He later added, "It will be difficult."
Allied may also face difficulties with its hostile offer because Pennsylvania has some of the toughest anti-takeover laws in the country.
As a defensive measure, Allied filed a suit in a Federal District Court in Pennsylvania in an attempt to insure that investors would not be denied the opportunity to consider the offer.
Still, analysts agreed that the rich offer would put pressure on AMP's management to consider the bid carefully.
"Part of the reason the premium is as big as it is is to get AMP shareholders in line," Mr. Young, the Lehman Brothers analyst said. "If AMP management can't do as much as Allied Signal to get the stock price up, they run the risk of getting sued," by shareholders.
Eli Lustgarten, an analyst with Schroder & Company, said that Allied was seeking out AMP as an addition to what he said was a growing stable of high-growth and high-margin businesses. "AMP is a dominant company in a niche that has seen its market position and profitability eroded fairly considerably," he said. "But with a little bit of management smarts you can hopefully reinvigorate the company."
Mr. Lustgarten said that by going after AMP, Mr. Bossidy was seeking to reinvigorate the company's growth early in the next century. "With aerospace likely to slow, you can begin to raise questions about where they would turn for faster growth," he said. "This is pretty well thought out."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Will It Be A Rebound Or Relapse?

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
As the stock market swooned yesterday, Ron Reuss, chief economist at Piper Jaffray, felt vindicated.
Last November, he was an outsider among economists in predicting that the domestic economy would slow drastically this year. When most were forecasting double-digit growth in corporate earnings for the second quarter, believing the impact of the Asian crisis would be only a first-quarter blip, Mr. Reuss anticipated that earnings growth would be in the range of 4 to 6 percent. 
 Now companies are reporting second-quarter earnings in line with his forecasts, and Wall Street is bracing for further weakness with the negative effects of Asia expected to be felt at least into the third quarter.
"My bearish forecast is finally coming to fruition," said Mr. Reuss, who expects the United States economy to roll into a recession in the fourth quarter, even though the gross domestic product has so far outpaced his forecast this year.
Investors dumped shares yesterday, pushing major market indexes down more than 3 percent and nearly 10 percent off their peaks, the point that typically signals a correction.
In its worst decline this year, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 299.43 points, or 3.4 percent, to 8,487.31, its lowest finish since early March. It was the third-largest point decline in the history of the blue-chip average.
The trading volume of more than 834 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange was the second-largest ever, after the 1.2 billion shares traded on Oct. 28.
As a result of the losses, led by declines in I.B.M., J. P. Morgan and General Electric, the Dow is 9.1 percent below its July 17 peak of 9,337.97 and is up just 7.3 percent this year. It had been up more than 18 percent.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dived 40.32, or 3.6 percent. It is down 9.7 percent from its high of 1,196.75 set on July 17.
The Nasdaq composite index, laden with technology shares that led yesterday's slide, fell 65.46, or 3.54 percent, to 1,785.64, its lowest level since June 19, when it closed at 1,781.29.
Losses in bellwether issues like Microsoft, off 3 15/16, to 104 1/2; Intel down 2 7/8, to 81 15/16, and Cisco Systems off 3 3/8, to 93 1/8, mean the Nasdaq has had a correction; it is off 11.3 percent from its high for the year. In telecommunications, Worldcom fell 3 7/16, to 48 7/16; MCI Communications 4 1/2, to 59, and Lucent Technologies 4, to 87.
Behind the heavy selloff, analysts said, was distress about the outlook for corporate earnings and for Asian economies, especially Japan. Some forecast that the Dow could fall as much as 20 percent before rebounding.
"Some folks have been calling for this correction for a while," said Charles W. Johnson, head of equity trading at Blaylock & Partners in Baltimore. "This is good for the market. It's healthy because it makes people become cautious again."
Thomas Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that investors were unlikely to regain confidence in the market immediately. "We are in this information void period," he said, until there is news from Japan or a new round of corporate earnings data in September.
While Mr. Galvin and many strategists expect a rebound then, Mr. Reuss remains pessimistic. "I don't see a rebound in the third and fourth quarter," he said, adding that consumer spending is crucial for economic growth and many consumers will soon be forced to curb spending and pay down debt.
Financial stocks were also hard hit. The S.& P. financial index fell 4.9 percent, just trailing the Nasdaq telecommunications index, which fell more than 5 percent.
Among leading financial shares, Citicorp fell 9 5/8, to 154; Chase Manhattan 5 3/4, to 69 5/8, and J. P. Morgan 5 3/4, to 116 7/8.
Small-company shares continued to be hammered. The Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks was down 11.7 points, or 2.8 percent, to 401.63. The Russell is off 8.1 percent this year.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Rise, With 30-Year Yield at 5.63%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds rose for a fourth day yesterday, driving yields to the lowest level in more than three weeks, as a sharp fall in stock prices bolstered the appeal of less-risky Treasury securities.
"The weakness in the stock market" prompted the buying of bonds, said Kevin McClintock, head of taxable fixed-income assets at the Dreyfus Corporation. "It's a flight-to-quality trade." 
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 13/32, to a price of 107 4/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.63 percent from 5.65 percent on Monday. The yield was the lowest since July 10 and not far from the record low of 5.56 percent reached on July 7.
Earlier in the day, bonds fell along with the dollar after Haruhiko Kuroda, director general of the Japanese Finance Ministry's international bureau, suggested that Japan was ready to sell dollars for yen to bolster the ailing currency.
The expected sale of $9 billion in new debt by Worldcom and other companies also weighed on Treasuries, as did the sale planned next week of $38.5 billion in Government debt.
Treasuries bounced back as a last-hour plunge in United States stock prices increased the appeal of Government debt.
Bond investors welcome signs that the economy is losing steam, because slowing growth would reduce the risk of inflation.
Yesterday's rise in bond prices followed a larger-than-expected drop reported on Monday in the National Association of Purchasing Management's index of factory activity for July. It suggested that the economy was cooling off from a pace of robust growth earlier in the year.
The latest numbers followed a Government report last week that showed that the economy expanded in the second quarter at an annual rate of just 1.4 percent.
"We're starting to see the spreading impact of Asia," which could pave the way for lower bond yields, and thus higher prices, said Robert Alley of AIM Management in Houston.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
BIG SELLOFF SENDS DOW PLUMMETING NEARLY 300 POINTS

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
After months of shrugging off bad economic news from Asia and a slowdown in corporate profits in the United States, investors stampeded out of stocks yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 299.43 points, or 3.41 percent, to 8,487.31, and other market gauges were down even more sharply. While up 7.32 percent since the beginning of the year, the Dow is now down 9.1 percent from its peak on July 17. 
 The Nasdaq composite index, with its heavy weighting in technology and financial stocks, has lost 11.3 percent of its value from its peak in July. Nasdaq lost 65.46 points yesterday, or 3.54 percent. Even so, the index is up almost 14 percent this year.
There was no single reason identified as the culprit behind the market's plunge. Rather, investors seemed suddenly ready to give credence to red flags that had been waving for some time.
For example, the economic meltdown in Asia has translated into a sizable drop in demand for American products. Economic growth in the United States slowed to a 1.4 percent gain in the second quarter, down from 5.5 percent in the first quarter. The strong dollar has wreaked havoc on companies doing business overseas. Uncertainty over President Clinton's future in the face of the Monica S. Lewinsky matter weighed on the market as well.
But perhaps most significant was investors' sudden recognition that earnings growth, the engine that powers stock prices, is deteriorating at even the biggest and best-known American companies. Combine this with an increasingly narrow stock market advance -- more stocks going down than up -- and the outlook for stock prices turns decidedly bearish.
"Investors are finally, finally starting to realize that earnings growth has slowed," said Liz Miller, portfolio manager at Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen in New York. "If you have a weakening underlying economy, profits cannot keep going up."
Indeed, in recent days, such stock market stars as Procter & Gamble and Kellogg have disappointed investors with either lower-than-expected earnings or warnings of bad news to come. When the same blue-chip companies that have led the market to record valuations begin to lose steam, investors sooner or later take notice.
There was no sense of panic reported among brokerage firms yesterday. Several brokers said that the feeling among their clients was one of being resigned to a drop in stock prices. Indeed, in a measure of how far the market has come, the drop in the Dow was the third steepest in terms of points but not even in the top 20 in terms of percentage. Nice though the heady profits have been, investors seemed to think that the stock market was overdue for a fall.
Mutual fund investors did not appear to be crowding the exits, either. Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant, reported that more money went into funds across the company than left them. "There was some small movement from equities to money market funds," said Anne Crowley, a Fidelity spokeswoman, "but nothing of consequence."
The question on everyone's minds yesterday was where the market's fall would end. Was this the beginning of a stock market bloodletting or just a painful correction? A correction is a decline of 10 percent to 15 percent. Since the Dow peaked on July 17, it has lost 9.1 percent. A bear market is considered to have started once stock prices have fallen more than 20 percent from their peaks.
Following the rout on Wall Street, Asian markets were sharply lower early today. Japanese stocks were down 1.13 percent at midday, while Hong Kong stocks tumbled as much 2.5 percent before steadying.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, volume topped 800 million shares, the largest day of trading this year and the second biggest ever. Investors fleeing stocks sought refuge in Treasury securities, driving up the price of the 30-year bond and depressing the yield, to 5.63 percent.
Only time will tell, of course, whether the market will move into bear market territory. In recent years, investors have plowed back into stocks whenever they have declined, a phenomenon known as "buying the dips." Whether these investors will once again consider yesterday's precipitous drop in equity prices a buying opportunity remains to be seen.
Stocks began to slide in earnest about noon, when Ralph Acampora, director of technical research at Prudential Securities and a longtime bull on stocks, was quoted as saying that the Dow could drop 15 to 20 percent from its 1998 highs.
Stocks in all industries took a beating. Those hit hardest were the banks, down 5.5 percent on average, followed closely by the oil service sector, which lost an average 5.3 percent. Health care stocks fell an average 4.4 percent, and airline shares lost an average 3.8 percent.
Warning signs that stock prices might have gotten ahead of themselves had been evident for weeks, if not months.
Before the Standard and Poor's 500-stock index dropped 40.32 points yesterday, or 3.62 percent, to 1,072.12, it had gained 14 percent on the year. Yet the earnings growth reported by the stocks in the index during the first half of 1998 came in well below that gain, at about 4 percent. Something had to bring this disparity back into line and that something was stock prices.
Add to this the fact that labor costs are rising at the same time that intense competition among companies prevents them from raising their prices to consumers and corporate profit margins look particularly vulnerable.
Sharp-eyed investors may have noticed another sign that stock prices had hit something of a ceiling. Premiums paid in corporate takeovers had disappeared in recent months. Indeed, last week's proposed acquisition of GTEby Bell Atlantic offered GTE shareholders even less than the market price.
In addition, positive earnings surprises in the second quarter were no longer producing outsized gains in the stocks of companies reporting them. Indeed, companies with good news saw their stock prices underperform the S.& P. 500. This was an about-face from the period in 1997, when companies posting unexpected earnings gains of 10 percent or more above the Wall Street consensus outperformed the S.& P. 500 by 12.5 percent.
One money manager thinks the market has simply worn itself out moving to new highs in mid-July on a litany of bad news. "We'd had a big huge move relative to what had been happening," said William Fleckenstein, president of Fleckenstein Capital in Seattle.
"When you put that against the deterioration of the market itself, you could build a case that the market has exhausted itself," he said.
Painful though any fall in stock prices can be, some money managers who had been quietly raising cash and taking stock market profits were unsurprised by the move. To their view, such a drop was not a matter of if, but when. And if it ratchets down the exceedingly great expectations investors have come to look for in stock market returns, these folks say, the market's fall will be healthy.
"We were seeing valuations that were absurd relative to corporate earnings," said Elaine Hahn, of Hahn Capital Management in San Francisco. "But nobody wanted to listen."

HEADLINE: CANADA PACT GIVES A TRIBE SELF-RULE FOR THE FIRST TIME

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: NEW AIYANSH, British Columbia, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Canada's federal Government signed a landmark treaty with West Coast Indians today, giving a group of them control for the first time of a majestic swath of pine forest, crystal streams and towering peaks, along with the legal rights to run their own nation.
The Canadian Government had hoped the treaty -- seen as a model for dozens of other Indian land claims -- would foster the process of reconciliation between indigenous people and other Canadians. But its most immediate result so far has been division, suspicion and great uncertainty throughout British Columbia and across Canada. 
 Some Canadians argue that the treaty, which won't take effect until it goes through a full ratification process, fundamentally alters the Constitution and endangers the country's delicate unity by allowing the Indians a level of self-government that has been denied to French-speaking separatists in Quebec.
The rights granted under the treaty are comparable to those of Indian tribes in the United States, which already have the power to govern most of what happens on their reservations, although conflicts occasionally arise there over the extent of Indian jurisdiction and just who is covered by Indian laws.
But the treaty signed today in Canada carries with it even more potential for conflict because it was signed so much later than those in the United States, which were largely struck more than 100 years ago. Now about 50 other Indian groups are staking claims to territory covering virtually every square mile of British Columbia, even for already-developed cities like Vancouver.
If today's precedent, which covers about 750 square miles, is repeated, as seems likely, there will be intense clashes with high economic stakes.
Even before Canada's Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, Jane Stewart, arrived for the signing this morning in this remote corner of Canada, hard by Alaska, the historic treaty with the Nisga'a (pronounced nis-GAH) people was being attacked. Some residents of British Columbia fear the treaty establishes a new level of government based on race, with its own system of privileged justice and sanctioned inequality.
Others criticized its price tag -- the equivalent of $320 million in United States dollars spread over several years, in addition to the land -- as a giveaway.
The commercial fishing industry and others condemned provisions they feel give the Nisga'a unfair access to natural resources.
Indian claims were bolstered in December when Canada's Supreme Court issued a landmark ruling involving the Gitxsan, another British Columbia Indian group, that Indian claims extend to the land's natural resources. The court also recognized Indian oral history as having legal standing.
Nevertheless, rival Indian groups in the province oppose the treaty because it impinges on their own land claims.
Even members of one of the four bands that make up the 5,000-member Nisga'a nation has gone to court to stop the treaty. Some members, like James H. Stevens, say it is poorly conceived and badly executed because it omits 90 percent of the territory that the Nisga'a have traditionally claimed.
"It was done by a bunch of young guys on the negotiation committee who don't even know our resources or our culture," said Mr. Stevens, a 72-year-old elder of the Kincolith band of the Nisga'a. "Maybe they were just sitting there nodding their heads."
Despite the flood of criticism, federal negotiators and most Nisga'a leaders believe the treaty breaks new ground in Canada's long and not always successful relationship with its Indian groups.
"It's time we did it," said Lorene Plante, a Nisga'a woman who took part in the negotiations.
While also hopeful, Stephen Nyce was more guarded since he, like many other Nisga'a, has not yet seen the details of the treaty. "My grandfather told me not to celebrate until you know for sure what you are celebrating," he said.
Tom Molloy, the chief federal negotiator, said that for the first time an Indian treaty will resolve a question of territory while establishing the principles of self-government that can free Indians from dependency on the federal Government.
"Today we join Canada and British Columbia as free citizens, full and equal participants in the social, economic and political life of this country," said Joseph Gosnell Sr., president of the Nisga'a Tribal Council, who wore a headdress trimmed with seal whiskers and ermine furs. "We intend to live here forever."
While Indian self-government is a new concept in Canada, most of the more than 500 Indian tribes and councils in the United States already govern themselves to varying degrees, and with occasional challenges from non-Indians.
Jerry J. Cordova, a negotiator with the office of self-governance in the United States Department of the Interior, said that in most cases, non-Indians are not allowed to run for office or vote in tribal elections, but there are exceptions.
The American tribes consider themselves sovereign nations, a view not always shared by individual states and the Federal Government. The tribes often do not tax the people living on their land. In some instances, their right to levy taxes has been challenged in court.
The experience of the American Indians suggests that a tribe's ability to govern itself greatly increases the chances of its reaching economic independence.
"Tribes that do have better control over their assets -- whether cultural assets or trust funds -- are more successful in economic development," said Lela M. Shepard, development associate with the First Nations Development Institute, a nonprofit group that provides financial assistance to Indian tribes like the Pauma Tribe of Southern California, which used a $300,000 grant to improve its orange and avocado orchards.
Ms. Shepard said the biggest problem for most tribes is raising the money to begin projects, since many banks are reluctant to lend them money.
The Nisga'a treaty that was signed today will allow the indigenous people here to run most of the social and economic activity in the area they will control -- more than half the combined land and water area of Rhode Island. They will set and collect taxes and determine how the revenue is spent, while agreeing to eventually give up the exemption from some sales and income taxes they have had.
Ms. Stewart, the Indian affairs minister, praised the treaty, calling it "a just and honorable settlement" that reinforces the Supreme Court of Canada's directive that negotiation, not litigation, is the way to settle Indian land claims.
Following today's signing, the treaty proposal will be put to a referendum among the registered members of the Nisga'a. Fewer than 2,000 of the 5,000 Nisga'a live in the area that is considered their ancestral home.
Some British Columbia residents want a province-wide referendum on the treaty because they say that by preventing non-Indians from running for government offices or voting in such elections, the treaty fundamentally changes Canada's Constitution.
Indian leaders have rejected the idea of a provincial referendum, calling it "the white man's veto." The Premier of British Columbia, Glen Clark, said the 250-page treaty is too complicated to be put to such a broad test. The people of British Columbia will be able to make their views known when the treaty goes before the provincial legislature, he added.
Following that, it also will be voted on by the federal Parliament in Ottawa. Negotiators believe the whole process could be completed by next spring, although substantial objections could delay it.
Unlike the eastern provinces that signed land treaties with Indians hundreds of years ago, British Columbia entered into only a few such deals, on Vancouver Island and in the northeastern part of the province, before abandoning the process. Small scattered reserves were created but the Indians themselves never surrendered claim to traditional lands.
By all measures, Canada's 800,000 indigenous people are the poorest, least educated and least healthy Canadians, which deeply embarrasses many Canadians. The Government has been looking for a way to change the situation by embracing the idea of self-rule.
Government officials hope that by giving Indian groups clear title they can not only compensate for past injustices but also encourage forestry, mining and other activities to sustain independence. Uncertainty over who controls the land has hampered such efforts.
Today's treaty is considered full and final, and can be amended only with the consent of the Indians, the province and the federal Government.
"It's a done deal," said Jack Ebbels, the chief negotiator for British Columbia.
But this is not like past deals in which Indian bands were bullied into giving away most of their land.
The Nisga'a will become major landholders in British Columbia, owning the land outright, just like other property holders. They will own the rights to all the timber, except for existing leases, and subsurface minerals, and will be able to negotiate future contracts.
Local government will be in the hands of the Nisga'a, who will have the power to make laws concerning language and culture, property, employment, traffic and most social services. The 100 or so non-Indians living on Nisga'a land will not be allowed to run for office or vote, although they will have the chance to do so in elections involving education and boards of health that directly affect them.
These restrictions have already stirred a huge controversy that threatens to derail the ratification of the treaty. Despite the small number of non-Indians on Nisga'a land, critics are worried about the precedent of establishing governments on racial lines.
"For the first time I know of, they are entrenching inequality in the Constitution of Canada," said Gordon Campbell, leader of the Liberal opposition in British Columbia. Mr. Campbell said that this also endangers Canada's national unity. "We are giving to the Nisga'a government something that the Quebec government asked for a long time ago and were told, 'No, you can't have it.' "
But Ms. Stewart, the Indian minister, said the Constitution actually guarantees Indians special rights simply because they were in Canada before Europeans arrived. She said the federal Government fully supports the restrictions that the treaty places on participation in Indian government.
But that has proved to be a far more uncomfortable position for the province. "It was a thorny, thorny issue," said Mr. Ebbels, the provincial negotiator. He suggested that the province had been worried about non-Indians being taxed by the Nisga'a without any representation in the local government. In the end, Indian taxing powers were restricted to Indians, while others will continue paying taxes to the province.
"We took some comfort in that," Mr. Ebbels said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
GOODYEAR TO LAY OFF 580 WORKERS AT THREE TIRE PLANTS

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will lay off 580 workers at three plants as it grapples with a glut of tires because of the recent strikes that crippled General Motors assembly lines. Some of the jobs may be restored eventually if tire sales improve, a Goodyear spokesman, Chuck Sinclair, said yesterday. Most of the layoffs will be in a plant at Gadsden, Ala., where Goodyear is the largest employer. On Sept. 1 the company will lay off 449 workers there, about 22 percent of the work force of 2,000 at the plant. Mr. Sinclair said 85 workers would be laid off in Tyler, Tex., and 46 in Fayetteville, N.C.

SECTION: Section G; Page 9; Column 1; Circuits 

LENGTH: 1601 words

HEADLINE: Phone Lines, and Lines and Lines, Keeping Their Appeal

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
CALL it phone-line meltdown, if you will; consumers know it well. It's that angina-inducing moment when an avalanche of both voice and data transmission needs threaten to turn your single, humble phone line, as well as your patience, into a pile of ashes.
Trying to stay in touch with the office -- 20 calls a day -- as well as surf the Net? Good luck. Plain-vanilla phone lines can do only so much. 
 In the past year in particular, consumers have been given a growing array of options for meeting their escalating need to fax, phone, send E-mail and go out on the Internet. As a result, they no longer have to rely on just a phone line or two.
But many of these newer transmission options, like cable Internet connections and A.D.S.L. (asymmetrical digital subscriber lines), are currently available only in certain parts of the country. And while their prices are dropping, they are, for the most part, still expensive, with not just higher service costs but also extra charges for special modems, installation and even Internet service providers. Even then, technical support for the services is often less than encouraging.
Given the constraints of newer technologies, many consumers are sticking with the tried and true. That usually means simply increasing the number of regular phone lines, from one or two to three or four -- or more. By all accounts, sales of regular phone lines are booming. An extra line is usually no more than $20 a month, with installation starting around $75.
In California, for example, Pacific Bell has installed a record number of telephone access lines in the past three financial quarters, and almost all of those installations have been standard phone lines, which use analog technology. Pacific Bell now offers its customers 17.7 million access lines. But it still has only about 170,000 customers for its I.S.D.N. (integrated services digital network) service. The company is now introducing A.D.S.L. service as well.
At Bell Atlantic, sales of extra analog lines are also brisk. The number of sales first surged in 1994 and is now growing by 15 percent a year, said Debra Swann, executive director for consumer local and toll services at Bell Atlantic.
Families with talk-happy teen-agers, as well as home offices, account for a good chunk of the interest, of course. At Pacific Bell, for example, about one-sixth of the requests for extra phone lines are now coming from families that plan to give the lines to teen-agers, said John Britton, a company spokesman.
Still, heavy Internet use seems to be the factor that eventually drives most consumers to pile up dial tones. For example, in a survey of 7,800 households last fall, Ziff-Davis Marketing Intelligence found that 51 percent of those that used the Internet 16 hours or more a week had two or more lines, while 8 percent had three or more.
At Byte Sized Computing, a home-office consulting business in Rye, N.Y., Dominick Curatola, the owner, said he was asked about the need for second lines "almost every day." So far, he added, consumers seem to be sticking with analog technology. "I think there's interest in newer technologies on a theoretical level, but the small office or home hasn't really begun to push it," Mr. Curatola said. That's because most people are buying computers that have modems that use traditional analog phone lines already built into them.
"Quite honestly, consumers are having enough time with regular modems and services, let alone the fancier technologies," said Jim Mulcahy, who owns another computer consulting service, Computer Tutor @PCI in Bronxville, N.Y.
But many consumers may simply not yet need the lightning-fast transmission speeds of newer technologies like A.D.S.L. At its fastest, A.D.S.L. can pummel data along 250 times faster than a traditional 28.8-Kbps (kilobits per second) modem.
"The killer application for the Internet is still E-mail," said Doug Michelman, another spokesman for Pacific Bell. "More often than not, consumers are accessing the Internet for E-mail."
Cost, however, may be an equally strong motivator. Take the McCalmont family of Cincinnati. The McCalmonts already have three phone lines. Yet until recently, they found themselves juggling those lines constantly to meet their considerable voice and data needs. Both Mr. McCalmont and his wife, Alyce, for example, work from home as professional organizers; as such, they not only need to maintain a semblance of order at home regarding communications but also need to rely on open phone lines for business calls and the Internet.
But the McCalmonts' daughter, Laura, 16, is on the phone constantly. And their son, Drew, 14, spends so much time on the Internet -- up to 12 hours a day in the summer -- that he now has his own phone line.
Earlier this year, the McCalmonts realized that they needed to expand their phone line capacity fast. But they were already paying almost $200 a month for their three lines, an Internet service provider and three car phones. As a result, I.S.D.N. service was never an option. In the Cincinnati area, it costs $110 a month for service alone, while installation, an I.S.D.N. modem and Internet service cost extra.
Of course, the McCalmonts could have installed a fourth phone line, at a service cost of about $20 a month. Three months ago, however, they opted for an even cheaper, as well as simpler, solution: an Internet call manager service from Cincinnati Bell. For $7 a month, the service lets them answer or transfer an incoming call while they are using the Internet on their business line.They can also flash callers a message to let them know they will return the call.
Jon Kiphart is also staying true to his analog phone lines. As a freelance programmer who, among other things, automates theme park rides, Mr. Kiphart often finds himself connecting to the Internet from phones in far-flung locales like Malaysia that are not equipped to send and receive data on line and that also have limited access to digital phone technology.
For times like these, Mr. Kiphart carries his own acoustical modem, a coupling device designed for phones. At home, in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., he makes do with two analog phone lines, even though he often has to download large files chock full of graphics.
"I've heard that I.S.D.N. modems are very difficult to set up," he said. "And what I need is ease of use, durability and reliability, as well as the ability to tap into my computer from exotic locations."
Cost, however, is also a sticking point for Mr. Kiphart. "If the local cable service were able to deliver Internet service for $20 a month, I'd go for it," he said. "I'd also be willing to pay $30 a month for unlimited I.S.D.N. access. But right now I'm already spending between $200 and $300 a month for two analog lines, Internet service, a cell phone and a pager."
Digital technologies are becoming more affordable. For example, computer manufacturers are expected to roll out products that have A.D.S.L. modems built into them as early as next year. Meanwhile, A.D.S.L. technology, unlike I.S.D.N., carries the advantage of not being metered, so consumers can usually get unlimited service for between $70 and $90 a month. That fee, however, doesn't cover A.D.S.L.'s hefty installation and modem costs, which can chalk up an extra $600 or more.
Phone companies are trying to keep connection costs down as well. For example, when Bell Atlantic begins rolling out A.D.S.L. service next month, start-up fees will be held to less than $200 for an introductory promotional period. That fee will include a $99 connection fee and an A.D.S.L. modem for less than $100. Bell Atlantic says it will also waive fees for any home wiring work that may be necessary and any setup help that customers may need to reconfigure their computers for the new technology.
Peter Castleton, director of data products for Bell Atlantic, says consumer interest in the company's A.D.S.L. service has been overwhelming so far. "There seems to be pent-up demand for it," he added.
Still, for now, many consumers seem to be sticking with the technology that gives them the fewest number of headaches. One example is Beth Rowan, a public relations and marketing consultant who lives in Bronxville, N.Y.
Ms. Rowan works from her home and has two teen-agers, ages 13 and 16. Not surprisingly, she likes "to have things simple and straightforward, rather than the latest technology on the block." As a result, when she needed more phone capacity last summer, she simply installed a third phone line.
Ms. Rowan may move to a faster transmission technology yet: she says she is tired of the "antiquated" phone system in her county that allows her to surf the Net at a speed of only about 28 Kbps, even though she has a 56-Kbps modem. For now, though, sheis sticking with the simplest solution possible.
So is Elizabeth Wise, a psychology student in Bronxville. Ms. Wise does a lot of Web surfing, and her husband, a financial analyst, often has to use one of the family's two phone lines to transmit lengthy reports to the computer at his office in Manhattan.
Even though Ms. Wise's home was wired for I.S.D.N. technology in a recent renovation, she is sticking with analog phone lines for now because of cost and because she knows that newer transmission technologies, like cable and satellite, will be coming along.
"I'm waiting to see how these other technologies are going to shake down," she said. "I want what is simplest, as well as most economical, for the home user. And when I get it, I'll stick with it."

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1968 words

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
A House Where Rooms Are a State of Mind

BYLINE: By JOSEPH GIOVANNINI 

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

 BODY:
TROPHY houses, those 15,000-square-foot status symbols, may get all the ink in advertisements and the envy at cocktail parties, but the houses that are harder to measure and describe, the unconventional buildings with experimental or artistic qualities, are often more likely to throw a provocative curve at life.
Agents can easily show a 5-br prewar Tudor on lush 4 acres w vu of Snd, but how do they credibly push a house that is not a Jell-O mold for all-in-the-family living -- a house with, say, crackled concrete floors, voluminous space and gyroscopic sunlight pouring through faceted glass onto Stonehenge walls. The kind that is a catalyst for ideas and a trampoline for dreaming. 
 These exceptional houses are seldom found in ads; even when a client works with an architect, it's iffy to expect they can be built from the ground up.
In 1990, after wildfire incinerated the ranch-style house of Victoria and Richard Blades, along with 500 other houses on a hillside in Santa Barbara, the couple realized that their disaster was an opportunity to escape small, boxy rooms. They decided to look for a house with lofty, undecorated areas -- "No chandeliers, please," Mrs. Blades said. They wanted to live in a house that was a work of art, not one with a floor plan calculated for resale.
"We wore out a half-dozen real estate agents," said Mr. Blades, 58, whose work as a conceptual sculptor and metal fabricator influenced his eye for architecture. Mrs. Blades, 52, works in a high-tech company, managing a department that develops CD-ROM's. They have no children.
"Real estate agents wanted to deal with the number of bathrooms and bedrooms, and the kind of roof style," Mr. Blades said. "We were looking for volume. For us, the usual tiny family rooms meant an absurd compartmentalization of space. In most of the places, we couldn't get back far enough to see art. We tried to tell agents we were looking for tough, masculine materials." Instead of a typical high-end house, what they really wanted was a New York loft, set in Santa Barbara.
After many months of looking, the couple chanced to see the Crawford House in Montecito, a collaged composition of cubic forms and materials that fuse with the landscape. They found their way to its architects, the Santa Monica firm Morphosis, to confer with Thom Mayne about building a similar house on their one-acre lot, a house that would become a companion for thinking and sculpturing. The meeting was the start of a sometimes perilous five-year, hands-on collaboration.
With insurance money and savings, the Blades proposed building a $600,000 home of approximately 4,000 square feet, including pool and decks, or about $150 a square foot, with one master bedroom, an upstairs study and a double-height art gallery. (Many design-intensive houses range between $300 and $400 a square foot.) Mr. Mayne, 53, a member of the next architectural generation in Los Angeles after Frank Gehry, designs complex buildings energized by broken and chaotic forms, built of tough but finely crafted materials. Up front, given the budget, the architect said he told his clients that "there would be no marble, no exotic detailing, that we'd be building in generic materials like concrete and wood and metal and block -- that the welds would be showing and the metals would be left rusting and exposed." He added: "It'd be constructed like a cabin. The value of the house would not be in the raw materiality but in space and light."
The budget also meant that the architect's sometimes overfed designs -- as a young architect he often jammed too many ideas into too small a building -- would have to diet. Part of the economic strategy was to eliminate doors and some cabinetry; that decision in turn increased the sense of openness and emphasized the roughhouse qualities the couple had sought in a loft.
Mr. and Mrs. Blades had met a soul mate -- though one with his own esthetic agenda. The house would become a dual story -- of their search for an architectural house and Mr. Mayne's search for architecture.
Mr. Mayne was interested in taking his idea for the Crawford House, a fusion of architecture and landscape, a step further. Instead of placing a self-contained house on a passive piece of land, like setting a plate on a table, the architect wanted to cut and burrow into the earth, shaping the ground as part of the house's form. His inspiration for using the earth as an architectural element was the land artist Michael Heiser -- "He operates on a site by subtracting, rather than adding," Mr. Mayne said -- and the early Los Angeles modernist Richard Neutra, who put humans back into nature via a house that spread into the yard behind expanses of glass. Mr. Mayne's house would not be sited front and center.
His strategy was to create a large outdoor space with high, intermittent walls that suggest an oval and then to cut across the oval with a long thin house under an arching roof. "It's a continuous fluid space," Mr. Mayne said. "You can see all the way through for about 100 feet."
The Bladeses had their loft, or at least its California hillside incarnation. Starting with the kitchen at the lowest level, a big open space steps up the site, moving to the living room and then to the bedroom beyond. The long narrow room splits at the bedroom level, becoming a Y-shape plan. A staircase to Mrs. Blades's second-story study branches off to the right, alongside a dynamically tilted and angled wall that seems to be taking off over an outdoor pool. To the left, the Y branches into the bedroom and dressing area, where an open shower, with poured-in-place concrete half-walls recessed in the ground, anchors the space.
The bedroom, study and staircase area is an intense finale, where all the geometries of the house and site converge and pass through each other, like traffic at an intersection without a signal. No single order dominates, but several jockey for position in a landscape of fragments that marks an ambiguous and intriguing edge between outside and inside.
"There are never any complete geometries, only allusions to complete geometries -- there are never any wholes," Mr. Mayne said. "I was attacking the notion of a single boundary in a house. I wanted to create layers of boundaries."
The architect can afford the openness in the bedroom and bath area because he creates privacy along the street with a long straight, poker-faced wall that houses the garage, bathroom, entrance and gallery. The many "backyard" windows, which come in all shapes and are high and low in the structure, need no curtains.
During construction, the couple lent a hand, becoming subcontractors, fabricating the rails, stairs, parts of a shower and other metal details. "After the catastrophe, the whole design effort and the construction were very motivating," Mr. Blades said.
Although his wife kept her day job, he stopped his sculpture: the house was taking on a demanding life of its own. Living in an interim rental, they worked side by side on weekends, and after the work crews left, they could be found in boots browsing the site as though on a hike. "It was an opportunity to work together," he said.
But even with this help, and periodic cost-control meetings, the price crept beyond the budget, and it became clear that the couple wouldn't be able to afford the house. Mr. Blades, a sometime investor, played the stock market, investing in options and eventually getting into trouble. Just when he faced a $90,000 loss, he bet the ranch by holding on to stocks that seemed to be heading south. The market turned.
"We muscled our way through and ended up a couple hundred thousand dollars ahead," he said. "I had no other way of making money, so we went for it. I wouldn't do it again.'
They finally moved in, five years after they met Mr. Mayne (and after they dislodged an overdedicated contractor). True to unconventional form, the couple have not colonized the interior with designer couches and chairs but have settled in slowly, testing how they want to live in it. Its ambiguity makes it a house of several natures. "The complexity gives us many different locations in the house and on the property to be in," Mr. Blades said. "It's a matter of slowly evolving into the house."
Although the kitchen, dining and living areas and bedroom occupy parts of a continuum under the arching roof, "they're all open to each other," he said, adding, "We're definitely living in a loft, but a loft open laterally to adjacent yards and terraces."
Mrs. Blades said: "There's a feeling of continuity going through inside and outside, and for us that opens up opportunities. From inside, you just see all of nature come alive -- the grass changing colors seasonally, the moon casting its shadows through the house, coyotes on the kill." Duped by Mr. Mayne's sliding glass doors and overlapping boundary walls, a road runner and a gopher snake had, she noted, dropped in for a visit.
T HERE is not just one way to live in it. "Because of the fragmentation, you have to mentally complete the work yourself," the architect said. "I want the house to engage people's perception. That's how people finally interact with the work: they're involved with it. If it's completely predigested and there's only one reading, finally it's just not interesting."
The Bladeses spent months living primarily in the kitchen and bedroom areas, adjusting to its character like a sailor tuning and trimming a boat. They talk excitedly of exploring rooms, of "sleeping in an area that was more of a cave entrance than a house," Mr. Blades said. "Most structures, you walk around a corner, and you understand it right away, and you're bored with it," he added. "Here the windows in the concrete walls are all different, and you can clearly feel the sun moving, projecting shadows through the openings. Your eye steps from one fragment to another, which keeps the house from being flat."
His wife said: "Unlike houses where your views are limited to 15 feet, here your eye moves 40, 50, 60 feet. The area of privacy has expanded way out into a much larger visual field."
They're still tentative about furnishing it. "Do you need a living room?" they ask each other. "What is it, anyway?" For Mr. Blades, populating this open space with sofas is the equivalent of moving furniture into a natural picnic area: one should tread lightly, if at all. "We prefer it kind of empty. We feel more connected to the outside."
When they slide open the room's glass doors, they feel, Mrs. Blades said, "as though we're in a tent, or under a tarp swung over a branch, and the house is like a series of pathways from one part to another."
They are equally tentative about finishing the yard, and not only because Mr. Blades had quadruple-bypass surgery this year. In addition, Mr. Blades said, "financially we hit a wall." The final cost was $800,000.
"The property has native oak and grasses, and we've been struggling with how to extend that within the building," he said. "The yard has a wild, heavy Western feel, and it is interesting to formalize it without killing the native influence, which I'll do with plants and sculpture. From Day 1, I've been waiting for that moment. For now I get partway through a piece, and I can try it in a zillion different places, in the yard and in the house, and stand it two feet away, or 40 feet, getting a continuity of approach that you just don't usually have in many buildings, let alone houses.
"I feel free here. And for our relationship, we're much better able to do things together, cooking in that kitchen, doing the art. I feel an opposite of claustrophobia. I feel much more comfortable. It's really a riot, taking a shower in the open -- it feels so funky. Life has expanded for us."

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: In America;
The Damage Is Done

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT; William Safire is on vacation.

 BODY:
We have to wait now for the farce to run its course.
The voters have come to expect so little of Bill Clinton that they are willing to let him off the hook if he will only make a hypocritical little speech about his relationship with Monica Lewinsky. ("I'm sorry. I lied to protect my family," etc., etc.) 
 But if he refuses, and if he sticks to his story before the grand jury, and if DNA tests link him sexually to Ms. Lewinsky despite his adamant denials ("I did not have sexual relations with that woman") -- if all of that happens, well, the voters will probably let him off the hook anyway.
In other words, unless somebody comes up with an X-rated video of the President and his intern cavorting in the Rose Garden, you can forget about impeachment.
But the damage is done. The nation handed its highest office to a man who embodies the narcissistic extremes of the baby-boomer generation. It's all about Bill. And like everyone else who has had a relationship with this irresponsible and self-absorbed individual -- his wife, his friends, his loyal aides, his party -- the nation is paying the price.
There are important issues waiting to be dealt with -- an economic crisis in Asia, the extraordinary gap between America's haves and have-nots, the future of Social Security, campaign finance reform, education, health care, race relations and a Congressional election in November. But there is no leadership coming from Mr. Clinton. He's worried about his grand jury testimony and a devilish stain on a blue dress.
The Clinton Presidency is like a car disabled on the side of the road.
"Half the White House staff is distracted by this," said Senator Patrick Leahy, a Vermont Democrat. Referring to pending legislative matters, Senator Leahy said, "The people we need the most are constantly preparing for grand jury testimony."
Bill Clinton was never about dignity or integrity or respect for others, qualities that should be prerequisites for the Presidency. He raised hopes with his style and his rhetoric, but it turned out there was very little that was authentic about the man. His contempt for the truth is legendary. His idea of ethical behavior is to operate as close as possible to the borders of corruption. His treatment of women, as the world knows, seemed at times both compulsive and atrocious, and became a source of profound embarrassment to the feminists who supported him so strongly.
Although he is nearly 52, Bill Clinton seems the perpetual adolescent, forever calling on aides and friends to clean up the messes he is forever getting himself into. Several associates, enmeshed in his scandals, have gone broke from the legal bills that resulted. Who can forget the terrified expression on the face of the President's personal secretary, Betty Currie, as she made her way to her first grand jury appearance?
The use of Ms. Currie as a go-between is instructive. It was another example of Mr. Clinton's penchant for using people, for seeing human beings as things, as tools or toys to serve his outsized needs. A survey of the consequences of being close to Mr. Clinton would be chilling. The price of being in this President's orbit can be fearfully high.
If Mr. Clinton was at all remorseful about any of this, you'd never know it. Last week he was out in the Hamptons, raising money and hanging with the movie stars.
This is not to say that Bill Clinton's enemies have not behaved atrociously themselves. The extreme right wing of the Republican Party would be happy to impeach the President for any reason at all, for having impure thoughts or daring to breathe. And Kenneth Starr, if he could get away with it, would very likely do its bidding. But it's Mr. Clinton's own behavior and lack of judgment that has so frequently betrayed and undermined his supporters, and provided his enemies with the opportunities and the ammunition to attack.
 The lesson, of course, is that character does matter. The voters will probably remember that the next time around. In the meantime, Mr. Clinton may or may not be contemplating a mea culpa. It doesn't matter. It wouldn't be any more sincere than anything else he has said. If he had any sense of dignity or personal responsibility, he'd be working on his resignation.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Maybe the lottery raises a lot of revenue, but as an investment, it's chancier than you might think.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IT'S the latest American success story: Save your pennies, invest in an organization that donates a third of its income to good works and walk away with a big nest egg, say $161 million.
Maybe Powerball -- and the state lotteries with more modest seven-figure prizes -- aren't what Horatio Alger had in mind. But for the vast majority of people, lotteries are merely a harmless pastime that diverts funds from illegal gambling. "The original idea was to replace the numbers racket and raise some revenue painlessly," reminds Charles Clotfelter, an economist at Duke University. 
 As the states work ever harder to persuade people to play, though, this reasoning is growing weaker. "Once you make it legal," argued Peter Reuter, an economist at the University of Maryland's School of Public Policy, "you inevitably lose control of the promotion."
For economists, locked in utilitarian reasoning, gambling is hard to explain among people who spend tens of billions of dollars to reduce personal risk. Why, for example, would someone shell out hundreds of dollars every month for medical insurance to eliminate the small risk of having to pay $20,000 in hospital bills -- and then turn around and trade the sure thing of a dollar in hand for one chance in 50,000 of winning $20,000?
And why do lottery players seem to be attracted to the games with the highest payoffs? So-called progressive games, in which uncollected jackpots are carried forward, might explain this phenomenon: as the prize accumulates, the expected return to each dollar wagered does rise, in some cases actually exceeding the amount bet.
But psychological research suggests a simpler explanation. People, it seems, just aren't up to the challenge of comparing tiny probabilities of unlikely things happening. So they may assess the chances of winning a $100 million jackpot as roughly the same as winning a $10 million jackpot.
Besides, noted Robert Frank, an economist at Cornell University, there's a sense that a few million dollars no longer counts as much because it no longer symbolizes true, drop-dead wealth. "Great fortunes are far more visible today than a few decades ago," he said.
No matter how the frenzy is explained, there's no doubt that business is booming. Last year, according to La Fleur's World Lottery Almanac (www.lafleurs.com), Americans paid $34 billion for lottery tickets -- up from $16 billion in 1988. Of the $34 billion, prizes absorbed 54.5 percent, and selling costs 5.8 percent. That left $11.5 billion for state-financed causes like education or aid to the elderly.
While states almost always earmark lottery proceeds for the needy at the outset, Mr. Reuter notes that the revenues do not seem to change government spending priorities in the long run: One way or another, an extra $100 million from the lottery for schools means roughly $100 million less for education from general revenues.
Lottery proceeds, like taxes on cigarettes, are widely perceived as "good" taxes because they are voluntary. No one, after all, is forced to buy lottery tickets. But while no one can deny the popularity of this back door to revenue, economists are generally appalled by the states' increasing dependence on lotteries. "This is a large, terribly regressive tax on a service sold by a state monopoly," Mr. Reuter argued.
What would he do about it? A modest step would be to eliminate advertising aimed at expanding the market. Massachusetts, where lottery spending (at 1.7 percent of personal income) is twice the national average, has been shamed into gestures in this direction.
A much bolder step would be to slash the effective tax rate by increasing the percentage paid in prizes. If one state did it, others might be forced to follow. On the other hand, why would a state kill the goose that is laying those billion-dollar eggs?
Robert Frank of Cornell argues that the state monopoly itself is a mistake because it links government to the socially destructive impulse to try to get rich quick. "I think states should be out of the business entirely," he said, perhaps by licensing and taxing private lotteries.
There is some hope that advertising for the lottery will subside, if only because the market is saturated. But even economists aren't naive enough to believe that the states will abandon a vastly profitable -- and popular -- monopoly in the name of civic virtue.
Besides, great things are sometimes done with lottery proceeds. "They built the Sydney opera house, perhaps the most interesting building in the country, with lottery money," recalled Mr. Reuter, who is Australian born. "Of course, it cost many times the amount originally budgeted," he said, "and that meant the hospitals did without lottery proceeds for a few extra years."

HEADLINE: Machinists Reject Northwest Airlines Pact

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: EAGAN, Minn., Aug. 5

 BODY:
The International Association of Machinists announced today that members had rejected tentative contract agreements with Northwest Airlines and authorized a strike.
The vote means that both sides will return to negotiations under a Federal mediator. No date was set for resumption of talks between Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest airline, and its largest union. 
 "We're actually very proud of the show of solidarity," said Jill Hogan, secretary-treasurer of the International Association of Machinists.
"We are disappointed," said Doug McKeen, a Northwest vice president in charge of labor relations.
The countdown is already under way toward a strike by Northwest's pilots. The National Mediation Board declared talks between Northwest and the Air Line Pilots Association at an impasse last week, causing a 30-day cooling-off period. Pilots could strike as early as Aug. 29.
Pay and work rules are major issues in both disputes.
In announcing the results of the vote, Northwest's largest union said 85 percent of its voting members had authorized a strike.
More than 23,000 of the approximately 27,000 union ground workers cast ballots, Ms. Hogan said. Union members include mechanics, baggage handlers, office and security workers, with hourly pay ranging from $6.53 to $21.63.

HEADLINE: A Healthy Turn for China's Army

 BODY:
Over the last 20 years, China's army has become almost as formidable a force in the Chinese economy as it is in military affairs. Encouraged by the Government to supplement official defense budgets with profits from army-owned businesses, the military developed a multibillion-dollar empire of some 15,000 companies, including clothing manufacturers, airlines and hotels as well as defense-related industries.
Last month President Jiang Zemin ordered the army to sever its connections with these companies, with some of the lost revenues to be replaced by increased government spending. His initiative should reinforce China's economic and budgetary reforms, strengthen civilian authority over army leaders and create a more professional military, less likely to intervene in political affairs or complicate relations between China and the United States. 
 Having army-owned businesses sell defense equipment to the military invited corruption. Army businesses also proved ideal conduits for smuggling, with their ability to move luxury goods undetected across borders. The financial cushion provided by these businesses also made military leaders dangerously independent of government control and individually rich and powerful.
Since consolidating power last fall Mr. Jiang has put forward a surprisingly ambitious agenda of reforms, including closing unprofitable state industries, reducing government bureaucracy and, now, extricating the army from business. He has also encouraged a limited debate about introducing more democracy into China's authoritarian political system.
These are promising steps, pointing toward a better governed, more market-oriented and slightly freer China. China now has a leader with a reform plan and the political authority to put it into effect.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
What Caused Wall Street's Summer Swoon?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
If you own stocks, taking a summer vacation may be a bad idea. You might return a lot poorer.
It was less than three weeks ago, on July 17, that the big stock indexes hit new records amid general celebration that the American economy was performing ever so wonderfully, whatever might happen to Asia. 
 But by late yesterday afternoon, the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks had lost 10 percent of their peak value, although there had been no epochal event that would seem likely to cause such a fall.
At least for now, that plunge has been halted. Just before 3:30 P.M. yesterday, a flood of buy orders hit the New York Stock Exchange, many of them to be executed at the close of trading. It looked as if a big mutual fund -- perhaps an index fund that buys all the stocks in the S.&P. 500 -- had committed a lot of money to stocks. Whoever did it, the move lifted prices, and spirits.
Still, the question remains: What set this off? There is no shortage of explanations from the seers. They point to worries about Asia, to weakening corporate profits, and even to Monica Lewinsky. Some see disappointment over Senate resistance to further cuts in capital gains taxes, or over testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who seems unwilling to lower interest rates despite signs of a slowing economy.
There is a case to be made for all of those things having negative implications for share prices, but there could be a simpler explanation. Maybe American investors are running a little low on money to pour into the stock market. The most notable factor in the recent growth of the American economy has been the strong purchasing by American consumers. All that buying of goods may have left less cash available for stocks.
In fact, the great bull market of the 1990's was looking a bit shaky even before the current plunge. Big stocks recovered from a sag that began in the spring, but little ones did not. The Russell 2000 -- the best index of small stocks -- is down 19 percent from its April peak. The stocks that were moving were the big blue chips, which have risen to unprecedented valuations, and some Internet stocks that produced rampant speculation.
Notwithstanding the recent turmoil, there is no sign that Americans have lost their faith in stocks. Aging baby boomers still see stocks as the best place for their retirement money. It is unlikely that will change unless stock prices fall much further -- and over a much longer time period -- than they have so far. With long-term Treasury bonds yielding less than 5.7 percent, alternative investments do not look attractive.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the Goldman, Sachs strategist who has been bullish -- and right -- since 1991, reassured her followers yesterday by saying that profits were better than they seemed while the worst impact of Asian problems was behind us. You can get an argument on either point, but a wholesale flight from American stocks seems unlikely until the arguments are decided. It would probably take an American recession.
There is a wild card here, however. Never before has the American economy been so dependent on the stock market. Some economists say that a large part of recent growth in consumer demand has reflected the feeling of wealth brought on by higher stock prices. A bear market, if one comes, would damage the economy. The nice circle -- with the economy and the stock market pushing each other higher -- will not last forever.
