HEADLINE: Mexico City Journal;
Crime Is Unleashed but the D.A. Is Undaunted

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Samuel Del Villar, Mexico City's Harvard-educated District Attorney, works like a man with a mission, guzzling black coffee through 15-hour days in his crusade to suppress crime and corruption. And there's always more to do.
In the eight months since Mexico's City's opposition Mayor appointed him to office, he has dismissed police commanders accused of torture, auto theft, assault, kidnapping and narcotics trafficking. Last week, 63 detectives were dismissed after they tested positive for drug use. Three days later, he ordered the arrest of a prosecutor and eight subordinates after the jail-cell rape of a teen-age prostitute who sought police protection from her pimp. 
 Along this march of dismal events, however, Mr. Del Villar had cause to brighten one recent day when, on a visit to a downtown police precinct, he heard a detective complain that typing up routine reports took hours on a manual typewriter.
"Could you use some computers?" Mr. Del Villar asked, savoring the July 21 settlement that followed his prosecution of International Business Machines on conspiracy charges related to a procurement contract. I.B.M. is to pay Mexico City $37.5 million in cash and new computers, which he says will help to modernize the city's vast criminal justice bureaucracy. "We're going to have lots of computers!" he said.
The I.B.M. case is the largest achievement so far for Mr. Del Villar, whom Mayor Cuauhtemoc Cardenas swore in last December with the pledge, "We're going to take the city back from the criminals." Mr. Del Villar is under pressure to show progress before Mr. Cardenas's expected presidential run in 2000, but he faces a staggering challenge, not just because organized crime is so entrenched but also because the police are discredited and he faces daily nit-picking in a hostile press.
"Corruption has been Mexico's disaster, because nobody has taken the law into account," said Mr. Del Villar during a breakfast of papayas and mangos at his downtown offices. "This is our chance to work for the rule of law."
Mr. Del Villar, who is 53, presides over the Attorney General's Office of Mexico City, supervising the city's 3,700-officer detective corps, known as the judicial police, and the 1,500 prosecutors, in a city of 8.5 million.
"I found him very bright, very interested," said Ray Kelly, the former New York Police Commissioner, with whom Mr. Del Villar discussed New York's efforts against police corruption during a dinner last year at the home in New York of Victor Gotbaum, the longtime union leader. "He was looking at what we'd done. He seemed familiar with the details. But obviously he has a heavy lift ahead of him on police corruption in Mexico City."
Mr. Del Villar, who holds degrees from Mexican and European universities and a doctorate in law from Harvard, has sought criminal justice reform throughout his career. He returned from Harvard in 1972 convinced of the need to strengthen Mexico's Supreme Court, which has been a mere holding pen for presidential cronies, and urged a prominent leader of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, to seek appointment as Chief Justice.
But the PRI leader scoffed, Mr. Del Villar recalled. "He said that to be on the Supreme Court was just to be in limbo."
Mr. Del Villar got his own chance at reform when President Miguel de la Madrid appointed him in 1982 to head a campaign aimed at rooting out corruption. Eventually Mr. Del Villar concluded that he lacked presidential support and resigned, but not before arranging passage of a law requiring competitive bidding in Government procurement contracts.
That was the law he accused I.B.M. executives and city officials of violating when they arranged the 1996 purchase of a $26 million computer system.
His largest step toward political reform came after the 1988 presidential voting, which he denounced as fraudulent. He quit the PRI and helped Mr. Cardenas form the Party of the Democratic Revolution.
If the I.B.M. case has drawn him considerable praise, previous months were difficult. His first week in office, he was stunned by accusations that a top commander he had just appointed had headed a police unit tied to the torture and murder of a prisoner. Mr. Del Villar replaced the commander but faced weeks of attack in newspapers.
"This is an intelligent man who has always been a crusader," said Denise Dresser, a political scientist. "His main problem is that he is not fully in control of the Attorney General's office."
He is working to consolidate his grasp. During his tenure he has ordered the arrest of 60 subordinates. He has outlined sweeping plans to decentralize his agency, setting up new offices for reporting crimes throughout the city, including some in subway stations.
He has also inaugurated programs to train thousands of police officers and to consolidate law enforcement as a professional career by raising salaries. A rookie detective earns $517 a month.
These efforts keep him running. One day last week, his Chevrolet Suburban nosed into an underground garage before 8 A.M. and minutes later he was in his 11th-floor office, briefing a reporter over breakfast. At 10 A.M. he was at the head of a conference table with civic leaders, shining a laser pointer on a wall map of the city center to outline a campaign against muggers.
At noon, he was leading a tour of a precinct station that is a pilot project for a plan to reorganize the way citizens report crimes and the police book suspects, with an eye to eliminating delays and bribery.
He ordered the precinct's holding cells, which were originally adjacent to desks where citizens report crimes, relocated down a hallway after discovering that detained suspects were shouting threats at crime victims. From behind the bars of the newly constructed cells, a teen-age purse-snatcher whispered to him that corrupt police were protecting his daily thievery. Mr. Del Villar ordered an aide to investigate.
Through the afternoon there were meetings at two other precincts and examination of the curriculum at the Police Academy. As the sun set, Mr. Del Villar was back at headquarters, discussing security for the subways and schools. During a pause, he pored over graphs that he said showed reported crimes decreasing since he took office. Critics dispute that.
"I'll vouch for Samuel's honesty, but it's too early to draw judgments about crime trends," said Rafael Ruiz Harrell, a criminologist at the National University.
If there is debate over short-term trends, there is none about the alarming surge over recent years. Reported crimes doubled in the city in four years, from 366 daily in 1993 to 700 last year. Some criminologists attribute this to the economic crisis and some suggest other causes. Mr. Del Villar blames changes in the penal code in 1993 that encouraged criminals by raising the evidentiary threshold required for prosecutors to obtain indictments.
He has proposed legal reforms, and two PRI senators were waiting to discuss them. It was 9:30 P.M. when Mr. Del Villar poured another cup of coffee and stepped into his office to greet them.

HEADLINE: Summer, and Working Is Easy;
Nation's Resorts and Parks Are Feeling the Labor Pinch

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.

 BODY:
Sonji Thomas of Kingstree, S.C., started working at the Pavilion Amusement Park in this popular beach resort in late May, after finishing her junior year at Columbia College, a small liberal arts school in this state's capital.
Earning $6.25 an hour for everything from taking tickets to filling in for co-workers on break, she said, "I've earned money, made friends and met a lot of people." 
 She would have made even more if her roommate had not quit her summer job in late July, leaving Miss Thomas to shoulder the entire $170-a- week apartment rental herself -- an amount equal to two-thirds of her weekly salary.
She reluctantly returned home to prepare for the start of school on Aug. 26 -- leaving the Pavilion to fill the void left by her and the rest of the park's 475 seasonal employees who quit before summer's end.
Syreeta Owens, 18, of Marion, S.C., is planning her own departure from the Pavilion on Aug. 14 in order to begin her freshman year at Winthrop University in Rock Hill, S.C., on Aug. 26.
Increasingly, at resorts and parks throughout the United States, the late-summer void left by American students is being staffed by retirees and foreign students, whose school terms often begin later in the fall.
While most retired workers work only part time, they have become essential to the seasonal tourist industry, especially during a period of low unemployment. The retirees are vital in national and state parks in October, after the students depart and millions of visitors arrive to view the changing leaves. And any number of amusement parks, from Dollywood in Pigeon Forge, Tenn., to Six Flags Great Adventure and Safari in Jackson, N.J., roll out the welcome mat for retired people.
In fact, the number of employees age 50 and over at Six Flags, New Jersey's biggest seasonal employer, has more than doubled to about 600 since 1996. And this year, for the first time, Sea World of Florida -- whose 900 part-time workers include many retirees -- is offering part-timers who have worked six consecutive months the choice of cash bonuses or either of two medical insurance plans.
At his post beside a collection of amusement park antique autos in the Pavilion at Myrtle Beach, where he and his wife, Minnie, work as ride operators, Joseph McCracken, a 74-year-old retired farmer with a pacemaker, said he was well satisfied to be working at the park at his age and in his condition.
"Farming's never done," he said, explaining that both he and his wife spent years behind a mule, plowing their 35-acre farm in Aynor, S.C. "In all that time we never had a vacation. This is a vacation."
Mary E. Basden, the head of human resources for Burroughs & Chapin, the company that owns the Pavilion and many other attractions here, said: "It's usually a problem getting college students to stay through Labor Day. But it has never been as much of a problem as this year, mostly because there are so many job openings in Myrtle Beach and not enough people to fill them. People will quit to go someplace else for a nickel or a dime. And these aren't experienced workers. A lot of them are kids with their first job, and a lot of them still lack social skills."
The Pavilion, in order to retain student workers, gives a bonus to every seasonal employee who stays until Labor Day, and a scholarship bonus of up to $2,500 for employees who work at the park four consecutive years.
As if to underscore the labor shortage, restaurants, motels, souvenir shops, pizza parlors and convenience markets all along Route 17 and Ocean Boulevard, this city's two main roads, are plastered with help wanted signs, often with assurances that experience is not necessary.
But Myrtle Beach is not unique when it comes to a shortage of summer help, only that its problem is exacerbated by the fact that it draws some 13 million tourists a year, most of them in summer.
Employers in tourist destinations are scrambling as never before to hire seasonal employees and to retain those they have. Not only was the 4.7 percent unemployment rate in June the lowest in almost 30 years, but high schools and colleges increasingly begin fall sports practice and even classes by the third week of August, often because they have longer breaks during the school year. And, employers report, many students spurn entry-level salaries for vacations of their own or for summer internships, even unpaid internships.
To lure even inexperienced workers, many hard-pressed employers are offering $6 or more an hour, or at least 85 cents above the $5.15 national minimum wage -- and as much as $7 or $8 for cooks, chambermaids and security guards. Many employers recruit retired men and women at job fairs, or hire the many foreign students who arrive through student exchange employment programs, or, increasingly, simply turn up asking for a job.
When all else fails, or simply to prevent a labor shortage, many employers are offering inducements practically unheard of a year or two ago:
*At Seagram's Universal Studios in Orlando, Fla., employees who stay until at least the third week in August are eligible for a drawing whose prizes include a 1998 Chevrolet Tracker, a four-day Caribbean cruise for two, a free flight for two anywhere in the United States and cash awards of $5,000, $3,000 and $1,000.
*Elitch Gardens amusement park in Denver budgets up to $5,000 for scholarships, the amount depending on length of service, and recently began helping students apply for Federal aid and student loans for which they are eligible.
*At Lake Powell, the vast recreation area on the border of Arizona and Utah, the Aramark Corporation, the park concessionaire based in Philadelphia, pays an additional 25 cents an hour in a lump sum at the end of the summer to employees who fulfill their summer contracts. In addition, employees are treated to luaus and barbecues, and given free use of a houseboat for a week.
*The Inn on Lake Superior, in Duluth, Minn., pays about $5.50 an hour -- but adds an additional $1 an hour to an employee's tuition fund, up to $500 a year.
*At Yellowstone National Park, new workers start at $5.25 an hour, but are given subsidized room and board. They are also allowed to arrange their schedules to create an occasional four-day weekend. Even at that, to fill the park's 2,600 positions throughout the summer requires Amfac Parks and Resorts of Aurora, Colo., the park concessionaire, to hire 3,400 people.
*Ocean City, N.J., where the beach patrol dwindles from 125 lifeguards early in the season to fewer than 50 by Labor Day, recently sent invitations to "all old guards who are interested in returning to guard part time in August." The city expects about 25 old-timers, about the same as last summer, among them teachers, airline pilots and other professionals.
While Ocean City's invitation is somewhat unusual, in that lifeguards usually conjure up images of youth, summer businesses would have a hard time operating this summer -- other than on a vastly reduced scale -- without retirees.
"We use a lot of retired people, especially when we start losing employees in mid-August," said Terry Slowinski, regional general manager for Aramark, which operates the refreshment concessions and catering services at Lake Powell, Alaska's Denali National Park and a dozen other national and state parks.
Akane Nagatomo, 22, who has been working at Lake Powell since May and plans to remain until Labor Day, said, "I noticed older people working here, and it's impressive how much they accomplish and how much they seem to be enjoying themselves."
Unlike most of the foreign workers holding summer jobs up and down the Atlantic Seaboard who come from Europe, Miss Nagatomo is from the island of Kyushu in Japan. Majoring in hospitality at Mesa State College in Grand Junction, Colo., she earns $5.75 an hour, plus dormitory housing, at Lake Powell while fulfilling the 540 hours required of her internship. Many other parks, including amusement parks, offer internships to students, as do many hotels.
Except for occasional "strays" who turn up, most foreign students arrive with J-1 visas allowing them to work and travel in the United States for up to four months.
"It's basically a program that allows the kids to learn English," said Casey Slamin, project manager of Interexchange, which has been bringing foreign students to work in the United States for more than 20 years. This summer, he said, Interexchange has brought in about 3,500 such workers, most of them from Europe. In the winter, when the seasons and the school year are reversed in the Southern Hemisphere, it brings in college students from Australia, South Africa and Latin America to work in ski resorts.
Despite periodic demands that America tighten its immigration policy, there appears to have been little or no backlash against foreign college students -- not just because of the shortage of home-grown workers this summer, but also because "most employers want to internationalize their work staff," Mr. Slamin said, "so even during high unemployment, foreign workers would still fill a niche."
Another big reason for hiring foreign students, employers here and elsewhere say, is that European colleges do not usually start before October.
Peter Nolan, an electrical engineering major at University College Cork in Cork, Ireland, is not due back until Oct. 5. He is a busboy at the Kansas Steak House here earning $5.25 an hour. "I'm hoping to become a server," he said, "because they make good tips."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Fed's Survey Finds Economy Is Cooler but Remains Warm

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The American economy was operating at a healthy pace through July, but growth showed signs of slowing as slumping exports to Asia and labor shortages were felt nationwide, the Federal Reserve said today.
"Despite the high level of economic activity in recent weeks, many districts noted that labor shortages, shipping bottlenecks and continued weakness in East Asia were beginning to temper growth in their regions," the Fed's beige book economic summary said. 
 The survey by the central bank covers June 8 through July 27. It was based on interviews with business executives in all 12 Federal Reserve districts and will be used by policy-setting members of the Federal Open Market Committee when they meet on Aug. 18 to consider interest-rate strategy. The signs of slower growth and restrained price pressures suggest the Fed can keep interest rates steady.
The Fed's summary implied that robust domestic demand was still warding off the worst effects of Asia's crisis, but it highlighted the influences that were putting some drag on domestic expansion.
The Fed said manufacturing remained at a high level in July despite a United Automobile Workers' strikes against General Motors, weakening demand for exports and a general slowing in high technology.
But factories were starting to feel the impact of Asia's woes, as exports slowed and the volume of cheap imports rose.
Jobs were plentiful and skilled employees especially were in demand.
Farmers hit by falling commodity prices -- in part because Asian countries are unable to buy as much food from America -- were feeling a profit pinch, the Fed noted, aggravated by drought conditions in the South.
Consumer spending at retail stores increased in late June and July and inventories were described as balanced, a sign that producers were not being restrained by large stocks of unsold goods from the first quarter, when inventory-building occurred at a record pace.
Separately, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported today that its index of nonmanufacturing business conditions fell to 57.5 in July from 61.5 the previous month. A reading above 50 indicates expansion.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
ABC and ESPN Make a Dual $600 Million Bid to Acquire N.H.L. Television Rights

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Despite falling ratings for National Hockey League telecasts, ABC and ESPN have mounted a combined $600 million bid for broadcast and cable television rights for five years to start in 1999, said executives involved in the talks.
At $120 million a year, the bid would represent a stunning 167 percent leap over the average annual rights payment that Fox ($31 million) and ESPN (about $14 million) have been paying. The offer would also double what Fox and ESPN are to pay in the coming season, the last year of their deals. 
 But Fox only has to match the ABC offer by Aug. 14 to retain its rights. The ABC part of the deal is about $250 million, the executives said.
"We've been informed of the ABC and ESPN bid and we're examining our options," said Vince Wladika, a Fox spokesman.
The cable portion, which is an estimated $350 million, is greater than ABC's because ESPN and ESPN2 would carry more games. ESPN has been showing one game a week and ESPN2 has shown three.
Fox could counter with a dual bid, adding FX or the Fox Sports Net as its cable component. Fox and FX currently carry major league baseball nationally. But low ratings and the size of the ABC-ESPN bid make matching unlikely.
"Hockey has good demographics, a high proportion of young males watching and growth projected because of the roller blading side of the game," said Neal Pilson, a sports television industry consultant. "But if these numbers are true, I'm hard pressed to come up with a rationale based on television economics."
ABC and ESPN, which are subsidiaries of the Walt Disney Company, made no comment on their joint bid. Their talks, which were held at the N.H.L. meetings in Nashville, were first reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. The ABC-ESPN bid is the newest evidence of escalating sports rights costs. In January, ABC, ESPN, Fox and CBS agreed to eight-year deals worth $17.6 billion to carry the National Football League games. Now, ESPN and ABC are heavily cross-promoting full seasons of Sunday night and Monday night games.
In mounting its hockey bid, Disney is trying to protect important programming for ESPN and ESPN2 from an incursion by Fox, and to create a broadcast position, with ABC, from which hockey can be heavily cross-promoted.
Disney's N.H.L. ties also include ownership of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks. Disney is also looking to a hoped-for uptick in national hockey interest because of in-line skating and the addition of teams in Nashville this season, Atlanta in the 1999-2000 season and Columbus and St. Paul the season after.
But even with Fox as hockey's broadcaster, ratings struggled. Fox's regular-season Nielsen rating fell 33 percent to a 1.4 from a 2.1 peak two years ago. And with teams from markets like New York, Philadelphia and Chicago faltering in the playoffs, Fox's post-season rating dropped from a 2.1 last season to a 1.8 this season. Disappointed by the ratings skid, Fox pared its 1998-99 regular-season schedule from an average of six regional games a week to three, over 11 weeks.
ESPN's rating last season fell to a 0.7 from a 0.8 in the 1996-97 season, while ESPN2's 0.4 rating was unchanged from last year.
Regarding ESPN's bid, Mike Soltys, a spokesman, said, "Our extension is not finalized." He would not address the ABC bid.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall as the First of Big Debt Sales Begin

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bonds fell yesterday as the Treasury and companies, including Worldcom Inc., lined up to sell more than $40 billion of debt in coming days.
"Supply continues to weigh heavily on the market," said Dan Johnedis, who helps manage about $15 billion in bonds for Baring Asset Management in Boston. He has been buying high-yield bonds from companies that have little exposure to Asia's financial turmoil. 
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 17/32, to 106 17/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.67 percent, from 5.63 percent on Tuesday.
The Treasury said it will sell $37 billion in 5-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds next week, in its quarterly debt sales. Worldcom and other companies are expected to sell about $6 billion in corporate bonds in coming days, after Fannie Mae sold $3 billion in five-year notes yesterday. Treasury bills and notes, securities considered to be among the safest and easiest to trade, gained as some investors sought shelter from a volatile stock market.
"Equity accounts are looking for a safe place and that is helping" shorter-term Treasuries, said Tony Crescenzi, chief bond strategist at Miller, Tabak Hirsch & Company.
Fannie Mae kicked off yesterday's debt offerings, selling $3 billion of its five-year benchmark notes at 27.75 basis points more than comparable Treasury securities. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
The nation's largest buyer of home mortgages started its benchmark note program earlier this year, in part to capitalize on a decline in debt sales by the United States Government.
The $37 billion in securities scheduled to be sold next week by the Treasury is about $1.5 billion less than anticipated by analysts. A strong economy and surging tax revenue have put the Government on track for its first budget surplus in almost 30 years, and reduced its borrowing needs.
The Government will sell $16 billion of 5-year notes on Tuesday, $11 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $10 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE TRADING;
Fund Investors Buoy Stocks as Dow Recovers A Bit of Loss

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
While professional stock traders vacillated yesterday between certainty that the worst was over and fear that more declines remain ahead, mutual fund investors, who have provided crucial fuel to the market's advance in recent years, remained steadfast, if cautious.
As a result, the day was volatile, with prices swinging wildly between gains and losses but finishing generally higher. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 59.47 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,546.78. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was the second heaviest ever, after a market plunge last October, with 859.21 million shares changing hands. 
 Midsized and small stocks continued to suffer. The Nasdaq composite index eeked out a gain of 2.56, to 1,788.20, but the Russell 2000 index, a small-cap benchmark, fell seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Much of the credit for yesterday's gains might go to Abby Joseph Cohen, Goldman, Sachs & Company's widely followed investment strategist, who weighed in from Israel, where she is vacationing, to call the recent decline an "overreaction."
Ms. Cohen's comments echoed through lower Manhattan's financial district yesterday, drawing sighs of relief, if not cheers, even from traders at rival firms. On Salomon Smith Barney's giant trading floor, traders repeated Ms. Cohen's remark that "stocks are trading at undervalued levels" throughout the morning.
As on Tuesday, much of the move in the major market averages yesterday came in the last half-hour of trading, when the Dow industrials bounced from a loss of 125 points to a gain of 59 points. Earlier, the industrial average at one point was up more than 87 points.
Throughout the day, the stock market looked as if Sisyphus were in charge. Bouts of selling from computer-driven investment programs sent the market averages plunging. Slower, steadier gains followed, only to be overtaken by rapid declines.
The one clear, unwavering factor in the recent activity has been the bullish stance of Ms. Cohen. Yesterday she said that she continued to believe that earnings, Asian developments and the outlook for inflation and interest rates all support "a favorable case for equity ownership."
In an interview, Ms. Cohen said, "The recent weakness in stock prices has not been accompanied by a proportionate fundamental weakness." In addition, she said, "the latest news on the economy and corporate performance has been better than is commonly perceived."
Therefore, Ms. Cohen said, she expects the Dow industrials will "easily surpass" the 9,300 level by the end of the year. "We look at a somewhat longer time horizon," she said. "Over the longer term, the fundamentals still look quite favorable," despite any "short-term noise."
Ms. Cohen pointed out that although overall earnings for the companies in the S.& P. 500 stock index did not grow from the period a year earlier, operating profits -- measured before special charges -- rose by 5.7 percent in the quarter.
But even that is less than some investors would like to see. "At the beginning of the year, people were expecting earnings to grow 14 percent," said Robert C. Doll Jr., manager of the $2.2 billion Oppenheimer Growth fund. "While 5.7 percent is not so awful on an absolute basis, relative to the 14 percent people were expecting, it's a horrible shortfall."
Not that Mr. Doll has been selling stocks this week -- for more than a year, he has kept more than one-third of his fund's assets in cash, because he cannot justify buying when most price-earnings multiples are so high.
Over the last two weeks, however, Mr. Doll said, he has been "nibbling away," buying certain stocks as prices declined and reducing his cash position to 36 percent of assets from 42 percent.
Corporations, too, seem to see some value in the lower stock prices produced by the recent market decline. At least 15 companies announced programs this week to repurchase their own stock, said Richard Peterson, an analyst at the Securities Data Company.
Mutual fund investors did not appear to be too troubled by the market's last two days. Some fund companies, like Fidelity Investments, the country's largest, reported that investors moved relatively small amounts of money from stocks into bond and money market funds. Others, however, like the Vanguard Group, said that optimistic investors put as much money into stock funds as pessimistic investors pulled out.
Brian Mattes, a Vanguard spokesman, said a far greater number of callers to Vanguard's telephone center were interested in simply checking their account balances.
A big reason investors are not likely to be much worried is that they generally still have hefty profits in their mutual fund accounts. Since the beginning of 1995, investors have poured nearly $600 billion into mutual funds that invest primarily in American stocks and they have aggregate profits totaling 46 percent, based on a weighted-average calculation of the prices at which that money flowed into mutual funds -- 739 on the S.& P. 500 -- and where it is now, 1,081.43.
Clearly it will take more than a 3 percent decline in prices, as the market suffered Tuesday, or more than the 10 percent decline from its peak that the S.& P. 500 hit at its low yesterday, to shake investors' faith. Yesterday the S.& P. 500 rose 9.31, for a gain of nearly nine-tenths of a percent.
Foreign equity markets generally declined yesterday, following Tuesday's sharp drop on Wall Street. European stock indexes fell between 1.5 percent and 2.5 percent, while Asian markets generally declined by 1.5 percent. Japan's Nikkei index fell less sharply, however, on Tuesday, declining by two-tenths of 1 percent.
Most professional investors expect the volatility to continue. "Unfortunately, too many people have gotten used to relatively low volatility and one direction of stock movement, which is up," said Robert Bissell, president and chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management, a unit of Wells Fargo & Company.
The biggest remaining question for investors around the world is whether the weight of the bull market might be getting too heavy for Abby Cohen to keep pushing up the hill.

Tuesday marked the 22d time since 1987 that the market fell at least 5 percent from its peak over a period of a day or more. If history is any guide, the market will rebound. It is unlikely to recover all its losses in four weeks, though, as that has happened only twice. The graph shows the Dow Jones industrial average since 1987. HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE INVESTORS;
Small Stockholders Again Refuse to Panic

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Jean Taranto isn't the kind who frets over a gyrating stock market. Prices go up and down, sometimes violently, but the American economy appears to be as strong as ever, she says. All that is to say that the stock market selloff Tuesday, which saw the Dow Jones industrial average plunge 299.43 points, is just one of the things investors must get used to.
"It's nothing to get desperate about," said Ms. Taranto, a Brooklyn teacher. "The news people are making it sound like a catastrophe. But I have a lot of telephone stocks, and my stocks did O.K." 
 That attitude, one of staying the course -- investing for the long term and remaining loyal to one of the greatest bull markets in history -- has time and again guided investors through the bumps and bruises of Wall Street trading in the 1990's.
But whether such complacency -- or a lack of fear -- is enough to pull the stock market out of a nasty slump that seems to have been caused in recent weeks by continuing fears about slowing profit growth at home and the festering economic crisis in Asia is another question.
The Dow Jones industrial average rallied yesterday, closing 59.47 points higher at 8,546.78. The gains were unremarkable, and hardly a clear indication of buoyant investor sentiment. Yet they are a sign that investors are not fleeing the market.
"What am I going to do?" asks Barbara J. Lewis, who runs a bed-and-breakfast in Cornish, N.H. "I don't know what I can do. I think just waiting would be a good way to handle this."
One thing is certain: Americans have had a love affair with the stock market. They now have more of their assets tied up in stocks than at any time in the last 50 years. And that means that sharp price movements can rapidly alter an individual's financial worth, for better or worse.
Since 1990, of course, a tremendous bull-market bubble has created enormous wealth for many Americans, and created young billionaires as well. In the fall of 1987, when the stock market crashed, and the Dow industrials fell to 1,738.41, Wall Street feared a recession. But the Dow has since rebounded and then some -- rising as high as 9,337.97. The question now is: has the market run its course? And how are investors coping with a summer selloff that has erased 8.5 percent from the industrial average and much more from an array of smaller-company stocks?
The only consensus is that Americans are transfixed by stocks. Their optimism has been buttressed over the years by bullish calls of Wall Street analysts and financial planners, who have long held that times are good and that the best way to save for retirement is by investing long term in a rising market. "I don't see any alternative but to wait it out, so I don't plan to change anything," said Dale Strok, a software magazine editor in Long Beach, Calif.
Of course, it is unclear whether summer vacations are skewing trading and Wall Street impressions of investor sentiment. But retail stockbrokers and mutual fund companies said that phone lines were not jammed yesterday and that it was caution, not panic, that had set in.
And in interviews with smaller investors around the country, many of whom have weathered sharp declines, the attitude is: the market will come back. "I'm going to stay the course," said Daniel Saltzberg, 75, a retail clothing consultant. "This market has to go up to at least 10,000. The economy is great. And where else will capital go?"
Mr. Saltzberg and others point to events last summer. A sharp market downturn began in August with a currency crisis in Southeast Asia, punishing stock prices, and this set the stage for the fierce selloff on Oct. 27, when the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 554 points, or 7.2 percent, in one day. (The market slowly recovered, and went on to gain more than 30 percent in less than a year.)
So the seasonal volatility could be exaggerating the market's course. For while the summer is best known for rallies and record highs, the late summer has also been known for volatile swings in prices and sharp declines that lead to banner headlines. In August 1990, for example, the Dow lost about 10 percent of its value as the nation confronted Persian Gulf tensions caused by Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait.
Still, the knowledge that stock prices can go through violent swings, and still move higher from year to year, may be comforting investors who believe they can ride out the latest downturn. "I'm not that concerned," said Theodore Garner, 48, a financial auditor in Portland, Ore. "I've been in the market for 10 or 12 years, and I'm not going to take money out for another 10 years; so it doesn't bother me much. The gains from the mid-1980's have grown so much that it doesn't matter if the Dow slips back down to 7,000."
Mr. Garner is not alone. A nationwide poll released Monday said it would take an "unprecedented market drop" of about 1,000 points in a single day to fully shake the confidence of small investors.
Of course, such a drop in the Dow would mean a loss of 11.7 percent, a figure that would not be unprecedented. The Dow fell 22.3 percent on Oct. 19, 1987, and 7.2 percent last Oct. 27. But such a huge point decline could seem monstrous to investors, some of whom may not realize that gains in points are less significant with the Dow near the 9,000 range.
According to the survey, by America's Research Group, stockholders would alter their investments if an armed conflict broke out or with Presidential impeachment. And they could fold if the Dow plunged 1,000 points in one day. But among the biggest concerns was a rise in interest rates, the same thing that shook bull markets in 1929 and 1987.
Few strategists think that interest rates will climb in coming months. But corporate earnings are growing at their slowest pace in more than seven years and if earnings growth sends the market into reverse, the experts do not know whether smaller investors will continue to buy into the slumps.
"I still think the psychology of the small and medium investor is buy on the dips," said Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and author of "Stocks for the Long Run." "But what concerns me is not the first dip; it's the second dip. People who have bought the first dip have always been winners. But suppose the market continues to fall. Who will buy then?"

HEADLINE: Auto Dealers Settle Charges of Boycott

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
A group of 25 auto dealers in the Northwest agreed today to settle Federal charges it illegally threatened to boycott the Chrysler Corporation in an effort to thwart competition from low-priced Internet dealers.
In an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission, the car dealers, members of the Fair Allocation System Inc., agreed not to participate or threaten a boycott of any automobile manufacturer. The Montana-based group includes a substantial number of Chrysler dealerships in eastern Washington, Idaho and western Montana, the F.T.C. said. 
 The F.T.C. said the group planned to boycott the nation's third-largest car maker unless it restricted distribution to rival dealers that market on the Internet. Group members threatened to refuse to sell certain Chrysler vehicles and limit warranty service, the F.T.C. said.
The group primarily picked as a target Dave Smith Motors of Kellogg, Idaho, a Chrysler dealer that had been attracting customers by offering low, pre-determined prices via the Internet, the Federal agency said.
Chrysler allocates vehicles based on a dealer's total sales. Fair Allocation System members wanted the company to distribute based on expected number of sales in a dealer's local area. That would have substantially cut the number of cars to Dave Smith Motors, whose customers hail from a wider geographic region, the F.T.C.'s complaint contended.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Rebound a Bit In Heavy, Volatile Trading
Trading was hectic as stock market averages jumped around, but ended the day higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 59.47 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,546.78, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased nine-tenths of 1 percent, or 9.31 points, to 1,081.43. The technology-heavy Nasdaq lagged, gaining just 2.56 points, to 1,788.20.
Even so, market strategists predicted more rough spots in the next few weeks. They expect investors will now be focusing on a company's underlying business and how it is achieving its numbers. Page A1. 

G.M. Expects to Build New Plants
General Motors plans to build highly efficient assembly plants in North America using fewer workers and more outside suppliers. G.M. also said that sales in July fell sharply because of the strikes in Flint, Mich. A1.
 
Chrysler will build Mercedes sport utility vehicles at an Austrian factory and may buy a type of air bag from Mercedes, two results of the planned takeover this fall of the auto maker by Daimler-Benz. D2.
 
Economic Growth Appears to Slow
The economy was operating at a healthy pace through July, but growth showed signs of slowing as slumping exports to Asia and labor shortages were felt nationwide, the Federal Reserve said in its survey of business conditions known as the beige book. D8.
 
CBS Profits Fall Short of Estimates
Shares of CBS dropped $2, or 5.94 percent, to $31.6875, after the company's second-quarter earnings fell a penny short of analysts' expectations. Net income rose fourfold, to $4 million, because of advertising growth at its television and radio stations. Revenue rose 16 percent, to $1.48 billion. D5.
 
F.C.C. Easing Rules for Data Links
The Federal Communications Commission intends to propose rules that will accelerate the deployment of high-speed cyberspace links to homes across the nation. D4.
 
Northwest Machinists Reject Pact
Members of the International Association of Machinists rejected tentative contract agreements with Northwest Airlines and authorized a strike. D2.
 
Japan Selects a Financial Adviser
Toyoo Gyohten, who is known as a man fluent in the language and culture of the global financial markets, was named a special adviser on financial matters to the new Prime Minister of Japan, Keizo Obuchi. D3.
 
S.E.C. Official to Join Law Firm
Barry Barbash, head of the division of the Securities and Exchange Commission that regulates mutual funds, is leaving to join the Washington office of the law firm of Shearman & Sterling. D7.
 
Auto Dealers Settle F.T.C. Charges
A group of 25 auto dealers in the Northwest agreed to settle Federal charges it illegally threatened to boycott Chrysler in an effort to thwart competition from low-priced Internet dealers. D7.
 
Ernst & Young Selects Agency
Ernst & Young named D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications in New York to handle its account with worldwide billings estimated at more than $100 million. Advertising. D5.
 
30-Year Bond Yield Rises to 5.67%
The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 5.67 percent, from 5.63 percent on Tuesday. D8.

HEADLINE: View From Pataki's Garden: A Serene Campaign Strategy

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Last Sunday, Peter F. Vallone, one of four Democrats hoping to wrest the governorship from George E. Pataki this fall, spoke at three churches in New York City, held a news conference to receive an endorsement, then raced up to the Orange County fair in Middletown to press the flesh.
Mr. Pataki spent the day at home. It was not just a day off the campaign trail. It seemed to be his campaign strategy. 
 Deep into the primary season, at a time when most other candidates are running hard -- including his would-be Democratic challengers and his political mentor, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- Mr. Pataki, the Republican incumbent, seems to be barely breaking a sweat in his race for a second term as Governor. But even as Mr. Pataki paces himself, he has stepped up his aggressive campaign for national attention, with a book tour, appearances on television and fund-raising trips that have taken him far from New York.
Last week, for example, a Republican contributor in California or Colorado, where the Governor spent three days raising money for his campaign, had a better chance of getting a glimpse of Mr. Pataki than did a New York voter. He made just two public appearances in New York -- a 10-minute speech to a police chiefs' association aboard a Lake George steamboat, and a press conference called on short notice to react to the Assembly's passage of his bill to sharply curtail parole.
With Mr. Pataki enjoying enormous leads in the polls and in fund-raising, and the Democrats still facing a hotly contested primary on Sept. 15, the Governor's advisers have decided that the best way for him to campaign is not to campaign at all.
"They're probably right in thinking that way," said John Zogby, a pollster and political analyst. He noted that his most recent poll showed Mr. Pataki leading each of his challengers by more than 40 percentage points in head-to-head contests.
"This could be as close to a front-porch campaign, or a Rose Garden strategy, as we've seen in modern times," Mr. Zogby said.
Mr. Pataki is hardly the first well-placed incumbent to adopt such a strategy. Indeed, the man he defeated four years ago for the Governor's office -- Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat -- lay low on the campaign trail during his re-election races in 1986 and 1990 when he held huge leads in the polls. And just last year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York showed an equal disdain toward the Democrats clamoring for his job, including the eventual nominee, Ruth W. Messinger, whom he trounced.
But there is a risk to Mr. Pataki in embracing such a classic incumbent's gambit. In the last year, he has aggressively courted national attention and basked in the political glow as his name has been mentioned along with those of other Republicans, like Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, in connection with the race for the White House in 2000.
That has put pressure on Mr. Pataki not just to win this fall, but to win by a margin that will boost his national standing.
Aides insist that Mr. Pataki is working hard on the campaign out of the public eye, averaging two fund-raisers a week and consulting with strategists.
"We've been all over the place," said Zenia Mucha, the Governor's chief spokeswoman for the last four years, who became his campaign manager this week.
Campaign records released last month showed that Mr. Pataki had already spent $2 million on broadcast advertising, and still had $12 million in the bank, almost six times as much as any of his opponents.
But his schedule is still filled with trips that take him across the country in pursuit of thousands of dollars more in campaign money and widespread national attention. In addition to the California and Colorado trips, he is planning one next week to Virginia.
When Mr. Pataki has taken to the stump during this primary season, it has been more in the role of incumbent than candidate. He does not mention the election, and he never refers to his opponents, even to criticize them. When asked how the campaign is going, all he will say is, "Fine."
The Governor's public events around the state, generally no more than one or two in a day, are invariably billed as the usual business of being Governor, like signing bills or breaking ground for new businesses. That allows him to avoid appearing overtly political while touting his achievements, and it also permits him to travel the state and promote his record at taxpayers' expense, a luxury his competitors do not share.
His approach has also caused a drag on the campaigns of his Democratic challengers -- Mr. Vallone, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn and James L. Larocca, a former state transportation and energy commissioner -- who are hard-pressed to win attention when Mr. Pataki ignores their moves.
While Mr. Pataki is careful not to seem to be taking things for granted, his advisers are much less reserved.
When asked recently about polls showing Mr. Vallone pulling ahead of Ms. McCaughey Ross among Democratic primary voters, Ms. Mucha said: "It doesn't matter. Either way."
When it was noted that a Democratic primary victory by Mr. Vallone would set up a three-way race, because Ms. McCaughey Ross has the Liberal Party nomination, Ms. Mucha replied, "It still doesn't matter."
Even the press release earlier this week announcing that Ms. Mucha was moving from the Governor's press office to head his re-election campaign carried an air of supreme confidence. It concluded that "Mucha plans to return to the administration after the November election."
At best, it has left the Democrats hoping that the Pataki camp becomes overly confident.
"They are so over-confident -- no, don't print that," Mr. Vallone said early this week. "Better to say they think it's going to be a cakewalk."
Anyone who dropped in on Mr. Pataki in each of the last three summers, and again now, would be hard-pressed to tell which was the election year. The Governor is no more visible, except on television, and he has stuck to the same few themes -- tax cuts, job creation and fighting crime -- on the stump and in his television advertisements.
"We are winning, slowly, this fight against crime," he declared at the police chiefs' meeting last week. "We are turning the tide and now we've got to make sure the tide goes all the way out."
Gerald Benjamin, a professor of government at the State University of New York at New Paltz, said, "The Rose Garden strategy makes perfect sense."
"He's way ahead," Professor Benjamin said. "The Democrats are beating each other up, the economy's doing pretty well, and there's no voter anger this year. And when the time comes, he'll campaign more actively and blanket the airwaves.
"In his situation," he asked, "why do anything?"

HEADLINE: General Motors Plans to Build New, Efficient Assembly Plants

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Aug. 5

 BODY:
Seeking to improve the productivity and competitiveness of the world's largest company, the chairman of General Motors said today that the auto maker planned to build a new generation of highly efficient assembly plants in North America.
To the dismay of the United Automobile Workers union, the plants could use as little as half as many workers as current assembly plants do. Outside suppliers, many of them with nonunion workers, would do much work previously done by G.M. employees. 
 The plans for new assembly plants are part of a broad effort by the auto maker to transform itself into a company that designs, assembles and markets cars and trucks, but makes few of the parts.
John F. Smith Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive, said the new plants would be modeled mainly on G.M.'s efficient new operations in Brazil, and to a lesser extent on its other factories overseas. Those factories rely on outside suppliers to produce large chunks of vehicles, like fully assembled dashboards, instead of delivering lots of little parts that are bolted together on the assembly line.
But in the United States, four out every five outside auto parts factories are not unionized, so shifting work to them weakens the union's grip on the industry and erodes its membership. Last week, the union settled a strike of nearly two months at two auto parts factories in Flint, Mich. Anxiety about G.M.'s plans to follow the Brazilian model in North American manufacturing was one of many union concerns during the Flint strike, but was not resolved.
In an olive branch to the powerful U.A.W., Mr. Smith said today that he wanted to develop a closer relationship with union leaders and planned to discuss how the new factories would work. Speaking at the University of Michigan's annual auto industry conference here in this Lake Michigan resort, 200 miles northwest of Detroit, Mr. Smith also promised repeatedly that G.M. would not lay off anyone in the coming years, but would rely instead on allowing workers to retire without replacing them.
Union officials were studying today's announcement and had no immediate reaction. But the auto maker and the union have been quietly discussing the new assembly plants for weeks and the union response in these meetings has been mixed.
The union leaders are pleased that G.M. is interested in investing at all in the United States instead of overseas, but deeply troubled by the kinds of factories that G.M. plans to build.
In a rare speech and news conference, Mr. Smith presented his plans for new assembly plants for the first time, part of a broad vision to change G.M., the world's largest company in terms of sales and share of global economic output. G.M. announced on Monday that it would turn its vast auto parts subsidiary into an independent company, with stock in the subsidiary, Delphi Automotive Systems, to be distributed next year to G.M. investors. G.M. announced on Tuesday that it would combine the corporate staffs of Buick, Cadillac, Chevrolet, GMC, Oldsmobile and Pontiac into a single marketing organization that might be able to sell cars more effectively, although the names on dealerships and car models would not change.
Mr. Smith said that this week's moves had long been planned and that the strike had only delayed them a little. But Mr. Smith has also been under enormous pressure from Wall Street to take decisive action to make G.M. more competitive.
Some Wall Street analysts even asked publicly during the strike whether Mr. Smith was the right person to lead G.M., suggesting that while he had led the company back from the brink of bankruptcy after taking over in 1992, he had taken few bold moves since then and had not laid out a vision for the company's direction. Many institutional investors had expected G.M. to inflict a crushing blow to the U.A.W. at the end of a strike that cost the company $3 billion in after-tax earnings, and have pushed down the company's stock in response to the very limited settlement that actually resulted.
Mr. Smith discussed his plans for the company here at midday and G.M. stock closed at $68.375, down $1.125.
Mr. Smith refused to discuss today when or where G.M. would build its new assembly plants, which would be its first in the United States since the construction of the 7,000-employee Saturn factory in Spring Hill, Tenn. in the late 1980's. "We are planning on building some new assembly plants to replace and consolidate older plants," Mr. Smith said. "The new plants will be lean and agile in every respect, operating 24 hours a day."
After describing the large role that suppliers play in Brazil, Mr. Smith said, "We believe that vehicle manufacturing will evolve in this direction here in North America."
Ronald E. Harbour, a manufacturing consultant in Troy, Mich., said G.M. would probably start by building one of the new type of assembly plants, which could take a couple of years, and then watch how it worked before building more.
Next to each new assembly plant, G.M. plans to put a factory that could stamp hoods and other automotive body parts from sheets of steel, Mr. Smith said. That plan sheds new light on G.M.'s strong stand against the U.A.W. during the recent strike in Flint, Mich. G.M. tried unsuccessfully to stop investing in a low-productivity stamping factory in Flint that would be a logical candidate for closing if G.M. builds new stamping factories.
G.M. has already eliminated 125,000 hourly jobs in the United States since 1990 by not replacing people who retire or leave for other reasons, and thinks that it can continue reducing its work force this way, he said, adding, "We're not talking about layoffs or anything like that, we're talking about working within the window of our attrition rates."
With a steadily shrinking market share, G.M. has hired few employees since the late 1970's and has 220,000 hourly workers left in the United States, mostly represented by the U.A.W. The auto maker has 600,000 employees worldwide and continues to lag rival auto makers in terms of the number of autos that each worker produces annually.
"How do we close the productivity gap without costly work stoppages is the clear focus in my head," Mr. Smith said.
The strikes in Flint severely hurt G.M.'s sales in July. The company said today that its sales of cars and light trucks dropped 37.7 percent, as car sales plunged 45 percent while sales of sport utility vehicles, pickups and vans fell 28.1 percent. G.M.'s overall share of the light-vehicle market decreased to 21 percent, trailing the Ford Motor Company, at 27.5 percent, for the first time since a two-month strike in 1970 also crippled G.M.'s production.
G.M.'s plans to build efficient new factories might well provoke a flurry of offers of tax incentives and other financial assistance from state governments, Mexico and Canada.
Mr. Smith avoided saying whether G.M. would put any of the new assembly plants in Mexico. But he did say that G.M. was considering the construction of new plants close to existing ones. The U.A.W.'s contracts with the Big Three auto makers give workers the privilege of turning down transfers to work sites more than 50 miles away, and the workers have virtually guaranteed lifetime employment.

HEADLINE: Sex Shops Try to Obey Law, as Written

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
Despite a string of resounding legal victories by the Giuliani administration in its effort to curb New York City's sex industry, the vast majority of 144 adult video stores and strip clubs singled out by a new anti-sex shop law are investing their hopes in a novel legal strategy that a State Supreme Court Justice could either bolster or dismiss in a hearing in Manhattan today.
Who prevails in the legal battle, which is expected to generate months of appeals, will determine whether Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will be able to eradicate much of the city's sex shop industry or simply put a prettier face on it. 
 Herald Price Fahringer, a lawyer representing 107 of the 144 sex shops affected by the law, said all of his clients would try to remain open by conforming to a provision in the law that essentially says the stores are considered to be X-rated enterprises if 40 percent or more of their stock or floor space is in adult materials.
"I think all of them are going to try to stay in business," Mr. Fahringer said. "I haven't talked to anyone who said they're going to close up and move away."
Across the city, adult video stores have completed or are planning feverish renovations and bathing suit purchases that help them avoid the definition of an "adult establishment" under the law.
Store and club owners have responded by selling T-shirts, souvenirs and feature movies in 60 percent of their floor space and pornography in the rest. Strip clubs say they have confined topless dancing to less than 40 percent of their floor space.
As of yesterday, 75 percent of the stock in Show World, a sex emporium at the corner of 42d Street and Eighth Avenue that for three decades has symbolized the adult-entertainment business, was dedicated to luggage, perfume, souvenirs and other trinkets intended to capture the tourist trade, managers said.
Last night in Scores, an Upper East Side strip club that the city has so far not accused of violating the law, employees said they were trying to have the same number of strippers dance in the club, but in a small, curtained-off portion of it. Men in business suits crammed the dance area, while a vast, newly created dining area set up on the other side of the curtain was nearly empty.
Mr. Fahringer is expected to argue that because Show World has changed its inventory, it should not be closed under the law.
But city officials are expected to argue that the renovations are little more than subterfuges meant to avoid the law. City officials have refused to discuss the details of what they will present in court today. But when asked yesterday whether it would be acceptable for clubs to limit stripping to 40 percent of their premises, Steven M. Fishner, the Mayor's criminal justice coordinator, dismissed the idea.
"We don't anticipate that it's going to be a change in the utilization of the floor space," he said. "We anticipate a change in the actual use. A change from being a strip club to being some other kind of establishment."
Albert Fredericks, a former assistant corporate counsel who helped draft the law, said the clubs were trying to take advantage of wording the administration had to include to make the law constitutional.
Mirroring measures recently enacted in other cities, the law does not flatly outlaw the sale of pornographic materials or the existence of strip clubs, Mr. Fredericks said. Courts have repeatedly ruled that such bans are a violation of free speech.
"The problem is with the Constitution. It cannot be banned," he said, referring to adult material. "A law had to be drafted that dealt with the problem but still allowed reasonable access to the material."
The zoning ordinance and other city documents have specific language defining how the 60-40 ratio is to be applied, essentially measuring how much floor space and inventory are devoted to adult entertainment.
But Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, which opposes the law, said the measure was not precise enough and created an opportunity for stores to remain open.
"What happens if in addition to 1,000 videos, the store is selling 1,000 pencils?" he said. "Does that mean that there are 2,000 items? What about T-shirts or dolls? Is it one for one, each T-shirt, each pencil, each doll, is that equal to one video? Do you put them on a scale and weigh them?"
But Mr. Fishner said yesterday that he was confident the city would prevail in court. He also said inspections to find grounds to close the clubs would continue.
Supporters of the clubs say that even if they win the legal battle, it is not clear that they can remain economically viable if they can devote so little of their floor space to adult entertainment. "We're all not sure whether this is going to work," one Scores employee, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said last night.
For now, owners of the sex shops and their lawyers appear to be awaiting the result of today's hearing, which involves the city's attempt to close six clubs: Show World; NRS XXX Video on Eighth Avenue in midtown; the Harmony Theater and Harmony Theater II strip clubs on Church and West 22d Streets; Les Hommes video store on West 80th Street, and Angel's strip club on Walker Street.
Judges in Brooklyn and Staten Island yesterday granted joint requests from city lawyers and the owners of two strip clubs padlocked over the weekend, Wiggles and Shark's, that their cases be adjourned for several weeks. Individuals associated with both clubs said yesterday that clubs owners were trying to identify ways they could reopen under the new law.
Solomon Kaplan, the lawyer representing El Coche, a strip club padlocked in the Bronx last week, said its owners also hoped to somehow reopen under the new law.
Mr. Fredericks, who helped draft the law, said that while many American cities had laws restricting sex shops, New York's sex shop owners might be one of the first groups to try to battle the law even as it is being enforced. "I think I've read just about every decision out there," he said. "There is very little out there that deals with this."

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE OUTLOOK;
Market Gyrations May Point To Shift in Investor Strategy

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
For the last three years investors have been sleepwalking their way to riches in the stock market. Putting money into a stock index fund -- a one-decision move -- has proved not only the best way to avoid underperforming the averages, but also the path to outsized profits. The Vanguard Group's fund that mirrors the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has almost doubled since the end of 1994.
But the heyday of this particular investment strategy may have ended on Tuesday when the Dow Jones industrial average lost 300 points. Even though the major market averages rebounded ever so slightly yesterday, the sharp drop on Tuesday, coming on top of recent weakness, belied what might be the beginning of a big shift in investor psychology. 
 Trading was extremely heavy and exceedingly volatile yesterday. More shares traded hands on the New York Stock Exchange than had during the big drop on Tuesday. The averages whipsawed up and down all day, with the Dow ending up almost 60 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, and the S.& P. 500 rising almost 1 percent. The Nasdaq lagged, gaining only fourteen-hundredths of a percent on the day. Page D1.
Although investors were undoubtedly relieved that stocks held their own, the market's chop was discomforting. Market strategists predicted more rough spots in the weeks to come. "If we were down another 600 points on the Dow, I wouldn't be surprised," said Carey Leahey, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics, a investment consulting firm in Valhalla, N.Y. "Not that the U.S. fundamentals aren't good, it's just that they're not good enough to sustain stock valuations."
Until Tuesday, investors had seemed to shrug off the idea that rising stock valuations had to be sustained by ever-rising corporate earnings. Now, the relationship between a company's stock price and its earnings is front and center for both professional and individual investors across the nation.
That reassessment makes some market watchers believe a profound shift in stock market strategy is under way. What has worked in the past may not work in the future.
"Boring is going to outperform sexy," said Robert Olstein, manager of the Olstein Fund and a veteran of Wall Street and its passing fads. Instead of just looking at where a company's stock price is headed, investors will be focusing on the company's underlying business and how well it is performing. "There is going to be more looking behind the numbers, more scrutiny paid to nonrecurring write-offs, more religion adopted."
What that leads Mr. Olstein to conclude is a return to active money management, the type of hands-on stock picking that comes from analyzing balance sheets and income statements. If this type of strategy becomes more profitable than buying a fixed basket of stocks, a practice known as indexing, it would represent a big change. Last year, only 10 percent of money managers who actively select stocks outperformed the S.& P. 500, down from 70 percent in 1993.
To be sure, money managers have been predicting for several years that active management would once again beat the indexers' returns. So far, the prediction has been premature. Still, no investment strategy remains on top forever. As the big capitalization stocks weaken and the indexes appear to lose some of their impressive momentum, the argument for hands-on stock picking gains more credibility.
With the two most widely followed market gauges down nearly 9 percent from their July peaks on no fresh bad news, a change in market psychology has clearly taken place. If Mr. Olstein is right about the new direction, and a chorus of fund managers agree with him, then investors may begin shunning the index strategy that has been so popular in recent years. In the first five months of this year, 18 percent of the net cash flows into equity mutual funds went to index funds, up from 11 percent in the comparable period of 1996, according to Strategic Insight, a New York mutual fund research and consulting company.
Certainly, with corporate profitability looking weaker and weaker, stocks that have taken the indexes to all-time record valuations -- Coca-Cola, Microsoft, Dell Computer, General Electric -- are much more vulnerable to disappointment than they were when earnings expectations were rosier. Wall Street analysts began the year believing that the earnings among the S.& P. 500 companies would rise 8.5 percent in 1998. Seven months later, these forecasters say earnings will grow only 5.6 percent. This may turn out to be optimistic as well.
Given that the stocks in the S.& P. 500 are trading at 25.66 times their earnings of the last year, some stock prices carry significant premiums to what they will likely produce in earnings growth this year.
The result? "I think we'll see a shift in what stocks the market punishes," said Nancy Tengler, money manager at Global Alliance Value Investors in San Francisco. "Investors will say 'I can pay 12 times earnings for 12 percent earnings growth or I can pay 50 times earnings for the same 12 percent growth in the case of Coke.' You're going to see people move more defensively."
One reason for this, Ms. Tengler believes, is that the volatility of recent weeks -- the Dow up 100 points one day, down 100 points the next -- is more than most investors want from their stock portfolios. Although they still believe the stock market is the place to be, they may want to take a more defensive posture.
Tuesday's market plunge may not have convinced all investors that their old practices of chasing earnings surprises and big market movers no longer work. But several brokers who deal with small investors said that most of their customers' calls yesterday came from those wishing to reconfigure their portfolios in a more sensible way. These investors were weeding out high-fliers for more stable names.
Whereas in recent months, the sexier the stock the better -- think high-flying Internet companies with no profits and maybe no revenues -- the dullest companies in the doggiest sectors may now be where the greatest profits lie, analysts say.
As it happens, investors reconstituting their portfolios have the chance to buy some stocks at fairly reasonable prices. The average New York Stock Exchange issue has lost more than a quarter of its value from the high, while the average Nasdaq stock is down more than 35 percent. This damage has produced buying opportunities unseen for years by value investors.
"This is an opportunity to buy companies that pay you for uncertainty up front via a dividend and generate earnings growth going forward," Ms. Tengler said. "And they're cheap."
Ms. Tengler recently identified 180 stocks in the S.& P. 500 that she considers good buys because of their relatively high dividends. At the end of 1996, she found 140 such stocks.
Stocks that look attractive to Ms. Tengler include Halliburton, the oil service company; Eastman Kodak; Phillip Morris; H. J. Heinz, and American Home Products, the pharmaceutical concern.
Mr. Olstein likes semiconductor equipment makers like the Altera Corporation and Xilinx Inc., and oil service concerns such as the Rowan Companies. He also says companies building the infrastructure for communications will be winners -- especially Superior Telecom and Corning Inc. -- as will beaten-down steelmakers LTV and AK Steel Holding.
Will old-fashioned stock picking once again outperform the indexes as it did in previous eras? They say that everything old becomes new again, even perhaps in the world of investing. If so, investors can welcome back the age of reason.

 BODY:

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
LTX ANNOUNCES IT WILLREVAMP AND REDUCE WORK FORCE

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
The LTX Corporation, a supplier of semiconductor test equipment, said yesterday that it would reorganize operations in the fourth quarter because of a downturn in the worldwide semiconductor market. The company, based in Westwood, Mass., will cut about 30 percent of its work force, or about 300 jobs. The company expects to record a fourth-quarter charge of $40 million to $50 million for the revamping and a write-down of inventory. Shares of LTX fell 68.75 cents, to $3.0625, a 52-week low.

HEADLINE: NEWS WATCH;
Japanese Senior Managers Are Lagging in Internet Access

BYLINE: By BRUCE HEADLAM 

 BODY:
Remember a couple of years ago when Americans believed that Japanese business could do no wrong? Neither does anybody else, apparently. The newly formed legions of Japan-bashers can look for more ammunition in a recent study on Internet usage. According to a survey by Andersen Consulting, only 71 percent of Japanese executives have access to the Internet, the lowest level among senior management in nine of the world's leading economies. 
 American executives led the field, with 99 percent having access to the Internet, followed by executives from Canada (98 percent), France (91 percent) and Britain (91 percent). Only 13 percent of Japanese executives were reported as "comfortable" or "familiar" with the Internet, compared with 46 percent of American executives, although the Japanese were much more likely to use E-mail (69 percent) than their counterparts in Germany (55 percent).
