HEADLINE: Bach, Tangos And the Beach

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
The Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival, which opens its 15th season this weekend at the Bridgehampton Presbyterian Church, was started for reasons that were entirely noncommercial but sensible nonetheless. Marya Martin, a flutist from New Zealand who settled in Manhattan, and Ken Davidson, who ran his own investment company, had recently married, and Mr. Davidson was dismayed by the prospect that Ms. Martin would be spending her summers traveling the festival circuit while he worked in the city and spent weekends on his own in the Hamptons.
From what Mr. Davidson and Ms. Martin could tell, there was no great demand for chamber music in the Hamptons; concerts they had been to in the early 1980's were poorly attended. Nevertheless, when Mr. Davidson flew to New Mexico to hear his wife perform at the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, two weeks after their wedding, he had a proposal. Why didn't Ms. Martin start her own festival so that they could spend their summers together? 
 As the new festival's director, Mr. Davidson raised the $15,000 budget for the first season, and as artistic director, Ms. Martin invited three colleagues -- the violinist Ani Kavafian, the cellist Fred Sherry and the pianist Andre-Michel Schub -- to join the endeavor. She also persuaded the initially reluctant elders of the Presbyterian Church to let her present her concerts in the sanctuary of their 19th-century building.
That first summer, the festival was really just a pair of concerts, each a different program but both devoted entirely to standard fare, from Telemann through Mendelssohn and Dvorak. Since then the festival has grown slowly, and this year it has a budget approaching $300,000, with a roster of 25 musicians who will join forces through Aug. 25 in various combinations for six regular programs, plus an opening benefit and a children's program.
In addition to the festival, concertgoers can attend programs offered in the Hamptons this month by two musical training institutes.
Because the Bridgehampton Festival performances are held in a 440-seat church, the configuration of which puts everyone close to the performers, there is a level of intimacy that the players consider close to what has historically been the chamber music ideal -- or at least, closer than they often find during the season, when tours take them to all-purpose halls better suited to larger forces.
Actually, much of the standard repertory, written before 1900, was composed to be heard in even smaller spaces than the church; composers' wealthy patrons commissioned works for semi-private performances in their own salons and drawing rooms. On the other hand, 20th-century chamber works, which are now a significant part of the repertory, were composed with concert halls in mind.
Indeed, the contemporary repertory, particularly American music, has been an increasingly important part of the programming mix at Bridgehampton. Ms. Martin's concerts adhere to the current programming fashion, in which diverse works are linked by common thematic threads. So besides all-Bach and all-Mozart programs, there is a concert called "American Sounds," with works ranging from Gershwin theater songs to Copland's Sextet and recent works by Ned Rorem and Eric Ewazen, as well as a program called "The South American Soul," with works by Ginastera, Villa-Lobos, Nazareth and Piazzolla. Another program, "East Meets West," looks at Asian influences on Western composers.
Even the most programmatically amorphous concert -- the opening night program, which includes Stravinsky's "Histoire du Soldat," a flute transcription of the Faure Violin Sonata and a Dvorak Piano Quartet (Op. 87) -- has a theme of sorts, the journey from Romanticism to early modernism.
 
Bach and Mozart Sell
"Juggling the programs is the tough part," said Ms. Martin, who discusses ideas with her colleagues and accepts suggestions from them, but who in the end is responsible for both the individual programs and the shape of the festival as a whole.
"This year I came up with another three programs I would love to do," she continued, "but which I'll have to save for another year. In the 'American Sounds' program, for example, I was going to do a concert in which everything was related to the year 1900. Kurt Weill was born that year, as was Aaron Copland. So was Colin McPhee, whose 'Balinese Ceremonial Music' we're including in 'East Meets West.' But then, I wanted to do the Rorem, because it's his 75th birthday, and this Eric Ewazen piece for flute, French horn and piano is quite fantastic. So the 1900 concert will have to wait."
There are also what Ms. Martin regards as necessary compromises; the Gershwin works on the "American Sounds" program, for example, are meant as drawing cards.
"If I programmed Copland, Ewazen, Rorem and something else that people didn't know," she said, "we may not be able to sell the house. And I've got to think of that, too."
But Ms. Martin said the all-Bach and all-Mozart programs made it easier for her to sell the more adventurous ones.
"I feel that the Bach and Mozart concerts help give me as much leeway as I need for the 'American Sounds,' 'South American Soul' and 'East Meets West' programs," she explained.
"I want the average concertgoer to feel there is something for them to go to, and if someone who hasn't attended the festival before sees the series, they may buy tickets to the Mozart concert, but they will probably then buy tickets to something else as well. Rarely do people buy only one concert. We've found that most people buy tickets to three."
The festival has been a popular draw since the beginning. When it opened for business in 1984, Ms. Martin and Ms. Kavafian were rehearsing backstage just before the concert when Mr. Davidson asked them to come to the front of the church, where a long line had formed on the path leading to the door.
 
After Practice, Picnics
The festival is also popular among the musicians. They say that because Bridgehampton is a small community -- and because many of them stay at the homes of board members while they are playing at the festival -- they have gotten to know the audience.
"There is a wonderful social scene at the festival," said Mr. Sherry, the cellist who was a regular in the festival's early days. "I don't know if people understand how important the social scene is, among musicians. In the early days especially, it really was a mom-and-pop festival, and everybody was involved in everything. We'd spend the day hanging around the church, rehearsing, then we'd all go to lunch at a coffee house, then back to rehearse some more. Then we might practice on our own, then go to the beach, where we'd all have picnics. It was idyllic, and the music making was very relaxed."
Though Mr. Sherry is traveling this summer, he said he expected to return in other seasons.
The musicians also say that the festival, more than many others on the summer circuit, allows them time to perform in a far less pressured atmosphere than they are used to during the regular concert season.
Alan Kay, a clarinetist who is playing in all but the Bach and Mozart concerts this summer, said: "During the season, you're playing chamber music but also rushing around doing 10 other things. At Bridgehampton, the schedule keeps us pretty busy, but it's not pressured. We have three or four days to put each program together, and it's very collegial. We also have time to go out after concerts, or hang out at the beach, and all that adds pleasure to playing the concerts."
 
Surviving the Heat
Ms. Martin said she considered the church where the performances are held to be one of the pleasures of the festival.
"It's very New Englandy," she said. "It's got a beautiful spire, and because Long Island is so flat, if you're at all above the tree line, you can see it. And the building is very pretty; it's all white, white inside, with white benches and a red carpet. And the acoustics blew me away when I first went there, years ago. That's why we wanted to do it there."
The church is not air-conditioned, however, and that has been a mixed blessing. For Mark Peskavov, a violinist who is playing on the opening program, and who has played at the festival in past years, the heat has its charms.
"Because of the lack of air-conditioning," he said, "the door is open when we rehearse, and people who were outside, going about their business, hear the rehearsal and wander in. I don't recall the musicians ever minding that. It's part of the casual atmosphere."
But the heat has wrought some near disasters. The violinist Ida Kavafian, who was a Bridgehampton regular in the festival's early years (her sister Ani having been on the founding roster), but who now has a festival of her own, Music From Angel Fire, in Taos, N.M., pointed out that heat and humidity tend to affect precious instruments adversely.
"One summer my sister was playing first violin in the Mendelssohn Octet on the second half of a program," Ms. Kavafian said, "and she got to the concert, warmed up and went out to listen to the first half of the concert. When she got back at intermission, the tailpiece on her Strad had broken, everything was in pieces. So they asked the audience if anyone had a violin that wasn't too far away. Someone brought one, and the show did go on.
"But it's a funny thing about Bridgehampton. It's like a collective attitude about 'we don't need air-conditioning.' Everyone seems to go out of their way not to have it."
Ms. Martin said that she'd happily raise money to air-condition the church, but that the elders were not interested. The festival has survived the heat, as well as the economic and scheduling vagaries of presenting a music festival.
And it has changed. At first a small band of musicians remained together as a troupe for the entire festival. Now, most of the players are on hand for only a single performance. That said, Ms. Martin has focused on her guests' specialties.
The pianists Claude Frank and Lilian Kallir, for example, are lending their expertise in Mozart's two-piano music to the all-Mozart program. The harpsichordist Robert Wolinsky will play Bach, and Pablo Ziegler, a commanding tango player, is the pianist in the Latin American program.
In 1994 and 1995, Ms. Martin sought to extend the festival's reputation -- and get second performances for some of the more interesting works -- in a series at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan during the concert season. But when she realized that it would take too many years of deficits before she could get proper foundation or private support for a Manhattan series, she shelved the idea.
In 1996, the Bridgehampton Festival itself took a sabbatical for the sake of reorganization (but it's still calling its current season its 15th). Mr. Davidson, who had retired, became the festival's chairman, and Ms. Martin hired a staff to help with the administrative work.
In 1986, the festival's third season, Ms. Martin began bringing in new American music, with works by Mr. Rorem, Arthur Foote and William Schuman. Soon music by John Corigliano, David Diamond, Ellen Taaffe Zwilich, Roberto Sierra, Jonathan Kramer, Lukas Foss, Leonard Bernstein and Henry Cowell, as well as a humorous work by Peter Schickele and arrangements of jazz classics by Louis Armstrong, rounded out the festival's prospectus, along with standard repertory and 18th- and 19th-century rarities.
Mr. Rorem's work on this summer's "American Sounds" program, "Bright Music," was commissioned by the festival for a 1988 premiere, and is making a second appearance. Musicians from the festival also recorded it, along with Mr. Rorem's "Winter Pages," for New World Records.
 
Off the Beaten Track
The festival has also commissioned works from Mr. Bunch and Bruce MacCombie, and Ms. Martin said her dream was to commission eight works for a single festival, with one performed on each program.
But commissioned pieces are expensive, and until she raises the money, Ms. Martin can expand the festival's repertory by looking around during the regular concert season. Since she plays on all the festival programs, her explorations in the flute repertory turn up both new and familiar works. She has also discovered a few out-of-the-way composers, like Louise Dumont Farrenc, a 19th-century French composer whose work Ms. Martin brought to the festival in 1995.
Besides playing recitals and teaching at Boston University and the Manhattan School of Music, Ms. Martin is a member of the New York Wind Soloists, a quintet with David Jolley, the hornist; Steven Taylor, the trombonist; Frank Morelli, the bassoonist, and Mr. Kay, the clarinetist. Some of the pieces that have been on the quintet's programs have found their way to the festival, too, and her colleagues have introduced her to composers like Mr. Ewazen, whose Horn Sonata is in Mr. Jolley's repertory.
The quintet also plays a Mozart program in which, like the one at this summer's festival, Mozart's letters are read between works. And the "East Meets West" program was influenced by the quintet's work on pieces by Mr. McPhee and other composers.
 
Other Festivals
Other musicians have started festivals in the area more recently. Several flourished for a few years and then folded. Those that have survived tend to offer, as Bridgehampton does, a few condensed weeks of programming, and avoid overlapping with the competition. That way festival administrators don't have to worry about fragmenting the audience and listeners can partake of one festival after another.
The Festival of the Hamptons, which has been directed by Lukas Foss for the last two years, has already run its course. In July, it offered 10 days of concerts in Southampton, East Hampton, Westhampton and Bridgehampton. But two musical training institutes that present public concerts are still running.
Three years ago, the violinist Itzhak Perlman and his wife, Toby, transformed the Hamptons Summer Music festival into a training camp. Now called the Perlman Training Program, and based in East Hampton, it offers private lessons, chamber music coaching classes and orchestral sessions, as well as tennis lessons, to gifted young (pre-college) musicians.
Between Aug. 14 and 27, the students will present several public performances, including an open chorus and orchestra rehearsal conducted by Mr. Perlman. The camp was Mrs. Perlman's idea, but Mr. Perlman seems happy to devote part of his summer to it.
"This program is very dear to me," Mr. Perlman said. "It gives me a chance to coach, conduct, teach and to learn from my students. What more could I ask for?"
 
More Classical Music
Another institute, Pianofest in the Hamptons, is based in Southampton and runs through Aug. 11. Its main focus is a series of master classes for 30 students from around the world, ages 16 to 27, but there are also public concerts, including a marathon tomorrow evening in which a dozen students will play works they have studied in the classes. Pianofest, which is celebrating its 10th anniversary, is the direct result of a visit to the Bridgehampton Festival by the pianist Paul Schenly.
"After one of the concerts," said Barbara Goldowksy, the manager of Pianofest, "Paul went backstage to say hello to Andre-Michel Schub, and while he was there he began speaking with a local man named Bill Plate, who told him that the Hamptons needed more classical music and invited him to start something new."
Ms. Martin is protective of her festival. When another ensemble sought permission to hold a festival in the church where the Bridgehampton concerts are held, she argued against it -- and prevailed -- on the grounds that her festival had a close association that she preferred to keep exclusive. Still, she speaks highly of festivals taking place elsewhere in the Hamptons, and says that "if they can survive, it's better for music."
"We do have a very loyal audience," she added. "There is a woman who sits in the front row, who's been sitting there ever since we started. I say hello to her when I walk out on stage. I don't know her name, but it's as if she's part of the family."

HEADLINE: Retailers Report Strong July As Shoppers Flock to Stores

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
It took retailers more than a year to catch up with the stellar American economy, and now, as growth slows slightly and the stock market behaves erratically, shoppers are showing no signs of slowing their spending.
Retailers yesterday reported the strongest July same-store sales in five years, a result of robust demand for clothing and housewares. The figures resumed a trend that began with a 10.2 percent gain in April and a 7.1 percent rise in May. Sales stumbled slightly in June, increasing 4.4 percent. 
 Goldman, Sachs & Company's retail composite index rose 4.8 percent last month, compared with figures from the month a year earlier, the best July gain since 1993, when sales rose 5.4 percent. Same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least one year, are considered the best measure of a retailer's health. Undeterred by hot weather, shoppers filled their carts with ceiling fans, bathing suits, spiral notebooks and planting soil -- indeed nearly every category of merchandise flew off the shelves, much of it at full price.
Leading economic indicators pointed to strong demand.
"All our key indicators are flashing green," said Richard N. Baum, a retail analyst at Goldman, Sachs. "Real wage growth was up in June, the most recent month, 3.2 percent, which is the strongest in 25 years. Real personal consumption expenditures were up 5.3 percent in June, and you'd have to go back to about 1983 to find the last time that number was over 5 percent. And housing turnover, which is a key indicator of sales of home-related products, was running up 14.7 percent in June."
The big winners were specialty apparel stores, which for years lagged behind the rest of the industry as consumers stocked up on basic casual clothes that have become the staple of the American wardrobe. The church of basics, Gap Inc., reported sales gains of 19 percent, with strong performances in all of its divisions, which include Gap Kids, Old Navy and Banana Republic.
Other specialty stores showed similar gains. Limited Inc. said same-store sales were up 7 percent, and Ann Taylor Stores reported same-store sales gains of 23.2 percent.
Among merchants of off-price clothing, which has been extremely popular with shoppers for more than two years, the story was the same. Ross Stores reported gains of 7 percent, the TJX Company said its sales rose 9 percent and Value City reported gains of 6 percent.
"There was a lengthy period when apparel underperformed," Mr. Baum said. "So there was some pent-up demand, and we are still seeing some residual of that. And there are favorable demographics: Teen-agers are the fastest-growing group, and they spend a lot of money on clothes."
The strong apparel sales only made weaker players stand out more. Sears, Roebuck & Company said its sales rose a mere 1.7 percent, mostly because of a weakness in their apparel department. At the J. C. Penney Company, sales fell 5.7 percent.
At the same time, department store results were mixed. Kohl's, which sells less expensive merchandise, said sales rose 10.4 percent, and Saks Holdings said sales rose 9.9 percent. But Dillard Department Stores reported a sales decline of 2 percent, and Mervyn's, a unit of Dayton Hudson, said sales fell 3.1 percent.
Department stores are likely to continue feeling the squeeze from the off-price shops, as are discounters, where apparel accounts for about one-third of their merchandise. Wal-Mart Stores said its sales rose 7.1 percent, compared with figures in the month a year earlier, while Target, another Dayton Hudson unit, reported a 6.7 percent gain.
All these strong sales bode well for profits. "Most retailers are entering the third fiscal quarter with very clean inventories and the wind at their backs," Mr. Baum said. "They ought to have really good second-quarter earnings."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Foreign Economic Warning Hurts American Express

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Nervous investors drove shares of the American Express Company down 6.8 percent yesterday after the company warned that its growth overseas would be hampered by the Asian financial crisis and by a softening of the global economy.
"Given the interdependencies among markets, the effects of Asia will eventually spill over," Harvey Golub, the chief executive of American Express, told analysts at a meeting in New York on Wednesday. "We can expect to see the impact of Asia on Latin America, and have seen it to some extent in Europe and the U.S." 
 American Express is one of the most geographically diverse United States companies and, while no single company is a proxy for financial developments overseas, many analysts and investors look to American Express for insights about global business prospects -- particularly as they pertain to the company's core travel services and credit and charge card operations.
Mr. Golub said American Express had hoped, within a "reasonable time frame," to increase its overseas profit 25 percent to 30 percent a year, with earnings from abroad accounting for half of overall profit.
"The current economic slowdown, however, is depressing the financial results of both our card and travel business and will likely delay our progress in attaining these 'mix' goals," he told the analysts.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, shares of American Express plunged $7.375 yesterday, to $101.0625, on nearly five times the normal trading volume.
"I don't think the sky is falling because it's too early to figure it out," said Samuel Liss, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston. "I think the Asian problem and the impact of the euro on their foreign-exchange business are among some of the things they need to consider."
Mr. Golub spoke privately with the analysts on Wednesday, and the company did not widely distribute copies of his statements until yesterday.
In his remarks, Mr. Golub said he thought the company would "continue to do well, but it will not be as easy or simple to match the performance of the last two quarters."
American Express has posted solid financial results lately, driven by an upswing in its card business and tighter expense controls. The company recently reported that its second-quarter profit increased 11 percent, to $578 million, compared with $520 million in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 8 percent, to $4.8 billion.
But Mr. Golub said there were important unknowns, including the possibility of further economic deterioration in Japan or a downturn in China, as possible "risks in our ability to cope."
Another blow for American Express was its decision this year not to bid on the United States Government's card account, which had been an important account to the company in terms of billing volume and number of cards. Mr. Golub said American Express was not willing to go after a contract with the Government if a bidding war meant that that the profitability of its card business would suffer.
Some analysts thought that the stock market overreacted yesterday to Mr. Golub's comments, noting that the warning was evidence of cautious management and a prudent approach, given current economic uncertainties.
"I look at this company and think they have a lot of flexibility on the expense side and have a strong financial cushion," said Susan Roth of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. She added that "all financial service companies are considering how their resources should be managed, given the spillover from Asia."

HEADLINE: Chrysler's Chief Will Fare Quite Well in Daimler Merger

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Whether the merger of Chrysler and Daimler-Benz succeeds or not, Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, is guaranteed to do well, documents released by the companies showed yesterday.
To persuade Mr. Eaton, 58, to stay on for three years under the combined DaimlerChrysler, he can earn nine extra years on his pension -- in addition to the three he would earn anyway. Those nine extra years alone are worth $30,000 a month for the rest of his life. 
 But if he quits or is dismissed during the two years after the merger, he will be paid $24.4 million, with DaimlerChrysler paying the "golden parachute" tax for him and the taxes on the compensation paid to cover the tax.
And he will also get stock appreciation rights on 2.27 million shares of DaimlerChrysler, a benefit worth almost $23 million for each $10 rise in the price of the company's shares.
Severance benefits and stock appreciation rights were also issued to 29 other Chrysler executives, but only Mr. Eaton was given the pension sweetener.
The pay plans were disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the the No. 3 United States auto maker and the German luxury-car company in anticipation of closing their merger in November.
Chrysler has scheduled a special shareholder meeting for Sept. 18 in Wilmington, Del., to vote on the merger.
Investors will be issued DaimlerChrysler shares, which will trade on exchanges around the world, including the New York Stock Exchange. Each Chrysler share will be exchanged for 0.6235 share of DaimlerChrysler. A holder of 100 Chrysler shares would be issued 62 shares of the new company and a cash payment for the difference, the companies said.
Daimler-Benz shareholders will exchange shares on a one-for-one basis unless 90 percent swap their shares for DaimlerChrysler stock, in which case they will receive a bonus of one-half of a percent, giving them 1.005 shares of DaimlerChrysler for each Daimler-Benz share. That bonus is so small that either way, Daimler-Benz shareholders will have 58 percent of the new company and Chrysler shareholders the remaining 42 percent.
In a sign of how the global economy will make life more complicated for investors, the two companies said that Americans who hold DaimlerChrysler shares would also face new tax complications. One-quarter of each dividend payment will be withheld to pay German taxes, but by filing a German tax form most of the tax can be refunded, the companies said.
The merger highlights key differences in the compensation styles of German and American companies.
No compensation details were disclosed for Jurgen Schrempp, the chairman of Daimler-Benz, and the nine other top executives there because their compensation packages are not being changed by the deal. Mr. Schrempp was paid no more than $2 million last year, compared with $6.1 million in salary, bonus, incentive pay and other cash for Mr. Eaton, who also made $5.3 million from exercising stock options.
When the merger is complete, Mr. Eaton will also receive $66.2 million in DaimlerChrysler stock in exchange for Chrysler options of the same value, and $3.7 million in cash, the bonus he earned for the first 11 months of the year under Chrysler's pay plan.
Chris P. Theodore, a vice president for engineering at Chrysler, said that he and colleagues were joking recently about how they hope compensation changes after the merger. "What we said was: 'We have a great idea. We'll have Daimler vacation policy and Chrysler pay policy,' " Mr. Theodore said.

HEADLINE: Reprieve for the Salmon

 BODY:
The United Nations has declared 1998 the International Year of the Ocean. This has provided a pretext for lofty talk about rescuing the oceans from pollution and overfishing, but not, as yet, much useful action. Recent decisions by Canada and Greenland to close down commercial fishing for Atlantic salmon originating in North American rivers are thus cause for celebration.
Wild Atlantic salmon -- as opposed to the farm-raised variety most people find on their menus -- have been declining at an alarming rate. Industrial wastes, polluted runoff from farms and the construction of dams killed most of the salmon spawning in the United States by the late 19th century, leaving only a handful of precarious wild runs, all in Maine. Canadian salmon have also dwindled. Scientists estimate that the number of large fish returning to Canadian rivers, mostly spawning females, reached an all-time low of 114,000 this year, one-sixth the number of 20 years ago and barely half the number required to sustain the species over the long term. 
 The decline continued despite Canada's decision to shut down a large commercial fishing ground in Newfoundland in 1993, as well as temporary measures to reduce the salmon catch near Greenland, where the fish congregate in large numbers before returning to their native rivers. In desperation, Canada closed its last remaining commercial fishery, in Labrador, on June 9.
Three days later, influenced by Canada's example and by entreaties from Canada's Atlantic Salmon Federation and Britain's Atlantic Salmon Trust, Greenland agreed to close its commercial fishery. This was a courageous step because there are not many other jobs for unemployed fishermen in Greenland. On the other hand, the move could ultimately save Canada's recreational fishing industry, valued at $100 million a year.
The decision will be reviewed in one year, and will presumably be renewed if mortality rates do not improve. In the meantime, Greenland will be allowed a subsistence catch for local consumption, while thousands of wild Atlantic salmon receive a badly needed reprieve from the gill nets.
The reprieve will also allow conservation groups, and Washington and Ottawa, to turn their energies to other threats facing Atlantic salmon. These include polluted watersheds and dams that have outlived their usefulness as sources of power and serve only to diminish the future of a once-flourishing species.

HEADLINE: RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE;
A Neighborhood Called Dumbo Has High Hopes

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A 1915 warehouse overlooking the Brooklyn waterfront that had been used as an office building in the last decade is now being converted into condominium lofts, offering views of the East River and the Manhattan skyline.
The $30 million conversion of the Clock Tower Building at One Main Street is the latest step in the slow transformation of the gritty swath of land between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges into a contemporary urban address. The onetime manufacturing area is known as Dumbo, for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass. 
 When the developer, the Two Trees Management Company of Brooklyn, completes the conversion in October, the 16-story building will be the first in Dumbo to become housing. It will have 124 one- to three-bedroom apartments, all with 11-foot-high ceilings and some with dens or home offices.
Most units will range in size from 1,161 to 2,592 square feet and in price from $220,000 to $980,000. Three lower-floor units are priced from $160,000 to $180,000, and three 3,200-square-foot apartments in the tower, to be offered as unfinished space, are to cost from $1.5 million to $2 million.
The company, which for 18 years has owned 2 million square feet of space in eight area buildings, plans over the next year to convert two of its nearby vacant buildings into 150 more units. The plan ultimately is for a total of 1,000 residences, David C. Walentas, its president, said.
"I always envisioned having residential here, and now, I got lucky," he said, noting that all the ingredients -- from a strong economy to a tight housing market -- were in place.
A ripple effect from Manhattan is benefiting the Brooklyn housing market, especially neighborhoods like Brooklyn Heights, which is adjacent to Dumbo. "There is a dearth of product," said Christopher D. Thomas, sales director at the Brooklyn office of William B. May, the Manhattan brokerage concern. But this is the first project for that area, he added, and the test is if buyers will be willing "to step into an unestablished area and pay prices consistent with those in Brooklyn Heights for a product with features -- space and views -- not widely available."
In addition, they will be betting that the area, desolate at night, will develop "with residential services and night life," he said, observing, however, that "the area is next door to Brooklyn Heights, an established neighborhood, and three long blocks from bodegas and restaurants."
In the two weeks since sales opened, contracts have been signed on 30 apartments. Jed Walentas, the project manager for his father, said prices would soon be increased by "as much as 15 percent on some units, and not at all on others" in response to demand.
Since he bought the buildings, David Walentas's vision has been to turn the area into a SoHo-like neighborhood. In the intervening years, he has renovated four buildings into office space and upgraded others to enhance their use as storage or warehouse space as well as artists' studios.
The area's zoning, however, did not permit turning the buildings into housing. But last year, the developer won rezoning from the city for two blocks, in and around where the Clock Tower sits. At the same time, the building, which Two Trees had renovated into offices at a cost of $20 million, was losing its tenant, the city's Department of Labor.
Those factors, along with the building's size and views, made it ideal for conversion, Mr. Walentas said, adding: "Part of what people are buying is the future of the area, and this will set the tone for later conversions."
Amenities planned for the project, designed by the Manhattan firm of Beyer Blinder Belle, include a concierge and rooftop deck. There will also be underground parking, for an added charge, for 120 cars in a building across the street. Financing is coming from a $30 million construction loan from the Emmes Asset Management Company, also in Manhattan.
Mitchell Maxwell, with his wife and two children, will relocate to a 2,100-square-foot Clock Tower loft from a condo in Manhattan. Mr. Maxwell, a Broadway and film producer, said he was about to buy a similar-size apartment in Manhattan for $1.1 million, but instead bought the 12th-floor loft for $550,000.
Estimates are that monthly maintenance fees will be $199 to $1,048. Tax abatement from the city will help keep real estate taxes low for 10 years. The taxes, which are not included in the estimated maintenance figures, are to range from $42 to $220 a month; without the abatement, they would be $135 to $710 a month.
Verdell Bivins, district manager for Community Board 2, said many area residents thought the conversion was "good because it will bring people into the community." But, she said, "what potentially concerns residents is that the developer will operate unilaterally" on his plan for the waterfront area.
Six months ago, the city "conditionally designated" Mr. Walentas as the redeveloper for city-owned land beneath the two bridges. And over the last year, he has been negotiating with the state to redevelop its waterfront property, comprising a three-acre state park and seven Civil War-era warehouses. Mr. Walentas had been designated the developer for both sites in 1982, but that project never came to fruition.
The developer's proposal calls for retail stores, a 100-slip marina and expansion of the park to nine acres, including an esplanade, a movie theater and parking garages.
Meanwhile, the Downtown Brooklyn Waterfront Local Development Corporation, established in December by the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, and other Brooklyn officials, is pursuing, with community input, the redevelopment of five piers into a park.
"We want input into the development of the entire waterfront, not just the piers, to insure that there is a comprehensive plan in place," and that the community's primary goals of open space and public access are met, Ms. Bivins said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The condominium conversion of the Clock Tower Building in Brooklyn includes unfinished apartment space in the tower. Formerly a warehouse, the building offers views of the Manhattan skyline and the East River. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Region Gains Jobs, but Gap in Incomes Widens

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut continue to benefit from robust job growth, but the income gap has widened sharply between the highest- and lowest-paid workers, according to two reports released yesterday.
Perhaps most striking, at a time of huge gains on Wall Street, an analysis by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York found that full-time workers near the bottom of the region's income spectrum have seen their paychecks shrink, after inflation. 
 Compared with the rest of the nation, "the earnings gap grew at a faster rate in the region, with a particularly pronounced rise occurring in the New York metropolitan area," said the Federal analysis, which looked at wages from 1979 to 1996.
Coming six years into recovery from one of the New York region's deepest recessions in decades, the Federal report, taken together with another by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, points to several areas of economic strength that may seem reminiscent of the boom years of the 1980's.
Once again, as Wall Street prospers, the rich get richer. And once again, as the regional economy perks up, real estate prices surge.
But the Port Authority, in what has become an annual economic report and forecast for the region, underscored sources of economic strength that are now different from, and probably more resistant to downturns than those that fueled the 1980's boom.
"The economy is growing at the strongest rate in a decade, and the difference now is in its diversification," said Eugene Spruck, acting chief economist for the Port Authority.
"Almost every sector is participating," he said, pointing to buoyant growth in the last two years in construction, tourism, retail sales, movie and television production and Broadway ticket sales, which have generated strong economic gains to complement the wealth and employment being created by Wall Street.
According to the Port Authority report, the region has yet to make up for all of the 600,000 jobs that were lost during the recession, from 1989 through 1992. But its recovery is moving rapidly. After a gain of 133,000 jobs in 1997, the biggest annual increase in 30 years, the Port Authority forecast at least 100,000 more new jobs this year.
As in other parts of the country, New York City and its suburbs are feeling the impact of the steep downturn in Asia, where cutbacks in trade with Japan, Malaysia, Thailand and other nations could become more severe, the Port Authority said. The most prosperous Asian nations collectively account for a third of the New York region's international trade, the authority said.
But the region is far less dependent on Asia for exports and imports than some other parts of the United States, the report said, and should weather the Asian downturn better than most. For example, Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif., rely on Asia for more than 80 percent of their international merchandise trade.
While the report said New York and its suburbs would be more resilient in a Wall Street downturn than they were a decade ago, Mr. Spruck said gyrations in the stock market would affect economic conditions throughout the region.
Although stock brokerage houses employ a tiny fraction of the region's workers -- about 156,000 -- their high wages ripple through things like real estate values, sales of luxury goods and the business of restaurants, resorts and Broadway theaters.
"There is the potential for a shock from the Asian downturn and possibly another on Wall Street," Mr. Spruck said, "but I don't think the region is in for a major setback over the near term."
In its analysis of wage levels, the Federal Reserve Bank looked at the amounts paid to full-time male workers in the 17 years ended in 1996, the most recent year for which data were available from the United States Census Bureau.
It looked only at what was made by people in the 90th percentile of the income spectrum and those in the 10th percentile. The average inflation-adjusted annual income of people in the 90th percentile increased 26 percent, to $80,000, during the 17 years studied, the report found, while for those in the 10th percentile it fell 21 percent, to $15,000.

HEADLINE: The Debate On Banks Gets Nasty In Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 6

 BODY:
A six-month discussion about Mexico's $62 billion bank bailout has suddenly turned into a national brawl.
Opposition politicians are accusing pro-Government businessmen of enriching themselves at public expense, while Government officials are warning that the debate is degenerating into a witch hunt. 
 The debate began when President Ernesto Zedillo proposed that vast debts from the Government's rescue be assumed by the Mexican Treasury.
The widening confrontation of recent days led to opposition demands for an investigation into the financing of Mr. Zedillo's 1994 campaign as well as to threats of lawsuits by wealthy bankers who say they have been unjustly accused of financial wrongdoing.
Some analysts are calling the debate a watershed in Mexico's political life.
For the first time powerful forces, including the opposition parties in control of the lower house of Congress, are demanding a thorough airing of the cozy dealings between Government officials and the circle of wealthy industrialists and bankers who finance Mr. Zedillo's Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI.
The latest battles flared on Monday, when the leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution, or P.R.D., made public a list of 310 people, including several billionaires, characterizing them as beneficiaries of the bank rescue that followed the 1994 peso devaluation, though the party acknowledged that in many cases its information was sketchy.
Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, the P.R.D. president, said the party pieced the list together from people in the banking and business worlds after the Government cited bank secrecy laws for refusing to provide details of the bailout.
"We've been asking for information, bank by bank and file by file, but the executive has refused," Mr. Lopez Obrador said at a news conference. "If this was a matter between two private parties, where one owes and the other is trying to collect, we wouldn't care about knowing secrets. But any attempt to make the debt of a handful of private people public makes full information indispensable."
For its part, the Government contends that the bailout was aimed at supporting ordinary depositors by saving the banks, but it acknowledges that the banks cannot collect some very large loans made to wealthy people, some of them bankers themselves, on the basis of their reputations, and without collateral.
The P.R.D.'s defiant action has provoked angry criticism from the Government and its supporters.
Officials at the bank rescue program, the Fund for Bank Savings Protection, immediately attacked the P.R.D. list as inaccurate and sloppy.
"This list does not agree with the information that exists in our databases," the fund said in a statement.
The Treasury Department's spokesman, Marco Provencio, said at a news conference that the P.R.D.'s tactics were similar to Senator Joseph McCarthy's demagogic use of a list of supposed Communists in Washington in 1950.
The Mexican Bankers Association published full-page advertisements in newspapers, expressing concern about the "radicalization of positions," and the PRI issued a statement calling publication of the list "political impertinence."
Central to the showdown is the Government's argument that while it wants to inform the Congress fully about the bank rescue, and has already made available 8,000 pages of documentation, it cannot share the names of people whose unpaid loans have been assumed by the fund. Mexico's bank secrecy laws prohibit such identification, the Government says.
But the Government has a history of enormous flexibility in interpreting, and reinterpreting, statutes in ways convenient for the PRI and its supporters. Given that, opposition leaders and some independent analysts have characterized the Government's legal arguments as tactics to protect inappropriate transactions from scrutiny.
"Until now, the tight alliance between the Government and the economic elite permitted that the most powerful industrial groups could do almost whatever they wanted, as long as they did it within a framework of support for the official party," Jonathan Heath, a prominent private economist, wrote in a newspaper column today. "The publication of the list by the P.R.D., despite its inaccuracies, has broken that taboo."
Because the debate has begun to challenge longstanding relations between Government officials and wealthy supporters, "it is marking a watershed in our political system," Mr. Heath said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Strategy: Keep the Pressure on Iraq

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The United States vowed today to "keep the pressure on" to persuade Iraq to end its defiance of United Nations arms inspectors, but said it was too early to contemplate a military response to the latest standoff between Iraq and the United Nations. Iraq said on Wednesday that it would end all cooperation with the inspectors.
"Noncompliance is completely unacceptable," said P. J. Crowley, a White House spokesman. "We will not allow Iraq access to resources necessary to restart their weapons of mass destruction program. We will continue to keep the pressure on until Iraq complies fully with their obligations." 
 Mr. Crowley also said that President Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair discussed "Iraq's latest bout of noncooperation" today in a free-ranging talk that produced renewed determination to keep sanctions in effect.
James Foley, a State Department spokesman, noted that this was not the first time that Baghdad had refused to cooperate with the arms inspections, only to back down.
"We've seen this time and time again," he said. "We're not calling it a crisis because, frankly, we don't want to play into Saddam Hussein's hands. Clearly he's in a box. He's trying to squirm his way out. He's trying to provoke a crisis."
The Defense Department said it had "a very adequate force" in the region of the Persian Gulf -- 19,000 troops, 167 planes and the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln -- to deal with Iraq in the case of any military confrontation.
But Administration officials said the Iraqis' apparent motive was to provoke a crisis in hope that it would further divide the United States from other members of the United Nations Security Council, especially Russia and France, who have sought to lift the economic and military sanctions imposed on Baghdad after the 1991 gulf war.
In its announcement, Iraq called for the inspection team, the United Nations Special Commission, to move its headquarters to Geneva or Vienna from New York to reduce what Baghdad sees as undue American influence.
"There is an obvious effort -- and it's not the first time -- on the part of the Iraqis to characterize this as a confrontation between Iraq and the United States, and we categorically reject that characterization," Mr. Foley said. "The fact of the matter is that the confrontation, if there is one, is between Iraq and the U.N."

HEADLINE: United Healthcare Takes a $900 Million Charge

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW and REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Proving that few, if any, companies are immune to the financial perils facing health care providers, the United Healthcare Corporation, one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations, said yesterday that it was taking a $900 million charge in its second quarter, in part to abandon unprofitable Medicare plans.
The move ignited an investor stampede out of health care stocks and possibly jeopardized United Healthcare's proposed $5.5 billion merger with its rival, Humana Inc., which would create the nation's largest H.M.O., with 10 million members. 
 Worse still, United Healthcare's announcement, unexpected by Wall Street analysts and investors, raised serious questions as to whether H.M.O.'s can make money covering Medicare patients.
"People seem to forget that Medicare was created because private insurers could not make money on the elderly population," said Diane Archer, executive director of the Medicare Rights Center, a consumer group in New York. "Now managed-care plans are discovering the same lesson all over again and are getting out."
Analysts think that many people on Medicare will not be affected. But the company did not give details about which markets it might leave or how it might change its coverage. Analysts said that the most vulnerable markets were those where United Healthcare does not have enough enrollees to negotiate steep discounts with hospitals and doctors. For example, Utah is nearly devoid of managed-care coverage for people on Medicare.
While United Healthcare had said it would realign its operations, few analysts expected the scope to be so broad or the write-off, covering future Medicare losses and its exit from some markets, so steep. Having watched many of its competitors like Oxford Health Plans stumble, United Healthcare, based in Minneapolis, had emerged as Wall Street's best hope for managed care.
The company's chairman and chief executive, William W. McGuire, was well liked and viewed as having a strong grasp of the fundamental issues of managed care. "They were and supposedly are the best in the industry," said Larry Feinberg of Oracle Partners, a New York hedge fund that specializes in health care.
That belief was largely shattered yesterday when the company disclosed the reorganization charge as the cause of its $565 million loss in the second quarter. United Healthcare said that the company's continuing operations remained profitable, with its commercial business remaining robust, but acknowledged that it could not afford to cover Medicare patients in some areas. The company said it was losing money in two-thirds of the 24 markets where it provides care to people on Medicare.
"Medicare is clearly our largest disappointment," Mr. McGuire said. The company also said it was leaving several commercial markets as well.
Investors, who were caught completely off guard by the news, immediately fled the stock, dumping many other health care stocks in their wake. United Healthcare plunged $15, or 28.4 percent, to $37.875. Humana dropped $6.625, or 25.7 percent, to $19.125. Pacificare Health Systems fell $5.375, to $63.75, and Wellpoint Health Networks dropped $1.6875, to $56.25.
With health care stocks tumbling, and with United Healthcare indicating that it was rethinking its aggressive push into the Medicare market, analysts questioned the fate of United Healthcare's pending acquisition of Humana. A spokeswoman for United Healthcare said yesterday that the deal was still progressing on schedule, but Humana, based in Louisville, Ky., was not so enthusiastic.
Soon after the announcement was made public, Humana, which received no warning of United Heathcare's write-off, released a terse statement saying it would not comment on the charge until it discussed it with United Healthcare executives.
Mr. McGuire said yesterday during a meeting with analysts that Federal and state regulatory review of the merger was continuing and that the shareholder vote was expected at the end of this month. Asked about Humana's statement, he refused to comment.
"With the stock prices so low, the acquisition may be renegotiated," said Linda Varoli, an analyst with Merger Insight. "Humana's board of directors has a responsibility to their shareholders. They may want more assurances from United Healthcare or get more considerations from them in the deal."
And much of the merger's appeal is Humana's strong presence in the Medicare market, although Mr. McGuire emphasized that United's losses were caused by the start-up nature of its programs.
Even if the acquisition is completed, United Healthcare, which said it has 1.3 million people in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey and is an aggressive player in the area, will face questions about its commitment to Medicare patients. Consumer advocates clamored yesterday that United Healthcare's move to drop certain counties was typical given that H.M.O.'s tended to put profits in front of health care.
But Mr. McGuire said that United Healthcare was not abandoning this group. "We remain committed to serving seniors in a variety of ways," Mr. McGuire said yesterday. United Healthcare will re-evaluate its programs in specific markets to see whether it can generate what he described as "acceptable margins." Still, the company is prepared, he said, to leave markets where it cannot make money."
United is the latest managed-care company to stumble in an attempt to make money serving the Medicare population, and many of its competitors have decided to withdraw from that market. Oxford has attributed some of its heavy losses on its Medicare programs in some areas, and several companies, including Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield and Health Net in California, have recently decided to throw in the towel.
The economics of serving people on Medicare make it virtually impossible to make money, said Karen Korn, a health care services analyst at Putnam Investments in Boston. The Government has approved rate increases for Medicare-managed programs of about 2 percent while medical costs are rising at 4 percent or higher. "There's no way that translates into O.K. margins," Ms. Korn said.
Despite the Government's push to have more Medicare members in managed care, there may be few providers that remain interested in serving the population. "We'll see a lot more dropping out of it than getting into it," predicted Barry Barnett, a principal at Kwasha HR Solutions, a unit of Price Waterhouse Coopers.
But United Healthcare's woes also raise the question of whether managed care works as a model for the future of health care in keeping costs under control. While the company's difficulties are limited to caring for the elderly, it is unclear how successful any managed-care company will be once it covers more people. The backlash from consumers, who are increasingly demanding more from their plans and want more choice of doctors and hospitals, adds to the difficulty of containing costs. "You can't make huge margins in this business long term," Mr. Feinberg argued.
The effect of yesterday's announcement on employers, many of whom are now choosing health plans for their employees, is unclear. While some benefits consultants said that they thought the news would have little effect, others said that it would give some employers pause.
"I'm tired of managed-care companies believing they can control health care costs," said Todd B. Richter, a health care analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "They need to learn how to price health care. They are insurance companies. And that means they are in the risk-management business."

United Healthcare's stock dropped dramatically after an announcement of a $900 million pretax charge. The graph shows the daily close of the stock since January 1998. (Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Increased by Only 0.1% in June

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Held back by slumping demand for aircraft and autos, orders to factories rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department said today.
Still, the report exceeded the expectations of analysts, who had expected it to show a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent. In issuing June's data, the Commerce Department also revised May's decline to 2.2 percent, the biggest drop in three years, from the 1.8 percent reported previously. 
 In the second quarter, factory orders fell seven-tenths of 1 percent from the prior three months. Economists said the decline reflected Asia's economic turmoil. Export sales to Asia have plummeted, and American manufacturers are facing increased competition from Asian products whose prices have fallen because of currency devaluations.
However, a separate report today from the Labor Department suggested jobs remained plentiful despite the manufacturing slowdown. The number of first-time applications for unemployment benefits edged higher last week, to a seasonally adjusted 307,000, but remained near the 15-week low of 301,000 that was reached the week before.
That was well below the 394,000 claims registered for two consecutive weeks in late June and early July, when workers idled by the General Motors strike filed for benefits.
The June factory report was weighed down by the transportation industries. Excluding those manufacturers, factory orders increased 1.1 percent in June, in contrast to a decline in May of 1.8 percent.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and its players met constructively, they thought, for nearly two hours yesterday morning. Then they broke for lunch, and each side had to wonder what was in the water the other side had with its food.
Within 15 minutes after the negotiators returned from lunch, the owners' group abruptly ended the session, dismissing a union proposal as economically perilous. Both sides accused the other of deliberately torpedoing the meeting and the immediate chance for progress in the off-season lockout. 
 "They were like my 4-year-old," said Karl Malone, who traveled from Alaska for his first taste of collective bargaining. "I don't want to play anymore so I'm going home."
The half-dozen owners who were in the conference room of a midtown Manhattan law office, on the other hand, were described as stunned and insulted by post-lunch developments.
"We thought the best thing to do to preserve any semblance of a bargaining balance for continuity would be to end discussions right there," said Commissioner David Stern, who with his deputy and chief negotiator, Russ Granik, expressed disappointment and sadness at yesterday's developments.
The negotiators were meeting for the first time since June 22, and the first time since the league imposed its lockout on July 1, suspending all N.B.A. business, including the signing of free agents and the payment of salary that teams contractually owe players for the 1998-99 season.
No further bargaining sessions are scheduled, though lawyers for the league and the players will meet today with an arbitrator, John D. Feerick, to schedule a hearing on the union's grievance over the teams' failure to pay guaranteed salaries. Feerick's decision in that case is expected to have a major impact on the future of talks.
League officials, in fact, suggested that the union strategy centered not on negotiations but on the salary grievance and an unfair labor practice charge it filed with the National Labor Relations Board.
"The strategy here is to litigate, arbitrate and make no concessions," said Granik. Billy Hunter, the union chief, countered by saying that the players will use every avenue available to them to undermine the lockout, but that they want to negotiate a new agreement.
At the morning session, the owners who were present engaged in back-and-forth dialogue with the 13 players who were at the large table. Stern called the exchange constructive. Hunter said at least part of it was acrimonious, particularly an early exchange between Malone and Jerry Colangelo of the Phoenix Suns.
But the exchange prompted the union to make a post-lunch proposal. Jerry Kessler, one of the union's outside lawyers, said: "Colangelo said we had to address the drug agreement, rookie issues and a hard salary cap. They want to slow the growth of salaries."
So the union returned from lunch with a proposal that would change the 20 percent salary increase veterans receive in new contracts, grant clubs the right of first refusal on players ending their three-year rookie contracts and would add marijuana to the drug-testing list if all economic issues were resolved first.
But the owners viewed the overall effect of the elements of the economic proposal as perilous. The union's ideas, they said, could increase, not decrease, the percentage of revenue that would go to players' salaries. In addition, the owners took offense at remarks made by Kessler.
"When they lecture you on the grave risk you face if you don't take their proposal, that's when it's time to leave," Stern said. "That's not the tone in which we address the players."
Kessler said he wasn't lecturing the owners.
"When they were about to storm out of the meeting," he said, "I suggested that they recognize there are going to be some very important legal decisions to be made rather quickly and it might be in their interest to negotiate seriously before those decisions come down."
Patrick Ewing, the union's president, said the players felt they were making progress with their proposal and the owners "showed disrespect by getting up and walking out."
At the morning session yesterday, one of the participants said, the owners raised a salary cap idea they had previously discussed with variations. They proposed implementing a hard salary cap for the future, though current players would not be affected by it.
The players rejected the idea, and then everyone went to lunch and drank the water.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Stocks Lower Yet; Tokyo Is Up

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Friday, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Stocks continued to fall here early today after declining sharply on Thursday.
The benchmark Hang Seng index hit a three-and-a-half-year low Thursday, as interest rates rose and the local currency -- the last in Asia still pegged to the United States dollar -- weakened slightly. 
 In early trading this morning, the Hang Seng was down 121.16 points, or 1.67 percent, at 7,133.20. It closed at 7,254.36 on Thursday, its lowest since January 1995. The Hong Kong dollar traded around 7.75 to the American dollar, the same as on Thursday, compared with 7.7492 Wednesday.
In Tokyo, stocks were modestly higher at the midday trading recess. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 86.87 points, or a little more than half of 1 percent, at 15,963.09.
Speculation has been growing that the region's slowing economies may force China and eventually Hong Kong to devalue their currencies.
Problems abound locally, as well. After Cathay Pacific Airways posted its first loss ever Wednesday, the conglomerate Swire Pacific announced on Thursday that its first-half profit fell a worse-than-expected 39 percent.

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Security Council Is United In Criticism of Iraq Action
The Security Council closed ranks to berate Iraq for ending cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors, but took no action other than to demand that Baghdad reverse its decision. Secretary General Kofi Annan suggested that the Iraqis were desperate for movement toward ending sanctions and needed to be brought more closely into deliberations at the United Nations. A1 

The United States vowed to keep the pressure on Iraq, but said it was too early to contemplate any military action. A6
 
Palestinian Cabinet Protest
Two of Yasir Arafat's cabinet ministers, Hanan Ashrawi, left, and Abdul Jawah Saleh resigned to protest what they said had been Mr. Arafat's failure to address problems within the Palestinian Authority. A12

Rebels in Congo seized control of a strategic oil port in the far west, according to rebel spokesmen and foreign diplomats, significantly widening their campaign to wrest power from President Laurent Kabila. A4

Tax collectors swooped down on three of Russia's biggest oil companies, seizing cars, apartments and other assets for payment of $150 million in back taxes. The seizures accompanied new indications that President Boris N. Yeltsin's economic advisers were serious about carrying out the latest last-ditch program to stave off fiscal collapse. A3

NATO and European troops will hold exercises in Albania from Aug. 17 to Aug. 22 and in Macedonia in September to press President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to end military action in Kosovo, the Pentagon said. The announcement came after Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright told Mr. Milosevic that his offensive against ethnic Albanian guerrillas in Kosovo had increased the threat of NATO military intervention. A5
 
Mountbatten's Killer Is Freed
Ireland freed Thomas McMahon, an I.R.A. guerrilla convicted of killing Lord Mountbatten and three other people, as part of the Northern Ireland peace agreement, officials in Dublin said. Lord Mountbatten, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II and the last Viceroy of India before independence in 1947, and the other victims died in an explosion on board their small fishing boat off the northeastern coast of Ireland in August 1979. (Agence France-Presse)
 
Czech President Rallies
The heartbeat of President Vaclav Havel returned to normal after he nearly died with a severely accelerated pulse earlier this week, doctors in Prague said. Mr. Havel, whose official duties are mainly ceremonial, led the peaceful overthrow of the Czechoslovak Communist Government in 1989. A former chain smoker, Mr. Havel has suffered several bouts of ill health since lung cancer surgery in late 1996. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: SECURITY COUNCIL CLOSES ITS RANKS AGAINST BAGHDAD

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The Security Council closed ranks today to berate Iraq for ending cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors, but took no action other than to demand that Baghdad reverse its decision.
But even as Iraq was isolated in the Security Council, the Government got mixed signals from Secretary General Kofi Annan, who suggested that the Iraqis, "desperate" for some movement toward ending sanctions, needed to be brought more closely into deliberations here. 
 But in a written statement in Washington, President Clinton said, "Far from hastening the day the international community lifts sanctions," Iraq's failure to permit inspections "will perpetuate those sanctions and keep the Iraqi economy under tight international control."
The Security Council members, united in shock and a touch of weariness at having to work their way through another unexpected crisis created by Baghdad, called Iraq's decision to freeze cooperation with inspectors "totally unacceptable."
In Beijing, Moscow and Paris, the capitals most sympathetic to the Iraqis, Governments distanced themselves from Baghdad in statements. In Russia and China, there were expressions of concern about the consequences of continued Iraqi defiance.
"It is now extremely important not to stoke tensions over Iraq," the Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vladimir Rakhmanin, told a news briefing in Moscow. A Chinese spokesman, Tang Guoqiang, said his Government would do what it could "to avoid a worsening of the situation."
While President Clinton said the Iraqi move "once again will backfire," his statement emphasized sanctions as the wedge to force Iraq to comply with inspections. Administration officials said there was no immediate consideration of military force, saying that the situation so far seemed to be less serious than it was last October, when the Iraqis expelled American inspectors.
But they said that the Administration would consider the use of force if the situation deteriorated. "We'll take our time -- we're not going to let Saddam call the shots," one Administration official said last night, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Surveillance went on as usual in Baghdad today, though no actual site inspections were attempted because Iraq barred them on Wednesday, United Nations officials said.
When Iraq decided this week that it would end cooperation with arms inspections and allow only passive monitoring by surveillance cameras, the Iraqis were aware that they were actually close to meeting disarmament requirements in some areas, Richard Butler, the chief arms inspector told the Security Council today.
But officials of the United Nations Special Commission, known as Unscom, said today that the Iraqis also knew that problems in accounting for biological and some chemical compounds were serious and growing. Right up to the present, Iraq has continued to change figures and alter other information earlier presented as "full, final and complete" declarations.
At times the Iraqis have been forced to revise a story when confronted with evidence by inspectors -- as in the recent case of the discovery of traces of VX nerve gas on shell casings after Iraqis denied that they had used it. At other times, they volunteer new information -- but that only raises more troubling questions about why an account has changed.
In recent examinations of old warhead remnants, for example, weapons experts found more traces of anthrax than they could explain, Unscom officials said today. When the Iraqis were pressed, they revised earlier "final figures" to say that they had actually filled three times as many warheads with anthrax -- 16 -- as with botulism -- 5. Until then, Iraq said it had filled weapons with more than three times more botulism than anthrax.
This admission has revived speculation among inspectors that Iraq produced not only more anthrax, but also two kinds of it, one in a dry form that is easier to spray and has a longer shelf life. Officials insisted today, however, that this is only speculation at this point.
"Every time Iraq changes the figures, it has a ripple effect throughout their entire declaration," said Charles Duelfer, deputy chairman of Unscom. "That is a very complicated procedure because a declaration is built and substantiated to support one set of numbers and to change that becomes very difficult."
This week Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister and chief negotiator on weapons issues, gave a new explanation of how VX nerve gas could have been found on the shells. In a letter to the Security Council on Wednesday, he said the traces could have been created from the "decomposition of other chemical substances or from the use of equipment which had already been used to produce the VX agent."
After today's lengthy Council meeting, a Western diplomat said that nobody relished having to take strong action to make Iraq conform to its agreements. Until the arms inspectors are satisfied that Iraq has provided answers to outstanding questions about biological, chemical, nuclear and missile programs, President Hussein cannot hope to see the end of sanctions, which were imposed in 1990 after the invasion of Kuwait.
"Everyone was weary, everyone was annoyed and everyone was concerned that this not turn into a crisis that would force the United States to act as it had to act last year," the diplomat said.
The Council action came after Mr. Butler briefed members on his aborted trip to Iraq, which ended when talks broke down earlier this week. He also spoke on the Iraqi leadership's refusal to turn over documents, including one discovered in July that shed light on the amount of "nonconventional munitions" used during the 1980-87 war with Iran.
Diplomats said that the document could prove that there are larger quantities of chemical -- and possibly biological -- agents unaccounted for in Iraq than inspectors were told about last year. Iraqis said that they had filled 101,080 warheads with chemical weapons in the 1980's, but the new document reveals that fewer than that were actually deployed. The inspectors want to know what happened to the rest.
Secretary General Annan also spoke to the Council about his assessment of Iraq's position after talking this morning with Mr. Aziz. Mr. Annan told the Council that Iraq was "clearly in violation of the resolutions of the Security Council and the memorandum of understanding I concluded in Baghdad in February."
"I believe this is well understood by the Government of Iraq," he said.
But Mr. Annan added that he thought Iraq's position was "not a closed one," that Baghdad had acted out of frustration and even desperation, and that it might be the right time "to stand back and make a comprehensive reassessment of where we are, where we are going and how to get there."
"In undertaking this comprehensive review," he said, "it might be helpful to engage the Iraqis much more closely than we have hitherto."
Over the last year, Iraq has persistently and successfully managed to broaden its diplomatic contacts with United Nations officials, skirting the Security Council when it could. Iraqi has complained repeatedly that the Council and the disarmament commission are dominated by the United States.
In a letter to the Arab League today, Mr. Aziz appealed for support against what he called the "injustice" of Unscom.
Arms inspectors see this as an Iraqi tactic to bring international politics into what is essentially a technical operation to disarm Iraq and destroy its capacity to make new weapons of mass destruction.
Mr. Butler also provided the Security Council today with results of a technical evaluation in July of Iraq's "full, final and complete disclosure" on biological weapons, a document the Iraqis say closes the file on that issue. This was the third such technical evaluation demanded by Iraq over the last year, and its findings were no different from earlier ones.
"No new material was presented by Iraq at this meeting," Mr. Butler wrote in his report of the July technical evaluation. The international experts again concluded that Iraq's latest disclosure "was not adequate to allow for credible verification."
The biological experts found problems with Iraqi accounts of what they had done with bombs, warheads, spraying devices or quantities of the agents themselves, including botulinum toxin, anthrax bacillus and aflatoxin.
Today Bill Richardson, the United States representative to the United Nations called the Iraqi demand "disarmament by ultimatum."
"That's not going to happen," he said.
