HEADLINE: Lewinsky Said to Detail Clinton Affair

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. and JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Ending months of anticipation with a resigned shrug, Monica S. Lewinsky walked into a Federal courthouse here today, and, a lawyer familiar with her account said, testified that she and President Clinton had carried on a sexual affair inside the White House.
Her testimony before a Federal grand jury, which contradicted a previous sworn statement, tightened the legal and political vise around Mr. Clinton. The President denied under oath in the Paula Corbin Jones sexual misconduct lawsuit that he had had a sexual relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, and he has denied it as well to the American people. 
 Ms. Lewinsky testified to having had several sexual encounters with Mr. Clinton in his small, private study down a short hallway from the Oval Office, the lawyer said. As expected, she also testified that she and the President had talked about ways to conceal their relationship, the lawyer said, but she also said he never directly told her to lie under oath.
Kenneth W. Starr, the independent prosecutor, is investigating accusations that Mr. Clinton lied under oath and obstructed justice by trying to conceal the relationship.
More than six months of waiting for Ms. Lewinsky to tell her story ended just before 8:30 A.M., when she stepped from a dark green Toyota Land Cruiser, embraced a lawyer, shrugged and vanished inside. As portable generators rumbled in the background and one cameraman swept the scene from a cherrypicker 50 feet over Third Street, about 20 satellite trucks beamed the images of Ms. Lewinsky, once an unpaid, anonymous sorter of White House mail, around the planet.
Ms. Lewinsky, who is 25, answered questions in exchange for immunity from prosecution for any wrongdoing she describes. She is vulnerable to prosecution only if she lies in her testimony, in a deal worked out with prosecutors nine days ago. In an affidavit on Jan. 7 in the Jones case, Ms. Lewinsky swore that she had not had a sexual relationship with the President.
An associate of Ms. Lewinsky described her six and a half hours before the grand jury as grueling. "She was asked very specific questions about very private matters which are very hard to discuss in public," the associate said.
Indeed, Ms. Lewinsky has agonized for months over the prospect of damaging Mr. Clinton's Presidency, friends have said. One of her friends described Ms. Lewinsky as saying Wednesday night, as she prepared for her testimony: "What I'm doing tomorrow is something I never ever wanted to do. It breaks my heart."
Since Jan. 27, the 23 grand jurors have listened to the testimony of more than 70 witnesses and hours of surreptitiously taped conversations between Ms. Lewinsky and her former friend Linda R. Tripp. Today was the grand jurors' first opportunity to look Mr. Starr's prized witness in the eyes, question her and judge her credibility for themselves.
Before another media scrum after Ms. Lewinsky completed her testimony, her spokeswoman, Judy Smith, said she had answered questions from prosecutors and jurors "truthfully, completely and honestly."
"Monica and her family are relieved that this ordeal finally appears to be coming to an end," Ms. Smith said.
Mr. Clinton has never publicly described his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky in any detail, beyond defiantly declaring that it was not sexual.
In a capital whipsawed between disclosure and denial, starkly different days unspooled at the Federal courthouse and the White House. Summoning the authority and trappings of his office, as well as his own storied political resilience, President Clinton went about his official duties today without betraying a hint of interest in the former intern's testimony.
"I have looked forward to this day for quite a long time," Mr. Clinton said in one speech at a Washington hotel, referring to his opportunity to address a White House conference on building economic self-improvement in Indian communities.
At the White House, the President appeared before a row of uniformed police officers in the sun-gilded Rose Garden to call for a permanent five-day waiting period for people seeking to buy handguns. With a quick left-handed salute after the official remarks, the President cued a brassy Marine band to strike up "Stars and Stripes Forever." Reporters waiting to shout questions about Ms. Lewinsky were stymied.
Some White House advisers gave vent to frustration over the spectacle at the courthouse and the unremitting pressure of the Lewinsky investigation. "I hate the whole thing," said one. "I hate you, I hate us." Then, in his disgust, words failed him. "Ugh," he added.
Barry Toiv, a White House spokesman, provided the official reaction to the testimony. "The President has not expressed any views to us on this," he said in a contentious and sometimes raucous briefing today, "except we know that he does agree with us -- and probably all Americans -- that if this means that we're coming to the end of this four-year, over $40 million investigation, then that would be a good thing."
Another official said the White House had no interest in drawing attention today. "We're showing wise restraint," he said. "Nobody's going to criticize Ms. Lewinsky, and we're not going to get in the story. It's a big enough story without us."
For all their restraint, White House advisers telephoned reporters late this evening to ask what they had learned about Ms. Lewinsky's testimony.
Just last week, Ms. Lewinsky's version of her relationship with the President was still in doubt. But Mr. Starr's investigation has rushed forward since then, with her immunity agreement and Mr. Clinton's own promise to testify at the White House on Aug. 17. In striking the deal with Mr. Starr, Ms. Lewinsky also turned over a navy blue dress that prosecutors have sent to the Federal Bureau of Investigation crime laboratory. Technicians there are trying to determine if the dress contained physical evidence of a sexual encounter.
Ms. Lewinsky was asked a series of questions about the dress today. Prosecutors have left open the possibility of recalling Ms. Lewinsky before the grand jury, perhaps after the President testifies.
Reporters from across the country and around the world converged on the courthouse today, clucking over the spectacle and contributing to it at the same time. Some reporters began claiming choice spots as early as Wednesday evening for a glimpse of Ms. Lewinsky, only to be flummoxed this morning as she took an unexpected route through the courthouse, up to the third floor in an elevator reserved for judges.
Outside, as passers-by stopped to take in the scene, scores of photographers lined up for a shot of her. When George Hancock, a supporter of Ms. Lewinsky's from Bowling Green, Ky., tried to raise his yellow hand-lettered sign wishing her luck, he cut off their line of sight. "You wave that sign again," screamed one cameraman, "I'll kill you!"
Ducking out of view, Mr. Hancock was surrounded moments later by reporters and photographers, some of whom berated him while others tried to interview him. "How's it make you feel, buddy?" Dominic Mumeka, 33, murmured as if to himself as he stood off to one side. "This is your 15 seconds."
Mr. Mumeka, who cleans a taxi depot, said he had dropped by to watch history be made. "There hasn't been anything like this since Watergate, and before that since Andrew Johnson, 1869," he said. But, he asked, "Can a guy really get impeached for going to bed with someone?"
The White House has resolutely refused to question Ms. Lewinsky's credibility publicly. But there have been fragmentary accounts that White House officials were concerned that she had a crush on the President.
An Indianapolis lawyer who has worked as a Democratic operative said in an interview today that he had been asked to keep an eye on Ms. Lewinsky at an Oct. 23, 1996, fund-raiser here to insure that she did not "embarrass the President."
John J. Sullivan, a lobbyist and lawyer from Indianapolis, said he had been asked by a friend in the Administration to watch Ms. Lewinsky because she had recently left the White House and there were concerns she was "disgruntled."
Mr. Sullivan recalled his friend as saying about Ms. Lewinsky: " 'We don't know if she has fantasized a relationship with the President. But she keeps showing up at these events.' "
Mr. Sullivan said he had watched Ms. Lewinsky reach out with both hands to hug the President. "And he hugged her back," he said. "Then he said to her, 'How are you doing?' She said, 'Fine.' He said, 'How's your new job?' And she said, 'Great.' He said, 'I wish you the best of luck,' and that was it."
Mr. Sullivan said he spoke on Monday with a television station in Indianapolis. In a sign that the White House is following up any lead to bolster Mr. Clinton's story, Mr. Sullivan said David E. Kendall, the President's personal lawyer, called him on Wednesday to ask a number of questions.
Mr. Sullivan said he felt no pressure to tell his story publicly.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Monica S. Lewinsky leaving the Federal courthouse yesterday after testifying about her relationship with President Clinton. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gingrich Plans to Push Smaller Tax Cuts in Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich conceded today that huge tax cuts would probably have to be put off until next year, but he and other House Republican leaders said they would forge ahead this fall with a smaller tax cut in the belief that President Clinton would ultimately accept it.
In meetings with fellow Republicans over the last week, Mr. Gingrich has said Mr. Clinton will probably accept a bill cutting taxes by a maximum of $70 billion to $80 billion over five years. 
 On the one hand, the Speaker's decision can be seen as a retreat in the face of opposition from the President and moderate Republicans. Mr. Gingrich and other conservatives had been promoting legislation that would cut taxes by $167 billion over five years and by $700 billion over 10 years. On the other hand, Republicans said, the strategy could prove to be a big advance toward getting a tax cut enacted into law this year.
Senate Republicans had made clear that they would not approve tax cuts of the magnitude Mr. Gingrich originally wanted. And the White House sounded cool even to the idea of a smaller tax cut.
In an interview tonight, Gene Sperling, assistant to the President for economic policy, said: "The President is not going to sign any new spending or tax initiative if it drains any of the surplus that is reserved for Social Security, whether it's $700 billion, $70 billion or $7 billion. We believe that all of the surplus should be reserved for Social Security until we have a comprehensive bipartisan reform solution for that program."
By contrast, at a caucus of House Republicans, Mr. Gingrich said, "We believe the surplus money will go to save Social Security and to provide tax relief." He vowed that "every penny of Social Security payroll taxes" -- but not necessarily every penny of the surplus -- "will be used to strengthen Social Security."
The Congressional Budget Office foresees a surplus of $63 billion this year and a total of $1.5 trillion in surpluses over the next 10 years. In this fall's elections, Mr. Gingrich said, Republicans will ask voters, "Do you want the money to go back to the American taxpayer, or do you want the money spent by bureaucrats in Washington?"
The House Republicans' top priority for this year's tax bill is to reduce the effects of a longstanding quirk in the tax code known as the marriage penalty. Because of this provision, many married couples with two incomes pay higher taxes than they would if they filed separate tax returns as individuals.
Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, who writes tax legislation as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said: "I look forward to producing a middle-income tax cut bill in September, and I hope the President will sign it. If he doesn't, he risks being known as the President who imposed a marriage penalty on the American people."
In a speech to the House Republican caucus today, Mr. Gingrich listed five other priorities for tax-cutting legislation this fall and next year. For example, he said, Republicans will try to cut capital gains taxes, eliminate estate taxes and increase the tax deductions allowed for the purchase of health insurance by individuals and small businesses.
Capital gains are profits from the sale of stocks, real estate and other assets. Mr. Gingrich wants to reduce the top tax rate on such gains to 15 percent, from 20 percent.
Mr. Gingrich said the Republicans would also "work to" repeal a law that reduces Social Security benefits for elderly people who earn more than a certain amount, $14,500 a year. Critics say the earnings limit punishes people for working and forces some people to retire though they would prefer to work.
Finally, Mr. Gingrich said the Republicans would try to repeal provisions of the 1993 budget law that increased the taxation of Social Security benefits for people with substantial income from other sources.
The President said today that he would accuse the Republicans of weakening Social Security if they pursued a big tax cut financed by projected surpluses in the Federal budget. In the Rose Garden of the White House, Mr. Clinton declared, "We should reserve every penny of the surplus until we save Social Security for the 21st century."

HEADLINE: 'Magic Hour' Canceled

 BODY:
The final stunt for "The Magic Hour" will be a vanishing act. The late-night talk show, featuring the basketball legend Earvin (Magic) Johnson as its host, has been canceled by its syndicator, 20th Television, after only two months because of low ratings.
In New York, the hourlong show appears on Channel 5 at 11:30 on weeknights. Reruns will continue until early September. 
 "We were improving with each day," Mr. Johnson said in a statement, "but this is television, and shows are canceled all the time for one reason or another."
"The Magic Hour" had an average Nielsen rating of 1.6, or a little more than two million viewers each night, since its June 8 debut.
"While the show was gaining in popularity, the economics of such a major enterprise make it impossible to continue beyond its initial commitment without gaining higher ratings in a very short time," said the announcement by 20th Television, which is owned by the News Corporation.

HEADLINE: Paris Journal;
In the 'Free' World Now, But He's Still a Dissident

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Communist bureaucracy made Aleksandr I. Ginzburg stateless during the cold war. French bureaucracy would have left him stateless now if he had not raised his voice in protest.
Mr. Ginzburg knows something about protest. As a poet and outspoken supporter of human rights in the Soviet Union, he was in prison for much of the 1960's and 1970's. He was freed and flown to the United States with four other imprisoned dissidents in 1979 in an exchange for two convicted Soviet spies. 
 The swap left him with freedom but "indeterminate nationality," as described in the French travel document he must use instead of a passport.
Since he has lived and worked in France for most of the last two decades, he finally applied for French citizenship three years ago. But when the decision finally came, in a letter dated June 17, it was, as he puts it, "a resounding 'nyet.' "
"You understand and speak French only indifferently and can neither read nor write it," said the letter, signed by the Subdirector for Naturalization in the Directorate of Population and Migration of the Ministry of Employment and Solidarity.
That title might have come from Gogol's satire on the Russian bureaucracy, "The Government Inspector," prominently displayed in Mr. Ginzburg's library, but the Subdirector's letter was no joke.
"Under these circumstances, you cannot be considered assimilated into the French community," it said.
But Mr. Ginzburg, 62 and short of breath after a bout with cancer that left him with only one lung, has not lost his combativeness.
"It's a fact that I don't speak French well at all," he said, in Russian, in his sixth-floor apartment near the Gare de Lyons. "But it's also a fact that nobody ever gave me an examination that would justify such a finding."
France, like the United States, prides itself on two centuries of devotion to republican ideals of freedom, equality and human rights. After the Russian Revolution in 1917, it gave shelter to thousands of "white Russian" refugees who opposed the Bolsheviks. Some survivors of that immigration still do not speak French well, but they hold French passports.
Times have changed, though, and it is harder in these days of double-digit unemployment rates and mass clandestine immigration to qualify for naturalization in France or anywhere else in Europe.
So as things stood in June, Mr. Ginzburg would not qualify, though his wife, Irina, and their older son, Alexandre, 25, were granted citizenship. Alexandre's younger brother, Alexis, 23, grew up in Paris with him, but he was turned down.
"You have in fact attracted the attention of the police, in 1995, for willful damage to private property (graffiti)," the letter to Alexis, also dated June 17, informed him. But it said he could apply again for citizenship in a year.
"Paris is one of the world capitals of graffiti art," his father said in exasperation. "There are art galleries devoted to it, and four art journals. There are exhibitions from time to time, and the newspapers treat the artists as celebrities.
"My son is offended when the newspapers write about him and don't reproduce his art. He was painting on his own building when the police came by, and all they did was ask him to show his papers -- he never heard another word from them."
Mr. Ginzburg came to France in 1980, after his release, to take a job working for the European office of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., so he could not apply here for immigration status as a refugee. "I came here from New York City, so I wasn't fleeing persecution," he said, laughing.
He stayed in France to work for a Russian emigre journal, Russkaya Mysl, or Russian Thought, but he clashed with the editors, he said, and was dismissed last year. His dismissal, he is persuaded, was not unconnected to the refusal of his naturalization request, since the editors are well connected with the French authorities.
But so is Mr. Ginzburg, who says he has known President Jacques Chirac for years.
He proudly displayed an invitation to the July 14 Bastille Day garden party at Elysee Palace this year, though he was not feeling well that day and did not attend.
After news of his plight appeared in the daily Le Figaro and other French newspapers, he received a handwritten note from the Culture Minister, Catherine Trautmann, assuring him that his case would be rapidly cleared up.
"My colleague Martine Aubry," the Minister of Employment and Solidarity, "is personally taking charge of your difficulty, which we sincerely deplore," Mrs. Trautmann wrote.
On Wednesday, Mr. Ginzburg said, the police in the precinct where he had applied for naturalization called and told his wife that he would soon have his citizenship papers.
"Now I can finally get rid of this green snake," he said, unfolding the accordion-like travel document. "But they said they knew nothing about Alexis's application. Me, an old man, they'll accept, but they turn down a healthy young man who grew up in France and considers himself French."
He hopes, he said, that the authorities will soon relent and grant Alexis, too, the citizenship of his adopted country.

LENGTH: 1414 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tokyo Leader Calls for Cuts In Tax Rates

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 7

 BODY:
In his first major policy speech since taking over as Prime Minister a week ago, Keizo Obuchi today proposed cuts in individual and corporate taxes and additional spending for public works while making less-concrete promises to deregulate the economy and trim the Government budget.
While Mr. Obuchi spoke forcefully, he proposed primarily to speed up changes his politically less powerful predecessor had pursued for some time; he offered little in the way of shock therapy for Japan's ailing economy. 
 He plans to serve up a quick cocktail of tax cuts and public spending aimed at spurring the economy over the next year or two. For the long term, his menu is a far less detailed list of promises to deregulate, push administrative change, privatize the public sector and overhaul the tax system -- in short, the program the man he succeeded, Ryutaro Hashimoto, pushed for.
"I am determined to make my utmost effort, at the risk of the Cabinet's life, to bring the Japanese economy to a recovery path within a year or two," he told Parliament, alluding to newspaper reports that have described his Cabinet as standing on the edge of a cliff.
Mr. Obuchi may not have much time. "It seems he wants to engineer a soft landing of the Japanese economy," said Heizo Takenaka, a professor at Keio University, "and the basic question is, Is that possible? I personally feel that some kind of shock therapy is necessary."
In Washington, the Clinton Administration continued to walk a line between hope that Japan would move quickly to enact the changes necessary to shore up its economy and skepticism that decisive action was forthcoming.
"The early restoration of growth in the Japanese economy is critical not only for Japan but for Asia, other emerging markets and the world economy as a whole," said a senior official at the United States Treasury Department, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
"Japan also needs to move aggressively to use public money along with actions to strengthen and restructure banks, to dispose of the burden of bad assets and to improve bank supervision and disclosure," the official said.
The pace of deterioration in the Japanese economy has gained momentum of late. In the week since Mr. Obuchi took office, the unemployment rate hit yet another high, domestic auto sales were down for the 16th straight month and the yen sank against the dollar. Manufacturers are cutting production, and even in the midst of sweltering heat, air-conditioner sales are off.
"The problems are so serious right now that the best we can hope for even in a year's time is that he can stabilize the situation," said Jeffrey D. Young, chief economist at Salomon Smith Barney in Tokyo. And, indeed, Mr. Obuchi's immediate plans are to do just that. He promised 6 trillion yen, or roughly $41 billion, in overall tax cuts next year, effectively making permanent the 4 trillion yen in temporary cuts for individuals that Mr. Hashimoto extended this year.
He pledged to lower the maximum combined local and national income tax rate to 50 percent from 65 percent, the first step toward what he hopes will be a comprehensive reworking of the tax system.
And borrowing another page from Mr. Hashimoto's book, he said he would lower the corporate tax rate to 40 percent from 46.3 percent starting in April, bringing it roughly in line with Western levels.
Economists and business leaders have long criticized Japan's high taxes for inhibiting entrepreneurs and forcing dynamic individuals to move to other countries. "I paid 200 million yen in taxes last year," Takuya Okada, chairman and chief executive of Jusco Ltd., one of Japan's largest retailers, fumed recently.
The temporary tax cut he got this spring returned just 18,000 yen to him, which "did not really inspire me to spend," he said. "Now, if they cut my income tax to 50 percent, then I might think about spending," he added. Few economists, though, say a tax cut will put the economy on a path to lasting recovery.
"Tax cuts are necessary because bankruptcies are increasing and unemployment is spiraling up," said Andrew Shipley, an economist at Schroders in Tokyo. "But it's not going to start a consumer-led recovery."
Neither will corporate tax cuts necessarily stimulate capital investment. Only 35 to 40 percent of Japanese corporations pay taxes, and the low cost of capital -- companies can borrow at around 1 percent -- offsets the tax burden for those companies doing well enough to have to pay taxes.
While economists welcome a corporate cut, many say the tax structure itself is in need of a fix. "Companies now get tax breaks for certain types of investment that made sense a long time ago, but, given changes in technology and the economy, now make no sense," Mr. Young said.
Voters, however, are demanding something that makes sense. Mr. Obuchi's ruling Liberal Democratic Party lost control of the Upper House of Parliament when voters turned out in unexpected droves on June 12 to vent their anger. Popularity ratings for Mr. Obuchi and his Cabinet are so low that commentators see a bright side: they probably cannot get any worse.
The loss of the Upper House threatens to stall the passage of legislation to revamp the debt-ridden banking system, and foreign investors will continue to punish the stock market and the yen until they see evidence that change is for real.
Mr. Obuchi is well aware of that, and he was at his most eloquent when speaking about the financial sector. "The flow of funds is like the blood of society, and the financial institutions that are responsible for its circulation assume the role of the heart," he said. "A partial failure of the financial sector, therefore, might lead to a systemic crisis."
Nonetheless, he left lingering doubts about the Government's ability to swallow the strong medicine of failed banks and falling asset prices that would accompany a banking system overhaul. At a news conference after the speech, Akitaka Saiki, Mr. Obuchi's deputy press secretary, was pressed about whether the Prime Minister would allow insolvent banks to fail. Foreign investors are all but baying for a bank failure as a sign that the Government is serious about cleaning up the system.
"We don't intend to save bad banks," Mr. Saiki said. "They need to take responsibility for their actions."
The only specific long-term goal Mr. Obuchi proposed was to push through measures that would cut the Government payroll by 20 percent over the next decade and cut Government costs by 30 percent, both ideas that have been floated for years.
Mr. Obuchi plans to pay for tax cuts by issuing deficit bonds, a financing technique all but prohibited by last year's Fiscal Structural Reform Act. That law severely limited Mr. Hashimoto's ability to maneuver when the economy started sliding toward recession late last fall, and the Prime Minister said today that he would submit legislation in the fall to suspend that law.
He also proposed a supplemental spending budget of 10 trillion yen, or about $69 billion. That will come on top of 16 trillion yen put together in the spring by Mr. Hashimoto, meaning that Japan will spend more than 4 percent of its gross domestic product this year trying to get its economy going again with public works projects. "This is an amazingly big set of packages by any standards," Professor Takenaka said.
Mr. Saiki, the Prime Minister's spokesman, said Mr. Obuchi intended to spend this money somewhat differently from the way such budgets have been spent in the past, when they largely went to building bridges, transportation facilities and roadways that kept the politically loyal and labor-intensive construction industry afloat when the bubble economy started losing air.
Mr. Obuchi, he added, wants a bigger portion of the new supplemental budget spent on "industries of the future," like medicine and technology.
Those industries are considered the best hope for putting a plug in rising unemployment, which is a source of continuing discomfort for politicians, who consider it a ticking time bomb that could blast them out of office.
But economists see higher unemployment as painful but necessary, for it means companies are trying to increase productivity and profitability, which makes them more competitive globally.
And even Mr. Saiki said that if deregulation proceeded, Japan may face more unemployment in the short term. "The structure of the economy has to be changed," he said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 289 words

HEADLINE: Bite-Size Treasury Bills

 BODY:
There is no safer investment than a Treasury bill. But for nearly three decades, the Government has refused to make such safe investments available to those with less than $10,000 to invest. It is good that Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin has decided to end that practice.
The reasons for discriminating against small investors were never very good, but they vanished years ago. The policy was adopted in 1970 out of fear that small savers would seek the higher yields then available from the Government rather than the lower rates paid by banks and savings and loan associations. The Federal Reserve's infamous Regulation Q in those days limited the rates banks could pay, a move that supposedly kept mortgages affordable but in reality assured that mortgage money would dry up when market interest rates rose. 
 Beginning with next Monday's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills, the minimum investment in Treasury bills will be returned to $1,000, where it was before the 1970 change. The minimum for two- and three-year Treasury notes is being reduced from $5,000 to $1,000, which had always been the limit for longer-term Treasuries.
The Treasury also announced improvements in its Treasury Direct program, which lets investors buy securities directly from the Government, avoiding commissions. Beginning next month, investors will be able to buy such securities through the Internet. Telephone purchases will follow.
Once these improvements are up and running, the Treasury should consider reducing the minimum investments for Treasury securities even further, at least to $500 and perhaps lower. There is no reason that such safe investments should be denied to people with relatively little to invest.

LENGTH: 981 words

HEADLINE: Legal Obstacles Loom for Proposed Indian Casino Near Atlantic City

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
For 20 years, the New Jersey beach resort of Wildwood has been a town seething with envy. As hotels and shops along its boardwalk have tried to survive on the income they made three months out of the year, its more famous neighbor to the north -- Atlantic City -- has used its neon-splashed casinos to become a year-round mecca for tourists.
Now Wildwood is fighting back. 
 On Thursday, Wildwood's City Commissioners voted 2 to 1 to approve the transfer of a 2.5-acre municipal parking lot to the Delaware Tribe of western Oklahoma. In return, the Delawares would operate an Indian casino on the lot.
But this plan would immediately run afoul of Federal laws that give the state a deciding voice in the creation of new Indian land, a Federal Indian Affairs spokesman said yesterday. And Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's administration has been opposed to the city's gambling plan for years.
Undeterred, Mayor Fred Wager of Wildwood said yesterday that he believed the city could skirt the Governor's opposition by limiting the gambling to so-called Class II gaming, which includes bingo and, he said, keno poker and off-track betting.
The Mayor said he hoped that the low-level gambling casino would eventually grow into a full-fledged Class III casino, of the type operated by the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation in Ledyard, Conn.
"We're looking for all of it, but we're willing to start out with a Class II casino, where you have bingo and keno poker and horse racing, and move to a Class III casino later," Mr. Wager said.
He said the city could do this without Federal approval because Class II gambling was not regulated by the Federal Indian Gaming Regulatory Act. "As far as our checking into it, we don't need the state or the Federal Government's permission to do that," the Mayor went on. "I don't know if there's a way they can stop us, but the information we have is that we don't need their permission."
However, Rex Hackler, a spokesman for the Interior Department's Bureau of Indian Affairs, said that Federal rules governing the tribal ownership of land, and not the type of gambling the city envisions, stand in the way of an Indian Casino near the glitter of Atlantic City's 12 gambling palaces.
"Any Indian gaming has to take place on Indian land, and just because the town of Wildwood gave this land to the Delawares does not make it Indian land," Mr. Hackler said.
"Even Class II gaming cannot take place until the Indians have taken the land in trust, which basically means that the Governor must give her blessing."
The Delawares, who were compelled to move to Oklahoma in the last century, signed an agreement with Wildwood in 1995 to operate the casino. Larry Snake, the tribal chairman, said at the time that the tribe had had no plans to operate a casino until Wildwood merchants got in touch with him.
The tribe filed suit for the land in state court in March, citing archeological evidence of Indian habitation near Wildwood. Jeffrey April, the tribe's New Jersey lawyer, said in the spring that the litigation was intended to expedite a casino.
Turning the parking lot over to the Delawares would settle the tribe's claim to all of Wildwood as its ancestral lands. The tribe has not formally agreed to the settlement under which they would get the casino lot and the city's backing for a casino, Mayor Wager said. But, the Mayor noted, the Council still had to take the legal steps authorizing the transfer before a deal could be made.
Mr. April could not be reached by phone yesterday.
The Mayor said the Wildwood casino would not serve alcohol, or offer any dining more lavish than a food court, so that local businesses would benefit directly from the crowds they expect the wished-for casino would draw. Wildwood expects to earn more than $8 million a year in new revenues from the casino, as well as employment for 600 to 1,000 residents -- a lot of jobs for a town of 5,000.
"We're not looking to compete with Atlantic City. We're not looking to put 12 casinos in here, and we're not looking for the high rollers," Mr. Wager said. "We're looking for a family atmosphere."
Under the New Jersey Constitution, casino gambling is legal only in Atlantic City. The Attorney General, Peter G. Verniero, repeated through a spokesman on Thursday that the state was opposed to the creation of an Indian tribal casino at Wildwood.
But State officials were not clear yesterday which state agency, if any, would govern Class II gambling in New Jersey.
Bingo and similar games of chance are regulated by the Department of Consumer Affairs, but a Consumer Affairs spokeswoman said her department oversees only charity games.
Several municipalities and developers across the country have in the past tried to create Indian reservations out of private or municipal land for the purposes of creating a casino, but without success, and the Federal Government has never approved a grant of land to a tribe outside its home state, said Stephanie Hanna, a spokeswoman for Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt.
"What would have to happen is that they would have to establish reservation land in New Jersey and then enter into a compact with the State of New Jersey for Class III casino gambling," Ms. Hanna said. "There has to be some established legal record that gave them that land."
Moreover, said Mr. Hackler of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, approval to take land in trust in order to create an Indian casino is a rare occurrence, even with full state backing.
"In the entire history of the B.I.A. we have taken only one piece of land into trust for gaming purposes," Mr. Hackler said, "and that was in Duluth, Minn., and that came with the blessing of virtually everybody involved, including the state."
Mr. Hackler said, "We wish the town of Wildwood the best in developing its economy, but it isn't going to happen this way."

PUB-DATE: August 8, 1998

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1751 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Silver Lining in Japan's Debt?;
One Nation's Loss Is Another's Gain

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Norie Nishikawa scans the parking lot and walks into the apartment complex, moving quickly to a mailbox. She pokes the letters she finds there, noting the return addresses, especially the ones from collection agencies, before a building clerk asks her to leave.
Outside, she snaps a roll of pictures and is off, jotting down notes on everything from maintenance problems to hints of the presence of gangsters. 
 Miss Nishikawa and hundreds of brokers like her are working alongside American investment banks to transform Japan's mountain of bad debt and depressed property into an investment opportunity -- and, some experts hope, to reverse Japan's long economic slide.
For investors, acquiring Japan's bad real estate debt is a big gamble even at sale prices, but, if successful, could help shore up the foundations of the Japanese economy and reassure markets around the world.
Essentially, Americans and other foreigners are moving in to buy up "packages" of the bad loans held by Japanese banks, for around 10 cents on the dollar, and then trying to sell the collateral that backed the loans. They either hope to get an immediate profit or else to hold on and enjoy big gains when the property market picks up.
The dividends throughout the economy could be substantial: If foreign investors help increase liquidity in the Japanese property market, the banks could get rid of some of the nation's bad debt -- which is estimated at anywhere from $500 billion to $1 trillion. If property prices turn around, confidence in the economy could soar, and this could put new pressures on yakuza, as Japanese gangsters are called, who have been occupying many properties -- sometimes at the behest of property owners who want to discourage foreclosure.
"The whole economy is frozen because everyone thinks there's a yakuza in every garage," Jack R. Rodman, the national director for Asia at E & Y Leventhal Real Estate, said.
More broadly, investors here and abroad hope that the infusion of interest and cash could bolster the real estate market and help bring about an end to eight years of paralysis in the Japanese economy.
"It's a very active market, a very healthy market," Mr. Rodman said, though one, he added, that is fraught with frustrations.
The Government intends to give the emerging market for bad Japanese debts a push in the fall with a blueprint called the Total Plan that will encourage banks to part with their loans, partly by easing the process for them to sell collateralized properties at the Government auction.
 Friday, Keizo Obuchi, the new Prime Minister, announced a series of measures to stimulate the economy in his first major policy speech since taking office. He proposed tax cuts and public spending to spur the economy in the short term, but offered few details.
Already, over the last 18 months, many foreign companies have flooded into the business of combing the bad debt market and bidding up prices for the depressed land. So far, however, the profits and the number of transactions have been limited and they seem not to have done as well as they expected.
"We came in thinking it was a good business and everyone had their home office calling up and saying why haven't you done a deal yet?" said an American investment banker who is involved in such sales but refused to be identified. "There is no market. These sales don't represent a market."
But whether or not the foreign companies make any money, their activity could still help rescue Japan's troubled economy as they create a new business: wrapping up the bad debt into a tradable security.
Mr. Rodman is helping put the packaged transactions together, advising Japanese banks how to take bad loans, bundle them in groups of up to 300 loans and sell them for a bit of cash and a lot of tax deductions.
Optimists like Mr. Rodman note that the method is similar to the way the United States extricated itself from the savings and loan debacle of the 1980's. One key difference, though, is that the United States Government set up the Resolution Trust Corporation to clean up the crisis in five years, which is about as long as the Japanese have taken just to talk about the idea.
But it is far from clear whether the plan will work as well in Japan as it did in the United States. For starters, Japan's bad loans are worse than America's bad loans were. Japan also is dependent for buyers not on local people -- who generally have not touched the stuff -- but on the fickle appetites of foreigners, mostly Americans.
The bundles of bad Japanese loans have already attracted significant interest: midsized real estate investors, as well as blue-chip names like Merrill Lynch; Goldman, Sachs; Morgan Stanley, and Bankers Trust.
After Japan's bubble economy, which had been built on inflated real estate values, burst in 1990, banks and property owners hung on to bad loans even as prices fell. The entire property market congealed and banks became stuck with bad assets. But they often did not demand repayment for fear of putting their longtime clients into bankruptcy.
"It's a freezing situation that was comfortable to both" the banks and their borrowers, said Kiichi Miyazawa, who was appointed Finance Minister in July and is a former Prime Minister. Mr. Miyazawa added, however, that Japan was now beginning to address the financial crisis.
The recovery of Japan's real estate market is central to the restoration of health of the finance sector and the economy as a whole. But for now, bad loans remain the fundamental source of economic disarray.
Properties in Japan have lost up to 90 percent of their value in some locations, so Japanese banks have been reluctant to sell collateral at cut-rate prices and lock in huge losses, or to turn their backs on long-time clients.
"We're pushing the banks," said Yasuhisa Shiozaki, who resigned recently as parliamentary vice finance minister. "There should be a variety of ways of resolving the bad debt, and the largest part should be through sales, bulk sales or singles sales -- straight sales to the market."
Japanese banks have been selectively selling their collateralized properties at public auctions and private sales, already removing billions of dollars worth of bad loans from their balance sheets. Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading economic newspaper, estimated that the face value of the transactions might have reached $28 billion, and bankers involved in such sales say that estimate is reasonable. If so, the sum is equivalent to nearly one-third of the official accounting of unrecoverable loans.
A typical sale works this way: A Japanese bank assembles a giant package of many bad loans, some backed by collateral properties, some not. The total face value of the package may be worth as much as a few billion dollars, but the bank sells the package to foreign investors at a deep discount, anywhere from 5 percent to 50 percent of the total face value.
Some of the savvier banks first go out and sell the collateralized properties themselves because they think they can get a decent return through the Government auction process or private placements. Then they include these unbacked loans in the package to foreigners free, bundling them along with the collateralized ones, just to sweep the bad debt off the books.
Selling loans can be a messy business because a collateralized property may have as many as 50 liens on it, making it hard for the bank to seize.
And the packaging of the bad debt is a risky undertaking for everyone involved, in part, investors and brokers say, because of the yakuza, the Japanese gangsters who control rackets involved in squatting in troubled properties and small-debt collection, among other activities.
No one wants to knock on the door to collect the rent on a new investment and find the yakuza at home. And while the police may be able to help in pinpointing a yakuza connection to a particular property, they sometimes cannot do much until it's too late; few have forgotten that a Sumitomo Bank executive involved in loan collection was murdered in 1994, and industry executives suspect the yakuza.
Many investment bankers say the yakuza connection is exaggerated and illegal squatting is on the decline because courts are starting to crack down.
Still, one of the most pressing questions on the mind of every investor is whether a given piece of property is somehow linked to the yakuza.
That is where Miss Nishikawa comes in. Her company copies the auction listings from dog-eared postings at the Tokyo courthouse, where real estate auctions are held, and she and her colleagues dash off to check out the properties and draw up a report for customers looking to buy homes or buildings on the cheap.
"Many people might have the image that this kind of property is involved in the cleanup of unhappy problems," said Takami Toriya, a board director at the Tokyo Auction Forum Company, which brokers properties sold at the Government's auction. "But there are good properties at any auction. We opened this place in central Tokyo to try to remove this dark, dangerous and fearsome image."
The problem arises because companies that own real estate with bubble-sized loans sometimes pay for the yakuza or other gangsters to squat on the property on the theory that they will dissuade the bank from foreclosing and make the property impossible to sell, according to experts in Japanese real estate.
"If a bank initiates a foreclosing and tries to evict a tenant or a loan shark, sometimes trouble happens," said Shoichi Honda, executive vice president at Kennedy-Wilson International, which helps evaluate mob connections when it appraises properties for investors. "When we checked one portfolio, we found 15 percent of the property contaminated."
One owner of a real estate company, who purchased a collateralized property at a Government auction, acknowledged that he had to call in mob affiliates to evict squatters in a building he bought.
"The properties put on auction are not such good quality," said the real estate executive, who refused to be identified. "They've got all kinds of dirty connections. In some cases, the houses are built illegally."
That presents another impediment to investors. For example, if buildings were constructed illegally, without access to the street, new investors may not get a local license to demolish and rebuild. "These properties," the real estate executive added, "are actually just trash."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Gain, But It's Too Early to Cheer

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market rallied for a third day yesterday as investors bought stocks whose prices had been pummeled during, and even before, the headline-grabbing selloff that began in mid-July.
But even with the three-day rally, the major market measures still ended the week down sharply, with the Dow Jones industrial average off 3.2 percent and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks down 2.8 percent. 
 "There are too many concerns around this market," said Marshall Acuff, an equity strategist with Salomon Smith Barney. "The market is going to remain volatile until they are all worked out."
The buying of battered stocks kept the technology-heavy Nasdaq index and the Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks well above water, but still off their highs for the day. The Nasdaq finished up 17.26 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 1,846.77, while the Russell ended at 415.80, up 9.18, or 2.3 percent. Advancing stocks outnumbered decliners, 2 to 1, another positive turn for the market.
But the way the Dow and the S.& P. gave up their gains in afternoon trading was a signal of continued volatility -- and continuing investor concern. It seemed that after a turbulent week, in which the Dow suffered its third-worst one-day point decline ever, investors were just tired or wanted to take what profits they could from the rally.
"That is another sign that the blue chips have further to decline," said Ralph J. Acampora, director of technical research at Prudential Securities, whose sudden switch to bearishness on Tuesday helped knock the Dow down 299.43 points.
The Dow and the S.& P. index, which are dominated by the bigger-company stocks that many investors now feel are overpriced, sank into negative territory in the afternoon. The Dow struggled back to finish up 20.34 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, at 8,598.02. It had been up 112 points. The S.& P. ended off 0.18 point at 1,089.45, after hitting 1,102.54.
Yesterday's early rally was helped by an apparently favorable July jobs report. Despite the distortions from the nearly eight-week strike against General Motors, the data showed that the domestic economy, especially the service sector, was still quite robust.
But there were still reminders of the worries that helped send the Dow industrials down 9.1 percent before the end-of-the-week rally. The drag on American exports and manufacturing from the economic crisis in Asia was reflected in the generally weak increase of 66,000 nonfarm jobs last month.
And as the stock market was rallying, the Japanese yen tumbled and is now weaker than it was when the United States and Japan intervened in the foreign exchange market to support the currency in mid-June.
The renewed weakness in the yen is a result of the lack of confidence in the new Japanese Government's ability to turn the nation's economy around, a necessary ingredient in any economic rebound across Asia. The first policy statement of the new Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi, to Parliament yesterday just added to the disappointment.
"The market has tried to shrug off Asia, but I think the problems there are getting worse," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "Japan is becoming a modern macroeconomic policy makers' nightmare."
Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, was more confident about the economic outlook. "When you look at the core forces underlying the market, they remain in good working order," he said. "So the sky is not falling."
The role battered stocks have played in the market rebound the last three days can be seen in the performance of the semiconductor industry, oil stocks and smaller-company stocks.
Worries about demand from Asia and climbing inventories had sent semiconductor stocks, including Advanced Micro Devices, Motorola and Teradyne tumbling. The Philadelphia semiconductor index, which also includes Intel, had fallen 29.5 percent from its February high to its low on June 15. But in the last three days the index is up 8.8 percent.
Oil stocks had also been off sharply as the price of oil plunged. The Philadelphia oil service index, which includes Halliburton and Schlumberger, dropped 48.5 percent from May 1 to Wednesday. But on Thursday and yesterday, the index jumped 7.8 percent. The Standard & Poor's index of major oil companies, including Exxon and Chevron, rose 3.3 percent yesterday after falling 16.8 percent since May 1.
Lastly, the Russell index of smaller-company stocks had fallen almost 19 percent from its high in April to a 1998 low on Wednesday. But in the last two days it jumped 4.3 percent.
In the bond market, the jobs and wage data in the July employment report did not upset investors because it supported the view that the Federal Reserve, whose policy-making committee meets on Aug. 18, will leave interest rates unchanged.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 20/32 , to 107 4/32 , while the bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.63 percent, from 5.67 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Vacco Says Man Led Ring In Illegal Sale Of Medicines

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
A Bronx man who is suspected of leading one of the largest black-market prescription drug operations in the state was indicted yesterday after more than $1 million worth of prescription medicine was found in his apartment, the authorities said.
The suspect, Elvin Mendez, 27, is accused of running the operation by buying prescription drugs from street-level dealers, stockpiling them and reselling large quantities to middlemen who then sold them to pharmacies throughout the nation. 
 The street-level dealers typically either bought the drugs from Medicaid patients for a fraction of their cost, stole the drugs from hospitals or clinics, or enlisted the help of medical professionals who could write and fill prescriptions, the authorities said.
Mr. Mendez was indicted after a six-month investigation in which investigators said they found plastic bags stuffed with AZT, the expensive AIDS medication, and other drugs at his Bronx apartment last spring. Investigators from State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco's Medicaid fraud unit also found a large number of empty prescription bottles, counterfeit drug manufacturers' labels, seals and packaging inserts, the Attorney General's office said.
Mr. Mendez is charged with one count of criminal diversion of prescription medications and prescriptions in the second degree, a felony, and faces up to seven years in prison if he is convicted. He was arraigned in State Supreme Court in the Bronx and was being held in $50,000 bail. Mr. Mendez has pleaded not guilty.
"This increasingly common scam, known as drug diversion, costs taxpayers millions of dollars," Mr. Vacco said, "and also potentially places the public at great risk because the drugs that are diverted from regulated channels of distribution are often expired, mishandled and potentially unsafe."
Mr. Mendez is accused of paying only a fraction of the cost for powerful drugs. Among the drugs the authorities said they found were Invirase and Viracept, two AIDS medications; Biaxin, an antibiotic; Procardia, a heart medication; Prozac, an antidepressant, and Proventil, an asthma drug.
Pointing to inconsistencies in the laws for such offenses, Mr. Vacco has proposed stiffer penalties for drug diversion. "A drug diverter who is caught selling a $1,100 bottle of medication would be slapped with a felony," he said. But if Mr. Mendez had been prosecuted solely for the $1 million worth of prescription drugs stashed in his apartment, he would have been subject to only a misdemeanor charge, Mr. Vacco said.
Most prescription medications that are diverted through the black market end up on the shelves of pharmacies, Mr. Vacco said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Motives For the Bombing

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
It is still unclear who is behind the evil bombing attacks against two U.S. embassies in Africa, but if you want to speculate here are some things to consider:
First, the targets -- Nairobi and Dar es Salaam -- were most likely chosen because these were soft locations, with open borders and lax police, where perpetrators could easily smuggle in explosives, assemble car bombs and detonate them without fear of detection. To pull off nearly simultaneous bombings, outside U.S. embassies in two different African countries, is not something your local terrorists are likely to be capable of. This usually requires at least the help of a state intelligence service, with access to safe houses, bomb-making techniques and diplomatic pouches. 
 Which countries or groups might have the capabilities and intentions to pull off such a twin attack?
Iran: Anyone who is following Iranian politics can see that there is a civil war going on inside Iran, between hard-line fundamentalists associated with Iran's spiritual guide, Ali Khamenei, and moderates aligned with President Mohammad Khatami. Although Mr. Khatami is President, Iran's intelligence services -- which are suspected of involvement in previous bombings against Jewish targets in Argentina and U.S. targets in the Middle East -- are still under the control of Ayatollah Khamenei and the hard-liners.
The White House has recently made important overtures to President Khatami and the moderates to see if it is possible to forge a new relationship, which Mr. Khatami himself has encouraged. The Iranian hard-liners are not pleased with this, and they are trying to undermine Mr. Khatami and his allies every way they can. The Iranian hard-liners may believe that the best way to kill any budding rapprochement between Iran and the U.S. is by killing Americans. Indeed, you can be sure that the closer the U.S. and Iran inch toward better relations, the more the hard-core, anti-American Iranian forces will do things to rupture them.
Iraq: Iraq too would have the capabilities and intentions to hit U.S. targets. It's hard to see why Iraq, when it's desperate to get the U.N. economic sanctions lifted, would undertake such an egregious attack on the U.S., which could only set back the lifting of sanctions indefinitely. But when it comes to Saddam Hussein, any perverse logic is possible.
A new Ramzi Yousef: Ramzi Yousef and his gang were sophisticated enough to pull off the 1993 truck bomb attack on the World Trade Center in Manhattan, which killed 6 people and injured more than 1,000. Mr. Yousef, a native of Pakistan, was not a country or a superpower. He was a super-empowered angry man. He had no particular ideology or political goals. He just hated America. He felt the U.S. was hostile to Muslims, and his goal was simply to kill as many Americans as possible.
There are more than a few Ramzi Yousefs still out there. They hate America because it is the most powerful country in the world, because they feel it throws its economic weight around with great arrogance and because its cultural exports uproot their traditional societies. They use the best of today's modern technology for the most evil of deeds. One reason Ramzi Yousef was caught was because police found his Toshiba laptop computer in his Manila apartment where all his plots were filed on the hard drive.
For now one can draw only a couple of conclusions. One is that the U.S. pays a price for letting things like the Khobar Towers bombing go without retaliation. Khobar Towers was the U.S. military apartment building in Saudi Arabia where a huge truck bomb exploded June 25, 1996, killing 19 Americans. The Saudis have never turned over all the evidence because some of it reveals links to Iran. The Saudis didn't want the U.S. retaliating against Iran and then leaving Saudi Arabia to absorb the counterstrike. The White House basically bowed to Saudi wishes. But when people think they can attack the U.S. with impunity, they will be tempted to try again.
The other conclusion is that if the U.S. is compelled to retaliate, the Monica Lewinsky affair can only complicate matters. Every foreign or domestic actor who is looking for excuses to oppose any U.S. retaliation in this case will say that President Clinton is only acting to distract attention from his embarrassing entanglements, and that will make building diplomatic support more difficult. Just one more reason it was so reckless for the Commander in Chief to be involved in any sort of improper relationship in the Oval Office.

HEADLINE: Job Growth Slowed a Bit in July But Still Kept to a Vigorous Pace

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The economy created jobs at a slower but still robust pace last month, and the unemployment rate held steady at 4.5 percent, the Labor Department reported today. Continued strong employment growth in service industries more than offset the damage that Asia's woes are inflicting on manufacturers.
Employers added 66,000 jobs to their payrolls in July, the lowest monthly figure in two and a half years. But the number was distorted by the strike against General Motors, which was settled late in the month after idling nearly 200,000 workers. 
 Economists said that without the temporary effects of the G.M. strike, the payroll increase would have been more than 200,000, a slight slowdown from the pace of job creation earlier in the year.
The figures provided further, but by no means definitive, evidence that the economy may be gradually cooling off, reducing concerns about inflation without raising any serious risk of recession.
Coming after a sharp selloff in stocks on Tuesday and several subsequent days of sweaty palms on Wall Street, the report reassured investors that the economy remained basically stable despite the confusing and sometimes conflicting forces, from Asia's downturn to the buoyancy of consumer spending, that have left the outlook unsettled.
After gaining as much as 132 points today, the Dow Jones industrial average fell back in late trading and closed up 20.34 points at 8,598.02.
"We're moving toward a desirable soft landing, but we're not quite there yet," said M. Cary Leahey, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm.
During the first half of the year, the economy added an average of 245,000 nonfarm jobs a month, raising concern that employers would have to bid up wages to attract workers, setting off an inflationary spiral.
Mr. Leahey said that July's underlying gain of about 207,000 jobs was consistent with an economy growing at 2.5 percent to 3 percent a year, still high enough at the current low unemployment rate to make inflation a threat, at least in the view of many Federal Reserve officials.
To bring growth within the Fed's noninflationary "speed limit" of about 2.25 percent would require that job gains decelerate to around 150,000 a month, Mr. Leahey said.
Although the economy slowed to a 1.4 percent growth rate in the second quarter from 5.5 percent in the first three months of the year, most economists see growth in the second half of the year running at an annual pace of 2 percent to 3 percent.
The most striking aspect of the report was the wide gulf between the strong growth in consumer-oriented service jobs, especially retailing, and the slide in employment among manufacturers, which are having trouble exporting to Asia and are facing increasing competition from imports from that part of the world.
Service industries created 229,000 jobs during the month, including 125,000 in retailing. Manufacturers, on the other hand, shed 176,000 jobs during the month, including those lost temporarily to the G.M. strike. Even after adjusting for the effects of the strike, the manufacturing loss was about 20,000 jobs in July, in line with the scale of the manufacturing downturn throughout most of this year. Last year, manufacturers added an average of 20,000 jobs a month.
"Manufacturing and services are in two different worlds," said Cliff Waldman, an economist with the National Federation of Independent Businesses.
The report showed that wage gains appeared to be moderating or holding steady. Average hourly earnings in July increased 3 cents, or two-tenths of a percent, to $12.79, although the gain might have been slightly greater in the absence of the G.M. strike.
Over the last 12 months, earnings have increased at a 4.2 percent annual pace, matching the pace over the 12 months ended in June and slightly lower than the annual pace in April and May.
The Federal Reserve has been looking intently for signs of inflation since March but has not raised interest rates, because there is little evidence that inflation is taking root and also because any rate increase could further destabilize the already-shaky financial markets in Asia. Today's report is unlikely to lead the Fed to change its stance at its next meeting, on Aug. 18, analysts said.
They added that Fed officials were sure to track closely the tug-of-war between those sectors of the economy that are being hit by the combination of the strong dollar and Asia's difficulties and those being driven by consumer confidence and a willingness to spend.
The Fed reported today that consumer installment credit in June jumped $6.7 billion -- a 6.4 percent annual growth rate -- indicating that consumers remained willing to borrow to continue their long spending spree.
Some analysts think consumers are about to become more cautious, reflecting the slowdown in wage growth and record-low savings. But others see few signs of consumer moderation and think service-sector job growth will continue to put pressure on wages even as manufacturing shrinks.
Today's job report "indicates only the most minor slowdown in labor demand, almost exclusively in the manufacturing sector," said Ian Shepherdson, an economist with HSBC Securities. "There is nothing in this report to support the idea that a wider slowdown is gathering pace."

HEADLINE: G.M. Marketing Chief Glum In Assessing Strike Damage

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Aug. 7

 BODY:
The nearly eight-week-long strike this summer at two General Motors parts factories will continue to hurt the auto maker's sales until October, and some customers have been permanently lost, G.M.'s top marketing executive said here today.
In the gloomiest assessment yet of the strike's damage, Ronald L. Zarrella, the group vice president for North American sales, service and marketing, said that G.M. dealerships would not be fully restocked until mid-September. The introduction of some 1999 models will also be delayed, he said, because G.M. has so many parts left over for 1998 models that it is cheaper for the company to keep building those models instead of discarding the parts. 
 The company will run new advertisements this weekend that will emphasize that the auto maker is back in business and that 1998 cars and trucks are available at discounts that reflect the end of the model year, Mr. Zarrella said. But G.M.'s market share, usually about 31 percent, will be below 25 percent in August and will not rebound fully until October, he said.
Without giving a number, Mr. Zarrella said some longtime customers had decided to buy cars and trucks from competitors and would be hard to woo back. Each percentage point of market share is worth 150,000 cars and trucks a year, or $3 billion in annual sales.
Susan G. Jacobs, an automotive consultant in Rutherford, N.J., said that General Motors' permanent loss might be as high as one and a half percentage points because the strike slowed its introduction of several completely new car and truck models. But G.M. executives may benefit from highlighting the strike's harm, she said.
"They can refer to the long strike as derailing them from staying over 30" percent, a convenient excuse for declining market share, she said.
Wall Street's assessment of the strike's costs grew steadily grimmer this week, and the company's share price drifted down despite G.M.'s announcement of several initiatives long sought by institutional investors, including a spinoff of the auto parts subsidiary and a consolidation of marketing operations. Shares rebounded to $72.50 during the day today, from $70.25 on Thursday, but then gave back some of the gain after Mr. Zarrella's disclosures at a midday news conference at the University of Michigan's annual auto industry conference here. The stock closed up 81.25 cents a share at $71.0625.
G.M. announced on Wednesday that its sales dropped 37.7 percent in July compared with July 1997. Its market share was just 21.1 percent.
In a typical year, many G.M. factories would be closed by now to install new equipment for the production of the next model year's cars and trucks. The new models would then go on sale in late September and early October.
But Mr. Zarrella said the company had continued to produce 1998 models since the strike ended on July 29. It still has 1998 model-year parts for 200,000 more cars and trucks, or about two weeks of production. The company will use up these parts before converting production to the 1999 model year, he said.
Auto makers have traditionally introduced their new models at the same time because of a belief that laggards could lose sales to companies that move faster. But Mr. Zarrella said it was not clear whether G.M. would suffer this autumn by offering a mix of 1998 and 1999 models even as other auto makers have ample supplies of 1999 models.
Wall Street analysts estimate that the strike cost G.M. $12 billion in lost production and $3 billion in lost after-tax profits. Until this week, some analysts thought G.M. would be able to recover most of the lost profits by running its factories around the clock for the rest of the year.
But John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said on Wednesday that even with extra production through the rest of the year, the auto maker's permanent loss would be about $2 billion.
"We ran into a buzz saw in the strike," Mr. Smith said.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Illegal Smoke For the 90's, From Cuba

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
LAST night, on Day 3 of the great Federal crackdown against Manhattan's outlaw Cuban cigar aficionados, a cigar bar seemed just the place to puff awhile and wait for the smoke to clear.
"Dragging those people off just for smoking Cubans, it's absurd," said John McFadden, an investment banker who was savoring an Astral cigar and gesturing in the general direction of his companion, Joseph Avantario. 
 "This whole Cuban thing was topic one at lunch today," said Mr. Avantario, lighting up another of Mr. McFadden's Astrals. "Just about every U.S. Senator smokes Cuban cigars. So why not go after them?"
They were enjoying a predinner puff last night with a friend, Janine Johnson, in the Cigar Bar at Carnegie Bar and Books at 156 West 56th Street, a cynosure of the smokily comfortable, clubby little world of the upscale Manhattan cigar worshipper.
True, it was the Friday night kickoff to a summer weekend, and many high-end cigarophiles had already headed for the Hamptons or were firing up entirely legal Cuban Cohibas in the hills of Tuscany.
But in New York, 35 diehards were breathing cigar smoke, sipping cocktails and listening to light jazz in the mahogany-and-maroon bar, with its bronze chandeliers and showcases filled with Partagas, H. Upmann and Dunhill cigars.
Subi Gurge, a financial consultant, was puffing a Honduran Padron as he sat with 11 colleagues under the bar's ornate stairway. He was ruminating annoyedly about "that ridiculous embargo against Castro."
"The rest of the world doesn't support it," he said, "and it isn't effective anyway."
Last night, most of the smokers said they were well aware of the news that on Wednesday, Federal officials charged the operators of an upscale restaurant and a private club in Manhattan with illicitly selling Cuban cigars to customers.
Federal agents with search warrants seized hundreds of boxes of cigars from the humidors of the Patroon restaurant on East 46th Street and the Racquet and Tennis Club on Park Avenue. On Thursday, prosecutors charged four investors and businessmen, including two chief executives, with buying contraband Cubans.
Yesterday, two more cigar smokers were drawn into the Federal investigation, bringing to nine those arrested. Michael Dana, 38, a managing director in the investment banking division at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, and Jeffrey Kelter, 44, president of a real-estate investment company in suburban Philadelphia, were arraigned in Manhattan Federal Court and released on their own recognizance.
"The enforcement seems so selective," Ms. Johnson said. "Why single these people out from all the people who have Cuban cigars?"
FEDERAL officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity said high-profile Cuban cigar prosecutions were a deterrent that not only responded to violations of Federal law (since owning them is a felony), but also supported United States foreign policy and helped to deny economic benefits to Cuba, since the state manages cigar production.
One of Mr. Gurge's colleagues, who gave his name only as Eric, said: "Americans shouldn't smoke Cubans because that's supporting the Cuban Government," he said. "And they're evading paying taxes."
But Mr. Avantario, an investment banker who lives in Chappaqua, N.Y., said Cuban Cohibas, Montecristos and Romeo Y Julietas are ubiquitous. "If you want them, you can get them," he said. "They even hide them under the ribbons of Dominican cigars."
Only a few in the bar would admit to having gone Cuban. "I did have one Cuban cigar," said Peter Genet, a real-estate consultant, "but I didn't inhale."
His companions in the book nook near the door, Robert and Marie Guarnieri, rolled their eyes as they laughed. "I had my first and only Cuban cigar on my wedding night in Sweden," said Mr. Guarnieri, a technology consultant who lives in Manhattan.
"And that was legal!" Mrs. Guarnieri said.
At the ornate mahogany bar, Eric Lightner, the manager, explained to a visitor that "people ask all the time for Cubans," he said. "What we tell them is the truth. We don't have them."
However, "many customers come in with their own Cubans to smoke them here," said Tara Oniki, the cocktail waitress. "They aren't worried by all this. They don't take this seriously. In fact, the only reason they smoke Cubans is for show. You know why I think they smoke them? Because they're illegal."
