HEADLINE: Permission Granted to Kill a Whale. Now What?

BYLINE: By Robert Sullivan; Robert Sullivan is the author of "The Meadowlands: Wilderness Adventures at the Edge of a City," an adaptation of which appeared in The New York Times Magazine in February.

 BODY:
In the fall, the Makah Nation, a Native American tribe of 2,000 people that makes its home at the very northwest tip of the continental United States, plans to send a crew of eight men out into the Pacific Ocean in a canoe to harpoon a whale. It will be the first time a Makah crew has hunted a whale since the late 1920's, when a tradition of thousands of years was ended because of overhunting. So it is an event of great significance to the Makah people, who consider the whale hunt to be a sacramental act. It is turning out to be an event of great significance to people who aren't Makah too.
In the Northwest, a little tribe that no one had heard of is suddenly front-page news, with environmentalists' protests and anti-Makah Web sites springing up like the late-summer wildflowers that drape Washington State's Olympic Peninsula, site of the Makah reservation. On a sunny day last winter, as the newly chosen whaling crew was making its first practice run in Neah Bay, John McCarty, one of the Makah who were organizing the hunt, stood on the beach and watched the canoe put into the white-haired waves. "The whole world," he announced, "is watching the Makah." 
 For the most part, the world is not too happy. In 1996, with the support of the Federal Government, the Makah applied to the International Whaling Commission to hunt whales, citing an 1855 treaty that they say allows them to do so. But by the time they received permission, in October 1997, to take up to five California gray whales a year for five years for ceremonial purposes, everyone from an Australian animal rights group to an international whale-watching association had begun complaining. This spring, just as a $310,000 grant from the Commerce Department was winding down, preparations for the hunt nearly came to an end. At an anti-Makah rally in downtown Seattle in June, Representative Jack Metcalf, a Washington State Republican who has spoken of the American people's "special relationship with whales," vowed to stop the whale hunt.
As the time for the hunt approaches and protests become increasingly belligerent -- an anonymous letter threatened that one Makah would be killed for every whale -- the tribe has taken to meeting regularly with a law-enforcement task force, partly to protect the Makah, partly to protect the protesters who are expected to show up in Neah Bay at the end of this month at the tribe's annual Makah Days celebration.
The protest operations are being led by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, the marine-conservation group based in Marina del Rey, Calif., that prides itself on having sunk nine whaling ships during 20 years of whale-hunt protests. In the past, Sea Shepherd has been a champion of Native American rights, but in this case it insists that a Makah hunt will be used by worldwide commercial whaling interests to break the world's moratorium on hunting whales. (Whale hunting is generally banned internationally, though a few nations ignore the ban and several aboriginal groups are allowed special privileges to hunt.) Paul Watson, the president of Sea Shepherd, plans to block the Makah whaling crew with his command ship, a flotilla of private boats and a small decommissioned Norwegian Navy submarine armed with killer-whale sounds intended to frighten away gray whales. "This is possibly the most important whale hunt in the past 25 years," Watson says.
All this is not exactly what the Makah imagined when they dreamed of one day having a chance to hunt a whale again, back when it looked as if just getting permission to hunt was the big hurdle. And yet the Makah -- despite the protests, the political pressure and a nasty bout of internal squabbling -- are moving ahead with the hunt.
"It's a war out there, and we know it," George Bowechop, a village elder and a member of the tribe's whaling commission, told me one night at a celebration for the return of the hunt. The protesters' scorn, he said, has made the Makah only more determined. "They want us in the museum. They'd rather we just said, 'Oh, the Makah were great whalers,' and leave it at that. They want us to have a dead culture. But it's been our way of life. We look at the ocean and we feel we not only have a legal right but a moral right to whale."
On the day last winter when the whaling crew was making its very first practice run, a few Makah village elders surveyed the action alongside local kids and a small team of aboriginal and commercial whalers who had flown in on a kind of whalers' field trip. They came from Iceland and Tonga and Japan and a few of the other whale-hunt-friendly places around the world. One Icelandic whaler -- blond-haired and blue-eyed and wearing a parka, in contrast to the shirtless, dark-haired Makah crew members who were shedding their basketball shoes and preparing to paddle off in gym shorts -- reminded another visitor that the actual whale-hunting portion of a whale hunt can be difficult too. "In Iceland," he said, sizing up the Makah's 34-foot canoe, "we hunt for whales much smaller than the gray whale and we use a boat that is much bigger than this one. I hope they are careful, because with a whale, you know, it's not a game."
Micah McCarty was at the front of the Makah canoe as it set out that day. Micah is the son of John McCarty and great-grandson of Hishka, one of the last of the great Makah hunters, and for a long time Micah has been talked about as the Makah expected to harpoon the whale. As he paddled out toward the mouth of the bay, out toward the snow-covered mountains of British Columbia, all was quiet except the paddles as they sliced through the gray surf: when you closed your eyes you could imagine a hunt that was free of protests and politics and bureaucracy -- a hunt like his great-grandfather might have led. "If you paddle right," Micah said, looking out ahead of the canoe, "you can paddle for hours."
As he continued to paddle, Micah talked about how the canoes of his ancestors were equipped with food and water for several days, in case the whale fought and ran and dragged the boat through the ocean. "We could get one right away or we might have to go for a while," he said.
With that, Micah rose up in the canoe, and, though there was no great hump of barnacled whale rising up from the flat surface of the sea, he drew back his arm and stood as if he were about to launch his harpoon.
For the Makah, the idea behind the whale hunt was simple: by resurrecting this cultural and spiritual centerpiece of the tribe, the community would blossom again and the local economy might even be revived. Unlike most tribes in the United States, the Makah live on their ancestral land, on the very peninsula of cedar trees and rocky, volcanic cliffs from which their great-grandparents set off in search of gray whales. As it is now, Neah Bay, the reservation's main village, is a small fleet of ramshackle houses on streets lined with old furniture and rusty appliances: about 50 percent of the villagers are unemployed. The hunt has in some ways created a canoe-based empowerment zone.
Though the Makah no longer crave the taste of whale meat, the gray whale has historically been considered life sustaining. Traditional tribal stories tell of the time when the Makah could not leave the land for food because of great storms and Thunderbird, a flying wolflike god, delivered a whale to their shores. But for the last two generations, this life-sustaining relationship has become a parody. Even when dead whales have washed ashore on the Makah's beaches, armed Federal guards have been posted to keep the tribe from carving them up.
Some opponents of the Makah's hunt have argued that it was actually dreamed up by commercial whalers in Iceland or Norway or Japan. But as some Makah remember it, the tribe's fisheries-management people were down by the docks when they read in the local newspaper that the gray whale would soon be coming off the endangered-species list. John McCarty, who at 63 is too young to have witnessed his grandfather's last whale hunt, recalls walking up from his fishing boat at about that time and hearing someone say: "Hey, John! How'd you like to go hunt a whale?" It wasn't long before the idea became a hit with the tribal council, and the simple idea began its accrual of modern complications.
The complications began last fall, with the choosing of an eight-man crew. In the old days, each family had its whalers, but now the council had to jump-start the dead tradition. A whaling commission was formed to select the crew and to draw up some physical and spiritual guidelines -- paddling-endurance standards, for example, and instruction in methods of personal prayer, all of which had to be culled from old stories and archival sources, since no living Makah had been on a whale hunt. Everything had to be cleared by the tribe's Seattle-based lawyers, and a whale-management plan was written in cooperation with the National Marine Fisheries Service. The tribal whaling commission came up with a budget, hired a staff and tried to set up its computer, such that over the winter the sacred act of whaling became a kind of bureaucracy in itself. Aside from being the great-grandsons and -nephews of Hishka, aside from being connected by tradition to the spirits of the sea, the crew would also have on-the-job insurance.
At the core of the crew were the first four men named. Wayne Johnson ended up being the leader of the squad, in charge of getting everyone together for physical and spiritual training, though he tended to emphasize the physical. He is tall and thin; he looks like a semiretired stuntman. At 45, he is by far the oldest crew member -- and is likely, when the hunt comes, to follow alongside the whaling canoe in some kind of a chase boat. Darrell Markishtum, in his mid-30's, is the crew's unofficial chaplain, its spiritual center. He works for the tribal fisheries office but in his spare time collects traditional Makah stories. Donnie Swan, in his early 20's, is a fisherman and hunter who rides a motorcycle and wears Oakley sunglasses and camouflage. He is strong and quick and anxious for the hunt. "My oldest daughter's always saying, 'My daddy's gonna catch the whale!"' Donnie says.
Micah McCarty, 27, is the crew's bohemian, a kind of Save the Whales whaler who sees environmentalism and whaling as compatible if conducted on ancient Native American terms. He generally wears black jeans, a black shirt, black hiking boots and a black beret; he ties back his long, dark brown hair in a ponytail. He carves traditional masks and totems from cedar and exhibits his work in galleries in Seattle and Victoria. He is smart and sharp-tongued. "Our sacred tradition is all wrapped up in red tape," he often says. Micah lives amid carving tools and paperbacks in an old military barracks, a few dozen yards from the ancient Makah whaling village. "I grew up as a minority kid and I knew I was the descendant of these people who were like kings, and I was like, Why? To me, I'm living the last will and testament of my ancestors, as opposed to dying on the job in some industrial reality."
The members of the Makah Whaling Commission had envisioned a kind of Colonial Williamsburg-style hunt, one that would resemble the hunt of their ancestors, with at least one exception. In keeping with tradition, the crew was given spiritual training and learned the old whale-hunting songs; they traveled to Alaska hoping to sing and dance and hunt with native whale hunters. The big exception was that, in addition to the harpoon, the Makah crew would take along a gun. That gun is a .50-caliber rifle with an infrared sight; it's light green-gray and is heavy and looks to the untrained eye like a bazooka. It was modified with the help of a ballistics expert (who is also a veterinarian) to quickly kill a gray whale without knocking the hunter out of the canoe. The people protesting the hunt have called the Makah's rifle inhumane. "There isn't a trace of 'ceremonial whaling' in this plan," Sea Shepherd has written. "It's blatant, undeniable whale warfare!"
But to the crew, the rifle is a safety precaution, and they don't see why a modern traditional whale hunter shouldn't have one. "The rifleman will shoot as this is in the air," Micah explained to me one day on the beach, holding aloft his practice harpoon. "It will be simultaneous. Because that's the way we feel we can achieve the quickest time-to-death ratio. Basically, the time to beat is 15 minutes until the whale is subdued."
Even with a rifle along, however, a whale hunt is something to be anxious about. Early one morning last winter, when the bay was like a sheet of glass in the just-risen sun, Wayne got the crew together at J.J.'s Pizza, a little beachfront bakery. Everyone was there but Micah, who at the last minute caught a ferry to British Columbia to visit his girlfriend. The whalers talked about taking group hikes and group sweats. Darrell was thinking about getting back into tai chi. Everyone was needling Donnie about having given up smoking in preparation for the hunt.
In the old days, Wayne was saying, there were periods of quiet and prayer and deprivation before the hunt. Men would purify themselves by living alone in the woods and bathing in mountain ponds and streams; they would abstain from sex. "If they hunted a whale," Wayne said, "and the whale got away, the first thing they would do is look around the canoe and say, 'O.K., who slept with their wife?"'
After coffee, the men wandered down the beach. They shared some modern whale stories, like the one about the Russian whalers who were tossed from their canoe and dangled in the freezing water while the whale came back and studied them as if it were pricing a cheap jewel.
"When we met the Russian chief, he said that not everyone's going to come home all the time," Wayne said. "The gray whale, if he gets mad, he'll attack you."
They all nodded their heads and were quiet for a while, and then they compared the length of a 50-foot gray whale with the length of their canoe.
March was to be the month that the crew's rigorous training started, but things didn't go as planned. The month began all right, with a potlatch for the crew, a night of celebration and dancing, after which the crew flew to Alaska. But the whalers returned to discover that the protesters were gaining strength and that their own momentum had stalled.
The men were reduced to sitting around -- this was the week, coincidentally, that "Moby-Dick" was playing on cable TV. They went out in the canoe a few times, and trained a little on their own; Donnie was smoking again, but he had also begun to harpoon seals and sea lions. Micah, too, continued to practice throwing his harpoon. For the most part, however, the crew members were frustrated. In the crew's sweat lodge one night, across the street from a diner, Wayne lamented in the steamy darkness that they weren't getting out in the canoe enough. "The women are out there every night canoeing," he said. "And if the women can do it, we can, too."
As executive director of the tribal whaling commission, John McCarty was coming under stealth attack; unbeknown to him, factions of the whaling commission and the tribal council were moving to shut him down. They felt he had not moved fast enough and that he was not taking proper advantage of the technology available to the hunt. For a time, John tried to run the hunt without the tribal council's blessing; in the end, he decided to pull out altogether and moved away from the reservation for a while to work a roofing job. His son Micah stayed on the crew.
By the end of June, training was back on track. Wayne had the crew out paddling after work almost every night. The carving of a traditional 36-foot whaling canoe was almost done. Keith Johnson, the president of the Makah's whaling commission, announced that, barring any legal challenges, the hunt would go on sometime in October -- which is when the whales arrive and also the time when the ocean normally begins to turn dangerously rough. Keith, for his part, was trying to keep expectations down. "We're going to learn a lot," he said. "There are a lot of unknowns. We could have a great, great hunt and not get a whale."
Although momentum had been recaptured, the tone of the hunt had somehow changed. The crew seemed more interested in using modern technology to get the first whale and traditional methods later, after it had established -- to protesters, to the world -- the tribe's ancient right to whale hunt. No one seemed to lament this more than Micah. He was still planning to go on the hunt, though it wasn't clear who would throw the harpoon. "Whoever throws that harpoon is going to go down in history," Wayne said.
For his part, Micah said he would give up his place in the canoe only if he felt the hunt was somehow sacrilegious, if it was not respectful of the whale. He also talked about the possibility of leading his own hunt, perhaps next year. As for training, Micah had managed to stay focused during all the turmoil. Most days, he woke, said a water prayer, stretched out, put on his Nike Air cross trainers and went out for a long run. From his home, he crossed the river where his great-grandfather Hishka would have bathed. Micah trained not for the sake of body-fat reduction but to make himself worthy of a sort of nobility, an apostolic succession. "There's an old saying that the whale chooses the whaler," Micah said, "and I want to be honorable enough to be chosen by the whale."
Earlier this summer, Micah took a long hike north along the beach. He left late in the day and walked into dusk and then built a bonfire and catnapped before the growing flames. As the sun was setting, he heard an otter breaking open shells on its belly, and then he imagined ancient canoes and ancient hunters, and then he was just looking out over the ocean, over the horizon, looking, listening.
Along the hike, he found himself thinking about his own whale hunt and even picturing the whale, as he often does these days. "I was visualizing the scenario of the final approach," he said, "with the whale blowing its stack. I was visualizing plunging the harpoon. And I was wondering, Would it be an electrical charge from the animal to me? What will the animal feel in its heart? What would it be like? What would it be like to be there with the whale?"

HEADLINE: Taking a Flier on a Ferry

BYLINE: By ROBERT PACKARD; ROBERT PACKARD lives in Maine and New York City, where he has yet to ride the Staten Island Ferry.

 BODY:
AN unlikely vessel is racing through the waters between Bar Harbor, Me., and Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, four times a day. This ship, nearly as big as a football field, travels up to 55 miles an hour. It can accommodate 762 passengers, 240 cars and 4 buses.
Named The Cat, it looks like a huge black sea beast with windows for gills. Its colorful pointed bow, high above the water, is shaped and painted to suggest dynamic flow, with a stylized cat leaping over the ship's name. The original catamaran, a narrow raft of parallel logs propelled by sails, has here metamorphosed into a 300-foot-long, 85-foot-wide, water-jet-driven behemoth. 
 The Cat was launched last September on the island of Tasmania and for a short time provided ferry service across Bass Strait between Melbourne, Australia, and Tasmania. It moved to Maine this spring. The old Bluenose ferry, which The Cat replaced, traveled at a service speed of about 19 knots (about 22 m.p.h), making the 118-mile trip from Bar Harbor to Yarmouth in six and a half hours. The new ship takes just two and a half hours and makes two round trips a day.
The Cat's speed is possible because it pierces the waves with four 9,500-horsepower engines and two wave-piercing hulls, augmented by a stabilizer between them.
As one who feels queasy in a canoe when a lake breeze causes a slight ripple, I was less than enthusiastic about embarking on The Cat. I spend my summers on a dead-end rural road in the bluest of blue-collar Maine communities, and life there offers precisely the tranquillity I seek. Furthermore, I had absolutely no reason to travel to Yarmouth. But my friends Beth and Jason persuaded me to take a one-day round-trip cruise with them on The Cat last month.
"There's a bar," Beth said.
"And a casino," Jason added, "along with a cafe."
"Don't forget the duty-free gift shop," Beth reminded me, although its contents in the purlieus of Yarmouth and Bar Harbor transcended my acquisitive imagination. Unpersuaded, I hesitated, but the phrase "hidebound and stuffy" somehow wafted in my direction. I packed my knapsack.
For some reason, it's de rigueur to rise at 5 A.M. in rural Maine, and thus we arrived at the Bar Harbor dock well before the 8 A.M. departure. By 7:15, more than 100 cars were lined up waiting to board The Cat. Those of us on the day-trip "cruise" parked near the administration office, where we purchased our tickets ($44.95 round trip).
The ship itself was distant enough to make taking the shuttle bus sensible. But on that chilly sunlit morning, we walked to the stairways near the ship's stern. The bow faced the island-studded sparkling harbor; the stern opened up to allow, on this Sunday morning, 141 vehicles to drive aboard.
We entered the passenger area of two top decks, accommodating close to 800 passengers (we were 436 on this trip) in long lines of seats, as many as 30 across, with tables that fold down from the back of the seat ahead. On the upper seating deck are rows of two seats abreast near the high windows. No portholes on this ship.
"Let's park ourselves and our gear right here," Beth said, indicating a short aisle row next to a window.
"Let's explore the ship before we take off," Jason said -- his airline terminology seemed entirely appropriate.
"Let's not," I said, as a formidable jet-propelled roar resounded.
With surprising ease and enormous panache, we began moving past the small islands outlying Bar Harbor and soon had attained a speed of some 40 miles an hour. I kept waiting for us to be airborne. My first erroneous expectation of this flight on the sea's surface envisioned wide-open decks, deck chairs and sun-drenched areas. Had that been the case, passengers would have been blown into the frigid Atlantic. My stock of sunscreen, sweaters and visor caps indicated my preconceptions -- not to mention my store of inedible squashed sandwiches.
Directly behind our seats, a door led to an open observation deck at the stern. Leaning on the rail, we were treated to a dazzling sight. Two jet-propelled spumes rose high in the air from the hulls. The spumes became mist as they ascended, and beyond them, the wake caused by the ship's speed left long white trails on the ocean's green surface.
There were heavy swells but no breaking waves. The ship developed a roll sufficiently pronounced that for anyone intrepid enough to walk about, holding onto seat backs and stair railings became a sensible tactic. Jason's complexion acquired a distinctly greenish hue. Beth went to the cafe for coffee. Queasy, I pretended to read my book's wavering print.
But the ship became steadier as we progressed. The surface of the sea was calmer, and we moved into a heavy fog (the Gulf of Maine and the Bay of Fundy specialize in fog).
We went our separate ways: Beth to take photographs; Jason to find a fresh-air spot on a slice of open deck up by the bridge; I to satisfy my curiosity by tormenting the crew with questions about their duties and facts about the ship.
The crew is mostly Canadian (the parent company of Bay Ferries Ltd., operators of The Cat, is on Prince Edward Island) and many live in the Yarmouth area. They work 12-hour days for a week, then have a week off. The ferry runs till the end of October. This winter, it may return to Australia for service.
In the course of the five-hour round trip, I covered the gift shop, the cafe, the vast underground decks where vehicles are parked and the bridge. The gift shop's best seller is liquor, which for Canadians is close to 50 percent cheaper. Next in sales are tapes of Nova Scotian musicians.
I bypassed the bar in the interests of sobriety, and the casino (slot machines, black jack and poker) in the interests of economy. I checked out the cafe.
In the interior's snugly welded garage decks, with a 240-vehicle capacity, the hypercautious driver of one car had attached his steering wheel safety lock against the prospect of a thief driving it through the hull and atop the waves; on the dashboard of another car, a white cat snoozed peaceably despite the jet's roar. Ken Winter, the purser, showed me the operation of the 10 inflatable life rafts (each with a capacity of 100 passengers), which can be activated within minutes.
The fog lifted. Yarmouth harbor appeared in the distance; I wished I had been on land to see us approaching. The sun shone. We debarked for 45 minutes; Jason's complexion improved on terra firma, and I marveled at the contrast between our Yarmouth landing area and that in Bar Harbor.
Yarmouth looked more like a Maine coastal fishing town half a century ago, while the backdrop of Bar Harbor's departure area consisted of upscale lodgings with tennis courts and swimming pools. From this limited perspective, Yarmouth appeared to be an unspoiled charmer, as natural and hunkered down as its rocky, pine-strewn, working-vessel environment; Bar Harbor, beyond its pleasure craft, looked sophisticatedly inviting, augmented by Acadia National Park, whose entrance is close by the ferry terminal.
On the return trip, we had mostly different passengers, different vehicles, a calm sea, breaking clouds and a fog-free skim atop the ocean at some 40 miles an hour.
"Try to savor the environment," said Beth, who was fed up with my scouring the innards of the ship. "Come up to the open deck rail by the bridge and see what you've been missing."
Both she and Jason are avid bird-watchers and sea-creature aficionados. With their help, I saw many storm petrels, a cormorant flying parallel to and at the same speed as The Cat, schools of harbor porpoises, some dolphins and I'd like to say a whale, but alas none appeared. Yet on the bridge, we observed through a window a woman who is conducting a five-day-a-week whale watch study on these trips.
The captain, David Doucet, sided by the navigator and chief engineer, occupies a bridge area whose radar and computer goodies rival those of a jet plane's cockpit. Captain Doucet shared a minute with me, and I learned that he had accompanied The Cat on its leisurely three-week trip up from Australia. They traveled at a moderate speed (30 m.p.h.), with stopovers in Tahiti and Panama. His enthusiasm revealed his pride and admiration of The Cat, with its maneuverability, unequaled passenger-ship speed and seaworthy capabilities.
What didn't I like about the ship? I'm too queasy to go on it if the sea were really rough, I wish that announcements on the public address system were more intelligible and that the video screen map of our progress were less indistinguishable. In other words, piddling complaints for an exhilarating experience.
"The next time," Beth told me, "try not to talk to so many people, interrupting their duties. And no more squashed sandwiches."
"Add a sprinkling of seasick remedy," Jason suggested, "to make them truly appetizing."
Next time they can bring their own.
 
Racing the birds across the Bay of Fundy

 Getting Aboard
Same-day tickets for The Cat can be bought at the Bay Ferries office, at 121 Eden Street, Bar Harbor, Me., by the dock.
Schedule and rate information are available from (888) 249-7245, as are reservations, for which there is a $5 service charge.
Walk-up passenger rates each way for the two-and-a-half-hour trip between Bar Harbor and Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, are $45, $20 for ages 5 to 16 and $40 for those 65 and older; children under 5 are free.
Motor vehicles up to 20 feet cost $55, 20 to 30 feet $88, 30 to 40 feet $122. Motorcycles are $32 and bicycles $10.
One-day round-trip cruises cost $44.95, $19.95 for children and $39.95 for ages 65 and older.
All sales aboard are in American dollars (there is a currency exchange aboard) and Visa, Mastercard, American Express and Diners/ Enroute cards are accepted.
 
 Shoving Off
Through Oct. 3, the Cat departs Bar Harbor at 8 A.M. and 3:30 P.M., and Yarmouth at 12:30 and 8 P.M. From Oct. 4 to Oct. 30, it leaves Bar Harbor at 10 A.M. and Yarmouth at 3 P.M. (These are local times; Yarmouth is in a different time zone from Bar Harbor, so a 12:30 departure from Yarmouth would be at 11:30 Bar Harbor time.)
 
 What's Aboard
The Cat has a cafe that serves snacks, rolls, muffins, fruit, coffee, and light meals, like chicken or lobster wraps ($6.45), chili ($4.50) and chowder. Seating areas on the cafe deck have a number of small tables.
There is a bar, the Wave Piercer; a casino with slot machines, black jack and poker; a duty-free gift shop with bargains on liquor and tapes of Nova Scotia regional music, as well as good-looking sweaters and T-shirts and postcards and placemats. Free children's movies are shown in the family area.
Seating areas and rest rooms are kept scrupulously clean, and there are changing stations for infants.

HEADLINE: Q/A

BYLINE: By Joseph Siano

 BODY:

Rembrandt, by Rembrandt
 
 Q. I have heard that there will be an exhibit of Rembrandt's self-portraits next year, both at the National Gallery in London and the Maurits huis in The Hague. Do you know the dates? -- Jim Graham, Flint, Mich.
 
 A. Rembrandt wrote his autobiography with a paintbrush, creating 60 self-portraits -- the first at age 20 or 21, the last at 63, shortly before his death in 1669. The paintings, drawings and etchings help trace his stylistic development, from youthful self-confidence to the searching portraits of old age. 
 Rembrandt painted himself in many roles: as artist, in extravagant dress, as the Apostle Paul and at the feet of Christ during the raising of the Cross. This exhibit, which will first be shown in London before moving to The Hague, will study the significance of these varying depictions as well as the facial expressions the artist chose. It will include numerous paintings and about 30 of his etchings and drawings. In addition, a small selection of works by Rembrandt's students will show how their self-portraits were influenced by their teacher. The works will be on loan from the Netherlands, Britain, Germany, France, Italy, the United States and other countries.
 The show is first scheduled to run at the National Gallery on Trafalgar Square in London from June 9 through Sept. 5, 1999. Early plans are for 40 paintings and 35 etchings and drawings by Rembrandt to be on display. There will be an admission charge to the exhibition (the permanent collections are free), to be called "Rembrandt by Himself," but it has not been set yet. Information: (44-171) 747-2885.
The Mauritshuis, 8 Korte Vijverberg, The Hague, has chosen the simpler name "Rembrandt Himself" for the show, to run from Sept. 25, 1999, to Jan. 9, 2000. This exhibition will feature 25 paintings, fewer than the number at the National Gallery. Tickets for the Mauritshuis show will be available beginning June 1, 1999, and will be sold for specific entry times. Visitors will have a one-hour window in which to arrive and will be able to stay as long as they wish. For information, call (31-70) 302-3456.
 
Buenos Aires Hotels
 
 Q. My husband and I will be staying in Buenos Aires in November. We saw that one major American chain hotel costs $390 a night. Can you suggest something more moderate? -- Mary Jane Baker, Portland, Ore.
 
A. Here are three possibilities:
The Hotel Plaza Francia, 2189 Schiaffino, telephone and fax (54-1) 804-9631, has 50 smallish but cozy rooms in the elegant Recoleta district. Nearby are trendy shopping centers, outdoor cafes and major museums. Rooms at the front of the hotel offer views of the pretty tree-lined streets below. A double room is $152.46 to $175.45, including tax and Continental breakfast.
Overlooking the Libertad Plaza and two blocks from the Teatro Colon is the Hotel Bisonte, 1207 Paraguay Street, (54-1) 816-5770, fax (54-1) 816-5775. The 87 rooms are not overly elegant, but they are comfortable and are particular favorites for business travelers, with their computer ports and 24-hour room service. A double is $169.40, with tax and buffet breakfast.
If you want to go higher on the amenity (and price) scale, the Hotel Claridge, 535 Tucuman Street, (54-1) 314-7700, fax (54-1) 314-8022, is a traditional English-style hotel in the middle of the financial district. The 161 rooms are large and well-appointed, and there is an outdoor pool. The Claridge Grill is one of the city's better-known restaurants. Doubles: $290, with tax but no breakfast.
 
Airport Parking
 
 Q. I recently left my car in the Kennedy Airport long-term lot for a week. The cost was reasonable, but after leaving the lot, I noticed that my license plate number was on my credit-card receipt. How is this done and why? -- Leonard A. O'Connor, Watertown, Conn.
 
A. How your license-plate number gets on your receipt is fairly simple -- the cashier in the booth can see it thanks to a mirror (it's also recorded by a video camera) and enters it in the register. But the background is a little more complex.
Bill Cahill, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the agency that operates La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark airports, said that in 1991 the authority installed a computerized revenue-control system for the daily and long-term lots at each airport. One problem at these lots in the 1980's was car theft, but the new system has helped reduce that. Each night, an employee with a hand-held computer records the license plate number and location of each car parked in these lots. Besides helping to reduce auto theft, it also helps the authority to find out where travelers like to park and for how long, data that can be used to improve customer service. If a customer has a complaint about a cashier, that employee can be identified. And if you come home from your trip with so many great memories that you forgot where you parked your car, the computer can find it for you.
Mr. Cahill also said that by the end of the year, the Port Authority planned to have at least one lot at each of the three airports that accepted payment with EZ Pass, the system now used at the authority's bridges and tunnels to automatically record toll charges for drivers.
 
Nevis Runway
 
 Q. I really enjoy the island of Nevis in the Caribbean, but it takes the better part of a day to get there since I must first fly to San Juan, then to St. Kitts, then switch planes for Nevis. The runway at the island's airport is being lengthened. How soon can I expect direct flights from, say, San Juan? -- John Wellenbach, Narberth, Pa.
 
A. The runway, which is being extended to 4,000 feet to accommodate larger jets, was originally scheduled to be completed this month, said Christine Walwyn of the St. Kitts and Nevis Department of Tourism, but the target is now early next year.
Unfortunately, neither American Airlines nor its subsidiary, American Eagle, plans to provide more direct service to Nevis after the project is completed. "It wouldn't make economic sense for either one of the airlines to do it at this time," said Mitch Baranowski, an American Airlines spokesman.
So for now, you will just have to keep taking those 10-minute flights from St. Kitts (there's also a 45-minute ferry trip instead), or try the longer flights from Anguilla, Antigua, St. Barts, St. Croix and St. Maarten. JOSEPH SIANO

HEADLINE: Portraits of the Past For the Mashantucket

BYLINE: By BESS LIEBENSON 

 BODY:
THE Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center has been much anticipated. Dominated by a tower and steel-ribbed glass abstraction of a wigwam, the $135 million, 308,000-square-foot center officially opens on Tuesday, but has already been selected for the 1998 American Architecture Award given by the Chicago Athenaeum.
The center steps down a hillside. Boulders and rock outcroppings deposited by glacial movement define the land. 
 "It's the only museum of its type in the world in terms of being about, owned and operated by indigenous people," said Steve Dennin, director of marketing and development for the center. "It has been over 20 years in the planning. Long before the casino, this tribe had the desire to tell its story . . . the story of an Eastern Woodland tribe, a story they felt had not been told, and to tell it in a thoughtful, carefully researched manner. The idea grew."
Along with creating housing, economic opportunities and pursuing Federal recognition, "The tribe has long wanted to foster research and education," said Dr. Kevin A. McBride, an assistant professor of anthropology at the University of Connecticut in Storrs and director of research at the museum. "The tribe wanted to redress several inaccuracies of Pequot history portrayed in history books -- for example that the Pequots were extinct. The museum tells the complete story of a people over a long period of time."
The journey begins at an imposing glass and steel Gathering Space -- an engineering feat of semicircular roof and suspended glass soaring 60 feet and floored with seashells imbedded in blue terrazzo, one of the building's three basic architectural elements. There is a research center and a library with archeological laboratories and archives.
The tour travels chronological paths -- moving from the last Ice Age to the present, recounting Mashantucket Pequot history, that of other tribes and of the region's environment. Broken into zones, the whole complex makes it easy at three different points to stop out for films in auditoriums or lunch at the restaurant, which beyond staples will introduce a changing selection of Native American cuisine.
The welcome sign -- "Listen here, go right in, the door is open -- this is my family" -- was written by a tribal member and is an invitation to all. For the visually impaired, there are talking signs with selected artifacts -- spearheads, fur clothing and tools -- to touch. The hearing-impaired will have access to closed-captioned films, computer interactives and videos.
Throughout, sounds and scents add realism. "You're kicked back 20,000 years into the glacial period," said Michael A. Hanke, principal of Design Division Inc. in New York, who in consultation with tribal members is responsible for the design of the 85,000-square-foot exhibit space. Visitors walk through an atmospheric ice blue undulating crevasse, feel chilling air, see and hear water cascading down a waterfall, then enter an exhibit showing how glaciers shaped modern-day land forms.
From there they encounter a 50 foot in diameter diorama with a broad blue sky and black spruce trees, reaching up. Life-size hunters (cast from real people) are shown throwing spears. One side depicts the kill, the other, the harvesting and butchering.
Viewers pass through changing social and natural environments 6,000 years ago, and on to the re-creation of a 16th-century coastal Pequot village. This is a high-tech 22,000-square-foot "immersion environment" showing daily life leading up to European contact. They walk among chestnuts, oak and maples, through wigwams and past handcrafted figures cooking, talking and working, sounds accompanied by aromas of woodlands and campfires.
Another setting introduces Dutch and English settlers and their impact, trade and mounting tensions. A 30-minute film "The Witness," dramatizes the Pequot war (1636-1638). Then a recreation of a farmstead house, circa 1780, invites visitors to a two-acre farmstead including orchards and gardens.
"Many people have misinformation and bias about native culture, past and present," Dr. McBride said. "We hope the museum will create awareness of native people, the Pequots in particular, and the complexity of their culture."
"It's intended as a noneditorial view of the history," Mr. Hanke said, "an attempt to get away from stereotypes."
 
The Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center is at 110 Pequot Trail, off Route 2 and Route 214 near the Foxwoods Resort and Casino, in the Mashantucket section of Ledyard. It is open seven days from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. (860-396-6800).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Clockwise, from far left: 16th-century Pequot village, diorama; Elizabeth George, 1973, a tribal elder; engraving of an English attack on a Pequot fort, 1637; 17th-century Pequot fort, on computer view; engraving depicting Pequot man by Wencelaus Hollar, 1645. (The Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center)

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Spotlight Finds an Always-Moving Choreographer

BYLINE: By VALERIE GLADSTONE; Valerie Gladstone is co-author with Robert Maiorano of "Balanchine's 'Mozartiana': The Making of a Masterpiece."

 BODY:
THE choreographer Donald McKayle can be as difficult to locate as he is to classify. Instead of staying in one place, he shuttles between New York and California. Rather than create dances for just one medium, he regularly invents them for Broadway, television, film and the concert stage. He loves choreographing but enjoys teaching just as much. Moreover, these are not the only unusual aspects of his life. When he started his modern dance company in New York in 1951, Alvin Ailey, Arthur Mitchell, Lar Lubovitch and Eliot Feld were among its first members.
Although as a black choreographer and teacher, Mr. McKayle has greatly inspired young blacks, both Ailey and Mr. Mitchell achieved more recognition for their advancement of blacks in dance. And Mr. Lubovitch and Mr. Feld have won more renown as choreographers. Why? Most people in the dance world believe Mr. McKayle has not, until recently, received due recognition because he has refused to specialize in one medium or to be identified solely as an African-American artist. But in making those choices he was only being true to himself. 
 Now, at 68, Mr. McKayle increasingly finds himself in the limelight. "It's hard to keep up with all the awards and honors I receive," he said, sounding amused. "Next, they'll try to bronze me." In 1995, he won a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts to create a student dance company at the University of California at Irvine, where he has been a professor of dance since 1989. The next year, an award of $100,000 from the National Dance Residency Program made it possible for him to serve as resident choreographer of the Jose Limon Dance Company for two years. This support also gave him time to write his autobiography, "I Will Dance With You," which Gordon and Breach Publishers will bring out next summer.
Now Lincoln Center Out of Doors is celebrating Mr. McKayle. On Thursday and Friday and on Aug. 20 and 21, the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company and the Limon Dance Company will honor him with performances of his works. The programs feature "Games" and "Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder," two modern-dance classics, and the New York premiere of "Heartbeats," commissioned by the Limon company. "He's a master and among the most humane people in dance," says Jenneth Webster, the festival's producer.
Although Mr. McKayle spends more time on the West Coast than on the East, New York City holds warm memories for him. "I first fell in love with dance in the New York Public Library," he said. "As a boy, I went there to research my heritage and moved on to dance." Encouraged by his Jamaican parents, he continued his studies at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, where he found photos and books on major artists of the past. "It wasn't long before I went to a performance," he said. "That did it. Immediately, I wanted to dance myself."
IN 1947, at the age of 17, Mr. McKayle arrived at the midtown studios of the New Dance Group, where he encountered some of the most innovative figures in modern dance: Pearl Primus, Sophie Maslow, Jean Erdman, William Bales and Hadassah were all teaching there. No one style prevailed at the New Dance Group, so Mr. McKayle tried them all. Later he danced briefly with the companies of Martha Graham, Anna Sokolow and Merce Cunningham.
These disparate experiences left an indelible impression on Mr. McKayle. Although he often uses African-American traditions and themes, to call him an African-American choreographer would be as misleading as to label Balanchine a Russian one. He knows East Indian and flamenco styles as well as he knows African, and he incorporates all of them into his choreography. "I've never thought, 'This is my culture, and that is your culture,' in relation to anyone from anywhere," he said. "How could I? I'm too mixed. My middle name is Cohen, after my Jewish-English grandfather."
Mr. McKayle's "Games," his first major piece, set the tone for all his works. Made for his company in 1951, it deals with children at play in the city's streets. Calling upon his memories of the fears that haunt urban children, he shows how danger threatens their fun. "Long before child abuse became an everyday news story," said Joe Nash, a dance historian, "Donny made you feel its reality. He's a master of theater."
His next important dance, "Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder" (1959), depicts the suffering and hopes of a group of men on a chain gang. As in many of his works, his powerful, rhythmic movements convey the strong, archetypal emotions that drive human beings. "These became classics," said Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Ailey company, "because there's no dillydallying about the point. They touch the heart."
Mr. McKayle didn't work in a variety of mediums simply for self-fulfillment. As a husband and father of three children, he felt obliged to look for economic stability outside of concert dance, which barely sustains its members. Although his company achieved success with works like "Her Name Was Harriet" (1952), about Harriet Tubman and the Underground Railroad, and "District Storyville" (1962), which chronicled the growth of jazz, he could not support his family on its earnings. Consequently, in 1969, he dissolved his troupe and went to California to choreograph for several television series.
Over the following decades Mr. McKayle also worked on films, among them "Bed knobs and Broomsticks" (1971), with Angela Lansbury, and "The Jazz Singer" (1980), with Neil Diamond and Laurence Olivier. At the same time, he managed to fit in Broadway, collecting Tony nominations for "Golden Boy" (1964), starring Sammy Davis Jr., and "Sophisticated Ladies" (1981).
"First, I took on projects just for the money," he said. "But once I got involved, I discovered I liked working with actors and singers. Every process feeds another. Frankly, being a purist would have bored me. If I ever got fed up with people in one field, I knew I could go someplace else." His forays into television, film and theater did not cost him his place in modern dance. He continued to choreograph for many troupes, including the Los Angeles Contemporary Dance Theater and Lula Washington's Los Angeles Contemporary Dance Theater.
At Lincoln Center Out of Doors, Tamica Washington, a principal with the Washington company, will perform "Los Angelitos Negroes" from "Songs of the Disinherited" (1991). "I love Mr. McKayle's way of using bodies to make contours and shapes," she said. "Movement just flows from him. This piece especially affected me. It asks artists, 'Why don't you paint black angels?' "
Although Mr. McKayle often deals with serious subjects, his works never lack humor and romance. A passionate music lover, he came up with a group of deeply emotional songs from many countries for "Heartbeats." They convey everything from a young girl's musings on love to the anguish of a wartime separation. "Each song reveals a particular way of connecting to life," Mr. McKayle said. "I know so many. I always wake with a song on my lips."
Fame may have arrived late for him, but apparently joie de vivre did not.

HEADLINE: Habitats/Fran Reiter's Co-op at 11th Street and Second Avenue;
A Former Deputy Mayor Buys Into Her Family's Past

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
IN 1928, Fran Reiter's grandfather finished construction of the first luxury high-rise apartment building on the Lower East Side, a building that became a center for the Jewish intelligentsia and theatrical community that thrived in the neighborhood. It was so appealing that the family left its town house farther south to move into a nine-room apartment with high ceilings, a large foyer and an eat-in kitchen.
A year later the stock market crashed, and with it the economic well-being of many people who lived in the building. They couldn't pay their rent. Graciousness and kindness demanded that people be given a little leeway, because after all, who wants to make a neighbor homeless? 
 "His tenants were his friends," says Ms. Reiter, the president of the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau, and a former deputy mayor and campaign manager for Rudolph W. Giuliani. "When no one could pay their rent, they stayed -- which is a nice way of saying he lost my inheritance." Because, inevitably, her grandfather, Herman Bauman, could no longer make the mortgage payments, and in 1933 the bank took possession of the building.
The family stayed on, for although it was no longer rich it had the means to pay the rent. Now, 70 years after her grandfather built the building at 170 Second Avenue, Ms. Reiter has taken back a piece of it. A few months ago, she bought an apartment in the building, or rather she bought shares in the co-op that now owns it.
For Ms. Reiter, whose nonprofit organization is the official marketing agent for the city, the building at the corner of 11th Street has been home for almost all of her 44 years. To her, its mix of people, and its neighborhood filled with small shop owners who know most of their customers by sight, represent what is best and most important about New York. It is not anonymous and distant; on the contrary, it is as personal and interconnected as the mythical American small town.
She bought her apartment after living there as a tenant for 18 years. And she moved there after living upstairs with her parents and older brother from birth, except for a few years in college and a few months in Ohio. In something of an understatement, she explains, "I don't like to move."
Her roots in the building, across the street from Peter Stuyvesant's grave, are so deep that she says being an owner rather than a renter does not make her feelings any more profound. But the fact of ownership has made one difference. She wants to renovate the apartment, something she never did as a renter. And she wants to spiff it up.
After five years of working first in Mr. Giuliani's campaign and then in his administration, she says, her home life is a little tattered. "I haven't served a meal in five years," she says. "You do subjugate your life."
A collection of unusual teapots serves as a testament to a domestic -- and collecting -- urge. "I'll put in a new kitchen," she says, "and take down my 1970's bookshelves." She also plans to have the apartment painted and the wall-to-wall carpeting replaced.
AND if the work becomes bothersome, she will probably escape upstairs to the apartment where her mother still lives, and which her mother also recently bought. It's the apartment Ms. Reiter grew up in, although it's not the one her grandparents first took. As their children grew up and moved away, her grandparents moved into smaller apartments. Ultimately, Ms. Reiter's mother and grandmother, and then her mother and father, lived in the two-bedroom apartment where Ms. Reiter spent her childhood.
Upstairs in her mother's apartment, Ms. Reiter can show you the regular seat she had at the kitchen table, across from her mother, flanked by her brother and father. "All the important things happened around the table," she says. "I think the disintegration of family life started with the doing away with the eat-in kitchen."
In the 11- by 15-foot bedroom she and her brother, Jonathan, shared, she can show you how their territories were delineated by a wall unit that ran down the middle. (He now lives a few blocks away.) Their identical reading lights and their identical closets are still in the room.
Ms. Reiter went off to Boston University intending to work in theater as a director and producer, and she did for a while, but a temporary job in New York led her into the television syndication business, and she liked it.
In 1980 she realized that she was in New York for good, with no more theatrical road trips, and that she could no longer camp out with her parents. She and a friend looked for an apartment together, but in the perennial lament of New Yorkers found only sky-high rents. Just before total despair set in, salvation arrived, albeit sadly.
"All of a sudden, two people in this building died on the same day," she says. Having lived in the building forever, she was part of the "telegraph system" that alerts everyone to anything important. And she was friendly with the former superintendent, who had moved up in the organization and had some clout. He got her the apartment, which made the leap from the mid $300's to $400 a month when it moved with the vacancy from rent control to rent stabilization.
There was one problem, but she decided to get over it. "I was going to be living in the same building with my parents," she says. "As close as I am to my parents, well . . . , " she says, her voice trailing off, no need to state the obvious. "But it was too good a deal."
For her, it has proved to be a great deal. Her mother, Shirley, is upstairs, seemingly willing to put her up and feed her whenever necessary, and yet not desirous of invading her privacy. "To this day 18 years later, I can probably count on both hands the number of times my mother has been in this apartment," Ms. Reiter says. "She respects my space far more than I respect hers."
In fact, when Ms. Reiter first moved in, she quickly got into the habit of eating with her parents. Her roommate, an actress, was waiting tables at night and she didn't want to eat alone.
"I was forever going up there for dinner," she says, "until my mother stopped feeding me," which happened after her father, Louis, retired and her mother took a job as a secretary. Now her mother is widowed, and they more often go out to restaurants together.
MS. REITER, whose roommate left after two years, had a chance to buy her apartment 10 years ago, when the building became a co-op, but like most of the tenants declined because the maintenance far exceeded the rent. But in the last few years, more tenants have been buying as higher rents and lower interest rates have eroded the disadvantage of buying.
In addition, the company that turned the building into a co-op lost possession of its unsold shares, leaving most of the shares to a bank that was anxious to get rid of them. The bank offered the tenants deals they couldn't refuse, Ms. Reiter says. She declines to name the price she paid for her two-bedroom apartment but says she recently had it assessed at three to four times what she paid.
The neighborhood, Ms. Reiter says, is thriving after a long period of difficulty. In the 1980's, her work in the television business took her to many cities, and many of them seemed better than New York. "This is a city I really thought was on the decline," she says. Occasionally, she would think about leaving. But then things started to improve. And while she was working for the Giuliani administration, she grew to know it much better.
"When I became deputy mayor," she says, "I was 40, and I had never been to Jamaica, Queens. I had never been to Woodlawn, or Bensonhurst."
Her work took her everywhere, she says, "and it was wonderful. It was a revelation to me. I fell in love with my own city." And now, she says, "I certainly don't think about leaving."

HEADLINE: Where's the Blame In Lilco Buyout?

 BODY:
The politicians howled for the head of William J. Catacosinos -- and they got it. Until July 31, Mr. Catacosinos was chairman of Marketspan, a new corporate creature created from the remains of Lilco and Brooklyn Union Gas.
When the old Lilco board voted him a bonus of $42 million for the year, Governor Pataki and other pols put the heat on Marketspan to dump Mr. Catacosinos. Now the company has given in and pushed their $42 million baby overboard. 
 Mr. Catacosinos did not ask for the $42 million. He demanded $70 million. And no doubt about it, he was robbed. He is America's most underpaid executive, bar none.
For 12 years, the Suffolk County government paid me to investigate Mr. Catacosinos, beginning the day he took over Lilco. A quick review of my files on Billy Cat shows a man underestimated time after time.
Among the milestones of his decade and a half reign at Lilco: the state penalized the company $1.7 billion for mismanagement. The company paid $400 million to settle racketeering charges brought by the county government and an additional $50 million to settle claims of securities fraud. The state forced Mr. Catacosinos to close his unquestionably dangerous Shoreham nuclear plant, the most expensive plant ever built and never run.
Mr. Catacosinos first gave the public a taste of his unique management style when, in 1985, Hurricane Gloria left 750,000 homes in the dark. In response, the chairman ordered all workers off vacation, while he continued his Mediterranean cruise.
Mr. Catacosinos created what a former local legislator calls, quite accurately, "the highest priced, least reliable, most arrogant and, when they owned Shoreham, most dangerous electric company in America." Then he sold it to the state last month for more than $7 billion. Pure chutzpa, pure Catacosinos.
Investment bankers had valued the corporate mess called Lilco at substantially less. The windfall for Lilco shareholders will be tacked on to electricity bills over the next 40 years, with interest. Econometric models indicate the electricity surcharge will cost about 36,000 jobs.
Good for Bill. His job was to get the best deal for his stockholders and he got it.
But heads should roll. And its easy to identify whose. Mr. Pataki filed legal challenges to the Catacosinos bonus. But it was the Governor who cut the deal for the Long Island Power Authority to buy Lilco. It was Mr. Pataki who then shrouded over the bloated purchase price with accounting trickery. One of the Governor's degimmicks was to promise a bonus -- $101 in Suffolk and $232 in Nassau -- to every Long Island ratepayer as a benefit of the deal. He did not mention that the bonus was due from Lilco anyway, the final payments on the racketeering and other court settlements.
And it was the Governor who personally injected himself into negotiations and caved in to Mr. Catacosinos's every bullying (and brilliant) demand. The Governor called the $42 million for Mr. Catacosinos "an extraordinary secret act of greed." Hardly. Several analysts, myself included, warned his office that the giveaway from the public's purse would trigger Mr. Catacosinos's golden parachute and stock options, the source of the bonus. The bonus was neither extraordinary nor secret, but the takeover deal cut by the Governor was both.
Mr. Catacosinos's true crime was that the bonus for his success exposed the government's failure.
Mr. Catacosinos does not work for the public, but for his shareholders, whom he has served frighteningly well. But Governor Pataki is supposed to work for the long-suffering electricity customers. He has demanded the resignation of the man responsible for this costly mess.
That, Mr. Pataki, is an excellent idea.
 
GREGORY PALAST
Peconic

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Public/Private Deal Saves Hunterdon Farm

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE 54-acre Lane Farm on Pleasant Run Road in Readington Township, with its 156-year-old farmhouse, water tower and barn, has long served as a reminder of this Hunterdon County community's rural past.
But with increasing development pressure swirling around the 48-square-mile township the municipality, like others in the state, has stepped up efforts to preserve that past by conserving its open land, including parcels like the Lane Farm. While the development group that owned the farm could have built 18 single-family homes, the property is also bordered by other farms that the township feared could be amassed for a 150-home subdivision. 
 In June, after 18 months of planning and negotiations, Readington was not only able to keep the Lane Farm permanently protected, but also managed to preserve its historic buildings and create public access to township-owned recreational space. It did so with the help of the Morristown office of the Trust for Public Land, a national nonprofit conservation group, which devised a creative three-way transaction between the township, the state and a private buyer.
The trust purchased the hilltop farm from its owner for $620,000. It then sold both five acres at the edge of the property, which will be used for a public trail, and the development rights on the remaining 49 acres to the township under the New Jersey Green Acres Program. The 49 acres then were sold to a private owner with deed restrictions requiring that the property be left open or farmed in perpetuity and that the structures be renovated.
The transaction marks the first time the state has used Green Acres funds to work with the combination of a nonprofit group, a municipality and a private party to protect and preserve historic and natural resources, said Kevin S. Richardson, principal planner in the Bureau of Green Trust Management within the state's Green Acres Program. Conservationists say the deal underscores the value of public-private partnerships and provides a method to achieve multiple preservation goals as well as to stretch public funds at a time when competition for such funds is fierce.
"Any tool that we can effectively use to preserve a meaningful amount of farmland and open space is an advantage," said Julia C. Allen, a Readington Township committee member, referring to the transaction. While the township -- whose population has increase by 25 percent to 16,000 in the last decade -- has preserved 2,000 acres of land, there are still 14,000 acres of developable farmland within its borders.
The 37-year-old Green Acres program has been the main source of funds to state, county and local government agencies for preserving open space. In 1991 it began offering nonprofit conservation groups matching grants, which have been used to buy land that would be kept open to the public.
In the case of the Lane Farm the township holds the deed restrictions on the 49 acres and on the five-acre parcel and the state, to protect its interest, holds secondary rights of enforcement on both. To provide the required public access the five-acre parcel will serve as part of a greenway leading through a cluster housing development to a township park and ballfields. Because it is along the banks of Pleasant Run Creek, which flows into the south branch of the Raritan River, it also helps preserve the waterway and offers a scenic view corridor to the public.
The Readington transaction shows that "towns don't have to buy an entire parcel to achieve their open space objective and the state's goal of public access," said Mr. Richardson, the Green Acres planner. In such cooperative projects "costs are shared, helping to leverage both of our funds," he said. Mr. Richardson said he already knew of at least three other nonprofit groups hoping to do similar transactions.
THE movement by conservation groups and municipalities to keep parts of New Jersey forever natural has strengthened in recent years as the pace of development, stoked by a strong economy, has gained momentum.
Late last month the Legislature passed a bill calling for a referendum in November on whether the state should spend $1 billion over the next 10 years to preserve a million acres of undeveloped land -- half of it as open space and half as farmland. The bill also poses the question of whether to amend the state constitution so that the state can dedicate up to $98 million a year in state sales-tax revenue over the next 30 years. The money would be used to buy the million acres and retire bonds. If the referendum were approved, it would also give the state the authority to issue an additional $1 billion in bonds for preservation purposes.
The referendum also would give New Jersey its first stable source of financing for open-space acquisition. In the last 37 years $1.39 billion for such acquisitions has come from nine voter-approved bond issues, which have permanently preserved 922,000 acres under two state programs. They are Green Acres and the state's Farmland Preservation program.
In Readington, the Trust for Public Land began working with the township in 1994 to help preserve land, like the Lane Farm, along three main stream corridors that run through the community. A year later it received a $500,000 matching grant from the state's Green Acres program to do just that.
Typically, the trust secures land and holds it until sufficient funds are raised for a public agency or nonprofit group to buy it. In Readington three entities were brought together to buy the Lane Farm.
"The benefit to the township is that it is preserving this property for about one-third of its purchase price while not having to take on the responsibility of managing the land and restoring the buildings," said Julie A. Enger, project manager at the trust's Morristown office. In addition, selling the 49 restricted acres to a private owner also keeps the property on the tax rolls, she said.
The trust negotiated a deal with Wilshire Farms L.L.C., a land investment and development group in Somerville, which owned the farm to buy it for $620,000, which Bernard Senger of Somerville, the managing partner, described as reasonable.
THEN the trust was able to sell the development rights on 49 acres as well as the five-acre greenway parcel to the township for $386,000. Half the purchase price was financed by $193,000 from the state Green Acres grant the trust received and the matching half came from the township's open space trust fund. The 49 deed-restricted acres were sold to Dr. Marcia M. Zweerink for $300,000.
The best way to protect the land was to put it into the hands of a private owner, said Ms. Enger, noting that the sale shows that there is a market for properties even with restrictions. The trust worked for six months with the state to come up with the deed restrictions that "are strict and binding, yet livable enough" to meet the needs of all three parties, she said.
Township officials agreed. "We didn't just want to save the land for its agricultural use but for its open space, scenic, historic, recreational and environmental value," said Mrs. Allen, the township committee member. The added hope, she said, "is that the adjacent farms now will be thrown into preservation as well."
James T. Wall, the Readington Mayor, said the transaction produced "quite a bargain" to the township given the number of municipal goals it achieved. He said the township hoped to repeat the transaction to preserve one or two other farms in the community.
For Dr. Zweerink, buying the farm was an opportunity worth taking. She said she and her companion, James Brightwell, who have lived in Readington for five years, had searched for four months for a farm.
"But with the value of land and the pressures of development," she said, "the price of a site this large was well beyond my means or too far away from where we work." She is senior director of information services at the research division of Merck & Company in Rahway; he is a computer programmer.
She said she also welcomed the deed restrictions because she had no intention of developing the farm. And despite the renovations required to restore the farm buildings, "the value of the house and barn after the restoration will be greater than what we will put into them," she said.
Eventually, Dr. Zweerink, who has two Morgan horses, said she would like to raise and breed such horses on the site and perhaps even train sheep dogs. Right now, however, the land will continue to be farmed, she said, adding that in the end "the township gets the land protected and we get a magnificent place to live."

HEADLINE: Life Stirs Again in A Theater Long Dark

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
AFTER nine years of darkness, the old Shakespeare Theater in Stratford is getting cleaned, painted, and repaired for reopening. New, lighted makeup mirrors hang in dressing rooms. Lanterns, helmets and the chaise Katharine Hepburn reclined on in "Antony and Cleopatra" are neatly organized in prop rooms. The brass water fountains and theater seats, relocated decades ago from the Ziegfield theater in Manhattan, are clean again. And there are modern additions, including handicapped access ramps and a web site (www.Stratfordfestival.com).
On a recent sunny morning, Louis S. Burke, the theater's artistic director who initiated the current project, was bursting with enthusiasm. "You can feel just how extraordinary this is," he said. "I want to see what I've been dreaming about come to fruition." Decked out in a wide-brimmed straw hat, a black shirt with white polka dots, slacks, and sandals, he recalled that when he first visited the theater in 1986, it was so musty that mushrooms were growing inside. 
 On April 16, Mr. Burke and his partners in what is now called the Stratford Festival Theater signed a purchase and sale agreement with the state, the property's owner. Since then, they have been working to get the theater in good enough shape for some performances before the end of this year and to launch a full season next June, Mr. Burke said.
The goal is to stage a production of "Twelfth Night" directed by Mr. Burke for student audiences this year, as well as offer performances by visiting companies, he said. Negotiations are underway for a one-woman performance by a member of the Royal Shakespeare Company, and visiting opera and ballet companies, Mr. Burke said.
Soundfest, an organization devoted to the Long Island Sound and not connected with the theater, has scheduled a festival on the theater property on Labor Day weekend. And the theater is the centerpiece of a planned $180 million development. On the 14.4 acre property, it would include two other theaters, a theater museum and a five-story addition to the main theater for rehearsal halls. In nearby neighborhoods, inns, hotels, restaurants and shops would be established. The nonprofit portion on the theater property is expected to cost $80 million.
The closing on the theater property is scheduled for Dec. 15 and is contingent on the buyers' meeting a list of requirements: compliance with building and fire codes, obtaining environmental permits, devising development, financial and site plans, submitting development and construction documents for renovation work, and obtaining title insurance, according to Richard K. Clifford, chief of outdoor recreation for the State Department of Environmental Protection.
So far, partners in the theater have paid the state $50,000, and an additional $100,000 is due at the closing with nine annual payments of $150,000 to follow, Mr. Clifford said. The buyers also made a $350,000 escrow deposit before execution of the purchase and sale agreement, and subsequent deposits to total $1.7 million are to be paid on a scheduled time frame, Mr. Clifford explained.
The agreement was entered into by the state as seller and the Stratford Festival Theater Inc. and Brickhill-Burke Productions Ltd. as buyers.
During the administration of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the state had authorized $3.5 million in bonding for the theater, but that was rescinded early in the administration of Gov. John G. Rowland.
State Senator George L. Gunther, Republican of Stratford, said he'd like to see the theater receive substantial financial help from the state as have other theaters, including Oakdale in Wallingford, the Shubert in New Haven and the Polka Dot Playhouse in Bridgeport.
"It's time for Stratford to get a little bit of its share," he said.
Meanwhile, the work of carpenters, painters and volunteers is creating a buzz among theater enthusiasts. Alan Alda sent a check when he heard about the effort, said Louis D. Pietig, resident director and secretary-treasurer of the theater. Sharon Challenger, a set designer who has been volunteering at the theater, reports visits from tourists interested in the work.
There hasn't been a full season at Stratford, which opened in 1955, since 1982. In 1989, a summer season was offered. Various efforts to revive the theater failed.
Paul S. Timpanelli, president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council and a member of the theater's advisory board, had expressed skepticism in the past about the current project's viability. But he is cautiously optimistic now. "There's some activity, so I'm assuming it's a good sign," he said.
The project is "important for the economic development of the town of Stratford as well as for the region," Mr. Timpanelli said.
Mr. Pietig said that the plan calls for completion of the entire project three years after the December closing. The state law that authorized the sale of the property requires a performance three years after the closing as well as a 20-year commitment to provide annual performances, including one Shakespearean play a year.
David W. Killeen, Stratford's town planner, said that town officials and theater representatives have begun discussions about boundaries for a theater district that would allow ancillary businesses to be established in nearby neighborhoods.
"The purpose of the entertainment district is to recognize that the theater by itself traditionally has not been self-sustaining," said Mr. Killeen. "In no way does it touch on tax breaks or anything of that nature," he said.
According to Mr. Pietig, the new complex would attract people for two to three days to attend performances in all three theaters.
"For there to be a real festival environment, you have to have more than one venue playing simultaneously," he said. He said projections are based on experiences elsewhere, such as Stratford on the Ontario in Canada where traditional audiences come from as far as Philadelphia and Chicago.
Mr. Burke said that the Ontario theater contributes $100 million a year to its local economy and predicted that the Connecticut theater would bring more to Stratford and the region because it is just 63 miles from New York City, a massive population base.
Dozens of prominent theater professionals have signed on as founding members of the revitalized theater, Liam Neeson, John Goodman, Paul Newman, Elizabeth Taylor, Natasha Richardson and Angela Lansbury among them.
Mr. Burke has spent years attempting to acquire the theater from the state. Now a Stratford resident, he is originally from South Africa where he ran the His Majesty Theater in Johannesburg. He was director and co-producer of "Meet Me in St. Louis" on Broadway in 1989.
Four years ago, the state chose a different preferred developer, only to rescind the choice later. Mr. Burke eventually prevailed with a $1.5 million purchase offer. He and Mr. Pietig have been joined in in the project by partners with development and financial experience including Jack Blumenfeld and John Cutler, from the BBC Development Corporation in Philadelphia.
Frederick B. Conze, a former officer of Citibank and member of the Darien Planning and Zoning Commission, is president of the theater board and Fred C. Frassinelli Jr. of Fairfield, who owns a construction management and consulting firm, is the board chairman. Cameron Clark Jr., of Fairfield, former president of Warnaco, is manager of the theater's capital campaign.
