HEADLINE: Dissecting Data on Truck Accidents

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
ON the evening of June 14, a Sunday, a large tanker truck rig lumbered out of a petroleum storage complex in Bridgeport loaded with 8,500 gallons of gasoline, climbed up on Interstate 95, and headed east to make a delivery.
Traveling in the right hand lane, the driver rounded a curve onto the Moses Wheeler Bridge over the Housatonic River and found himself headed directly for a disabled car stopped in his lane. 
 Swerving left a beat too late, the truck hit the back of the car and overturned onto its side, miraculously without hitting any other vehicles. Only the truck driver was hurt, although not seriously. The accident left the tanker sprawled diagonally across all three lanes of the highway and gushing gasoline, which flowed into drains and poured into the river below, all 8,500 gallons of it.
The accident forced emergency personnel to close the highway's northbound and southbound lanes, creating long traffic jams in both directions and on Route 1, where traffic was diverted. It even temporarily shut down rail service on the main Metro-North and Amtrak lines, which cross the river on an adjacent bridge, for fear the gasoline might explode.
The next afternoon, another tractor trailer truck hit the interstate highway's median guard rail and flipped over in West Haven, a few miles east, causing traffic tie-ups in both directions that stretched through the rush hour. A week and a half after that, another truck exiting the highway in Bridgeport ran into the back of a small passenger car stopped on the ramp, crushing it, and seriously injuring the driver. There were also truck accidents on Interstates 84 and 91 around the same time.
These accidents, part of a sudden rash of mishaps involving large trucks, attracted the attention of State Representative Jacqueline Cocco of Bridgeport, a chairwoman of the state legislature's Transportation Committee. She and her colleague, State Senator Biagio Ciotto, the other leader of the committee, sent a letter to Gov. John G. Rowland appealing for an increase in State Police traffic patrols on interstate highways.
If State Police patrols increased, their higher visibility might make drivers slow down and drive more carefully, Mr. Ciotto said. "Just their presence will make a difference," added Mrs. Cocco. And in fact, up to 70 newly graduated troopers are scheduled to be patrolling the highways by late this month, state officials said.
But have trucks become more of a highway menace of late, or is it only a perception created by a statistically insignificant coincidence? The answer is there is no clear answer. Yes, there has been an increase in the number of accidents involving trucks, but no, the proportion ofaccidents involving trucks does not appear to have increased, according to Richard Martinez, Bureau Chief of Policy and Planning for the state Department of Transportation. "There's been an increase in total accidents," Mr. Martinez said.
Mrs. Cocco conceded that the recent cluster of accidents involving trucks might simply be a statistical aberration. "For four or five weeks, there was at least an accident every week," she said, but added, "Probably it was just a coincidence."
Mr. Ciotto wasn't so sure. "It's more than just perception," he said. "It's happening."
It's not, replied Mike Riley, president of the Motor Transport Association of Connecticut, a trucking trade organization. "It's a perception," he said. "Police tell us in accidents with trucks, most of them were caused by car drivers."
One powerful factor influencing the public's perception is that traffic tie-ups tend to be worse when a truck is involved. Then too, because trucks are so much larger than passenger cars, the risk of serious injury to a car's occupant is increased. Impatient drivers stuck in a traffic jam reach the accident site, and seeing a truck they draw the conclusion that the truck caused it. "A truck accident is just going to draw more attention," observed Trooper Richard Alexande, of the State Police Public Information Office.
When the trucks are carrying hazardous materials, and even more so when there is a spill that requires clean up, accidents can create even longer highway closures and attract more news media attention.
Chris Bruhl, president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association in Stamford, cautioned against a reaction aimed solely at trucks. Mr. Bruhl is the chairman of the Coastal Corridor Coalition, a group of business, civic and environmental organizations trying to solve highway congestion on I-95 and the Merritt Parkway in Fairfield County.
"It's a dangerous thing to believe in a single cause, because then you look for a single solution," he said. "We need a broad solution, not a silver bullet."
He and others listed a number of causes. Normally, the late spring and summer are times of increased traffic, higher use of alcohol and more inexperienced teen-age drivers on the roads. But the general increase in highway congestion was the foremost cause in their opinion, and the improved economy has made congestion worse.
Mr. Martinez said highways in Connecticut have experienced annual traffic increases averaging 1.5 to 2 percent. During the recession years in the early 1990's, there were no traffic increases recorded at all. But since 1994, when the economy began to improve, traffic for commerce, recreation and commuting has increased by 3 to 4 percent a year.
Department of Transportation statistics seemed to confirm Mr. Martiniz's analysis. There were a total of 72,550 accidents in the state in 1995, and 78,383 in 1996, the last year for which statistics were available. Gene Interlandi, a department planner, noted, however, that 1995 had a mild winter while the winter of 1996 was the snowiest on record, something sure to cause more accidents.
Still, the 1,676 accidents involving trucks in 1996, about 75 percent of them on interstate highways, was only about 2.1 percent of the total accidents. In 1995, they accounted for only 1.9 percent.
Mr. Bruhl said the Department of Transportation's vigorous highway improvement program is another factor. Construction zones typically feature narrowed lanes, sideward lane shifts, and nowhere for disabled vehicles to pull out of traffic.
Combine this with high traffic volume and passenger car drivers who do not drive defensibly and there will be a predictable rise in the number of accidents. Trucks, which are not as maneuverable as passenger cars, are particularly vulnerable, he said.
Mr. Riley said accidents involving trucks and cars would decline if passenger car drivers would understand that trucks have blind spots, and drive accordingly. Truck drivers have no way to see a car that is tailgating them, because the trailer blocks their view from their cab's side mirrors.
Similarly, a car traveling alongside the truck's right side door or just behind and alongside the left side of the cab is also in a blind spot.
He was in favor of stricter police enforcement, but said it should apply to passenger car drivers as well as truck drivers.
Mr. Bruhl felt, as did many others interviewed, that a cluster of truck accidents during a period of a few weeks didn't constitute a trend. "In the law of large numbers, you get clusters of unique events," he said.

HEADLINE: Questions Linger After Police Shooting in Ossining

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: OSSINING

 BODY:
WHEN her son was 10 months old, Renee Malone left the streets of the Bronx and the perils that often haunt overcrowded inner-city neighborhoods for a better life in the suburbs. Signs of spring abounded that March day when she arrived in this village overlooking the Hudson River -- Chris Anthony Malone in tow. The season's first flowers were in bloom. The air was full of promise, and the chubby baby boy had already begun walking, she recalled recently.
Last month, almost 24 years after Ms. Malone moved to the working-class neighborhood of tidy homes and small gardens, she buried her firstborn, who died after being shot repeatedly on July 19 by police officers who were chasing him, according to accounts. In addition to his mother, Mr. Malone left behind two younger brothers and a 5-year-old son. 
In the days and sleepless nights since Chris Anthony Malone's death, Ms. Malone has asked over and over again how it happened and why her family's hopes wilted and blew away.
Ms. Malone is black, and for others like herself, raising a son can be a perilous business, figures indicate. The June 1997 Vital Statistics Report published by the National Center for Health Statistics, a Federal agency, shows that the overall death rate for black men between 15 and 24 is 249 per 100,000, with homicides and legal intervention -- 132 per 100,000 -- the leading cause. By comparison, for white men in the same age bracket, the death rate overall is 122, less than half, with accidents as the leading cause at a rate of 58 per 100,000.
For black men in Harlem, as an example, life expectancy is shorter than that for men in Bangladesh; nationally, black men who are 15 to 29 die at a higher rate than any other age group except those 85 and older.
In the weeks since Mr. Malone was shot and killed, many blacks -- other mothers of black sons, N.A.A.C.P. officials and religious leaders -- have also asked how such a thing could have happened, and why this young black man became yet another digit among the statistics. Whatever the series of events that led up to the shooting, the end result is that "another young African-American has been shot down," Derickson K. Lawrence, chairman of the Westchester Coalition Against Bigotry, a community-based organization, said after the shooting.
In Mr. Malone's case, what is known is that he was shot and killed by three white police officers in the early morning hours in a section of the village where tension between the mostly white police force and young black residents has been rising in recent months.
From 911 tapes, which officials had access to after the shooting, it was learned that Mr. Malone had a gun and fired it before the fatal encounter. Several people who spoke on the condition of anonymity -- two village officials and a member of the police team investigating the case -- said the 911 caller identified Mr. Malone by name, described what he was wearing (jeans and a T-shirt) and said he tossed the gun aside when a police officer rushed by and then quickly retrieved it.
The police consider the neighborhood where Mr. Malone died an area of "street-level drug activity," Lieut. Michael McElroy of the Ossining Police said.
The office of District Attorney Jeanine Pirro said that a .40-caliber semiautomatic handgun with the serial number removed was recovered from the crime scene. Ballistics reports are being conducted.
A police statement issued after the shooting confirmed that three officers who were responding to the 911 report at 3:40 A.M. of an armed man chased Mr. Malone on foot. At one point, the police report said, Mr. Malone pointed a weapon at the three officers, and they in turn fired at him. He fell to his knees through a hedge in front of a small apartment building and died several hours later at Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla.
The three officers and two others who joined them at the scene were placed on paid administrative leave after the shooting and have not returned to work.
Court reports show that Mr. Malone's case is not atypical and that he had a record of arrests and convictions beginning in April 1994. Almost 1 in 3 (32 percent) of young black men in the 20-to-29 age group is under some type of correctional control -- like incarceration, probation or parole. That compares with 1 in 15 young white men and 1 in 8 young Hispanic men, according to United States Bureau of Justice Statistics. Figures also show that the unemployment rate for blacks is more than twice that for whites.
In 1994, Mr. Malone was charged with second-degree assault with a knife on the corner of Spring and James Streets. That is the same spot where he was killed by the police. Four years ago, he pleaded guilty to a lesser charge in that incident and was placed on probation. In September 1994, he was arrested for criminal possession of stolen property, a misdemeanor. He pleaded guilty to a lesser charge and was sent to the County Jail in Valhalla for 90 days.
A year later, he was arrested and pleaded guilty to criminal possession of a semiautomatic handgun, a felony, and was sentenced to a year in jail. Last April, Mr. Malone was again charged with criminal possession of a weapon after the police answered a call from his mother, who found a handgun and cocaine among her son's possessions, officials said. Mr. Malone was also charged with resisting arrest in that incident. Those charges were pending at the time of his death.
Ronald L. Kuby, a lawyer, and the Rev. Al Sharpton, president of the National Action Network, said they doubted accounts from the Ossining Police Department that Mr. Malone was pointing a gun at the officers when he was shot. Mr. Kuby, who is representing Ms. Malone, said that there were witnesses who said the victim never displayed a weapon.
Mr. Kuby criticized the police for failing to make further public statements about what happened and questioned the veracity of any explanations they would offer in the weeks to come. "There's no doubt that the police will concoct some kind of story," he said. His office has not filed an official complaint.
While many blacks have agreed to suspend judgment until more facts in the case surface, many still say that in general the police are quicker to target blacks than whites.
"Being African-American puts a male at risk, particularly at night or in the early morning," Winston A. Ross, regional director for the Westchester Chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said. "The odds are against you."
It is feared that young minorities who feel spurned by the mainstream of society and have little opportunities for employment are increasingly turning to a life of selling drugs and earning easy money. "An entire generation is being lost," Maria Nonni, vice chairwoman of the Westchester Coalition Against Bigotry, observed. "What options do many young blacks really have?"
In Yonkers, a program to help minority youths develop self-esteem and follow positive role models is providing new hope for some youths. Jim Bostic, who oversees the Yonkers Midnight Basketball Program, said officials in his city developed a program that "pushes kids beyond the brink." At a boot camp at two sites in Yonkers, sponsored by the Midnight Basketball Program, youths are taught to recognize their survival skills and understand that they can succeed.
"We have learned a very tragic lesson in the Chris Malone case," Mr. Bostic said. "From the initial reports, it seems that he had brushes with the law. But someone along the line did not reach this young man and help him alter the course of his life."
Others were less optimistic. In New Rochelle, Napoleon Holmes, chairman of the Labor and Industry Committee of the N.A.A.C.P. chapter there, said that despite the good efforts of some, the impediments remain. Mr. Napoleon, who tries to find construction jobs for young black workers, said his efforts have proved disheartening. "It's difficult for blacks to get jobs, much less get ahead," he said.
Mr. Kuby said within a week after the shooting death, he was optimistic that Mrs. Pirro's office would conduct a fair investigation. "She is the only D.A. in New York to put a white police officer in jail for killing a black man," he said. "The community has a degree of trust in her."
On Wednesday, David Hebert, a spokesman for Mrs. Pirro, said the District Attorney's office was continuing to interview witnesses.
Mr. Kuby was referring to the prosecution of Richard D. DiGuglielmo, a former New York City police officer, who was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison last year for murdering Charles Campbell, a black man, during a dispute in 1996 over a parking space in Dobbs Ferry.
At the Star of Bethlehem Church here, the Rev. Myrtle Smith urged parishioners to avoid stereotyping Mr. Malone's death as a racial issue. "No mother, black or white, would want this woman's pain," she said.

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
Poetry and House Calls

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
WHILE Atlantic City Medical Center celebrates its centenary this year, Dr. Joseph Linsk, its oldest practicing physician, has found this summer at the beach no different from the previous 74.
"I'm still writing poetry, I'm still reading and I still make house calls," Dr. Linsk said. "And my bookstore made it through its first year. Every time I think of retiring, this place looks better and better." 
 Before sitting down in his Old Curious Book Shop on Ventnor Avenue with a dusty copy of Dostoyevsky's "Idiot" ("my second time around for this one," he said), he had spent the morning making house calls, which he calls "the most enjoyable aspect of the practice of medicine."
"You get welcomed into a home," he said. "People show you how they live. The practitioners who complain about how unrewarding medicine has become should get out of the office and spend more time with their patients. It's so nice to be with the family. I try to tell the younger colleagues that they're missing something by chaining themselves to the office, but they're all tied up in technology."
He continues practicing "because I don't want to stop," he said. "Part of it comes from coming out of the Depression, when having a job, never mind how humble or exalted, was the most important thing and there was no excuse for not working."
Dr. Linsk poured himself a cup of coffee, which he gives away to browsers. "I can still remember my first house call," he said. "It was to the Marlborough Blenheim Hotel on the Boardwalk. I remember noticing how cold the air-conditioning was. It was a privilege to see a patient in some of those places. It was like stepping into another world.
"Most of my house calls nowadays are in nursing homes where my patients can't get to see me as easily as I can see them. I don't go into hotels anymore. I never made a house call at a casino."
The casino hotels have either house physicians or nursing stations that refer gamblers or employees to the medical center's emergency room. Dr. Linsk, who began specializing in cancer and blood diseases in the early 1960's, rarely sees emergency-room patients. "I am usually involved in diagnosis," he said. "My younger associates prescribe treatments. I try to stay in touch with as many patients as I can. No matter how much support they have from their families and friends, people who have cancer feel terribly alone."
Born in Philadelphia and reared in Atlantic City, Dr. Linsk lost his father to cancer. "I was less than a year old, so I never knew him, but I would always think about him," he said. "It was the Depression and times were very difficult, though it wasn't so bad in Atlantic City as it was in other cities. I remember the city printing scrip when it ran out of money to pay people. But there were always all kinds of odd jobs to do around the Boardwalk. I sold saltwater taffy and hot dogs, delivered newspapers -- you name it. A job and a book were enough to keep a young kid like me out of trouble. I fell in love with reading. When I was a kid, I wanted to read every book in the Atlantic City Public Library."
He married Doritt Newman, his high school sweetheart, and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a bachelor's degree in economics. After serving in the Army, he went to New York Medical College.
Atlantic City's only hospital "was pretty small back then," he said. "We only had one administrator, a nurse, who ran the place. A two-week hospital stay in the 1940's was something like $30, but there were some who didn't have that. I remember one fellow giving me a turkey in lieu of payment. A fisherman gave me a lobster."
He began specializing in cancer after his sister-in-law died of the disease in the 1960's. Later, the Linsks helped found the Ruth Newman Shapiro Cancer Foundation in her memory. Two of his four children have gone on to practice medicine.
Last year, Dr. Linsk opened the bookstore because "I wanted a place where secret poets like myself could read their work and not feel embarrassed," he said.
So far he has met few local poets. "But there have been other rewards. After that 100 Best Novels list came out, there was a run on James Joyce. A fellow asked me what kind of book 'Ulysses' was. I warned him that it wasn't your typical beach read, but he bought it anyway."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Joseph Linsk at his second workplace, the Old Curious Bookstore. At 75, he still practices at the Atlantic City Medical Center. (B. Vartan Boyajian for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
The Mayor of Fort Dix

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

DATELINE: FORT DIX

 BODY:
ONCE a day, Col. James L. Snyder does something physical. He tries to give himself an hour for exercise while most of the 96,000 people, military and civilian personnel, at Fort Dix under his "influence," as he puts it, are eating lunch.
Now in his second month as post commander of New Jersey's largest military base, Colonel Snyder avoids the word "command." 
 "The traditional authorities are still there," he said, wearing the camouflage uniform that makes him even more recognizable on the post. "But my role has changed considerably. I now serve more as a mayor or a landlord."
Where once soldiers in olive drab marched at one of the Army's busiest basic-training camps, Fort Dix has, in military slang, "gone purple"; that is, it now houses functions of various military branches as well as civilian organizations. Since 1992, 15 tenants, most of them military, have renovated existing structures and built new ones at Fort Dix. These tenants, including divisions within the Coast Guard, the Navy and the Air Force as well as Federal and state prisons, pay rent to the Army for the privilege of being there.
Fort Dix would have stayed olive drab if not for reduced national military spending and consolidation of the armed forces' facilities. New Jersey politicians who in the late 1980's relentlessly fought to keep the base open and thus maintain the $200 million that Fort Dix and its support contractors contribute to the regional economy. Fort Dix's tenants pay about $29 million of the post's $128 million yearly operating budget.
As mayor, landlord and otherwise highest authority in this 50-square-mile chunk of Federally owned pine lands in Burlington County, Colonel Snyder, 48, uses his daily five-mile afternoon run as an unofficial patrol. Few of the soldiers he passes salute the trim, sandy-haired figure in nondescript shorts and running shoes as he plies the base's boulevards and unpaved back roads.
He chooses a different path every day and so far hasn't trodden the same ground twice. "I use it as a chance to check up on how things are going on the post without intruding or appearing in an official capacity," he said. "I look to see if people are happy, contented. I also look at the grounds, to see that the post is well kept, presentable."
A native of Kansas who originally trained to be a builder, Colonel Snyder was impressed with "how peaceful and beautiful it is," he said. "You're close to nature wherever you go."
He can trot along Fort Dix's sprawling golf course, where membership is not a privilege of rank. "My golf game isn't good enough," he said sheepishly. He can glance at the Boy Scout and Girl Scout clubhouses, duck between slumbering tanks and artillery, cut through the parking lot of the post hospital, note what's playing at the movie theater, observe training exercises on any of the post's 50 rifle ranges or watch jets roar off from McGuire Air Force Base.
There is one place he visits on nearly every run, rain or shine: the parade ground at Eighth and Pennsylvania Avenues. The plot of land officially known as Infantry Park holds a collection of monuments to soldiers who have trained at Fort Dix and gone on to fight and die elsewhere. The park is dominated by a larger-than-life bronze of a charging infantryman that was created by Fort Dix personnel in 1959. In 1990, while rumors of Fort Dix's closing brought panic to the neighboring towns of Pemberton, Wrightstown and Browns Mills, the statue was recast and placed on a black granite pedestal. Carved in the base of the statue is the legend "If they are not there, you don't own it."
"I look at that," Colonel Snyder said, "and remember that that is, ultimately, what we're all about."
Daniel Zimmerman, curator of the Fort Dix Museum and historian of the post, agrees. "What's happened in the last six years is essentially that Fort Dix has come full circle," he said. "It has gone back to what it was between World Wars I and II -- that is, a staging and training facility for the Army Reserve and National Guard."
The fort's reputation as a basic-training camp developed "because of all the soldiers moving through it on the way to or from wars," Mr. Zimmerman said. "It still is a major staging area on the East Coast; troops moved through her during Desert Storm, Ethiopia and now Bosnia. But that's tended to obscure the post's long-term function, which has been to maintain the Reserve components in a state of readiness."
Colonel Snyder is the post's 66th commander since 1917, but his installation on June 30 was especially significant, Mr. Zimmerman added, because he is the first commander in the post's history to have come from the ranks of the Army Reserve, in which he has been on active duty for 15 years.
"Though the distinction might not be seem important outside the military, it's very significant in terms of the post's peacetime mission," Mr. Zimmerman said. "Having a commander at a Reserve training post who was brought up through the Reserves is sort of like electing a mayor of Newark who was actually born in the city, as opposed to someone who was born and raised in another town 15 miles away. The assumption is, the experience and familiarity are going to give you leadership more in line with the interests of the people the leader is supposed to serve. The Reservists can look at him and say, 'He's one of us.' "
Each week, Fort Dix is visited by as many as 10,000 members of the Army Reserve and the National Guard, who train in classrooms and in simulated combat situations. The complexity of military technology, as well as cultural changes within the armed forces, are changing the roles these weekend warriors play.
"The training has never been more important than it is now," Colonel Snyder said. "The old days of thinking about the Guard and the Army Reserve -- that you come back to the post two days a month and two weeks year -- are well in the past.
"In Desert Shield and Storm, the Army Reserves were among first personnel to arrive in Saudi Arabia, serving in direct support of the regular Army. I happen to know a little bit about that because as a reservist, I served with the Third Army in in both missions. I've been trained as an engineer, and I assure you that the construction, planning and logistical work that's done to keep an army at its maximum strength is extremely complex, regardless of the size of the mission. What we have to do is make sure that the reserve component from New York to northern Virginia can go and supply that support anywhere in the world, at the moment it is needed."
He also has a larger responsibility of the Fort Dix's presence in South Jersey. "The Army is not in the business of being an island unto itself, if it ever was," Colonel Snyder said. "When the national base closure proceedings were going on 10 years ago, a lot of people realized that the regional impact of a military installation was more than economic, and that a military presence in or a near a community comes with many quality-of-life issues that have to do with raising families and making intelligent decisions about the environment and recreation. That's where I see myself more as a mayor. There is a social aspect to command. Both myself and my wife, Kimberly, feel that this post should represent, as best as we're able, the most important American values."
The programs that represent those values, ranging from substance abuse counseling to Fourth of July fireworks and clean-ups of the few remaining Superfund toxic waste sites on the post have been mostly the work of Colonel Snyder's predecessor, Col. Timothy A. Peterson, now serving with the Army Congressional Liaison Office in Washington. Colonel Snyder credited Colonel Peterson with "leaving me with a pretty tight, well-functioning operation" but added: "It will be especially challenging for us to maintain his commitment because, the way defense funding is going, each year we're obligated to do more, in terms of services and quality of life provisions, with less. I can foresee some hard decisions ahead, though I'm still too new to the post to talk about what they might be."
Until then, he savors the complexities of a command that "keeps me wearing different hats for so many different people."
His favorite hat?
"One of the duties in being a staging area is providing a place for troops to enter the United States after they've served abroad, before they go back their loved ones," Colonel Snyder said. "It's a very emotional moment, for me, to be here to welcome them home."
 
Many Rms, Pine Vu: The Tenants at Fort Dix
 
GOING purple is military slang for moving numerous branches of different armed services, as well as civilian government organizations, to single installations. In the last six years, Fort Dix has changed from an Army Reserve training center to one of the deepest-purple Army posts in the country. Many of its 15 tenants are connected to neighboring McGuire Air Force Base, paying rent to the Army to use Fort Dix facilities.
Aside from the Army Reserve, these organizations now call Fort Dix home:
 * The Naval Reserve Readiness Command Region 4, which coordinates Navy Reserve units in Northeast.
* The Northeast Army Reserve Intelligence Support Center.
* The Air Mobility Warfare Center, an Air Force educational center.
*The Defense Energy Office, which oversees distribution of fuel for military installations in the Northeast.
* The Federal Bureau of Investigation's Newark and New York divisions.
* The Federal Correctional Institution, a minimum-security Federal prison with 3,800 inmates.
* The Mid-State Correctional Institution, a medium-security state prison with 500 inmates.
* The Coast Guard Strike Team, the environmental response team for the Northeast.
* Walson Air Force Medical Facility, an a clinic serving McGuire Air Force Base.
* The Veteran Affairs Medical Clinic, which treats veterans.
* First Union Bank branch.
* American Red Cross, Fort Dix Chapter.
* 514th Air Mobility Wing Medical Unit, an Air Force training unit. BILL KENT

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Judith Insell and Peter Staack

 BODY:
Judith Lynn Insell, a classical and jazz violist, and Peter Christopher Staack, a teacher, were married in Manhattan yesterday by the Rev. J. Stuart Sandberg at the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Chapel at New York University.
Ms. Insell-Staack, 29, is the head of the string department at the Bloomingdale School of Music in Manhattan, where she teaches viola and violin. She graduated and received a master's degree in music from the Manhattan School of Music. 
 She is a daughter of Jerusha H. Insell of Jacksonville, Fla., and the late William Insell, who was a certified public accountant in the Bronx. Her mother, who is retired, taught home economics at Intermediate School 151 in the Bronx.
Mr. Staack, 29, was until June an assistant teacher at the Village Community School, a private Manhattan grade school. Next month, he will become a kindergarten teacher at Public School 185 in Manhattan. He graduated from Hofstra University and received a master's degree in elementary education from Hunter College.
He is a son of Joya and Kenneth Staack of Manhattan. His mother teaches English at Clara Barton High School in Brooklyn. His father is an architect with the Postal Service in Hoboken, N.J.

HEADLINE: Nissan Gives a Glimpse Of Its Plan for Recovery

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB 

 BODY:
ITS advertising slogan notwithstanding, Nissan has not been enjoying the ride. Now, it is counting on some new models to get it down a very bumpy road.
In Japan, where the company has historically been No. 2 to Toyota, sales have fallen in a slumping economy while its debt has soared to $30 billion. Nissan posted a net loss of more than $100 million last year. 
 In the United States, sales plunged 28 percent in the first half of 1998. Sweet leasing deals of years past have produced a glut of used cars, overvalued on the books, that haunts new-car sales today. With 215,000 new vehicles unsold at midyear -- despite discounts of up to $2,500 -- Nissan cut output at its plant in Smyrna, Tenn., by 25 percent.
Once known as sort of a Japanese BMW, thanks to durable, fun-to-drive cars like the Datsun 510, Sentra SE-R and Maxima, Nissan took chances on innovative designs, like the 240Z that created a new market for moderately priced sports cars. But many recent Nissans have lacked flair, though the vehicles' quality ratings remain high and their performance is competitive.
With the axing of the 300ZX sports car two years ago, dealers were left without an image-builder to lure shoppers. And Nissan's Japan-centered decision-making showed a failure to understand changing American tastes: The company still lacks a small sport utility, and it is trying to sell a revamped Frontier pickup with four cylinders, two doors and a cramped cabin to Americans who want big engines, multiple doors and lots of space.
With dealers anxious and the financial community suggesting that Nissan might become a takeover target -- possibly for a newly merged DaimlerChrysler -- the company gathered its top executives last month for an American tour before dealers, financial analysts and automotive journalists. In an unusual move, it also offered a peak at future products and prototypes.
 On the business front, Nissan reiterated its plan to reduce its debt by 25 percent within three years and to consolidate its two North American units to streamline decisions. It plans to reduce the number of platforms -- the costly basic building blocks of cars and trucks -- from 25 currently to 10 by 2003 and to slash $1,000 a car from its production costs, which are now higher than Toyota's or Honda's.
Significantly, the company's design studio in California is getting more responsibility to develop models for North America. In the past, American designs were often pushed aside in favor of more conservative vehicles from Japan that failed to catch on.
Some analysts said that while Nissan's coming products would help, they did not go far enough. "For Nissan to really change the image of the brand, they need the coupes and convertibles and fun-centered concepts," said Susan G. Jacobs, an automotive analyst in Rutherford, N.J. "Most of its competitors will be coming out with fun cars, while Nissan will be focused on sedans, wagons and trucks. It's very hard to change a brand with sedans and wagons."
Nissan executives say they're building a base for the future. "There's nothing like a good jolt of fear to release the creative juices," Jerry Hirshberg, president of Nissan Design International, said in New York as he took the wraps off these vehicles:

2000 SENTRA -- More expensive-looking than the current model, the next Sentra has a stylish rear end evocative of the Audi A4. Mr. Hirshberg called it an entry-level car "people don't have to apologize for."
 
2000 MAXIMA -- In a bid to revive the Maxima's sporting image after the last redesign produced a more mainstream family sedan, the prototype of the next Maxima appears larger and jazzier, with styling that emphasizes the wheels. Prominent, round taillights are set into a tapered, Jaguar-like tail.
 
FRONTIER FOUR-DOOR -- Nissan's slow-selling pickup will get a V6 this fall; next fall, it will be available with four full-size doors.
 
SMALLER SPORT UTILITY -- Based on the Frontier, this yet-unnamed truck is likely to be priced around $20,000. But in contrast to the car-based Toyota RAV4 and Honda CR-V, the Nissan will be defiantly rugged, with body-on-frame construction, a two-step roof like the Land Rover Discovery's and higher "theater seating" in the rear.
Aimed at young buyers -- "people who need places for lots of stuff," Mr. Hirshberg said -- the vehicle will have many nooks, crannies and cubbyholes, including a "backpack" built into the inside of the tailgate.

SPORT UTILITY TRUCK -- Also based on the Frontier, the "S.U.T." has the look of a miniature Hummer. Mr. Hirshberg cited surveys showing that truck owners use the cargo bed less than 70 percent of the time, and even then, they use only 20 percent of the space. Nissan would substitute a small bed for a utility vehicle's usual cargo area, with a twist -- to accommodate objects too large for the truck bed, the back seats could be folded and the rear of the cabin opened.
Initially viewed as a design exercise, the utility truck now seems likely to be built, since it would cost little to produce.

LATTER-DAY 'Z' CAR -- To come up with an image-lifting car for the future, Nissan designers turned to the past, producing an updated concept version of the Datsun 240Z of 1970 that meets modern safety standards.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Inflation Intrudes on the Cocktail Hour

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE 

 BODY:
HOSSEIN AIMANI opened the vault of his Long Island City warehouse, releasing a luxurious fishy smell. Inside were two tons of caviar packed in blue four-pound tins. Total street value? One million dollars, and possibly more soon.
Many in the caviar business say there will be shortages and price inflation this fall because the populations of sturgeon that produce the eggs known as caviar are declining and because new regulations will limit how much caviar can be imported. 
 "Based on the inventory, I'm not worried," said Mr. Aimani, who founded Paramount Caviar in 1991. "We have caviar stored in Europe. They are bringing in product as we speak."
It may be no more than slimy eggs extracted from the bellies of various kinds of sturgeon, especially those in the Caspian Sea, the mammoth lake between Russian and Iran, but caviar is big business in New York City. Two thirds of the 60 tons or so of caviar legally imported each year comes through New York, according to the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service.
"The bulk of it is bought and sold by New Yorkers," said Charlie Gagliardo, a manager of Citarella, the fish store with locations on the Upper West and Upper East Sides. "Go to Ohio. They aren't going to pay for it. They don't even know what it is."
These days caviar dealers operating in New York are bracing themselves. Some 90 percent of imported caviar comes from Russia. But because of rampant overfishing since the fall of the Soviet Union, last spring the sturgeon were officially declared to be endangered. Caviar prices have already begun to inch up, and dealers expect a steeper rise in the coming weeks and perhaps an even worse one over the winter holidays, peak caviar time.
"I'm fearful of this holiday season," said Saul Zabar, whose mega-deli, Zabar's, is one of the biggest retailers of caviar. "Either we won't have product or we'll have the product but at bizarre prices."
Several companies in New York import caviar, and the five that are widely considered major forces in the business all say they get their stock directly from Russia. They all sell retail through catalogues and "800" numbers and wholesale to restaurants and hotels. Some have multiton contracts with air and cruise lines. Some, like Petrossian, Caviarteria and Caviar Russe, have their own restaurants. Others, like Paramount Caviar and Urbani Truffles and Caviar, operate out of warehouses.
Caviar dealers have a reputation for being tight-lipped. "It is a business that is so full of mystery," said Susan Friedland, author of "Caviar" (Scribner, 1986). "It is so hard to prove the provenance of a pound of caviar." Dealers agree, at least when it comes to their competitors.
"I always thought that this industry was made up of an incredible group of car salesmen," said M. David Magnotta, the managing director of Caspian Star Caviar, which owns Caviar Russe.
Caviar was not always so mysterious. Ms. Friedland said that during the 1800's American waters were so full of sturgeon that New York bartenders offered the roe free with beer. Pollution and fishing wiped out local populations around the turn of the century, and dealers began importing caviar from Russia. In the Soviet era, prices rose drastically because the Communists placed tight controls on the sturgeon catch. The caviar was of uniformly high quality then, dealers said, but the quantity was roughly half what it is today, and prices were much higher.
Then the Soviet Union fell, and the sturgeon were left unprotected. In the 90's, caviar of varying qualities and from various sources poured into the United States. Prices dropped. "Without controls it was every man for themselves," said William Donato, an agent with the Fish and Wildlife Service in New York.
But now over-fishing and pollution is threatening to wipe out Caspian sturgeon. According to the Federal Government, the number of mature Caspian sturgeon has declined 70 percent since 1978. Last year, the sturgeon were placed under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. There will now be limits on the Caspian sturgeon catch and on the amount of caviar allowed in the United States. All imported caviar will now need documentation on its origin and will be subject to random DNA testing. Caviar that doesn't match its papers will be sent back, almost insuring that it goes bad, or seized.
"I think it is going to go back to the 80's when the Russian Government controlled caviar," said Rosario Safina of Urbani. "The price is going to double or triple."
The important spring catch was tiny this year, dealers said, and prices have already gone up slightly, by up to 5 percent. But that, dealers say, is just the beginning. In addition to the new limits on the sturgeon catch, a 15 percent customs duty on all Russian imports, which went into effect June 30, will have an impact on prices.
But as one dealer put it, caviar has always been a matter of luxury, and an expensive price tag never hurt a luxury item. "There are people who will pay any price," Mr. Magnotta said. "Some people will drop out, others will pay more, and it will balance out."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At Urbani Truffles and Caviar, the proprietors foresee price rises. "I think it is going to go back to the 80's when the Russian Government controlled caviar," said Rosario Safina. (Carol Halebian for The New York Times)
 
Table: "SHOPPING LIST: The Price of Eggs"

But prices now are relatively low compared with seven years ago, dealers say. Price can also depend on the quality of the caviar, the wholesale price a store pays and its markup. HEADLINE: Two's Company, Three's a Society

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
NEW YORK often seems like individuality run amok. So in a city with a statue dedicated to liberty, why not groups devoted to a peculiar pursuit of happiness? Thumb through the Yellow Pages and the Encyclopedia of Associations or click around the Internet and you'll find eccentric New York societies, associations and clubs galore.
Out march the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, who encourage the growth of democracy in Spain, the Vlamingen in de Wereld en New York, who encourage everything Flemish, and the Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel, founded in 1953 to stop the draining of Israel's wetlands. But a phone call won't necessarily get you the Society for the Advancement of Christian Art. "Everyone is on vacation," a female voice barked last week before hanging up. 
 Then there is the Disabled Veterans Key Chain Tag and Chauffeur Badge Collectors Association. The group is pretty much Edward H. Miles and about a dozen other New Yorkers (there are about 150 members nationwide). An optometrist who grew up in Brooklyn and now lives in Gramercy Park, Mr. Miles, 62, used to collect stamps. But around 1968, he noticed chauffeurs' badges for sale in a stamp catalogue. Shiny, oval, about the size of a chocolate-chip cookie, the metal badges were required by New York State, beginning in 1904, for anyone who wanted to drive a taxi, limousine or bus.
"They were big, they were colorful, they were more fun than stamps," Mr. Miles said. He now has more than 2,000 of them, which he bought at prices ranging from 15 cents to $100 (for badges from the World War II era, when metal was rationed).
That led to collecting validation stickers for license plates (more than 1,000 from every state and American Samoa), at prices ranging from a few cents to $10. And that led to collecting key chains made by disabled veterans between 1942 and 1975 (when the practice was discontinued). Mr. Miles has more than 10,000 of those, for which he paid from 50 cents to $100. Somewhere along the line he also picked up nearly 1,000 license plates. He displays about 20 of them in the window of his optometry office on Eighth Avenue near 52d Street.
"It's like being a very thorough historian in the company of other very thorough historians," Mr. Miles said of himself and his fellow collectors.
At the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York, with headquarters on East 58th Street near Park Avenue, history is second nature. Membership is open only to those who can prove direct descent from one of the more than 100 passengers on the Mayflower, which set sail in 1620 from Plymouth, England for what was to become Plymouth, Mass.
Rowland Folsom Pease, 76, a writer who grew up in Newton, Mass., and joined the Mayflower Society in New York in the 1950's, said he was aware of criticism that such societies were elitist and racist. "Frankly, there are people who are frightful snobs, who want to elevate themselves above everyone else," Mr. Pease said, "but really I joined out of patriotism and a sense of history." He was, he said, "a lowly private during D-Day."
He delights in describing his Mayflower ancestor, on his mother's side, as "John Howland, 16 years old and an indentured servant, who fell overboard and was then fished out, to the great future relief of his descendants."
Esperanto, the artificial language created by Ludwig Zamenhof, a Polish eye doctor, in 1887, is more than a historical pastime to Jim Medrano, 38, a computer graphics specialist, and his wife, Nancee Medrano, 37, a secretary. To them, it is a growing contribution to world amity. The couple head the Esperanto Society of New York, at United Nations Plaza, and often house visiting Esperantists from around the world.
The couple first encountered Esperanto, a simplified language based mainly on European languages like French and Italian, while students at Queens College, but began studying it in earnest at Stuyvesant Adult Education Center in 1983. They try to speak it a few hours every day.
Mr. Medrano said he has read more than a dozen books in Esperanto, including a translation of Shakespeare's "Midsummer Night's Dream." At an Esperanto Society picnic in Riverside Park in June, adults and children sang the song "Guantanamera" in Esperanto.
"The beauty of Esperanto is that no one has to learn the other person's language," Mr. Medrano said. "You can meet each other halfway and that's got to help reduce world conflict." He estimates that there are more than 100 Esperantists in New York. "For us, and our little circle, Esperanto has taken off," Mr. Medrano said. "If no one else learns it, that's O.K."
But for the Young Communist League U.S.A., the branch of the Communist Party U.S.A. for Marxist-Leninists 14 to 30, expanding its circle is crucial. In the 1980's and most of the 90's, the party seemed to be headed to the ash heap of history. Then came the World Wide Web. Noel Rabinowitz, 28, the national coordinator for the league, whose headquarters are on West 23d Street, said that since the league's Web site (http:/ /www.yclusa.org/yclusa/home.html) went up in March 1997, it has signed up more than 1,600 members by E-mail. "With the Internet, it's not about us finding them, it's about them finding us," he said.
Mr. Rabinowitz, whose parents and older brother are Communists, said his non-Communist friends introduce him at parties as Noel the Commie. He said he's used to hearing people say, "I didn't know there were any of you guys left."
Like other American Communists, he is undaunted by the collapse of the Soviet Union, China's embrace of capitalism and the foundering economies of Cuba, North Korea and Vietnam. "Maybe Communism is a lost cause and I'm just not aware of it," Mr. Rabinowitz said. "But Communists are pretty optimistic people."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1999 Nissan Quest;
Growth Spurt for a Mini Mini-Van

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
FIFTEEN years ago, as millions of baby boomers were settling down to raise families, Lee A. Iacocca played midwife to the Chrysler Corporation's own promising, strapping newborn, driving the company's first boxy mini-van off the assembly line. It was the right product at the right time, and it virtually supplanted the station wagon as family transportation.
Chrysler still holds 40 percent of the 1.2 million mini-van market, even as every major manufacturer has crowded in. But the next wave of competition is sweeping in, with an all-new, bigger Honda Odyssey arriving in October and redesigned vans from Ford, Mazda, Nissan and Mercury. 
 For 1999, the Nissan Quest and Mercury Villager are getting their first substantial makeover since they were introduced as 1993 models. As before, they are nearly identical, and they are still produced through a joint venture of Nissan and Ford: the engine, transaxle and body stampings come from Nissan's nonunion operations in Smyrna, Tenn., and the vans are assembled by United Automobile Workers members at a Ford plant in Avon Lake, Ohio.
The Quest and Villager are on the small side among mini-vans, with a wheelbase 7 inches shorter than the Dodge Grand Caravan's. They are thus more nimble and carlike than most of the competition.
Since 1992, the mini-vans had received only minor tweaks and fell behind in competitive features like a fourth door. The redesigned Quest keeps its old body structure and retains its relatively agile handling, but it gains another door and adds horsepower and cargo capacity.
 For 1999, the Quest's wheelbase is unchanged at 112.2 inches, but the body has been stretched nearly 5 inches and it is about an inch wider. The interior capacity has grown by about 10 cubic feet.
Styled at Nissan's American design center in California, the Quest has a fresher appearance. Every body panel is new, but the most noticeable change is up front, where a prominent oval grille protrudes like a snout. Other than that, the appearance is mainstream, a plus with mini-van buyers who seem to like blending into the crowd.
For owners, functionality is all-important, and a second sliding door, this one on the driver's side, is now seen as essential. The extra door is standard on the Quest, and it comes in handy for unloading children away from traffic or loading shopping bags without having to walk to the passenger side.
Just as important as the extra inside space are features that allow more versatility. The second-row seats can be easily removed. The third row slides forward or back on rails. You could, for instance, remove the second-row seats and slide the third row all the way back to provide maximum room for long-legged teen-agers or to carry adults limousine-style.
Behind the third row, Nissan has added a cargo shelf that can be set at one of two levels, or removed entirely. The shelf is useful for lining up two rows of grocery bags, for instance -- one on the floor and one on the shelf above -- and nothing gets crushed. Or, you could load a stroller, golf bags or luggage underneath, and line the shelf with shopping bags.
Despite the extra space and added versatility, cargo capacity still falls far short of larger vans'. With my two children strapped in, I drove a '98 Quest to a rented cottage in northern Michigan, loaded with paraphernalia for a week's vacation. Space was tight, so I couldn't imagine how the van would accommodate a larger family on such an outing, unless they pack more economically.
On my return, I picked up the '99 model. Although it is not vastly larger inside, space is used better and storage compartments are more plentiful. Other ergonomic features have been improved. The audio controls, for instance, are now situated above the heating and air-conditioning controls that are used less often. My children most appreciated the improvements in the cup holders. In front, they pull out of the center dash and are sturdier than the wobbly gadgets that folded down from the side of the seat in the '98 model.
Options include an integrated transmitter that opens garage doors and security gates, and driver's seats that memorize preferred positions. New is a sportier SE model with 16-inch wheels and a stiffer suspension. The Quest also comes with a standard security system, less forceful dual air bags and four-wheel anti-lock brakes.
The Quest's most significant improvement is under the hood, where a 3.3-liter V6 producing 170 horsepower has replaced a 3-liter V6 with 151 horsepower. While a difference of 19 horsepower may not sound like much, back-to-back comparisons of the old and new versions showed the '99 to be much livelier. The 1998 Quest, albeit loaded with gear, had chugged up hills out of breath. Even empty, it gave me pause when passing. In contrast, the '99 stepped smartly away from traffic lights and confidently passed other vehicles on two-lane roads.
Prices have not been announced, but they are expected to remain in the range of the current model, from $23,589 to $29,087. The Villager is priced about the same, and differs mainly in its front styling, available colors and optional trim.

INSIDE TRACK: A van for families that know when to stop packing.

HEADLINE: At 38, He Runs A Hotel Giant (Jealous Yet)

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
WHEN Richard D. Nanula is not in the middle of changing jobs and moving, he likes to unwind by watching five television sets at once, using a customized touch pad to change channels quickly and adjust the sound. Oh, and he sometimes reads at the same time.
"I'm a multiprocessor," he said. 
 And listening to Mr. Nanula, 38, talk about his life is also like watching several channels at once.
There he is at the Walt Disney Company, which hired him out of Harvard Business School 12 years ago and named him chief financial officer at the age of 31. He quickly made his mark, negotiating long and hard to get the troubled Euro Disney theme park on firmer financial footing, handling more than $1 billion of financing for Disney films and issuing rare 100-year bonds.
And there he is pursuing his second career as one of the world's greatest sports fans. He once moved intensive business negotiations to the Super Bowl so he wouldn't miss the game. When he learned that Shaquille O'Neal, the Los Angeles Lakers center, had moved into his Beverly Hills neighborhood last summer, Mr. Nanula got his wish for a pick-up game with him.
And there he is again, in a T-shirt, sunglasses and a baseball cap, on the back cover of the menu at the recently opened ESPN Zone restaurant in Baltimore. The restaurant is a Disney property, and executives who knew of Mr. Nanula's passion for sports agreed that he should be the poster boy for serious fandom.
"It's one of my favorite things I've ever done," Mr. Nanula said of the menu.
Now Mr. Nanula (pronounced na-NOO-lah) faces perhaps the hardest thing he's ever done, taking over as chief executive of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, the world's largest hotel company.
Consider his challenge. By acquiring Westin Hotels and ITT, Starwood has become, in a way, a $16 billion start-up. And Mr. Nanula, who became its chief on June 1, must now assemble a team to run Starwood's many distinct parts -- including the Caesars World casinos and the company's Sheraton and luxury hotels -- and assemble three companies into one at its new headquarters in White Plains.
To cut costs, he is using the company's size to renegotiate contracts for its 650 hotels on everything from mattresses to shrimp to long-distance service. He hopes to raise revenues by, among other things, stitching together reservation systems and frequent-guest programs.
All the while, Starwood is growing, with 125,000 employees and $1 billion of projects in the pipeline, and it is starting a new brand, W Hotels, to compete in the so-called boutique hotel market.
Lest Mr. Nanula's job grow too dull, he must also develop a new corporate structure for Starwood, which recently lost a battle with Congress and the White House to extend the tax advantages of its unusual corporate structure.
The company's stock price, meanwhile, has sagged, along with others in the lodging industry; Starwood shares have fallen 5.7 percent over the last year, better than the 6.4 percent drop in the Chicago Board Options Exchange index of real estate investment trusts but well below the 16.7 percent gain in the Standard & Poor's 500.
"I'm not sure anyone has tried to pull off what we're doing here," Mr. Nanula said during three hours of interviews squeezed into his schedule. "It is a big and interesting challenge."
 ALSO at stake is the reputation of Barry S. Sternlicht, a longtime friend of Mr. Nanula. Mr. Sternlicht, who is 37, built Starwood at breakneck speed and is now its chairman, but he acknowledges that he lacks the operational skills to make it all work. Mr. Nanula's efforts will go a long way toward determining whether Mr. Sternlicht will be regarded in coming years as a savvy deal maker or as someone who paid too much to create an unwieldy corporate giant.
"What you see today is a company operating on 2 of its 12 cylinders," Mr. Sternlicht said.
Many people on Wall Street are betting that Mr. Nanula can make Starwood hum, though no one minimizes the enormity of his task.
"For Richard Nanula to have left his job at Disney says a lot about what he believes is the potential for Starwood," said Jason N. Ader, an analyst at Bear, Stearns. "But he's got to focus to manage the assimilation process."
Mr. Nanula's route to Starwood can be traced, in part, to his penchant for juggling several tasks.
On his first day at Harvard, in 1984, he took a seat in the lecture hall at the end of the last row -- or "skydeck," as the students called it -- so he could read newspapers and magazines or do course work when class discussions bogged down.
Two seats away sat Mr. Sternlicht, another multitasker. "I'm really good at doodling and listening at the same time, which drives people crazy because they don't think I'm listening," he explained recently.
The two had pursued different academic interests. Mr. Sternlicht was a liberal arts major at Brown University in a program called Law and Society (or "Lost in Society," as he called it). Mr. Nanula studied economics at the University of California at Santa Barbara and was a certified public accountant.
 BUT the men soon found common ground. They spent many Sunday afternoons watching football together. During intramural basketball games, Mr. Sternlicht played point guard, often setting up Mr. Nanula, who is said to have a pretty good outside shot.
Mr. Sternlicht also helped Mr. Nanula land his first job. In their second year, Mr. Sternlicht organized a field study project at Disney, in part because he had a good contact there, but also because Disney was far away from the chilly Northeast. He recruited four classmates, including Mr. Nanula, to study the feasibility of a new theme-park attraction of mini-factories showing how things like bread and cheese are made.
Mr. Nanula made a quick impression on Disney executives and was hired into the strategic planning department even before the students made their final presentation.
Mr. Sternlicht was not jealous, he said, because he preferred to work in a smaller company. "I didn't like hierarchy," he said. "My goal was to do deals, to learn to negotiate."
Mr. Nanula, though, was drawn to the breadth and complexity of a large corporation. He was also following in the footsteps of his father, who had run companies that made products ranging from cooling towers to automatic sprinkler systems (and, on occasion, was known to read a book in front of the TV).
Though fast friends, Mr. Nanula and Mr. Sternlicht assumed that they would never work together. But they soon found themselves sitting across from each other at a negotiating table. Mr. Sternlicht landed a job at JMB Realty in Chicago, and he and Mr. Nanula haggled over the sale to JMB of the real estate assets of Disney's Arvida subsidiary.
They stayed in touch -- Mr. Nanula sometimes called Mr. Sternlicht to needle him about the California weather -- and they often went on vacations and attended the N.C.A.A. Final Four together. But their career paths were very different.
Mr. Sternlicht's trajectory dipped sharply early on. He led a team that analyzed the finances of Randsworth Trust P.L.C., a British real estate company, before JMB and some American pension funds bought it in 1989. Randsworth collapsed two years later, for a loss of more than $425 million. Mr. Sternlicht has said he was made the scapegoat for the debacle.
But failure, he said, "teaches you intellectual discipline and humility."
In 1991, after he left JMB, Mr. Sternlicht started Starwood Capital with investments from the Ziff publishing family and others.
In 1993, Starwood, named for the community near Aspen, Colo., where it was assembled, bought its first hotels. The company took off in 1995, when it acquired Hotel Investors Trust, a real estate investment trust and standard operating company that traded as a single stock -- a so-called paired-share or stapled REIT.
Armed with its special structure, Starwood stormed the industry, acquiring properties and companies that today give it hotels or casinos in 70 countries. For most of that time, Starwood's stock has performed well, far surpassing the average for hotel companies and REIT's. It has risen 284 percent in the last three and a half years, despite its recent drop.
At Disney, meanwhile, Mr. Nanula rose quickly. As chief financial officer, he not only handled the negotiations over Euro Disney, now known as Disneyland Paris, but also revamped the way Disney financed its films, making the terms not quite so favorable to outside investors. He learned Disney's businesses, from theme parks to films to retailing.
Mr. Nanula also picked up a few things that would come in handy at Starwood. For one thing, Disney has about 25,000 hotel rooms. And Mr. Nanula has some familiarity with casinos, having made regular trips with friends to Las Vegas.
 AS chief financial officer, Mr. Nanula was known to push colleagues time and again for more analysis to back up recommendations to invest in new ventures.
"He was very good in a company where risk is part of the culture, but where you have to manage risk in a conservative fashion," Michael D. Eisner, Disney's chairman, said in a recent interview. "He has pretty good antennae for spotting problems in advance of everyone else."
Mr. Eisner made Mr. Nanula president of the company's Disney Store Worldwide unit in November 1994 to give him operating experience. Without it, Mr. Eisner said, "he wouldn't have been able to go all the way."
When Mr. Nanula's replacement as chief financial officer, Stephen P. Bollenbach, left in early 1996 to become chief executive of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, Mr. Eisner named Mr. Nanula to the job again, to help integrate Disney's $19 billion acquisition of Capital Cities/ABC.
Mr. Nanula's accounting for the purchase was questioned in a lengthy article in Barron's in March of this year; it said Disney had created an undisclosed reserve of as much as $2.5 billion to absorb expenses related to the merger without reducing its reported earnings. When asked about this, Mr. Nanula said, "Nobody who was up on accounting standards ever questioned the accounting."
For 12 years, Mr. Nanula immersed himself in the life of a Disney executive. He stared down the difficult decision of which character's costume to wear for a stroll through Disney World as part of a theme-park orientation. (He chose Tigger, Winnie-the-Pooh's sidekick). He met his future wife at Disney -- Tracey Hart, an executive assistant in strategic planning.
And his wealth rose. The 1997 Disney proxy said Mr. Nanula was paid a salary of $632,692, plus a $1.3 million bonus. His exercisable optionshad gained about $15 million in value. Options that he lost upon leaving the company were worth an additional $30 million or so.
(Starwood has not released details of Mr. Nanula's pay package, including the degree to which he was compensated for what he gave up, though he has invested about $500,000 in Starwood stock. Besides nurturing his own holdings, Mr. Nanula will now play an important role in sustaining his friend's wealth; Mr. Sternlicht owns Starwood stock worth about $400 million, plus options worth $80 million at the end of last year.)
Disney executives grew to rely on Mr. Nanula to add levity to meetings. If someone proposed an idea that no one liked, Mr. Nanula might break the silence by saying: "That's a great idea. It would put us out of business in three days. But that's a great idea."
"Being the C.F.O., or the C.E.O., you've got to say 'no' a lot without having everybody hate your guts," Mr. Nanula said. "You want them to keep coming up with good ideas."
Mr. Nanula built a collection of 50 Disney neckties and appeared to be settling in for the long haul. He was often mentioned as an eventual successor to Mr. Eisner. "I never thought a minute about leaving Disney," Mr. Nanula said.
But, ever multitasking, Mr. Nanula often offered Mr. Sternlicht advice -- on everything from takeover tactics to dismissing executives. "I'm not good at firing people," Mr. Sternlicht said. "When I had to let somebody go, Richard and I would rehearse what I was going to say."
They also helped each other through difficult personal times. Last year, Mr. Sternlicht learned that his youngest son had juvenile diabetes, and Mr. Nanula's twin daughter and son were born 15 weeks early, weighing only one and a quarter pounds each. (Mr. Nanula's children are now fine, and Mr. Sternlicht has joined the board of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.)
As Starwood grew, Mr. Sternlicht mentioned the possibility of turning his friendship with Mr. Nanula into a business partnership. But Mr. Nanula politely waved off the idea. When Mr. Sternlicht closed in on the $13.3 billion deal to acquire ITT, however, he raised the issue again. This time, Mr. Nanula had a different answer: He would consider it.
Mr. Sternlicht was certain that his friend would be the best candidate, even though working so closely together would put their friendship at risk. But the decision to hire a chief executive would have to be made by Starwood's directors.
There were other candidates. Buying some of them out of option-laden contracts, however, would have been too costly. One even demanded that he be given the chairman's title after a year. "That's a little overreaching, I'm afraid," Mr. Sternlicht told him.
The board settled on Mr. Nanula, in part because of his skills, which complemented Mr. Sternlicht's, and in part because of the chemistry between them.
Though they walk into each other's offices at least a dozen times a day to run through decisions, in the kind of shorthand that develops between friends, Mr. Nanula and Mr. Sternlicht are still adjusting. "It's just very different having him next to me," Mr. Sternlicht said.
But Mr. Nanula is often on the road, flying in a Gulfstream IV jet to visit the company's many operations, refining goals for managers and setting a tone for the company.
He likes meetings with free-wheeling discussions, like those he had at Harvard and Disney. "There's no teacher," he said, "just a bunch of us in the room figuring out what to do."
But Mr. Nanula has little patience for people who are unprepared, and he will direct a manager to do more homework before setting up another meeting or phone call with him.
"Frank Wells was that way," he said, speaking of Disney's late president. "He would simply say, 'Go get the answers, and we'll make the decision when you get them.' "
Occasionally, Mr. Nanula calls managers far down the ladder to get front-line perspective. And he often sends managers handwritten notes with a simple happy face or frowning face sketched in the corner, for a quick take on his mood.
This approach, he said, "takes the edge off a little bit" -- an edge that is likely to exist when older executives find themselves reporting to a thirtysomething boss. But former ITT executives who are the resident graybeards at Starwood say that, after the first few weeks, they like working for Mr. Nanula.
"You can tell by the way he asks questions that he wants to gather all the facts," said Daniel P. Weadock, 59, a special assistant to the chairman after working for ITT, in one stint as president of its hotels, for all but one of the years that Mr. Nanula has been alive. "They do take the input I give them."
 MR. NANULA grew up in Pasadena and Santa Rosa, Calif. He held a number of jobs as a teen-ager, waiting on tables many a summer -- "good, general people training," he said.
His parents said they were at times concerned that Richard had too many irons in the fire, his schoolwork competing with jobs, sports and dating.
But Mr. Nanula grew into a serious student at Santa Barbara. With many fellow students pursuing majors in partying, Mr. Nanula saw an opportunity. "If I was the only one studying," he said, "I could probably get A-pluses and get into any business school I wanted."
In fact, he did, though Harvard deferred his acceptance, so he went to Deloitte, Haskins & Sells in Atlanta for two years, becoming a C.P.A.
Mr. Nanula, whose father is white and mother black, said he rarely encountered racism growing up in mainly white neighborhoods, perhaps in part because his light skin color made many people think he was Hawaiian or Egyptian. "Thankfully, nobody really cared," he added.
And today, he said, he does not often think about being one of the few blacks in the highest ranks of corporate America. "I do believe in being a good role model," he said. "But I've generally just operated on doing my job, and race and age and background has never really played into it very much, so I've just not focused on it."
These days, as he waits for his new house in Greenwich, Conn., to be renovated, he is focusing on Starwood during long workdays, though he tries to be at home to help put his children to bed and spend time with his wife, as well as to see his two golden retrievers. He generally brings home a briefcase of work for the weekend. There is not much time to watch even one television set.
He and Mr. Sternlicht have talked about working out together again, playing basketball or taking a "spinning" class -- Mr. Nanula said he is a "gigantic fanatic" about riding an exercise bike to pounding music for an hour.
"We haven't found time to do either one of them yet," he said. "But we'll do that."

Chart: "The Value of A Crimson Tie"
Classmates at Harvard Business School a decade ago, Richard D. Nanula and Barry S. Sternlicht stand atop the global hotel industry as leaders of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide. Neither has turned 40.

Richard D. Nanula: MAY 1986 -- Graduates from Harvard Business School.
 
Aug. 1986 Joins Disney as senior planning analyst.
Aug. 1987 Promoted to manager of strategic planning.
Aug. 1988 Promoted to director of strategic planning.
DEC. 1989 Named vice president and treasurer.
AUG. 1991 Named chief financial officer.
JULY 1993 Disney issues 100-year bonds.
MAY 1994 Oversees financial restructuring of Euro Disney
NOV. 1994 Named President, Disney Stores Worldwide.
FEB. 1996 Again named chief financial officer, replacing Stepehen P. Bollenbach.
JULY 1996 Disney issued largest global corporate bond offering in history, rolling over $2.6 billion.
APRIL 1 1998 named chief executive of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide.
AUGUST 1998 Reunited with Mr. Sternlicht, who is Starwood Hotels' chair-man, Mr. Nanula now must bring order to the company's disparate parts.
 
BARRY S. STERNLIGHT: MAY 1986 -- Graduates from Harvard Business School.
 
SEPT. 1986 Joined JMB Realty in Chicago as an analyst.
JAN. 1987 Negotiated with Mr. Nanula over JMB's purchase of Disney's Arvida community development subsidiary for $400 million in cash and notes.
NOV. 1988 Led JMB's $920 million acquisition of Amfac, Hawaii's largest private landowner.
JULY 1989 Led JMB acquisition, in partnership with several big American pension funds, of Randsworth Trust, a London, for about $425 million. Two years later, the investing is a total loss.
APRIL 1991 Established Starwood Capital Group to invest in real estate, with initial investments from the Ziff publishing family and the Burden family of New York, descendants of Cornelius Vanderbilt.
NOV. 1994 Starwood Capital and Goldman, Sachs acquire Westin Hotels in a deal valued at $561 million. (Starwood bought out Goldman early this year.)
JAN. 1995 Buys and restructures Hotel Investors Trust,
a real estate investment trust and standard operating company that traded as one stock, and renames it Starwood Lodging.
FEB. 1998 Starwood acquires ITT for $13.3 billion.
